Volume 3 Numbers 2 & 3

about us  
We felt some explanation of why we haven't published an issue since  
August was due. One reason is childcare which was work done by mo-  
thers and a few childless women with very little help from the rest  
of us. But after the last issue some women confronted the rest of  
the women's community about not doing enough in childcare and since  
then we have been busy beginning to share that work, helping at a  
new daycare center in town, doing outside childcare, & meeting with  
the non-biological mothers groups we formed to help deal with the  
fears and inadequacies that some of us felt about childcare. We have  
also been in an upheaval within the AIAW collective. In fall we had  
decided that our collective needed to be a tight one - a primary  
collective for all of us and that that would solve the internal mis-  
trust that was coming between us. Well, the process of tightening  
up the collective (dealing with how we all felt about the group,  
how we felt about working together) caused so much trauma, that we  
were forced to reconsider whether at this period in the community  
a tight closed collective was what we needed. There are a lot of  
women in the community that we trust and feel close to politically  
and personally, & although there are times when isolating yourselves  
is advantageous, our interests currently are much more wrapped up in  
the women's community here. We share the same struggles as other  
women in town. We finally reversed directions; calling a meeting of  
women in the community we felt we could work with to talk about po-  
litical directions, about what political work we each wanted to be  
doing, to ask for suggestions about the paper & talk about the idea  
for this issue. Since the last issue & that meeting several new  
groups have formed. There are various groups now revolving around  
the daycare center, a group of women printing an anthology of the two  
women's poetry readings that were held here, & a group planning to  
start a women's press. The membership of these groups overlaps a  
lot - overcommitment is something we can't seem to solve. There  
is so much we want to do. The AIAW collective has had some changes  
in membership during this time but still remains pretty small. We  
all feel that the paper is a good thing because it's the one thing  
we do that communicates with women who we don't know or work with.  
But it is difficult to find new women who we could work with who  
want to join a collective that is 2 yrs. old. The idea of a women's  
press is new and exciting & the paper is feeling its age. But most  
of us want it to continue & to somehow serve as a chronicle of the  
struggles of our community here - to somehow have them recorded, ex-  
plained, & analyzed. That's why this issue seems important since the  
struggle over childcare has touched almost everyone in the women's  
community. —

about this issue  
All of our time seemed to be consumed with childcare - doing it,  
worrying about doing it, worrying about not doing it, fighting over  
it & the meetings to decide what to do about the paper, what to  
publish, who to work with, seemed distant. Mothers and a few non-  
mothers had been doing an astounding amount of work on daycare for  
yrs. & lots of other women in the community were finally getting in-  
volved with childcare too, hassling about it, doing it, or not do-  
ing it & feeling guilty, or always doing it & feeling angry. It  
seemed so logical that what we published should reflect what was  
going on in the women’s community in Iowa City & much of what was/  
is going on here revolves around childcare. & everyone has something  
to say. If you put up a sign at the daycare center about anything,  
several scribbled answers, a graffiti dialogue, will appear in a  
couple days' time. Those of us working on the paper couldn't possi-  
bly present the whole issue of childcare as it concerns this com-  
munity. Except for two of us, we have just recently got our shit  
together & started working at it. None of us are mothers. We hung  
up announcements of this issue asking all the women in the commun-  
ity to write something & decided anything submitted would be print-  
ed. We kept copies of all articles handed in in a notebook at the  
daycare center so everyone could read them. A lot of the copy in this  
issue is a result of women responding to articles other women wrote.  
We think all the articles together present a pretty good picture of  
the issue of childcare as struggled over in the women's community  
in Iowa City & that's what we wanted to do. Our hope is that people  
will read the entire paper in sequence because it is the entirety of  
the issue that tells the story. What is and has happened here as re-  
gards childcare we think is useful to other women in other communi-  
ties but in some ways our struggles may be different. This community  
is small and on a whole pretty privileged, which does not make the  
lives of poor or working-class women here much easier. But being in  
a privileged university community does make some things more possi-  
ble. The university (great white father/employer/landlord/& master  
of us all) rents out huge bourgeois houses for $75 a month because of  
the pressure put on them & hard work done by women over a year ago,  
women in the community contribute financially to support the center  
because so many can afford to do so, & only two weeks after it start-  
ed it was full of toys, furniture, etc. It's true that some of that  
stuff was acquired from Goodwill dumpsters but even the dumpsters  
here are surrounded by goodies to snatch that you don't see around  
the dumpsters in Chicago or Boston. It was hard work to start the  
new daycare center but it was possible here. Low-income women and/or  
women in large cities may encounter struggles we glided through or  
avoided. Most women can't get beyond fighting for the physical fa-  
cility in which to start a center. But we think our experiences could  
be helpful & perhaps because our community crosses class lines and  
involves gay & straight women, a spectrum of community thought pre-  
sents a fairly accurate analysis of an issue that is real important  
in one way or another to all of us.

mother’s  
manifesto  

Mystification of Motherhood  

Motherhood is a mystique. It fails to separate the biological  
function of delivering a child from the social function of care  
and socialization. The sexual double standard reappears in child  
care: men threatened with the responsibility simply leave the  
scene - sometimes physically, sometimes mentally. The woman is  
left with the burden. Abandonment of children by women is seen  
as an unnatural, monstrous act. Men abandon children regularly  
without comparable social disapproval. After birth a child takes  
on a life of its own. Every function necessary for its survival  
and growth can be performed by any competent adult.  

On Her Own  

Those who assume the motherhood role are systematically excluded  
from employment and participation in any organization or institu-  
tion outside the home. These organizations, precisely because  
mothers are an insignificant portion of their membership, are un-  
aware of (or can ignore) the problems of child care. Thus, the  
exclusion of mothers is self-perpetuating.  

How are women with children kept outside the mainstream of society?  
Children need constant care. When the woman wants to do something  
else, a substitute must be found. Lack of free, 24-hour child  

care centers bind women to their children. This lack of facilities  
is most serious for women who care for very young children, or  

who cannot afford a babysitter, or who live alone. Even in co-op  
day care centers, where theoretically there exists an awareness of  
the need for child care to liberate women, membership has argued  
for the exclusion of families with diaper-aged children. Take-  
home pay for most jobs open to women, already low to begin with,  

is decimated by babysitting fees. Even when other adults are in  
the household, they seldom provide reliable relief.  

Another and more subtle way women are excluded is through sched-  
uling of activities. NUC, for example, (this organization is only  
typical...most follow the same pattern) arranged as many as four  
meetings a month at 2-tavern between five and seven on Friday  
evenings. Not only was no child care provided, but the time in-  
terfered with such routine tasks as providing meals. Those who  
can afford them argue for babysitters: one day care co-op scheduled  
six parent meetings with no provision for child care. With baby-  
sitting, both parents could attend; without it, only one. Obvious-  
ly those who hired babysitters acquired more control.  

This is a common syndrome which eventually restricts membership  
and control to childless, moneyed, and male people.  

Yet even when child care is made available for meetings, this is  
only a minimal attempt to rectify the problem. What of meetings  
and events scheduled late, or which run to late hours? The child-  
less membership does not get up with the children.  

Mothers can never participate fully when commitment requires  
energy beyond meeting attendance. ALL major time commitments  
exacerbate housekeeping and mothering tasks. When the woman has  

a job outside the home (dealing with welfare is a job) the problem  
is compounded.  

Finally, guilt paralyzes most women once they take a step away  
from home. Children cry, dishes collect, and she wonders if she  
is doing the right thing. If no one is there to say yes and give  
support, she will decide No on her own.

Vol-3 No. 2 and No. 3  

Nuclear Family I  

What keeps women tied to their biological children? The nuclear  
family. As long as it is the dominant social and economic unit,  
women will remain enslaved to the motherhood role. At present  
each female is personally responsible for the consequences of her  
biology. Each must negotiate the situation of pregnancy with a  
single male (father, lover, husband,) or a male institution (adop-  
tion agencies, welfare.)  

Pregnant women, if not fired outright, are discouraged from work-  
ing. Teachers in Iowa are retired at their fifth month. Then  
they are rehired (at one-third pay) as substitute teachers until  
delivery. Welfare women must often work for unscrupulous people  
at below minimum wage. The pay loss is compensation to the em-  
ployer for the "favor" he does her of not reporting the wages to  
the welfare department. The effect of such treatment is to drive  
women to be dependent on the greater economic security of males.  
She stays home while he goes out to earn. He is rewarded for  
working with money, and gains power and prestige. She engages in  
unpaid labor - averaging 99.6 hours per week.  

This workload is more than double that of the male.  
Nuclear Family II  

The woman left in her house with her children has no power to ne-  
gotiate the terms of her 99.6 hour job with other adults. Her  
singular responsibility for children leaves her in a position  
where she can be counted on to work when others prefer not to.  

The welfare of the children urges her to participate in this ar-  
rangement, though it is physically and emotionally damaging. The  
situation is not better in most collective living arrangements,  
where supposedly the child care is shared. The attitude remains  
that the mother has ultimate "say" and responsibility, with no op-  
tion to neglect "her" duties.  

Society provides one major alternative to marriage for economic  
security: remarriage. Even following the rules of the situation,  
this is difficult. Thus, alimony and ADC, pittance that they are,  
hold the survival line for families not headed by a male. Until  
all women have employment at decent pay, the begging, pleading,  
and threatening for this survival money will remain and grow as  

an economic institution.  

Economics  

Exclusionary practices result in loss of basic learned and social  
skills - consequently women lose the ability to earn an adequate  
salary. Projecting personal rather than social responsibility  
for children maintains the oppression of ALL women. All are  
treated as potential mothers who must be supported by men. This  
circumstance is an excuse to keep women out of career-producing  
areas of education, to employ them marginally, and to pay them  
minimally. Until economic realities are dealt with, demands of  
women will be met only under conditions prone to co-optation.  
Paid maternity leaves, 24-hour child care, salary supplements  
for child care, paid time off to work in day care co-ops: these  
demands fall in this category.  

Continual dependence on others results in loss of control over  
one's own life; little opportunity for growth; and a sense of fu-  
tility and valuelessness in activities. Gay mothers cannot and  
do not rely on men but on other women for support, when possible.  
Often gay mothers are forced to rely on welfare, and must "pass”  
as straight.  

Even experience with and ability to care for children is consid-  
ered of little value. Pediatricians, specially trained teachers,  
child psychologists - all who generally have little experience  
outside a specialized area, are looked to as authorities on the  
subject.

Who Owns Children?  

The nuclear family as the basic economic unit is the precondition  
for the belief that children belong exclusively to the family,  
that is, the property of the male and the responsibility of the  
female. In divorce cases, the child becomes the property of the  
state and is given over to the custody of the mother. As male  
property, both female and child take his name.  

Women are encouraged to measure their success in life through  
their responsibility for children. It is no accident many of  

them try to live vicariously through their children (or through  
the more powerful husband.) But if mothers fail in child rearing,  
the community also fails. It is the community, not the individual  
women, who reaps the benefits of a successfully “raised" child.  
Societies need children to carry on culture and work. The male  
social order needs the fruits of, but does not want to tend, the —  
growth of children. Women are persuaded and coerced into the job.

While it is true that relating to children has its moments of  
ecstasy, it also has moments of hell. Mothers need support and  
aid from the community—especially from childless members of  
that community.  

Excuses  

Often childless adults will refuse to associate with children.  
"I just don't like being around them." "Sorry, I don't like  
children." They may as well say they don't like peaches or  
prunes. This attitude relegates children to the status of ob-  
jects that can be taken or left. By comparison, such statements  
as yet fail to evoke emotional reactions, as would "I don't like  
Blacks." Children, however, ARE people in the same sense as any  
adult category.  

Like adults, children need warming up to. When a person has been  
dependent on another for a long time, as is generally the case  
with children, they are threatened by advances from new people.  
This situation must be struggled with among child, new person,  
and whoever was the focus of the child's dependency.  

Others realize, dimly or clearly, that child care is a drag.  
They simply don't want to give.  

"I'm no good at it."  

"I'm so busy!"  

"I have more important things to do."  

"I don't want to hear about it."  

The underlying assumption here is that women choose to have child-  
ren and should want to take care of them.  

A Choice  

The "choice" attitude is based on consciousness of what child  
care involves. Many assume that because THEY at this time, know  
what child care involves, so did all the mothers, years ago, when  
they conceived. Therefore, they feel absolved from responsibility.  
Actually, it is largely a matter of chance which particular women  
conceive. Consciousness comes with changing social circumstances  
and experience. Biological ability to become pregnant usually pre-  
dates having much consciousness of any kind.  

Further, the attitude that women choose is both anti-feminist and  
class-biased. The "choice" depends on:  

- availability of general health and birth control information.  
- total effectiveness of birth control.  
- money for and access to abortions.  
- ability to project divorce, separation, and death.  
- time for and probability of contact with others conscious of  
  what child care involves.  
- support to withstand social pressure to conform to the mother-  
  hood role.  

All these factors decrease with class status.  

Problems of Daycare Co-ops  
How They Oppress Women  

Even in the most progressive of parent-controlled (none are yet con-  
trolled in any significant way by non-parents) day care co-ops,  
individual women definitely bear the consequences of their bio-  
logy. Volunteers, especially male volunteers, are hard to find  
and harder to keep. In families with two parents, women most  
often fill work requirements.  

Although child care is for women and children, decisions are not  
made by women. At general membership meetings, some women say  
nothing. At women's daycare meetings, these same women say plenty.  

Day care co-ops are white, middle-class, university affiliated.  
There are no child care centers for third-world, lower-class, or  
non-university women and children.  

Co-op membership has been reluctant to deal with issues of class-  
ism, racism, sexism, homosexism, and ageism. Consciousness  
raising, with its probing into personal values and activities,  
has been firmly resisted.  

The parent(s)-child unit remains the principal sub-unit of the  
co-ops. Childless persons are in a position of having to justify  
their actions to parents. Little is done to re-socialize child-  
ren. An illusion of dealing with sex roles is maintained by  
treating the children "equally." This means encouraging them to  
be passive. Once in school, boys will be expected to grow away  
from passivity, and girls will be reinforced in it. Re-socializa-  
tion of children cannot begin until adults deal thoroughly with  
their own socialization. This is a long way off.  

Women's Movement  

Child care is not yet considered a responsibility of the larger  
feminist community (gay and straight). Children who don't attend  
day care co-ops are left pretty much with their mothers. Day care  
was initiated as an important part of the women's movement, yet it  
is now virtually ignored by most non-mother feminists. Gay and  
straight women are both guilty. Many gay women have consciously  
made a choice not to have children as a part of their choice not  
to relate to men. This should not excuse them from child care  
responsibilities involving women. If any woman is not sharing  
child care, she contradicts herself as a feminist.  

The isolating quality of child care erodes a mother's ability to  
deal with other adults effectively. Losing self-confidence and  
speaking ability, she is easily intimidated by those with more  
practice.  

Women coming to the movement from a housewife/mother situation  
need encouragement as well as child care. Too often political  
women react with disgust at unsophisticated viewpoints. It is  
rare that any group of women considers child care for its member-  
ship an important initial concern.  

Child care problems must be dealt with by women at this point.  
This is not, however, the total solution. At such time when men  
deal with themselves and change (and as they do) child care will be  
their responsibility as well.  

Oppose Federally Sponsored Daycare  

Government sponsored and subsidized day care (as opposed to 24  
hour women and children controlled child care) maintains and in-  
creases exploitation. Females are "liberated" to work a low-  
paying job, but resume the mommy role once the job ends. The  
Family Assistance Plan (FAP) of the Nixon administration is such  
a carga work relief. Women using these centers are doubly bur-  
dened.  

Federally sponsored day care (already typified by Project Head  
Start) encourages the belief that biological mothers are respon-  
sible for biological children.  

Mandates  

A. Political priorities must include that 24 hour child care  
facilities be provided on a widespread basis, free of all cost,  
to women, particularly to women not yet served. (Non-white,  
lower/working-class, non-university.) All aspects of child care  
situations must be controlled by women and children.  

B. Collective living situations must be organized as a counter-  
institution to the nuclear family. Every adult must share equal  
responsibility for child care and housekeeping REGARDLESS OF COMMIT-  
MENT TO OTHER—INCLUDING POLITICAL AND ECONOMIC—ACTIVITIES.  

A part of every living situation should be discussion by all lead-  
ing to consensual agreement on how the children are to be socialized.  
To fight the children-as-property attitude, and encourage viewing  
children as people, collective child care should integrate physical,  
social, and political welfare.  

Toward these goals we must engage in the following:  

1. CONSCIOUSNESS is a prerequisite to taking direct action. All  
CR groups must include mothers and must provide child care. Meet-  
ings must be scheduled at times convenient for mothers. Groups  
should not be sedentary but lead to a program of action. Every  
group member must learn practical aspects of child care and find  
a situation to apply what she learns. This means taking care of  
children on a STRUCTURED, reliable basis in a communal living  
arrangement, in a child care center, or in the home of a woman  
who needs more help.  

2. CR groups must work toward community programs which transcend  
and incorporate problems of individual women.  

- 24-hour centers  
- collective living arrangements  
- paid time off for child care  
- further formulating and disseminating an analysis of the child  
  care struggle  

"Childless" persons already involved should do their own CR and  
take an aggressive role in this, especially in taking power and  
responsibility away from biological parents. Men have equal say,  
which is hardly equitable, since they have different interests from  
women and children.

what I wrote for this issue on daycare from

what I can remember about how

I saw it

In the spring of 1970, the Women's Liberation Front in Iowa City
split into small cells along interest/project lines. At that time
I saw the daycare cell as one of many projects people could choose
to do but not as something that everyone should be doing. I chose
to work in the publications collective and the publishing of Ain't
I A Woman? became my priority. I sort of understood -- but not
really -- that when we split into project groups that some of the
women who chose daycare did so out of political necessity since
they had children and needed daycare. Who knows what their choice
would have been had daycare been available to them. Had I had
children of my own I too would have been in the daycare cell --
probably never allowing myself to think about whether I wanted to
work on a paper.

I did start working one morning a week at Dum Dum, the first
daycare center that the WL daycare cell organized and opened. It
was a good experience for me learning that I did in fact like kids,
that none of the kids died while I was working, that I could learn
to change a diaper. I had never been around kids before and cer-
tainly didn't completely overcome my fears, but it was a beginning.

It was just around that time that I had broken up with my hus-
band and admitted to myself that I was gay. My hatred and resent-
ment toward men was still sizzling and I found working with men
(who were recruited to volunteer at the center) hard and often of-
fensive. I saw no reason at that time (and still don't) to struggle
with men in most instances, but I understand now how women who have
children to take care of don't see that option (to not relate or
struggle with men) as a viable one even if they'd like to. In a
sense the men seemed to have incredible power in the situation
since the women needed their help and were willing to give them
equal control and struggle with them to get it. Most of the women
involved were heterosexual and had no intention of cutting men out
of their lives, but even the few women who did have that intention
didn't think women could do it themselves -- could or would take
care of each other including each other's children. At that time
I saw that as straight male-identified thinking and lack of trust
in other women. Now I think I understand better why women with
children didn't trust those of us who had no children -- who had
other political priorities, who at the most did a half day of day-
care a week and had the option not to do any.

Still there were many disagreements I had with the women who
worked in daycare. Mostly they were over separatism and over the
fact that even the women who were separatists working in daycare
did not support me and other women who were separatist or gay, and
pandered to the men and women who used the center. They believed
in community control and it seemed like any sacrifice in politics
was acceptable to that end. I don't see any way to simply describe
what I mean by community control. In this case the center was run
by general meetings of parents and volunteers. I also can't spell
out exactly how I think it should have been run. There is no op-
posite to community control, really. My complaint about it is that
there are so many contradictions between volunteers and parents
and that the way those contradictions generally get worked out is
by majority rule rather than consensus (which I think is more
right). Also even though I think people using a service and people
working there should control it, I don't think that means they have
the right to oppress anyone. Like an all-white community doesn't
have the right to be racist under the guise of community control--
like parents don't have the right to be homosexist under the guise
of community control of a daycare center.

It was during that first summer that the center was opened that
the women in daycare and the women putting out the paper clashed.
The daycare center wanted to put out some recruiting literature
to hand out at registration here at the university. AIAW offered
to give them the centerfold of the paper which could be removed
from the paper and we offered to cover the cost. However, we wouldn't
change any of our policies -- one of which was no males writ-
ing in the paper. The daycare women wanted to include reactions
from male volunteers and thought our policy was wrong. From then
on the disagreements between the paper and daycare only got worse.

In thinking back to that time I still feel my disagreements with
the daycare cell were political and valid. At that time a feminist
community was just beginning to grow and the women building it by
attempting to live independently with other women, to not relate
to men, should have been given respect and support. There never
seemed a valid reason to reject our complaints about daycare while
making concessions to male volunteers. And the arguments from the
daycare cell about the need of the parents I could never see since
the center was pretty freaky and university oriented. It all seemed
pretty middle-class to me. Mostly the disagreements we had kept me
from ever seeing the other (perhaps real) issue of daycare which
was that those of us who did not have children of our own had a re-
sponsibility to share the work involved in taking care of children.
We talked about a feminist controlled center at that time but never
did anything about it. I stopped working at the center completely
by mid-winter and pretty much didn't relate to any women who
worked in daycare except two women who lived in my living collec-
tive. One of those women later moved in with a woman, her husband

page Vol. 3

and three kids. I never could completely understand how she could
stand living in such a heterosexual scene but I do understand now
how much help she gave in taking care of the children. I know I
could never do anything like that and though I better understand now
how much help a biological mother needs and how I have a responsi-
bility to share the work involved, I still don't feel that it is
fair to expect a gay woman to live in a heterosexual environment
to fulfill that responsibility. But then I no longer think it's
fair that any biological mother be left alone with the responsibi-
lity for her children either. At that time as I said I didn't re-
late to any biological mothers, children, or even women working in
daycare. I think there are all kinds of walls and dividers blocking
single (especially gay) women from relating to children. For a
while this didn't bother me much at all and I still didn't feel I
had a responsibility to do daycare in addition to my other politi-
cal priorities. But eventually I started feeling that I wanted to
relate to children but relating to them always seemed to mean being
with men or heterosexual couples.

Somehow this changed somewhat. Maybe it was due to more women
becoming gay and more women becoming part of or relating to the
women's community here -- some of whom had children of their own
and some of whom had been doing childcare for some time. Through
these women and through my friend who was living with three child-
ren, I started being around children more and in situations where
I felt I could be myself and be honest with them -- instead of be-
ing uptight about my politics or gayness slipping out in front of
parents or men.

Just this summer a small group of parents and volunteers (mostly
gay) split from one of the daycare centers in town over its sex-
ism and homosexism. They began planning a feminist controlled day-
care center. When I was called about it, I was surprised at how ex-
cited I was. And I must have changed some by that time in terms of
my consciousness of the daycare issue because even though I still
wanted to have a political group or project that was my priority
and I was pretty sure that I didn't want that to be daycare, I was
willing and thought it right that daycare time be demanded of me.
The center was started in temporary housing to provide daycare for
the children that had been left without it after the split and was
still very much in the planning stages when I left town for two
weeks. When I came back the concept of the center had changed. It
was now a center to serve low-income and working-class women. That
really disappointed me a lot. Why it disappointed me is a whole
other article but real simplistically: 1) being working class my-
self I felt that since most of the women involved in starting it
were middle class that it was presumptuous at best to think they
could supply a service to low-income and working-class mothers that
would not be exploitative and 2) I was afraid of the sacrifices
that would be made regarding feminism -- there was talk at that
time of gay women having to shuffle at the new center. However since
the center was still to have only women working there, I intended
to be active. I also saw the center as involving many women in the
women's community and being a good way to struggle over the issue
of daycare.

Also when I came back to town the women who had been most in-
volved with the center were angry as all hell and ready to kick ass
over the fact that many women did not do enough daycare and/or were
irresponsible about the daycare that they did do or said they'd do. The
real gut of the issue I think, where the anger came from, was the
anger of women who were responsible for children (in most cases
their own) toward those of us who had the option of doing daycare
or not -- who had not been much of any help in the past and who at
the most had a pretty superficial understanding of childcare.

The first general meeting that was called of all volunteers and
women who wanted to work in the center was almost totally consumed
with putting all of us who are not mothers and who hadn't done much
daycare up against the wall. The meeting began with two women leav-
ing to go get another woman who hadn't shown up and eventually
physically fighting with her, and from there on the meeting only
got worse with the issues of daycare, class, violence versus non-
violence, getting thrown around in confusing and sometimes really
incorrect ways.

It wasn't the first time I really disagreed with what was com-
ing down over daycare and it wasn't the first time I felt really
offended by some of what mothers were saying in regard to gayness
and class. People were so angry over other people's laxness on day-
care and so self-righteous about it that much was thrown out that
I found offensive to gay women and particularly to working class
women. It was really hard for me to listen to middle class women
(who had children) tell me (working class) about the needs of work-
ing class mothers since I felt there was a lot of classist stereo-
typing expressed in their ideas. It was also hard to listen to
middle class women talk to me about how privileged I was because
I didn't have children.

The women who were planning the center issued financial state-
ments to be filled out and used as a basis for taxing the volun-
teers and thus financially supporting the center. I found that
pretty threatening since there was an atmosphere of classifying

women without children as privileged in regard to childcare with-
out being sensitive to their class backgrounds or other oppressions
they may have suffered. In the same way, mothers were labeled op-
pressed seemingly without regard to their class positions. However
it was the first time I knew I could not correctly choose to not
deal with daycare because I disagreed with the politics of the
women involved. Despite how incorrect in some ways I think the
anger was directed and used, it was that anger and being put up
against the wall that forced me to deal with an issue I had ignored

for so long.

The daycare issue in this town has always been complex, but in
the past when contradictions developed between people, the child-
less women would split. I think our political consciousness has
grown higher now and does not allow us that option. Doing child-
care is now respected political work that is expected of women
active in the women's community. There is social pressure put on
women who refuse to do childcare and this, I think, is as it should
be. The complexities of the issue have increased by the number of
women who have to deal with it and the contradictions between gay
women and straight women, mothers and non-mothers, women of dif-
ferent classes.

I don't see any easy direction -- I know I'm not sure of what
is the absolute way of dealing with it. Right now there are hassles
between the needs of mothers and the needs of gay women who work
in the center. The only way I know to deal with that is to deal
with it -- not ignore it and for all of us to be sensitive to
everyone's needs and oppressions. As regards childcare I think
mothers must be listened to because it is they who best understand
the issue and work involved. I realize that what I say could
sound like wishy-washy liberalism -- everybody should be listened
to, etc. But I think we have long passed the stage of seeing things
in simplistic contradictions and as regards contradictions between
women (lesbian/straight, working class/middle class, etc.) I don't see
that any contradiction is primary or any oppression is primary.

I am only sure that no oppression should be ignored.

When I was eleven I started babysitting.
I enjoyed it and children liked me; often
they would come and ask me to "babysit
them" without their parents’ knowledge. I
was tall, skinny, and not very articulate
(my mother was beautiful and intelligent
and never could understand how she'd gotten
this dumb and ugly daughter) but child-
ren didn't seem to mind, and I didn't care
that they were little and not very articu-
late.

By 18 I had filled out enough to fit the
emaciated vogue and my mother, being a
realist, often told me I'd better get
married before I lost my figure and couldn't
find a husband. I was just 19 when I
followed that advice to her relief.

In the next eight years my husband some-
how taught me that my whole worth was in
my body which began to betray me with age
and pregnancies. I remember wanting my
first child, but I also remember crying
and freaking out, wanting to leave my hus-
band, wanting to stay pregnant and not
have the baby, wanting not to be pregnant,
angry screaming sessions when I would
threaten to leave knowing that I had no-
where to go, no way to get there, and no
money that was not his. Money was what
kept me with him, and guilt, and a feeling
that I was a rotten person and all these
feelings were evil, and anyway I was cer-
tainly not capable of taking care of my-
self. I used to wish he would die and
fantasize about how I should react when
they came and told me.

For years I stayed up until two and
three a.m. then crept quietly into bed
trying not to squeak the springs so he
wouldn't wake up, and when he did lying
quietly, responding as little as possible,
trying to keep my mind on other things,
feeling inadequate and not wanting him to
know. At first it did hurt to have sex; after
the children it was mostly just degrading
and a time-consuming bore which kept me
from getting enough sleep. I was always
tired.

Our second child was an unfortunate
mistake. By this time I knew enough to be
terrified of giving birth, and of having
the responsibility of children; and my
husband was in Viet Nam doing his macho
adventurer, and at that time glorified,
thing; so I was alone with this one.

Smiling male lab technicians gave me the
good news that I was indeed five months

pregnant and were shocked when I started
crying and couldn't stop (after all I was
married!). I felt like a selfish sub-hu-
man. I cried every night for months and

it was my first child who often climbed
into bed with me patting my back saying
“don't cry mommy." I felt guilty for that
too. That child was my only reason for
surviving. We, together, dealt with what
was happening without words, without ex-
planations -- with hugs and smiles and rag-
ing screaming tantrums. I began to deny the
pregnancy and in that way with the support
of a two-year-old I coped. But when the
undeniable happened and the new baby came

I didn't love her, I didn't even like her,
I didn't want her. And now a new problem
set in. You can't go anywhere with a tod-
dler, an infant, two diaper bags and a
purse. About once a week my mother babysat
(more often if I begged) and I had enough
money for a babysitter once in a while,
other than that I took out the garbage and
talked to the mailman. Three months later
my husband arrived home, in a wheelchair,
having been seriously injured in Viet Nam.
So now I had to push him around and wait
on him as well as always be cheerful so as
not to make him feel depressed. The only
thing he could do was have sex. The first month
he was out of the hospital I had to bundle
up the children and drive him to the hospi-
tal for shots every six hours.

I began to go through depressions that
lasted for months, only getting drunk
helped, which I did as often as possible. I
thought constantly of death, the look he'd
have when he found me, what others would
feel -- bad, I hoped. I began to resent,
hate the children. My daughter was into
smearing the walls of her room with shit
once or twice a day, she screamed, fussed,
cried, or was into something all the time
and was generally unpleasant to be around.
My best escape was sleep, but with the
children I couldn't sleep in the daytime,
and at night there was my husband to con-
tend with. I didn't even think about leav-
ing at first; all that talk about broken
homes and juvenile delinquents and how
could I support two children and what I
owed everybody else, especially the child-
ren and my duty and responsibility, somehow
I was stuck forever and it was their fault.
I had no friends; married women seldom do,
their husbands carefully see to that. I had
only him to talk to and over the years I

had learned that he was always right in the
end until I could barely formulate an opin-
ion much less make a decision; to say what
I thought was to have it changed into some-

(that still happens, after all those years

months to decide to leave, then it was six
more months before I left, six months of

me begging for money and him being cool and
logical and reasonable, telling me how I
couldn't manage and me explaining that it

gether, then I'd surely be back if he'd

I think, fear that I would kill myself or

The next two years were almost as bad as

I was lucky, I was only forcibly raped

It goes on and on, a million memories

But I don't like people touching me now.
And I have little patience with children.
I'm terrified of the gay women's community

what it's done to me. I don't think you
realize that you can't erase those years

a mother like every other form of oppres-

DIALOG BETWEEN OLD GAYS

I never wanted a child, or wanted anything to do with children.  
After doing babysitting in my early teens I had nothing more to do  
with children until this last year. I've gone through really rad-  
ical changes in my attitude about children: from being threatened  
about how little control I have with their candidness to being less  
authoritarian and giving them more control over activities, trying  
to be non-age chauvinistic, from feeling they are helpless, puzzl-  
ing and fragile to encouraging them to be independent, self-suffi-  
cient and tough, listening to their ideas and respecting children.

I shared the attitude held by many lesbians who have been gay  
for years--why should I do any childcare? Children come from  
heterosexual relationships that not only oppress me, but socially  
ostracize me when the opportunity comes up. Children cannot be  
entrusted to homosexuals because we are perverted, say the straight  
parents, to the point of keeping us from teaching and any occupation  
dealing with children, so why, now, should I do childcare for women  
with children, whether they are poor, don't have husbands, or even  
if they are gay? I'm gay and with that I accept not having child-  
ren, I do not want children, and I do not want to have anything to  
do with children.

Where I'm coming from about kids is liking them O.K. but just  
not having much contact with them. My only brother was one year  
younger and my only younger cousins lived in Minneapolis and came  
down once a year. I didn't like to babysit because the thought of  
the parents coming home drunk made me cringe.

When I was a teenager everyone reinforced my behavior with kids  
and told me I was good with them. But because my interactions were  
so far between, I never have had much confidence in my ability to  
come through in a pinch and calm a crying child. I'm only just  
most recently realizing that I can meet children's needs, like  
Saturday night when I did overnight care at Sparky, I got them  
all to bed without crying just by kissing them. But still I have  
real problems with getting angry when a child is crying for no rea-  
son that I can see. Sometimes I can't control it and it scares me.

I didn't like babysitting either, but I did it because I always  
needed money. And, yes, the parents were usually offensive when  
they came home drunk: Because of that I've come to realize that  

part of my not wanting to be around children has been environmental.

Straight households are oppressive to everyone including the child  
and the babysitter. Children in this situation have caused me a  
lot of grief. They have called me names in front of their parents,  
they've asked me if I am a man, and they've even told their parents  
that I had a girlfriend over. Statements like that aren't so un-  
comfortable for me in the environment I'm in now, but because of  
the children's honest and eager observations in the straight home  

I usually had to make some witty and self-put-downish comment to  
appease both child and onlooking parent. These circumstances were  
great reinforcers of the self-hatred most gay people live with in  
this stiflingly straight society. The flaw in my resentment is  
that it was directed toward the children involved rather than ag-  
ainst the oppressive straight, nuclear family.

Castigation of gayness is induced by straight society onto not  
only gay people but children who will carry on that attitude. It  
is self-contemptuous of me to promote anti-homosexuality when doing  
childcare, and I will not do it. When I babysat in the straight  
environment that is what I had to do, and that is one reason why I  
no longer wanted to do childcare in any capacity. In such an envi-  
ronment a gay person has no stake in the care and development of  
any child--not even her own--and is forced to contribute to her  
future oppression. This society brainwashes children to hate and  
adopt biases against people for no direct reason other than that's  
what the parents were taught. I refuse to promote sexist, homo-  
sexist, racist and fascist attitudes in children I do childcare  
with because it is ultimately self-destructive to me and the soci-  
ety I want to live in.

I agree with you. There are many real and material reasons why  
gay women don't seek out children to relate to. Over the years  
gay people have been burned, castrated, hung, jailed and beaten  
for even looking crossways at children. And if those consequences  
seemed far removed to me, very few times have I related to a child  
since I've been gay without looking over my shoulder to see who's  
watching and what they're thinking. Society has planted the seed  
and I carry it and torture myself.

One of society's most basic and powerful psychological weapons  
against gay women is that living with a woman means you're cutting  
yourself off from having children. Most gay women have to deal  
with that within themselves very early. If it is overcome, it's  
done in varied ways, but certainly one defense is to reject child-  
ren and motherhood as anything valuable.

I have also felt paranoid constantly with children because of  
some of the things you pointed out. But another problem for me  
has been even accepting my responsibility to children because I am  
not ultimately responsible for them and because of my painful inter-  
actions with them in the past. Also, because of my isolation in a  
rural, extended-family type community I was not early aware of the  
many women who have to raise their children alone, I was not aware  
of the difference class makes in childcare responsibility even if a  
husband is present, and I didn't take into account that all women  
are socialized to be child-bearers and that I was casting off that  
role earlier than many women would. I now accept responsibility  
for children because they are people who need to be cared for be-  
cause of their age and because in primary parent/child relation-  
ships the daily child-rearing falls on the mother's shoulders.  
Women with children need to be freed from that.

My transition to taking responsibility for other women's child-  
ren hasn't been smooth. The glaring facts remain unresolved and  
undealt with that: 1. I have qualms about doing childcare for  
women who relate to men exclusively because those relationships  
create more space for heterosexuality and do nothing to lessen my  
oppression as a gay woman. 2. I question the criticism from mid-  
dle-class gay women with children whose approach it is that I am  
privileged not to have children and responsibility for them because  
where they are coming from is a doubly privileged position from  
mine: their money could buy childcare services and their hetero-  
sexual relationship was socially sanctioned. 3. I resent being  
told by new gay women with children that my conscious decision at  
the age of 13 that now gives me more time than a woman with child-  

ren, is a privilege because the ensuing, daily oppression by  
straights from my decision was certainly a long unrewarded and  
painful struggle--while heterosexual standards rewarded marriage  
and children.

I understand the unsmoothness of the transition. I have simi-  
lar qualms, but I think the problems between gay women and mothers  
are caused by oversimplification on both sides.

Your number one in the last paragraph doesn't fall into that  
category, however. I have the same gut level feeling when I think  
about doing daycare for heterosexual women. But we are assuming  
that struggle within them isn't going on. Last night at the Sparky  
general meeting which 3 heterosexual mothers came to, I saw them  
struggling with and realizing why we as gay women did not want sin-  
gle men parents in Sparky--and how it was oppressive to us. The  
other thing I always want to be careful of is to not rule on other  
women's sexuality or make my responsibility to them contingent on  
their being gay.

I know it's hard to listen to the anger of a mother when she's  
middle class and more privileged than you in some ways. If it were  
a working-class mother you could hear the anger and oppression much  
more clearly, but it's there in a middle-class mother also. (A lot  
of times I catch myself playing "More oppressed than thou" and have  
to stop and make myself listen to what the woman is angry about.)  
The oppression of motherhood hits both classes.

Not so long ago you both as gay women were all real self-right-  
eous in putting other women up against the wall about dealing with  
our homophobia. You sometimes made mistakes and were blind to the  
other oppressions that some straight women suffered. Still in the  
long run your confronting straight women was a good thing. It help-  
ed a lot of gay women, gave them space and pride and it also developed  
the consciousness of the whole movement. Perhaps the anger of  
mothers will do the same. I just think we should give them the re-  

spect we want given to gay women.

I cringe when I am told I am privileged not to have children.  
It's not a privilege--it's the logical outcome of my way of life  
which is fought against and sneered at in this society. If mothers  
talk privilege like that to gay women I'll bet they'll get a lot of  
women who feel they have been deprived of relating to children  
against their will. And there it is, not a matter of privilege,  
but two different types of people who are oppressed in different  
ways. It's too simple to say we are privileged because in very  
basic ways we are not.  

So why does there seem to be this "more oppressed than thou"  
bargaining with oppressions? Last night at the Sparky general  
meeting a working-class gay woman got mad at a middle-class gay  
mother about class and the mother got mad at the other about child-  
care. They ended their exchange with one saying "I'm sick of hav-  
ing you not listen to me about class." To which the mother replied  
"I'm sick of having you not listen to me about the oppression of  
children and mothers." The mention of one oppression should not be  
used as a defense against having to deal with another's oppression.  

But this goes on a lot. It's because of the peculiar context in  
which oppression is seen within a community whose members all have  
been maimed by society in one way or another. In order to overcome  
the psychological effects of oppression you must become angry and  
realize that instead of there being something wrong with you, there  
is something wrong with society and those oppressing you. Once you  
do that you can respect yourself. Others also, if they are urged to  
consciousness about gayness, class, or motherhood, come to respect  
what you have done and what you say politically. And that is how  
oppression becomes a source of community respect instead of a  
scourge.  

Because this is a political community and politics has to do  
with oppression, oppression and good politics are basic sources of  
respect. They, therefore, take on additional social and emotional  
meaning and that's where things get messed up. Oppression almost  
becomes a commodity that people bargain for because their egos are  
tied up in there somewhere.  

"More oppressed than thou" is an offshoot of this. It says  
"I'm more oppressed than you are so I don't have to deal with your  
problem." We must begin examining our motives when we are defens-  
ive in such a way about someone else's oppression.

Think about what it would be like to live my life

This may take the form of an open letter to all non-biological
mothers, those of you who refer to yourselves as such and to those
of you who are not doing much childcare, for some reason or another.
I would like to start out by saying that we need help! Having a
child is a never-ending responsibility. It is too often a very fine
thing, but it is often a burden too. Mothers are accused of not
trusting you enough and of trying to exercise too much control over
our children. I want to trust you implicitly but it has been my
experience that surrogate parents will always split for one reason
or another. I can only trust you so far when I realize that your
commitment is only good as long as you are living with me or as
long as you live within geographic proximity. For this reason, I
am learning to take all the help I can while I can get it, but
taking long-term commitments lightly.

I don't want complete control of my child but I know that I
will be the only person who will be consistently responsible for
his life for the next 15 years, so I have to retain at least 30%
control. Oftentimes it is 90%. It is unfortunate that adults do
have to exercise control over children, but it is unnecessary to go
into reasons for this. Even when I've lived with two other people
who are sharing responsibility, I find that I'm the only one who
cares if he spends too much time at daycare. Children burn out on
one place and one group of people also. I'm the only one who washes
his hair or cleans up his room. As a mother I am forced into the

position of coordinator of his care. I'm the one who has to see
that some adult is with him at all times. Oftentimes my only re-
sources for childcare are other biological mothers who shouldn't
be asked to take on additional responsibility. These are the peo-
ple, however, who understand and share my problems. We are forced
to help each other for lack of non-parents taking responsibility.
Please do childcare for us and don't ask us to shuffle for it,
to always have to ask and to be sure to say please and thank you.
Call me and ask if you can take him that night or just go pick
him up from daycare and leave me a note on the blackboard. Show
me I can depend on you. I will burn out. Without your help I
will soon be looking for a divorce from my child. Also please
don't choose female children over males. We couldn't determine
the sex of our children. Mothers of male children need even more
help. It is impossible for me to reinforce non-sexist behavior
alone. This may sound very preachy and sometimes bitter. That
wasn't my intention but it might serve to demonstrate my situation,
and those of most other mothers that I have talked to. I should
add that there are a whole lot of women in this community who are
doing a fantastic job as non-biological mothers but there are too
many of you who do little childcare because you have other commit-
ments. Well I have other commitments too and there is a lot more I
want to do that I don't have the time for. Think about what it
would be like to live my life.

"Et cum spiritu tuo.

I am a gay working-class non-biological
mother. I grew up as the oldest in a
Catholic family of eleven, and have done
childcare duties at home and for other
people for eleven years as a babysitter,
substitute parent (both mine work full-
time), and daycare worker. I do regular
childcare, with the help of my living
collective, outside of daycare for four
children from the women's community, plus
irregularly for several others. I have
a commitment to three "regulars" I con-
sider to be ongoing until it's not needed
anymore, and want to maintain close rela-
tionships with them for as long as possible.
I guess that hinges on their agreement to
that when they're all old enough to make
a choice, as I have done. My involvement
with all three of them came about through
daycare, before I knew their mothers, or
had specific friendships with them. This
situation has sort of free meaning to me
that I value. I do not want my relations
with these kids to be controlled by their
parents or the people they live with.
About ten children were walked out of my
life over a political split between adults
in a center here this year, and the thought
of it happening again is frightening. I
love them a lot and have as much right
and responsibility as a parent - and I am

determined not to fuck that off. I do
think that some agreements exist
between biological/legal parents and us

others, but I think it's wrong for rela-
tionships between adults to dictate or

control relationships between adults and
kids. It's unfair and fucked-up for all.

Childcare has been a primary commitment
for me since before the beginnings of my
feminist politics and involvement in the
Iowa City women's community. I came to
this town in 1969 to go to college on the
typically inadequate crumbs that the Uni-
versity and government dole out to lower-
class kids trying to "better themselves"
and class climb. It's a burn and an in-
sult -- but that's another story, right?
Bullshit...

Anyway, after my dazzling freshman year
and another stint at home, DOING 24 HOUR
CHILDCARE FOR A WORKING CLASS WOMAN, I
moved to Iowa City permanently and delib -
erately started working in a daycare cen-
ter because I needed to find a place to
live and support myself. My growing fem-

inist consciousness, spurred by the vari-
ous males, liberals, and/or straight midd-
le-class students around me, directed me
to Women's Liberation. There were daycare
centers, a living collective, a gay cell,
music cell, and Ain't I A Woman? - all of
which interested me. I chose daycare be-

because I did think everyone should relate
to them for humanitarian reasons about
their value as the "future of the Revolu-

When I was home babysitting and working
my ass off all the time in my younger days,

den and too often an emotional one, too.

My mom cracked up and almost died twice in
19 years. I always dug the idea of schools
or communities where kids could live and
work and run their own lives. (Actually, in
those days I didn't want to go to school, and

if I'd behave and lose weight and tow the

Fuck it! I made my decision not to get

nomic privilege telling me how oppressed

The new collective finally formed above

Our collective was supposed to clean the

My commitment to the center and its mem-

Working in the cooperatives here is

There were major freak outs over teaching

Sparky was irresponsible, untrustworthy,

Ten of us are now members of a collective called "Non Biologi-
cal Mothers Group One." It is basically a support group of women
new to childcare who have come to see childcare as a political
priority. The process that brought us to the place where we knew
we needed the kind of collective we have was a long, often con-
fusing and scary one. We feel it's important to analyze the con-
ditions that brought us here, and explain the reasons our collec-
tive is necessary to us.

When the Iowa City WLF broke into cells in the spring of 1970,
one of those cells was Daycare. It was responsible for establishing
Dum-Dum Daycare Center, the first cooperative, free daycare
center in Iowa City. Since its formation about a half-dozen simil-
ar centers have formed, and many women in the Women's Movement
have volunteered at some time or other at the two centers which
were politically closest to us. For political reasons explained
elsewhere in this issue, a group of gay women split from an exist-
ing center and formed Sparky Daycare in the spring of 1972.

None of the ten of us participated centrally in any of this
history. We were all involved in political projects such as women's
medicine, providing transportation services to local poor people,
AIAW, gay consciousness raising, etc. etc. There have been over a
dozen groups in those two years, some for the whole period, most
shorter-lived. Daycare was looked upon by most non-mothers in the
Women's Movement as another group with political importance, but
no political priority.

The error in this analysis gradually became clearer to many wo-
men in the women's community. We realized that childcare counts
so much it should go without saying; that childcare is essential
to the political life of a community which is not going to exclude
biological mothers, and which envisions a society that includes
all mothers equally. We came to this analysis as a result of angry
mothers finally forcing us to recognize their oppression and act
to change it. Another factor was a growing awareness of our age
chauvinism that was brought about at the insistence of women in
the community eighteen years old and under. And finally, having a
daycare center available that was controlled by women, all of whom
were gay, gave us a forum that allowed us to see how providing
childcare was identified with meeting our own needs.

In this case a beginning analysis was far easier than handling
the uproar all of our minds were in as we saw the direction that
had to be taken. That uproar reached crisis proportions at a Sparky
General Meeting that was called by the small collective of women
who had been running and staffing the developing daycare center in
temporary facilities. Many women attended the meeting who had only
just committed themselves to the politics and action of doing
childcare. We were confused about our responsibilities, afraid of
the confrontation of mothers and full of guilt because of the va-
lidity of their anger towards us. Overall was a feeling of power-
lessness; we were at a loss for direction. The group was diverse,
unorganized except that we all wanted to relate to Sparky and
childcare.

All of these feelings had a material effect on the group. An un-
organized group has no way to deal effectively with the individual
fears and confusions among its members. Even though the general
purpose might be accomplished -- in this case, daycare staffing --
political progress by individual members is made almost impossible.
With no ways to deal with the problems of people, energies are dis-
sipated that might otherwise be channeled into growth and change.

Fortunately this kind of possible stagnation was avoided when
a woman suggested that small groups of childless women be formed
to deal with the fears and hassles many people had felt and ex-
pressed at that meeting. And we were scared! We felt awkward
around kids, and defensive when people who had a lot of experience
took over situations easily. We didn't know the "right" way to
handle things. We didn’t know how to play, how to talk to kids,
how to get them to do things. A thousand "what ifs" were in our
minds, pigshit and bullshit. And we felt powerless in the adult
group.

At the first meeting of our non-biological mothers group we dis-
cussed much of this, and drew up a statement of purpose as a first
attempt to communicate to the general membership of Sparky. This
is our statement (written mid-summer 1972):

Purposes:

1. To raise our consciousness about the oppression of biological
mothers and to struggle with one another (in this group) to change
our part in that; to not expect biological mothers to have to
raise our consciousness of how we oppress them.

2. To decide what our fears and hassles with doing childcare are,
and to work out solutions to those with other non-biological
mothers.

3. To commit each of ourselves to an established and regular amount
of time in childcare each week, that care to be divided between
work in a daycare center and in our homes. To discipline and sup-
port one another in meeting that commitment, and to increasing it
over time.

4. To interact with children, not passively as babysitters but pos-
itively as people who have responsibility to children; to break
down the socialized and pigshit things in our heads and the heads
of others that work against that.

5. To build positive relationships with children.

Methods: (Methods under #1 relate to Purpose #1, etc.)
1. Meeting regularly for discussion about childcare, consciousness-
raising on the oppression of biological mothers and children.

2. Taking children in our homes for gradually increasing periods of
time. Making our homes baby-proof, safe and enjoyable for children
to be in. (Examples: poisons locked or out of reach; treasured
breakables removed; have things to play with; have some “good foods;
sleeping places with privacy -- and safety -- for children.)

When taking children in our homes, we will try not to have to
work alone; one other of us will help out. This should prevent
freakouts (for both adults and children) and backsliding on our re-
sponsibilities. It should help us learn what to do faster and make
fewer mistakes. It will also solve some problems of one person
with more than one child having to be in two places at once.

3. A proportion of the time we commit to childcare will be time
put in at Sparky Daycare Center. As a group we will guarantee Spar-
ky 60 hours a week regularly, and members of this group commit our-
selves to covering for each other, if any of us can't make her full
daycare time commitment in a given week. There are ten of us in
the group. At present three of us work full time during the hours
that Sparky is open.

So that those of us who work during Sparky's hours do not have
to put all their childcare time into non-collective, at-home child-
care, we are considering setting up nightcare at someone's house
one or more nights a week; would announce it in advance. May also
try to see that childcare gets done during events that women in
general would like to attend (parties, actions, etc.).

4. Once we have started and established as a regular practice our
childcare time commitment (both at home and at the daycare center)
we shall struggle among ourselves, with others, and -- if necess-
ary -- with biological mothers over issues which come out in the
process of re-educating ourselves to making childcare a community
responsibility. (Example: dealing with the nuclear family social-
ization that says that biological mothers are the only and ultimate
authorities about how their biological children should be treated.)

5. Given that children are people, friendships should develop if:
we discipline ourselves to spend enough time with different child-
ren and if we overcome our own fears and uptightness, so that we
can enjoy the people we are with.

number 2

Looking back, from this point in the collective's life, we can  
see both benefits that we didn't anticipate when we formed and,  
also, some weaknesses in the ways we've been operating.  

Among the benefits, the first is that we've all found it much  
easier than we expected for us to begin making childcare a natural  
and basic part of our lives. Most of us are inviting children to  
be with us in our homes on a frequent, if irregular, basis in addi-  
tion to the scheduled institutional and non-institutional child-  
care we're doing.  

Second, we've found it to be true -- what AntiMass (see AIAW,  
Vol. 2, No. 9) writers say both about how politically critical it  
is for us to become Subjects instead of Objects (actors instead  
of those acted upon), and about the best work being that which you  
create out of your own needs. It was out of our needs that we ini-  
tiated Saturday afternoon, night and overnight care at the center.  
(The evening care provided by the group of gay and straight men,  
Monday - Friday, at our center made our plans for those of us who  
are employed 8-5 unnecessary.) The individual childcare we were do-  
ing on weekends made clear to us our own and others' needs for more  
regular care that would accommodate more children on Saturday af-  
ternoons and nights.  

Third, organizing ourselves has meant that we have a group  
voice/work in the daycare center's policymaking and operating.  
However, we would like to encourage other biologically childless  
volunteers who are not in a childcare-related collective to organ-  
ize themselves too, for their own good and the good of the daycare  
center. Our voices could easily get too loud or heavy among volun-  
teers in the daycare center if we're the only ones organized. (Bio-  
logical mothers are organized, and since this article was written  
another non-mothers group has formed.)  

Through this group also we've been collectively dealing with  
our financial responsibilities to childcare. The daycare center we  
all relate to needs money to run. When it began to get a lot of  
volunteers (about the time most of us got involved in it) the  
group organizing the center demanded pledges from all volunteers  
(not mothers) to be paid monthly on a regular basis. At first they  
were going to do it by taxing people on the basis of a voluntarily-  
prepared financial statement. People objected to what they called  
being "taxed" without having a say in how the "taxing" was done,  
so the group that was organizing/administering the daycare center  
decided to just ask people to pledge money out of their own sense  
of what they could afford. Both because accountability -- for how  
the books were being kept -- was unclear and sketchy and because  
some women in our collective were unable to contribute any money,  
we decided as a collective to contribute a set amount (from money  
we could hustle out of other people and from ourselves). It turned  
out later that we were able to get more than that amount together  
(when people weren't laid off from work) but it didn't seem nec-  
essary or desirable for us to put all of that into Sparky since,  
according to the budget set up and other incoming monies, they  
didn't need more than that on a regular basis. And, since our  
collective was organized to do childcare a lot of times and places  
besides the daycare center, we felt that money was needed for  
those other responsibilities (like getting equipment, toys, etc.).  

As with the time commitment thing, we've found that dealing  
with the money responsibility both to the daycare center and to  
each other (there are both working class and middle class women  
in our collective, women who live collectively and alone, women  
with debts and without, women employed and not) in a collective  
way has been better than leaving each woman to hassle with it in-  
dividually. It helps both in terms of confrontations (with people  
outside the group) and in terms of our helping deal with the class  
and time differentials amongst us within the collective.

February, 1973  

Another daycare need we found was pressing was transportation.  
Currently we pick up and take home three children regularly, ro-  
tating among those of us who have, or can hustle up, the time and  
a car.  

Finally, as a collective we've been doing physical maintain-  

ance -- cleaning, repair, and some of the building work -- for the  
daycare center. Childcare for us has meant not only spending time  
with the children, but also taking on other tasks -- including  

learning new skills related to their safety, health and develop-  
ment. Many of us had for some time wanted, for example, to do  
household repairs, electrical and carpentry work, but until the  
needs of the daycare center and other childcare commitments de-  
manded those skills we did not apply ourselves to them.  

There are at least two large criticisms that we have of our-  
selves and our work thus far. We have not yet (we've been a col-  
lective for four months) struggled enough with other biologically  
childless women and men to get them to begin to meet their child-  
care responsibilities. We see that everyone has childcare respon-  
sibilities and, in a society with an evolved political conscious-  
ness, childcare would be shared by everyone and so no burden for  
anyone.  

Also it has been difficult for us to make sure that the three  
women (of the ten of us) who live alone do not have to do child-  
care work alone (see #2 under Methods, above). The former are hes-  
itant to ask the women who live collectively for help out of fear  
that the latter will wind up having to do double their share. We  
need to do more to prevent this. Maybe going outside our group for  
childcare-sharing work is the answer. Clearly, being able to do  
childcare with the help of another adult is a luxury most biolo-  
gical mothers can't afford, so it may seem contradictory that we  
should try to meet that goal. But since we're trying to create a  
new way of raising/caring for children, we should try to live that  
new way as much as possible.  

X Doris and the Sparkettes is the new name for the  
collective & non-mothers dealing with childcare. We  
changed the name when we realized through criticism,  
that the name was offensive to mothers because it  
sounded like we thought of ourselves as mothers.

What's the set-up for federal and state funding of daycare centers?

The Office of Economic Opportunity and the Bureau of Health, Edu-
cation and Welfare both have funds which can be used for daycare
but there's endless amounts of requirements that have to be met for
centers to qualify. Both of these federal agencies work together
as far as daycare is concerned. They both allot so much money to
each state annually for daycare but the state can't use that money
unless it can come up with "matching funds".

What are "matching funds"?

The federal government won't directly pick up the total bill for any-
thing, so it filters its money through the state. If the state
wants to use it, it has to come up with a percentage of the cost - then the
federal money - as 3/4 of the amount can be gotten. By the end of
the fiscal year (in June) a lot of states' money isn't used up be-
cause they haven't matched it. This money is turned into the fed-
eral government and then given over to different regions around the
country. (Iowa City's region includes Iowa, Kansas, Illinois,

and other midwestern states) The money that's turned back into
the federal government can be used by a state if it can prove worthy
cause. And this money does not have to be matched.
