Lost Lesbians of Literature

Natalie Clifford Barney and Renée Vivien, French Poets.

Having spent a year at La Sorbonne, gotten my B.A. in French Literature and gone
on to one year of graduate study, I thought that I knew a good deal about French
poetry. Imagine my surprise when while doing research in an extraordinary book,

I discovered two lesbian poets whose work impressed me deeply. I had studied all
these years and had never heard of these women.

My information comes from a remarkable book: Sex Variant Women in Literature
A Historical And Quantitative Survey, by Jeannette H. Foster, PH.D. Vantage Press,
New York, 1956.* (all references except where otherwise noted will be from this book).
This volume can be consulted at the University of Denver Library. Dr. Foster
covers the entire literary field (up to 1956). Her section on German Literature is
particularly good, but as a French student I will concentrate on my two pet
discoveries.

All of the following analysis is based more or less on Dr. Foster's study, as
neither of these poets is available here in either French or English. With one
exception: Dr. Foster gives no translations, so the interlinear transliterations
are my own. For them I beg indulgence, for I'm no poet.

Strangely enough, The Songs of Bilitis, a rather anemic imitation of Ancient
Greek styles, has been and is popular among lesbians, while Natalie Barney and Renée
Vivien remain unknown and unpublished. Yet both women were contemporaries of Louys
(the man who wrote The Songs). At first they even gave him manuscripts to criticize
seeing in him ** ‘the champion of the young girls of the future'....They found him
more inclined to admire ‘jeux latins et voluptés grecques’ (Latin games and Greek
pleasures) than the ‘exagérées préoccupations’ (exaggerated preoccupations) of
lesbiennes (the common French term for lesbians). *Ibid, p.154.

‘The lesser, from a literary viewpoint, was Natalie Clifford Barney,

an American ...who was able to live independently in Paris and maintain
her own yacht...she had by the late nineties made contact with Pierre
Louys....In the garden of her luxurious Paris residence she built a
Temple of Friendship, and welcomed there many of the literary personalities
of the day".* Ibid, pp.154-155.

The only two volumes available are Aventures de L'Esprit, [adventures of the
mind] a sort of record of her relationships with the literary notables of her time,
and Actes et Entractes [acts and intermissions]: four poetic dramas and some poems.

One of these, "Couple," is a descriptive and sensuous picture of two lovers:

"Se tenant par la taille-- ainsi que deux bouleaux —
(they hold each other by the waist-- like two birch-trees)
Reliés par leurs branches--
(Joined by their branches--)
Elles vont, ondulant leurs têtes et leurs hanches...
(they pass, swaying their hips and their heads...)
Elles sont dans la nuit ainsi qu'au seuil d'un temple,
(they enter the night like the threshold of a temple)
D'un mystérieux temple...
(of a mysterious temple...)
Si quelque homme, épian ce couple insidieux,
(if some man, seeing this disturbing pair,)
De son mépris le couvre...
(covers them with his contempt...)
Qu'il sache que tout don de beauté plaît aux dieux ;
(let him see that all gifts of beauty are pleasing to the Gods;)
Que les lois ordinaires
(that such ordinary standards)
Ne peuvent s’appliquer à ces noces lunaires...
(could never apply to these lunar embraces...)

Elles ont, d'un élan plus divin qu'animal
(with a passion more divine than animal, they have)
Dans les vastes silences
(in the deep freedom of secrecy)
Joint avec des baisers leurs ressemblances,
(Joined with their kisses their similarity,)
Toutes leurs ressemblances.
(their complete similarity...)
Et par delà la terre, et le bien, et le mal,
(and beyond the world, beyond good, and beyond bad,)
Elles vont, diaphanes
(They pass, transparent)
Et troublantes, et ceux qui les jugent profanes
(and so troubling, and those who think ill of them)
Sont eux-mêmes profanes. * Ibid, [Barney, N. C., Actes et Entractes. Paris
(a themselves ill) Senset, 909] p.157. 

"Of greater literary importance is Renée Vivien [Pauline Tarn, whose poetry has
been pronounced most perfect in form of any French verse written in the first
quarter of the century, and this quality is the more remarkable in that her native
language was not French but English. As she died at thirty-two, its quantity also
deserves mention, for her collected poems run to five hundred pages; besides...
two volumes of 'prose-poems' which a decade later would have been called free verse,
a prose satire, and an autobiographical novel." Ibid., p.158.

"Vivien was more openly lesbian than any woman so far encountered in Dr.
Foster's book, but the few selections and biographical notes found in anthologies
are careful to conceal this fact,... so she will be discussed here at some
length." Ibid., p. 159.

of Vivien’s life and this relation to her work Here, I only attempt to give an impression of her poetry, hoping to stimulate those who read a little French, and perhaps to interest others in pushing for an English edition of these sisters who were saying seventy years ago what we are shouting now. And in some ways they said it better—speaking of beauty in beautiful words, they praised women without fear, without hangups, in verse of such sensual beauty as has not been equaled since Sappho laid down her pen. (I mean the French originals, of course, not my pitifully inadequate transliterations. After all, most of us know Sappho only through competent translations. Competent translations of at least Renée Vivien we must have!

Her English name was Pauline Tarn. All evidence points to an experience when Vivien was about seventeen. Her family had withdrawn her from happy school-life in Paris with her bosom-friend Violet to prepare her for the marriage market. Revolted by the prospect before her, Vivien poured out her emotions in letters to Violet. By all evidence her relationship with Violet—a very religious and mystical young girl—was completely innocent, but when Vivien's family intercepted these passionate letters they thought otherwise. A horrendous uproar of accusations, hate, and disgust seems to have followed, from which Vivien escaped only on becoming twenty-one, coming into her inheritance, and returning to Paris, free and wealthy in her own right.

Free at last, independently wealthy, Pauline Tarn returned to her beloved Paris, and soon acquired residences in Paris, Nice, and Mitylene, the first of which became legendary for its treasures of antique and oriental art, and to the end of her days she was an inveterate traveler, drunk with her new freedom...she found Violet too serious. Through her, however, she met Natalie Clifford Barney, who introduced her to Sappho. This double revelation: an intelligent woman whose talents, wealth, and sexual tastes matched her own, and a great classical poet who glorified these tastes—here was her “raison d'être,” her life purpose.

Soon after the beginning of her “new life,” perhaps as a symbol of her “pagan” (i.e. Ancient Greek) rebirth, she took the name under which she lived and wrote for the rest of her life: Renée Vivien. A common enough French name, surely, but it is interesting to note that renée means “re-born,” and that vivien has at least some etymological tie to vie (life) and vif, vive (alive, lively).

That at this time Vivien felt a sense of renewal and self-confidence in her newfound faith and pride in her socially despised experience is evident in two poems published in the same book as the one already quoted! (Poesies Completes, p. 152-55) The first, "Ainsi Je Parlerai" (what I would say), is a religious-philosophic fantasy concerning what one would say if the Last Judgment actually arrived, complete with a sympathetic and all-forgiving Jesus. What a temptation! (In that almost excessively moral era, almost everyone believed, really believed, and the worst sinners treasured the hope of a deathbed repentance and heaven's glory, for weren't they Christians, the chosen people? Hadn't Christ washed away all their sins if only they repented?)

Vivien has obviously no desire to repent. In "Ainsi Je Parlerai" she seems unaware of any sin at all. Although this complacent confidence does not survive unabated throughout her work, naturally enough, her sincerity and “liberation” at this time is conveyed in the innocent exaltation of her poems:

Ainsi Je Parlerai (what I would say)  
le Seigneur penchait son front sur mon trépas (if the Blessed Saviour came to my deathbed)  
Tui dirais: O Christ Je ne te connais pas. (I would say; Christ, I do not know you.)  
(Lord, your strict law has never been)  
Je vécus ainsi qu'un simple païen... (I lived as a simple pagan...)  
Le monde était autour de moi, tel un jardin. (the world was all around me just like a garden.)  
Je bus l'aube claire et le sol cristallin. (I drank the clear dawn and the crystalline twilight.)  
Le soleil me ceignait de ses plus vives flammes, (the sun girdled me round with his most eager fires,)  
Et l'amour m'incline vers la beauté des femmes. (and toward the beauty of women Love turned my desires.)  
Pardonne-moi, qui fus une simple païenne (so pardon me, who was a simple pagan!)  
Taisse-moi retourner vers Ta splendeur ancienne (Let me return to my ancient glory.)  
Et, puisque enfin l'instant éternel est venu, (and since at last the eternal moment has come,)  
Rejoindre celles-là qui n'ont point connu. (rejoin those who never could have known you.)

Vivien neither asks for forgiveness nor the hope of heaven; she would prefer instead to go to the pleasant, earthlike purgatory where the theology of the time placed those “good" pagans who had lived before the coming of Christ, and so had no chance to accept him. The particular pagans Vivien has in mind are clearly indicated by the use of the French pronoun celles-là in the last line. Sappho was perhaps not ‘on the list,’ so to speak, of good pagans at this particular time in history, but this specific feminine pronoun leaves no doubt as to which part of the ancient pagans she preferred—the splendor of the ancients to the joy of heaven.

Et nos maîtresses ne sauraient nous décevoir, (and our lovers could never disappoint us, really.)  
Puisque c'est l'infini que nous aimons en elles... (because we seek perfection with them, and don't demand it from them...)

Dr. Foster says about this poem:  
"Far from being the mere defiant sacrilege this seemed to some readers, it was the confession of a new faith to replace the one in whose name England had damned her.” 

In an age of Faith—hypocritical or not—this is a remarkable poem. There is no guilt, no scent of sin, and Vivien‘s witty twist of conventional theology at the end is not only clever but daring.

Vivien established a villa at Mitylene, and became for a time the dedicated priestess of the new “Golden Age.” The following lines from "Les Plaisirs" show her self-confidence and liberated spirit at this time. This was in fact the most "right-on" period of her life, before health, unwise love affairs, and false friends had time to tarnish the Golden Ideal. Commonly enough, her best poetry was yet to come. But the poetry of pain, of disillusion, in other words the work of maturity (yet she died at thirty-two!) is, while it may be better poetry than these "Youthful Pieces," beyond the scope of this article.

I do intend, however, to follow Renée Vivien on my own as far as the Denver area's limited facilities permit. Anyone who has ever heard of these women—even a name in an index or a line in a book—should write Barbara Kline, c/o The Lesbian Center, Women in Transition House, 1895 Lafayette St., Denver.

Surely the time is now for an edition of her works in English (preferably Bi-Lingual) for a poet of whom Reinach wrote the following...  
"I could quote from these volumes at least two hundred verses which rank among the finest specimens of French poetry... I am aware that there are some objectionable elements...but her genius—for genius she had—is the more extraordinary as she wrote in a language not her own. I feel sure she will be famous someday, and think it desirable that we should try to know more about her before it gets too late.” 

Dr. Foster goes on to say:  
“All the critics who grant her this superlative poetic quality agree that she has received nothing approaching her due recognition because of the lesbian element in her work. In view of the small number of persons in any generation who are tolerant of such love, it may be that she will never receive it.” 

All I can hope is that women and lesbians remain fashionable and “in” long enough to become, at least momentarily, a popular subject for scholarship, so that universities have the money and facilities to dig up the primary texts and get them into print. Once our lost literature is available in print, it's up to us. If Sappho Was a Lesbian Woman (no insult intended—it's a fine book, but strictly contemporary movement literature, not Belle Lettres) satisfies your needs, that’s fine. But this is our culture; it's been hidden from us; it's been simply neglected; it will soon be lost forever to us, our successors, our children. You don't ever have to actually read this stuff if you don’t want to. There will always be crazy women wild to study, and always, the humanity and need it to you from. Now before you get offended, remember High School Lit... Remember Dickinson and Herman Melville, remember Julius Caesar or whichever bored you most. Starlet penne? Hiss Magner? I'm not saying it would be any better, would be refreshing to hear; it's just too dull! If you can't read it, don't! Nonsense! Bullshit, that's all.

we are so consistently not included in projects we worked  
so hard to help--Lesbian mothers left so painful  
just to keep their children when  
women's concerns are not mentioned;  
just in case.  

Looking for husbands to fulfill our lives soon enough. The other levels, the emotional, personal factors are infinitely more difficult to deal with. Yet it is on these levels that the real changes must take place if people would see us as we are and accept us for what we are. The rest of it would be far less of concern. We are women who  
at some point felt uncomfortable having only options given  
to us by a world controlled by men,  
women who were strong enough to begin to build lives  
which suit us as individuals and not someone else's expectations.  
Women who find it easier to do that away from  
men who perpetuate those expectations.  
We are women whose love of other women is  
often more understanding, more complete, more genuine  
and more lasting than any heterosexual love.  
People evidently find it hard to believe me  
that anyone could really be happy as a homosexual;  
I find it hard to believe anyone could really be happy as a heterosexual.  
But if people are happy, what more is there to say...  
All I guess I'd like to see is for everyone to find  
what human qualities they would like to develop and to  
thereby be full human beings, and to let me do the same.  

May 22, 1973  
I've just been thinking that in the last  
five years or so I've gone  
it hard for people to imagine  
what we are. Not that we  
should feel compelled to explain to anyone what we are about,  
but I am tired of and angry with having people assume  
that because my lover is not a man, my love and/or commitment  
is somehow not complete.  

It seems only logical to me to share life with one who experiences it as I do--and no man knows how it feels to be a woman. To be socialized into a role so remarkably narrow that  
it is hard for people to imagine what we are.

A True Story By Linda T.  

The day began simply, but beautifully.  
I rode my bicycle to the hardware store and bought a crescent wrench,  
then I pedaled on to a bicycle store and bought a generator set.  
From that point on I was truly content.  
I was successfully mechanical, and I was using my own tool.  
Unfortunately, no one else seemed to appreciate my joy,  
but I decided that was only to be expected.  
Besides, I was too proud of myself to  
really be touched by rudeness or teasing.  

But later that evening, something different occurred.  
I was still ecstatic, although my roommates were beginning  
to get tired of me. Then my friend, Linda, stopped by.  
She: Look at my Genuine Crescent Wrench!  
Me: It's beautiful!  
She: See my new pen-knife? I just found it today!  
Me: Wow--it's really nice!  
She: Want to go to the bar tonight?  
Me: (who had recently given up on bars and resolved to be a social recluse) Okay--for a little while.  

Later that evening...  
She: Can I come home with you tonight?  
Me: Yes.

Marie's apartment had a
window which looked down onto
the quiet street in the city,
or onto the other old houses,
or showed a hint of the mount-
ains between the houses across
the street. The mountains
were the view Marie chose to
look at this evening. They
were why she had chosen to
move to Denver. But Denver
had become a cold, lonely,
city for Marie. It contained
few friends for her. She had
been in Denver for almost a
year, a year contained of few
events but many memories of
Rosemary. Rosemary was a
close friend from back East to
whom she had written for a
year at the email address
Marie had graduated from last
year, and where they both met
in a small "Social Concerns"
class the year before.

Marie was a good student in
college, majoring in Sociology.
In her senior year of studies,
she was quiet and
well liked by most of the
girls in the dorm.
She dated a
boyfriend

who didn't seem to adapt
in that atmosphere. It
seemed to bother Marie;
but it did bother the few girl
friends, and it especially
bothered her parents.

After all, her friends'
parents reminded her, college was to find the
one and only man for you to
spend your life with, and how
could she do this if
men like him were not around?

Rosemary was outgoing,
pretty and popular with the
men. She had quit her sorority
at the end of her sophomore
year feeling it was silly and
hypocritical. At the same time
she became active in the
peace movements on campus. Her

sharp skirts and pretty
sweaters changed to blue jeans

and work shirts. With all this
change, her boyfriend had be-
come critical and felt she was
becoming too radical for his
taste in women. Instead of
trying to talk through her
transition at Rosemary's pleas,
he wanted the relationship to
break up. So she gave back his
fraternity pin with feelings
of hurt and defeat but hoping
he might really want her back,

always hoping. But now her time
was spent with Marie, and
she enjoyed her moments totally
alone with her.

When Marie was approaching
her graduation, she wondered
what was going to happen in
the future. Her life philo-
sophy was centered around the
now time. Nothing was impor-
tant in the past, nor should
one worry about the future.
All energy and emotion should
be put into the present, the
now. But the paradox appeared
when she panicked at the
thought of graduating and not
coming back next fall to
school. She had to make some
plans for the future, something
to look forward to. She de-
cided it was a decision that
Rosemary should have a part in
also. They had talked about it
off and on, but one day de-
cided, since it was such a
beautiful day, to go into the
park and talk about both their
futures.

They both loved to explore
the park and thought they had
explored all of it when they
came upon a quiet, secluded
part far from the road, the
college, and any other person.
That was where they both de-
cided Marie should go on to
Denver, to explore a new city
and wait for Rosemary to grad-
uate. Then Rosemary would
join her in Denver, and they
both would stay there or go on
to San Francisco or Europe.
That was also where Marie

really saw the beauty in
Rosemary's eyes and her
emotions moved her enough to
venture a touch on Rosemary's

cheek with her finger. 

Rosemary was not startled by
the touch, she accepted it

fully. Marie took her finger
lightly down Rosemary's face
to the side of her mouth.
There she moved her finger
over Rosemary's lips lightly,
gently. Rosemary bent over
Marie and kissed her on the
lips, softly, delicately. Then
again they kissed and again
and their fingers ran through
each other's long, brown hair
that flowed on their bodies.

That was what Marie re-
membered now of Rosemary, her
softness, her beauty. Marie
would get letters weekly and
an occasional phone call to
keep her memories of Rosemary
flowing. Rosemary would soon
join her, and they would be
happily together again. Marie
was certainly unhappy now, but
in the future with Rosemary
she would be happy, they would
be happy.

The next few days in Denver
passed slowly in Marie's life.
Her horrible job in the office
added to her misery with the
people who mocked her for not
being a part of their ugly
world. But one day contained
a letter from Rosemary which
was greatly needed by Marie.
She ripped it open reading
rapidly. It read of trivial
matters in Rosemary's last
days at college, the papers
due, the tests coming up, and
more about some silly man
Rosemary had met. This upset
Marie, he was more a part of
Rosemary's life with each
letter. Marie became more
frustrated while reading
further about him. Then she
came upon the passage in the
letter that talked about
Rosemary moving into an apart-
ment with him after graduation.
Nothing was mentioned about
coming to Denver or being with
Marie. All was about him and
living with him.

Marie started pacing
around the apartment furiously.
She had no sense of things
around her, nor could she see
anything outside herself.
Miraculously, she did not bump
into anything but internally
she bumped into every memory
of Rosemary she possessed.
Marie had something in her
hand, heavy, hard, cold. She
then saw it flying through the
room crashing against the wall.
She then heard a scream that
started deep inside her and
found its way out through her
mouth.

Tears ran down her cheeks
as she went to the phone. She
became irritated when she
couldn't readily find Rosemary's
number. But why would she
need it when she knew it by
heart? She tried to steady
her hand and read the numbers
through the tears in her eyes.
The numbers clicked away, the
line connected, the ring,
Rosemary's voice. Marie
thought she would choke, no
words would come out at first,
but she was surprised at the

ease with which she spoke after.

Feminist Literature — in review

LESBIAN NATION  
Written by Jill Johnston  

Lesbian Nation is the product of  
an authoress whose unique writing  
style is probably one of the most  
revolutionary cultural tools given to  
the Lesbian Feminist Movement,  
the Women's Movement, and possibly  
the world.  

The book is peppered with brilliant  
insight into the phenomena of Lesbian  
Feminism, and into herself, and the  
changes she has undergone in both  
her creative and political life.  

It took this writer about two hours  
in the back of a car traveling through  
the Salt Flats of Utah, to appreciate  
Ms. Johnston's writing ability, reading  
excerpts of past Village Voice columns  
kindly provided me by one Lake Circumspect. When I finally finished reading  
them I felt as if I had met a very inter-  
esting, though obscure person. I wanted  
to know more about her.  

Lesbian Nation offered me the oppor-  

tunity to see more of Ms. Johnston's  
writing and to see much of the obscurity  
thrown off to reveal a very honest account  
of herself. Many of her theories on  
Feminism, I believe to be the logical  
evolvement the Lesbian Feminist Move-  

ment will be making.  

If you want a little stimulus  
and some new ideas, this is definitely  
a book you should read.  

The First Sex by  
Elizabeth Gould Davis  

"Barbara Kline"  

In this book Ms. Davis  
presents a variety of arguments for the superiority  
of woman never yet assembled together in a single  
volume. Pre-historical conjecture and hypotheses  
(i.e. Atlantis, etc.), biology, history, anthropol-  
ogy and above all archaeology are woven together to  
present a very convincing thesis.  

However, it discloses many pos-  

sible holes in this tapestry. This is not to say  
that Ms. Davis gets her facts wrong. Indeed, the author  
is very scrupulous to point out where she departs from  
facts into conjecture.  

Her conjecture doesn't always hold up; sometimes  
she goes a bit too far, in my opinion. Male reviewers  
and male readers will undoubtedly use this against  
the basic thesis of the book. However, in the opinion of  
this reviewer, The First Sex could be shorn of all  
Ms. Davis' fascinating though "un scholarly" hy-  
potheses and the facts would be much duller, but the ar-  
gument presented would be valid.  

And so regardless of  
some lack of university-  
oriented standards of "scholarship", I strongly urge every  
woman to read this book. Every woman, because, though  
written from a strictly heterosexual point of view, it  
presents many interesting and useful archaeological facts  
and discoveries previously unknown to this reviewer and  
undoubtedly to most women,  

which may be very helpful to parents  
and other heterosexual loved ones. Most of all, however, Sappho Was A  
Right On Woman presents Lesbianism  
as a valid and often preferable alter-  
native lifestyle in the context of our  
patriarchal world today.  

SAPPHO WAS A RIGHT ON  
WOMAN  
Written by Sidney Abbot  
and Barbara Love  
(Stein and Day, 1972)  

"In America They Call Us Dykes"  
from Our Bodies, Our Selves  
a Simon and Schuster publication.  
By Kate S.  

When the first edition of  
Our Bodies, Our Selves was  
published the only mention of  
lesbianism in the book was  
found in a few paragraphs in  
the chapter on sexuality;  
squeezed between the topics  
of fantasies and masturba-  
tion.  

Now that the second edition has hit the shelves we  
find an entire chapter devoted  
to lesbianism with the title,  

"In America They Call Us Dykes". Throughout the chap-  

ter we find that a much needed  
and long awaited pride and be-  
lief in lesbianism is portrayed.  

Like Sappho Was A Right On Woman  
then, I might have gotten a much  
truer and prouder view of myself as  
both a Lesbian and a woman.  
"In America They Call Us Dykes", continues in this vein  
of strength and pride by giving  
the stories of the lives  
of four lesbians. These stories  
are told honestly and candidly and cover every emo-  
tional gamut of Lesbianism  
from jealousy toward the boy-  
friends of close female friends,  
to pressures felt to conform  
to heterosexuality, to lesbian "  
phobia".  

The chapter deals again  
candidly with the advantages  
and pitfalls to "telling"  
friends and family. We also  
read of job discrimination  
directed toward Lesbians and  
also of problems caused by  
the law and by the medical  

professions.  

Drawing on the personal experiences  
of both the authors and other Lesbians,  
the book is a proud and clear-cut expli-  
cation of both Lesbianism and Feminism.  
Usually linking one with the other, it  
goes on to affirm and explain why  
Lesbians are probably some of the strong-  
est and healthiest individuals in our  
society today. The authors pull no  
punches about being gay and proud and  
often throw in a few of their own.  

The book in its entirety offers  
meaning for the younger Lesbian who  
may be unsure of what it really means  
for a woman to be gay; it gives hope  
to the older Lesbian who may have  
always had to live with the lies of  
a double existence and it puts forth a  

prideful and forward explanation.

are recorded that we are all too familiar with but which nonetheless need to be recounted.

A full two pages are given to a discussion of the psychology professions. Several appalling case histories are given and the truth revealed about the psychology professions' seemingly total ineptitude in dealing with homosexuality.

The bar scene is examined honestly for what it is and what it provides women. In the bars, the book says, "booze flows, alcoholism is encouraged and sometimes fights break out." But while lamenting that there are few places that aren't out to make money off of us, we are reminded that "there is no other place to be with lots of other gay women, open and unashamed, to dance, hold each other close..."

The single longest topic division is the topic entitled “Loving.” Again, we find extremely moving stories from the lives of women dealing with such things as coming out, daring to fall in love with a woman, dealing with jealousy, and the dynamics of a loving lesbian relationship.

Also, in "In America They Call Us Dykes," a working-class woman describes her life and writes a poem criticizing middle-class women for their "liberalism" and ignorance of their own class privilege. Lesbian motherhood is the topic dealt with and here we find discussions of informing one's children of one's lesbianism, raising children without a man, and lesbians' fight for the custody of their children.

At full value, Our Bodies, Our Selves is extremely honest and informative and breaks through the many previous taboos and unspokens of female sexuality, physiology, and health care. Some of the rest of the book may not be of TREMENDOUS interest to lesbians (chapters on birth control, childbearing, heterosexual sexuality) but certainly the chapters on nutrition, exercise, self-defense, menopause, the health care system, etc. pertain to lesbians as well as to heterosexual women. I only regret the first edition's liberal attitude toward and almost total dismissal of lesbianism.

Black Feminists Organize in NY

Carol Lease

Last August I saw New York City. The Palisades looked like a fortress against the city across the river. Manhattan crowded with dominoes end on end ready to fall. I paid my dues at the Museum of Modern Art and watched a ragged man beat his skinny dog for refusing to drink gutter water. A family of old men set up house with a sofa and an old stove and table under a viaduct to the Brooklyn Bridge. The Staten Island Ferry transported hoppy school children and seagulls watched to know exactly when to fly out of the ferry’s path. And in New York City in August of 1973 there was a press conference announcing the existence of a Black Feminist organization.

Late last November the National Black Feminist Organization held its first conference in New York. About 400 women from widely diverse backgrounds attended plenary sessions, participated in informal discussions and workshops covering issues that included welfare, child care, addiction, employment, Lesbianism and “the relation of Black women to one another and to the Women’s Rights Movement.”

White women’s liberation groups, according to NBFO founders, didn’t respond to the specific needs of Black feminist women. “There was no real communication, no cultural communication,” explains Doris Wright a member of NOW. “I can’t be concerned with making it on Wall Street - not that NOW doesn’t try to do something about child care and welfare, but it’s only attracted white middle-class women.”

Black men see the Women’s Movement as a “takeover plot,” according to Reverend Magora Kennedy of the Boston Women’s Movement, “and say that if a Black woman isn’t having a baby and standing behind her man, then she’s not a woman.” She also cited Stokely Carmichael’s statement on the position of women and the Black Panther emphasis on “having male children for the revolution” as ways in which Black men had kept Black women “subservient.”

According to the report on the NBFO conference in the December-January issue of Off Our Backs, not all the women who attended the conference were in basic agreement with the women who had formed the organization, namely, that the NBFO is a part of the Women’s Movement addressing itself to the specific concerns of Black women.

These issues were not resolved in the plenary sessions and were probably discussed in workshops but since the white female press wasn’t allowed into the workshops and the Black female press was told not to report on them, whether or not any resolutions were reached on these issues is unknown. Press releases and workshop transcripts have yet to be released. Membership to NBFO is restricted to Black women only.

However, Jane Galvin Lewis, one of the co-founders, said that the direction of the NBFO will not be changed because of objections raised by some conference participants. “This organization was formed for certain reasons, and those reasons still exist. There are plenty of other organizations that Black women who don’t agree with our basic tenets can join. We see ourselves as part of the Women’s Movement, a part with a special interest. We're not separatist.”

Angela Wilson, a member of NBFO, was the sole Coloradan at the conference. She saw “feminism in action” by the fact that so many women of such different ages and experiences were present. She was impressed by the organization that went into the conference that was tight and got things done, but was “loose enough to let changes occur” and left plenty of room for the individual. There isn’t any leadership ego-tripping apparent yet in NBFO, a lethal aspect that “tends to break any movement because leadership then doesn’t listen to the people.” Workshops were closed to the white female press because it was felt that some women “wouldn’t be as open” if white women were present.

Busy Getting Established

As far as Denver is concerned, Ms. Wilson believes that no chapter of the NBFO has been established because “Black middle-class women in Park Hill and in other parts of Denver are too busy establishing themselves in professions and poor Black women are too busy surviving day to day.”

Also—the impressions that Black women receive about Women's liberation and Feminism come from the media which can often distort women’s issues, focus on outlandish, unrepresentative aspects of feminism, or actually report what is happening in established women’s liberation groups which is often irrelevant to their lives.

Don’t Black women and white women have some of the same political, social, economic problems and priorities? It seems that the dichotomy of this segregated society has prevented Black women and white women from forming an alliance. In Wilson's opinion it’s a question of how you want to die: “slowly by marrying and moving to Englewood or quickly by living in a Black neighborhood and having your brain and body deteriorate.”

“A lot of Black men are very oppressive. They are oppressed by white society and in turn oppress the Black woman. When they move up through education they leave the Black community behind and criticize the Black women for the ‘matriarchal’ Black family,” Ms. Wilson insists. The oppressed accept and imitate the oppressor. So white patriarchal society means a Black patriarchal society. The strength and resourcefulness that the Black woman has had to develop is critical not only to her immediate survival but to her discovery of her own Feminism.

Recognizing Sexism

Organizations that are community-based and have grassroots support are “those that survive.” The National Black Feminist Organization is no exception. Black women in their own communities will have to recognize sexism and oppression and organize around their individual Feminist needs and priorities. Ms. Wilson thinks that “maybe a way to organize a Black Feminist action group would be for those Black women who are in Women’s Liberation groups to recognize specific needs for themselves and then establish a chapter.

Or maybe a group of Black women who, say, work in a hospital, could organize better because in their everyday lives they confront sexist oppression and are forced to live with it. They have no choice.

Or maybe we could just get an office going... the fact that it was existing might help Black women realize their power. But Denver is a complacent city. I don’t think there are 10 or 15 Black Feminists in this city.”

In the Black civil rights groups and in white leftist politics the personal life of the militant was unaffected by her political beliefs. Here lies the difference in Feminist orientation. No separation exists between the political and personal life of the Feminist. She lives her politics.

Not the Women’s Fault

“It isn’t the fault of Black women in Denver that nothing is being organized considering the struggle Black women have to go through,” according to Ms. Wilson. “It is a positive step for a Black woman when she sees sexism and oppression and realizes that her struggle isn’t for tomorrow but today." To realize the strength that organizing gives and the potential that a nationally organized group can give seems to be the next step for the Black woman in Denver.

The National Black Feminist Organization will have its first convention this summer to draw up a constitution and set policies. Whether or not Denver is represented will depend on Black Feminist consciousness in the Rocky Mountain Region.

Some arguments against Black feminism are that Black women can't afford to be competitive with Black men, that Black women have no time for Feminism because of their struggle to stabilize their families, that Black women tend to see all discrimination against them as being racist in origin, that Black women don’t have time to take up a white middle-class cause like Women’s Liberation unless they're trying to hide from the realities of the struggle for Black liberation. Impressions of ceaseless distortive rhetoric that tend to perpetuate the power of those that mouth it—not the powerless!

The rhetoric ends when the facts emerge. It is a fact that many Black women identify themselves as Feminists, that a national organization has been formed around that realization, and that once again national census figures reveal an increasing numerical discrepancy between females and males in the Black population of this country.

More Females than Males

The 1970 census shows that there are 1,096,000 more Black females than there are Black males. The 1960 census recorded the difference in the female-male ratio to be 648,000. Up to the age of 14 the Black male population slightly exceeds the female population. Then the decline begins.

In “Jim Crow and Jane Crow” from “Black Women in White America,” Pauli Murray says that “... while it is now generally known that women are constitutionally stronger than men, that male babies are more fragile than female babies... that the male death rate is slightly higher and life expectancy for males is shorter than that of females, the numerical imbalance between the sexes (of Blacks) is more dramatic than in any group in the United States.”

Between the ages of 15 and 24 there are 92 Black men for every 100 Black women. In the 25-49 age group the ratio is 84 to 100. There are about one and a half million more Black women over 14 years of age than there are Black men. The social implications of these statistics place the Black woman in a position where her life transcends the issue of civil rights. Again Ms. Murray states: “Equality for the Black woman must mean equal opportunity to compete for jobs and to find a mate in the total society. For as long as she is confined to an area in which she must compete fiercely for a mate, she will remain the object of sexual exploitation and the victim of all the social evils which such exploitation involves.”

Women have been traditionally expected to marry, produce children and household labor, and be largely if not totally economically dependent on their husbands. This keeps women out of competition in the job market. But now there is an entire group of women that may not be able to marry and will have to be self-supporting perhaps while also supporting others. Can Black women afford to subordinate sex discrimination to race discrimination? Feminism is an undeniable economic reality to all women, and an urgent one to Black women.

A woman's place:  
Breaking Bonds  

Janet Sergi  

Women are changing. What is a  
woman's place? How can we  
become new women? Today old  
modes of acting and interacting  
with one’s self and others are  
unacceptable. We cannot be the  
ever-nurturing females that  
many of our mothers were.  

Both our biological and  
mythical mother figures have  
forsaken their own identities to  
shape and mold their daughters  
and sons into the roles the  
patriarchy needs. Sons become  
workers or the professional  
elites. These males are  
psychically nurtured from birth  
to death by females: first by  
their mothers, then by  
mothering wives, and lastly by  
mothering daughters/nurses in  
old age.  

In a patriarchy, sons revolt  
from their nuclear family ties  
and set off on their own. In the  
course of a man’s rebellion, he  
finds a female who performs the  
nurturing role for him. In  
heterosexual men this takes the  
form of a wife and the cheap  
service and labor of women in  
the economy; homosexual men  
just have the latter.  

Women are men’s prime  
possession. This is the reason for  
the extreme competitiveness and  
aggression of males. The results  
are war, capitalism and of  
course, woman's  
dehumanization. She is but an  
object. Her function is to serve  
man. She cannot help herself  
nor her female children. A  
female has no identity other  
than her connection to the male,  
i.e. women take the last name of  
their closest male relative.  

Mothers break their bonds  
with their female child early.  
The daughter begins to nurture  
the other children in the family  
and dotes on her father before  
she is grown. Freud is incorrect.  
The daughter is socialized in a  
patriarchy to nurture her father  
and all men not for love but for  
survival. She turns into a  
mother/wife before she is  
allowed to be a daughter, a  
female to herself. This lack of  
mother nurture and female self  
identity produces much hatred  
and jealousy among women.  

This kind of horizontal  
hostility among women weakens  
them and makes them more  
amenable and available to the  
male power structure. The  
female has only one role, that of  
mother. Still after four years of  
feminist training, I tend to think  
of others first, afraid or unsure  
of my own needs.  

A new role for woman would  
be that of a daughter, a female  
for herself. A daughter nurtures  
herself. A daughter rebels  
against everything that denies  
her her own energy. A daughter  
climbs every hill and valley of  
experience without even the  
thought, “Is this proper for a  
woman to do?” A daughter to  
herself, is the greatest threat to  
the patriarchy. She deprives men  
of female nurture and service.  

Men use women's energy to  
control the world for their own  
benefit. Control and power are  
the unifying concepts of sexism,  
racism, classism and imperialism.  
White, upper class men control  
the rest of the world’s energy.  
First, they usurp their mother’s  

energy, then through their  
patriarchy they become a  
parasite to all women, the lower  
classes, and other races.  
Females, racial minorities, the  
working classes and the Third  
World have no identity or power  
other than their nurturing role  
to white males.  

Radical feminism begins to  
break this cycle of oppression.  
Daughters become daughters to  
themselves. Females begin to  
have a self-identity. They keep  
their own power and energy  
unto themselves. Thus white  
males are deprived of ill-gotten  
energy. Men are not allowed all  
their mother’s energies. The  
cycle begins to break. Men are  
not given the right to other  
people's energy, be they female,  
poor or racially different.  

What is needed is a daughter’s  
rebellion. Rebellious women are  
daughters to themselves; the  
vitalities of a new order. A  
daughter to herself keeps her  
power and energy to herself and  
thus stops the vicious cycle of  
white male supremacy.  
Concretely, we need to learn  
skills in all fields of human  
endeavor. And we need  
to build a woman's community.  

These communities should be  
social and political units capable  
of giving love and support, time  
and energy, and wisdom and  
knowledge to other women. A  
women’s community is the place  
where women’s energy will be  
generated and stored.  

The minority and Third  
World Communities are building  
their power bases. Likewise  
women must regroup themselves  
for the long task ahead. We are  
working for a place where each  
of us is powerful unto herself.  
The patriarchy needs to be  
replaced, not by a matriarchy  
nor any form of hierarchy, but  
by an energized society. It might  
be called a woman's place;  
a woman's place is a place for  
herself.
