Big Mama Rag Born Out  
of Frustration, Success  

Elissa Meyer  

Big Mama Rag was born out  
of the need for expression,  
women’s expression. She began  
as an idea conceived at a  
women’s festival in Denver and  
was published for the first time  
nine months later, in October of  
1972.  

The women who worked on  
the paper and grew with Big  
Mama have learned the depth of  
meaning involved in expression  
and communication. The paper  
has become much more to some  
of us than a form of mass media.  
We have learned to share the  
frustrations and successes of  
creation, to start with nothing  
and replace the emptiness with a  
reality.  

In the beginning the  
excitement of actually seeing  
those finished and folded pieces  
of newsprint, the paper that told  
our stories and reflected our  
emotions, was sufficient to  

enhance the dedication of our  
group. Most of us had full-time  
jobs in institutions or with  
children. We met and worked on  
the paper in the evenings and on  
weekends, and although we  
encountered many difficulties in  
trying to create a newspaper  
given our time limitations, we  
managed to publish pretty  
consistently every two months  
for over a year.  

Recent Grant  

Being proud and encouraged  
by our accomplishment, we  
pursued alternative modes for  
continuing and supporting the  
publication of Big Mama. In  
January of 1974 the Aton  
foundation granted us a small  
sum of money to back the paper  
for six months. This money  
provides for one full-time salary  
of $350 per month, which we  
now split three ways among the  
co-editors, and for office  
expenses and some promotional  
money.  

Receiving this grant really  
marks a transitional period for  
Big Mama Rag. She has evolved  
from a feeling to a full-fledged  
periodical. And now the women  
who make up the staff are  
tackling the task of making Big  
Mama a successful business. Not  
in the sense of making a profit,  
but we do want the paper to  
become a self-supporting

A great part of reaching this  
goal depends on how much the  
women’s community of Denver  
shares our enthusiasm for this  
means of expression and  
relationship with each other.  
The paper’s longevity depends  
largely on continued financial  
and volunteer support, in the  
form of subscriptions,  
contributions and work.  

We have continually kept ears,  
eyes and hearts open for ways to  
raise the necessary money. We're  
looking forward to having a  
booth at the People’s Fair on  
May 11, and we would ask any  
woman who would like to  
exhibit arts and crafts and share  
the proceeds with us to call  
Becky at 623-3423 and join us.  
We also welcome any other  
fund-raising suggestions as well  
as the energy to carry them  
through.  

Thanks for Existing  

As the paper has developed  
throughout the last two years,  
the lives of those of us on the  
staff have changed, matured and  
mingled with each other’s. And  

when we stress the continuation  

of Big Mama we emphasize this  
process. Each time we receive a  
letter that says, “Thank you for  

existing. I live in Aurora (or  
Lakewood, or Golden, or  
Kansas), and when I see Big  

Mama Rag I realize that  
Feminism is active and growing  
and even reaching out here. I am  
delighted and encouraged.”  

Every time BMA elicits that  
kind of response, the staff's  
sense of responsibility deepens.  
We grow in our commitment to  
one another and to the larger  
women’s movement. The  
recognition that women need to  
relate, to express, to exchange  
our stories and experiences has  
added significance to Big Mama  
as a paper and to our lives as her  
creators.  

Because of this commitment,  
the paper’s reputation is growing  
nationally. Presently, Big Mama  
Rag is ranked among the most  
successful women’s papers in the  
country, along with Ain’t I a  
Woman, Off Our Backs,  
Women’s Press (to name some).  
We are grateful to our readership  
and to the many women who  
have helped with the paper’s  
production.  

With this same kind of  
support, we will stay around and  
will continue to touch the  
spaces where women are  
growing stronger, where we are  
beginning to realize our  
potential as individuals, where  
women are emerging in affection  
and unity as Feminists. Because  
wherever this is happening our  
potential for social change is  
limitless.

Working Girl Mystique  

Lynda Hartman  

Have you ever heard of the  
“working boy mystique”? Well,  
neither have I. In the business  
world, there is a very definite  
“working girl mystique” where  
women are treated as girls.  

The mystique can be  
recognized by several  
characteristics. Men in offices  

are always looking for “girls”  
who will nurture them. It is not  
uncommon to be asked where  
supplies are; “get me a pencil!  
I’m helpless,” they say, “serve  
me.”  

Many men are also always  
looking for “girl’s” asses to pinch  
or trying to look at their legs  
and breasts. The shortest  
dresses, lowest cut tops (of  
course not too low) are  

excellent forms of dress. The  
men sometimes start competing  
amongst each other for the  
cutest “girl.” To call a female a  
woman often brings sexuality  
into full force. Men do  
not/cannot want to face up to  
the fact that the women in the  
office have their own sexual  
feelings, which go beyond being  
treated as “girls.”  

I have had sexual feelings  
towards the people I see eight  
hours a day. The difference for  
me is that I do not feel a need to  
compete with the other women  
for the men. I do not need to  
say how I have brushed up  
against a man’s penis or looked  
at another woman’s breasts. I  
have had fantasies about some  
of the men in my office, but I  
see them as only fantasies and  
nothing more. I can enjoy  
flirting with these men when  
both of us know all along that  
we are just playing a game, and  
we have no further intentions. I  
can also appreciate compliments  
on my appearance when it is  

done as an appreciation of my  
sexuality, and not as a pretty  
“girl” fulfilling someone  
else’s needs.  

Often the mystique role also  
comes out when one sees  
women carrying coffee to their  
male workers. How often do you  
see a man carrying two cups of  
coffee? “Girls” carry coffee as  
part of their job. They are  
considered indispensable. It is  
easy to find another coffee  
carrier! Also of course the  
female does all the kitchen work  
at home, so she can do it in the  
office. Many women today are  
calling kitchen work a job that  
should be shared by everyone  
who eats.  

It seems to me that if office  
people of both sexes cannot even  
share very simple tasks, that we  
have a long way to go before  
people will be on a more equal  

basis in offices. All office  
workers are basically  
interdependent upon one  

another. The tasks of all cannot  
be done without the other  
people in the office. We are all  
people who have to work to  
survive. Unfortunately, until  
women are treated as women,  
equality will not be seen in the  
business world.  

The “girl mystique” in the  
office must be changed.  
Nurturing, sex objects, poor  
pay, lack of privacy and  
respectability of work all lead to  
the “girl mystique.” Let's not  
forget or let people put us in  
another place; we're women!  

Work Not Important?  

The “girl mystique” comes  
into play in terms of physical  
set-up of office space. Women  
are not given offices, they don’t  

need privacy. “Girls’” work is  
not considered important  
enough for them to have the  
respect of their own office. I am  
now sitting in an area that was a  
secretary area in the entrance  
way to several offices. I am  
asked questions about the  
whereabouts of the men in the  
area even though they are in  
different departments and I  
rarely work with them.  

Salaries are another “girl  
mystique.” “Girls” do not need  
to earn much money. They may  
be supporting children and are  
sole heads of a household, but  

they’re “girls.” Also the single  
woman feels the salary  
discrimination. The trend in  

business seems to be that single  
women do not need to earn  
money! For more on women  
and job positions see BMR (No. 6 April, 1974).  

The “girl mystique” includes  
the fact that “girls” cannot  
make decisions on their own.  
They present the problems,  
bring up the solutions, and the  
male bosses make the decisions.  
This of course frees the “girls”  
from having the responsibility of  
making a wrong (bad) decision!  
Heaven forbid! Of course it also  
frees them from making a right  
decision. Part of the mystique is  
saying that “girls” cannot make  
decisions, so why worry their  
little heads!  

Personal defense classes are  
being held every Thursday night  
at 7:30 p.m. downstairs in the

through June. The instructors

physical self-confidence.

Big Mama Rag Vol. 2 No. 7

Brass Plum: Birth, Life of a Co-op

Carol Lease

wondered  
what happened to all the energy  
that dissatisfaction generated in  
the early seventies when the  
rhetoric was fading and people  
were “getting into themselves”?

Have you ever

Did anger creating its own  
frustration seek comfort in  
drugs whose banal highs eventually  
descended to religious ex-  
perience?

Many people recognized  
opportunity in the marketing  
potential of the dissatisfaction  
of “young” consumers, rounded  
up capital and invested in  
counter-culture profits. Some  
people wanted an alternative  
structure to live and work in  
that would not alienate their  
convictions from their necessity  
to survive in a city. And a few of  
these people looked around  
until they saw a store on 17th  
Street across from a small island  
park for rent and took their  
energy and made a co-operative  
for artists and craftspeople to  
make and display and sell their  
work.

The Brass Plum opened in  
December of 1970 when about  
thirty people decided that they  
wanted to work and sell their art  
and crafts through a co-opera-  
tive business structure. Annie  
Wood, an original member of  
the co-op, recalls, “a lot of  
different people were into social  
change at that time... high  
school kids from some kind of  
street academy helped build in  
the store, their teacher really  
liked the idea of a co-op and let  
them stay in the store instead of  
a classroom.

Co-op Did Well

“We opened before Christmas  
and did really well. There were  
workshops taught by co-op  
craftspeople in the part of the  
store that is now the Denver  
Free University’s coffeehouse.  
Then came the after Christmas  
sales slump and some people left  
when their work didn’t sell.

Meanwhile we learned that too  

many open doors and too many  
people wandering in and out led  
to thievery which, along with  
our lack of business experience,  
put us into debt. Our organiza-  
tion was too loose.

The Brass Plum then began to  
change from a counter-culture  
fling to a stable co-operative  
venture. Members learned that  
there is seldom instant return on  
their work, that being in a co-op  
means accepting responsibility  
not only for yourself but for the  
entire structure also through  
cooperation with each other.  
“The co-op lets each of us forget  
100% of the hassles of owning a  
store individually because we're  
all in this together and we  
support each other,” according  
to Annie.

Having the opportunity  
to meet people who buy your work  
is another advantage of the  
co-op. The artist doesn’t have to  
deal with high consignment  
rip-offs that push up prices and  
discourage sales. In a co-  
operative business the money  
exchanged for work is much  
closer to the true value of that  
work than in a profit-seeking  
business due to the absence of  
the middleperson and their in-  
come.

Co-ops Respected

People respect co-ops. A man  
stole a candle from the Brass  
Plum but brought it back with a  
quarter and an apology when he  
found out that he had ripped off  
a co-operative business.

The expenses of the co-op  
such as rent and utilities are paid  
by monthly dues and new  
membership fees. If any money  
is left over it is used for  

advertising, something that  
Bette Warren, a dressmaker in  
the Brass Plum Co-op, thinks is  
sorely needed. “No one knows  
we're here. In the past we  
haven’t done as much adver-  
tising as we would have liked to.  
We hope that the Street Fair this  
spring when the Folklore Center  
moves up to 17th and Park,  
right across from our store, will  
help us become more visible to  
the community.”

The co-op holds bi-monthly  
meetings at which business deci-  
sions are discussed and decided  
through consensus or vote.  
Every three months a new  
chairperson of meetings, secre-  
tary, treasurer, custodian, and  
advertiser are chosen. This way  
each member experiences every  
aspect of the co-operative busi-  
ness structure. Nobody wants to  
be the leader and nobody can  
become a controller. There is no  
need for a boss because cooper-  
ation tends to level the heights  
that people tend to rely on for  
survival.

Members help each other out,  
according to Jim Bednar, a  
potter from Castle Clay Co-op.  
“When I started to sell things I  
wasn't very confident. People at  
the shop were friendly and  
encouraging and now I make a  
significant part of my income  
through my craft.”

Open for Change

Even though the co-op is  
always open for changes and  
suggestions, it has basic written  
rules that are adhered to because  
it's “too messy without rules,”  
insists Annie. Being the store-  
keeper twice monthly is such a  
rule. Working two days a month  
in the shop is not as inflexible as  
it may seem. Members can work  
half days and Saturdays if they  
have other jobs and can even  
make arrangements with friends  
to work in the store for them.  
Co-op members can trade off  
days for long periods of time so  
that a member can go on long  
trips. Deals can be made as long  
as the work rule is obeyed.

As for the future, Annie says  
that the co-op “takes it as it  
comes. The reason we’re here is  
that this is the logical way to go  
about doing something you  
want to do while being in an  
atmosphere with other crafts-  
people and artists.”

There is no distinction within  
the co-op between the ten women  
members and the three men  
members. Collective action  

keeps the store going, not sexist  

stereotyping.

When asked if she experi-  
enced problems at the Brass  
Plum because of her sex, Annie  
replies, “In the co-op, no. In  
life, yes.”

Different Position

The position of a woman in  
any profit-motivated business is  
radically different from her  
position in a co-operative busi-  
ness. In the former she must  

have credentials—material and  
emotional, social and psycho-  
logical—that are indispensable  
parts of getting a job. Her life  
becomes fragmented and is split  
into the behavioral expectations  
of the boss and the customer  
and the secretary and the  
accountant. Individuality is ana-  
thema in this type of economic  
structure. Going home from  
work temporarily dulls the alien-  
ation but only change creates  
permanent relief that especially  
affects a woman who is in the  
double locked jail of capitalist  
sexism.

In the latter, each member has  
specific responsibilities in the  
co-operative store. Duties are  
cycled so that the absence of  
any co-op member cannot  
inhibit the operation of the  
entire co-op. The possible lack  
of experience that a woman (or  
anyone) may bring to the co-op  
is unimportant. Everyone learns  
and changes and hopefully  
grows, thus creating growth in  
the structure and function of  
the co-operative. A woman who  
works in a co-op isn’t seen as  
being any different from any  
other woman because she isn’t  
any different.

Theory Shattered

She shatters the “unique-  
woman-pulls-herself-out-of-  

the-baby-bottle-ghetto-theory,”  
which, like its racist counter-  
part, keeps the oppressive laws  
and practices alive and denies  
women their rights but most of  
all life.

Some of the work on sale at  
the Brass Plum Co-op includes  
photography, pottery, jewelry,  
plants, clothing for infants to  
adults, candles, toys. The store  
accepts merchandise on consign-  

ment from people who do not  
wish to become members of the  
co-op. Their consignment per-  
centage is the lowest in town.  
Anyone who may want to sell  
their work at the Brass Plum  
should bring a sample to a  
general meeting held on the  
second and fourth Wednesdays  
of every month at 5 in the  
evening at the store.

If you want to become a  
member of the co-op you  
needn't worry about elitism and  
hidden power structures. This  
co-op functions on an equali-  
tarian basis. This co-op denies  
shiny, slick, chic stores addi-  
tional income from high consign-  
ment image peddling. It destroys  
the parasitic relationship be-  
tween sellers and buyers and  
producers, insures the buyer  
high quality work and fine craft  
work at half the price, and  
dilutes the fragmentation and  
mystery of the artist's life.

Women Must Control  
Own Medical Destiny  

Barbara Hume  

The other day I picked up  
Milestones in Midwifery  
expecting to find this book  

filled with all sorts of wonderful  
things about those women  
throughout history who have  
given so much of what little  
medical care there was. Instead,  
once again, I was face to face  
with the reality of life as a  
woman. This 1967 book from  
England, a country where  
females still play a central role  
in midwifery, is by a man about  
men. Why does this book  
mention only two women? What  
can we do about it? And what  
implications does this hold for  
the Women's Movement in  
general? The answer to why this  
book is so male oriented is  
subtly provided by the author,  
Walter Radcliffe, himself. Both  
surgical techniques and  
education were the carefully  
guarded rights of men only  
historically. Of forceps,  
Radcliffe says: “...the young  
surgeons who wanted to be in  
the fashion by taking up  
midwifery...wanted to know all  
they could about the new  
forceps, which gave them a  
skill—and a weapon—which the  

midwives could not claim.”  
Though forceps and other  
surgical techniques certainly  

played a crucial role in barring  
women from the changing field  
of obstetrics, such a simple  
explanation alone does not  
satisfy why Radcliffe can claim  
all the milestones for men.  
Women were excluded from  
education at all levels. This  
meant that most midwives could  
not read or write, and so could  
not communicate their learning  
to the educated world of men.  
Thus Radcliffe is able to claim  
the use of ergot as a milestone  
for men though the female  
midwives had been using it for  
centuries before some man  
finally noticed and published his  
“new” discovery.  

No Credit  

Ergot is a parasitic fungus which  
grows on grain and in its refined  
forms is still one of the most  
important drugs in obstetrics. It  
hastens prolonged labors and  
helps the clamping down of the  
uterus after delivery to slow  
hemorrhage. Even Radcliffe  
admits that German midwives  
used it in prolonged labor, but  
he gives the credit not to the  
women who long saved lives  
with it, but to the man who  
wrote about it. We can help put  

women back into their properly  
central role in the care of their  
bodies by correcting these two  
still existent problems. This  
century has seen no increase in  
the number of women in  
medical school. Sometimes I  
think this is because women are  
too intelligent to submit  
themselves to the inhumane  
atmosphere of medical  
education today. However,  
reality dictates that as long as  
the doctor is the power  
possessor in the medical world  
instead of one member of a  
good team, we need female  
doctors—lots of them. We need  
female doctors to help reverse  
the servant roles now so much a  
part of the hierarchy. We need  
female doctors who know the  
feeling of uterine cramps as  
directly as male doctors who  
know the ache of a scrotal  
injury. We also need male  
nurses. What of that majority of  
women not in medicine? There  
is nothing which keeps medical  
personnel more alert than a  
well-informed patient who asks  
intelligent questions.  

Publish or Perish?  

The what to do about  
“publish or perish” is clearly  
important in the female-male  
battle as well as in the more  
strictly academic world.  
Education is fairly open to us  
now. Individuals and women’s  
groups can use this tool to  
rewrite the history books and to  
research more effective and  
humane techniques in women’s  
medicine, and medicine in  
general. Barbara Ehrenreich and  
Deirdre English have begun to  
counter the male version of  
history in their pamphlet,  
Witches, Midwives, and Nurses.  
This extremely important bit of  
historical research reveals for  
instance that at the time  
midwives were outlawed in this  
country, it was not as we have  
always been told, because these  
uneducated women were less  
competent. In fact, a study by  
Johns Hopkins professor in 1972  
indicated that most American  
doctors were less competent  
than the midwives. Not only  
were the doctors themselves  
unreliable about preventing  
sepsis and ophthalmia but they  
also tended to be too ready to  
use surgical techniques which  
endangered mother or child. If  
anyone, then, deserved a legal  
monopoly on obstetrical care, it  
was the midwives, not the MDs.  
But the doctors had power the  
midwives didn’t.  

The self-help groups  
around the country;  
groups of women putting out  
such fine materials as Our  
Bodies, Our Selves; groups  
lobbying for less restrictive  
legislation of nurses, midwives  
and other paramedics; groups  
like the La Leche League who  
daily combat questionable  
obstetric and pediatric  
practices—these are the primary

The Women’s Defense Com-  
mittee was formed on January  
12, 1974, at a meeting held at  
the Gay Community Services  
Center in Los Angeles. Activities  
on the committee include mem-  
bers of the Tide Collective,  
National Organization for Wo-  
men, Westside Lesbian Femin-  
ists, The Gay Community Ser-  
vices Center, and the Gay  
Sisterhood at UCLA.  

The purpose of the WDC is to  
raise money for court cases  
dealing with Lesbian and Femin-  
ist oppression, and to build  
public support toward these  
causes.  

The committee is presently  
working on two separate cases.  
Lynda Chaffin has lost custody  
of her two daughters, ages 11  
and 13, to her parents because  
she is a Lesbian. Marie Nunes  
lost her job because she could  
not maintain her security clear-  
ance when it was discovered she  
was a Lesbian.  

Support is needed in the form  
of money, publicity, and women  
who can give their time. Anyone  
interested in donating money,  
please send checks made payable  
to Women’s Defense Committee  
to: Women’s Defense Commit-  
tee, 373 No. Western Ave., No.  
202, Los Angeles, Calif. 90004.  
Women interested in working on  
the committee, or who have any  
helpful suggestions, please write

Harpies Bizarre

Rita Williams as Rinso White.

Big Mama Rag Vol. 2 No. 7

Sharon Niederman expounds upon welfare motherhood.

“We wanted to hit them pow, pow, pow, pow,” explained one of
the performers, relaxing and still out of breath following the
rehearsal. And Harpies’ Bizarre, which played at the Changing Scene in
early April, did exactly that. *

Comprised of eight brief segments, the play barraged its audience
with statements about women and women’s roles.

The performance of Harpies’ Bizarre marked the debut of the Great
Grand Daughters of the American Revolution (GGDAR). The group,
made up of local feminists Marilee Long Saxe, Sharon Niederman, and
Rita Williams, wrote, directed, and performed the play.

Costumed in vibrant hot pink leotards and multi-colored
patchwork skirts, the trio sang, danced, and presented their poetry to
Denver viewers. With action that ranged from straightforward to
highly stylized, they focused first on one woman’s problems then on
another's pride.

Mother and daughters, wives and waitresses expressed themselves
through Harpies’ Bizarre. Three monologues, “Welfare” by Nieder-
man, “Waitress” by Williams, and “Mothers” by Saxe, provided
glimpses of disillusioned women who were either out of work or
bitter about their jobs.

Relying on a minimum of props and a maximum of energy, the
segment “Rinso White” became effective satire on women as
girlfriends, mothers, and housewives.

Somewhat more abstract, the “Ashgrove” and “Hist ye Gossips”
explored woman through poetry. These segments dealing with the
moods and sensitivities of women seemed somehow to wrap the
others into perspective and the play into an aesthetic, cohesive whole.

Harpies’ Bizarre, GGDAR explained in a Denver Post interview,
consists of “our own thoughts and views of the world.” But even
more, they emphasized, the play is an example that women can create
successfully together.

The group indicated that they are available for performance,
though they do require payment.

socially assigned sex role... are not therefore a “real woman” or a
“real man.” The grudging admiration felt for the tomboy, and the
queasiness felt around a sissy boy point to the same thing: the
contempt in which women—or those who play a female role—are
held. And the investment in keeping women in the contemptuous
role is very great. Lesbian is the word, the label, the condition that
holds women in line. When a woman hears this word tossed her way,
she knows she is stepping out of line. Lesbian is a label invented by
the Man to throw at any woman who dares to assert the primacy of
her own needs.

Divides Humanity

“Lesbian” is one of the sexual categories by which men have divided
up humanity. While all women are dehumanized as sex objects, as
the objects of men they are given certain compensations... Should a
woman confront herself by confronting another woman, there are
fewer rationalizations, fewer buffers by which to avoid the stark
horror of her dehumanized condition. Herein we find the overriding
fear of many women toward being used as a sexual object by a
woman, which not only will bring her no male-connected compensations,
but also will reveal the void which is woman's real situation.
This dehumanization is expressed when a straight woman learns that
a sister is a Lesbian; she begins to relate to her Lesbian sister as her
potential sex object, laying a surrogate male role on the Lesbian...
For women, especially those in the movement, to perceive their Lesbian
sisters through this male grid of role definitions is to accept this
male cultural conditioning and to oppress their sisters much as they
themselves have been oppressed by men.

Women in the movement have in most cases gone to great lengths to
avoid discussion and confrontation with the issue of Lesbianism....
But it is no side issue. It is absolutely essential to the success and
fulfillment of the Women’s Liberation Movement that this issue be
dealt with. As long as the label “dyke” can be used to frighten a
woman into a less militant stand, keep her separate from her sisters,
keep her from giving primacy to anything other than men and family—
then to that extent she is controlled by the male culture. Until
women see in each other the possibility of a primal commitment
which includes sexual love, they will be denying themselves the love
and value they readily accord to men, thus affirming their second
class status. As long as male acceptability is primary—both to in-
dividual women and to the movement as a whole—the term Lesbian
will be used effectively against women.

... It also should be said that some younger, more radical women
have honestly begun to discuss Lesbianism, but so far it has been
primarily as a sexual “alternative” to men. This, however, is still giving
primacy to men, both because the idea of relating more completely
to women occurs as a negative reaction to men, and because the Les-
bian relationship is being characterized simply by sex, which is
divisive and sexist. On one level, which is both personal and political,
women may withdraw emotional and sexual energies from men, and
work out various alternatives for those energies in their own lives. On
a different political/psychological level, it must be understood that
what is crucial is that women begin disengaging from male-defined
response patterns. In the privacy of our own psyches, we must cut
those cords to the core. For irrespective of where our love and sexual
energies flow, if we are male-identified in our heads, we cannot
realize our autonomy as human beings.

Self-Hate

... The consequence of internalizing this role (of male-defined sexual
and family functions) is an enormous reservoir of self-hate. This is not
to say the self-hate is recognized or accepted as such; indeed most
women would deny it. It may be experienced as discomfort with her
role, as feeling empty, as numbness, as restlessness, as a paralyzing
anxiety at the center. Alternatively, it may be expressed in shrill
defensiveness of the glory and destiny of her role. But it does exist,
often beneath the edge of her consciousness, poisoning her ex-
istence, keeping her alienated from herself, her own needs, and
rendering her a stranger to other women. They try to escape by iden-
tifying with the oppressor, living through him, gaining status and iden-
tity from his ego, his power, his accomplishments. And by not iden-
tifying with other “empty vessels” like themselves. Women resist
relating on all levels to other women who will reflect their own oppres-
sion, their own secondary status, their own self-hate. For to confront
another woman is finally to confront one’s self—the self we have
gone to such lengths to avoid. And in that mirror we know we cannot
really respect and love that which we have been made to be.

... It is very difficult to realize and accept that being “feminine” and
being a whole person are irreconcilable. Only women can give to each
other a new sense of self. That identity we have to develop with
reference to ourselves, and not in relation to men. This consciousness
is the revolutionary force from which all else will follow, for ours
is an organic revolution.

For this we must be available and supportive to one another, give our
commitment, and our love, give the emotional support necessary to
sustain this movement. Our energies must flow toward our sisters,
not backward toward our oppressors. As long as Women’s Liberation
tries to free women without facing the basic heterosexual structure
that binds us in one-to-one relationships with our oppressors,
tremendous energies will continue to flow into trying to straighten up
each particular relationship with a man, into finding how to get better
sex, how to turn his head around—into trying to make the “new man”
out of him, in the delusion that this will allow us to be the “new
woman.” This obviously splits our energies and commitments, leaving
us unable to be committed to the construction of the new patterns
which will liberate us.

... It is the primacy of women relating to women, of women creating a
new consciousness of and with each other, which is at the heart of
Women’s Liberation, and the basis for the cultural revolution... We
see ourselves as prime, find our centers inside of ourselves. We find
receding the sense of alienation, of being cut off, of being behind a
locked window, of being unable to get out what we know is inside. We
feel a realness, feel at last we are coinciding with ourselves. With
that real self, with that consciousness, we begin a revolution to end
the imposition of all coercive identifications, and to achieve maximum
autonomy in human expression.

We would again like to re-emphasize that both Lesbians and straight
women are in different stages of consciousness at different times.
Consciousness raising must be done with this difference in mind,
remembering that there are countless ways to reach the objective of all
women’s culture and all women’s efforts should be encouraged in this
direction.

—Chocolate Waters

Women and  
the Arts  

The apathy of the Denver  
public, galleries, and museums is  
stifling potential creativity; and  
offering, virtually, a dead-end  
road to women.  

In cities responsive to art,  
women have been able to  
successfully fight the  
mainstream and have built a  
creative and competitive force.  

Womanspace, a Los Angeles  
art center for women, was  
originated by L.A. women in  
January, 1972. According to the  
Women’s Survival Catalogue,  
this is the first comprehensive  
west coast exhibition space for  
women.  

Womanspace has members  
from all over the states, and  

offers unprecedented services  
and nurturance to Feminist  
artists. For twelve dollars a year,  
Womanspace members are  
offered: a slide registry,  
exhibition and voting  

privileges; and a subscription to  
Womanspace Journal.  

Other benefits available to  
L.A. women include lectures,  
workshops, and exhibitions in  
all of the fine arts. Sometime in  
the future Womanspace may  
also put on traveling exhibitions.  

Another organization outside  
of Denver which is beneficial is  
the Slide Registry. A woman  
may send up to four slides of  
her work to the registry along  
with information regarding her  
work and herself. This  
information then becomes  
available to participating artists,  
galleries, and curators. The  
W.E.B. (West-East Bag) area  
representative maintains the  
registry. Our area rep is the art  
department at the University of  
Colorado.  

Women’s art centers,  
collective and non-collective in  
membership, have sprung up in  

many cities, including: the  
Chicago Women's Graphic  
Collective, Powerhouse in  

Montreal, Women’s Art Center  
in St. Louis, AJI.R. in New  
York, and centers in  
Connecticut, Ohio,  
Pennsylvania, California, and  
Massachusetts.  

The  

non-collective  
charge a twenty to thirty per  
cent commission on works sold.  
(The average is 40 per cent.)  
Along with the art centers a  
good number of film, video, and  

theatre collectives have  
blossomed. All of these help  
bring women’s art into the  
community where it belongs.  

Denver is far behind these  
towns but some constructive  
effort is being made.  

The Thread Co., a group of  
five Denver women who pooled  
their resources and minds,  
consists of Nancy Campbell,  
Susan Cole, Nancy Deveraux,  
Pauline Olsen, and Karen White.  
These women have taken all  
kinds of fibers and turned away  
from conventional crafts to fiber  
sculpture.  

A Denver collective is now  
also being organized. They meet  
weekly at 1895 Lafayette St.  
Call Kim at 355-8950 or Ghigui  
at 756-4377 for detailed  
information.  

Although it is hard for any  
kind of serious fine art to  
blossom in Denver, it is good to  
know that a few women are  
accepting the challenge and are  
getting down to work instead of  
complaining.

“I'll Be a  

Banker”  

In working-class Irish  
Catholic Boston, even today a  
Feminist is a woman who  
asks her husband to dry the  

dishes sometimes. Few of  
the daughters in that white  
ghetto where I grew up es-  
caped; when I am in Boston  
visiting friends and relatives I  
find my childhood friends all  
living just blocks from their  
parents and sending their  
children to the same  
parochial schools they went  
to.  

To most of them, I am a  
Radical Feminist. They are a  
long way, both geograph-  
ically and emotionally, from  
my woman friends here in  
Denver who are exploring the  
possibilities of self-recognition. The one question I have  
been asked by both groups of  
women is why I have chosen  
to try to break into finance.  
The answer doesn’t come  
easily.  

Painful Choice  

In a few months I will  
graduate from the University  
with a degree in finance and  
have put out the first feelers  
toward a position as an of-  
ficer in a local bank. It was a  
painful decision at best to  
make that choice and I can  
only trace its making back a  
year to another night in April  
when I listened to a strong  
and courageous Feminist talk  
about power.  

I went to interview  
Florynce Kennedy with other  
BMR staffers there and in-  
stead of an interview got an  

amazing dose of realism. I  
had spent my few years as a  
Feminist listening to people  
talk about collective vs.  
hierarchies and group  
strength vs. individual  
power, but in Kennedy, I was  
confronted with a woman  
talking about personal power  
being used to open doors and  
about the foolishness of  
denying one’s strengths to  
help each other.  

For the first time I un-  
derstood why I felt cheated in  
classes where the professor  
had opted out of a leadership  
position in the classroom.  
Because, (let's face it), they  
still gave out the grades all  
the while they were denying  
they had anything to teach.  

One of the basic truths of  
life may be that the strength  
to help other people is direct-  
ly proportional to the  
strength you have to help  
yourself. It may seem like a  
very simple truth but its  
application changed my style  
of life.  

Soc-Fem.-Maoist?  

I have found it threaten-  
ing to have someone ask  
what my politics are. The  
people who ask this question  
all seem to expect simple  
definitive answers which I  
don't have. I have long wish-  
ed I had a ready answer like,  
“I, my friend, am a Socialist-  
Feminist with Maoist  
leanings.” (I heard someone  
describe herself like that  
once and couldn't decide  
whether I was impressed or  
scared).  

It's not a problem  
anymore. I am a woman who  
believes in the power and  
strength of women, who  
would like to see America as  
a female culture. I see no  
dichotomy between that and  
my wish to work toward that  
end by opening doors for  
others with my own personal  
money-achieved powers. To  
those who have asked me  
what I will do, “after the  
revolution,” I answer again,  
“I'll be a banker.”  
Revolutions, contrary to a  
widely-held daydream, do  
not turn countries into  
agrarian paradises. CPAs,  
bankers, pilots, mothers, file-  
clerks, and grocery checkers  
need apply.  

Dropping out is not the answer;  
fucking up is. Most women are  
already dropped out; they were  
never in. Dropping out gives  
control to those few who don’t  
drop out; dropping out is  
exactly what the establishment  
leaders want; it plays into the  
hands of the enemy; it  
strengthens the system instead  
of undermining it, since it is based  
entirely on the nonparticipation,  
passivity, apathy, and  
non-involvement of the mass of  
women. Dropping out, however,  
is an excellent policy for men,  
and SCUM will enthusiastically  
encourage it. — Valerie Solanas,  
Scum Manifesto.

High School Women:  
Denver Career Fair Sexist  

Becky Bohannan  

A Career Exploration Fair  

descended upon Denver March  
11-15. Its purpose was to give  
high school and junior high  
students a chance to discover  
what they want to do in life.  
The information booklet that  
was available to students stated,  
“Career education...will help  
you know yourself better. What  
are you like? What do you want  
out of life?” These worthy goals  
ended up on the floor of  
Currigan Hall along with soda  
cans, straws and papers to be  
swept into trash cans and  
eventually buried. For Explo ‘74  
as it was called, did not allow  
students to answer the question  
“what shall I do with my life?”  
But instead things went more  
along the line of, “Since I am a  
girl what shall I do?” and “Since  
I am a boy what shall I do?”  

Little Effort  

Little noticeable effort was  
made to interest teenagers in  
any career outside their  
traditional roles.  

The information booklet  
students received was blatantly  
sexist. Throughout the booklet  
were sketches of persons in  
various occupations. On the  
front and back cover were  
construction workers, a taxi cab  
driver, a doctor and many others  
all of whom were male. Not one  
woman was on the cover. Inside  
the booklet women were  
depicted in the usual role of  
nurse, secretary, model,  
stewardess, and housekeeper.  
Possibly the worst sketch  
showed a woman standing on a  
chair, raising her skirt and  
screaming at a mouse on the  
floor. The sketch above it  
showed a man exterminating a  
bug. How are we ever going to  
successfully combat sexism  
when students are supplied with  
information such as this? At the  
fair booths and displays were set  
up with representatives from  
practically every imaginable  
occupation. I talked with people  
in careers traditionally occupied  
by men. All those I talked with  
were men and any pictures at  
the displays of people in that  
particular field were of men.  
This also held true for fields  
generally occupied by women. I  
first talked with a man from a  
large engineering firm, who told  
me that only three women at  
the Denver plant held positions  
other than secretarial work.  
When asked about schooling  
involved in becoming a certain

menses) we should not just  
accept the discovery without  
question, but should keep our  
minds open to exploring both  
the positive and negative aspects  
of the new discoveries. By  
continual self-criticism and  
education we will revolutionize  
our health care and be ready  
with a better system if our  
government is ever replaced with  
a system in which better ideas  
can flourish. In this as in other  
areas of the Women’s  
Movement, knowledge is the  
first step toward gaining power  
to control our own lives. It is  
much more difficult for a doctor  
to treat you poorly if you know  
enough to ask pointed questions  
at the crucial time, or to  
recognize an omission or error.  
It is much more difficult for the  
legislature to pass poor health  
programs or prejudicial licensing  
acts if a large body of informed  
women is questioning their  
actions. It is more difficult for  
men to retain power in any area  
if we know how and why they  
attained that power or  
position.

Millions for Salaries-Pennies for Daycare

Boulder Students Unite for Quality Daycare

Jan Throndson

“A group of men, women and children have just taken over the
Alumni Center...the university police are on their way to oust them
unless we go to show our support."

Standing in the fountain area of the Colorado University
Memorial Center, the young Feminist student shouted through a
bullhorn to 24 demonstrators, who had gathered in the cold, drizzling
rain of Monday, April 26. The demonstrators who had come to
rally at the fountain for better daycare (and who were unaware
that there was to be a building takeover) moved abruptly toward
the northwest corner of campus to lend their solidarity.

Why the drastic action? The history of the struggle for more quality
daycare on University of Colorado’s campus tells the story.

In 1971, student, faculty and
staff women at CU requested an

improvement and expansion of

existing daycare facilities, which
had changed little since they
were first established at the
close of World War II.

Baily Report

With this pressing request,
the regents, the governing board
of the university, commissioned
a study by the experienced and
widely respected educator, Bill
Baily. A year later, “The Baily
Report” was completed and
filed.

In his study, Baily documented
a need for daycare for 350
children, and recommended a
budget of $345,000. He proposed
a unique program of decentralized
“daycare homes”—private houses where
small groups of children could be
taught and cared for. Backed by
daycare professionals and
members of Boulder’s Task
Force on Women and Children,
“The Baily Plan” also sought a
central facility where children
could benefit from a preschool
atmosphere and where trained
adults could work in the daycare
units.

The study, costing approximately $25,000, was disregarded by the regents, and Baily’s contract was never renewed.

A second proposal was made
by the CU administration—the
“Taber Proposal.” This reaffirmed the need for childcare for
350 youngsters and proposed a
budget of $200,000.

It was not until April of this
year, after members of the CU
Women’s Liberation Coalition
(WLC) and other concerned individuals marched at Regent's
Hall, that the Board of Regents
appropriated funding for childcare. A total of $89,000 to
provide daycare for just 60
children was allocated.
Members of the WLC have taken
issue that this compensatory
move will do little more than bring the same inadequate childcare a bit closer to campus.

Women and Children Hold Office
Throughout Monday afternoon and evening, the
demonstrators inside the Alumni Center persisted in holding
down the director of University
Foundations, Inc., Dwight
Roberts’ office, while outside a
constant number of nearly 40
demonstrators persisted in the rain.
Not only were
protestors from the WLC, but
also from CU's United Mexican
American Students, Vietnam
Veterans Against the War, Gay
Liberation and the student
government—the UCSU.
Numerous unaffiliated students,
faculty and staff members joined
with student organizations during the entire Monday and Tuesday 32-hour takeover.
By Tuesday noon, the adults
occupying Roberts’ office felt that the children should not remain
cooped-up any longer, and at
that time the children were escorted out by the adult
demonstrators, all the time under
the watchful eye of the university
police.

Day Care is Our Right

In a prepared statement, read
from Roberts’ window to the
demonstrators below, Ms.
Jeanne Winer, member of the
WLC and staff secretary of the
UCSU, said, “...the time for
serious action has come. No
longer will we beg on our knees
for what should be ours by right.
The university is ours. We pay
for it.”

Winer continued, “Our
children are the human
resources of the entire society. It
is the responsibility of that society
to provide collectively for their
care and education. Too long has
this social duty been forced onto
the shoulders of individual
women at the expense of our
own health, careers, education,
economic well-being and personal lives... Too long have
children been confined to individual homes and limited
resources of single families. The
bonds between mother and child
should be bonds of love, not
chains of slavery.”

Winer, claiming that the
regents’ action was “criminally
inadequate,” said that the
center proposal for $89,000 will
at best provide for one-sixth of
the present daycare need and
that operational costs had not
been adequately considered.
She also stated that in the
regents’ proposal, women will
still be expected to bear the
monetary burden of childcare
costs through increases in their
housing fees.

“Individual expenses,” Winer
said, could amount to “the tune
of $81 per child per month.”

Interestingly enough, the
daycare demonstrators selected
Dwight Roberts’ office in the
Alumni Center, because it is the
“University of Colorado Foun-
dations, Inc.—one of the several
sources from which funding
could be found for childcare.”
This office solicits funds from
donations for specific projects,
such as the law and pharmacy
buildings, and the business
library, but at no time has it ever
made daycare a priority for funding.

Insensitivity to Women

Citing this as an example of
administrative insensitivity to
women’s needs, Winer said,
“There is no reason why a university with an annual budget of
over $600,000,000, that can afford to pay its figurehead president
$50,000 a year plus benefits, can’t provide $345,000 for adequate childcare.”

It was also emphasized that
there would be no need for an increase in student fees or a
decrease in student benefits to
provide for childcare.

Various speakers on
Tuesday's bright, sunny afternoon expressed several views in
support of a better quality
daycare program.

One spokeswoman from Kiddie Kampus, the present CU
childcare facility, said she per-
sonally had been working for
change for three years. Speaking
from experience in working
with low-income families, she
said, “Try living on $300 per
month and try to spread it evenly
among two adults and a
child...you can’t live reasonably
well when 27% of your income is
going to pay for childcare.”

“Besides this,” she said, “that
27% for childcare expenses
leaves nothing for the child’s
medical insurance.” She was
speaking to the issue that
besides the need for high quality
childcare, the care should be
low-cost.

Ann Markusen, assistant
professor of economics at CU,
addressed the Tuesday afternoon crowd of nearly 100, on the
importance of daycare, as a
necessity of Women’s Liberation.

“Childcare enslaves women
to the home, especially lower in-
come women...the necessary
conditions of Women’s Liberation are economic conditions.”

President Claims “No Authority”

During the entire 32-hour
dramatization for childcare, the
participants encountered
numerous difficulties with the
university police and regents’
non-responsiveness. While the
building was being held, the inside demonstrators and CU student body co-presidents, Cyndy
Calkins and Anita Sanchez,
made countless attempts to
mediate with the regents and
police.

Detrimental to the outcome of
the demands of the group was
the fact that all the regents were
out of town (some in New
Orleans at a university banquet)
and were impossible to reach in
order to talk out the demonstrators’ demands. After
a telephone session with
recently-dismissed President
Thieme, whose term lasts until
June 1, the mediators reported
that Thieme said he had no
authority left to call the regents
back for a meeting with the
demonstrators.

Later, Tuesday night at 8:30,
Thieme rediscovered his
authority, and ordered the university police to oust the occupiers of Roberts’ office. Earlier
notified by Dean of Student Af-
fairs, James Quigley, that they
had to be out by 5:00 pm, or they
would be issued summonses,
the demonstrators left two and a
half hours later, charged with
“interference with faculty, staff
and students in an educational
institution and failure to leave
the building after being ordered
to leave.”

Day Care Demands

The list of ten demands stated
by Ms. Winer, and left unmet by
the regents were whittled to two
demands after the first few
hours of the demonstration. The
two major demands included
amnesty for the inside
demonstrators and a guaranteed
meeting to discuss the daycare
problem with the regents.

Amnesty was granted for those
who left before 5:00 Tuesday
evening; however, a daycare
meeting with the regents was
never guaranteed.
Among the list of demands,
the following were included:
— That Sept. 1, 1974 be set as
the completion date for the $89,000 housing units for Kiddie
Kampus, passed on April 25,
1974, by the regents.
— That operational costs for the
daycare center be added to the
$89,000.
— That operational costs for the
daycare center be added to the
$89,000.
— That there be no increase in
married student housing living
costs to get funds for childcare
expenses.
— That the regents call a
meeting devoted solely to the
issue of committing themselves
to the demands.
— That total and unconditional
amnesty be granted to all people
inside Dwight Roberts’ office.
The Silver and Gold Record, a
CU faculty and staff newspaper,
reported that, “The only childcare facility is Kiddie Kampus, a
perpetually underfunded
program, housed currently in
ramshackle buildings...and
staffed by persons who rarely
make more than $2 per hour.”
In fact, in the past the program
was housed in World War I-vintage quonset huts and frequently staffed by work-study
students at minimal wages.
Kiddie Kampus Inadequate
Daycare professionals have
reiterated that the high turnover rates at Kiddie Kampus and
the use of barely-trained
students could increase the
problems of young children,
already burdened with the stress
of low incomes and broken
homes.

It is a widely-known fact that
some CU parents find it
necessary to bring their children
to classes with them.

After the unsuccessful
attempt on April 29-30, daycare
demonstrators again marched
on Thursday, May 9.

An educational drive is now
underway to inform all students,
faculty and staff of the inadequate daycare facilities. A survey is being taken by the daycare
committee to find just exactly
how much the need for childcare
has increased since “The Baily
Report,” and how many people
would support the drive for more
quality daycare.

Morgan: We’re the  
Women That Men  
Warned Us About  

Chocolate Waters  

“We all know the male mass media stereotype of the Women’s  
Movement: ‘If you've seen one Women’s Libber, you've seen ‘em  
all—they each have two heads, a pair of horns, and are fire-  
spouting, man-hating, neurotic, crazy, frigid, castrating-bitch,  
aggressive, broom-riding witches.’ So I want to start out by saying  
that this shocking stereotype is absolutely true,” said Robin  
Morgan to a group of about 100 people gathered in University of  

Colorado's Mackey Auditorium, April 8.  

Morgan, Feminist author,  
editor, and speaker went on to  
cover a number of topics perti-  
nent to women—including  
gynocracies, women’s revolu-  
tion, rape, pornography, and the  
Church. She began by explain-  
ing that we women are really a  
colonized people who have been  
alienated from our basic  
land—our bodies. “We have  
been used for childrearing and  
sex and have been made to feel  
unclean, but the time is here for  
us to take back our own land.  
Yes, we are the women men  
have warned us about!”  

She continued by talking  
about the Women’s Movement  
itself and observed three basic  
areas which have emerged. The  
first one being the Civil Rights  
area where groups (such as  
NOW) tend to work within the  
capitalistic and patriarchal  
system. “Although these groups  
often settle for legislative  
reform, their work is still in-  
tensely valuable,” said Morgan.  

The second area is what she  
called the Women’s Liberation  
part of the movement, where the  
refugees from the Left (or the  
“boys’ movement”) gathered  
together. Said Morgan of the  
woman who had been working  
in the Left, “wiping the tear gas  
from her eyes, she would then  
go home and make supper.” She  
added, “If people wonder why  
the Left is dead, it’s because  
most of the women (who were  
doing the shitwork) have left.”  

Radical Feminism  

The third and perhaps most  
important is the Radical  
Feminist part of the movement  
where women are not interested  
solely in reform. Affirmed  
Morgan, “I do not want to be  
equal with what it is men are in  
this society.” She went on to ex-  
plain that Radical Feminists are  
interested in working towards a  
world run by and on the power  
and love of women. In clarifica-  
tion of power (a tricky concept),  
she added, “not in the male  
sense of power over someone,  
but in the context of a ‘power  
plant producing energy.’ The  
power plant itself radiates life-  
giving energy, but does not con-  
trol life.”  

In such a society there would  
probably be few of the ills which  
characterize the patriarchal  
world of today. One of these ills  
is rape. Speaking out against  
rape, Morgan defined the crime  
as “any pressure on a woman to  
have intercourse against her  
will. According to that definition,  
the bedrooms of happily-married  
couples are often scenes of rape  
and every man could be defined  
as a rapist.”  

She also stressed the need for  
rape crisis centers run by  
women and further pointed out  
that in New York City last year  
only 4% of all rapes were  
reported and for the 18,000  
cases that did get to court there  
was only one conviction.  
Statistically, white women are  
raped most often by white men  
and Black women by Black men  
(contradicting the myths). “But  
interestingly enough,” she add-  
ed, “70% of all rapists are  
men.”  

Verbal Visual Rape  

Concerning verbal and visual  
rape—pornography, Morgan  
called it “one of those areas  
where mama was right.” Sex is  
used pornographically in a  
destructive, sadistic, conquering  
manner—just one more way of  
putting women down. She com-  
mented about “judges reading a  
lot of dirty books with one hand,”  
but went on to say that women  
are finding some of their own  
ways to deal with pornography.  
In Knoxville, Tenn., for example,  
women took pictures of men as  
they emerged from dirty book  
stores and plastered these pic-  
tures up all over town.  

As Morgan came to the end of  
her talk, she explained that a  
woman had requested a reading  
of “Monster,” the title poem from  
her first published book of  
poetry. Although she doesn't  
usually read her poems during  
speaking engagements, Robin  
closed the evening with a most  
powerful and moving reading.  
Seconds of silence followed by  
tears and thunderous applause  
affirmed that the audience in-  
deed shared the pain of Robin  
Morgan's experience as a  
woman as well as her hope of a  
new and promising world for us  
all.  

- An Interview  
With Robin Morgan  

Maureen Mrizek  

Chocolate and I traveled to  
Boulder to interview Robin  
Morgan on the afternoon of April  
8. We found her conducting a  
discussion in the upstairs of the  
SMC building. She sat patiently  
answering questions and  
illuminating Feminist concepts  
with an unending supply of facts  
and analysis.  

After the discussion we walk-  
ed down to the Women’s Center  
for the interview. I may add that  
the Women’s Center was bright-  
ly festooned with pictures of  
women supporting some of the  
most recent male national  
liberation struggles, and there  
were posters advertising the  
Women’s Center presentation of  
“Lucia” (a movie about a woman's  
role in a man’s revolution). Lucia  
seemed to be the hottest thing to  
hit town since the Betty Crocker  
Bakeoffs.  

Back to the interview—we  
didn’t really push a lot of things  
into the interview because Robin  
had been talking politics all  
afternoon and her voice seemed  
to be fading away. But we talked  
about a few important topics. We  
wanted to know her view of the  
differences that exist in the  
Women’s Movement. She said  
that she felt there could be “a  
tremendous strength in diver-  
sity”—that we have a “12,000  
year old battle to fight and there  
will, most likely, be more than  
one way to fight it.” She said she  
felt that diversity is a “natural  
outcome of our growth as a  
movement,” and that “it matters  
less where a woman is coming  
from than where she’s going to.”  
She suggested that we should  
ask ourselves “What is our com-  
mitment to a worldwide  
Women’s Revolution?” She felt  
that instead of developing in  
terms of “vanguardism” and the  
“correct line” we should con-  
centrate more on “respect for  
the individual and where she  
feels most comfortable.” She  
suggested that some of our  
divisions “are the product of  
moral laziness. They are an ex-  
cuse for not confronting men,  
the real oppressors.”  

We talked about the  
differences that women face in  
working together politically,  
which I, for lack of a better term,  
labeled the “Consciousness  
Chasm,” the differences in  
women’s Feminist con-  
sciousness. She said that  
women with a more advanced  
Feminist consciousness  
“should not lose sight of where  
they themselves have been,”  
that “all of us at some time in our  
lives have thought ‘I’m not op-  
pressed’ and believed it.” She  
suggested that we view  
ourselves as “facilitators un-  
covering the layers of defenses  
women have built up for survival  
in a man's world.” She said  

More on Page 3  

Political, Spiritual  
Feminism Flourish  
In New Mexico  

Linda Fowler  

“The Women's Movement in Santa Fe is really together,” a friend  
told me. It seemed like a good idea to check it out.  

Going into my second day in Santa Fe, I could feel the birth pangs my  
sisters were suffering. They had been able to establish the Women’s  
Health Services (in spite of hassles from the state over abortion  
counseling), the Santa Fe Women’s Commune which the  
women published on their own press, and a women’s center, “The  
Gathering” (I Ching), established on little more than energy. With this  
last development, social stigmas arose because the center is located  
on the edge of the barrio and had been founded by a predominantly  
Lesbian group.  

In an effort to dissolve the stigma and establish a unified sisterhood  
in Santa Fe and statewide, these activist sisters sought to join with the  
New Mexico Women’s Political Caucus during the planning session  
for the state convention scheduled to be held in Santa Fe. As so often  
happens, the situation came down to the issue of Lesbianism; in this  
case, simply the right to use the word and call oneself what one really  
is. The meeting of the by-laws committee was packed. Those who felt  
“Lesbian” is not a dirty word won out. The by-laws were rewritten,  
and many of the women who had opposed this change—some of  
whom were in a position to be politically helpful to Feminism—walked  
out of the meeting and withdrew from the caucus. Result? Same old  
story: a lingering atmosphere of debate and division within the  
Women's Movement. And in this case, giving up on the sisterhood.  
The activist women, feeling oppressed by their own sisters, have lean-  
ed heavily on Marxism and are seeking to merge with other oppressed  
groups in Santa Fe. They have abandoned the women’s magazine, and  
will instead begin publishing a general community newspaper, hoping  
to be joined by other oppressed people as the paper develops. Theirs  
has become a class struggle. Their predicament underlines a dilemma  
common to many women's efforts in the embryonic stage: until suf-  
ficient grassroots support can be established, women are forced to  
deal with the system on its own terms through coalition and com-  
promise.  

Factionalism Blurs Vision  

Is this the road the Women’s Movement is going down? Fac-  
tionalism, with the resulting blurring of vision and scattering of  
energies? Here are women who feel they are better off compromising  
their Feminism because they cannot come together with their sisters,  
and cannot, on the other hand, cease functioning. Channeling their  
women’s energies (these women alone created the new community  
newspaper) into a coalition with other oppressed groups, they can no  
longer look to their own oppression as their fundamental cause. And  
once again women’s position becomes secondary.  

What happens in this situation to a woman who wants to be active  
but not just in another splintered political group? As a woman named  
Columbine told me, “I want to live in Santa Fe. I want to work in the  
Women’s Movement. But I want to work with other women; not with  
men. And I can’t put out a paper alone. I feel torn.” She talked of an ap-  
proach other than political—another level deeper in. And we went to  
Albuquerque, to the Labe’ Collective.  

Labe’ Collective  

The Labe Collective had been formed by a group of ten Lesbian  
women, many of whom are craftswomen, activists, and spiritualists.  
They seem devoted to living together collectively and harmoniously,  
i.e. a musician, an artist, a silversmith, a creator of leather clothing, all  
living together in one house and apparently flourishing; to individual  
development—they have an awareness of the need for each woman to  
have time alone, to be in her own space; to stress individual as well as  
group activism; and to the channeling of energies not into changing  
the existing structure but into the development of a woman's culture.  

This development requires a fundamental spiritual base, not a  
political one. Although politics can get you what you want, politics can  
not tell you what you want. In order to know what you want you must  
know who you are. Knowing this is the basis for a women’s culture.  
Being it is the culture. You are it.  

In an atmosphere that is non-competitive, that is supportive of self-  
knowledge, self-ability, and personal development, in a living collec-  
tive composed entirely of women with a minimum of outside male in-  
fluence, craftswomen, writers, artists—all conscious women—come  
to discover those things which are basically, commonly woman and to  
express those characteristics through their creations. Here are the  
beginnings of a Feminist culture.  

Why within Labe? Because Labe is generative. Generative because  
being Lesbian, separation from male influence is much easier. And  
this separation may be necessary if any women’s culture is to be  
found. Generative because spiritualism (the looking inward to know  
the self) and closeness become elemental.  

The elemental, the spiritual may prove a better base for achieving  
Feminist goals than a political one. While political focus is external in  
nature, spiritualism looks inside and tells us what women are, who  
women are, who we ourselves are. It can unite us through the  
knowledge and understanding of what is basically woman, and can  
perhaps give us the rudiments of a matriarchal religion. Lesbians may  
be the ones who can lay down a framework, rather than the hand. (See  
letter p.9 from Labe Collective.)

**Interview**

**Mama Rag Vol. 2 No. 8**

**Dr. Wolf Analyzes Women's Roles**

**Linda Fowler**

Dr. Wolf is a nationally known sociologist, a feminist, and founder of the Denver chapter of the National Organization for Women (NOW). She is a professor at Colorado Women’s College (CWC) where she teaches a course on women in social situations. With the termination of the academic year, she will leave CWC to become head of the sociology department at Ohio Wesleyan University.

I interviewed Dr. Wolf in her office at CWC. We talked about the influence of various kinds of social structures on the development and behavior of women in the United States today, about the development of women within the family, and through groups of other women within the Women’s Movement.

**BMR:** Dr. Wolf, could you comment on the influences of the American family on the development of women?  
**Dr. Wolf:** A while ago I thought the nuclear family was the worst thing that could happen to women. It’s been an absolute disaster. And I thought perhaps communal living might be the answer. But then I did a study of three mountain communes, and almost without exception, women seemed to be carrying the load—doing all the work. And men are doing what I call the new role for men, the male drone role where they expect all the traditional privileges but none of the traditional responsibilities. The best of all possible worlds. So I don’t think that's the answer. What we're looking for is a real sharing of roles; a blurring of roles. And the term “unisex” doesn’t frighten me one bit.

I think we're going to go on having family units of some kind. What kind of unit would provide openness for every individual to develop? I think maybe in some ways a small family is better than a large one; mostly because of cross-cultural research which points out that when there are lots of male and female adults there is a division of labor, and it seems to go along sexual lines; there isn't a crossover.

**Raising Children Collectively**

**BMR:** What do you see as possibly developing for a family situation? Obviously, the commune isn't the answer. It’s pretty evident to me that in most communal situations there are certain surface differences that are quite different from the society at large, but when you come down to the basic interpersonal relationships they are exactly the same as they have been; so that doesn’t answer the question. What do you think about the collective as a system of child-rearing and family integration where several families might live together or in the same area? The raising of children is done collectively by the entire group.  
**Wolf:** I think so far it’s one of the best ways, and certainly for children. Children cease to be the responsibility of some poor woman basically and of the couple basically, and should and do sometimes become the responsibility of the whole collective. I think, probably, the best places I've seen for women, even though they haven't lasted very long, are those that have been in cities and people all work outside the home. They are families living together in a big house or on a farm and go into town to work—like in Boulder on the Nelson Road place. There you have a lot of problems, but I think maybe it’s more conducive to the development of women.

**BMR:** Do you think there is a significant difference between women who are functioning in marriage and women who are functioning more or less alone? Do you think there are any differences in the pressures that are felt in their ability to develop as individuals?  
**Wolf:** I think it’s probably easier to develop if you're living alone and you can choose friends without pressure. I think we should have great compassion for the housewife. Financially and emotionally there is a great amount of pressure for her to stay where she is and not change; and those who do manage to isolate themselves from this situation need support. The Women's Movement is providing this support in all kinds of unlikely places that a few years ago seemed hard to get to. We who have some awareness can't simply step away from all this—we've got to help one another—we need each other—we need the grassroots—we've got to help other women.

**Middle Class—Working Class**

**BMR:** It seems to me that it’s often very difficult to get this kind of awareness from the middle-class woman about what her own personal and social situation really is, because she has privilege to make her feel she has freedom and they are not the same thing at all. Working and lower-class women, on the other hand, rarely have the same kind of privilege. Their oppression is much more overt and they can see it more clearly.  
**Wolf:** They see economic oppression more clearly; they do not see interpersonal oppression as clearly and this has always been the case. We have to face some kinds of real things that occur in terms of communication. Communication goes from the top down—how the image of upper and middle-class women is emulated by working-class women. If you can get people to realize that, that’s an important first step.

**BMR:** Are you talking about taking steps to reach women in middle and upper-class communities as a means of influencing those women who are in lower socio-economic groups?  
**Wolf:** I think these steps have already been taken—in television, certainly a lot in magazines. A few years ago women who were in the Women’s Liberation Movement were funny; humor in a kind of scaffolding fashion (you laugh and then you destroy). It’s not happening too much now. This has made it acceptable for poor women who depend on a job and have been afraid to have Women’s Liberation attached to their name. Afraid to be other than, quote, feminine. You've got to get support from other women.

**BMR:** What things do you think begin to happen when women come together in groups within the Women's Movement? We talked about women functioning alone and also within the family. But then you go on to women functioning in groups of women. There seem to be changes that occur when this happens.  
**Wolf:** I think probably one of the great things about the Women’s Movement is that we have come to desire and like our own company, and we didn't used to. To go out with women was considered the worst kind of thing to do. You know, “Can't you do better than that?” Part of the whole horrible picture of hating ourselves, hating one another and judging everything in terms of the dominant class ideology—male. I don't think this happens so much anymore. I think women who are involved in the movement really enjoy the company of other women and really like women as individuals. This great sense of solidarity has come through the movement.

**Radicals in the Movement**

**BMR:** Do you feel that radicalism within the women’s movement has value?  
**Wolf:** It frightens some women; for some it is absolutely terrifying. If you say anything in terms of the family structure it scares them.  
**BMR:** Nothing is going to change, really, in the society until the family itself changes. This is the keystone.  
**Wolf:** This is why I felt reluctant in terms of what the future might bring even if you have a communal situation or if you have families living together; the kernel of the family is the same thing. Nothing changes. It’s like a raisin pie in which the raisins are in a certain relationship to each other: you can transport the pie all over the place but nothing changes internally.  
**BMR:** There is a surfacing now of radical Lesbians in the Women's Movement. What sort of effect do you think this is having on the movement and on societal structure generally?  
**Wolf:** I think Lesbian women are a very valuable part of the Women’s Liberation Movement. I think we have to include all women in the liberation movement. Probably when I came face to face with it, was when I, as a member of NOW, was called a Lesbian. At first I said, “Oh no. No, no.” And then you think, “Goddamit, what are you trying to beat me with?” I don’t think we should let this be a club.  
**BMR:** This is one of the most potent things to hit women with because this is something that definitely steps outside of the male-oriented culture and therefore is quite a threat to the patriarchy. Thereby it is a threat to women who are still very much identified with the patriarchy. The lifestyles that are developing within the Lesbian community are certainly radically different from the nuclear family unit that holds the whole society together. And this may be something of a key to what is needed to change the society as a whole. There is an absence of dominance-subordinance patterns and sometimes collective child-rearing in collective households. Do you think this might begin to really change things?  
**Wolf:** I think that’s fine if it does. I don't think it’s happening with great enough frequency to have any effect at all. What worries me is that there will be a kind of repressiveness. Economic situations, political situations have not been very conducive to an openness. There is a fear, as with the sexual preference bill in Boulder, and if there is enough momentum here I think it will have an effect of beating people back into closets, back into kitchens. And these hard-fought gains of all of us in terms of making life a little more decent for all kinds of people—I mean how many gains can we hold on to?

**New Directions**

**BMR:** If Lesbianism is discussed...**

**More on Page 10**

**Gays Meet Vice Chief**

At a recent meeting with Captain Jerry Kennedy, Denver Vice Bureau chief, Gay Coalition representatives discussed harassment of gays by vice squad officers in gay bars. Marge Johnson, coalition member, said that on various occasions vice squad officers had told women in The Three Sisters Bar, “We just came to look at all the pretty little dykes,” and “Don’t get uptight, girls—we just came to watch.” She also told Kennedy that vice officers have tried to solicit dates from female customers in the bar. “This is unprofessional conduct,” she said, and pointed out that Lesbians believe vice squad officers go there to provoke trouble.

Kennedy replied that to his knowledge no vice squad officer had recorded in the bureau log having been at The Three Sisters. He suggested that the bar managers keep a log of vice officer visits to the bar and that women record the name, physical description, and officer’s badge number and file a complaint with Kennedy if they feel they've been harassed.

Sometimes vice officers work undercover and, therefore, are not obligated to provide identification when requested to, according to Kennedy. He pointed out, however, that customers could get license plate numbers and turn them in to him.

He said he instructs vice bureau officers to “enforce the law and keep your opinions to yourselves.”

**Rape is a Vice**

Ms. Johnson also asked Kennedy whether the vice bureau is involved in surveillance of gay groups in Denver and in investigation of rape cases. He replied “no” to both questions. Ms. Johnson said she considers rape to be a vice.

Coalition members said they wanted to hold “education sessions” with vice officers and to get a liaison officer between the vice bureau and the gay community. Kennedy agreed to these requests. Gerald Gerash of the Gay Coalition pointed out to Kennedy that being gay is not the problem, per se—homophobia (fear of homosexuality) is the problem that needs to be dealt with.

Coalition representatives also recommended to Kennedy that there be gay representation on the vice bureau. Kennedy responded, “Do you have anyone to suggest?” Coalition people said not at the moment, but that they would communicate Kennedy's interest to the gay community. Any gay person who is interested in working on the vice squad is asked to contact Cordell Boyce at the Coalition office, 831-8838.
