Games We
Still Delay

Anne Zeigler

The new wave of Feminism, the sisterhood we have generated
over the past few years, and the embryo accomplishments of our
new consciousness have given women a glimpse of the heights and
breadths we can reach as women. And yet, simultaneously with
our growth as Feminists, we have developed a new repertoire of
games (some of them insidiously incorporating Feminist analyses)

as a new rationale for passivity.
I have found many ac-
complices in my own self decep-
tion, and have substantially aid-
ed other women to deceive
themselves. Some of the games
we play are new disguises for old
ploys—others are developed as
we are increasingly exposed to
new and threatening situations
and need some way to hide from
ourselves and whomever we are
trying to manipulate into loving
us. As we allow ourselves to
continue to play these games,
we remain bound to the tread-
mill of non-success which has
been trapping us for centuries.
“Dancing Dog”

I call the first game “Dancing
Dog,” after an often-quoted in-
sult of Ben Johnson: “A learned
woman is like a dancing dog: one
wonders not that it is done well,
but that it is done at all.” The
woman who plays dancing dog
tends to be astonished that she
actualizes anything at all, and to
expect others to praise her for
doing much less than she really
can. This is a good way to avoid
criticism, as a dancing dog can
hardly be criticized for not being
Rudolph Nureyev.

Dancing Dog is also a very
effective way to avoid the con-
flict of not wanting to fail, but of
being afraid of success, a dilem-
ma in which many women often
find themselves. Sisters who
reinforce a player of dancing
dog, refusing her the dignity of a
loving but honest appraisal of
her work, may do so for many
reasons. I think these reasons
are mainly rooted in the issues of
identity and competition. Rather
simply put, if we are male-
identified to some extent, a
woman who does well becomes
a competitor for approval and
attention. If we are struggling to
become woman-identified, we
have to face the scary situation
of knowing that we, too, can
succeed, and deal with all the
fears that success evokes.

Another dynamic that main-
tains the game of Dancing Dog is
our ineptness in handling feed-
back. Rather than accepting
feedback as an opportunity for
growth, we often see it as a
critical undermining of our
achievements, and even more
intensely, as an undermining of
ourselves. And rather than giv-
ing feedback in a loving, tactful,
sharing way, we tend to feel
critical out of our own sense of
competition or inadequacy, and
to avoid anything like criticism,
lest it reveal our anger or fear or
insecurity. We are not so fragile
that we should be afraid of
breaking or destroying each
other by assuring each other of
our potential for growth.

“There, there, dear, you just
cry all you want to.” All the nur-
turing and caring that we have
developed are used in this game
to smother us. Nurturing should
make us stronger in the face of
obstacles, should generate
energy, should encourage us
with the knowledge that we are
loved and unconditionally
worthy of love.

“There, there” is a game in
which support becomes
crutches, and stumbles and falls
evoke attention and sympathy
for their own sakes. We need to

learn to express our concern, but

we need to help each other to
realistically analyze and con-
front setbacks, fears, con-
ditioning, rather than to wallow
in them. We need to help each
other to develop discipline and
staying power, to gain a sense of
perspective towards obstacles.
Girls Give Up

Experiments with children un-
der two years of age have shown
that little boys, when confronted
with a barrier between
themselves and their mothers,
will try to cross the obstacle or
find a way around it, with some
persistence. But small girls, if
they try at all, give up soon and
cry to be rescued. The habit of
giving up was ingrained in us
very early, and we need to
recognize it and gain a sense of
faith in our power over our en-
vironment, rather than to admire
ourselves and others for the
number and difficulty of the
adverse circumstances we find
and create for ourselves. We all
need help and love, but we must
learn to ask for and give help and
love, rather than to ask for rein-
forcement for pain and failure.

Dilettante: this is another
favorite game, which seems to
spring from several sources. The
first is that it's okay for a woman
to be bright...but not too bright;
competent...but not too compe-
tent. So when we find ourselves
getting competent, we switch to
another area of interest where
we are less accomplished. This
way, we don’t violate any
achievement taboos, but still can
find challenge and opportunity
for growth.

A dilettante is spared the
frightening responsibility of tak-
ing herself or her work seriously,
of avoiding the risks involved in
commitment to one discipline,
and some dilettantism also
seems to be a remnant of the
way we prepared ourselves to be
ready to help our man in his
work—whatever it turned out to
be; to be sufficiently informed to
be stimulating companions, but
not so much as to be
competitive. A smattering of
everything makes us more
marketable, adaptable to more
men’s lifestyles.

Begun to Explore

Another, and more positive,
source of dilettantism is the fact
that we have begun to explore
the world around us with a new
attitude, that it is full of exciting
things in which we were
previously forbidden (by custom
and isolation, as well as by law)
to participate.

But as we establish our new
identities as actors rather than
as bystanders and helpers, we
are going to have to learn the
habits and attitudes of commit-
ment and serious participation,
rather than those of helpful
amateurs and accessories.

Us-Them: one of the most bla-
tant manifestations of our in-
security is our tenden-
cy—still—to find strength and
identity in elitism. “We older
Feminists” do not have any
monopoly on the right ideas or
any superiority as women, just
because we have been aware of
our oppression for a few years
longer, or know the rhetoric a lit-

“Great Art” proves that men are
superior to women, that men are
women, being labeled “Great
Art,” almost all of which, as the
anti-feminists are fond of
reminding us, was created by
men. We know that “Great Art”
is great because male authorities
have told us so, and we can’t
claim otherwise, as only those
with exquisite sensitivities far
superior to ours can perceive
and appreciate the greatness, the
proof of their superior
sensitivity being that they
appreciate the slop that they
appreciate. — Valerie Solanas,
Scum Manifesto.

little better than other women

We are all just beginning to
ask the right questions, let alone
struggle through to the answers
that will liberate us. There are
many people with whom we may
disagree; there are many times
when we know that sharing past
experiences could provide some
guidance to other women who
are in the midst of similar ex-
periences now. But to deny
another woman's feelings or ex-
perience, or to subject her to
ridicule because she has not
learned the same lessons in the
same way will only reinforce all
that traditional conditioning to
which she has been sub-
jected—it will not strengthen
either of us or help to unite us.
There is no us-them; there are
different perspectives and
knowledge and strengths and
experiences. To push someone
over into a “Them” position
limits her, implies that she is not
capable of growing and
changing—limits us in our small
progress—and exemplifies the
caste system in its most efficient
operation.

There is more than one way to
be a Feminist, or even a Radical
Feminist; there are important
issues and trivial ones; there are
concessions we all make to sur-
vival and comfort. To make each
other feel guilty or less woman-
ly; to perceive ourselves in the
role of exemplar of
Feminism—or even more
destructively, as inadequate at
Feminism—will drain energy
that should be used for creative
and constructive solutions to our
differences and difficulties.

The games I have discussed
here are ones which I play all the
time, and help others to play.
They are especially prevalent
among white Feminists with
middle-class origins. To deny
our origins is to deny our roots;
but recognition of the sources of
fear and games will strengthen
us. We owe it to each other to
stop playing and start challenging
each other to grow.

Rebels or Collaborators
Raps Florynce Kennedy

Carolyn Agosta

Once more Denver received
an earful in the form of Florynce
Kennedy, radical, Black,
Feminist lawyer. Her “rap”
began with four songs, three of
which are take-offs from the
originals, “Richard, the Red-
Necked Reindeer,” “Abortion
Rap,” “Striped Christmas,” and
“God Rest Ye Merry
Gentlemen.” Since she was
speaking at the University of
Colorado Medical Center, her
talk centered around the

medical profession. She stated
that the health community has
been neutral in the past...but
that now, no one can be
neutral...we are either rebels or
collaborators.

“Women are still studying
nursing and if there ever was a
group of ‘niggerized,
niggerizers,’ it's the nurses.”
Niggerization is a divide and con-
quer technique, a sort of DandC
Strategy, and is a part of the mid-
dle class. But according to her
claim, there is no real middle
class, since 90% of the country is
poor and the other 10% is rich.
This was demonstrated during
the tornadoes. People who had
been labeled “middle class” lost
their mortgaged homes, cars;
people who had thought that
they were ‘above’ welfare,
suddenly were forced to turn to it
for help. This “instant niggeriza-
tion” brought on many symptoms,
like paranoia, that are
associated with poor people.

M.D. Fetus-fetish

Ms. Kennedy talked about the
nursing profession and the
whole medical profession as not
being ‘absolutely dedicated,’
that politics plays a large role in
them. Gynecological

departments are heavily
dominated by Catholic men,
fetus-fetish M.D.s, who take the

Breakdown Elitism

and now includes students and
clerical personnel, which has
very much enriched it. "The
hierarchical professional elitism
is breaking down.”

To close, here is a quote from
Flo Kennedy, call it a thought for
every day: “Anyone who is close
enough to hurt us has some
weak point that we can shoot
at.”

one of the founders of the

Organization, co-author of the
book Abortion Rap, and
author of Pathology of Oppression.

Anne Zeigler, Carol Lease

ROCKY MOUNTAIN
WOMEN IN THE ARTS
(RMWA) is a newly-formed,
non-profit group for all area
women interested in com-
munication with other women
artists, in showing and selling
their work, and in establishing
a Center where their efforts
can be centralized and
recognized.

Women working in any art
form are welcome, as are
women who wish to support
the artists’ goals. Specific
group goals range from
consciousness-raising to sales,
in an ultimate effort to en-
courage excellence in women’s
art, RMWA’s most ambitious
hope is to establish a Women’s
Arts Center in Denver where
women can show regularly,
meet and exchange ideas and
experiences, and share ser-
vices and facilities.

Women interested in Rocky
Mountain Women in the Arts
can come to meetings held
every Tuesday evening at 8:00
at 1895 Lafayette Street, or
contact Jan at 388-6590.

Soup’s On Exhibit

The serenity and excellence
of RMWA’s first show at
Soup's On, a downtown
Denver restaurant, belie the
frustration, betrayal, and
struggle that went into setting
it up, and are a tribute to the
resilience and persistence of
the women involved.

According to the two RMWA
members with whom we
spoke, the story goes
something like this:

The group had been discuss-
ing putting on a show or
creating alternatives to
showings when their meeting
was interrupted by a telephone
call from a would-be Sir
Lancelot named Richard Vin-
cent. Vincent offered, as a
political and artistic statement,
to organize a show for RMWA
at Soup's On. He extravagantly
promised to provide free
publicity, lots of wine, and
comprehensive mailing lists.
He offered to make all
arrangements with Soup's On
and with the Friends of the
Denver Symphony, for whom
the show was to be a benefit.

Although some women in
the group were instinctively
turned off by the man, their in-
experience, disorganization,
and lack of confidence made
the idea seem like “an answer
to our prayers.” So the group
made a decision to work with
Vincent.

Sir Lancelot Foiled Again

At this point the deception
began. Vincent changed the
date of the showing without in-
forming anyone, hired an auc-
tioneer that he said had had
considerable experience, but
who in fact had had none at all,
and had invitations printed that
did not even mention the art
show, thus forcing the women
to redo them. Despite such ob-
vious deviations from the truth,
Vincent's air of
professionalism, in demanding
deadlines, in seeming to know
so much, was still convincing
to the RMWA women; and it
wasn’t until almost show time
that the women realized how
thoroughly they had been con-
ned.

Despite all the frustration in
putting the show together, and
despite Vincent's “help,”
despite the fact that few, if any,
of the “Friends of the Denver
Symphony” showed up, and
despite the refusal of the
owners of the show to exhibit
two works by Fran Gottlieb
which they called “obscene,”
the show was a financial and
emotional success. Rocky
Mountain Women in the Arts
has made and is making money
from the show.

RMWA Grows

Rather than being destroyed
by their betrayal by Vincent,
the RMWA women have been
strengthened. “We learned not
to depend on others to do our
work for us. We learned to talk
about our mistakes. We see
that our group was essentially
used by a man trying to make
a name for himself."

This summer RMWA will
participate in the Street
Festival in Denver (the date of
which has not been set). It is
organizing shows and doing
some consciousness-raising.
The RMWA women are all con-
cerned with being women ar-
tists, and there is great diversi-
ty among group members as to
whether “women” receives
the emphasis or “artists.” They
welcome all women.

“Ladies of Mexico” by Carole Katchen

Judy Chicago says women’s art comes from an inner sanctum, and
this makes women’s art intrinsically different from men’s. She has
observed four patterns in women’s art. Maryse Holder in Off Our
Backs, “...repeating forms (cylinders for instance); circular forms
(deriving from the breast perhaps); organic forms (she calls these
“biomorphic”). Examples would be plants, genitalia, gardens. ...Cen-
tral aperture, the representation of an opening in the center of a pain-
ting. These openings could appear as hearts of flowers (O'Keeffe), or
as tunnels or portals leading to a mysterious infinity beyond.”

Organic Imagery

However, organic imagery is not limited to women. I think the early
Egyptian, Byzantine, and African art to be very biomorphic and organic
in form. They possessed those same smooth curving planes as the
Surrealists later developed. Arp, Dali, Ernst, Miro, Fini, Moore, Oelze,
Oppenheim, Tanguy, and Toyen all expressed themselves with
dynamic organic and biomorphic forms, whether in painting or in
sculpture. Surrealism is these forms—not from the exterior realistic
world; but from the interior, the unconscious and the imagination.
“Expressing inner perceptions visually,” as Andre Breton put it.

Organic and biomorphic imagery have been around since the
earliest artists, and have been created successfully by men and
women. Women have also created concrete and realistic imagery and
forms. Cindy Nemser and Irene Moss from The Feminist Art Journal
express their viewpoints:

Other critics, such as Linda Nochlin and myself, are unable to pick
out any all-prevailing traits in either painting or sculpture that will im-
mediately proclaim it to be the art of a woman. This is hardly strange,
as psychologists and biologists have been unable to discover any
definitive relationship between female hormones and female ar-
tifacts. Moreover, since the two sexes have jointly built and par-
ticipated in similar cultures, it seems rather unlikely that the art of each
sex should be highly distinctive from that of each other. At this time,
however, our total culture is in a stage of transition and evolution. A
new woman is emerging, a woman who is often setting herself apart
from man, or at least is in opposition to him in order to sound forth her
own individual voice. Why not wait, hold back, and examine each in-
dividual sound for its own rhythm, beauty, and harmony as it appears
or has appeared in the recent past? Why work in the old way to create
an amorphous category and dump all females into it? All women are
not alike.” —Cindy Nemser.

Women artists should be able to paint “tender” paintings if that is
what they want to do or “bold” ones if they are so inclined, or “circles”
but, in any case, only because that is what they want to do and not
because they have a hang-up about their wombs.” —Irene Moss

Art history has relegated women to either the “decorative arts and
crafts,” or to the back pages behind men. The art world is run
predominantly by men, for male collectors and buyers, and for male
critics and jurors. Many women, art separatists as well as those who
believe art is art (men and women have equal talent but are not equal
in the art world) have found the need for an alternative system. Art
collectives and women’s galleries have shot up throughout the coun-
try, Denver notwithstanding.

Review

The Rocky Mountain Women’s
Art Show, May 1-25 at Soup’s
On restaurant in downtown
Denver was the first attempt of
area women collectively making
an effort to show and sell their
work. They couldn't have chosen
a better place for ex-
posure...downtown, crowds at
lunch time, and an almost
gallery effect from the interior
design of the restaurant. For a
first timer it was good. A lot of
women were represented and
quite a few sold; there were also
a good number of methods and
media shown—plastic arts,
prints, photographs, sculpture,
pottery, and fibers. However, the
overall quality of the work left a
lot to be desired. Sloppy techni-
que and poor realization of the
subject matter predominated.
Barbara Baer and Carol Katchen
offered the best in my eyes.

Carol Katchen had a series of
black and white prints. She uses
smooth, clean and strong lines,
expressing movement vividly.
“Fire,” a woman bent over
backwards on her legs and hips,
emanates grace and passion and
lots of energy. Barbara Baer had
two sculptures, “Chain Gang”
and “Anthro-Lectric.” “Chain
Gang” is a simple sculpture
made from plexiglass and small
link chains. The coloring and the
simple forms produced provide a
compelling design which is high
in originality. Her other piece ex-
hibited was an organic, breasty-
looking light structure. The form
is great; all I can say is it’s
beautiful and very refreshing to
see good modern sculpture
small and concise.

I am glad the show was put on
and hope there will be others, for
each of us has to work, develop
and grow with our art.

The Twenty-Second Annual
Metropolitan Show at the
Denver Art Museum came in
with over one-third of its works
produced by women. The best,
without any doubt in my mind,
was “Rocking Chair” by Marilyn
Martin. It’s a plexiglass rocking
chair with solid smooth planes;
the seat is a clear box half-filled
with different colored pebbles
and water. It reminds me of a
mountain pool, so cool and
smooth, while I rock in the chair,
daydreaming of putting my hand
in the slightly greenish water.

Kay Koch-Brown had a good
entry. Her technique is good, her
colors defined but subtle; yet her
subject matter leaves a lot to be
desired. I am not too partial to
mid-western regionalism,
though if you have nostalgia for
tractors in Kansas you would
hang it in your living room and
dream on.

“The Go Game” by Susan
Walp was recommended for a
one-person show. I was greatly
surprised; it was one of the
worst things in the show. It was
poor technically, unsanded sur-
face with lots of air holes, poor
brush stroking and muddy color-
ing. The subject matter was bor-
ing, not even inspiring your im-
agination to wander.

Other outstanding con-
tributions were made by Alice
Abrams, “Flame ring hanging,”
a beautifully simple sculptured
ring; Becky Clune, “Myth,” an
attractively designed neckpiece
made from silver, brass, amber,
garnets, and bone; “Bread Box
—B.L.T.” Peg Goldberg evoked
the pop art imagery of the sixties.
A larger than life B.L.T. staring at
you in the face brings back the
smells of the “round the corner.”

MARTIN/LYON

Metivists, Authors, Lesbian

Phyllis Lyon and Del Martin are probably the first two women you
ever hear about in terms of national exposure about being Lesbians.
In 1955 they started one of the first organizations in the country for
Lesbians and they have been active ever since, first with the Civil
Rights Movement, then with Gay Liberation, and now they are work
ing primarily within the Women's Movement. Sometimes referred to

affectionately as the “Mothers of Lesbian Liberation,”
they recently published a book called Lesbian/Woman, 
which has been a proud act
in Denver on April 5 to do as
the University of Denver Center and it was
Big Mama Rag (by Janet Sergi) and 
others who “picked their brains”

about being both

Lesbians and Mothers.

For information on the Women’s Movement,
we sought out Del and Phyllis, two of the first
engagements at Colorado University
to see that several women from

the Daughters of Bilitis, the recently-formed San Francisco
Lesbian Mothers Union and anything else we could think of.

Although they graciously gave us a two-hour interview and supplied
us with a wealth of information, we were only able to reprint a portion of
that interview here. The following are excerpts.

Choc: Do you see the Women's
Movement as just a civil rights
movement, or do you see it as a
lot more than that?

Phyllis: I think it’s both. The
Women’s Movement is running
on a lot of different levels so you
have women doing things from a
lot of different levels of con-
sciousness. NOW has primarily
aimed at civil rights, but there’s a
lot of awareness among NOW
women that they also need to
deal in terms of what's going to
happen in the future — what
kind of society do we want — and
what in the hell are we talking
about when we talk about
revolution.

Del: What kind of a society do we
want to live in? We may think in
terms of what could happen in
the next 5 or 10 years, but we
have to go way beyond that. We
think it is very necessary for
there to be some women’s think
tanks where different women
from various groups really get
together and start thinking about
the future and what is it we want
in this society. So we would like
to see Feminists rally all over the
country doing this sort of thing.
And then maybe getting
together later to see what all
we've come up with, you know,
sort of brainstorming.

Phyllis: There are a lot of women
who have decided maybe
socialism or Marxism or
whatever “ism” is the answer,
but it doesn't necessarily seem
to me in view of what we've seen
of socialist societies that that’s
really the answer for women and
gay people anyhow. I have not
seen any societies evolving
around the world that I would be
comfortable living in in terms of
being a woman and being a gay
person.

Del: Not only that. At least in this
society we know who the enemy
is, we know what we're dealing
with. Some of these other con-
cepts — like a socialist govern-
ment — would just change the
name of my oppressor and I
wouldn't have the advantage of
at least knowing the structure
and knowing the society I'm
dealing with. You talk about
revolution — you turn things up-
side down — but the way I see it
now, certainly gay people would
still be oppressed.

Phyllis: You don’t want to turn it
around so that we still end up on
the bottom.

Choc: Do you think that all
women are, or should be,
Lesbians, in order for a real
women’s revolution to take
place?

Del: Speaking personally, I'm
certainly not a Separatist. I don’t
see how you can do away with
half the population of the world. I
also wouldn’t want to live in just
a gay society. I'm really in-
terested in all human beings. I
think there needs to be a lot of
consciousness-raising...a lot of
changes in society. Every in-
stitution needs to be turned up-
side down. Some women who
want to separate out — who
don't even want to have their boy
children — this is counter-
revolutionary. I think I’m too
much of a humanist to buy all
that.

Phyllis: Yeah, I'd agree with that.
As far as all women being
Lesbians, I think certainly all
women have that potential. Or
even more broadly, all people
really have the capacity to relate
to both sexes — on a sexual
basis. A lot of switching is
happening within the Feminist
movement. A lot of women are
becoming aware of either their
own inherent Lesbianism that
they weren't aware of, or were
afraid to face. Or simply that it’s
a lot easier to deal with women
nowadays than it is to deal with
men. I've never quite been able
to understand why everybody

freaks out — all the heterosex-
uals seem to think somehow or
other that if we loosen up the
laws on homosexuality,
everybody is going to turn gay.
I've really always had a little
more faith in heterosexuality
than that — than they seem to
have.

Janet: What do you think about
the concept of a woman's
culture? The Women’s Move-
ment is not just a civil rights
movement and it’s not exactly a
humanist movement. At this
time in history, we have to focus
on women and the concept of a
woman’s culture with woman's
art philosophy, critiques of the
male-dominated culture. What
are your views on that aspect of
Feminism?

Phyllis: I think it’s really exciting
— the kinds of things that are
happening. I think that a
woman's culture is not
necessarily being developed —
it's being dredged up out of
where it’s been. It isn’t as if we
haven't ever had a women’s
culture — it’s been suppressed,
repressed, never discussed,
nobody knew about it. Now it’s
being pulled together so that
more and more women are
becoming aware of the
capacities of women to create.
Marge: I understand you are the
co-founders of the Lesbian
Mothers Union, or helped to
found it. What is this organiza-
tion, what is it all about?

Del: The Lesbian Mothers Union
grew out of the Gay Women's
West Coast Conference in 1971.
At this point I threw out the idea
that there were Lesbian mothers
and that their issues were not
being dealt with either in the gay
movement or in the Women’s
Movement. All of a sudden we
had a bunch of women deman-
ding a workshop and also
questioning why we didn’t have
child care there. Nobody ever
thought in terms of having child
care at a Lesbian conference
because of literature that’s been
handed down by the
professionals who talk about
sexual behavior rather than the
whole person — who might be a
gay person even though there
are lots of women who are ac-
ting out heterosexual roles.
We've been following all the
different custody cases and
helping and supporting women
who have custody cases going.
Then we also have rap sessions
where women can discuss some
of the problems they have with
their children, with their
neighbors, within the family —
how do you tell your kids? Are
you open in front of the kids?...
They also have socials where
they get their families together
because they think it is impor-
tant for the children to have
peers who are in the same
situations...
Marge: You said earlier you con-
sider Lesbianism to be the
backbone of the Women’s Move-
ment. Why do you think that?

Phyllis: There’s just so many of
us in it and we all seem to be do-
ing a lot of work. And we don’t
have to ask our husbands if it’s
all right for us to go to the NOW
meeting or whatever meeting.
We're free to get involved. DOB
(Daughters of Bilitis — the first
Lesbian organization in the U.S.
—Ed.) was essentially a
women's rights organization
from the beginning. It didn’t real-
ly quite know that’s what it was,
but a lot of the things DOB was
saying in the late 50’s and 60's
are the same kinds of things that
the Women’s Movement is say-
ing now. Since Del got on the
national board of NOW, we dis-
covered there are all these gay
sisters who are presidents of
NOW chapters and who are very
involved on this level or that
level. And more and more all the
time are coming out and being
open about it. There's just really
no question that a lot of the work
and a lot of the creativity and a
lot of the blood, sweat and tears
in the Women’s Movement has
come from gay women, mostly
gay women in the closet until
fairly recently.

Phyllis Lyon

Choc: You've been working with
Lesbians for a number of years. I
wonder if you could tell us of
some of the changes you've
seen. How would you compare,
say, working with Lesbians in
1974 to working with Lesbians
when you first started
Daughters of Bilitis?

Del: In the first place, it's Bilitis
(Bilitis)... a

Choc: I never did know how to
pronounce that.

Del: Bilitis makes it sound like
tonsillitis and a disease, and
we're trying to get away from
the disease concept. There's just
been tremendous changes.
When we first came out so to
speak, everybody was into the
whole butch-femme trip. You
found that that was the way you
had to act in order to be accepted
by your peers, and of course,
everybody's looking for a support
group, so we got into the role-
playing in the beginning. Except
I had a problem playing the butch
role — I was a pretty sissy butch.
I remember there were eight of
us who'd started DOB — four
couples, and there was one
other couple that the butch
didn’t seem so butchy either so
she and I became buddies. We
began to get into more discus-
sion and we decided we should
be developing our own ways of
relating instead of imitating the
only relationships we'd had as a
model — the heterosexual one.
We would have to really start to
think in terms of how best we
could work out our own
relationships and not do this im-
itation thing. As we delved into
that we began to realize then the
whole thing about sex roles —
what are called masculine and
feminine are indeed human
traits and that we all have these
varying traits to varying degrees
and that what society had been
handing down was really a
cultural thing because in other
cultures the role could be reversed.

Marge: I'd like to play the devil's
advocate for a few minutes
because in doing panels, es-
pecially in high schools, one of
the most sensitive areas is that
of gay parents and the children
in that situation.

Phyllis: That is a problem. Any
child growing up in any kind of
“deviant” family, whether it’s
hippy, divorced, poor, rich, if
they're different than their peer
group, they're going to have
some kind of trouble with their
peers. I almost died the first time
I had to go to school wearing
glasses. Everybody knew boys
never make passes at girls who
wear glasses. In those days that
was the feeling. So you cannot
protect kids from what's gonna
happen in the outside world. But
that's not a reason not to be open
and honest with your kids. You
can't raise your kids and never
tell them you're a Lesbian
they'll have all these strange
feelings about what's going on
with their mother and who are
these strange women that come
in and you never see any kind of
affection, they never know about
love between adults. That seems
to me to be a lot worse than
somebody yelling on the
playground, ‘Yeah, yeah, yeah
your mother’s a Lesbian,” or
something like that. If you give
the child the support within the
home so that the child un-
derstands the whole situation
and understands why the kids
are going to yell that, it's not a
pleasant thing for them, but they
can certainly deal with the other
kids, deal with a hell of a lot. And
I think they can deal with that kind
of thing a lot better than with
growing up in an anti-affection
home or in a home where they
always know there’s something
there that they can’t quite put
their finger on. And where the
mother’s miserable. It's like kids
that grow up in families where
the parents stay together for the
sake of the children, the kids
always know there's something
wrong. Kids are very perceptive.
Marge: You mentioned that in
addition to your book
Lesbian/Woman that you have
two other publications?

Phyllis: We've done a little
booklet through the National Sex
Forum called Lesbian Love and
Liberation, which is illustrated
with photographs of gay women.
And we're also working on a
book called Lesbian/Mother,
but we haven't started writing it
yet.

comment and health  
‘Rooming-in’~ Outdated?

This is a column for men and  
children as well as for women.  
This is a column about the first  
hours and days of child care.  
Since the woman is central  
physiologically in the childbirth  
process, we must reclaim our  
rights from the hospital and the  
doctor. This means knowing  
what is available today in the  
hospital, knowing what we want  
and why we want it. This means  
having the facts that give us the  
courage to stand against male  
mate and male doctor if their  
opinions are different than ours.  
(The subject here is limited to  
hospital deliveries though some  
of the ideas may relate to home  
delivery as well.)

“Rooming-in” refers to the  
newborn child’s remaining with  
the mother in her room almost  
immediately after birth through  
discharge from the hospital. This  
was the usual arrangement in all  
U.S. hospitals until the turn of  
the century, and there never has  
been nurseries for normal new-  
borns in most European  
hospitals. So why did the new-  
born nursery, with strictly  
limited parent-child interaction,  
become the norm in this coun-  
try? I have been able to find only  
suggestions, not definite  
answers.

Possible Answer

One possible answer is the  
worry over infection. It should be  
remembered that at this time  
most deliveries were still done at  
home. Women entering the  
hospital were often otherwise ill  
or had problem pregnancies. These  
women and their babies went to  
large open wards rather than to  
rooms of two to four women as is  
done today. Screening techni-  
ques for disease organisms  
were primitive or nonexistent, so  
an infected woman's bacteria or  
virus literally flew around the  
ward finding easy prey in the  
debilitated women and the new-  
borns. However, it has since  
been clearly shown that  
“rooming-in” is actually safer  
than nurseries with respect to  
infection.

At the turn of the century, a  
French doctor, Pierre Budin, was  
busy popularizing nurseries and  
incubators for premature in-  
fants. Budin sent a young stu-  
dent, Martin Cooney, to exhibit  
his methods at fairs in England  
and the United States. Cooney  
finally settled on Coney Island  
where, in 39 years, he raised  
over 5,000 premature infants.

Why the ideas for premature  
infants came to be applied to all  
infants may have to do with  
Cooney’s commercial success.  
For whatever reasons, nurseries  
soon became the rule in our  
hospitals. With this separation  
often went other rigid rules  
which discouraged breast  
feeding and depersonalized the  
childbirth process. Healthy  
women, eager to care for their  
new children, were treated as in-  
valids. Fathers were often  
treated as intruders.

Today there is a swing back to  
“rooming-in” and other more  
open procedures, but this swing  
has been slow getting started.  
The roots go all the way back to  
some problems recognized by  
Budin and Cooney, who ran into  
many trouble spots as well as  
benefits with their procedures.  
One big problem was getting  
mothers to accept their children  
after the long period of separa-  
tion caused by using nurseries.

Slow Start

Then in the late 1940s, Duke  
Hospital decided on an ex-  
perimental program of com-  
pulsory rooming-in. Interesting-  
ly, the rationale used was similar  
to that for instituting the nursery  
system in the first place—  
prevention of infection. The  
biggest obstacle wasn't con-  
vincing the mothers; it was the  
obstetricians and nurses who  
objected. Though prevention of  
infection was the motivation for  
the experiment, the primary  
rewards were psychological and  
educational.

Over twenty-five years later,  
“rooming-in” is still the excep-  
tion in U.S. hospitals, but  
evidence in its favor is piling up.  
Some of this research is review-  
ed in an outstanding article,  
which I recommend in its entire-  
ty to all of you. This is “Mothers  
separated from their newborn  
infants” by Marshall H. Klaus  
and John H. Kennell in Pediatric  
Clinics of North America, vol.  
17, no. 4, November, 1970.

Part II of this article, which dis-  
cusses specific ideas for  
women who are considering  
“rooming-in”, will be published  
next month. — Ed.

Note: Nothing has yet been  
decided about the legality and  
limits of midwifery in Colorado.  
We will report what is happen-  
ing as soon as anything does  
happen.

‘Girls,’ Start Cheering!

by Becky Bohannan

Athletics is a field which men have dominated ever since the  
Olympics of ancient Greece. But lately, with the Billie Jean King-  
Bobby Riggs exhibition and such heartthrobs as Olga Korbut, more  
and more people are taking an interest in women’s athletics. With  
this newly acquired enthusiasm, I investigated Cherry Creek High  
School's sports program. What I discovered simply reaffirmed my  
initial impression, that though the situation is not without hope,  
sexism abounds in the athletic department.

Cherry Creek offers thirteen  
varsity sports for boys, plus  
junior varsity, freshman, and  
sophomore teams. It offers the  
girls a grand total of five, which  
are gymnastics, swimming, ten-  
nis, track, and field hockey. The  
situation is improving. For the  
last ten to fifteen years (accor-  
ding to one coach) girls have  
been playing volleyball and  
basketball on the chance that  
these sports would become  
sanctioned by the Colorado High  
School Athletic Association.  
Now finally, both sports have  
been sanctioned for next year,  
which means they will be able to  
receive funds out of the activities  
budget and play in a regular  
league.

Pat Morgan is a member of the  
girls’ track team in which her  
events are discus and shot-put.  
She is also on the volleyball  
team. Pat has a number of com-  
plaints about the sports  
program. Speaking on the small  
amount of funds granted to girls’  
teams, she says, “Boys get this  
and boys get that and they  
always come first in equipment  
and privileges. No attention is  
given to the girls.” The coach of  
one of the girls’ teams says the  
same thing. She could not quote  
the figures exactly, but there is a  
large difference between the  
amount of funds the boys received  
compared to the amount girls  
sports receive. She also  
protested the fact that in the  
sport she coaches, she is ex-  
pected to coach her entire team  
herself while the boys’ team of  
the same sport has a coach and  
two assistant coaches. Each  
team has an equal amount of  
participants and events. “I’m try-  
ing to do an impossible job,” she  
says, “if I'm to come out with a  
winning team.”  
Tiny Articles

Girls’ sports are rarely  
publicized to any extent, a fact  
which especially bothers Pat.  
“There's almost never anything  
in the school paper about the  
girls’ sports except maybe some  
real tiny article. The girls’ swim  
team puts up their own signs. No  
one comes to watch the track  
team. Oh, at the district and  
state meets there will be a few  
people, but otherwise it’s zilch.  
Of course, we don't have a fan  
club following us around. In pep  
assemblies, you never hear  
about girls’ sports. The boys’  
football team has been in-  
troduced so many times you  
know every single guy. But the  
girls’ teams are never in-  
troduced. If they did, I don’t think  
the boys would take it.”  

In looking through the  
school’s annual for the last two  
years and back issues of its  
newspaper, it became evident  
that Pat had every right to com-  
plain. Cherry Creek's 1972 an-  
nual contained 22 pages  
devoted to sports. Four of these  
were about girls’ sports. The  
amount of space allotted to girls’  
sports actually declined in ‘73  
with only two pages representing  
two of the five sports. A  
number of issues of the paper  
didn't even mention any girls’  
sports. Others had one article or  
possibly two. None were in a  
prominent position on the page.  
Most of the articles just gave a  
straight news story.

One article with the title  
“Women’s Lib in Sports,” (from  
The Union St. Journal, Sept. 21,  
1973) stood out from the rest. Its  
introductory paragraph began,  
“In the age of male dominance,  
the female role in sports was sit-  
ting on the sidelines cheering on  
the varsity (all male) teams.  
Now, however, the girls are  
realizing how much exercise  
conditions their figures, keeping  
them slimmer, trimmer, and  
generally good looking...”  
“Can't Leave Out Girls’’

Another example of the con-  
descending attitude toward  
girls’ sports appeared in an arti-  
cle written by a coach. He spoke  
of the outlook for the spring  
sports program and mentioned  
all the boys’ teams and a number  
of male individuals. At one point  
he stated, “...and yes, we cannot  
leave out the girls’ program...,”  
which was the only mention of  
girls in the entire article. This  
statement seems to reflect the  
general opinion of the school.  
‘Let's not forget the girls’ but  
that’s exactly what people do.  
Forget the girls.

The major complaint of the  
two women interviewed is the  
way in which men react to them,  
especially men also involved in  
athletics. “What really upsets  
me,” said the coach, “is that too  
many of the student body and es-  
pecially the boys involved in  
athletics, cut down the girls who  
go out for sports.” Being an ob-  
ject of this contempt, Pat said, “I  
get the impression sometimes  
that we're really looked down  
on. Especially in my event 'cause  
most girls don’t go around lifting  
weights.” She then went on to  
say, “The most recognized girls’  
sport at Cherry Creek is Pom-  
Pom, Cheerleading. Wow! It's  
fine to be a cheerleader but is  
that all the girls can be? The boys  
have the idea of putting us in the  
category of cheerleaders so that  
we can idolize them with their  
great accomplishments, not to  
be equal but to stay below and  
idolize, well FORGET IT!"

Contemptuous Treatment

If Cherry Creek is any indica-  
tion of other high schools, girls’  
athletic programs are neglected  
by school administrations and  
actually treated with contempt  
among certain students. But the  
situation is changing slightly. In  
the last two years, two new  
sports have been added to the  
program and two more will be  
added next year. This could easi-  
ly be attributed to the Feminist  
movement, which has  
generated all the publicity and  
discussion of equal rights. The  
climate was right to expand the  
girls’ program. The contempt  
shown for girls in sports by  
athletic boys is probably their  
natural negative reaction to  
change that confronts their  
stereotypes of the role of women  
that we have all been indoctrinated with.

All Pat and others like her are  
asking for is a change. “Athletic  
girls just don’t have a fair chance  
to progress. None. Girls that  
want to compete should be able  
to. We have the same  
capabilities. We can compete  
against other women in the  
same events men compete in.  
But we're never given any  
recognition.” Well, the male  
athletic establishment had  
better beware, women athletes  
not only have the drive to com-  
pete, they also have the drive to  
prove themselves, and they will.

To our sisters in Denver,

A group of ten women here in Albuquerque have come together to form the Labe Collective. We are concerned primarily with the Lesbian community and have begun to try to create an alternative to the bar. We have already had various activities and will continue to do so until we have raised enough money to put a down payment on a building located centrally in the City.

One of the ideas that has been discussed is a Summer Solstice Celebration to be held on property located on the edge of the Santa Fe National Forest approximately 90 miles northwest of Albuquerque. Preparations are already being made; we want your help; we would like to have you join us in getting it together, i.e., planning and conducting workshops, etc. We think it will be fruitful to provide a variety of entertainment, booths, workshops and daycare, not systemized but structured enough so that it would be a creative learning experience, not just a tribal stomp run through a haze of alcohol and dope. We invite the women of Colorado to participate in any way they so desire through the above mentioned concepts.

We will be facing some problems and need many ideas to deal with them. Some of these problems are: cooking facilities, water facilities, sanitary facilities, daycare, information services. We would like to deal with these problems in the safest and most ecologically sound manner. We would like to provide a large main shelter in case of rain and a large communal cooking area. We feel the best way to deal with the sanitary question is to bury evacuation and deposit paper in a fire. We would like to set up an area and have personnel for daycare so that women with young children can enjoy the festival without the constant demands of their children.

Some of the activities we would like to provide are booths so that women with arts and crafts may have an opportunity to sell their wares, food booths for women with special interests in cooking, one-day workshops including Yoga, breathing, coming, sun-bathing, cloud watching, massage, mandala-making, silent hikes, Sufi dancing, an all-inclusive Essence of Women trip. Other workshops may include self-help, women and the law, occult studies, etc.

Any suggestions, help, participation, energy, love are welcome.

This festival will be free. The booths will cost approximately $2.00 a day to rent. We ask that sisters bring their own food, water and sleeping bags for 2 days of celebration.

In sisterhood,  
representing Labe,  

Kris  

620 Free(wo)man N.W.  
Albuquerque, N.M. 87107

Dear Big Mama Rag,

I’d like to share with Big Mama Rag readers my response to the NOW panel on Lesbianism and my changing perspective.

NOW was criticized for not inviting a Dyke Separatist to participate on the panel. The person responsible for organizing the panel had had previous experience with Dyke Separatists. Her experience was that wherever Dyke Separatists are included on panels the atmosphere fills with animosity and hatred, and that energies converge on the issue of separatism to the total exclusion of other Lesbian perspectives. She felt that since this was the first panel on Lesbianism at NOW, she preferred there be a broader based discussion this time and that issues of Dyke Separatism be discussed at another time.

Secondly, this panel was essentially an exchange by the Gay Coalition of Denver and NOW. April 16th two NOW women presented a panel at the Coalition general meeting. Lesbian panel members did not presume to represent all aspects of Lesbian perspectives.

Thirdly, I want to point out a double-standard I see inherent in this Dyke Separatist criticism of NOW. I hear the Separatists saying to NOW women: “You should have invited us. You should want us although we want nothing to do with you. You are all wrong and we are all right.”

If you want to speak to a NOW general meeting, Separatists, why don’t you go to the NOW board and tell them what you want? NOW women aren't mind-readers. I don’t understand why it’s important to you to zap a NOW meeting since you detest NOW women and don't want to work with them anyway.

During the evening the zappers criticized me for wearing earrings, for my clothing choice, for my choice of words, for my political priority — working on a state anti-discrimination bill. Sounds to me like they’re on the same old trip — intolerance of diversity and imposition of their values on me — just like out there in the macrocosm — whites imposing their values on blacks, Chicanas, Indians, etc.; straights on gays, men on women.

As I see it, it’s very important to you Separatists that I be just like you. It’s very important to me that all of us cultivate a climate in which we feel free to express our uniqueness rather than demand conformity of one another.

I am reminded of the medical model with which psychiatrists relate to people. This is a belief system which focuses on illness: what's wrong with you or me. Inherent in this perspective is the assumption that only certain people have the knowledge of what's wrong, and can, therefore, make the diagnosis — tell us what our wants and needs should be.

In the field of mental health, psychiatrists, of course, hold this power position. So that a depressed housewife is sick — she needs to become a better wife, mother, or whatever. A Lesbian is a Lesbian because she got screwed up in her sexual preference — she had bad experiences with men and all she really needs is a good fuck (by a man of course and of course this “good” fuck will change her sexual orientation).

The only difference in this particular situation is that it’s the Separatists who have taken the power position, the assumption of the “correct” value system, and have applied it to me, other Lesbians and NOW women. We “deviate” from the Separatists’ model code of good behavior. The terms used are different but the essence is the same. Because I wear clogs, corduroy jeans, a turtleneck top and earrings, I'm a classist. Somehow I don’t quite see the connection between what I choose to wear and how my choice discriminates against Separatists. I haven't determined for them what they should wear.

My choice of words somehow comes out of the Separatists’ version of the sickness model as being a reflection of my intellectualism. I feel like I'm back in the McCarthy era with that accusation.

In contrast to the medical or sickness model, the model I feel comfortable with is the growth or existential model, in which the focus is on being. This model recognizes and values inner experience and returns the locus of evaluation within the individual from the traditional external sources: God, men, and what will the neighbors think.

The staff of Big Mama Rag would like to extend our appreciation and 1,000 thank yous to Elissa Meyer and Linda Lane, who resigned this month as co-editors. Where would we have been without you folks? Where We're At

by Jackie Bryson

During the past four months, the staff of Big Mama Rag has been struggling with its own internal problems, while attempting to slay society's dragon of sexism. We want to share with our readers the process and outcome of our struggles.

In January, the old staff of BMR (approximately eight women) called together women of Denver who were interested in working with the paper. More than 40 women responded. We were delighted with the response, and, quite frankly, overwhelmed with some of the logistics and complexity of feelings that developed with an organization of this size. We tried to adjust our structure to accommodate. We became more hierarchical — with an editorial board, three part-time, paid staff members, and many talented and enthusiastic women who wanted to help. We tried assigning tasks to new people and dispersing responsibilities. Personal contact facilitated the growth of trust and understanding among some women, but frustrations and misunderstandings developed among others on the staff. Some new people felt left out of decision-making; staff members felt overburdened trying to work out feelings and publish a monthly newspaper at the same time. Charges of elitism, Lesbian-overkill, and editorial authoritarianism were made both face-to-face and behind people's backs. We made some mistakes. Some were mended. Some were not. We were getting uptight, so we decided to slow down and take a look at our process.

At a general meeting early in May, we all decided that we needed time to get to know each other, to share ideas and questions, to develop the kind of trust that is essential in working on a women’s paper. We have been taking time to do this, and that is why this issue of BMR is a bit late. We also decided to hold some informal “educational consciousness-raising” sessions (Radical Feminist Theory, Feminist Poetry, Feminist Journalism, and Feminist Photography). We have been discussing our personal and political ideas in these small groups in order to re-define the needs and structure of BMR.

To some extent this has worked. For the women who have stayed with the paper, there is much optimism and a re-commitment to the goal of the paper — to represent a radical feminist point of view in covering local news and feature stories, as well as to continue to develop our theories and practice of a female culture. We have found it necessary again to re-structure our group. Presently, there are 15-20 women who have a firm commitment to the paper, and with a group of this size, we have been able to return to our original structure as a collective. Meetings are held twice a month and business and editorial decisions are made by a consensus of women present at those meetings. Any women participating in decision-making or any solely “creative” aspect of the paper (photography, graphics, writing) is expected to do some share of the footwork involved in keeping the paper operating.

There are other internal decisions we have arrived at which are perhaps too petty and/or too boring to go into here. Mainly we want to let you know that BIG MAMA LIVES! We are alive, healthy, and functioning. We continue to get responses from our readers, but we want (and need) very much to hear more — letters, manuscripts, graphics, photos, etc. In addition, our monthly business meetings will be held on the first Sunday of the month at 10:30 a.m. in the BMR office (1724 Gaylord) and are open to any woman who wants to come.

The Oil Crisis?

Maureen Mrizek

We're in the midst of an oil crisis, the cause may or may not be over  
demand and limited supply. We may never know, but one thing we can  
be sure of is that the oil industry itself will continue to prosper and  
grow. The oil crisis may continue indefinitely for a decade or more or  
we may find a way to end it.

One idea for ending the crisis is to nationalize the oil industry. To ac-  
complish this feat would require something close to a nuclear war  
because of the amount of economic and political power the industry  
wields in relation to the government.

Another idea is to nationalize the oil industry and give the oil  
tycoons the political recognition they deserve in terms of the real  
economic and political power they have. In other words merge the  
government and the corporate state. The way to accomplish this  
merger would be in the form of a monarchy. Originally monarchs  
came into being because people needed to be protected, a King would  
form a band of warriors and promise to defend a tribe or nation of peo-  
ple. The people in return would swear allegiance to the monarch and  
would trust in the King’s discretion as their ruler and governmental  
head. Our civilization (?) has now changed to the point that people do  
not need monarchs to defend them, but they are dependent on a highly  
developed technological economy which has at its base the need for  
oil...

The idea of a monarch has not been without its place in American  
history. There were many people who supported the idea of making  
Washington King after America had won her independence from  
England. The office of the president has many of the vestiges of an-  
cient royalty and the American people have always (WELL, ALMOST  
ALWAYS) encouraged and enjoyed a type of royal pageantry for its  
leaders. A very likely candidate for King in 1976 would be John D.  
Rockefeller (of Standard Oil). Rockefeller wouldn't be losing that much  
and America wouldn't be losing a president, she would be gaining a  
King.

At last the issues of democracy and economics could be clarified.  
People would no longer have to labor under the idea that they are  
working for themselves, that if they could only pull themselves up by  
their own bootstraps or G-Strings (whichever fits) they could be  
successful. Economic feudalism would be the name of the game, and  
now people would know what to call it. People would be working in  
royal factories for the king or some other nobleman. Actually people’s  
existences wouldn't change a lot. The Constitution and the Bill of  
Rights might be abolished, but it’s unpatriotic to exercise those rights  
anyway, so people wouldn't notice that. You might see the Royal Seal  
on gas station signs in place of Standard Oil or Exxon or some other  
brand name. An incredible moral burden would be lifted from the  
shoulders of citizens who had been chasing the elusive concept of  
democracy in a capitalistic economy. Sociologists, psychologists, and  
psychiatrists wouldn't have to be sneaky about socializing people,  
they could just tell them to get back to their class or class-caste, or off  
with their heads.

So you see a monarchy would actually clear up a lot of confusion  
and clarify our society for us. The next time you sit shivering in the  
dark—think in terms of a Royal Standard Oil and ask not what Stan-  
dard Oil can do for you but ask what it can do for the Kingdom.

One wish

to Buddha

on stone-chapped knees  
two cents per wish  
and mine a dollar

just to be sure  
Siddhartha means  
every wish fulfilled  
One wish to gold-leafed  
Siddhartha

One love wish

for you and me

and fourteen hours  
down

to Bangkok.

A postcard

from you now

and then  
Remembering,  
laughing, when

we were eagle-carried  
to a dream.

There,  
and back again.

Jeremy

To An Anonymous Woman Disc Jockey  
from an anonymous university secretary

The only reason, frankly,

that I was up so early,

was to take a shower, prepare

my body for the daily sacrifice;  
they pay me to sit at a desk

for eight hours — food

for hungry birds who pick

me clean by five.

So usually I don’t crawl out

until after sunrise, thickly protected  
with sleep like a cheap coat

that unravels slowly as I dance

on top of my brown, wooden

desk and perform all kinds of marvelous feats for money.  
By five, I'm a bloodshot parody of myself.  
But, as I said, I rose early

and turned on the radio — music  
morning jazz a woman's  
voice something about

a sunrise and I opened my door  
and there was rose grey

yellow blue

thank you. —Jeanne Winer

OUR MOTHERS—OURSELVES

Last night, I dreamed my mother stomped my guts into the floor  
with raging Army feet all cast in silver spurs and I threw up and  
over everything I lay there waiting to be tramped again  
into the floor

she only looked at me—the silver shining from her eyes  
gleaming Army boots inside

When I was young she always listened

fed herself into her young

and never made a sparrow of a noise

We tramped her in the living room

Marched upon her in the garden, buried her with tulip bulbs,  
We pushed her down the stairs

and stuffed her in the kitchen sink to drown.

One time she came around

brandishing a chair into our faces upside down

A Lion Tamer pacing round and round

jabbing at the air and stomping

stomping up and down until she cried

she cried/ran down/slumped down upon the hardwood floor  
Last night I dreamed my mother stomped my guts into the floor  
The silver tears ran down her eyes

Until I couldn't see her anymore/no more/  

no more...  
—Chocolate Waters

Carol Lease

Chicana Welfare Rights is a
nationally organized, non-
funded group that functions
solely through the volunteer
work of welfare mothers, and
deals principally with welfare
injustice against the Chicano
community. The Chicanas
who founded this organization
had worked with the National
Welfare Rights Organization
which is, according to Patricia
Estrada who works with
Chicana Welfare Rights in
Colorado, “a predominately
black-interest group. One
reason we broke away from
NWRO was that they wouldn’t
recognize the need to have
forms printed in Spanish.”

The national headquarters
of Chicana Welfare Rights is
in Los Angeles with Alicia
Escalante as its head. Nation-
ally, the organization is in the
process of challenging the
Talmadge Amendment Public
Law 92-223 to the Social
Security Act which requires

those in need of public
assistance to register for
employment at the Depart-
ment of Employment or to
participate in the Work Incen-
tive Program (WIN). Locally,
the organization is primarily
fighting the inequities and
injustices of the welfare
system, and has become
involved in cases they term
“Parent Abuse” by the Denver
General Hospital, the Child
Welfare section of the Denver
Department of Welfare and the
Juvenile Courts.

The deaths of two children
earlier this year from child
abuse that wasn't recognized
as such or dealt with by
official agencies despite the
pleas of at least one parent
of one child and hospital and
social agency workers, has
created an “overreactionary
flood of suspected child
abuse and child neglect
cases,” says Ms. Estrada.
These cases have resulted in

More on Page 15

Talmadge

Welfare

Anna Nieto-Gomez

Amendment

Wages

The Talmadge Amendment to the Social Security Act requires
all those in need of public assistance to either register for work
at the Department of Employment or participate in the Work

Incentive Program (WIN).
The Chicana Welfare Rights
organization believes that to
require people to work when
they need food, clothing and
shelter is in direct contradic-
tion to the philosophy of the
Social Security Act to help
people in need. The Talmadge
Amendment cannot help peo-
ple get off welfare. People are
required to register and to
look for work although jobs do
not exist. If they do find work,
they will work for their welfare
check and not for a minimum
wage. Supportive services,
child care and vocational re-
habilitation necessary to en-
able people to look for jobs
are nonexistent. Government
training programs have failed
to provide employable people.
The rights of women are
denied when a law forces a
woman to work outside the
home. It also ignores the right
of a family to stay together.
“Rider” Not Discussed
The Talmadge Amendment
was approved by both the
House and the Senate as a
rider to a bill which provided
burial payments to bereaved
relatives of deceased service-
men whose bodies could not
be recovered for burial from
Vietnam. Discussion — sur-
rounding the actual Amend-
ment arose from only one
Congressman, Mr. Byrnes of
Wisconsin. He felt that not
enough information nor dis-
cussion had been presented
about the bill. He also pointed
out that the bill had not been
totally printed more than a day
before presentation to enable
time to read and study the bill
- much less approve it.
Congressperson Gross
supported Mr. Byrnes in
stating he had mistakenly

thought he was approving
only a burial bill. However,
Congressperson Mills of Ar-
kansas replied that this was
the same bill Congress had
passed in 1972, but due to
disagreements (not identi-
fied), it was not approved.
Therefore, the only change
required would be to change
1972 to 1973. He also
reasoned that since the
session soon had to adjourn,
there was insufficient time to
explain the bill.

Byrnes withdrew his objec-
tion and the Talmadge A-
mendment was passed unani-
mously by 326 Congressmen
with 105 members absent.

The Chicana Welfare Rights
Organization hopes to call to
the attention of the taxpayers
the fact that most Congress-
men did not even know what
bill they were passing, al-
though they voted on spend-
ing millions of the taxpayers’
dollars. In addition, the
Chicanas are asking for indi-
vidual responses from Con-
gress members as to their
stand on the Talmadge A-
mendment in order to call
their attention to what can be
done.

At present, the Talmadge
Amendment is in its registra-
tion phase in Denver. In the
surrounding rural area, it is
being implemented through a
demonstration project called
the Public Service Employ-
ment (PSE). To date, the
program has been considered
a “success” in lowering the
welfare rolls because people
have not registered. The low
number of registrants is
played up as though welfare
recipients had been placed
into jobs.

PSE Required

The purpose of the Public
Service Employment is to
assist registrants to become
job-ready by giving them the
opportunity to learn new
skills, gain valuable work
experience, and to develop a
work history. Participation is
a requirement for welfare
eligibility. The registrants do
not receive a wage for their
PSE activity. They merely
work for their welfare check.
Another problem is that actual
employment opportunity does
not exist.

PSE participants do not
qualify for union jobs, nor for
unfilled vacant positions if
they are “established” job
positions, or jobs advertised
in the newspapers. PSE
participants qualify only for
“useful public services jobs
not otherwise accomplished.”
Such jobs need not be
full-time either. In other
words, PSEs qualify for the
jobs which don’t exist and are
trained (?) for undefined jobs.

Each registrant is required
to conduct an adequate job
search. If she discourages the
employers to hire her, has a
negative attitude, or in her
personal appearance is unac-
ceptable to employers, she is
considered to have conducted
an inadequate job search and,

therefore, is ineligible for
welfare.
Thus, if she does not have

the money to dress in an
appealing manner for the
employer's eye, she is out of
luck. If she tells the employer
that she does not like the job,
and that she could do
something better for a better
wage, she is out of luck. If she
complains about the condi-
tions surrounding her em-
ployment facilities, she is out

of luck. Her actions will be
considered as discouraging
the employer, and as a
negative attitude. In other
words, she neither has the
right to choose her employer,
nor her working conditions.
Neither does she have the
freedom to dissent, nor to tell
the truth.
WIN Program a Failure

The WIN program is regarded
by many as a failure. Only
11% of 223,302 people en-
rolled were placed in jobs.
Many programs offered meet-
ings and pep talks instead of
training. Fifty percent of the
frustrated, disappointed en-
rollees dropped out of the
programs as a result. Others
were discouraged due to bu-
reaucratic breakdowns which
slowed, or stopped financial
aid. Although many could
have taken advantage of more
meaningful programs out of
WIN, such programs would
not be sanctioned for sti-
pends. Only 40% of those
people placed in jobs are
receiving an annual income.
These jobs still require fami-
lies to stay on welfare. The 67
million dollars spent in the

Bertha Romero is a Peace Corps Volunteer in Thailand who teaches English to blind students from kindergarten to the eighth grade. She has been in Thailand since January and has the following to say about women in Thai society.

Sumalee is a Thai woman, very verbal and active in women’s rights. She was writing articles every week until recently - about two months ago - and is still behind the lights. Rumor has it that many Thai (both men and women) have been offended by her writings and she was advised to be more careful. Also, there might be fear for her life because she apparently “knows too much.” Another woman journalist, an American named Claudia Ross, was murdered in Bangkok about that same time (two months ago). So things are slowly dying down - it’s funny how the mass media is never really made aware of how things turn out in the end. But she hasn't been writing at all lately.

I've learned too, that Thai women are very aggressive, equal, and outspoken. Sumalee also worked on a draft of the constitution to include women’s rights, wages, improved job conditions, etc. - but the House turned it down. The bill was not published, and the only thing people read in the papers was: “She was asked to remove herself from the room because she had her legs crossed. She refused, stating that all the men had their legs crossed and if she was asked to leave they should be too. (She was also the only woman there.)” She was finally physically removed, I've gathered. And when I mention her name to some Thais, either men or women, they immediately say “She's foolish and nobody pays attention to her anyway.” That’s the way it is in Thailand.

Feminist College to Open

With more than 1,000 colleges offering women’s studies courses and 80 making it possible to earn a degree in the same, is a college devoted to feminism necessary?

Such a college - it will be called an institute - will open in the summer of 1975. Founded by feminist activists, Sagaris will answer the need for the study of unadulterated feminist philosophy.

Dr. Joan Peters, one of the founders, said in an interview that there will be greater academic freedom than found at any college or university offering women’s studies.

“Present courses leave something to be desired,” she said. “In many schools the women’s studies are controlled by men or locked into a system that does not allow adequate freedom for maximum intellectual growth.”

Dr. Peters, of Goddard College in Plainfield, Vt., and Brooklyn, N.Y., told how the institute got its name.

“The name was taken from the Sagaris, the double-edged sword of the ancient Amazons, who, according to mythology, were militant only when necessary to protect themselves from aggressors.”

The Amazons, mythology holds, were powerfully strong women who waged war on the oppressors. Dr. Peters stressed that they take Sagaris in a political and not a military sense.

“Our institute, which we call an institute to allow ourselves the intellectual freedom not possible in establishment colleges, is meant to be a feminist-humanist alternative to existing patriarchal society schools of higher education,” Dr. Peters said.

The founders include writers, teachers, and activists. Among them is Blanche Boyd, author of a book titled “Nerves.” Also involved, according to Dr. Peters, is Ti-Grace Atkinson, pioneer theoretician of the women’s movement in America.

‘Girl’ Gets $9,000.

Mary Joyce, 26, who complained to her boss about calling her “the girl” and a day later she was fired, will get $9,000 from her former employer by order of the New York State Human Rights Division. Miss Joyce said in her complaint she was fired after telling assistant vice president John Maloney of AVCO Financial Services, Inc., she didn't like being called “the girl” when her title was “Commercial Paper Salesperson.”

She said she was called in the next day and dismissed on grounds of “misconduct.” Under a settlement signed by both sides, AVCO will pay her $9,000 and give her a mutually agreed upon letter of recommendation informing future employers she was “capable, competent, and satisfactory.”

Minority Women’s Task Force

Carol Lease

In March the Minority Women’s Task Force of the Denver chapter of the National Organization for Women (NOW) decided to leave the nationally recognized women’s rights group and become an independent organization, retaining its original name while working on issues directly related to minority women in Colorado. Accounts of the incident were published with an anti-feminist, anti-woman bias. The issues and the ideas of the women involved in the separation were ignored. The following has been written about the split after conversations with Corina Aragon, chairperson of the Minority Women’s Task Force (MWTF) and Charlotte Hebeler, president of the Denver chapter of the National Organization for Women (NOW).

The Minority Women’s Task Force was formed to research and act on problems that often disproportionately affect minority women rather than non-minority women. The Woman's Prison at Canon City is currently one focal point for action. Some women on the Task Force were members of NOW and others were not. The committee itself was open only to minority women (although any woman could participate in the activities of the Task Force) because the presence of non-minority women usually precipitated problems with control and decision making that “happened so many times” in other committees with mixed minority and non-minority membership. “Minority women wanted their own identity. They wouldn’t have it with white women telling them what to do,” according to a present member of NOW.

There was considerable argument over the issues of exclusive involvement of minority women in only minority related issues and the exclusive control of all Task Force decisions by minority women. “Perhaps that’s right,” says Corina Aragon. “Maybe minority women need to work on issues relevant to ourselves and our lives so we can develop our own strengths and self-confidence. Then we can extend ourselves to other women-related issues.”

Task Forces report in at Board meetings of NOW and according to Charlotte Hebeler each Task Force “bases its own strategy on its own wisdom but must be willing to change strategy if the Board suggests it. This control was unacceptable to the women in the Minority Women’s Task Force.”

Task Force Leaves NOW

The final decision to leave NOW came after a wine and fondue meeting lasting almost 3 hours. Remaining within the nationally recognized organization included the advantages of retaining the clout that NOW wields, using its resources of lobbying, expertise, and working with and influencing attitudes of non-minority women.

Disadvantages included the continuous problem of insensitivity among many non-minority women, “and we didn’t want to spend our time” in arguments and discussion about why the Task Force wants to do certain things and why minority women feel the way they do. When I called NOW the next day to tell them our decision the woman who answered the phone said that “we are sort of sorry to hear that.”

“Well I was very sorry to have to say that we had voted to leave NOW. I did not vote to do it but I don’t regret the decision to leave. If I were in the white woman’s position,” continues Corina Aragon, “I would have attended the Minority Women’s Task Force meetings, humbled myself, shown concern for minority women’s problems, and tried to work it out.

“It seems that the real problem was a lack of communication, sincere communication from woman to woman. I hope that we can get back to the point where we can really communicate.” Charlotte Hebeler’s feeling was that the Task Force needed “to accomplish what they needed to accomplish on their own...to grow, develop their own wisdom, their own strategy, to make their own mistakes. There was some sort of feeling that even if we do it wrong, at least we do it. But it was a very amicable split... we still communicate...many of us in NOW have had the same kinds of feelings about doing it on our own. It's sad in a way to lose their knowledge and wisdom but in another way it’s kind of neat when somebody says we're going to do it on our own.”

There is currently no Task Force in NOW that deals with the minority woman's problems. The minority women that are presently in NOW seem to be involved in and committed to other things.

Sociologist’s Nightmare

NOW is a “sociologist's nightmare” says Ms. Hebeler. “We are constantly getting new people with varying levels of consciousness to minority problems. Some members are probably racist and will remain so all their lives - but they are not turned off by this Denver chapter because there are so many things to do in the organization. There is concern on the Board to have strong minority participation in NOW...we need to find that minority person to come forward to the Board to do this...we have an informal, personal relationship with our minority members, so it’s not a threatening thing but a growth enhancing thing. Most of us see minority women as women only not as women and members of a minority. We realize that minority women have special, unique problems that require continuing processes of consciousness-raising in this group and we will continue to do it.”

Meanwhile the Minority Women's Task Force is continuing to focus its attention on the Women’s Prison at Canon City. On July 5 they will help to produce a filmed documentary on women prisoners called “The Hidden Minority” to be telecast on Denver Now on channel 2, KWGN-TV. 

Target: Canon City

“Sexism in the Colorado prison system is unbelievable, shocking,” Ms. Aragon reports. Before the Minority Women’s Task Force visited Canon City, federal and state funds provided rehabilitation and pre-parole programs that were exclusively for men. Of course this is a blatant violation of the law, but I suppose that the wardens and...

Petition Alleges Discrimination; Sparks KOA Boycott

Carol Lease

A coalition of women and minorities has filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to deny KOA its broadcast license renewal because of alleged discrimination against women and minorities. The coalition is instituting a boycott to give their petition a financial bite.

The coalition is comprised of the Colorado Committee on the Mass Media and the Spanish-surnamed, the National Organization for Women (NOW), the Mass Media Task Force and Sundiata, Inc., and the American Indian Movement (AIM).

The controversy centers around the under-utilization of and discrimination towards women and minorities in positions at the station and discriminatory programming concerning women and minorities.

The coalition is asking all people to support their boycott of General Electric products and of companies advertising with GE broadcasting stations KOA-TV, KOA-AM, and KOAQ-FM radio until an acceptable agreement can be reached.

The coalition is also asking people to write letters to the management at KOA encouraging the station to settle the dispute.

KWGN-TV Agreement

The coalition also filed a petition of denial of broadcast license with the FCC against KWGN Television, channel 2. An agreement was reached on May 22 that resulted in the withdrawal of the petition.
