Cable TV: Women and the Media

Elissa Meyer

Occasionally I have heard Cable Television referred to as an alter-
native to broadcast television, the hour after hour barrage of
stereotypes and triviality that comes into peoples’ homes through
the airwaves. Cable television is different; it is brought to homes
through wires which carry electronic signals. The range of channels
which can be brought in through the cable is much wider, and it can
provide a much more diverse and realistic selection of program-
ming. Unfortunately, after attending the national convention of the
National Cable Television Association, I feel less than hopeful
about Cable Television’s potential.

I had hoped that the conven-

tion would have one redeeming

factor—that was the Public
Access activity. According to
FCC regulations, when a cable
company receives a franchise to
go into an area, it must provide at
least one Public Access channel
through the cable. When that
channel becomes occupied dur-
ing a specified period of time, the
company is obligated to open
another channel. Under the FCC
guidelines these channels
would make studio time
available to any individual or
group with a TV message at no
cost. Again, the possibilities for
utilizing television as a com-
munications tool under this
system are opened up as never
before. So what is really happen-
ing in these two areas, Cable
Television and Public Access,
especially in terms of changing
attitudes and opportunities for
women?
Profits or People?

On arrival at the Conrad Hilton
in Chicago, the location for the
NCTA Convention, I began to
sense the tone which pervaded
the entire four days: making
Cable a profitable business.
Over three thousand smartly-
suited businessmen were
gathering to shake right hands
and to increase assets. The
overwhelming reality is that it
does take money to lay miles of
cable throughout a geographic
area, and that in order to sell
subscriptions to the cable,
Cablecasters think they must
have slick, pre-packaged
productions to compete with
broadcast. But in this writer's
opinion, they are missing the
point. They ignore the explosive
possibility that if people knew
they could get easy access to TV
time and to the necessary
production tools through Cable,
they would be more likely to sup-
port it. Cablecasters downplay
Public Access because of what
they consider the mediocre
quality of the programming
produced by the newly-
enfranchised public who have
taken advantage of existing
Public Access channels.

As to be expected, this
chauvinistic attitude was ex-
tended to and reflected in the
roles of women at the conven-
tion. There were few women
there who represented top ad-
ministrative positions in Cable;
there were a small minority of
women who were production
managers for Public Access and
local origination programming in
small metropolitan centers. But
the most conspicuous women at
the convention were those not in
positions of responsibility, but
rather those who were dressed
and made-up as models at the
equipment exhibits. In this
multi-million dollar jungle of
sophisticated mixers, switchers,
cameras, and monitors, these
women were planted by the
manufacturers to make their
brands more attractive and
saleable. If this is the mentality
of the Cablecasters, we can ex-
pect little in the way of change in
the programming provided by
them as opposed to present
programming over broadcast
television.
Best Production of the Year
I must admit, the “gentlemen”
did give token recognition to the
work of women in the field of
Cable Television. At the NCTA
Awards Ceremony, Ms. Kim
Beaman and Ms. Nancy Hauser,
the production managers for
Public Access and Local Origina-
tion programming in Jackson,
Michigan, received five top
awards including Best Produc-
tion of the Year for a videotape
called ‘Nancy.’ The tape is a
sensitive, delicate portrayal of a
woman, mother and wife, who is

approaching middle age and
feels trapped by her cir-
cumstances. In a skillful inter-

and outside her home in her ac-

At an ad hoc Women's
Caucus, twenty-five women

alienation with Cablecasting. At
this forum, Kim and Nancy
revealed the frustrations of their
work. They work full time for
part-time salaries, making them
the lowest paid employees
among the professional staff.
They also told us that “Nancy”
was one tape of a series shown
weekly which they created and
produced themselves about the
local community. Using portable
videotaping equipment, they
went out into the Jackson area

and found people, activities and

a format, and after many ad-

the community about itself; it

None of this valuable work

Letter to Denver

Feminist Guide to Tucson

May 19, 1974  
Hello

all you Denver sisters! I’m from Tucson and am

finishing a long weekend stay in Denver, which has turned out to
be one of the best times I have had in your city. This is the first
time I have been here alone, so I decided to try to contact some
Feminists and check out what’s going on here.

I was a little uneasy about calling up total strangers and

saying, “Hi. My name is Barbara,

I'm from Tucson and I want to

meet some Feminists here.” But after a couple of beers and a
long-distance call to Tucson to gain energy from my sisters

there, I got up enough courage

to make my first call.

First, I called The Women’s Voice and got the number of the
Women in Transition (WIT) House. From there on it was easy!
The sisters at WIT House were warm, friendly and full of
information about what was going on in Denver—complete with
names and telephone numbers. But most of all, they made me
feel like an accepted friend, not a stranger to be tested out.

There has not been enough time on this visit for me to connect
with all the programs, activities, and sisters in Denver that I have

learned about. Fortunately, I am
returning in June and will have
more time to follow through with
my “mission.” Everyone that I

did meet, however, was very interested about what was going on
in Tucson. So it seemed a good idea to try to give you a picture of
the situation in my town and some contacts, in case you are

interested.  
Overview of the Community  
Setting

Tucson is roughly one-third
the size of Denver. We suffer
from over-population, urban
sprawl, and an unfortunate
tendency toward “Californi-
zation.” The community is
surrounded by mountains,
which gives a feeling of
strength and security and
allows an easy “escape” from
the city.

I would describe the general
atmosphere of Tucson to be
friendly, mellow, low-parano-
ia. There seems to be an
attitude of co-existence so
that it is fairly easy to pursue
a different life-style. Contrary
to popular opinion, Tucson is
not a community of mostly
retired people. Young “freaks”
are more visible than the old
folks.

Given the political conser-
vatism of Arizona and the
smaller size of Tucson, it
came as a surprise to me to
realize that Tucson is devel-
oping into something of a
“hot-spot” of Feminist activity
in the Southwest. There is, for
example, a lot more going on
in Tucson than in Phoenix.
Here is a list of some of the
organizations and activities
currently in Tucson.

Tucson Women’s Center - 912 E. Sixth St. 792-1929

Provides a place for wo-
men’s groups for meetings
and social events. Transient
women can crash there for up
to two nights while they get
their feet on the ground and
locate other lodging. Acts as a
resource-information center.

Generally, the center has
two-to-four full-time residents
who help pay the rent. Other
donations are solicited
through individual monthly
pledges from local Feminists.
Persons using the center are
urged to contribute 25 cents
each time.

Alternatives for Women

40 E. 14th Street, #5 884-9776  
A Feminist counseling /

consultation service, this is

where I fit in. In December of

last year, three women—two
psychologists and a social
worker (that’s me) formed a
partnership to create an
alternative mental health ser-
vice for the women of Tucson.

For us, “Alternatives” is a
place where we can utilize our
skills and develop new skills
in a way that is not
exploitative of women who
seek our services. We heartily
reject the traditional “thera-

pist” role since this puts the
“other” in the role

of “patient.”  
The therapist/patient role
model assumes a hierarchi-
cal, one-up / one-down
relationship, focusing on the
“patient's" weaknesses. It
also makes assumptions a-
bout the strengths and super-
ior skills of the “therapist”
that make us uncomfortable.
So we prefer to act as
consultants and friends to the
women we work with and
focus on their strengths.

Right now we are doing
mostly individual work, with
some groups going and others
planned. Ann has a con-
sciousness-raising group go-
ing, and will be starting
another soon. I have a
Bodywork for Women group
on Wednesday nights that
includes yoga, massage and
belly dancing. It’s an open
group, so that a woman can
drop by any Wednesday she
feels inclined; she doesn't
have to sign up for a series.
Dorothy is working on a
Lesbian Identity group.

We are a low-profit organi-
zation. The client sets her own
fee based on her own assess-
ment of what she can afford.
We explain that we need an
average of $8 per visit and that
every dollar above that helps
for those who must pay less.
It works! Most weeks we
average close to $8 per visit.
But we would like to find
sources of support so that we
aren’t totally dependent on
fees.

Contact: Barbara Bird, Doro-
thy Riddle, Ann Yelott.  
Antigone’s Books - 415 N. 4th
Ave. 792-3715

Specializing in women’s
and children’s literature, Anti-
gone’s is a very comfortable

place to drop in if you're
cruising through town or need
a place to start from. Contact:
Pat Kelly or Johnee Cunning-
ham  
Minerva - Feminist Astrology
Center 415 N. 4th Ave.
792-3715

Located in the loft of
Antigone Books, this is a
brand new organization form-
ed by one of the women of
“Alternatives for Women,” a-
long with two others. “Alter-
natives” refers all those
seeking astrological consul-
tation to Minerva, since in
order to practice astrology in
Tucson, one must pay $300 to
be licensed as a fortune-teller.
YUK! Contact: Coleen Bent-
ley, Debbie Dobson, Dorothy
Riddle  
Women’s Self-Help and Gyn-
ecological Clinic - 256 S.
Scott 622-8821

A part of the Tucson Free
Clinic, the Women's Clinic is
open on Monday nights to
offer free gynecological care.
The clinic is staffed by
volunteer Feminist-oriented
patient advocates and nurses,
with a local gynecologist
standing by for consultation.
Instruction in gynecological

self-help (do your own pelvic

exam, etc.) is offered but not
pushed on women attending
the clinic. The atmosphere is
warm and relaxed. Contact:
Coleen Elegante  
Fifth Avenue House - 847 S.
Fifth Ave. 792-1890

This is a collective formed
by five beautiful women.
Although a private home, it is

a core of feminist activity in
Tucson. It is through Fifth
Ave. that we have established
and maintained ties with
women’s collectives and
Feminist activities in Arkan-
sas, New Mexico, Oregon and
Washington. Contact: Ann,
Colleen, Debbie, Leslie or
Tina.

Men’s Consciousness Raising
Group

Formed by several gay and
straight men, we consider this
group to be an important
adjunct to the Feminist
movement in Tucson. These
are men who are committed to
raising their own conscious-
ness and breaking down
sex-role stereotypes. We love
them dearly and collaborate
with them frequently. “Alter-
natives for Women” is cur-
rently exploring ways to work
together, such as in providing
some mixed women/men
workshops for those who
want to work on inter-sex
relationships. Contact Jack
Lathan 623-0994 or Perk Clark
623-1072.

This pretty much exhausts
my supply of information (and
me). I'll probably learn what I
left out when I get home. I
hope this letter doesn’t come
on like an underground
Chamber of Commerce report.
If it does, it's because I really
love the place and most of the
people.

Please feel free to contact
any of the places or people I
have mentioned—by phone,
letter, or in person. We'd love
to meet you!

We hope to see many of you
at the Summer Solstice in
New Mexico this June. In case
you don’t know about this BIG
EVENT, it’s a gathering of

women from all over the west.

There will be booths, arts and
crafts, displays, workshops,
and all manner of goings on.
All the Feminist businesses in
Tucson will be closing down
and forming a large caravan.
See you there.

Sisterhood is not only
powerful—it’s fun.

Barbara Bird

Tucson, Arizona

struggle goes beyond the  
borders of this nation and

working sisters and brothers  
throughout the world through  
concrete action of interna-  
tional workers’ solidarity.

Women will seek to accom-

Editorial  
Just Reduction of People?  

The Talmadge Amendment has demonstrated that its goal is  
the reduction of the number of people on welfare - nothing else.  
Concern for the human condition of people who need assistance  
to survive in this country is probably written somewhere in a  
memo connected with this law but has never been a part of it.  
The distorted, prejudiced stereotypes that make receiving welfare  
a stigma in this society have been strengthened again and again  
through the work ethic. Expending physical or mental energy -  
does not make a person well-off, rich, or even maintain a  
sustenance level of life. Work has nothing to do with wealth. The  
survival of this economy necessitates the existence of a welfare  
class.  

It is the unskilled woman, minority and non-minority, who is  
forced to prostitute herself in a meaningless, dead-end, slave  
wage job for the Department of Welfare that is unaware of and  
unresponsive to her needs. Even within these “improvement”  
programs men receive priority in training over women although  
women are the vast majority of welfare recipients. But now it is  
the women on welfare who are uniting and supporting each other  
in their struggle. We support Chicana Welfare Rights nationally  
and locally in their efforts to repeal the Talmadge Amendment to  
the Social Security Act.  

One Reader’s Opinion  

Carol Hansford  

A “straight” woman is a woman without any feminist  
consciousness. A straight woman is not merely a woman who  
sleeps only with men. Defining a woman as “straight,” if she is  
not homosexual, creates resentment which ultimately can lead  
to alienation from other women.  

Some lesbians feel that all women are lesbians whether they  
know or will admit it. All women are not lesbians just as all  
women are not heterosexuals. It is lesbian chauvinism to think  
otherwise. Commitment to other women does exist - strong and  
honest without sexual involvement. It comes from a true, deep  
feeling of women as sisters; it is not dependent on sexual  
encounters.  

There seems to be a feeling of “more Feminist than thou” by  
some lesbians in the movement whose actions and attitudes say,  
“If I sleep with a woman, I am more radical, heavy, together than  
a woman who sleeps alone, with men or with women and men.”  

An aspect of feminism is that a woman must control her own  
body - all aspects of her body - in the area of sexual activity as  
well as motherhood. Feminism also demands the making of a  
woman's culture through the creation of viable alternatives and  
the denial of any oppression among people: honesty.  

Some Feminists recognize lesbianism as a viable alternative,  
although sections of the lesbian movement don't recognize  
heterosexuality as a viable alternative. Heterosexuality is not  
exclusively culturally determined. All women have the option of  
accepting or rejecting it. It is a choice that Feminists make.  
Straight women don’t make that choice. They are locked into  
societal expectations of their sexual behavior, but Feminists  
have stepped away from this and are not bound by such stringent  
social roles.  

As long as sexual preference is allowed to create a difference  
among Feminists the divisiveness rampant in this women’s  
movement will remain and be a detriment to real change. Women  
should unite around their politics not their sexual proclivities.  
Let's put our energy into fighting sexism - our common enemy.

Nurture

Barbara Hume

Cross-cultural studies indicate that, almost universally, mother and child are close together the first few days after delivery. The father may or may not be included in this togetherness. The degree to which the father is involved usually reflects his later role in child-rearing. Some people suggest that it is the early contact of father and child which triggers his increased participation in parenting. The system of separation of mother and child, at its extreme in high risk and premature nurseries, is unique to our society.

While studies on other animals clearly show a critical period during which separation of mother and child leads to severe problems or rejection of the child, there has been a reluctance to extend these ideas to the human animal. Now, however, evidence indicates that human beings have their own species-specific routine pattern of behavior which crosses cultural lines. Filmed observations show a routine pattern beginning with fingertip touching of the infant's extremities and proceeding to massaging and palm contact with the trunk. Mothers of premature infants follow a similar sequence if allowed to touch their infants, though at a slower rate. At least some researchers feel that eye-to-eye contact is also crucial as one innate releaser of maternal caretaking patterns. Yet other studies indicate that mothers separated for 20 days have more trouble bottle feeding than mothers who have early contact with their infants. Cuddling was diminished for these late contact mothers as was eye-to-eye contact. This is very important for the child’s subsequent development since it has been shown that “...early maternal attentiveness facilitates later exploratory behavior in infants.” (Klaus and Kennell, p. 1025)

“Observations in human mothers suggest that affectional bonds are forming before delivery, but that they are fragile and may be easily altered in the first days of life. A preliminary inspection of fragments of available data suggests that maternal behavior may be altered in some women by a period of separation, just as infant behavior is affected by isolation from the mother.” (Klaus and Kennell p. 1035)

The newborn nursery is a medical fad which became the norm despite limited evidence in its favor. Before we risk a similar mistake with respect to rooming-in, more evidence should be gathered and alternatives explored. Home delivery and maternity hospitals are successful in many countries. A local alternative is the newborn nursery at Colorado General Hospital where parents enter and leave the nursery freely at any time of day or night. Conversely, babies go out to the mother’s room any time, for any length of time. It has been found that adequate handwashing and isolation of diseased mothers and babies is all that is required to provide a safe place for mother and child.

If you are about to deliver a child, consider (1) what you feel your needs are, (2) what facilities are offered in your community, and (3) insist on using the most suitable of these facilities to its maximum. If you plan to breastfeed, a hospital which forbids breastfeeding the first 12 hours, and then brings the child every four hours only, certainly isn’t going to help you develop a good milk supply.

The men’s prison has a pre-parole program that allows prisoners to live in special housing thirty days before their release. The men have a period of readjustment into community life, attend orientation groups, get their driver's license, and use real money instead of the wooden tokens of the prison.

Certain petty rules apply only to women prisoners such as no talking in the T.V. room, no leaving until a show is over, no exchange of food in the dining room, no talking from table to table while eating.

“Say Something Nice”

After the first visit of the Task Force the women prisoners were told by their female warden to “say something nice” about their home away from home. A few rules have been changed since then. Women can now dye their hair, can choose their own seats for meals, and now women can leave the prison in pants suits. The former rule was that no woman could go outside of the prison walls in anything but a dress. Now all women must wear pants, not dresses.

Two women were punished for hugging each other when one heard of her release. Women are subjected to dehumanizing medical exams whenever they return to the facility from the outside. There is no male-female socialization because of the fear that the women might get pregnant.

Women still do not have a work-release program that men have which allows the prisoner to live and work in a city outside of prison. Women prisoners must remain in their prison and do the laundry and sewing for the prison.

EnerGizing the Feminine Principle Today

Linda Fowler

Women form the oldest and largest continually oppressed
group in the family of humankind, their subjugation dating from
the downfall of communal society and the rise of private
property. The oppression of women exists today at all levels of
social, economic, political, and psychological interaction.

At the social and personal
levels, women’s oppression is
manifested through a lack of
personal identity. Women are
recognized, not as individu-
als, but through their men,
i.e., fathers, husbands, or
family. Through discouraged
relationships with other wo-
men, particularly in groups,
women have grown up with
the idea that they did things
with women socially, only
when they could not have the
company of a man. Through
the frequent threat or actuality
of open hostility and physical
aggression, women are kept
“in line.” In the case of
Lesbians, who are sometimes
physically assaulted, this is
primarily because they do not
relate to men physically or
emotionally, and are not
dependent on them either
economically or psychologi-
cally—are not the property of a
man or men. In the case of
women, wife-beating is not at all uncom-
mon. When Women’s Aid (a

society to aid women who
suffer physical abuse from
their men) opened its doors in
England, fifty-four women
and their children appealed for
help the first day of operation.

“The origin of caste (and the
beginning of class) was the
subjugation of the female sex.
The struggle against the basis
of oppression is at a higher
stage of revolution than the
archaic strategy of the present
radical analysis. In a time
when nearly every American
male is economically capable
of possessing a household
slave or a pretty toy, we
consider women to be the
proletariat.” 1

Economically, women are
now and always have been the
most exploited members of
any working class. Women
receive lower pay for equal
work. In fact, U.S. Govern-
ment statistics show that
white women earn less pro-
portionately than black men
(one example of caste within
the system of class). The
housewife, working endless
hours in the home (99 hours
per week, according to a
Chase Manhattan Bank esti-
mate), is the chief source of
unpaid labor in this or any
country in the world. Without
her slave labor, the entire
economic system could col-
lapse. “The rationalization is
usually that women are
inherently altruistic, which
makes about as much sense
as Senator George Murphy’s
remark that Mexicans are
better suited to stoop labor
because they are ‘built low to
the ground.’ ” 2

All men, whether intention-
ally or unintentionally, have
benefited from the social
position of women, just as all
whites have benefited from
the social position of blacks.

Engels saw the middle-
class man’s woman as a
domestic slave, not a middle-
class person. He wrote: “The
first oppression that occurs in
history coincides with the
development of the antagon-
ism between man and woman
in monogamous marriage,
and the first class oppression
coincides with that of the
female sex by the male.” It is
no accident, Engels said, that
the enslavement of the woman
coincides with the rise of
private property; in fact,
woman (her labor and her
product) was (and still is,
psychologically) the most
valuable property that a man
could possess.

Political oppression until
recently has been total. The
right to vote was not granted
until 1920, many years after
the black man had received
this privilege. This fact is
testimony that all women,
regardless of the social
position of their husbands or
families, are members of a
caste which is considered
lower than that of any man,
whether he be black, white,
upper, middle, or lower class.
Even today women hold less
than 1% of elected offices in
the United States.

WOMEN’S IDENTITY

Although certain social and
legal adjustments can be
documented, mass consci-
ousness itself has not
changed accordingly. The
most severe oppression, and
the crux of all others, has
been and continues to be
psychological. Women suffer
extreme identity confusion,
lack confidence in their
abilities, have little sense of
self-worth, and experience
alienation from other women
and from their own feminine
principle.

They are apart from someone
else. Just as blacks live in a
world defined by whites,
women live in a world defined
by males. (The generic term
for human being is “man”;
“woman” means “wife of
man.”) Thus identified and
defined, a woman has little if
any sense of herself as an
individual entity. (We do not
suggest that there are no
women who have escaped this
situation; certainly, all of us
could cite a few obvious
exceptions. But the excep-
tional woman is not the
problem. The problem is the
situation of the vast majority
of women today.)

With little confidence and
almost no sense of self-worth
(impossible without a sense
of “self”) or the worth of other
women, she looks up to and
identifies with men, particu-
larly those to whom she is in
the closest proximity, i.e.,
those of her political lean-
ings, social position, or race.
For example, the black poet-
ess, Nikki Giovanni, was
quoted by the Denver Post
(Feb. 28, 1973), “The first
thing we must do as black
people, as black women, is
get power for black men.” And
Kathleen Cleaver in a San
Francisco Chronicle interview
stated she wanted nothing
more than a private life as
mother and housewife; that
she was only fighting to help
her man out, so he could be a
good father and breadwinner.

This socially conditioned
sense of altruism, coupled
with derogatory attitudes to-
wards women, and especially
towards Feminism, produces
in women a dislike of other
women, and thereby a hatred
of themselves.

THE FEMININE PRINCIPLE
As long as this abject image
of Woman remains intact,
women will have no incentive
to attempt a rediscovery of the
feminine principle. This re-
discovery of and reintegration
with the feminine principle is
the crucial point for both the
society and the individual.
The feminine principle of
life, nurturance, balance, and
harmony is the principle of the
earth itself. And it is this
principle which is being des-
troyed in the individual, in our
interpersonal relationships,
and in the earth which has
given us birth and continues
to give us life. The life-giving
energy manifest in the form of
woman, in the feminine
principle, is being destroyed
through the male principle of
power.

“It is no accident that the
second wave of feminism has
coincided with the interest in
the earth’s ecology. Our
ecology is in an almost
unbelievably perilous state.
Balance has been upset to the
point where all our lives are
threatened. The earth, the
eternally feminine, has been
brutally raped. Man’s desire to
“master” nature has become a
mastery of death-force.

This feminine principle—
that which is maternal,
materialist and peaceful (non-
competitive)—must, for the
survival of us all, be reassert-
ed at all levels of interaction.
It is woman, the biological
female, who can reaffirm this
principle through her own
self-knowledge.

THE POLITICS OF GROWTH

Woman in her present
condition does not know who
she is, through either her
history (almost totally de-
stroyed) or her identity, and
hence, cannot begin to
reaffirm what she is (the
feminine principle). The right
of every entity, indeed the
necessity, is to know who and
what we are. Without this
knowledge, no growth is
possible.

Men and women have
reached a point of combative
interaction at which all move-
ment stops. And with it all
growth. And with that, all life.

Both men and women must
assume responsibilities for
eliminating that combative
interaction—for seeing what
is happening at all levels of
interaction.

Presently, every sphere of
government and influence is
controlled by men. Personal
solutions or exceptional ad-
justments to political problems
are not revolution. The solu-
tion is found in uniting with
other women to assert the
integrity of us all. Conscious-
ness-raising is more than the
awareness of one’s condition;
it is the ability to move.

When a woman is just
beginning to establish her
own identity, to explore
herself as a full person in her
own right, rather than as an
appendage of some “other,”
she is on very shaky ground
personally—unsure of any-
thing. Previous to this point,
she has had some identity
(through men, family), if not
her own. Now, with nothing to
rely on, she is more easily
than ever intimidated.

Passivity has been woman’s
accommodation to oppres-
sion on all levels. Through
years of social conditioning to
be passive, it is now impossi-
ble for her to assert her
identity in association with
the male. She is so condi-
tioned to non-assertiveness in
association with men that she
cannot possibly get it
together to assert something
of which she herself is
unsure.

It makes no difference at
this point what the particular
attitudes of men may be,
either positive and encourag-
ing or negative and discour-
aging. She is so well-condi-
tioned and so insecure that
she cannot function in their
presence.

She does not know her
identity and needs her sisters'
parity and support to discover
it. Working together on
projects and in discussion
groups, women start to see
each other not as competitors
or inferior companions, but as
sisters in a common struggle.
Identity with other women on
all levels is the ideal for the
Feminist seeking equality,
self-realization, and reinte-
gration with her feminine
principle. She attains an
increasing sense of self-worth
in an atmosphere of real
equality in which no party has
the social advantage. This
atmosphere is created in
centers and groupings which
are specifically women’s. We
need places to encounter
ourselves and each other and
places to affirm our culture.

The feminine principle must
be reaffirmed by us all. It is
woman who is in touch with
this principle. She must have
a conscious awareness of
this, a firmly established
sense of personal being and
personal worth, a sense of her
own entity—she must know
who she is—before she can
meaningfully contribute to an
evolving society; before she
can effect social change. The
“feminist’s withdrawal as far as
possible from the source of
her oppression can in no way
be construed as a political
cop-out. On the contrary, it is
at this point that the conflu-
ence of the personal/political
(articulated but not sufficient-
ly explored by feminists as a
whole) attains the dimension
of imperative reality, . . .” 3

Liberation is not handed

More on Page 14

4 Announcements ee Big Mama Rag Vol. 3 No. 1

Feminine Principle  
continued from page 13

down from above. We must  
fight our own battles without  

paternalistic assistance. We  

must fight our own oppres-  
sion with our own force. This  
requires a sense of our own  
identity. Because we have  
traditionally been identified  
through men and families  
rather than through ourselves,  
we now need a certain degree  
of withdrawal into ourselves. In  
order to realize a deeply  
personal identity. This means  
women functioning together  
with women in order to know  
the essence of Woman. Only  
as women come to know  
themselves will they be able  
to function successfully in  
coalition with men. “Once  
women have shared the  
process of self-discovery and  
the experience of independent  
decision-making, they are  
ready for the great struggle...  
This is not a struggle against  
men... Women cannot be  
free until men are free... . The  
solutions for women lie in  
solving far-ranging social  
problems. But this involves  
nothing short of revolutionary  
restructuring of the most  
basic institutions in society.”  

RADICAL FEMINISM

As the radical Feminist  
sees it... “The Feminist  
movement generally is still  
basically a ‘reform’ movement  
directed toward bigger and  
better participation in the  
male privilege through equali-  
ty in his system and thus a  
further denial of her own  
identity in the wages of power  
in the same sexual caste  
system which she claims to  
be the source of her depriva-  
tion.” Until sexual oppres-  
sion is eliminated, oppression  
itself will continue regardless  
of any social, political, or  
economic adjustments. Radi-  
cal Feminists do not want  
equal privileges in the existing  
society, do not want equality  
with what maleness is -- with  
aggression, destruction, and  
death. We want to restructure  
society, changing its existing  
definitions of masculine and  
feminine. We see that we  
must begin creating the new  
person within ourselves. We  
want men and women to reject  
their programmed roles and  
question every single aspect  
of this society, their role in it  
and their behavior.

Male supremacy is not a  
personal problem, but a  
pervasive social force. We will  
begin to solve the problem  
when women organize and  
back each other up. That is  
the immediate goal of Femin-  
ism -- to get women together,  
to make them see each other  
as sisters and allies instead of  
competitors for male favors.  
As yet we have no clear vision  
of the new society. That will  
develop with time. But we do  
know that sexism, like racism,  
is incompatible with human  
dignity.

Chicana Welfare Rights

From Page 1

the separation of children
from their families “especially
in the Chicano community.
They are reacting to their own
incompetence and using the
Chicana mother as their
scapegoat,” she continues.
Since the Chicana Welfare
Rights has been using space
temporarily in the Legal Aid
office at 820 Santa Fe, 55
cases have come to the
welfare rights group from
parents who want to institute
legal proceedings to have
their court-separated children
returned to their custody.
Chicano Culture Ignored
Patricia Estrada says that

much which has been written
about the child abuser is
misused, misinterpreted and
misdirected to the Chicana
mother. “No research has ever
been done on Chicano culture
in the areas of child abuse.
Black and Anglo women who
were known abusers were the
groups studied that furnished
profiles for Dr. Henry Kemp’s
book The Battered Child
Syndrome that is used by
hospitals to recognize a child
abuser.

“In the Chicano culture it is
normal for the young Chicana
to help raise her mother's
family. But this past experi-
ence of a Chicana mother who
takes her child to the hospital
for treatment cites her as a
potential child abuser accord-
ing to the prevailing accepted
studies,” she continues.

The separation of a child
from its family, especially if it
is prolonged or repeated
during the child’s first three
years, can have damaging
far-reaching effects according
to John Bowlby, an English
psychiatrist, in his book
Attachment and Loss, Vol. II,
Separation. The child's feeling
of detachment may last an
entire lifetime stunting “the
child's personality, outlook on
life, ability to trust, to love
and eventual independence.”

William Byler, executive
director of the Association on
American Indian Affairs, test-
ified that 25 to 35 percent of
all Indian children are placed
in foster or adoptive homes or
institutions. He said that
social workers who are ignor-
ant of Indian customs “fre-
quently discover neglect or
abandonment where none
exists.”

Estrada Lifestyle

Patricia Estrada came to
Colorado from California
where she worked for seven
years with the problems of
welfare and their effects on
people. She receives welfare,
has one daughter with her in
Denver and two other daugh-
ters and three grandchildren
in California. She is personal-
ly challenging being forced to
go into WIN since she is busy
working with Chicana Welfare
Rights. “I have a job. I’m just
not getting paid for it. I did this
same thing when I was on
welfare in California and was
considered a Case Aid and got
paid for it. I helped to get a
group off the ground to fight
WIN. Then I decided to come
to Colorado, principally to put
my daughter in Escuela
Tlatelolco. The public school
system is so bad. I am also
refusing to accept child care
provided by the Welfare
Department. I am the only one
who can provide child care to
my child because of our
culture. So I should be given
child care money for doing so
this summer.

“The foster homes that
Chicano children are placed in
when they are taken from their
parents do not provide Chica-
no culture. The Welfare
Department says ‘Well, get us
more Chicano foster mothers.’
Bullshit. We all know that we
can’t meet their qualifica-
tions.

“When we win a case in
court by having the child
returned to its home, what
do we really win? There is
always a Stipulation of so
many visits per month by the
visiting nurse and social
worker. That social worker,
their expert Spanish-speaking
Anglo, is the one who causes
the trouble in the first place by
imposing her middle-class
standards on the Chicana.
Having her return to the home
just makes the mother more
defensive.”

Chicana’s Babies Taken

In one case, Ms. Estrada
says, all but two children were
returned to the mother. The
two who were kept had the
lightest skin. “How can she be
a good mother for all of her
children except the two with
the fairest complexions?” She
feels that the prevalence of
birth control and abortion in
the country has caused a
shortage of adoptable child-
ren. “The gringo is no longer
producing the blue-eyed, light
skinned baby. So the Chica-
na’s babies are being taken
away from her.”

“Women who are on wel-
fare,” she continues, “are
forced to go to clinics where
the personnel try to convince
them to use birth control
methods to limit the size of
their families. This is simply
preparing the Chicana for
forced sterilization.

“Living on welfare is a
matter of survival. If there
were any other place to go
other than to welfare, we
would be there. With welfare
money you get only enough to
survive on - enough to exist.
You can't buy soap or toilet
paper with food stamps and
so when your kids are dirty
you are accused of neglecting
them. We need the support of
all women's groups to fight
the Talmadge Amendment. I
would like to see a woman
lawyer working with Chicana
Welfare Rights. We mothers
do this work because it has to
be done. We're doing it for the
agencies that don’t do the job
that they are supposed to be
doing.”

VICTIM

I had just moved into a house. A friend of mine was coming to Colorado and we were going to share the house. I was talking on the phone to her when all of a sudden the line went dead. I thought that we were disconnected but then I realized that the phone was completely dead - I couldn't get the operator or anything. I followed the cord into the hallway where I found it in two pieces. I thought that my cats had chewed it and got some tape to fix it. Then I saw a shadow out of the corner of my eye.

I knew that someone was there so I said “Who is it?” A young, scruffy hippie walked into the living room. He had on an army jacket and blue jeans and wore shoulder-length hair. He stood there with both hands in his pockets. I asked him what he wanted and then I went cold. I thought: don’t mess around with this guy - see what he wants.

I remembered going to a rape conference of Radical Feminists in Philadelphia, where rape victims talked to other women about their assaults and the thing that these women said over and over was that they kept talking to their assailant at first while they tried to piece things together and decide what to do.

All this time my body was cold. I was so scared with fear. He didn’t match my image of a rapist. He looked like an ordinary guy. I pleaded with him not to hurt me - not to kill me. I thought he had a knife in one of his hands. He said “I don’t want to hurt you. I want to love you. Relax, baby, you'll love it, baby.” I thought of escape but realized that I had locked myself into my house by all the safety precautions I had installed. If I screamed, I thought, no one will hear me since it’s so late and maybe it will make him mad and then he will hurt me. The whole time I didn’t know if he was going to kill me or beat me up.

He pulled me into the bedroom and raped me. While he was raping me he grabbed my hand. This was the first time I felt that he wasn’t going to kill me. We were both victims.

He left. I called some friends of mine who came right over. I was very calm but I was hysterical. I wanted to go to the hospital for the examination before I talked to the police. I didn’t want to go to Denver General. I called Rose Memorial but they refused to take care of me in their emergency room. Then I called a private gynecologist to see me. (He is the head of OB-GYN at a big Denver hospital), my friends took me there. All the doctor said while he was there was “disgusting.” Nothing else except when a nurse gave me some DES and I questioned the side effects, he yelled from an adjoining room “that only happens in 1% of all cases.”

"+ Sex Detail Strikes -

He said that I couldn't because there were no policewomen on the detail. RAPE

by Carol Lease

Photo by Babs Nash

LEGISLATION

The second rape that takes place in the courtroom has finally been recognized as possibly the biggest detriment to a woman's reporting her assault. Feminism is creating a consciousness in women that can no longer accept the existence of the rapist whether he be of the body or of the mind. But criminal codes that define rape and traditional courtroom proceedings that determine the treatment of the alleged rapist and his victim have been created by and for a patriarchal society that is blatantly sexist and anti-woman. And it is the confluent conflict of these socio-political forces that have provided adequate motivation for the District Attorney’s office to present proposals on rape and victim compensation that are to be given top priority for legislative action.

Richard Wood, a chief deputy district attorney who represents the office in legislative matters, says that the D.A.'s office is “very open to any input into this legislation.” He has already met with representatives of almost all of the organizations in the Denver area that are concerned with rape.

Although some of the proposals are controversial, he expects to see some legislative action and would like to see the Colorado District Attorney’s Association sponsor the bill but “if they won’t then the D.A.’s office will.” According to Wood, the former chief deputy of Public Defenders of the State supports the bill. The Denver Post and the Rocky Mountain News have come out editorially in favor of the legislation. “I haven't seen any broad opposition to this legislation,” says Wood.

Abolish “Lord Hale”

The first proposal deals with the “Lord Hale” instruction that most judges in Colorado give the jury at the beginning of a rape trial warning them that the charge of rape “is one easily made and once made, difficult to defend against.”

This instruction unnecessarily singles out rape cases for special treatment, for special “comment” on the victim’s testimony and allegation, and in doing so, tends to prejudice the victim's case. The proposal is that this instruction is not to be given in any rape or sexual assault trial.

The second proposal is one which will prohibit admission into evidence in rape or sexual assault cases testimony relating to the victim's previous sexual conduct on the issue of consent or submission except as it may relate to the victim’s prior sexual conduct with the defendant.

“We think that anyone can be raped. A prostitute can be raped. A jury holds it against a woman if she doesn’t have a sexual life they feel she should,” says Wood. “The testimony that a woman can be forced to give concerning her previous sexual life is often highly irrelevant and can go back several years. Some judges won't allow this kind of fishing expedition of a defense attorney but it is still up to the individual judge and it is generally admitted into evidence.

“Half of the victims reported that if they had to do it again they wouldn't report their rape because of the cross-examination that occurs at the preliminary hearing and at the trial.

“The prohibition of such testimony would hopefully have the effect of encouraging victims to report and prosecute rapes and sexual assaults without fear of public humiliation.”

A proposal similar to this was defeated in Iowa but a substitute was passed that stated that if the defense counsel wanted to inquire into the victim's past sexual history he or she would have to do so in court chambers. If the judge felt that the testimony was relevant then that and only that would be brought out in the trial. This idea has been incorporated into the Colorado proposal.

More on Page 18

HELP

The Denver Coalition on Sexual Assault was organized in March of this year for the purposes of education, rape prevention, encouraging women to report rapes, and providing advocacy services for women.

An ACTION grant that was to be used to recruit volunteers for the coalition was initially approved and then delayed due to alleged budget error on the part of Congress.

The coalition was initially formed to meet the increasing demand for a city-wide agency to deal with victimization. When the Southeast Denver Neighborhood Services Bureau opened it was deluged with calls from all over the city concerning rape victimization programs. It didn't have the money, space, or people to work in the entire city. “We were racing all over...trying to do everything...there just weren't enough of us...so the coalition was formed,” says Dr. Katherine Saltzman, victimization coordinator for SEDNSB.

The coalition sponsored four conferences in May and had a city-wide conference in March. There are task forces to deal with specific areas of concern such as counseling, legislation, victim rap, speakers bureau, health care, minority member, and mass media.

“The coalition needs people power,” says Ms. Saltzman. The summer months have a greater incidence of rape compared to other seasons. The general public that composes juries in rape trials and who are traditionally unsympathetic to rape victims need to gain understanding of the entire issue of rape and the victim. The coalition does not take any particular political approach to the rape issue. Screaming and ranting turns people off. We require some kind of political sophistication.

“The coalition has both men and women, some of whom are victims working with it who need periodic rests.”

Almost any organization or institution in Denver that deals with rape (with the exceptions of the Denver Police Department and their Sex Offense Detail) is represented in the Denver Coalition on Sexual Assault. Both the professional from the District Attorney's office and the woman who works all day at home work together on a common concern - rape.

A Child Advocacy Task Force is being formed in the coalition with the intent of making the child the primary concern in any courtroom proceedings. Often parents won't prosecute their child's molester because of fear of the treatment that the child may get in an open courtroom.

The Counseling Task Force is currently working on a pamphlet for preventive counseling, on counseling immediately after the rape and on long-range counseling through professional and victim-rap groups.

In the past the Victim Rap Task Force has taken part in guided fantasy which is a non-threatening way to get in touch with your feelings. Each rap session will have a specific topic or area of discussion.

The Speakers Task Force has people available to speak to any group that requests it.

The Health Care Task Force is investigating the indiscriminate use of DES (diethyl-stilbestrol), the morning-after pill that is given by emergency room doctors to women who have been raped and were using no form of birth control at the time. RAPE

I have never been free of the fear  
of rape. From a very early age, like  
most women, I have thought of rape as  
part of my natural environment—  
something to be feared and prayed  
against like fire or lightning. I never  
asked why men raped; I simply  
thought it one of the many mysteries  
of human nature.

I was, however, curious enough  
about the violent side of humanity to  
read every crime magazine I was able  
to ferret away from my grandfather.  
Each issue featured at least one “sex  
crime,” with pictures of a victim,  
usually in a pearl necklace, and of the  
ditch or the orchard where her body  
was found. I was never certain why the  
victims were always women, nor what  
the motives of the murderer were, but I  
did guess that the world was not a  
safe place for women. I observed that  
my grandmother was meticulous  
about locks, and quick to draw the  
shades before anyone removed so  
much as a shoe. I sensed that danger  
lurked outside.

At the age of eight, my  
suspicions were confirmed. My  
grandmother took me to the back of  
the house where the men wouldn't  
hear and told me that strange men  
wanted to do harm to little girls. I  
learned not to walk on dark streets,  
not to talk to strangers, or get into  
strange cars, to lock doors, and to be  
modest. She never explained why a  
man would want to harm a little girl  
and I never asked.

If I thought for a while that my  
grandmother's fears were imaginary,  
the illusion was brief. That year, on  
the way home from school, a school-  
mate a few years older than I tried to  
rape me. Later, in an obscure aisle of  
the local library (while I was reading  
Freddy the Pig) I turned to discover a  
man exposing himself. Then, the  
friendly man around the corner was  
arrested for child molesting.

An Uncle, A Father

My initiation to sexuality was  
typical. Every woman has similar  
stories to tell—the first man who  
attacked her may have been a  
neighbor, a family friend, an uncle,  
her doctor, or perhaps her own father.  
And women who grow up in New York  
City always have tales about the  
subway.

But though rape and the fear of  
rape are a daily part of every woman’s  
consciousness, the subject is so  
rarely discussed by that unofficial  
staff of male intellectuals (who write  
the books which study seemingly  
every other form of male activity) that  
one begins to suspect a conspiracy of  
silence. And indeed, the obscurity of  
rape in print exists in marked contrast  
to the frequency of rape in reality, for  
forcible rape is the most frequently  
committed violent crime in America  
today. The Federal Bureau of  
Investigation classes three crimes as  
violent: murder, aggravated assault  
and forcible rape. In 1968, 31,060  
rapes were reported. According to the  
FBI and independent criminologists,  
however, to approach accuracy this  
figure must be multiplied by at least a  
factor of ten to compensate for the  
fact that most rapes are not reported;  
when these compensatory mathematics  
are used, there are more rapes  
committed than aggravated assaults  
and homicides.

When I asked Berkeley, Cali-  
fornia's Police Inspector in charge of  

rape investigation if he knew why men  

rape women he replied that he had not  
spoken with “these people and delved  
into what really makes them tick,  
because that really isn’t my job...”  
However, when I asked him how a

The All-American Crime

Susan Griffith

This article was reprinted from  
“Ramparts,” September 1971 with the  
permission of Susan Griffith. A very  
small part has been edited.

woman might prevent being raped, he  
was not so reticent, “I wouldn’t advise  
any female to go walking around alone  
at night ...she should lock her car at  
all times.” The Inspector illustrated  
his warning with a grisly story about a  
man who lay in wait for women in the  
back seats of their cars, while they  
were shopping in a local supermarket.  
This man eventually murdered one of  
his rape victims. “Always lock your  
car,” the Inspector repeated, and then  
added, without a hint of irony, “Of  
course, you don’t have to be paranoid  
about this type of thing.”

The Inspector wondered why I  
wanted to write about rape. Like most  
men he did not understand the  
urgency of the topic, for, after all, men  
are not raped. But like most women I  
had spent considerable time speculating  
on the true nature of the rapist.  
When I was very young, my image of  
the sexual offender was a nightmarish  
amalgamation of the bogey man and  
Captain Hook: He wore a black cape,  
and he cackled. As I matured, so did  
my image of the rapist. Rape, I came  
to believe, was only one of the many  
unfortunate evils produced by sexual  
repression. Reasoning by tautology, I  
concluded that any man who would  
rape a woman must be out of his  
mind.

Rapists as Insane

Though the theory that rapists  
are insane is a popular one, this belief  
has no basis in fact. According to  
Professor Menachem Amir's study of  
646 rape cases in Philadelphia,  
Patterns in Forcible Rape, men who  
rape are not abnormal. Amir writes,  
“Studies indicate that sex offenders  
do not constitute a unique or  
psychopathological type; nor are they  
as a group invariably more disturbed  
than the control groups to which they  
are compared.” Alan Taylor, a parole  
officer who has worked with rapists in  
the prison facilities at San Luis  
Obispo, California, stated the ques-  
tion in plainer language, “Those men  
were the most normal men there. They  

had a lot of hang-ups, but they were  
the same hang-ups as men walking  
out on the streets.”

Another canon in apologetics of  
rape is that, if it were not for learned  
social controls, all men would rape.  
Rape is held to be natural behavior,  
and not to rape must be learned. But  
in truth rape is not universal to the  
human species. Moreover studies of  
rape in our culture reveal that, far from  
being impulsive behavior, most rape is  
planned. Professor Amir’s study  
reveals that in cases of group rape (the  
“gangbang” of masculine slang) 90  
percent of the rapes were planned; in  
pair rapes, 83 percent of the rapes  
were planned; and in single rapes, 58  
percent were planned. These figures  
should significantly discredit the  
image of the rapist as a man who  
suddenly is overcome by sexual needs  
society does not allow him to fulfill.

Far from the social control of  
rape being learned, comparisons with  
other cultures lead one to suspect  
that, in our society, it is rape itself  
that is learned. (The fact that rape is  
against the law should not be  

considered proof that rape is not in  

fact encouraged as part of our  
culture.)

This culture’s concept of rape as  
an illegal, but still understandable,  
form of behavior is not a universal  
one. In her study “Sex and  
Temperament,” Margaret Mead de-  
scribes a society that does not share  
our views. The Arapesh do not “…have  
any conception of the male nature that  
might make rape understandable to  
them.” Indeed our interpretation of  
rape is a product of our conception of  
the nature of male sexuality. A  
common retort to the question, why  
don’t women rape men, is the myth  
that men have greater sexual needs,  
that their sexuality is more urgent than  
women’s. And it is the nature of  
human beings to want to live up to  
what is expected of them.

And this same culture which  
expects aggression from the male  

expects passivity from the female.  
Conveniently, the companion myth  
about the nature of female sexuality is  
that all women secretly want to be  
raped. Lurking beneath her modest  
female exterior is a subconscious  
desire to be ravished. The following  
description of a stag movie, written by  
Brenda Starr in Los Angeles’ under-  
ground paper, “Everywoman,” typifies  
this male fantasy. The movie “showed  
a woman in her underclothes reading  
on her bed. She is interrupted by a  
rapist with a knife. He immediately  
wins her over with his charm and they  
get busy sucking and fucking.” An  
advertisement in the “Berkeley Barb”  
reads, “Now as all women know from  
their daydreams, rape has a lot of  
advantages. Best of all it's so simple.  
No preparation necessary, no plan-  
ning ahead of time, no wondering if  
you should or shouldn't; just whang!  
bang!” Thanks to Masters and  
Johnson even the scientific canon  
recognizes that for the female,  
“whang! bang!” can scarcely be  
described as pleasurable.  
You Loved It!

Still, the male psyche persists  
in believing that, protestations and  
struggles to the contrary, deep inside  
her mysterious feminine soul, the  
female victim has wished for her own  
fate. A young woman who was raped  
by the husband of a friend said that  
days after the incident the man  
returned to her home, pounded on the  
door and screamed to her, “Jane, Jane.  
You loved it. You know you loved it.”

The theory that women like  
being raped extends itself by  
deduction into the proposition that  
most or much of rape is provoked by  
the victim. But this too is only myth.  
Though provocation, considered a  
mitigating factor in a court of law, may  
consist of only “a gesture,” according  
to the Federal Commission on Crimes  
of Violence, only 4 percent of reported  
rapes involved any precipitative  
behavior by the woman.

The notion that rape is enjoyed  
by the victim is also convenient for the  
man who, though he would not  
commit forcible rape, enjoys the idea  
of its existence, as if rape confirms  
that enormous sexual potency which  
he secretly knows to be his own. It is  
for the pleasure of the armchair rapist  
that detailed accounts of violent rapes  
exist in the media. Indeed, many men  
appear to take sexual pleasure from  
nearly all forms of violence. Whatever  
the motivation, male sexuality and  
violence in our culture seem to be  
inseparable. James Bond alternately  
whips out his revolver and his cock and  
though there is no known connection  
between the skills of gun-fighting and  
love-making, pacifism seems suspi-  
ciously effeminate.

In a recent fictional treatment of  
the Manson case, Frank Conroy writes  
of his vicarious titillation when  
describing the murders to his wife:

“Every single person there  
was killed.” She didn’t move.

“It sounds like there was  
torture,” I said. As the words  
left my mouth I knew there was  
no need to say them to frighten  
her into believing that she  
needed me for protection.”

The pleasure he feels as his  
wife’s protector is inextricably mixed  
with pleasure in the violence itself.  
Conroy writes, “I was excited by the  
killings, as one is excited by  

catastrophe on a grand scale, as one is  
alert to pre-echoes of unknown  
changes, hints of unrevealed secrets,  
rumblings of chaos…”

To: The Denver Sustaining Fund

From: The BIG MAMA RAG Collective

The Big Mama Rag Collective has decided that it will not be
returning to the DSF for additional funding in the future.

BMR has also decided to withdraw its membership in the DSF
because we feel that such participation is a drain of our energies
and a waste of time. We will be working with the women’s
community to raise the money we need to continue.

This decision was made by an overwhelming majority of the
women present at our meeting of July 14, 1974.

BMR also wants to state officially that we deeply appreciate the
support and help we received from the many community women
who attended the July 10 meeting of the DSF and from Kathy De
Paolo and Jim McNulty of the Board of Directors of DSF.

THE BOARD

The boys were playing their inherited role as bankers. We
unfortunately fell into the position of answering their absurd
questions of financial projections in similar terms instead of our
own politics - the necessity and vision of a woman's world...

The boys are only interested in supporting their own sense of
self-importance, $400 per month worth while funding the sacred
community $200...

I think the main issues were not dealt with. The underlying
conflict was the leftist male analysis and with it their priorities -
which are the male-defined community and a class analysis which
excludes the real status and experience of women in a sexist
society.

Janet Sergi

When the women from different groups offered support to BMR
at the DSF meeting, I was very excited. While I’ve been in Denver, I
have not seen support and strength to the degree I saw here. I felt
our roots growing together, strengthening the women’s
community. The fear I saw from some other people makes me
wonder how the DSF can presently hope to work with the
community if it is threatened by the community and the potentials
within it! The fund itself has a potential which won't be met until it
deals with its own fear...

Lynda Hartman

THE AUDIENCE

Putting out the newspaper is our first priority and the reason we
originally went to the DSF. Many hours of the staff's time was
spent writing and reworking proposals. It was our feeling that the
constant demand for new proposals was a way of evading the
issue of funds for BMR...

It is hypocritical for groups within the DSF with no working
class basis to criticize BMR for not having that basis. To us,
working class can be defined as living from paycheck to
paycheck. This definition applies to many of the women who
read BMR. It can therefore be stated that we do have ties with the
working class. We doubt that this is true of most of the groups
within the DSF.

—Carol Hansford, Kate Sharp

INTERVIEW |

Local Women’s Band

Says What They Think

Bourge Miller

Beverly Mayes, Sylvia Brady, Sharon Bankes. Three talented women who, as individuals, have come together to form the musical group known as B.S. Sugar and Company. Although the group is now in what they call its “infant stages,” none of the women are strangers to professional music. Beverly and Sylvia, who are sisters, started performing as a duo 11 years ago in California. They have performed together off and on ever since. Two and a half years ago Sharon, who sung with various rock groups, joined them and a close personal and musical bond was formed.

Sylvia, who plays primarily lead guitar, designed and built the sound system they now use. Beverly, who along with Sharon, lends her considerable vocal talents to the group, plays both 12-string and bass guitar.

In a small room in the Capital Plaza Inn, crowded with the activity of preparing for the evening's show, they talked about their music, its message, and its place in raising a larger consciousness in all of us.

BMR: As women, do you generally dress for your audience, giving a great deal of thought to projecting yourself visually in a certain way?

SHARON: We're not trying to get into a bag of three women looking alike, but we are trying to project a group image. Too often the people are maybe attracted to one thing on the stage and not us as a group. It’s like we want...we’re blending in with each other as much as with our music.

BEV: We do wish to produce a very solid front. A very solid group image. The group is a coordination of all of our efforts and we want our group image to be a coordination of all of our efforts.

The women consider that they are a local product musically. Beverly and Sharon had given up music in California because of the ways in which they felt they were being taken advantage of as women. Never quite being able to escape those particular circumstances until recently, they had not performed for ten months prior to this current engagement, preferring to devote their time and energy developing their other talents and strengths.

BEV: The bar scene is very difficult to handle because you constantly have people pulling at you and drawing everything away from you and not really adding anything back.

But they decided to regroup and start again after realizing that music was their deepest interest and because

BEV: ...from an economic standpoint we found that as women we can make more money doing music for a few hours a day.

SYLVIA: We're not being sold as sex objects either in our performances or otherwise. And I think perhaps that’s what was wrong before. We became a product.

BMR: Are there any specific problems or disappointments in marketing your music or yourselves as a group that you feel have grown out of being an all-women’s band?

SYLVIA: There is wonderment on many people's part at first. It’s a relatively new thing. Women coming together in groups to do things has been an unusual thing culturally. I would say we meet reluctance, but not non-acceptance. So far.

BEV: Of course whenever you're doing this type of thing, you’re in essence in a fishbowl and people are going to pick you apart. But from a behind-the-scenes standpoint, when Sylvia and I were together, I felt we were a freak. People would come just strictly to see what two girls were doing.

SHARON: (laughing) Now they come to see what three are doing.

BEV: In some instances we were catered to because we were women. In other instances we met with very strong opposition because we had more or less crossed a barrier.

BMR: Women aren’t supposed to do that sort of thing?

BEV: It’s alright if they do it, but they can’t be good at it.

SHARON: And that can’t be their main objective.

BEV: Not if you're playing an instrument. If you were a singer or a tambourine player or wore a sexy gown, that was fine. You were in your place and limited.

BMR: Don’t you think that’s symptomatic of the culture rather than the music business?

BEV: Yes, but that’s being alleviated. We don’t seem to meet the same opposition now. There is a certain acceptance now that we are women, we do this thing, and do it reasonably well. We’re not put down nor do other people feel threatened by us.

BMR: Don’t you think the women’s movement has helped that?

BEV: Yes, and we've found we appeal to a very wide variety of people... so ultimately we would like to have a message.

BMR: Is there one group of people or a particular audience you ultimately want to speak to through your music?

BEV: I think my message, and I don’t know if Sharon and Sylvia would go along with me completely, would be the total raising of everyone’s consciousness. To help people accept one another as human beings. First. Second, whatever else. I am a person first,

“We have to get our foot in the door first,” says Sharon Bankes, a member of the all-women band known as B.S. Sugar. From left to right: Sylvia Brady, Sharon Bankes, and Beverly Mayes. Photo By Germain Munoz

then a musician, then a woman. I feel that human beings can accept each other as human beings on a more open level. I feel we should look at one another first as persons and then whatever you do. And not put somebody down because they do something different than you or feel differently or act differently. I feel we have to learn to allow space for one another and at the same time being careful that our space doesn't infringe on someone else's.

BMR: That’s a very humanistic philosophy. Are any or all of you strong Feminists?

SHARON: In my own little realm I never had that much difficulty being a woman. I mostly spaced everybody out anyway. Lately, I’ve come to realize the difficulty in being a woman first. First you've got to prove something there. Then maybe they’ll look at your other talents. If they think you have one.

SYLVIA: I have a very humanistic feeling about the whole race. But there are problems women face, I’ve certainly faced a few in my life, that need to be equalized.

BEV: I think there are a lot of inequities in many areas. And until we as human beings can learn to live with one another those inequities will exist. The Feminist Movement, Black, Chicano, Gay Liberation. To me that’s like taking an aspirin when you should be taking penicillin. I think it’s treating the symptoms, not the cause.

BMR: You must be aware that to many women you may already be a certain symbol of success. Another group of women who've “made it.” Do you feel a particular burden for that?

SHARON: No. Absolutely not. I feel like marching for it. But marching for it in my own way, O.K.? I can't go out and march for Gay Liberation, or march for women. I don’t have the time for one thing. But if we ever do make it big, maybe I could be in a better position to help someone or something.

BEV: At this particular moment we don’t have the space to allow for a lot of things we’d like to allow for. To sum up our feeling about the whole thing: you can only raise someone else to your level. So if you're here (indicating waist level) you can only bring them up this high. But if you're here (indicating a level above her head) you can bring them up this high. And so I think our primary effort at this time will be devoted to our music because our music is our method of communication. And it's not all that we want it to be because there's not been time to say everything we want to say. But it will get said.

BMR: So in a way you're making some concessions, in a sense, as a means to an end.

BEV: Right.

SHARON: Exactly.

SYLVIA: I don’t know what you mean by concessions.

BMR: I meant that there are certain things you want to do with your music. The type of music you were doing Saturday night was very middle of the road, popular tunes and so forth, but by and large designed not to offend. Commercial. I assume this is not the music you'd rather be doing, ultimately, but you're doing it for a purpose, i.e. to establish yourselves on a firm foundation to go on and do other things. In that sense I meant making a concession.

SYLVIA: Right. Exactly. That's the concession. I'd hoped you'd done it right.

BMR: There is an immense amount of power that any form of mass communication wields. Advertising is one. Music is really no different. And there is an enormous responsibility that goes with that power. With music, the means of communication are even broader because music is more universal. It transcends the language. Putting myself in your place, and being a strong Feminist, if I had your talents I'd want to use them to further that particular cause. I wonder if you feel the same and if you feel you have to hold yourselves back in some areas so as not to offend now in order to someday...

SHARON: ...we have to get our foot in the door first.

BEV: Right.

BEV: We intend to lay a very concrete foundation. Because of our ideas of Ourself, and I say Ourself as one, because we are as one. Individually we are stronger about some things than we are about others. Sylvia and Sharon are both probably stronger Feminists than I am. But by the same token, with Ourself, yes, I would say we are somewhat Feminist. And yes, I feel we have some messages in that.

SYLVIA: I think what she’s trying to get at... People need to work at all levels for their particular cause each person has their own little thing that suits them to work for. And we would work for something like that (Feminism) because things like that need to be done first before the larger consciousness that Beverly is talking about can be achieved. The Blacks need their freedom first, then they'll be equals and able to function on this great consciousness level... women, I think, need equality, then everybody’ll be able to function a little better. And I think you have to meet those things in very small ways. And that’s the thing we try to do that we aren't making any concessions about. For instance, something that we use when we go on the stage and it’s probably misleading culturally. Everybody does it and if we can do one small thing to change that, we will have done something. We say “Good evening, ladies and gentlemen, welcome” to wherever we are. Beverly said...don’t you think we should be using something like hello everybody, good evening persons, or something like that. To let people know those differences don't exist.

SHARON: That separation.

SYLVIA: And I feel things get done in these small ways. A person who is aware that there is an injustice or an inequality has to try to change it. People are culturally habituated to saying things that are not equal or not just. Habits are really hard to break, and people like us, who have some influence over what goes on... if we start changes, perhaps they'll manifest themselves in other people... Anne-Marie Sandquist was  
interviewed at one of her  
games by two young reporters  
from BMR, Sally Morgenstern

Anne-Marie Goes to Bat

Anne-Marie Sandquist, a 9  
year old girl, is playing  
baseball for the Catholic  
Youth Recreation Association  
(CYRA), but it took a court  
order to do so. The CYRA,  
headed by Thomas E. Wilson  
of 850 Milwaukee St., took  
Anne-Marie off the Most  
Precious Blood Tigers team  
and forfeited two games in  
which she had played. They  
also fired coach Michael  
Ousley, who allowed her to  
play.

Following this, the Sand-  
quists went to court. Jean  
Dubossky, an American Civil  
Liberties Union member, filed  
a suit stating that Anne-Marie  
be allowed to play or the  
CYRA be unable to use  
city-owned parks. Denver Dis-  
trict Court Judge Robert  
Kingsley issued a 10-day  
restraining order on June 19  
which let her play until the  
case went to court.

The restraining order turned  
into a preliminary injunction  
on July 3, when the CYRA  
dropped its case. Anne-Marie is  
now able to participate until  
the end of this season and  
theoretically next season al-  
so. However, any other young  
woman wishing to play in the  
CYRA will also have to go  
through the court procedure.

The Sandquists are not  
satisfied with this, and an  
amended complaint has been  
filed, which will probably be  
heard this winter. While not a  
class action suit, the attor-  
neys hope for a declaratory  
statement that will affect  
more young women than  
Anne-Marie.

The real issue is not  
Anne-Marie Sandquist, but  
whether or not young women  
belong in organized team  
sports such as baseball.

One commonly repeated  
reason to keep young women  
out of team sports is that they  
are not as strong as boys.  
However, studies show that  
both sexes are equal in  
strength. Further, according  
to a Physician and Sports  
article, “Sex and the Little  
League,” women are in fact  
more advanced than men in  
bone development from ages  
8-12, the years of “little  
league” sports. There is also  
no evidence that women are  
more prone to bone breaks  
than men.

Another excuse is that  
traumatic impact, i.e. getting  
hit by a baseball, leads to  
breast cancer. Physician and  
Sports states that there is not  
any evidence to support this  
theory.

It is important that  
the sexes begin competing on an  
equal basis at an early age. It  
seems the only reason young  
women are kept out of team  
sports is male chauvinism on  
the part of directors, coaches,  
and parents.

Albuquerque Woman Shares Feelings on Monogamy

Dear T-,

Entering into this letter has
been most trying. My mind
goes into spasms of thought
leaving me too tired to write it
down, and usually goes too
fast for me to stop it long
enough to communicate it.

I am alone for the first time
in a while. I try not to think of
it as a long time, because I
have a feeling only loneliness
knows how long time can be.
Being alone isn’t as frighten-
ing as it once was. As I have
gotten older I have developed
a few distractions that really
work, but it is more a
confusing situation than any-
thing else. Confusing for its
blatant simplicity. In most
everything else there are at
least two sides to reason out,
why, where, etc., when I am
by myself, there is nothing to
figure out - I am. I might
question do I want to be by
myself, but then I am
confronted with the thought
that maybe I have something
to learn through it. Of course
that seems most logical, but I
guess my energies feel at an
incredible stalemate. The pro-
verbial question ‘why’ is
replaced by ‘what’ a seemingly
healthier question but equally
frustrating.

We are certainly living
through one of the most
difficult periods of evolution
our species has ever encoun-
tered. It sometimes seems that
through all our genius we have
figured ourselves out to be
extinct. No longer do we have
immediate goals to be fulfilled
ritually, filially, maritally, etc.
We are here as free beings to
note our essences, but to do
what with them?

When I think specifically
about our relationships with
one another, our honest
efforts in trying to figure out
our needs and desires, when I
then think about sexual
monogamy, celibacy, polyg-
amy, I become wary about
what we are really doing.
There seems to be a total
awareness between two peo-
ple when they first begin to
learn about each other, of
each other. There are two
living patterns of ideas,
feelings, attitudes, that, for
whatever reasons, try to
merge, move together, not
necessarily compromise
themselves but rather learn to
peacefully co-exist with each
other. All of this takes time,
weeks, months, years, but
when those people have
achieved an understanding
with each other, there is a
time of respite and almost a
honeymoon of sharing and
knowing; but then after that,
what?

It seems that what happens
is that the result has been one
finding someone else to be
alone with, depending upon
what those individuals want.
It can be a time of incredible
creativity or it can be a time of
frustration. That is where
monogamy sometimes ends
and the cycle begins anew,
flavored slightly with either
the original two not being with
each other, or both trying to
maintain the peacefulness
they've found with each other,
as well as attempting to
expand it with others.

The way I have seen and
experienced the latter has
meant an incredible amount of
pain with the results being
shattering. I am going through
it now and feel angry about
the waste of energy and
denial. I guess what I believe
is that the only time we can
honestly deal with a polyga-
mous situation is only after we
are sure that we can live with
ourselves first, and one other
happily, only then do we know
honestly what we are expand-
ing. Polygamy as it happens
now is just another way for us
to be distracted from whom
we are, in my opinion a
dangerous distraction.

With love and strength and
smiles......
KAREN
