We Got Your Number...

In July, Big Mama Rag, who has been a member of the Denver
Sustaining Fund since that group's inception, approached the
fund with her first request ever for funding. Through the events

that followed, we found the DSF not to be radical (going to the 

roots) in its analysis of society, economics or its own functioning.
Rather, it is a reformist group whose interest is in wresting power
from that part of the system presently in control, in order to hold it
for another party of that same system, Patriarchy. The age-old
struggle of the sons against the fathers; both against the women.

As requests for funding by various groups were reviewed, it
became apparent that decision-making was based more on politics
than on need. Our politics did not fit the “radical” mold. Another
version of Animal Farm. The “radicals” have a stake, become the
reformists, become the capitalists. To wit: The “boys on the Left”
(a term borrowed from Robin Morgan) were more concerned with
whether BMR could show a profit (this information was not
sought from other groups applying) than with whether BMR would
continue to exist in this community, without DSF support. BMR
tried to point out that our purpose for existing is an evolutionary
Feminist revolution — not the amassing of money. We are
concerned with communication, not profits.

While some 50 women, representing individuals and women’s
groups with memberships of close to 1000, turned out to show the
need for and support of a women’s paper in Denver, some DSF
members questioned our base of support in the community! It's
apparent the DSF sought evidence of our support not from among
the people, not from among the women's community, but from
within its own narrow vision. Once again, the definition of reality
was that which is male-dominated and controlled.

Because the women of this community asserted themselves
and sought to influence the DSF, they were labeled Mau-Mau, both
by a member of the Tenant's Union and later by the Straight Creek
Journal. Interesting. That people supposedly dedicated to the
elimination of oppression—sexist, racist, or political—used a
term designating a Black uprising (one that should have a positive
connotation) as a put-down. It can be so only if one is in
allegiance with the system whose foundations are being
challenged.

Dealing with such bigotry is a waste of our time and a
dissipation of our energies. “We will not attempt reform of our
oppressors while women are in such need. All women. We are
telling you, yes, there are working women here, yes there are
Lesbians, yes, there are heterosexuals, yes, there are children,
yes, there are Blacks and Chicanas, yes, there are differences in
our oppression, but we are all oppressed first because we are
women, and we know it. Yes, we are looking to our own
oppression. And yes, we've got your number: a revolution which
ignores the needs of women will produce a society which ignores
the needs of women. The freedom of women is a world to be
fought for.

An Open Letter to the Women’s Movement

ED. Note: The following open letter to the Women's movement concerns a lawsuit which was brought against Robin Morgan, Random House, and Vintage Books by Lucinda Cisler because of allegations that her bibliography was plagiarized in Sisterhood is Powerful. This lawsuit is depleting the money in the Sisterhood fund which ordinarily goes to women’s groups. At the beginning of this month Big Mama Rag attempted to contact Ms. Cisler by writing to her and asking if she wished to tell us about her side of the story before we published any of the criticism concerning her action. She did not respond and so we can only print one

Sisterhood, we say, is powerful. It is springtime, and while the male politics of the sixties grow less relevant in their rhetoric to people’s lives, women move on. This is a period of rapid expansion and outreach for the Women’s Movement as Feminism finds form in new health centers, community women’s centers, women’s studies programs, rape crisis lines, and similar projects which are opening and thriving in every city in the country. As we resurrect/create a female culture, so we find ourselves continuing to walk the tightrope above a crevice of self-destruction. We live constantly with the internal threat of that “woman-hating” characteristic to which we all are socialized, infecting and ultimately destroying all we are trying to build. The often vicious internecine warfare of the Women's Movement is still a present enemy.

But SISTERHOOD IS POWERFUL; it is our strength; it is the title of an anthology that introduced thousands of women to the Women’s Movement; it is a Fund—or rather, it was a Fund. It was an access to money for women’s projects supported by all the royalties from the book Sisterhood is Powerful. The Fund was established by Robin Morgan, who compiled and edited the anthology, to provide financial support for Feminist projects and actions. There are women who have grown rich on the movement. Robin Morgan is not one of them. Rather than profiteering from Feminism, she gave an effective example of real sisterhood in creating the Fund.

It was the first such Feminist “foundation,” and for four years it has given money to a wide spectrum of women's groups. Many of you reading this will know from first-hand experience that funding has gone to women’s centers and health projects, newspapers and anti-rape groups, Lesbian groups, welfare mothers, women’s cultural projects, third world Feminist groups, abortion campaigns, and more. The book royalties to date have approximated $40,000, yes, forty thousand dollars. And there has been no male-style “politicking” in the form of dissemination—groups requested funds, and the checks went out.

Only one example: Two years ago, when the Los Angeles Feminist Self-Help Health Clinic was busted, the Sisterhood Fund sent $2,000 for their legal defense. But two months ago, when three midwives of the Santa Cruz Birth Center were busted also for “practicing medicine without a license”—which will mean a heavy court case challenging the California law against midwifery and the concept of childbirth as a disease—the Sisterhood Fund could do nothing. Because the Fund is being destroyed through a lawsuit brought by a woman, Lucinda Cisler.

Contending that the bibliography at the back of Sisterhood Is Powerful was plagiarized from her “Women: A Bibliography,” Cisler is suing Robin Morgan, Random House, and Vintage Books for a minimum of $300,000. (One might ask: Will she turn it back to the Movement as Robin Morgan did the royalties? But then, again, who ever heard of plagiarizing a bibliography? Many women all over the country compiled bibliographies before or at the same time Cisler did. Similarities in all these bibliographies abound, as anyone doing research in Women's Studies well knows—so the question is really rhetorical.) In addition, Cisler is attempting to get an injunction to stop the printing of Sisterhood is Powerful. The standard book contract requires that all legal fees in such a suit against the publisher are to be absorbed from royalties. Morgan and the fund are powerless to stop this. So, while women in Santa Cruz are fighting to survive the man’s courts, the lawyers hired by Random House are depleting our fund at the rate of approximately one hundred dollars an hour because Cisler is suing.

Robin Morgan, when first faced with the suit, offered Lucinda Cisler the opportunity to settle this within the Women’s Movement, by the establishment of a Feminist court, or by Feminist mediation. But seeking to play a male game by male rules on male turf and with a male lawyer, Cisler proceeded on her original course.

As a result, legal fees for the suit have presently depleted the fund until at least 1976, and if Cisler persists into court the fees will destroy the Fund utterly. And, if Cisler is successful in stopping the printing of Sisterhood is Powerful, the book, a substantive part of the literature of our new and growing culture and a basic women's studies text will go out of print.

Some large questions beg to be answered:

Why?

Why did Cisler wait four years to take this action?

Why did she never approach Morgan personally?

How on earth is it possible to plagiarize a bibliography?

Why is such an apparently futile action being taken when its only effect can be to destroy part of us—the Women’s Movement?

If sisterhood is powerful it must be beyond self-destructiveness. If this case cannot be terminated very soon, the fund is not merely depleted for two years but destroyed permanently, a valuable book will be lost, and another sister will have been taken to the stake by one who claimed to be our own.

We have written this open letter for two reasons: We thought the Women's Movement has had a right to know what is happening with our sister, our book, and our fund. We would also welcome support, including any ideas or statements of solidarity. They can be sent to: Kathy Barry, 2327 J Street, Sacramento, California 95816.

It’s a long way from the self- and sister-lacerating realities of today, to our Feminist vision. But Sisterhood can be powerful, if we dare make it so.

Kathleen Barry, Women’s Advocate - Mary Daly, Feminist philosopher - Adrienne Rich, Feminist poet - Joan Hoff Wilson, Feminist historian.

P.S. The Cisler bibliography is available for $.50; write to Lucinda Cisler, 165 West 91st Street, New York, New York 10024.

NWPC Cont. Evokes Response

Libby Denham

The events of the National Women’s Political Caucus conference held June 27-29 in Wichita, Kan., brought strongly to mind a Happening at a Michigan college I once attended.

In both instances, the depth of understanding of each participant was the measure of the benefit received. The good listener at the conference must have deepened her awareness of the female plight and some of the ways to alleviate it. The good speaker would have enjoyed the satisfaction of having influenced the thinking of a group.

At a national conference, such as this, no legislation can be enacted but some 600 delegates can, and did, express themselves in all the areas of the struggle for women's rights.

The ordinary functions of sleeping, eating and drinking were temporarily suspended as participants attended workshops designed to “awaken, organize and assert” women's political power, responded to intense discussions of Feminist issues from sisters from all over the country and then heard the broader issues of Women’s Liberation defined anew by Congresswoman Bella Abzug, Ms. Editor Gloria Steinem and others. A lot of mileage can be gotten from hot baths instead of hot dinners, cheese, crackers and coffee cake.

In the worst tradition of group action, the present financial plight of the National Caucus was left unresolved, unless a miraculous generosity develops among state caucuses — and soon. The national body says it should have 60 percent of its budget financed by membership dues — and suggests at least $10 per member. A determined group of “grass rooters” wants the organization to continue to distribute its political expertise for only $1 per member, citing benefits of broader membership. NWPC has been able to pay only salaries and postage for the past two months.

The better aspects of group function, I thought, were demonstrated on the day of the shooting of Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr. on the last morning of the meetings.

Chairman Sissy Farenthold made the announcement at the plenary session. The full details of the tragedy were not known and most assumed the civil rights leader's mother had also been a victim of a racially-motivated radical.

An adjournment was announced while a Caucus formed to prepare an expression of sympathy. Consensus was hampered by the earnest desire of one member to make specific reference to racially-motivated violence.

The longest day of the year. That's what June 21 was.  
Summer Solstice. From sol - the sun, and sistere - to cause to  
stand still. And sisters from Albuquerque, Tucson, Denver, Min-  
nesota, Missouri, New York and various locations in between kept  
arriving throughout that long day, celebrating the solstice. Mak-  
ing that weekend stand still in a peaceful out-of-the-way camp-  
ing area in New Mexico.

A place marked with pine trees and swimming holes,  
streams, water fountains here and there, campfires, children, two  
hundred women with their hands joined singing: “We are one  
in the spirit, we are one in the soul, and we know that unity will  
some day unfold, and we know we are sisters by our love.” The  
sounds of women telling fortunes, reading poems to each other,  
the freedom of women together - in various stages of dress and  
undress and body paint and bare skin. The seeds of a world some-  
day guided by the power and love of women.

On the evening of the Solstice there was music and  
dancing until the sun set. Maureen shaking the tambourine. Judy  
and Sharon strumming homemade bass drums, fashioned from  
wash tubs and rope and broom handles. Gail plucking a banjo.  
Congo drums of bone and hide. Guitars, whoops. Shouts.

Chants. Dancing in circles. Dancing hand-in-hand. Alone or to-  
gether, hugging the earth with our feet and our bodies. Not the

kind of music you'd see in a bar, but dancing that came from some  
place deep inside each woman's soul. Fishtailing, spiraling out-  
ward, sketching patterns on the sky with arms and hips and knees  
moving back and forth steadily - slow or fast but always in time  
with the music each woman heard herself.

Strong Amazon voices, singing the songs that tell  
the story of woman. Sharing our evening meals together. Bathing  
together in the small pool under the waterfall. Tai Chi, movement,  
Yoga, massage. Women with their speculums, seeing their  
cervixes for the first time. "Smile if you're a Lesbian.”

A peyote ceremony underneath the pine trees.  
Psychic Feminism; feeling in tune with the Great Goddess  
and with our Indian sisters who once roamed the ground where  
we stayed. Attempting to call down our sisters in outer space,  
sighting their spaceships. Talk of the matriarchy and of its return,  
of parthenogenesis, of Amazon culture.

Feminist astrology, learning about herbs for our own  
health. Walking arm in arm. No one can walk up to each other  
without hugging, smiling, laughing. Happiness is contagious!

Women together without men can do anything,  
‘Amazon nation here in the mountains. If only for a short while.  
A precursor of what is to come!

Resistance to CR

Irene Peslikis

Thinking that our man is the exception and, therefore, we are the exception among women.

Thinking that individual solutions are possible, that we don't need solidarity and a revolution for our liberation.

Thinking that Women's Liberation is therapy. This, whether or not you belong to the organization, implies that you and others can find individual solutions to problems, for this is the function of therapy. Furthermore, the statement expresses anti-woman sentiment by implying that when women get together to study and analyze their own experience it means they are sick, but when Chinese peasants or Guatemalan guerillas get together and use the identical method they are revolutionary.

Thinking that some women are smart and some women are dumb. This prevents those women who think they're smart and those women who think they're dumb from talking to each other and uniting against a common oppressor.

Thinking that because we have an education privilege and can talk in abstracts we are somehow exempt from feeling oppression directly and talking about it honestly and, therefore, think of personal experience as something low on the ladder of values (class values).

Thinking that women consent to their own oppression (or that anyone does for that matter). This is a statement which puts the blame on the oppressed group rather than on the oppressor class which ultimately uses brute force to keep the oppressed where they are. It is an anti-women and anti-people statement.

Thinking that only institutions oppress women as opposed to other people. This implies that you have not identified your enemy, for institutions are only a tool of the oppressor. When the oppressor is stopped he can no longer maintain his tools and they are rendered useless. Present institutions and our feelings about them should be analyzed in order to understand what it is we want or don't want to use in the new society.

Thinking in terms of them and us. This implies that you are setting yourself off or apart from women (the people). In doing this you neglect to recognize your own oppression and your common interests with other people, as well as your stake in revolution.

Thinking that male supremacy is only a psychological privilege with “ego” benefits as opposed to a class privilege with sexual and economic benefits. The former implies a considerable amount of individual variation among men, therefore permitting you to find an individual solution to the problem.

Thinking that the relationships among men and women are already equal and thus immersing yourself in utopian fantasies of free love in spite of the fact that the objective conditions deny it. Love between men and women, free or unfree, is millennial, not real, and if we want it we will have to struggle for it.

Thinking you can educate the people. This implies that you are educated and you will get a revolution going by teaching other people what you know. Education does not bring on revolutions; but consciousness of our own oppression and struggle might. Unfortunately, formal education and political consciousness do not usually coincide.

Even formal education in Marxism-Leninism tends to make people think that they know more than they really know. When we think of what it is that politicizes people it is not so much books or ideas but experience.

Reprinted from Voices of Women’s Liberation, Signet Books, 1970.

The problem of sexual assault is one which affects us all, whether directly or indirectly, no matter what our age, race, or life-style might be. Sexual assault is not limited to the rape of young women, but includes attacks on infants as well as senior citizens. The following information was collected from various resources. These facts are not pleasant, but it is important that we all become familiar with them.

* Denver now has the highest reported rate of forcible rape in the country (52.1 per 100,000 population — FBI Uniform Crime Report.)

* The majority of victims are single, Anglo females between the ages of 16 and 34 (71% Anglo, 15% Black, 11% Chicano — Denver Anti-Crime Council, The Crime of Rape.)

* There has been a 121% increase in the number of forcible rapes that occurred from 1960 to 1970. In 1970 a forcible rape occurred once every 14 minutes in the United States (FBI Uniform Crime Reports.)

* The true rate of rape may be three to four times higher than police figures show because of the reluctance of many women to report the crime (National Opinion Research Center, University of Chicago.)

* Most rapes in Denver are stranger to stranger. In 67.1% of the cases studied between July 1970 and June 1972, the victim and the offender were total strangers to each other (The Crime of Rape in Denver, DACC.)

* According to the DACC report most victims (50.4%) attempted some sort of resistance, the most frequent being physically frightening off the attacker or verbally trying to dissuade him (The Crime of Rape in Denver.)

A Woman's Place

Janet Sergi

Unfortunately, there are two forms of rape: physical rape and mind-rape. These two man-made inventions serve as political terrorism over every woman in this patriarchy. They keep every woman in her place, that is in the shadow of every man.

Physical rape is when any man has intercourse with any woman without her total and free choice. It can and does occur at any time, in any place, by any man, friend, lover, husband, father, neighbor, or stranger.

From early childhood, every girl is socialized to forget herself and serve the interests of all males in her family. This conditioned response of submission of the female to the male sets the stage for physical rape. This background of female submission is the first and most pervasive form of mind-rape. A girl child in the patriarchy has no independent self-definition.

Thus she is the perfect prey for the rapist. She is mind-raped out of a consciousness of self.

So to go one step farther, most acts of sexual intercourse are rape: the submission of the female without free self-consciousness choice. So most men are rapists, and all women are rape victims.

Mind-rape is the permanent violation of our woman soul in the patriarchy. When we walk down the street and think of the danger of physical rape, we may avoid their occurrence, but in the process we are being thoroughly mind-raped. This second form of mind-rape occurs when we spend our psychic energy thinking about men, i.e., the rapist, instead of thinking about our woman soul, or our self-created identity. Mind-rape is the impingement of a male identity on the female consciousness.

Mind-rape is the loss of the freedom to be ourselves. Freedom for women equals our women friends, our art projects, our pets, our children, our lovers, our developing woman's culture, our poetry, and our mother earth. We are the unconscious participants in our own mind-rape when we unthinkingly look to men for our sense of self-worth, or as a source of income, or for protection, or as the only source of sexual intimacy. Mind-rape is the search for male approval.

Here is the precise point where we can begin to stop the patriarchy’s cycle of physical rape and mind-rape. If we stop looking towards men to protect us from their own institution, Physical Rape, we kill two birds with one stone. We take into our hands the task of education and defending ourselves against the traditional rapist on the streets. When we very consciously choose when and whom we make love to -- we stop the cycle of automatic submission to males. When we develop our own culture, we begin the task of undoing the patriarchy. When we create our own self-definitions we begin to define a woman's place.

Our woman vision is of that place where the mental or physical dominance of one sex over the other is unthinkable. In a woman's place, the bodies and souls we are born with will be honored, not violated. In a woman's place, we ourselves will create who and what we are. A woman's place is simply everyone's place.

Women and Health

Pat Sexton

Itching, scratching, burning... va-  
ginal infections are a pretty common  
happening for most women. Not only  
are they physically irritating, but they  
can also cause premature bankruptcy  
if you have to plunk down $25 for a  
check-up and $7 for a prescription  
every time they come up. All the more  
reason to learn to diagnose and cure  
them yourself! The following informa-  
tion is designed to familiarize you with  
the three most serious infections (not  
including syphilis and gonorrhea,  
which are serious!), their diagnosis  
and ways of curing them (both through  
prescribed medicine and so-called  
“home-remedies”).

In order to diagnose your own  
infection you will have to have a few  
items: a speculum (the instrument a  
gynecologist uses to spread open the  
walls of the vagina for a look inside;  
get one through your local self-health  
clinic or through a medical supply  
house), a mirror, a flashlight, some  
clean cotton swabs, a glass slide (or  
you can use the mirror’s surface),  
and... if you really want to get  
technical, you can have a microscope  
on hand.

Taking the speculum in one hand,  
holding the bills closed, and spread-  
ing the lips of the labia with the other,  
slowly insert the bills into the vagina.  
If this is hard or uncomfortable put a  
little K-Y surgical jelly on the blades  
(NOT Vaseline which can alter the  
environment of the vagina and allow  
infections to occur).

Using the Speculum

After the blades are in, turn the  
speculum so that the handle is facing  
up. Now find the thumb press lever  
and push it in and down until you hear  
it click. The speculum will then be  
open. Using the mirror with one hand  
and flashing the light on the mirror  
with the other, so that light is  
reflected into the vagina, you can now  
see the interior of the vagina.

Using one of the cotton swabs,  
scrape off some of the secretion  
inside. By smearing this onto a slide  
or the mirror’s surface, you will be  
able to gauge the texture, color, and  
consistency of the secretion and  
hopefully tell what type of infection  
you have.

Let’s start with a description of what  
normal mucus looks like. Your normal  
discharge will be transparent or  
slightly milky. When it is dry it may  
look yellow. This discharge causes no  
inflammation or irritation and varies in  
amount throughout your cycle. It will  
either have an inoffensive smell or no  
smell at all. The normal vagina is acid  
and contains many types of bacteria  
which keep out harmful germs. If you  
douche too much or use vaginal  
sprays and deodorants, these can  
destroy the bacteria and upset the  
natural balance of the vagina.

Now for the infections. We'll start  
with:  
1. Yeast - fungus, monilia, or candida.

Symptoms: You will find itching  
and inflammation of the vulva and  
outer vagina, which will just about  
drive you nuts! The discharge, when  
spread out on the slide, may be light  
or very heavy and thick like cottage  
cheese and stringy (this is more  
common) and will smell rather yeasty,  
like baking bread. There will be white  
patches of the yeast on the walls of  
the vagina, and if you scrape them off,  
there will be red raw patches  
underneath.  
Treatment: In order to relieve the  
itching on the outside, you can paint  
the whole area with gentian violet. It's  
a mess but it relieves the pain. The  
best and fastest way to get rid of yeast  
is by using Mycostatin suppositories,  
but these can only be obtained with a  
prescription (which means you will  
have to go to a doctor, who will  
probably insist that he check you over  
before he writes the prescription,  
therefore costing you mucho bread). If  
you have any friends who are doctors  
or druggists, have them get it for you.  
The suppositories should be inserted  
in the morning and at night for a full  
ten days to make sure that you  
completely get rid of the infection.  
Other Remedies

There is also a jelly called Propion  
Gel that you can put in once a day with  
an applicator. If the infection is not  
large you can sometimes cure it by  
putting in a tablespoon of plain yogurt  
(the type you can buy at the market). I  
have also heard (although not  
personally tried) that tea douche made  
from two herbs - osha root and golden  
seal - will sometimes completely cure  
a yeast infection. I would be interested  
in hearing from other sisters about  
other herbal remedies.

Circumstances that can make yeast  
infections easier to get:

1. Diabetes - causes sugar in the  
urine and extra carbohydrates in the  
vaginal walls, both of which provide  
good food for the yeast and help it to  
grow.

2. Antibiotics - when used anywhere  
in the body to fight infection, they  
also kill the bacteria in the vagina.

3. Pregnancy, birth control pills,  
bad diet, obesity.

7. Wearing nylon underwear keeps  
the vulval area warm and moist and  
yeast love warmth!

- Marriage No Excuse -

The third proposal is to redefine the
term “spouse” as it is used in
Colorado’s rape and sexual assault
statutes. The current law denies a
woman the equal protection of rape
and sexual assault laws if the
perpetrator happens to be her husband
and even though she may be living
apart from him.

There have been two suggested
alternative proposals to change this
law. One would simply delete the
words “not his spouse” wherever they
appear in the statutes. This would
make a rape or sexual assault a proper
charge in any case. The other
alternative would define the word
“spouse” in such a way as to exclude
from the definitivity a person living
separate and apart from the perpetra-
tor.

“There is no reason that if someone
marries, they should lose the protec-
tion of the law,” says Wood.

The fourth proposal would allow
evidence into a rape or sexual assault
case that would show a common plan,
scheme, design, motive as with the
rapist who consistently leaves identi-
cal evidence such as fingerprints or
exhibits a common behavior with each
victim. Wood says that by case law in
Colorado it appears to be the general

practice that any criminal
proceedings except rape or sexual
assault, may seek to introduce
evidence linking the defendant to the
case by establishing that, on other
occasions, the defendant acted within
a pattern.

Such evidence may be prejudicial
but it is difficult to understand why it
would be any more prejudicial in rape
cases than in robberies and homicides.
Again, continues Wood, there is no
reason for special treatment for rape
defendants.

Victim Compensation

The fifth proposal provides for
compensation for rape victims. The
state would finance the costs of
emergency and follow-up treatment
for victims of such violent crimes as
rape, assault, homicide and robbery.
Allowable costs would include abor-
tion, pregnancy, childbirth, and
psychiatric treatment. Burial costs for
homicide victims would be covered.

This proposal may be the most
controversial, admits Wood, and will
probably undergo major change in the
legislature. To help reduce the
possibility of fraud, state financial
assistance would be contingent upon
the victim’s cooperation with the
evidence of the bona fides of the
charge. Originally this proposal read
that the victim had to cooperate in the
apprehension and prosecution, if any,
of the alleged offender or offenders. It
was changed due to a suggestion
made by Pam Gleason, a member of
the Colorado Democratic Women’s
Caucus, that women should not be
forced to subject themselves to the
cross-examination tactics currently
being used by defense counsel in
court in order to receive the medical
and psychiatric care that they may
need.

Some discussion of this proposal
both at the District Attorney's office
where the proposals were initially
made public and at a recent meeting of
the Denver Coalition of Sexual Assault
centered around making the convicted
offender work while being held in
prison receiving a decent wage to
reimburse the victim (or the State) for
the expenses resulting from his crime,
and his family while he is in prison
that must often receive welfare while
he is being held.

Ms. Gleason also proposed that the
word “rape” be abolished since rape is
defined by penetration of a penis into
a vagina; it is a crime that applies only
to women as victims and is a sexist
term. Rape is not a sex crime, she
continues, but a hostility crime.
Non-penile penetration is still rape
although it is categorized as deviant
sexual intercourse and is considered a
class 4 felony with a shorter sentence
than rape which is a class 3 felony.
Ms. Gleason feels that any kind of
forced genital contact on either side
constitutes a sexual assault.

The D.A.’s office will support
changing and deleting the word “rape”
from statutes and replacing it with
“sexual assault” with various degrees.
Although it would only be calling a
rose by another name, it would still be
a better name, says Pam Gleason. The
humiliation and trauma connected to
the word rape and aimed at the victim
of the crime would hopefully be
lessened.

This legislation is not in final form,
says Wood. Draft copies of it are being
circulated for recommendations from
anyone who is interested.

WOMEN AGAINST RAPE

WAR (Women Against Rape) has
been formed as a result of the
self-protection classes for women
offered through the Aurora Police
Department. The present goal of the
group, according to Jackie Mitchell, a
graduate of the class, is to present a
petition concerning legislation on the
treatment for convicted rapists to
state legislators.

The petition demands that rape
statutes be changed from a criminal
status to a mental disorder status.
First offenders, according to Ms.
Mitchell, would be treated until cured.
Offenders who have been convicted
more than once would have to remain
in the facility and receive treatment
commensurate with the offense.

Ms. Mitchell cites the study done by
Menachem Amir published in his book
Patterns in Forcible Rape which
concludes that rape is a common form
of learned behavior and is also a
“mental thing.” So instead of being
put into a prison where the offender
receives practically no treatment
whatsoever and usually comes out
hating women even more than before
he should be treated. Ms. Mitchell
would also like to see the government
stop wasting money on projects
studying the perspiration of the
Aborigine and start spending money
on mental health at places like the
state hospital which is understaffed
and underpaid.

She would like to see the federal
government establish one institution
in the U.S. to handle all rapists in the
country and find out what is causing
rape and cure it.

WAR intends to contact NOW for
their support of the petition and will
be working with the Denver Coalition
on Sexual Assault. WAR will be
gathering signatures for the petition
from August 15 through August 31st at all
major shopping areas and will then
send the signatures and petitions to
every state representative in Colorado.

SOUTHEAST DENVER

The only victimization program in
Denver is at the Southeast Denver
Neighborhood Services Bureau
(SEDNSB). The bureau is funded
through the Denver Anti-Crime Coun-
cil’s High Impact Program.

The SEDNSB bureau deals primarily
with youthful offenders and youth-
oriented planning for the southeast
area along with offering support and
counseling programs for victims as
well as to provide general public
education and organization for the
prevention of victimization. The
efforts of public education are
directed primarily towards Capitol Hill

the city.

Victimization Coordinator who has
been instrumental in the formation of
the 24-hour crisis line. “The victim has
been ignored while the offender has
gotten all the attention and funded

referrals and have professional psy-

death. Broken bones, inability to get
to the store and medical expenses can
drastically change and even ruin a
woman’s life.

__Denver Doing Enough? |

From Page 10

A policeman at one of the department's storefronts said that the two
most disgusting crimes to an officer are child molestation and
rape. In both “helpless” people are concerned. It is easy for them
to see the effect of assault on a child, but for a woman to be raped
is something a woman is expected to bear.

If the Denver Police Department would like to improve its image
with the women’s community in Denver they will have to become
aware of their own sexist attitudes towards women. There is a hell
of a difference between what the police say it believes and what it
actually does. There have been reports from rape victims that a
married detective on the Sex Detail has visited them at their
homes on unofficial business - showing up at their front doors
complete with a bottle of wine to discuss some of the heavier
aspects of rape.

If the detail needs some consciousness-raising I suggest that
they attend some groups being organized by this paper, and not
invite themselves to the homes of rape victims.

Women do not need the “protection” of men whether through
law enforcement agencies (defenders of the morals of “good”
women) or through scare tactics for women to stay off the streets
at night or to avoid wearing attractive clothes.

We are not second-class citizens. We will not be clinging,
cringing, terrified females. We will not be degraded because we
are women. We will be free. We are not the property of men that
needs to be protected and revenged. As long as women are treated
as property in this society its institutions will perpetuate this
attitude.

The Coalition
The Coalition on Sexual Assault is rapidly dissipating into a
do-nothing, say-nothing group due to an exodus (purge?) of
women who want to take more radical steps towards dealing with
rape.

It seems that many in the coalition are worried about its
credibility (read: image) in the Denver professional community of
law enforcement and treatment, etc. There are endless ways to
help people change their attitudes towards rape, but the coalition
is working on just a very few.

The reason for a Coalition, it seems, is to provide a point for
different energies, perspectives, ideas to work together for a
common purpose. It is unfair and typically “male” to create a
structure that allows a few at the top to make decisions affecting
the whole “for the good of the company.”

The coalition does not need to support men to get things done.
More could be accomplished if the Coalition would forget about
working in the system exclusively, and think about women, their
positions in this society, and the part rape plays in that
subjugation.

The D.A.

The District Attorney's booklet on rape is slick and reminds all
of its readers that “the best way to protect your body is by using
your head.” What it really says is the best way to remain “unde-
filed” is to stay home behind locked doors, and keep your mind
behind locked doors. Yet statistics indicate there is a 50-50
chance that if you are attacked it will be in your home behind your
locked doors.

Rape isn’t a crime of passion. It is a crime of hate and political
terrorism against women. It is the ultimate manifestation of the
colonization of men over women. Rape is not the isolated behavior
of a few sick men. Psychological profiles indicate that the typical
rapist is the boy next door. Rape will exist until our bodies are
truly our own, until men cannot claim to own women.

Rape Research

Dr. Carolyn Hursch is a co-director
of a research project at the Violence
Research Unit, a division of Psychiatric
Services at Denver General
Hospital. The project is gathering
interviews of women who have been
raped and of women who have
successfully resisted sexual assault.

The interview is completely confi-
dential. A woman may use an
assumed name or just an initial. The
experience of any woman, no matter
how long ago it was that she was
attacked, is needed for the research.
The assault “isn’t something that a
woman forgets. Sometimes it’s easier
to talk as time passes,” says Dr.
Hursch.

A woman need not have reported her

rape to take part in an interview. This
research, when completed, will
hopefully provide a means toward
victim support, offender evaluation
and treatment. It may reveal more
successful means of resisting a rape
and show approaches of rapists.

Dr. Hursch is critical of the Denver
Police Department: “there is not as
comprehensive a preventive approach
as other cities have with rape.
Policewomen are not used as decoys.
The Police Department is not going
out after the problem.”

Any woman who would like to take
part in the research can call 623-8252.

Book Reviews

Trilogy. Diane Wakoski.
Doubleday. $2.95.
Janet McReynolds

This is a reissue of the first
three volumes of Diane
Wakoski’s poems, which have
previously been unavailable
except on the rare book
market, with an extremely
useful introduction by the
author. The collection, con-
sisting of Coins & Coffins,
Discrepancies and Apparitions
and The George Washington
Poems offer valuable
insights into the poet's later
work, as well as being a trip in
themselves.

Diane has always been
conscious of her position as a
female in a man's world. A
feeling of displacement and
alienation permeates these
poems. Unlike Adrienne Rich
and Anne Sexton, who both
seem at home in the feminine
side of their psyches, Diane
seems caught in a perpetual
conflict between the feminine
and masculine sides of her
mind, unsure of her own
identity and uncomfortable in
a world which insists on
treating her like a stranger.
She is inventing herself. Her
poems are an attempt to
construct a personal myth
which reacts to the dominant
patriarchal myth of our cul-
ture, at times complying with
it, at other times contradicting
it.

The dramatic poems take
the form of an extended
dialogue with a male who is
brother, father, or lover. The
brother, significantly,
committed suicide and ap-
pears in the poems as an
animus figure. The lover
poems are the most painful,
being filled with images of
dismemberment, fragmenta-
tion, and death of the ego. Again
and again she hurls her
identity against the “other,”
experiencing the sense of
loneliness and abandonment
which is a common feature of
love relationships in our
society. One of the poems
comments:

A realization of difference
came,

and comes and comes and
comes.

When will I find a lover

who is not a blizzard of
slashed feelings?

The George Washington
poems are an examination of
the failure of patriarchal
society, the world of fact that
depersonalizes both men and
women, leaving them es-
tranged from their own feel-
ings. George Washington as a
symbol is a surrogate for her
personal father, who aban-
doned her when she was quite
small. In “The Father of My
Country” she says: my father
made me what I am,/ a lonely
woman,/ without a purpose,
just as I was/ a lonely child /
without any father.”

George Washington is also
metal, currency, agriculture,
the flatness of fact. In
“George Washington: The
Whole Man” she tests the
symbol against the men she
has known, illustrating her
premise that “somehow we
have all been swamped by
history and bamboozled a bit;
that its elegance is also an
absurdity. That our feelings
which we honor, simply
because we have them, are
also mundane and foolish.”
“Trilogy” read as one long
poem, becomes a spiritual
autobiography, an extended
dialogue with the world, in
which the poet, with no
guidelines except her own
feelings, is continually reject-
ing false images, readjusting
her vision, seeing the same
experience over and over, as if
multiplicity must eventually
render up all possible truths.

Sexual Honesty
edited by Shere Hite
Warner Paperback $1.50

Donna Good

During summer my time for
reading increases sevenfold
and in the past month I've
outdone myself, reading al-
most everything I'd put aside
all winter. Of all that I’ve read,
two books stand out in my
mind so much that I feel an
almost evangelistic urge to
tell you about them.

The first book goes by the
rather straightforward title,
Sexual Honesty. And that’s
really what it’s all about. Two
years ago a NOW member by
the name of Shere Hite sent
out an incredibly long and
comprehensive sex question-
naire to women all over the
country. She went to a lot of
trouble to make sure she got a
random sample of women
including doctors’ offices, handing it
out freely to any woman met,
and, incredibly, having Oui
magazine publish it.

The book is subtitled, a
book by women, for women,
and is itself simply an
assortment of some of the
answers Shere Hite got in
response to her questions.
Reading the book, I was
depressed and, in turn,
elated. Most of the women
must have spent three or four
hours on their answers with
some of them obviously using
the questionnaire to vent
frustrations. Some of the
women just as obviously,
have used it to talk about a
forbidden subject.

I have never seen a book
which so clearly showed me
the bonds I share with other
women and how very basic
they are to our lives. I think
every woman should be given
a copy of this book on her
twelfth birthday (a new puber-
ty rite) and every man should
be required to read it at
ten-year intervals.

Walk to the End of the World
Suzy McKee Charnas
Ballantine Books $1.25

The other book I would like
to tell you about is a new
science fiction novel by Suzy
McKee Charnas called, Walk
to the End of the World. For
Feminists who love sci-fi this
book is a treasure. Instead of
the usual brilliant, virile,
dominant young fellow who
triumphs over the whims of
space and fate, we have a
whole new world built for us
— a world where the society
of the western world today
has been carried as far as it
can go along the way it now
pursues.

In Walk the atomic war has
come and long gone and a
new world has started to
rebuild itself; a world where
the sexes are completely
separate and women are the
dregs of the society, used for
breeding and total servitude.

Out of these dregs come a
strong female society (under-
ground of course) and from
this society emerges our
heroine — who is not saved by
any deus ex machina; does
not fall in love with the
handsome hero; and does not
give us our typical happy
ending.

Rape Offenders Treatment Program to Begin

The beginnings of an evaluation and
treatment program for sex offenders is
being instituted by Dr. Harry Chapman
who has recently become a part of the
Violence Research Unit at Denver
General Hospital. Dr. Chapman has
worked on an offenders treatment
program in recent years and now has
had a part of it funded.

An offender can be treated three
distinct ways by the court, according
to Dr. Chapman. After he is
prosecuted and is found to be guilty of
a sex crime he can be sentenced to
Canon City or Buena Vista where he
will receive little if any treatment or
rehabilitation. The second alternative
is for the judge to sentence him under
the Sexual Offenders Act which will
give the convicted offender a sentence
span of one day to life, with the intent
to provide treatment and rehabilita-
tion.

The decision by the judge is made
after an evaluation hearing at which
two psychiatrists and anyone else the
court deems necessary will testify as
to the mental condition of the
offender. The Department of Institu-
tions, not the court, will make the final
decision as to which facility to send

the man if he is sentenced under the

Sex Offenders Act - whether to the
State Hospital or to Buena Vista.

The third way a defendant pleads
not guilty by reason of insanity is that
he is given the psychiatric evaluation
which will determine his sanity. If he
is found insane he will be placed in the
State Hospital until the hospital staff
renders him safe to society and he is
released. Whenever the offender is
deemed “safe” is determined by
whatever process the staff at the
hospital uses for sanity. “We need a
systematic set of evaluation proces-
ses,” says Dr. Chapman.

Dr. Chapman feels that one way to
treat sex offenders is to have half-way
houses in the community where
offenders would live and return to after
holding jobs in the community. “But
no one wants a half-way house in their
community and the offender's behav-
ior needs to be evaluated in the
community. He needs community
experience. The rapist doesn’t fit into
any usual pattern of illness or mental
health. He is not the usual psychiatric
patient.”

He also feels that a possible reason
for this society’s sexual behavior is
that sexual activity is not taught to
children. “Children are taught that a
stove is hot but they are also taught
that it has other good uses - it cooks
food. But there is no teaching of
sexuality. It is not talked about except
in prohibitions. The family doesn't
teach it, the church and school don’t
teach anything good about sex. So
kids learn from peer groups. With
males it is typically self-centered, but
with females it is dealt with more in
terms of seduction: me-thou rather
than being personally centered. Social
mores require that the man is
aggressive and the woman passive.”

In Dr. Chapman's proposal he would
like to set up a program of evaluation
in order to discriminate between
rapists and sex offenders as to just
how dangerous (meaning how likely to
repeat their behavior) they are in order
to provide appropriate treatment.

“We will use clinical interviews of
the family, friends, associates and
psychological test batteries. Men who
volunteer for the evaluation will be
aware that we have a gentleman’s
agreement with the D.A. and the
Public Defender. None of the data can
be used by the defense or the
prosecution in court.

“We would like to provide part of the
overall treatment rehabilitation pro-
grams that would be available to
Canon City State Penitentiary, Buena
Vista Reformatory, or on the streets
with therapy, or in the community
setting for sex offenders. However,
the ultimate jurisdiction is with the
parole board and the courts. If they
decide that a particular offender
shouldn’t be in a program they can
remove him.

“This way there would be some
evaluation prior to release from an
institution and some basis for
assurance of what's going on with the
offender.”

Some possible means of treatment
would be psychodrama, bio-feedback
which is effective in teaching people
how to control certain aspects of their
functions. An offender with poor
impulse control needs to be more
effective in thinking of himself.
Bio-feedback will teach him that he
can control functions that he thinks

are purely automatic. He will learn that

“I want...” is the cue to thinking “I had
better hold back...” Behavior modifi-
cation is another means of treatment
and it is a touchy subject. Dr.
Chapman sees it as putting someone
in control of their own behavior,
because if he doesn’t control it,
somebody else will.

“At this point there is some
research literature on what we're doing
- lots of speculation - at the beginning
stages of this there is enough data to
suggest that the kinds of things we're
doing work. We are just gathering data
at this point. We want to be able to
discriminate among offenders.”

in the act of rape, the rage that one
man may harbor toward another higher
in the male hierarchy can be deflected
toward a female scapegoat. For every
man there is always someone lower on
the social scale on whom he can take
out his aggressions. And that is any
woman alive.

This oppressive attitude towards
women finds its institutionalization in
the traditional family. For it is
assumed that a man “wears the
pants” in his family--he exercises the
option of rule whenever he so
chooses. Not that he makes all the
decisions--clearly women make most
of the day-to-day decisions in a
family. But when a conflict of interest
arises, it is the man’s interest which
will prevail. His work, in itself, is more
powerful. He lords it over his wife in
the same way his boss lords it over
him, so that the very process of
exercising his power becomes as
important an act as obtaining
whatever it is in his power can get for
him.

This notion of power is key to
the male ego in this culture, for the
two acceptable measures of masculinity
are a man’s power over women
and his power over other men. A man
may boast to his friends that “I have 20
men working for me.” It is also
aggrandizement of his ego if he has
the financial power to clothe his wife
in furs and jewels. And, if a man lacks
the wherewithal to acquire such
power, he can always express his rage
through equally masculine activities--
rape and theft. Since male society
defines the female as a possession, it
is not surprising that the felony most
often committed together with rape is
theft. As the following classic tale of
rape points out, the elements of theft,
violence and forced sexual relations
merge into an indistinguishable
whole.

A Woman’s Story

The woman who told this story
was acquainted with the man who
tried to rape her. When the man
learned that she was going to be
staying alone for the weekend, he
began early in the day a polite
campaign to get her to go out with
him. When she continued to refuse his
request, his chivalrous mask dropped
away: “I had locked all the doors
because I was afraid, and I don’t know
how he got in; it was probably
through the screen door. When I woke
up, he was shaking my leg. His eyes
were red, and I knew he had been
drinking or smoking. I thought I would
try to talk my way out of it. He started
by saying that he wanted to sleep with
me, and then he got angrier and
angrier, until he started to say, ‘I want
pussy,’ ‘I want pussy.’ Then, I got
scared and tried to push him away.

That’s when he started to force
himself on me. It was awful. It was the
most humiliating, terrible feeling. He
was forcing my legs apart and ripping
my clothes off. And it was painful. I
did fight him--he was slightly drunk
and I was able to keep him away. I had
taken judo a few years back, but I was
afraid to throw a jab for fear that he'd
kill me. I could see he was getting
more and more violent. I was thinking
wildly of some way to get out of this
alive and then I said to him, ‘Do you
want money? I'll give you money.’ We
had money but I was also thinking that
if I got to the back room I could
telephone the police--as if the police
would even have helped. It was a
stupid thing to think of because
obviously he would follow me. And he
did. When he saw me pick up the
phone, he tried to tie the cord around
my neck. I screamed at him that I did
have the money in another room, that I
was going to call the police because I
was scared, but that I would never tell
anybody what happened. It would be
an absolute secret. He said okay, and I
went to get the money. But when he
got it, all of a sudden he got this crazy
look in his eye and he said to me,
‘Now I’m going to kill you.’ Then I
started saying my prayers. I knew
there was nothing I could do. He
started to hit me--I still wasn’t sure if
he wanted to rape me at this point--or
just to kill me. He was hurting me, but
he hadn't yet gotten me into a
strangle-hold because he was still
drunk and off balance. Somehow he
pushed into the kitchen where I kept
looking at this big knife. But I didn’t
pick it up. Somehow, no matter how
much I hated him at that moment, I
still couldn't imagine putting the knife
into his flesh, and then I was afraid he
would grab it and stick it into me.
Then he was hitting me again and

we fell down the steps and
that’s when he started to strangle me.
He was on top of me. He just went on
and on until finally I lost conscious-
ness. I did scream, though my
screams sounded like whispers to me.
But what happened was that a cab
driver happened by and frightened him
away. The cab driver revived me--I was
out only a minute at the most. And
then I ran across the street and I
grabbed the woman who was our
neighbor and screamed at her, ‘Am I
alive? Am I still alive?’

Threat of Death

Rape is an act of aggression in which
the victim is denied her self-determination. It is an act of violence which, if
not actually followed by beatings or
murder, nevertheless always carries
with it the threat of death. And finally,
rape is a form of mass terrorism, for
the victims of rape are chosen
indiscriminately, but the propagandists
for male supremacy broadcast
that it's women who cause rape by
being unchaste or in the wrong place
at the wrong time--in essence, by
behaving as though they were free.

The threat of rape is used to
deny women unemployment. (In Cali-
fornia, the Berkeley Public Library,
until pushed by the Federal Employ-
ment Practices Commission, refused
to hire female shelvers because of
perverted men in the stacks.) The fear
of rape keeps women off the streets at
night. Keeps women at home. Keeps
women passive and modest for fear
that they be thought provocative.

It is part of human dignity to be
able to defend oneself and women are
learning. Some women have learned
karate; some to shoot guns. And yet
we will not be free until the threat of
rape and the atmosphere of violence is
ended, and to end that the nature of
male behavior must change.

But rape is not an isolated act
that can be rooted out from patriarchy
without ending patriarchy itself. Rape
is a classic act of domination where,
in the words of Kate Millett, “the
emotions of hatred, contempt and the
desire to break or violate personality,”
takes place. This breaking of the
personality characterizes modern life
itself. No simple reforms can
eliminate rape. As the symbolic
expression of the white male
hierarchy, rape is the quintessential
act of our civilization, one which,
Valerie Solanis warns, is in danger of
“humping itself to death.”

My name is Mary Louise  
Aragon. On March 4, 1973 I  
was sentenced to the Colora-  
do Women’s Correctional In-  
stitution. My crime was  
aggravated robbery and my  
sentence was indeterminate  
to 10 years. This action ended  
a crime and drug experience  
that had drawn itself out to  
almost ten years of my life.  
On March 6, I was transported  
to CWCI to start paying my  
debt to society.  

My encounters with the law  
by that time had been many  
and I remember thinking how  
degrading and inhumane the  
conditions were in the city  
and county jails. The toilets  
and showers are in plain view,  
giving no privacy at all. Some  
people might say “What the  
Hell?” but when you think  
about it put yourself in that  
position trying to use the  
toilet with a room full of  
people watching your every  
move. So far the conditions  
are minimal compared to what  
a woman is subjected to at the  
prison.  

Upon arriving I was greeted  
by a cold, fenced building that  
was isolated from the town at  
the end of a normal rural  
street lined with typical single  
family wood framed houses.  
The guards all wear white  
uniforms with name tags. The  
name tags show only the last  
name with the initial of their  
first name. That told me that  
they were to be referred to as  
Ms. or Miss or Mrs. Although  
they knew that my name was  
Ms. Aragon they called me  
Mary, which automatically  
tells me that they place  
themselves at a higher posi-  
tion than the inmates. I was  
officially accepted at the  
prison as I signed some  

papers. Up to this point prison  
was just a word to me but now  
I was led through electrically  
controlled doors which  
slammed behind me. From  
that point on I knew I was in  
prison although I can recall  
times when it was comparable  
to a concentration camp or  
even a nursery.  
Prison as Medicine  

Never having been in prison  
before I was somewhat fearful  
of what might happen to me. I  
had heard many stories about  
prison and the physical abuse  
that one might receive while  
being there. But the building  
was fairly new and very clean  
and it was almost like being in  
a hospital. Well to my surprise  
there was very little physical  
abuse. But in its place were  
far more dangerous methods  
of abuse, dehumanization,  
physical and sexual depriva-  
tion, loss of identity, and  
failure of identification.  

My first day in isolation  
(where all new prisoners go)  
was spent in awe of my  
environment. My personal  
feelings at that time were of  
resentment, anger, loneliness,  
fear, and alienation from the  
whole world - and a good deal  
of self-pity. I had never placed  
any emphasis on just being  
able to touch another person  
but during the next two weeks  
the only interaction I had with another  
human being was when I was  
given tests by the doctor, or  
the guard. Often the guard  
would give medication that  
only a qualified nurse was  
supposed to give.  

I reflected a lot on my past  
and my family and I can say  
that at that time I desperately  
needed to talk to someone. I  
really needed a feeling of  

some kind of self-worth. But  
unfortunately there was none.  
So, consequently, by the time  
that I got out of isolation I was  
more than ready to accept any  
member of the prison peer  
group who would at least  
listen to some of my frustrations.  
I needed to tell someone that  
just because I broke the law I  
was still a human being and  
not some kind of an animal to  
be caged up and forgotten.  

As I said earlier, my  
involvement with the criminal  
justice system had been  
extensive, but one of the  
things that has bothered me  
most is that in spite of all the  
classifying, testing, and diag-  
nosing no one ever asked me  
why I did what I did. I guess  
that’s not part of what  
correction is about.  

After two weeks in isolation  
I was given a room in the  
north wing. I was now upper  
north 3 - number 41654. By this time  
my nerves were at a breaking  
point. I spent a lot of time in  
my room which is identical to  
isolation rooms. The only  
differences were a small throw  
rug, bedspread, a small desk  
like table, a closet, and the  
door was only locked from  
10:00 pm to 7:00 am.  

The Rules  

I was given a small book  
which supposedly contained  
rules of the prison. I remem-  
ber thumbing through the  
book and landing on a page  
that said something like no  
moustaches or long side  
burns. Then I realized that the  
book was probably for the  
men’s prison. Then I found the  
page that related to the  
women's institution. The rules  
on that page seemed to be  
relatively simple and per-  
tained mostly to mail, and  

visiting rules.  

But as the days dragged on  
I found that there were many  
unwritten rules that apply to  
some of the people some of  
the time and to some of the  
people all of the time. All in all  
I’d say that there were more  
than 200 of these unwritten  
rules and they are changeable  
on a day to day or shift to shift  
basis. One rule is that you  
can’t have bananas or cucum-  
bers. Another is that you can’t  
go into anyone else’s room at  
all. You can't hold hands with  
visitors. At the men’s visiting  
room they can hold hands.  
Dumb rules that you never  
know if you’re breaking or not,  
but if you do they'll write it up  
and put it in your file and then  
when you come in front of the  
parole board they'll read all  
this “bad girl” stuff and you  
don’t get parole.  

One of the things impressed on  
the women at CWCI is that  
they are ladies and are expected  
to act like ladies. But every day  
I would hear a guard tell a grown  
woman “you know that’s a  
no-no.” Sometimes you would  
get put in lock-up for breaking  
a rule in addition to being  
written up. Lock-up is being  
locked in your room after  
supper and not getting to  
watch TV. I used to get to the  
point where I’d say rules,  
rules, rules, there must be a  
rule for everything in this  
place and if there’s not one,  
believe me, one would be  
made up.  

Stomach Nerve Pills  

Almost all of the women  
take some kind of medication  
there. Of course it’s all  
prescribed legally but is often  
given by a matron who might  
not know what she's doing.  
You almost have to have  
tranquilizers to cope. Living  
there is a constant, constant  
bullshit thing with the same  
people 24 hours a day. You  
worry about your kids. Lots of  
people aren’t the easiest  
people to get along with. A lot  
of vulgarity goes down and  
lots of time you feel like  
hauling off and punching  
someone, but you know if you  
do you'll be put in the hole.  

The hole is underneath the  
isolation area. It's in the  
basement of the basement.  
There are three small cells:  
Two have toilets and matres-  
ses with three solid walls and  
one wall of bars. The third one  
just has a hole in the floor -  
nothing else. No one was ever  
put in there while I was there.  
But I heard that two women  
who tried to escape in 1970, I  
think, were put down there for  
30 days.  

One of the most strictly  
enforced rules there is no  
body contact. YOU CANNOT  
TOUCH ANOTHER PERSON  
FOR ANY REASON. Even  
when you hear that you are  
going to get out or when  
another woman needs to be  
comforted. I'd be told “Mary,  
you know that’s a no-no” they  
treat you like a two-year-old.  
To people on the outside it  
doesn't seem like anything  
not to be allowed to touch  
another person, but for a  
person to feel the impact of  
what I’m saying try going for a  
whole day without touching  
another person or showing  
your feelings physically. And  
then multiply that by months  
or years and you would know  
what a rule like no body  
contact does to you.  

While I was there I worked  
on the yard crew. I got to mow  
the grass and sometimes I’d  
be on this little tractor cutting  
the lawn and I would go crazy  
driving like a nut making hand  
signals. It would help me to  
forget where I was. You know,  
a woman is made up of many  
things and one of the heaviest  
things is emotion. If it is  
suppressed it just surfaces at  
another time.  

The recreation is not very  
good. They have hula-hoops  
and ping-pong tables and you  
can play baseball but there is  
no gym to really let off steam  
and keep yourself in shape  
from the starches you eat. But  
once we really had fun. It was  
on Labor Day when we asked  
to have a picnic in the yard.  
We were going to do all the  
planning and all the work so  
that there would be nothing

Dear Big Mama Rag:

In your August issue you
reported the story on Big
Mama Rag’s application for
funding with the Denver
Sustaining Fund. You stated:
“We deeply appreciate the
support and help we received
from the many community
women who attended the July
10 meeting of the DSF and
from Kathy DePaulo and Jim
McNulty of the board of
directors of the DSF.” Jim
McNulty was the only one of
the “boys” who supported Big
Mama’s proposal. I would
appreciate it if you would
point out in your next issue
that Jim McNulty is a member
of the Board of Directors of
the DSF as a representative of
the Gay Coalition of Denver.
And on the issue of BMR, he
was specifically urged to vote
for the proposal and to
support it vigorously.

At the previous board
meeting of the Gay Coalition

(a predominantly gay men’s
organization) we unanimously
voted that Jim take the above
course of action at the DSF
meeting. This is based upon
our support of a strong
Women’s Movement in Denver
which we perceive as our
allies in the struggle against
male heterosexual sexism that
oppresses both gays and
women. We understand your
appreciation for Jim individu-
ally, but there is also a gay
organization behind him who
sent him to the meeting with
specific instructions. It is no
coincidence that the only
male support was gay male
support.
Jerry Gerash,
President of the Gay
Coalition of Denver

Dear Big Mama,

In your July issue, there
was an article about Chicana
welfare rights. I appreciated
your coverage of the concerns
of minority women. It’s
important that we understand

Inmate Talks Candidly About Prison Life

Sherilyn Brandenstein

Earlier this summer, I visited Colorado Women’s Correctional
Institution in Canon City and interviewed Ronelle Lee, an inmate
at CWCI. Most of the women there are serving time for relatively
“light” crimes (dealing with dope, prostitution, passing bad
checks, etc.). In some cases, they were engaging in illegal
activities in order to survive and keep their families going. Ronelle
gave us the following descriptions of her experiences in prison.

Zak Rombakis

BMR: Could you talk about
what happens when you first
came here to CWCI?

RL: Okay. When you come
into the prison, you have to
stay in isolation for two
weeks. This is where they're
supposed to run all their tests
on you. They run a physical
exam and they find out what
you're allergic to. They find
out if you're a dope addict.
There’s a whole battery of
tests they run on you. Like the
CAT to see what your grade
level is.

When I got to the prison,
driving up there, you say,
“Hey, this is a beautiful

building.” You think you can
do the time in a nice place.
You sit up there in the control
room and wait for the officer
to come down. Here comes
someone in a white uniform
taking all your personal things
from you.

BMR: Who brought you here?

RL: The Denver
Sheriff's Department, two men.
No women guard at all.

So next I went to the isolation
or hospital. Well, when I first
went out the door, she told
me, “Don’t look around. Look
straight ahead or keep your
eyes down.” In other words,
don’t look at the people that’s
already in here. I will see them
when I get out of isolation.
Cause one girl that was there I
knew on the streets. And then
I found that there were a lot of
them I knew on the streets.
You go in the isolation
ward...you know, you don’t
know what to do anyway.

They take me downstairs and
say, “Pull off all your
clothes.” So I start pulling
them all off and they put me
on the table. Ran their fingers
all up in my butt and stuff to
see if I brought anything in.
Then they spray you...bug
spray. Wherever you have
hair, that’s where they spray
you. And it stinks.

Okay. After they sprayed me
and gave me a towel to dry off
with and gave me a pair of
pajamas to put on (no shoes
to put on), I got a shower.
Then they gave me ten
cigarettes. I was in a room in
the Lower South for Thursday.
Then on Friday they took me
out of there and took me to
the hospital for a physical
examination from the so-
called doctor. He’s had a heart
attack and he’s still a doctor.
This girl who was down there
in isolation has a number
that’s almost like mine. My
last number is 7 and hers is 6.
So I'm giving him all my
information to go in my chart
and he fools around and
writes it on her chart. ‘Okay.
He took my blood and put her
name on it. I stayed in
isolation for one month
because of that. They had to
keep repeating the blood test
because they kept saying that
something was coming up in
the blood. Then I said, “Are
you sure that you have the
right name from the blood you
took in the beginning?” They
said yes. I said, “You must
not, because the blood that
has all this in it isn’t none of
mine.” Later they found out
that this girl was really sick.

Carol Lease

Late last spring a civil
action was filed in the United
States District Court against
the Warden of the Colorado
State Penitentiary, the Asso-
ciate Warden of the Colorado
Women’s Correctional Insti-
tution (CWIC), the Director of
the Department of Institu-
tions, the Chief of Corrections
for the State, the Parole Board
and the Physician for the
Colorado State Penitentiary,
on behalf of all women who
have been confined at CWIC,
are presently being confined
there, or who will be confined
there while the suit is pending
in court.

Among the violations to the
Constitution stated in the
complaint are that “the
conditions existing at CWIC,
from the physical arrange-
ment of the prison to the
degrading treatment of pri-
soners by the personnel,
subject (the women inmates)
to unequal and inferior treat-
ment on the basis of their sex,
violates their rights to equal
protection and in the totality
of the circumstances consti-
tutes cruel and unusual
punishment, all in violation of
the Eighth and Fourteenth
Amendments to the Consti-
tution;

that women prisoners have
been deprived of their rights
to free speech, to free press,
their right to political associ-
ation and religious freedom
guaranteed by the First and
Fourteenth Amendments to
the Constitution;

that inmates at CWIC have
been denied due process of
the law by being punished and
penalized for violation of
unwritten rules in an “arbitrary
and capricious manner;”

that the actions of the
wardens have violated the
Equal Rights Amendment of
the Colorado Constitution.

The complaint also cites
denial of access to the Courts
and to judicial process in
violation of habeas corpus and
due process as guaranteed by
the Fifth, Sixth and Four-
teenth Amendments to the
Constitution.

Class Action

This class action suit began
when husbands and wives
who were both confined to the
Colorado State Penitentiary
visited each other and com-
pared notes on their treat-

ment. It soon became obvious
that the women prisoners did
not have the same opportuni-
ties that the men did and were
treated more like children than
adults. One male prisoner was
a jailhouse lawyer and the
legal action was initiated, on
behalf of the women inmates.
Although there is an extensive
law library at the men’s
maximum facility, the initi-
ators realized that they needed
help from people outside the
prison walls. Help came from
the National Lawyer's Guild
and the Law Collective in
Denver. Later the court ap-
pointed Frances Olsen as the
attorney.

The Law Collective is
currently compiling affidavits
from women inmates and has
sent sets of “extensive”
questions to the Warden Alex
Wilson and Associate Warden
May Gillespie. “They are
required to answer all ques-
tions," according to Joan
Tempko of the Law Collective.
“If the answers given aren't
sufficient we will resubmit
them. They have to answer all
our questions whether they
are admissible in court or not.
If they don’t cooperate we can
get a court order and then if
they don’t they'll be in
contempt. But I don’t think
that will have to be done.”

After this stage is com-
plete, any person concerned
in the case can be deposed in
front of a court reporter or a
tape recorder. “We'll probably
talk to Ms. Gillespie a couple
of days,” and others too says
Ms. Tempko. “The whole
thing could take a year...Up to
a year ago there was no
contact like this with CWIC.
Then the Minority Women’s
Caucus and the University
Without Walls Teacher Corps
Program and the lawsuit all
became involved with the
women’s prison.”

According to Ms. Gillespie
the lawsuit is a “fad...we’re
