Woman as

Prisoner

Chocolate Waters

“Lord, help me this day to
learn to keep my big mouth
shut.” The plaques were
round and multi-colored and
also the very first things we
saw upon entering the Canon
City Correctional Institute for
Women. They had been
hand-made by the women
prisoners, who it would seem
from our visit, had learned the
lesson well. After all they had
to survive in this system while
doing their time and it was
obvious that keeping their
mouths shut was about the
best way to accomplish this
survival.

One thing must be made
perfectly clear at the outset:
all women, living as we are in
the patriarchal world—one run
by, on, and for the interests of
the other half of the species—
are living in a kind of prison.
The prison institutions, them-
selves, however—the way they
are run and the way women
inside are treated—are a
glaring example in miniature
of all women’s status under
the patriarchy and capitalism.
Women’s prisons confirm, in
concrete how the male-dom-
inated world views all women
in general.

This confirmation takes on
a variety of forms and sexism
and capitalism are at the root
of most of them: how women
are treated differently within
the courts and the flaws, the
kinds of crimes women
commit and for what purpos-
es, the way women are
controlled and indoctrinated
with “typical feminine” attri-
butes while in prison, the
kinds of “vocations” taught in
prison and the sparsity of
education and employment
programs for prisoners and
ex-cons.

Because of our economic
system, which is capitalism,
it is generally true that the
prison population of both
sexes is composed mostly of
the poor. Although studies
have told us that the average
urban resident commits ten
felonies a year, each punisha-
ble theoretically by a year or
more imprisonment, the ma-
jority of these people will
never see the inside of a
prison (not to mention our
ex-president). The people who
do not have access to money
and know-how are usually the
first to be incarcerated.

In a survey on court and
correctional services for wo-
men, the American Associa-
tion of University Women
found that 80% of the women
surveyed were unemployed
when they were arrested and
also that Blacks and Chicanas
were arrested more frequently
than Anglo women in com-
parison to their respective
ethnic communities.

Nevertheless, other than
being non-white and poor, the
similarities between women

More on Page 17

Page 4

Society tries to imprison all women and is generally
successful in doing so through its imposition of the
social-cultural-psychological-political-economic bars around us.
Some of us are less privileged than others and are often sucked
into penal institutions to do “time.”

A society sets up its own standards for crime and creates its
own conditions to encourage crime. So the criminal will inevitably
exist. And the treatment of a woman who commits a criminal act
in a patriarchy will be an exaggeration of her usual treatment in
the society. She is treated as a child, given no responsibility for
her life.

At the Denver County jail women who are either awaiting
trial or serving time have to or are encouraged to sew uniforms for
the men’s section of the jail. Women have to work or their
privileges are taken away from them, and they are not given “good
time” that will shorten their sentences. The men do not have to
work because there simply isn’t enough work for them. So why
can’t the men sew their own clothes?

At the Colorado Women’s Correctional Institution at Canon
City women sew shirts for other state institutions. The prison as a
source of cheap labor is a self-perpetuating system.

It seems that the ultimate idea behind the lawsuit against
the women’s prison is not exactly to provide women with the same
opportunities that the men have, but to stimulate serious
attention, research, and thought about the position of women in
the penal system. There are, however, individual changes that can
be accomplished to alleviate inequitable situations and Rudy San
Fellipo, the Director of the Department of Institutions, sees such
“administrative changes” as possible solutions to some
problems.

The prison psychiatrist at Canon City refers to women as
“junkie bitches.” The warden of the women’s facility refers to the
inmates as “my girls” as if she were running a finishing school.
She readily admits that a woman who has been institutionalized
for over two years will be harmed by being in the institution any
longer. But up to that time she feels that the “structured program
with a busy schedule with lots of things to do” is effective.

Indeterminate sentencing that is prevalent in courts today
places the decision for release on the prison officials and the
parole board. This gives tremendous indiscriminate power over
people’s lives to state officials who basically believe that as long
as there have to be institutions “we're proud of the ones we have.”

This penal system perpetuates itself. It will not make
decisions that would seriously jeopardize its existence. So any
impetus for real community corrections as an alternative to
isolated, alienating imprisonment that offers no rehabilitation and
is dehumanizing and alienating will have to come from individual
groups or a coalition of groups that are committed to prison
reform.

Women’s prisons are the ultimate oppression in a
patriarchy. The majority of women who are confined there are
guilty of victimless crimes, bad check writing and drug-related
offenses. They got caught while using survival tactics that many
women find necessary to exist in a society where women have little
power and are economically dependent on men.

Community corrections half-way houses must be
established in Denver and other communities for women to
“serve” time in. Then the prison could be turned into a museum so
the guards would have something to do. - C.L.

Big Mama Rag Vol. 3 No. 3

Out of Prison, Female
and Unemployed

Carolyn Agosta -

You’re a woman...there’s
strike one against you...you
have just been released from
Canon City on a charge of
conspiracy to commit a
burglary. While in Canon City,
you were taught to sew, wash
dishes and file. Now what?
Where does a woman turn for
help - finding a job, or
receiving training, finding a
place to live and food to eat,
clothes to wear and still keep
herself out of prison while not
having to resort to the old
habits that got her arrested
and sentenced to Canon City
in the first place? After speaking
with both private and com-
munity agencies that are
involved with ex-convicts, I
realized that a woman, just
out of prison and looking for a
job has little, if any help
available for her.

There are approximately 60
women and 1,250 men incar-
cerated in Canon City at the
present time. According to
Roger Lauen of the Teacher
Corps Program, “Women
should not be incarcerated for
the types of offenses typically
committed by women.” But
women are jailed and how
they are dealt with as convicts
and ex-convicts will...either
“make” them or “break” them
as self-respecting and self-
willed human beings.

In the prisons today, very
little is being offered to a
woman as hope for the future.
Once she is released there is
no more hope than when she
was in prison. Every person
that this writer spoke to
admitted that the conditions
in prison were worse for
women than men and that her
opportunities for any form of
rehabilitation were far less
than for men.

Discrimination

Sandy Carruthers of Better
Jobs for Women reports that
their agency is in the
“exploring stages” working
with other programs to dis-
cover what is already available
for women and what is the
“most viable plug-in” for their
agency. She states that she
hopes to have a referral
system set up by this fall.

Employ-Ex, which receives
funding from LEAA (Law
Enforcement Assistance Ad-
ministration) can only deal
with “high-impact” crimes,
which are burglary, robbery,
assault and rape. Only 1% of
all women imprisoned qualify
for help from this federally
funded program. George Ben-
ningfield, assistant director of
Employ-Ex, stated, “It is a
built-in discriminatory prac-
tice, since very few women
commit these types of
crimes.” He further reports
that since December of 1972
less than 10% of the convicts
they have assisted have been
women. The program is
supposed to help ex-convicts
to “become self-reliant.” They
are taught to “fill out
applications,” they receive
four hours of intensive coun-
seling to get them ready for
job interviews. They also
receive food, clothing, and
tools for a job and bus tokens.
There is no counseling to help
the ex-convict readjust to
family life and to the
community.

The Pinto Project, accord-
ing to Chuck Padilla, is just
beginning to take steps
toward assisting women who
have been in prison. They
have just met with a “major
business” to have them hire at
least two women who had
been in prison. Mr. Padilla
stated that it is “more difficult
to place women than men”
and to “combat the stigma of
her having been in prison.”
Their program concentrates
on what they feel are the three
major needs of a person just
out of prison: education,
employment and counseling.
Padilla also said that he felt
their program was “not highly
geared to help women” at this
time. But by October they will
have the funds to hire a
woman, preferably an ex-con-
vict to work with women in
prison. He further stated that
presently they “focus (their)
main attention on men, but
must gear it to women.”

The organization began at a
“Council of Unity” in January,
1971. People behind the
prison walls contacted Chi-
cana organizations asking for
their help so that they (the
inmates) could help them-
selves.

A staff of 17 was involved
with the program at the
beginning, but a drastic cut in
funds left barely enough for a
skeletal staff of 5. At the end
of October the Department of
Labor will be able to see its
way to funding the program
$292,000. Mr. Padilla says
that he has high hopes to then
develop the staff to its fullest
to meet the needs of both
women and men.

Vicki Romero of the Com-
mission on Community Rela-
tions had much to say
regarding women in prison:
“When she gets out, there is
not too much available to
her...women have it unusually
bad...there is no one to help
them.” One important point
that she brought was the
concern that women in prison
have for their children. An
agency that Ms. Romero
works with, Las Valentinas
(literally, the brave ones) tries
to help women by contacting
their families and children and
taking messages back to the
women, lessening some of
the pain and apprehension.

Her job with the commis-
sion allows Ms. Romero to
work with various groups such
as Las Valentinas, Minority
Women’s Caucus, Colorado
Caucus of Black Women and
Cooperative Endeavor #4 to
help identify community
needs the greatest of which is
penal reform.

College Program

There may be a small ray of
hope in the form of the
University Without Walls Na-
tional Teacher Corps. This is a
two-year program which has a
year to go. It involves 19
convicts and ex-convicts, only
two of whom are women due
to the ratio of men and women
in the penitentiary.

The women, one who is still
in Canon City and one who is
out on parole, have the
opportunity to earn a B.A. in
two years in non-traditional
working and teaching situa-
tions. The inmate is allowed
to leave the women’s facility
with minimal security once a
week for meetings; the
parolee lives in Denver and
checks in with the Teacher
Corps office to meet with
instructors. According to
Roger Lauen, the director of
the project, the program is
quite effective. There has not
been one drop-out. One
aspect of the program utilizes
the students as community
workers and crisis interveners
in assisting people with
problems. It is estimated that
over 2,000 people have been
aided through this aspect of
the program.

Some of the people at the
Teacher Corps have hopes
for an alternative to incarcera-
tion, that is a community
corrections program. This
would be a place where a
convicted person would sleep,
eat, and receive on-the-job
training and counseling. A
program to meet her total
needs from within the com-
munity.

Mobilizes

Shecat

The Lesbian Task Force of  
NOW is alive, well, and  
growing newly-formed chapters state-  
wide. While Lesbians have  
always been a vital part of the  
women’s movement, our unique  
problems have not been  
dealt with on any large scale  
and our needs have not been  
articulated or acted upon in a  
positive manner. The purpose  
of the Lesbian Task Force,  
therefore, is to attack on all  
fronts the issues oppressing  
us as Lesbians.

Uplifted by the recent surge  
of energy in the Feminist  

unity; but decided to  

go my way:  
attend the first meeting of the  

newly-formed Task Force. I  
went out of a desire to find an  
appropriate way to channel  
energy into a forceful group. I  
definitely liked the sound of  
the words, “Task Force”  
--serious, positive, and po-  
tentially powerful.

I was far from disappointed.  
From among the 15 or so in  
attendance, I saw experience  
and inexperience, zealous-  
ness and caution, open  
activism, and the shyness of  
still being in the closet, but  
every woman there was there  
because she wanted to do  
something. We talked about a  
broad range of subjects that  
included legislation, educa-  
tion, politics, logistics, and  
tactics.

Right now, most of our  
energy is concentrated on  
gathering statewide support  
for a sweeping gay anti-dis-  
crimination package for the  
state legislature, and we have  
people working diligently  
contacting legislators, insti-  
tutions, every kind of contact  
it is possible to make, doing  
crash education where needed  
(which is almost everywhere).  
We also are gathering docu-  
mentation of discrimination  
for those liberal (and other)  
fools who keep saying “Show  
us a gay complaint.”

Other fronts of attack are to  
gain full Lesbian representa-  
tion on various commissions,  
such as the Commission on  
Community Relations and the  
Commission on the Status of  
Women. We have people  
pressuring religious, educa-  
tional, financial, and political  
institutions; some sisters are  
writing and developing edu-  
cational portfolios; some are  
working toward ending dis-  
crimination and harassment  
of Lesbians in prison; some  
are starting to coordinate a  
mail-order type of book  
service.

We are also supporting  
other Lesbian Task Forces in  
the state, as we are painfully  

in Denver and in  

aware that any significant  
changes in this state will have  
to come from all the outlying  
conservative areas and not  
just Denver alone.

Another issue in the Task  
Force is the importance of  
class consciousness. Clas-  
sism and elitism are issues  
that have not been dealt with  
satisfactorily in the women’s  
movement, and working class  
sisters are encouraged to  
express their anger in the  
hope that we will not in any  
way oppress each other by  
leftover attitudes from a sick  
society that has failed to  
achieve dignity and freedom  
for all.

Women in the Task Force  
have spontaneously formed  
special interest groups as  
they are needed. This process  
is remarkable to me, since I  
have seen many groups, even  
women’s groups, where the  
leadership is forced to accept  
the burden of responsibility.  
In the Task Force, it’s like we  
all are leaders, in a way. It’s  
more the fact of us all working  
together in harmony in a  
process of collective evolu-  
tion, rather than following any  
traditional form of getting  
things done. Every woman is  
given the dignity of leadership  
that otherwise would fall to  
just a few. Our energy has  
become synergistic, so that  
we grow as individuals at the  
same rate the groups grow.  
One of the best things that  
happens at our meetings as a  
result of our process, is that  
whenever we hit an issue we  
can’t agree on, a “brainstorm-  
ing effect” occurs, and we  
usually come up with some  
surprising alternative satis-  
factory to everyone and that  
no one individual would have  
thought of it alone.

Some of our dreams, I  
discovered, were far too  
utopian to be considered as  
current projects, like my own  
hope of creating a woman’s  
center large enough in scope  
to provide a place where  
women could go to learn  
everything they are denied in  
our present culture. This kind  
of dream is an evolutionary  
one, and we decided in terms  
of practicality alone that for  
the present, we have to begin  
by an all-out attack on those  
elements of our society that  
most refuse to accept our  
existence. Only then will we  
be more free to build our  
dreams in peace.

astic about the Lesbian Task

Flagyl May Cause Cancer -- Three separate experiments have

rats. The Health Research Group has petitioned the Food and
Drug Administration to ban the drug but the FDA has offered little
response. Your doctor may not be aware of the findings about

drug.

Women &

History

MARIA MITCHELL, ASTRONOMER

Maria Mitchell was born on August 1, 1818 on Nantucket
Island. By the age of 13 she was assisting her father in his work in
astronomy. As she grew older, she became the librarian for the
Nantucket Athenæum and spent her evenings watching the skies.

In October of 1847, she discovered a telescopic comet
which bears her name, and a year later, became the first woman
elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. In 1850,
by unanimous vote, Mitchell was elected to the Association for the
Advancement of Science, again the first woman.

While Maria Mitchell had an unusually easy time
establishing herself in the field of astronomy, she did not forget
the oppression of other women. She worked both for the suffrage
movement and as president of the Association for the
Advancement of Women. While she was the first professor of
astronomy from 1865-88, at the newly founded Vassar College,
she criticized the male president and board of trustees for
employment practices such as hiring men for the highest
positions and giving women unequal salaries.

Believing that women had much to contribute to the
progress of society, Mitchell once said: “I wish we could give
every woman who has a novel theory dear to her soul for the
improvement of the world, a chance to work out her theory in real
life.” (reprinted from Uppity Women! A Legacy of Liberation.)

inimical. You share what's  
important to you with your  
students—a book, an idea.  
And if Feminism is an integral  
part of your life, your teaching  
would reflect that.

Jackie: I can think of a  
specific instance. Pre-schools  
more and more encourage  
kids to talk about their  
feelings. Mr. Rogers, on TV,  
for example. But that kind of  
talking seems to stop for boys  
at some age. It seems like it  
stops about the same time  
that sexual identity as a male  
begins. It would be a goal of a  
Feminist school for all kids,  
especially boys, to talk about  
their feelings.

Bonnie: Yes. You'd create an  

atmosphere of concern where  
they could express their feelings. And  
you'd have to have a lot of  
faith that that atmosphere will  
work. Kids can give an  
incredible amount of support  
to one another, but that kind  
of relationship must be  
fostered by the school.  
Yvonne: And remember boys  
need heroes, too. Can we find  
some? For example, Henry  
Blackwell, when he married  
Lucy Stone, insisted that she  
not take his name, and he  
continued to publish her  
Feminist works for many  
years after her death. Or Chief  
Joseph and other Indians who  
have had their roots closer to  
the earth.

Mary: What about the ques-  
tion of male teachers? Where  
do you find men who believe  
in Feminism?

Jackie: Right. In hiring a  
teacher, I would want Femi-  
nist principles to be as  
important to that teacher as  
they are to me. I’ve never met  
a man who felt that way—who  
would call themselves Femi-  
nists and be proud of it. Very  
few if any, men understand  
the cultural implications of  
Feminism.

Linda: As I’ve been listening  
and discussing all this, I’ve  
come up with the conclusion  
that we may be talking about  
two different things and  
confusing them. There is such  
a thing as a non-sexist school  
and there is such a thing as a  
Feminist school. A Feminist  
school would explore the  
ideas of women, of women’s  
culture, women's values. It  
would consider the general  
culture to be a patriarchy, and  
start from that assumption.  
Bonnie: Then you'd be tipping  
the scale.

Linda: Yes. I think of tipping  
the scale back into the  
balance that patriarchy upset.

This article is also intended to be  
an organizing tool. Women  
interested in continuing this  
discussion or actually planning a  
Feminist school are urged to call  
the BMR office (322-2010). We'd  
be happy to coordinate.

Very simple, it would seem. And years ago it was. A simple
handbill or two, a barker in the market place extolling the virtues
of his wares. These were sufficient means to convey the supposed
worth of a product or service. But that was, indeed, years ago.

Today, advertising is a complex, major multi-billion dollar
industry in itself. And it has grown immeasurably in reach,
sophistication and subtlety. It utilizes virtually every known form
of printed and electronic media. From brochure to billboard. From
product label to company letterhead. From your car-radio to that
big 21” color tube in your living room. It is estimated that an
individual is bombarded by over 1,500 advertising messages, in
one form or another, each day. And so, because of its virtually
limitless reach, its relentless ability to pervade even the most
private aspects of our lives, advertising wields an enormous power
in this country today. A power which we, as women, would do
well to analyze, to understand, and when necessary, to challenge.

We can by no means put a blanket stamp of “evil” on all
advertising. It has been, and will continue to be, a provocative tool
for social and political change. It can also, however unwittingly,
be the prime instrument for the perpetuation of social and sexual
stereotypes.

In the months to come, this column will attempt to analyze
and/or bring to your attention those ads which specifically relate
to women in this manner. Particularly those in which the
stereotyping is most subtle. But for openers, let’s take a look at
one not too subtle example.

Moving That Tail

Continental Airlines had a problem. Some bright young soul
in the marketing department discovered that they were less well
known than the bus people over at Continental Trailways. In fact,
a marketing survey revealed that only about 10% of the flying
public knew about them, even though the airline boasts the best
on-time record and is acknowledged by its competitors to be the
best.

A further discovery: their five year old slogan, “the Proud
Bird with the Golden Tail”, was more well known than the
Continental name itself. Which was fine, if they could get a yellow
pages listing under “P” for “Proud Bird”. Which, of course, they
couldn't.

So, what to do? What to do? Somehow their advertising had
to generate quick name awareness and better associate that name
in the public’s mind with the best service.

Benton & Bowles, the ad agency, had a solution. You've
seen and heard it. Cheerful faces, stirring music, snappy lyrics.
And a rousing “At Continental Airlines, we really move our tail for
you!” Terrific! An absolute natural! Everything was there. Name
recognition, plus capitalization on a phrase that has traditionally
implied good service which, at the same time, cleverly
incorporated the already successfully established “tail” theme.

Unfortunately, some confusion arose as to just whose tail
was moving. Continental claims it meant to convey that it was the
symbolic Proud Bird's tail. The male flying public, given to its own
peculiar brand of symbolism, thought otherwise. The result: a lot
of CA stews who wished they were flying United’s “Friendly
Skies” instead...and an advertising campaign offensive to both
CA women and the female public alike.

A recent issue of New Times magazine reports that a union
official for the Steward and Stewardess Division of the Airline
Pilots Association “informed the airline that the slogan
represented ‘a movement back years in time... to a period when all
flight attendants were unfairly held out as sex objects.’ ”

No, no, protests Ms. Diane Levine, staff Vice President, CA
Public Relations. Smugly pointing out that the TV spots depict
both male and female employees, and that the outdoor advertising
features a stylization of their aircraft's famous “Golden Tail”, she
insisted to a group of Denver ad writers that the campaign was
conceived in utter innocence, with no intention of creating
suggestive innuendos. “The Continental Proud Tail is moving,
nobody else's. This is not to be construed any other way.”

Yet the New Times article further reveals: “To add insult to
injury—the company prepared a film to help stewardesses cope
with what it admitted might be one result of the ad campaign,
suggesting witty retorts to any provocative questions. For
example:

Passenger: ‘Will you move your tail for me?’

Stewardess: ‘Why, is it in the way?’ ”

Not to be construed any other way, huh? Oh come now,
Diane, really?

Postscript: The airline, already saddled with a record of
discrimination against women in the area of credit extension,
dismissed complaints by the union about the campaign as just
a lot of agitation by some “hard core women’s libbers”. They
charged that the women were using the issue as a grievance to
gain more leverage in contract negotiations. Leverage is needed, it
would seem. Recently, a California judge ruled in favor of a CA
stewardess who had filed a discrimination suit against the airline.
She had finally been fired, after having been suspended seven
times over the past year for being overweight...sometimes by as
much as half a pound.

Reader comments and contributions are encouraged.

Casse Culver is a

Lesbian/Feminist songwriter

and musician of superb talent
and unique presentation.

Based in Washington, D.C.,
Casse is currently on a U.S.
tour performing for small
gatherings as well as larger
Feminist groups. She was in
Denver August 1, sharing her
art with those who attended
the Big Mama Rag benefit at
the Oxford Hotel and again
the following night at St.
Barnabas Church.

Casse accompanies her
unforgettable voice with gui-
tar, autoharp, harmonica and
piano. She has written over
200 songs with several re-
corded by Maria Muldaur and
country singer Dickie Lee.

Casse’s songs reflect her
personal experiences with
oppression and with a male
dominated society. She feels
it is this oppression and her
own feelings of dissatisfaction,
anger and hurt that
makes her music so appealing: “Because women as a
class are oppressed, it makes
the music universal. That is
why it touches as many
women as it does.”

Being a Lesbian has, said
Casse, “both hurt me and
confined me in my experience
with the recording industry. I
received no encouragement
from society to be who I am.
Being a Lesbian was very

limiting: I draw much of my
material from that. But the
record industry sees only
pocketbooks, not human
needs. So they sat on my face
for 4 years. It was an
atmosphere that was non-
supportive, gave me no
encouragement and offered
only negative comments
about my music.”

In 1972 Casse cut a record
backed by Maria Muldaur and
the Full Tilt Boogie Band. It
was never released because
the recording company felt
the ‘musical climate was not
right’. These struggles “have
made me strong and clear-
sighted,” said Casse, “but
that does not erase the loss of
time and my anger about
that.”

Have to Survive

Casse tried to fight the
system but was under a lot of
pressure simply to survive. “I
had to put my monetary
needs, feeding and clothing
myself, before my art. This is
the kind of thing that happens
all the time; mine is simply a
specific situation.”

So Casse left the straight
record industry, tried the club
scene, which turned out to be
pretty much the same thing,
i.e., the “show-a-little-more-
tit-baby” attitude, and is now
working to create a woman’s
musical culture with the help
of her “womanger” Spotts-
wood. Why a “womanger”?
“The word ‘manager’,” says
Casse, “is derived from and
implies to ‘manipulate’; to
turn someone into a purchas-
able product.” This definitely
is not the relationship that
Casse and Spotts have. They
both put full time and energy
into getting Casse’s music out
to the public. Spotts takes
care of the business matters
and Casse works on her
music. Their expenses come
off the top of any income and
the rest is split 50-50.

Feels Great Now

How does Casse feel now
that she is performing her
music for women? Great! “In
the straight music industry, if
you're writing about anything
other than ‘my man is here
and I’m happy and satisfied’ or
‘my man is not here and I’m
miserable and blue’ you don't
have a market. Supposedly.”
Casse is finding her new
atmosphere highly supportive
and energizing. Women, she
has found, are open to and
eager for a whole new area of
women’s art; one which
expresses their own feelings
and struggles.

Her audiences have, in fact,
been so supportive that Casse
is planning a new album for
the fall of this year. One that
will be on her own label,
Sweet Alliance Music.

Through Casse’s efforts to
politicize and unite women
with their art she is giving us
the soul of woman, moving
freely out of her own life and
struggle. It is a beautiful and
brightly shining soul, and full
of smiles.

In a heavily guarded,
makeshift courtroom in the
Civil Defense building three
miles outside Sioux Falls,
South Dakota, a 56-year-old
Oglala Sioux woman is on trial
for riot charges. Sarah Bad
Heart Bull, an Indian mother
of 8 children, stands trial
because of her protest against
the white murderer of her
19-year-old son, Wesley, killed
in January, last year:

Wesley was stabbed to

death by Darryl Schmidt and

the state of South Dakota did
not feel it necessary to try a
white man for killing an
Indian. Sarah announced she
would travel (in the dead of
winter) from the Pine Ridge
Reservation to the distant
town of Custer to protest the
state’s inaction.

When Sarah and her sup-
porters arrived at the Custer
Courthouse to talk to authori-
ties, they were attacked by
riot policemen, arrested and
charged with conspiracy to
riot, riot where arson oc-
curred, disturbing the peace,
etc. Sarah was jailed and bail
of $8,000 was set.

When S.D. authorities
learned her bail would be
raised by an Indian Women’s

group, “Indian Women United
for Social Justice,” located in
Los Angeles, she was re-
leased on her own recogni-
zance.

Then in April of this year,
another son, Butch (age 18)
was shot to death by a white
man in Allen, Nebraska. Sarah
was further brutalized by the
S.D. authorities when she and
other Indian defendants would
not stand to show their
respect for the racist Judge
Bottum, who had allowed
white people who said they
hated Indians to be seated as
jurors. She and the others
were beaten, maced, and
tear-gassed in the courtroom
by police when they would not
stand.

The all-white jury has been
seated and it consists of 7
women and 5 men. Sarah and
the other Indian people are
poor and their legal defense
depends on urgently needed
donations from people across
the country. If you would like
to help Sarah Bad Heart Bull and
the other Indian defendants,
please send your donation to:
Wounded Knee Legal Defense
Fund, Offense Com., Box 255,
Sioux Falls, S.D. 57101.

We challenge all forms of ageism + discrimination based on age.

We challenge compulsory retirement based on chronological age.

We seek the right to participate in determining policy and program decisions in the institutions that serve us.

We are a coalition of all ages, but especially the old and the young; who are outside the mainstream of society deprived of power and influence.

We seek improved public (Social Security) and private pension programs as well as better public and private health care, housing, and transportation, especially as these affect older people.

We are critical of the injustices, misplaced priorities, and discrimination based on race, sex, and age which exist in our society. We call for a reordering of national priorities which now favor military expenditures instead of supporting domestic needs especially affecting older people.

We believe in direct action on behalf of these principles including researching, lobbying, and publicizing these issues, testifying at public hearings, and participating in public demonstrations.

These are the principles of the Denver Gray Panthers, part of a nationwide network of individuals and groups “drawn together by deeply felt common concerns for human liberation and social change.”

The Gray Panthers were born about four years ago in Philadelphia by a coalition of retired persons and students. Among the first issues dealt with were the war in Vietnam and increases in social security. Retired people had the time and the freedom to act without fear of losing their jobs. Such issues as a national health plan, public transportation for reduced fares, housing, job discrimination, court reform, corporate responsibility, and the passage of the Equal Rights Amendment have been part of the focus of the Gray Panthers in recent years.

The Denver chapter of the Gray Panthers was organized in April of this year and has been successful in having walklight signals on Colfax and other streets lengthened so that all people are able to cross the busy streets safely. The Traffic Engineering department has been “very responsive” to this problem according to Dortha Howe, a member of the Panthers.

Other activities of the Denver group are issue forums for state legislative candidates which were held in August in conjunction with Common Cause. More are scheduled for October and specific information can be obtained by calling Common Cause at 534-8259.

Consciousness raising groups are being started that will be open to all - young and old, men and women. Anyone interested can call Ms. Howe at 831-7707, afternoons.

A shared living house for older people has been established in Lakewood at a cost of about $150 a month. Contact Fran Yehle at 237-0839 or Ann Voiland at 237-2495 for more information.

Action around the issue of nursing homes will be discussed at the next meeting of the Gray Panthers which will be held at Sunset Park at 1865 Larimer, on September 9 at 1:30 pm.

Trichomonas: This is another vaginal infection caused by a tiny
one-celled animal that has little whip-like tentacles that help it
swim around.

Symptoms: Once again the vulva and outer vagina will itch and
become inflamed (sometimes the rectum will become inflamed
also). The discharge will be greenish-yellow and either slimy or
foamy and the smell will be rather odorous.

Treatment: The only cure that doctors have used thus far is a drug
called Flagyl or metronidazole which is taken orally. It is
expensive and causes uncomfortable side effects. Recent studies
have also shown that the drug may be carcinogenic (causing
cancer) when used on laboratory animals. In other words, as a
cure it leaves a lot to be desired. However, there are no other
known prescribed cures, and the only herbal cure I have heard of is
to use creosote as a douche. The Tribal Medicine Council
recommends creosote as an effective cure. (Another cute thing
about Flagyl is that it can kill off the normal bacteria of the vagina
too, and lead to a yeast infection.)

Non-Specific Vaginitis: This infection is caused by a certain
bacteria (not by yeast, trich, or gonorrhea) and is very tricky to
diagnose and get rid of. The bacteria causes trouble only when
something disrupts the natural chemical balance, like being sick
or run-down.
Symptoms: You will have an itchy inflamed vulva, and a white or
yellow discharge which contains cells and bacteria (under a
microscope) and may be streaked with blood. If the bacteria get
into your uterus, fallopian tubes, or bloodstream, you may feel
back pains and have cramps and swollen glands.
Treatment: Sulfa drugs are used in cream or suppository form
every morning and evening for ten days. Brand names are Vagitrol,
Sultrin, AVC cream. If you are allergic to sulfa drugs, get Furacin
Vag-15 suppositories or Betadine douche cream. All of these are
prescription drugs, and alas! I know of no herbal cures.
Hopefully, these descriptions will shed a little light on how
to deal with these damnable infections. Learning to effectively
diagnose does take time and practice, but basically it isn’t that
hard to do. If you have self-help classes that are being taught

where you live, go to them! You can learn a lot about yourself and
help break down the monopoly of power that the male-dominated
medical establishment has effectively kept us trapped with.
Self-determination!

From Page 3

is Lt. Cooper. This is my penitentiary. You do as we say to do in here. You don’t go to other girls’ rooms. There is no body contact. You don’t touch. We do not practice homosexuality in our institution.”

So she runs it all down to you. No body contact means that if you had some death in your family and you were crying, and I’m one of your friends and I come up to you and say, “Hey, everything is gonna be OK.” and I pat you on the back to console you, then I’m accused of being a homosexual. That means that you and I have a thing going because of the fact that I’m patting you and consoling you.

After you talk to the warden, you go on up to your wing area and they assign you to your room. You might meet some of the girls in that wing area. I put all my things on the bed, then I went out with one of the girls that knew me. We went outside. I was shaking like this. I was really nervous because I’d never been around a lot of people, especially women, in the joint and it really got to me.

BMR: What’s the daily routine? Does everybody work?

RL: Six o’clock in the morning they come over the speaker and say, “Good morning ladies. It’s six o'clock.” BMR: The rest of

are girls. you're ladies?

RL: Right. Six-thirty comes and it’s time for count. You're laying in your bed, really resting. Six-thirty comes and you have to get up out of your bed, go to the door and stick your arm out until the officer comes down and counts every arm. On her way up, she says, “Thank you” and you can put your arm back in. If you want to stay up, you stay up. You have to be out of your room for breakfast at 7 am.

You go to the dining room and you have to sit at the seat where you're assigned. After breakfast you have your medication. If you work on the cleaning crew you have to go down to the auditorium at 8:00. If you’re in the sewing room you have to be there at 8:00.

BMR: How many different work areas are there?

RL: You have the cleaning crew, the sewing room, the yard crew, the state and industrial sewing room. You can work in the library or the kitchen.

BMR: Does the women’s kitchen prepare food for the men’s prison, too?

RL: No. Only for the women. In the women’s kitchen, they don't have enough stuff to work with, as far as cooking is concerned. Not enough seasonings. And they have a food service class! Now you can have vocational training. You can take typing, bookkeeping, shorthand, and filing. That’s it. Now I’ve been through all of that. I didn’t have anything to do.

BMR: Are the classes every day?

RL: Every day of the week. But you have to do your work detail. In the laundry you might be there an hour. On the cleaning crew you go to work at 8 and you might get off at 11. You never know how long you may have to work.

BMR: Which means when you get up in the morning, if you have something you want to do that day, like writing or something, you never know during that day when you're going to have some time to yourself.

RL: Right.

Interviewer’s note: If an inmate at CWC doesn’t behave in the approved manner, the prison administration has a number of ways to pressure her into obedience. One of the more effective ways is to threaten her with an extension of her sentence. This threat keeps many women from speaking or rebelling. Another disciplinary method, which has both immediate and long-term implications, is to place a woman in lock-up by herself.

BMR: Can you tell us something about lock-up?

RL: It’s the same room that you have isolation when you first come in.

BMR: What’s in there?

a blanket and a washcloth. What was so funny about it was that they took the string out of my pajamas so I couldn’t hang myself, but if I'd wanted to, all I'd had to do was to take the radio earphones and hang myself. They were still in there. Or the sheets. I could have taken my pajamas off and hung myself too.

BMR: Do people use cigarettes as barter in the women’s prison?

RL: Some people might. I don’t. See, you get two packages of Pall Mall on Friday. They give you one bar of soap. You can get 12 Kotex.

BMR: No tampons?

RL: If you want Tampex you have to take your own money and buy them.

BMR: What is contraband here?

RL: We can’t have gum. The reason for that they say is because ten years ago Sally Sue had gum and she jammed a lock. Or five years ago somebody had gum that she stuck on her plate and it got jammed in the dishwasher. You can’t have lighters. Because if there was lighter fluid around you could start somebody on fire. Our people can’t send anything in, like homemade goodies. Something might be in it. They’re afraid your parents might put some dope in it.

BMR: Are drugs easily available?

RL: No, but you can get drugs into the institution.

BMR: What are some of the ways that women relieve themselves of the insanity here?

RL: Well, now we can have tapes and radios in our rooms. And you can read or knit or crochet. That's what I don't understand about all this contraband. You can’t have matches and all this other stuff, but you can have scissors and knitting needles, needles, pins. Knives are contraband. If you want a knife, all you got to do is go down to the kitchen, put it in your sock and walk back to your room.

BMR: What else can you do?

RL: Well, you can pick up a book or do whatever you want in your room. But really you don’t have privacy in your room. The officers come and look in all the time.

BMR: And you can’t have a friend in?

RL: Not in your room.

BMR: So what you’re saying is that in the women’s prison there’s very little contact between the women as individuals?

RL: Right. Very little.

BMR: I'd like for you to talk a little bit about being gay in and out of prison.

RL: Okay. Well me, for instance. I’m gay. I was gay when I came in and I'll be gay when I leave. In the prison, you’re around women. You might see someone you might dig on and you might want to be with that person. So you rap to each other and you get real close to her.

BMR: When do you get a chance to talk to her?

RL: When the yard is open. Or going to dinner together. If you're in different wings, then you can go over to her wing and talk to her. You just go and stand at her door. She might pull a chair up to the door. But you can’t go inside anyone's living quarters but the one you're in. You can talk in the beauty shop when you are doing each other’s hair.

BMR: That's the only body contact you can have?

RL: Yes, when you're doing somebody's hair.

BMR: How many women in the institution are Lesbians?

RL: There are so many changes coming down here. There’s probably only two for real. Then there are some that came into the institution and don’t have anything better to do than this, get it on with women. They think, “I got to do my time. I might as well have somebody to do this with.” It's an outlet.” So they get involved. But there’s not that many who come in gay.

BMR: What are some of the differences that you can see between what happens in the women’s prison and in the men’s prisons?

RL: They have more freedom than we women do. I guess that’s because there are more men locked up than there are women.

Interviewer’s note: Ronnell didn’t expand on this point. A noticeable difference between the men’s and women’s institutions is the larger variety of vocational training and educational opportunities available to men. It seems that there are also fewer petty rules at the men's prisons.

BMR: What do you think is our responsibility as women outside to those of you who are inside?

RL: Women on the outside, not being aware of prison and how it really is, should get some type of group together and come and visit the women's institution. They should see how each woman feels in there about being locked up. There needs to be more communication among all women, inside and out. There are some women inside who have kids. There are women on the street who have kids and they're not away from their kids. They need to know how it feels to be away from your child, being confined, doing time. Women on the outside have no knowledge of this. You need to see how a woman feels when she has to go and do time and when she gets out her child doesn’t know her.

Like the NOW women came down and one lady brought her little boy down. Everybody was really enthused. But if they had their kids to come in, they would be more happy than they are now.

BMR: In other words, people on the outside should try to find out who has a child and bring them along when we come to visit.

RL: Yes, that’s one of the things I want to do when I get out. I want to relate to women on the outside that prison life is not for a woman. It’s really not. I want women to know, “Hey, don’t commit any crimes. If you got a man and he’s pimping you, tell him you want to do something better than going to prison.” You got responsibilities out there. You got more responsibilities if you got a child. Say one of my best friends had a case. She might have ten kids. She’s worried about what her kids are going to do, whether they’re going to go on welfare or the welfare department is going to take them away from her and all this. Before I see her kids given away, I'll take the rap for her.

Interviewers note: This was all the time we had to talk with Ronell during our initial visit. She is interested in staying in touch with women outside of prison. Those of you who are concerned about women inmates should consider visiting the women at CWC and possibly taking an inmate's child for a visit. For more information about the subject, read Women in Prison by Kathryn W. Burkhart.

Books

Psychology of Women:  
A Study of Bio-Cultural  
Conflicts. .  

Judith M. Bardwick.  
Harper & Row, New  
York, NY: 1971.  

In Psychology of Women,  
Judith M. Bardwick, Ph.D.,  
has confirmed and acknowledged the experiences that  
Every Woman has had. No  
longer need we worry about  
“penis envy”: we have our  
own reproductive organs and  
our own perceptions and our  
own reasons for feeling and  
acting as we do, in spite of the  
male sex.  

Bardwick herself has a  
Ph.D. and three children. She  
thinks that maternity and  
taking care of the young are  
crucial experiences for the  
self-identity of women. She  
claims that little girls don’t  
grieve for the penises they never  
had. As anyone who has been  

around little children will  
attest: a little girl who sees a  
pregnant woman is very proud  
to hear that she too might one  
day have a big belly and a  
baby (if she wants to). In other  
words, girls have their own  
source of pride and identity,  
right there in their own  
bodies.  

The notorious “passivity” of  
women just might happen to  
be functional, a necessary  
coping technique during such  
crises as pregnancy. (A  
woman who answers the  
demands of small children  
can hardly be called passive!)  

Bardwick discusses at  
length the relationship of  
women to their bodies. As it  
turns out, our bodies are  
fascinating. The menstrual  
cycle is a finely orchestrated  
balance of hormones, some-  
times operating in high gear  
and sometimes in low gear.  
When our hormonal levels are  
high, there is some indication  
in the research that it might  

contribute to a positive,  
nurturant psychological state.  
Pregnancy is one time of high  
hormonal levels -- and preg-  
nancy is certainly a time when  
a positive, well-integrated  
personality is very important  
to the well-being of the future  
child.  

Bardwick also talks about  
possible causes of heightened  
sexual arousal during mens-  
truation. She also suggests  
some possible psychological  
effects of taking birth control  
pills.  

Bardwick also describes the  
cultural influences on young  
women experiencing mens-  
truation, their first inter-  
course, marriage, orgasm,  
childbirth, etc. Some of her  
theories are as yet unprova-  
ble, but it is nevertheless  
worthwhile to read a feminine  
rendition of all the life crises  
that men are so vocal about.  

Again and again the author  
describes the denigration of  
female achievements in a  

culture which values male-  
ness. This is the part that  
roused the old feminist anger  
in me. While girls are being  
told to succeed scholastically,  
on the one hand, and then  
told not to do too well, on the  
other hand (so that they don't  
alienate prospective hus-  
bands); while they're being  
told that having babies and  
taking care of a home and  
husband are the most crea-  
tive, most contributory things  
they could do; they are  
simultaneously being put  
down for being “just house-  
wives”. As Bardwick notes in  
her chapter entitled “The  
Motive to Achieve”, the  
highest accolades of this  
society go to men who are  
competitive and achievement-  
oriented. If women exhibit the  
same behaviors, they’re told  
that they’re being “unfemin-  
ine”. Damned if you do and  
damned if you don't.  
Bardwick’s theory of an  
“affiliative motive” in women

Linda Fowler

As you have all surely noticed, Big Mama Rag has been
changing fast, and growing so rapidly we can hardly keep up with
her. We thought you'd like to know what’s happening with your
newspaper, beyond the printed page - inside BMR.

We also want to let you know what some of our needs are
and hope you will let us know about yours. Our aim is to
continually increase BMR’s effectiveness as a service and
communication organ for all women.

Perhaps the printed page is a good place to begin.

During the past few months, BMR has doubled in size. The
features section has been expanded with more in-depth coverage
of issues relevant to local women. We have added more interviews
with both local and nationally known Feminists, expanded the
poetry section, increased book and film reviews, added regional
news, national news, a Women and Advertising column, and a
calendar of events. Plans are to add a financial column (to help
women with money planning and management), to expand
coverage of working women and labor union women, and to add a
section on the herstory of women. Casse Culver and Spottswood
suggested more analysis of the political aspects of Lesbianism.
We hope to offer more here.

What We Need

We need writers to help with features, articles on theory,
analysis, news stories, and poetry. Along with the larger BMR
have come needs for more graphics--send yours in! We need a
graphics editor; someone to take on the job of finding artists,
lining up what needs to be done, doing it or getting it done. We
also desperately need a good proofreader, experienced, if
possible. This job would take about six hours per month.

More advertising to pay increased printing costs; call us
(322-2010) if you can help sell ads (even 2 or 3 hours per week). If
you know a business which might take an ad, call us. Take a
classified with us— 8 cents per word.

The demand for the paper is rapidly growing. Every day
women call the office asking where BMR can be bought, and our
distribution outlets are increasing. We plan to triple (for a start)
these outlets and are working on this now. It’s a big job. Please
help. We need women to get new outlets, stock existing ones, and
ultimately we will need someone to take over distribution
coordination entirely. This involves responsibility for all mailings.

Income is increasing, but so are expenses, so we are still
not out of the dark here. We're picking up about 30 new subs per
month, plus doing bulk mailings to bookstores and women’s
centers around the country.

We're increasing promotional activities and hope to offer
more women’s cultural events: music, poetry readings, film
series, etc.

We need: more subscriptions . . . Encourage everyone you
know to subscribe. Pledges. . . No amount too small or too large. $
for salaries. . . A better BMR requires more time from staffers.
Many are volunteers, some receive a bare subsistence wage.
Putting out the paper is a full-time job and can’t be done without
some salary money. If you know individuals or community-minded
groups who could contribute to this, please encourage them to
do so.

Where We Work

We've recently doubled office space to accommodate our
increased activities. We need: desks, overhead lights, chairs,
paint, envelopes (business size), thumb tacks, a 4x6 file card box,
note pads, lettering for our door, money (the rent went up).

We've talked a lot about classism and plan an issue on class
and Feminism, possibly for October. We also plan issues on day
care, women and madness, women in the military, revolution
(psychic, physical, spiritual, personal, political).

We hope to publish a poetry anthology from past BMR’s in
time for Christmas.

We are trying now to make BMR a regional women's
newspaper for the West. We need correspondents and distribution
points in all Western states. If you have contacts, let us know
about them, or them about us.

One of our big dreams is to publish every two weeks. We're
tentatively aiming for January or February of 1975. This is going to
require more full-time staffers and, thereby, more money for
salaries to pay these staffers. We're checking out possibilities of
grants for this purpose. If you have ideas on this, we'd love to hear
them.

What We’re Thinking About

Five of us are now living collectively, sharing a painting job
and a secretarial job and working almost full-time on BMR. Big
Mama pays one $250/month salary, which we also share. (We are
house painters--if you know of any jobs we can bid on, please get
in touch.)

In our personal lives we have been dealing with the overall
question of a woman's civilization and what that means. We feel a
woman’s civilization has to happen on all levels: cultural,
spiritual, political, personal, and philosophical, and are working
on these areas within our living collective and within BMR.

Living collectively has brought us many challenges and
many changes. And a lot of personal growth. We've had to define
and re-define our purpose and the way each one of us fits into
that. We've become more responsible to ourselves, each other,
and the women's community. We are stimulated; we work harder;
we see results; these results, in turn, give us added stimulus.

But while our minds and souls are turned on, our bodies are
exhausted. We’re looking for ways to solve that problem, for we
learned long ago the farce of altruism.

If you can share your work with Big Mama, Big Mama can
share her satisfaction with you, a reciprocal arrangement.
Reciprocity, fairness, holding together is what this Women’s
Movement is about.

affection. I’m really glad that
I’m over that now.

It’s a good feeling to be able
to touch somebody. It’s part
of what we’re about - feeling
and loving and caring.

On Thursday night before the Women's Festival, the Denver Women’s Center Coalition (DWCC) met to finalize plans for the Colorado Women's Festival and to make organizational decisions.  

It was decided that any funds from the Women’s Festival would be temporarily held until more definite plans could be made about the Denver Women’s Center. A temporary Women’s Center Council was chosen, made up of nine members--one from each of the six groups which were active organizing the festival, and three members to meet to make recommendations to the larger coalition on the following subjects: bylaws (or how decisions are made and by whom); statements of purpose (or what will the Women’s Center be and for whom); financial statements, incorporation, and criteria regarding who will be future members of the Women’s Center.  

An open meeting has been called for September 12, by which time the Council will present its reports to the coalition members, for discussion. The September 12 meeting will be held at 7:30 at the First Southern Baptist Church at 16th and Pearl.  

The groups which will be represented on a temporary council are: Rocky Mountain Women in the Arts, Herstory Theatre Group, Lesbian Task Force, Women in Transition, Big Mama Rag, and the Coalition Against Sexual Assault.

A Working Class

Perspective:

One Woman’s Personal Account

INTRODUCTION

There are some things that have to be said about class issues and they have to be said now. Some of us are getting hurt, a lot of us are getting angry, and it has to stop. What is happening is that middle - and upper-class sisters are laying heavy trips on working class women. I want to deal with that problem, and there is a lot to say about it. Most of it is painful, and more of it is easy. I am very grateful to Big Mama Rag for expressing an interest in class struggle and for allowing working class women the chance to be heard. Few others have listened at all.

I have decided, after a great deal of thought about it, to remain anonymous, for several reasons. First, I would be personally embarrassed for anyone to make special exceptions for me because of my struggles. Second, the purpose of this article is to reveal some of the gut issues of class struggle, not to air my personal grievances against an unjust society. Other opinions on the class issue as it relates to Feminism are wholeheartedly welcomed.

The only way I can deal with this issue is to draw on my own experience and consciousness. For me, this begins with an analysis of my childhood and what that has meant to my life.

I was plenty aware of class status when I was a kid, because we didn’t have any -- or if we did, it was at the very bottom. I grew up poor, the oldest of 4 children, in small midwestern farming towns. My father was a salesman and he never did very well until I was in high school and he and my mother started teaching school. Until then, we moved around a lot, like about once a year or more often. My mother worked at odd jobs, took in laundry and mending, and went to college part-time (when we had the money) while we were growing up, so that eventually she could bring in more money for our family. My mother was definitely from a working-class background, and my father was probably lower-middle-class because he was a preacher's son, even though his parents often struggled for survival, too.

Our family struggle while I was growing up was a determined one. The only real security we had was our love for each other, and even that grew thin at times, when we got really desperate. I never had enough to eat, and I remember there was at least one long stretch where all we had to eat was bread and milk, and we were glad for that. Often I had nothing to eat at school, even though there was hot lunch, because we couldn't afford it. We never went on welfare and I think the reason was either that we never knew it existed or if my father did know, he was too proud to have accepted it. It seemed there were a lot of times we nearly starved to death or thought we would, and I know we kids at least would have been glad for anything, no matter where it came from.

My parents had firm moral convictions and a firmly ingrained Puritan work ethic. Things like lying and stealing were punished severely, and I went through one long phase of stealing where I was black and blue all the time. There was never any play until the work was all done, never any liquor in the house, and we all went to church on Sundays unless somebody was sick, which was pretty often. Even so, we had a lot of fun making up silly games and just talking about things. No matter how bad things got, we weren't going to let it get us down if we could help it. These were some of the attitudes I grew up with that influenced me greatly.

But there were other influences at work, too, that were much more devastating in their effect, and much more insidious. Being poor meant mostly shame. I never had new clothes, except when my mother would “make something over” for me. My clothes were often too big or too little, and never in style. (I vaguely knew about style, but it never mattered much whether I did or not because we couldn't have afforded it anyway.)

As a child, I never understood why other kids wouldn't play with me and why their mothers wouldn't allow me to go to their kids’ houses. I knew it had something to do with our poverty, but I knew we weren’t “white trash” either. This enforced isolation had several effects on me. It hurt me deeply and probably forever, made me angry, made me feel ashamed and somehow “not good enough.”

I fought back with street words and often with my fists. I compensated in school by working hard and getting straight A's, and thereby won at least partial respect from my teachers. But I had practically no social life as a child. We moved too often, for one thing. And everywhere we went, I was avoided, ridiculed, and generally disliked for no reason that I could see. I remember being terribly confused at these cruel reactions from my classmates. In my own eyes and in the eyes of my family, I was a bright, sensitive, imaginative child who cared very much about other people. It was hard to understand why the love I gave so readily was returned with so much hostility, lies, ridicule, and fear.

At times I toughened myself. Other times I cried. Most of the time I was shy and defensive. I played with animals, who responded easily, made up games for myself and fantasies where I was a princess and all the other kids would treat me nice and bring me presents, and I learned nature. The out-of-doors was the only world I felt at ease in, because the sky and the earth and the silent growing things did not cast me out for any reason, let alone reasons I couldn't understand.

Sometimes my intense longing for friends, companionship, and conversation made me so desperate I would set out to “be accepted or else.” I would “show them” that I could “be somebody” too. And I would try to fix myself up as clean and neat as possible and politely ask somebody to come over to my house. And maybe they would, but mostly not. I would try so hard to be liked by them, I would do anything they wanted, even stupid, demeaning things. But it never really worked the way I always imagined it would.

I remember once someone I liked very much wanted me to steal some money for her out of the teacher's desk. She said if I would, she would buy me some candy after school. I fought with my conscience half the morning, and my conscience lost. I stole the money, thinking that at last maybe this was a way somebody would be friends with me. After school, we went down to the grocery store, and she said to pick out whatever I wanted. I chose carefully and took a long time (I hardly ever got to eat candy), while she was getting impatient and said to hurry up. I did, and we went to the counter to pay for it. She paid for hers, and then came a moment of revelation I will never forget as long as I live. She told the storekeeper that I was going to pay for my own, put the rest of the money in her pocket and ran out of the store yelling, “Sucker!”

I was so horrified and embarrassed that I dropped the candy and went outside and cried. I remember thinking how I had trusted her utterly and never once imagined that she could do anything so mean and cruel. I felt betrayed and cheated, and right then, in those first hot waves of anger, I began to see the source of all the injustice and cruelty. The real source was money, because money was power, and I had none.

As a child, I saw quite clearly a world where there was no entrance for me. So many times I wanted to scream, “How do I make you see that I am a person worth listening to, worth loving? Why can’t you put away your self-importance and recognize my right to human dignity?” But I wouldn't have known how to say it then, and I was laughed at so often that I only felt it would be useless.

I was taught by my parents that the only way to overcome all the problems facing me in my life was to go to college, and I was convinced at a very early age that a college education was the only answer to an otherwise certain future of desolation and

Analysis

Part 1

Why this personal account is important Although the trend is beginning to change, the women we hear from most are women from middle and upper class backgrounds. What about the real majority of women in the country -- the workers (and women who were raised in lower and working class families)? While one woman's struggle, as told here, does not purport to be representative of all working class or poverty backgrounds, its validity lies in the fact that her experiences, attitudes, and pain are a bond she shares with other working class women and which she does not share with women from other class backgrounds. We seldom hear what that feels like or how those experiences work in interaction among women. We know that experiential differences can keep us apart without us consciously realizing it. (Think for a minute who your closest friends are and what kind of background they have. Chances are, if their backgrounds are similar to yours, that you will see the truth of that statement.) We have to learn what there is about class attitudes and differences that keeps us apart, so that we can work to change things in ourselves that are destructive, and so we can understand and work with one another. This personal account is not just somebody's “sob story.” It should be the starting point for serious thought about what's going on in the feminist movement and why so many women feel excluded or alienated.

Women as a Caste

Just as problems among women from different class backgrounds create tension among us, we have to realize that this is all part of a larger oppression of women as an inferior caste in the patriarchal structure. Any perspective on class issues in the feminist movement must have as a reference point the fact that women are oppressed first as women and secondarily for their class background, among other things, such as their race or sexual preferences.

Some of the Problems

In thinking and talking about class and caste issues, women will be criticized for creating schisms in the women’s community. The problem is that they are already there.

Another problem is that in looking at value systems, we tend to make broad generalities, categorize and classify, in order to reach some of the causes of class problems. In the initial stages, we may fail to recognize that through raised consciousness, some women have managed to overcome the values, restraints, and/or oppression of their class backgrounds, and I think that is beautiful. But on the other hand, it’s very easy to think, “Well, they're not talking about me because I’m an exception,” and too often that’s just a cop-out. What

To The Denver Post:

This letter is being written  
in objection to your article on  
Big Mama Rag on page 3 of  
Sunday, September 8, 1974,  
Denver Post. The article was  
obviously biased, prejudiced  
and sexist in content, reflect-  
ing Mr. Goldman's personal  
fears. I hardly considered the  
article as objective reporting,  
and was surprised and dis-  
mayed that the Denver Post  
would even print it.

Mr. Goldman seemed to  
feel that since BMR was by  
women for women that it was  
“out to get” men. I have a  
close male friend who reads  
every issue which comes out.  
He does not feel that the  
paper is “out to get” him and  
even finds it enlightening.  
Besides, there are several  
dozens of exclusively men's  
magazines on the newsstands  
today, men are highly involved  
in many of the more tradition-  
al women’s magazines, and  
for hundreds of years men  
controlled who could read and  
write. So why is Mr. Goldman  
so fearful of one struggling  
women's newspaper?

Much was also made of Ms.  
Waters' statement that she  
was “indifferent” to men as if  
her indifference was both  
criminal and reflective of the  
attitude of BMR. Man's  
history shows he has been  
“indifferent” to women for  
thousands of years if not  
unjust, cruel, hateful and  
inhuman. And if BMR, or its  

staff, are “out to get” men,  
how can they also be  
“indifferent”? It seems incon-  
sistency is a male trait, too.

Last spring, a friend of mine  
became involved with BMR on  
a volunteer basis and then  
became one of the paid staff  
members, so I have been  
informed of the basic changes  
and objectives of BMR. Big  
Mama Rag was originally  
structured in a traditional  
manner and eventually many  
of the women involved felt a  
need for restructuring along  
less traditional lines. Through  
a desire to represent all  
women, the many women  
involved with BMR cooperated  
in love and understanding to  
create the present structure.  
My friend is now a coordina-  
tor, which precisely describes  
her activities and all women  
who wish to may help decide  
which articles are printed in  
BMR. The paper is not  
controlled by a minority few  
as Mr. Goldman stated.

Finally, Mr. Goldman re-  
sorted to Lesbian baiting by  
reporting that BMR was  
controlled by Lesbians  
preaching separatism. Over  
the past several months, I  
have met and known many of  
these women and I find them  
intelligent, creative and with a  
high, positive energy level.  
When I am with them, I  
experience a warm loving that  
accepts me and all those  
around them for who we are.  
Never during my acquaintance  
with these women have any of  
them approached me and  
preached separatism.

Since one of the more basic  
endeavors of the Women’s  
Movement is for women to  
define herself, it is my belief  
that Lesbian women may be  
best able to do this. The  
Lesbian woman is totally  
involved with and dedicated to  
women and is woman defining  
woman.

No, I am not a Lesbian, but I  
am a budding Feminist who  
cares about and loves my  
sisters. When Mr. Goldman  
attempted to discredit Big  
Mama Rag and those con-  
nected with it, he also  
attempted to discredit all  
women. This has gone on far  
too long and men had best  
realize it before he destroys  
himself.

Sincerely yours,  
Barbara A. Main

Working Woman’s Account...

From Page 1

Poverty. I was literally driven
by my fears to achieve as high
a goal as I could set for
myself, and I knew from the
beginning that I would have to
do it alone. There would never
be money in our family for
college, yet it was my parents’
burning hope that each of us
would go.

In my head, if I did not go to
college, it would mean that I
would never have friends,
never make a decent living,
and there was a very real fear
of starving to death in
loneliness and disgrace. (The
thing about friends was really
interesting. I thought for
many years that the only way
I would ever have friends was if
somehow I could get money
to buy nice clothes and live in
a nice house. I thought having
friends meant that you had to
have money, because that was
the message I was getting
loud and clear. This associa-
tion got me into a lot of
trouble with myself and
others, because at those rare
times when I did have a little
money, I often used it to try to
“buy” friends, and it wasn’t
until I saw that I was getting
ripped off and used that I
knew it wasn’t just the money
that was power; it was
everything that came with
money, and again I knew I was
still on the losing end of it.)

Because no one had ever
helped me before, with money
or making friends, I simply
assumed that no one ever
would. I made self-reliance a
supreme virtue, and some-
where in that process I went
through a “sour grapes” trip. I
decided that the virtues of
achievement were better than
the virtues of money (which
was actually correct thinking
but for all the wrong reasons
then), and I determined that I
would “be somebody” so
great that everyone would
have to respect me whether I
had money or not. I would
become famous (just as soon
as I worked out all the details).

All my hopes lay in the
future, and I worked very hard
to get there. I still struggled
for acceptance and friends,
but mostly to survive. I grew
up strong by myself, dream-
ing dreams of myself the way
I wanted to become, not once
thinking of failure. There was
no question in my mind that I
would make it: I had to. The
only alternative was death in

one form or another, and
since I was already living
through a very real social

“death”, no alternatives but
success were acceptable to
me. There was only one way
out, and I would get there no
matter what. The worse things
got, the harder I worked. At
the age of 11 I went to work for
real.

With my first job, at 11
years of age, came a growing
awareness of another nasty
little thing the world can
throw a person: the concept
of the inferiority of woman-
kind. I was surprised I hadn't
noticed it before, but there it
was, bigger than life.

I worked in the fields,
hoeing weeds out of bean
fields, shoveling manure, and
tending livestock. There were
a lot of things I wasn’t allowed
to do because I was a girl, and
that really made me mad. I
was taller, stronger, and
faster than any boy in my
class, and since the argument
used against “heavy” work
was that I might hurt myself,
it didn’t make any sense at all.

I set out to really prove
myself, and before long I was
working on a pony farm, doing
everything no one else wanted
to do. I threw bales, cleaned
tack (bridles, saddles, har-
ness, etc.), groomed horses
and trimmed hooves, mixed
grain, all kinds of things.
Most of the work was fun
because I felt I was helping
the animals to have a better
life, and that made me feel
good. But a lot of it was dirty
and hard, and I wondered if
“proving myself” had been
such a good idea; I was being
used in the worst way. I made
about 25 cents an hour and I
never saw a penny of it. It
went to put food on our family
table. (The most I ever made
until I was out of high school
was 85 cents an hour, and that
was working 12 to 16 hours a
day in the fields, doing
backbreaking work with only
one break, which lasted as
long as it took to eat whatever
lunch I had.)

And I did get hurt some at
my first job; a stack of bales
fell on me once, I got kicked
frequently, and several times I
was jumped on by ponies or
trampled. I never complained
to anybody, though, because
if I did I would lose my job,
and we needed the money;
also, I was learning a lot, and
that was very valuable to me. I
was only 13 then.

Since the day I first started
working, I haven't stopped.
After a while, I got to keep
some of the money, which
was great except that I used it
all wrong. At first I didn’t
realize that it was mine
because I had earned it. I
thought it was like a present
or something, and I spent it all
right away, or gave it to
someone who said they
needed it, or bought things for
other people. My parents
encouraged me to save, but it
was always such a pitiful
amount that it never seemed
to grow fast enough and there
was always something I
needed. It seemed impossible
that I would ever have
anything really big from what
I had earned, so I used it for my
own material comforts or
shims of the moment. That
seemed perfectly logical to
me, but my parents criticized
me sharply for wasting money
on things that weren’t abso-
lutely necessary. A lot of
times I listened to them, but
more often I felt that I
deserved to spend my money
any way I wanted since I'd
worked so hard to earn it.
Sometimes I felt terribly
selfish, though, for spending
money just for myself when
the rest of my family was just
as bad off as I was, and I felt
very guilty because I didn’t
share as much as I thought I
should. The fact that there
wasn’t much to share didn’t
make any difference; I was
used to that by then.

When I finally got into high
school, I discovered several
unique ways to achieve a
small amount of popularity.
The other kids were starting to
think about college then, and
since I got good grades, I
began to be “useful” at last by
helping other kids with their
school work. I was totally
aware that I was being used,
and why, but I was so glad for
some social contacts that I
didn’t care too much. Then in
our state, girls’ athletics were
very popular, and since I was
pretty good at sports, I made
varsity on all the teams and

made some friends that way.
But I was seldom asked out on
dates or to parties, and I still
felt very keenly the ostracism
of my classmates. I just
wasn’t “in”, and it was the
same story all over again. I
had no close friends, no one I
could really talk to or who
even seemed to care very
much whether I existed or not.
I worked harder than ever and
dreamed my dreams of col-
lege and future success.

The time finally came and I
was accepted to the college of
my choice, a medium-sized
state school with a good
reputation and low tuition,
and I nervously awaited to
hear about scholarships. The
college didn’t help me, but my
high school teachers did, and
I was so pleased and
embarrassed at the time I
thought I'd faint. It was only
$100, but that was a fortune to
me. I applied for work and a
government loan for the rest,
and that came through, too,
which seemed like a miracle
to me. I didn’t think I deserved
such good luck.

There I was at a major
turning point in my life -- with
the tool of college within my
reach, I was ready to build a
secure future and bury my
past forever. But I hadn't
counted on a lot of unexpect-
ed problems. Like sororities
and the incredible elitism bred
of the assumed superiority of
the middle and upper classes.
Like the fact that all the things
I thought to free myself from
confronted me more power-
fully than ever, with pressures
to conform to values I only
knew from the wrong side of
the tracks.

The things that still counted
with my classmates in college
were things I still did not
have: money, social standing,
good communication skills,
popularity. Time and again I
came across the power that
money has, when all my
friends would go out to eat, or
go shopping, or plan trips.
That was all totally impossible
for me. With stars in my eyes,
I made a bad mistake right
away. I went out for rush,
hoping to find sisterhood and
friendship with other women
in a close-knit group. The
entire process sickened me.
At rush parties I was greeted
with politeness and that was
all. My clothes were in
impossibly “poor taste”
(which was not at all
humorous to me), my man-
ners were not like anyone
else’s, and I was obviously an
“outsider” by my appearance
alone. I could not help that,
but I think then that that was
my last stand against being
judged on someone else’s
terms alone.

Others could talk about the
big money projects they were
involved in, or the car they
were going to get when they
graduated, or the house they
were going to buy, or the
clothes. All I could talk about
was if I had enough money to
eat for the rest of the week,
because that was on my mind
a lot. A lot of times I was
broke by Thursdays, and I
really tried to stretch my
money out, too. The differ-
ence between me and the
other people I knew was that
when my money was gone,
there was no more, period.
Being broke for me meant flat
broke, which, I discovered,
did not mean the same thing
