Part 2

The primary factors that
determine a person’s class
identity are:

1. THE WORK SHE DOES:

The bulk of work working
class women do is service,
factory, or office work, most
often low-paying and with
little hope for advancement. If
she has a family, she must
work two jobs: one in her
home and one in the labor
force. Work is a necessity for
her, not an option. The bulk of
work middle class women do
is managerial, professional,
or volunteer. For middle class
women, their work is not a
material necessity but an
attempt to achieve fulfillment
or escape boredom under the
illusion that somehow their
jobs are beneficial to the
world.

2. HER BACKGROUND:

The working class back-
ground: A woman growing up
in a working class family
knows what it is like to have
material needs. Her labor
power is important from the
time she is small, and often
she begins supporting herself
while still in her teens.
Schools and parents try to

Page 3

channel her into learning
practical skills for survival
such as home-ec and secre-
tarial skills, rather than
college-prep courses. If she
rebels against this, she learns
no skills and must work at the
lowest-paying, non-skilled
jobs or resort to prostitution.
If she aspires and goes on to
college, she finds it a
constant struggle. Because
she lacks the right contacts,
she has great difficulty
learning about loans and
scholarships and receives
little help finding employment
after graduation.

The middle class back-
ground: A woman growing up
in a middle class family learns
the skills necessary to “make
it” in the system. She learns
the proper ways of speaking
and relating to people. She
develops self-confidence
through the security of her
social environment. She is
assured of a college educa-
tion, learns what is expected
of her, and is promised a
social position. She has the
luxury of sampling the latest
fads, experimenting with dif-
ferent life-styles, or doing
things just for the experience,
because she knows that she
can always get money from
her parents if she needs it.
When she takes a low-paying
job, it is temporary because
she has the skills, contacts
and education to either find
another job or to align herself
with a middle class man.

3. HER RELATIONSHIP WITH
MEN:

This is the most important
determinant of class identity.
The economic class system is
a hierarchy of power among
men. A woman's class identi-
ty is determined by her
relationship to men: first by
her father, later by her
husband. The higher up her
man is in the class hierarchy
the more she benefits from
the system. The wife of a
middle class man need not
work for her survival outside
of her home because she is
provided for by her husband.
She is economically depend-
ent on him. The wife of a
working class man is forced to
be economically dependent
upon herself. The family
cannot make ends meet on the
husband’s income alone.

The single woman is obvi-
ously working class (ignoring
a few token exceptions)
because women are the
lowest paid workers. Any
woman who is economically
self-dependent rather than
male-dependent lives in the
material reality of the working
class regardless of her back-
ground.

To conclude, the most
general definition of a working
class woman is one who is
economically self-dependent.

The Denver Post in its issue of Sunday, September 8, published a feature article about Big Mama Rag. The article, in the best tradition of patriarchal arrogance, was a smear intended to discredit not only BMR but the women’s community of Denver and the entire Feminist movement. It is important to realize that the Post article, as written, passed the editor's desk with an okay for publication. This must be recognized as the attitude and position of The Denver Post toward Feminism.

Utilizing tactics of classism, Lesbian-baiting, out-of-context quotes, rampant misrepresentation of facts and innuendo, the article portrayed our women’s newspaper as a narrow-interest publication. (Fact: BMR provides national, regional, and local coverage relating to Feminist theory, women's poetry, women’s health, welfare rights and legislation, Lesbian issues, book reviews, NOW activities, union women's activities, media analysis and community announcements.) By the time UPI had “whispered down the aisle” a Philadelphia radio station named Chocolate Waters as the editor when in fact we have none, and a Houston newspaper called Ronnie Martin the only man on our staff, when in fact we have none.

It is apparent that the Post has at last felt the power and influence of a growing and active women’s community in this city; felt it as a threat. And rightly so. A recent Denver Post devoted four of its eighty-eight pages to women’s news. Over 50% of this space was given to advertising. The copy included fashion news, engagement announcements, news of a home decorators show and Ann Landers’ column, with less than one page of articles actually relevant to women as women.

Reacting out of fear, The Denver Post is contributing strongly to an already hostile political climate in Denver. As the women's movement grows this type of counter-action can be expected to increase. It is important that we have a clear understanding of what is happening and that we not be intimidated or divided by the defensiveness and smear attempts we will encounter.

The Post, realizing the necessity and power of effective communication to a growing movement, made an attempt to cut the heart out of Denver Feminism. By striking at what it considered to be the soft underbelly of Feminism (Lesbianism), the Post attempted to destroy one of our major exchange mediums and thus seriously curtail Feminist communication in Denver.

Through letters to the editor and cancellation of subscriptions we can show the Post (and other media interests) that the Denver women’s community cannot be so easily trampled or brushed aside.

The Post has performed two invaluable services for Denver Feminists: first, it has clearly revealed the position and depth of resistance we must overcome in order to realize Feminist principles in Denver; secondly, it has shown us the type of tactics which will be used against us; i.e., name-calling and traditional appeals to the standard bigotry against anyone who is not white, not male, not middle class and not supporting patriarchy.

To the Man Reporter from the Denver Post

Chocolate Waters

I knew from the start it was a mistake to talk to you—

Six Radical Feminists and the Man of the Press and his frightened photographer with the evil eye.

Even with those odds we were outnumbered.

But you expected us to be reasonable to defer to you as a man and a member of the Almighty Male Media to explain our position logically, to smile a lot.

After all we are living in a civilized world:

RECALL a picture of a woman hunched up on top of her knees, her mouth awry, the red blood rolling around her ankles like falling red stones with nowhere to go.

She is naked.

She is also dead.

The victim of an “abortionist” who already had all the money she could borrow tucked inside his shirt pocket when he left her there.

RECALL the housewife married 25 years to a man who called her Lard Butt because she ate a lot remembering the time when she had no food because her alcoholic father drank it all up. Married to a man who wanted to punch her frequently for being “stupid” and often did, then sat at his supper table like a king saying, “The potatoes are lumpy. You've burned the roast. and I’M the one who likes cream in my coffee.” We see it every day on TV - only in your version she’s the buffoon.

RECALL a young woman in the dormitory of a midwestern university lying unobtrusively on the floor with a broom handle rammed so murderously up between her legs that her intestines were hanging out her mouth like tiny penises in reminder—

It was not an isolated incident.

RECALL an old woman run over under the wheels of an Army truck driven by a young GI who could’ve been anybody's brother. Fleeing from her burning hut, she was a gook and the Enemy anyway; the story wasn't newsworthy.

RECALL a Lesbian woman whose face was torn apart by the irate husband of a straight friend. He claimed she had designs on his woman over coffee. She took the case to court.

“Are you a Lesbian?” the judge said. “Yes,” she said.

“Case dismissed,” he said. He didn’t say it would've been just as OK had he killed you. (The story did not make front-page news).

RECALL the 19th century sailors who captured an island full of Polynesian women - dragged them on their ships and brutalized and raped them, then tossed them overboard to drown. And when to the men’s surprise the women swam, the sailors shot them through the heads for sport with bullet holes arranged by one click of one finger pulled through weapons resembling pricks and talking louder.

It only took us 200 years to find this out.

RECALL NINE MILLION WOMEN tortured individually as witches over a period of FOUR HUNDRED YEARS which we never read three lines about in all your scholarly history books.

RECALL the disc jockeys of Every Major City in This Country who laugh at women 100 times a broadcast: “I was going to do a bit about the groupie as bowwow, but I lost the dog...” or “And there we have Helen Reddy singing ‘I Am Woman,’ the national anthem of Women’s Lib - Can you imagine saluting a broad on a flagpole?...”

Can you imagine a woman doing any of these things?

Because she hates men as you and your kind have hated women since the beginning of the time you first appeared on this earth?

Yet there you sit in your 20th century casuals—casually—with a notebook in your hands. Your hands writing busily. Your hands that are so clean they never dirty anything more than newsprint. Your mouth working rapidly. In the midst of six women-identified-women you say, “So first you get freedom for Blacks, then for women, then for Lesbians, then for rapists, then for axe-murderers. Now isn’t that carrying the argument to absurdity?”

Well, of course not. Anyone knows that it is completely reasonable to classify Lesbians with axe-murderers (though personally I have never known either a rapist or an axe-murderer who was a woman).

So we don’t smile at you. And you are shocked when we talk about the “boys and their games” (and you think THAT'S discrimination!)

Shocked when we say we are indifferent to you.

So shocked that you are compelled to write about “Lesbian bombardment and man-hating polemics.”

After you’ve said that the “women with beehive hairdos are really the enemy.” (You should look to your own polemics.)

The night after your article appeared in the Denver Post someone called me on the phone and said,

“Are you that man-hating lezzy Chocolate Waters? You're the one I want. I'm going to rape you and murder you.”

Six months ago someone called my sister on the phone 1600 miles away. She is not a Lesbian. She is not even quite a woman yet.

The voice said,

“Is your name Tena Waters? You're the one I want. I'm going to rape you and murder you.”

Neither voice belonged to a woman wearing a beehive hairdo...

Colorado Labor Union Women Move to  
Organize the Unorganized.

Women trade unionists  
from as diverse unions as the  
United Rubber Workers, the  
American Federation of  
Teachers, the Amalgamated  
Clothing Workers and the  
American Postal Workers Un-  
ion met together September  
14 to found the Denver chapter  
of the Coalition of Labor  
Union Women (CLUW).

CLUW was founded at a  
national convention in Chica-  
go in March of this year where  
3,200 union women from 58  
national and international  
unions attended. The stated  
purposes of the organization  
are to increase women’s  
participation in their unions,  
to press for reforms for  
women through legislative  
and political action, to initiate  
affirmative action programs  
and to aid in the organizing of  
unorganized women into the  
union movement.

Since the founding conven-  
tion, women in New York, De-  

troit, Seattle, Washington  
D.C., Los Angeles and other  
cities across the country have  
successfully held founding  
conferences to establish local  
CLUW chapters. The signifi-  
cance of the organization lies  
in the fact that it brings many  
of the issues raised by the  
women’s liberation movement  
into the realm of working  
women who up until now have  
often felt that the women’s  
movement was not concerned  
with their problems. The  
Coalition hopes to give rank  
and file union women a voice  
in their unions and on their  
jobs.  
The September 14 Denver  
meeting drew about 60 women  
from about 25 different locals  
in the area. The meeting laid  
out the basic purpose of the

COALITION OF LABOR UNION WOMEN  
STATEMENT OF PURPOSE  

(As adopted at the founding  
conference, March 23-24)

Of the 34 million women in  
the work force-- little more  
than four million women are  
members of unions. It is  
imperative that within the  
framework of the union move-  
ment, we take aggressive  
steps to more effectively  
address ourselves to the  
critical needs of 30 million  
unorganized sisters and to  
make our unions more re-  
sponsive to the needs of all  
women, especially the needs  
of minority women who have  
been singled out for particu-  
larly blatant oppression.

Women unionists work in  
almost every industry, in  
almost every part of the  
country. Despite their geo-  
graphical, industrial and oc-  
cupational separations, union  
women share common con-  
cerns and goals.

Full equality of opportuni-  
ties and rights in the labor  
force require the full attention  
of the labor movement...and  
especially, the full attention  
of women who are part of the  
labor movement.

The primary purposes of  
this new national coalition is  
to unify all union women in a  

viable organization to deter-  
mine, first - our common  
problems and concerns, and,  
second - to develop action  
programs within the frame-  
work of our unions to deal  
effectively with our object-  
ives. Through unity of pur-  
pose, the Coalition of Labor  
Union Women will seek to  
accomplish these goals. We  
recognize that our struggle  
goes beyond the borders of  
this nation and seek to link up  
with our working sisters and  
brothers throughout the world  
through concrete action of  
international workers’ solidar-  
ity.  
ORGANIZING THE  
UNORGANIZED WOMEN  

Since less than twelve  
percent of the women in  
today’s labor force are en-  
rolled in labor unions, it is  
obvious that most working  
women are suffering eco-  
nomically. Statistics clearly  
demonstrate that the union  
member enjoys higher wa-  
ges, better fringe benefits and  
working conditions and great-  
er job security than the unor-  
ganized worker. The Coalition  
of Labor Union Women seeks  
to promote unionism and to  
encourage unions to be more  

aggressive in their efforts to  
bring unorganized women  
under collective bargaining  
agreements, particularly in  
those areas where there are  
large numbers of unorganized  
and/or minority women.  
CLUW will seek to create a  
greater awareness of the  
benefits of union member-  
ship. Within our intra-, inter-,  
and emerging union structure,  
we will work to encourage  
non-union women to join us in  
the trade union movement.  
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION IN  
THE WORKPLACE  
Employers continue to pro-  
fit by dividing workers on  
sexual, racial and age lines.  
This encourages the segrega-  
tion of job classifications and  
results in wage and benefit  
losses to women. The power  
of unions must increasingly  
be brought to bear, through  
the process of collective  
bargaining, to correct these  
inequities. The Coalition will  
seek to encourage women,  
through their unions, to  
recognize and take positive  
action against job discrimina-  
tion in hiring, promotion,  
classification and other as-  
pects of work. Women must  
learn what their rights are  

under the law. They must  
become more knowledgeable  
of the specifics of collective  
bargaining and of the contract  
clauses and workplace  
practices which discriminate  
against them. They must be  
informed about what is and  
can be done within the labor  
movement to correct these  
situations. We seek to edu-  
cate and inspire our union  
brothers to help achieve  
affirmative action in the  
workplace.  
POLITICAL ACTION  
AND LEGISLATION  

It is imperative that union  
women, through action pro-  
grams of the Coalition,  
become more active partici-  
pants in the political and  
legislative processes of our  
union and our unions. Move-  
ment for full employment, and  
job opportunities, shorter  
work week without loss of  
pay, child care legislation, a  
livable minimum wage for all  
workers, improved maternity  
and pension benefits, im-  
proved health and safety  
coverage, expanded educa-  
tional opportunities, mass  
action for final ratification of  
the Equal Rights Amendment  
(ERA), guaranteed collective  

bargaining rights for all  
workers, the right to strike  
and an extension of truly  
protective legislation for all  
workers are only a few of the  
political action programs in  
which CLUW must partici-  
pate. Whenever and wherever  
possible CLUW urges all  
women to seek election to  
political office.  
PARTICIPATION OF WOMEN  

WITHIN THEIR UNIONS  

The Coalition seeks to  
inspire and educate union  
women to ensure and  
strengthen their participation,  
through full and complete  
democratic procedures, to  
encourage their leadership  
and their movement into  
policy-making roles within  
their own unions and within  
the union movement in all  
areas. The Coalition supports  
the formation of women’s  
committees and women's  
caucuses within trade unions  
wherever necessary.

WOMEN &
Shells

a column

Artemis

As our consciousness is being collectively raised by one
another; as we fill a womanspace fuller of our needs in areas like
midwifery, herbery, music, art; as we come closer each day to
what it truly is to be women, it strikes me funny that we are
ignoring a basic part of that journey -- total health.

I'm speaking about going beyond self-examinations,
home-deliveries and herbal medicine. To Being exactly what the
Great Mother Goddess made us to be in every way. I won't
elaborate on that idea as a whole now, however I do want to deal
with one specific.

Smoking, no matter how you look at it, is destructive, not
only to the individual doing it but all who are in her vicinity.

I would like to take issue with the politics behind cigarette
smoking. First and foremost it’s the Man's vice, designed to be an
eternal profit maker for such war mongers as American Tobacco
Company. One of the many legal vices that the people empty their
pocketbooks over the privilege of consuming. Second, it’s a
pacifier, one of the many offered to us from birth, rubber
pacifiers, suckers -- to keep us in our place, keep us from
speaking up, giving us a false sense of security. Third, it keeps
hands busy, more often than not, too busy to be doing more
constructive things. Many manage to smoke and perform a myriad
of tasks at the same time, little realizing what a psychic drain it is
to be doing two or more things at a time.

Cigarettes have the curious property of being a stimulant
and a depressant at the same time. Although not a stimulant in
the purest sense, many use cigarettes either consciously or
unconsciously to stay awake or to wake up. How many late night
meetings, parties or rap sessions would survive without nicotine?
How many people could go on spending money in America's bars
without falling asleep were it not for the shock treatment received
each time a cigarette is smoked? Although not a depressant in the
purest sense, bear in mind the numerous people who ward off
hunger and weight gain by lighting up. During times of stress and
nervousness, the air is clouded with a continuous stream of smoke
that dulls the senses out of awareness. Awareness of a stressful
situation is essential in learning how to deal with it and feeling
that stress often motivates people to avoid making a mistake a
second time.

Some very primary senses are dulled also, like that of smell.
Deadened olfactory nerves will not serve a person when needed
to experience the full pleasure of an apple blossom. The olfactory nerve’s
partner in delight, the taste bud, combine to give pleasure in
culinary indulgence. This pleasure is far from what it could be for
the smoker. I'm not sure how much credence you would lend to
my belief that even the clarity of hearing and sight are impaired
but all would agree that there is little to compare with a heavy dose
of fresh mountain air and clean lungs enhance this delight a
hundredfold.

I figure by now anyone who is at all concerned with their
health and the health of their loved ones is still reading. I’m not
communicating with you to proselytize or be self-righteous. I
know full well that people stop hurting themselves only when they
are ready to and all of the information or scare tactics in the world
isn't going to change that. In some ways I can understand where
smokers are at, I smoked for 10 years and I will not climb my
soapbox about inconsiderate smokers.

The purpose of this essay is to point out how we as women
are being robbed of a more total life by indulging as individuals in
a counter-productive vice. Imagine if you will as I do a world where
people gained the self-love and control to stop putting these
tubular objects in our mouths, applying flame and then inhaling
dignity out of our lives.

- ROC THER

Books
Women’s Life and Work in the Southern Colonies. A decade later, her
research at last completed, the book was published by the
University of North Carolina Press. W.W. Norton & Co., New York, 1972
reading this 400-page volume will absorb colonial daily life from the
founding of the colonies to plantation, small farm and city. The large questions of
why women came and where they lived are answered, as well as the small ones like
what was in a colonial bedroom, and what were household necessities and
luxuries. Generalities are supported by inventories of large estates, letters and
memoirs.

Julia Cherry Spruill began her lengthy research on
female colonial life in 1927 with a grant from the Institute
for Research in Social Science. 

One of the classics of American social history,
Women’s Life and Work in the Southern Colonies, first pub-
lished in 1938, was finally reissued in 1972, when the
time of history caught up with the past come alive: colonial
women's leisures and pastimes, their wardrobes and
accessories - where, how and from what they were made.
She tells of the rituals of courtship and marriage, of
southern women’s education and the contents of a typical
lady’s library.

Women’s Life deals, in addition, with the lesser-
known aspects of the female situation in the colonial era. In
detail she tells of the women who participated in public life.
There was Mistress Margaret Brent, a plantation owner in
Maryland so powerful as to demand a seat in the
Assembly at a time when women weren't even allowed
to speak in church! There were female ferry-keepers,
jailers, printers, and many other “non-feminine” occupations in which the feminine
were actively engaged. Women of all classes were
shopkeepers, artisans, tavern hostesses and planters. Spruill details many of these
women; some are quite fascinating, such as Eliza
Lucas. At age 17, she took over the management of her
father's plantation. In addition to tending to the business,
she spent much time engaged in agricultural experiments. It
was she who introduced the cultivation and processing of
indigo to South Carolina; it became a major export of the
colonies.

Crimes colonial women committed, and the punish-
ments which followed, are another aspect of our social
history one can read about in few other places besides
Women’s Life. Julia Cherry Spruill also deals with the
manner in which the laws and courts regarded women in that
era (not very favorably) by quoting from numerous court
records and newspapers.

Big Mama Rag Vol. 3 No. 4

FDA Nears Decision
on Dalkon Shield Ban

Nancy Heine

No one has ever known
exactly how the intrauterine
(IUD) works to prevent preg-
nancy. But the serious side-
effects of one of these devices--the Dalkon Shield--
are now a matter of public
record: it has been responsi-
ble for 209 septic spontane-
ous abortions and 11 reported
deaths.

On June 27 of this year, the
United States Food and Drug
Administration (FDA) called a
halt to the sale and distribu-
tion of the Dalkon Shield until
it could investigate the matter
further. Studies were con-
ducted and hearings held in
August for that purpose. The
facts are now in, according to
Mary Carol Kelly of the FDA
Press Office, and a statement
on FDA findings and conclu-
sions will come late in
September.

The story goes that over
2000 years ago, camel drivers
inserted stones in the uteri of
their female camels to prevent
conception and birth over long
journeys. Not until 1970,
though, did the IUD come into
wide use among women.
Alarmed by Senate hearings
on the dangers of oral
contraceptives but still desir-
ing birth control, large num-
bers of women in the United
States gave the device a try.

During this time the Dalkon
Shield gained popularity a-
mong women who had never
been pregnant. Touted as the
“IUD that’s changing current
thinking about contracep-
tion,” the Shield claimed to
have a lower rejection rate
than did other IUDs for these
women.

The first Dalkon Shield ad,
which appeared in medical
journals, based its claims on a
single study done by Hugh
Davis, Shield co-inventor and
medical consultant to A.H.
Robins Co., manufacturer of
the device. The ad claimed a
pregnancy rate of 1.1%, an
expulsion rate of 2.3% and a
one year continuation rate--
that is, the number of women
who continue to wear the
Shield for one year--of 94%.

But the study was not
conducted on women who had
the device in place for one
year. It was conducted on 640
women for 3,549 “woman-
months of use.”

Dividing woman-months by
the number of women involved, the average insertion
time was only 5.5 months.

In a later ad, the A.H. Robins
Co. recommended that a
patient use another form of
contraception along with the
Shield for the first three
months of use. An irate
physician, testifying before
the House Hearings on
Medical Devices, noted that
this ad made claims based on
a guarantee covering little
more than two months of time
during which the Shield is the
only form of contraception
recommended.

While these ads were being
published, A.H. Robins had in
its files at least 10 independ-
ently conducted studies
showing the pregnancy rate as
high as 4.3% and continua-
tion rates as low as 41%.

David Links, Director of the
FDA Office of Medical Devic-
es, wrote at this time that
besides “mild puffery” the ads
for the device seemed “rea-
sonable and accurate.”

Meanwhile, reports of heavy
bleeding, painful insertion,
uterine perforation, higher
than expected pregnancy rates
and pregnancy complications
began coming in from women
using the Dalkon Shield as
well as other IUDs. A
physician’s survey by the US
Center for Disease Control
revealed that IUD use led to
more than 3,500 hospitaliza-
tions during the first six
months of 1973.

Then, in May 1974, A.H.
Robins sent out letters to
120,000 physicians advising
them that six deaths and 36
septic abortions appeared to
have been caused by the
Shield. By June, reports of
more deaths and abortions
forced the FDA into action.
Sale and distribution of the
Dalkon Shield were halted.

In July, the Department of
Health, Education and Wel-
fare (HEW) told its 3,000
federally funded family plan-
ning clinics to stop inserting
the Dalkon IUD. But it had
already been phasing them
out for the past two years
because information from
their abortion clinics indicat-
ed that the Shield had a higher
pregnancy rate than had been
advertised.

On August 21st, the FDA
opened a two-day public
hearing to gather facts and
professional opinions about the Shield. Physicians testi-
fied that 1 out of every 25 IUD
pregnancies occur outside of
the uterus and must be
aborted. They added that 209
women had suffered septic (or
infected) spontaneous abor-
tions during Dalkon Shield
pregnancies and that eleven
had died of the resulting
blood poisoning.

Over the Labor Day holiday,
members of the FDA Special
Advisory Sub-Committee met
to assess information gath-
ered at the hearing. But the
final verdict will not be out
until the end of September.

Because the FDA regards
the IUD as a “device” rather
than a drug, it hasn't the
authority to require pre-mar-
ket testing of the contracep-
tive. Neither can it require the
reporting of adverse reactions
associated with the device,
the registration of IUD manu-
facturers nor the attachment
of warning labels to each IUD
package.

Once marketed, however,
the agency can assume a
regulatory function if it is
capable of proving in court
that the product is dangerous
to health when used as
directed or is improperly
labeled. But the FDA only
takes action when it’s sure it
can win in court.

In the past twenty years the
FDA has taken action against
only one IUD. After two slow
years of investigation, the
action was taken just five days
before the House Hearings on
Medical Devices threatened to
expose the Majzlin Spring as a
dangerous device.

In California, the Coalition
of Medical Rights for Women
is not waiting for the FDA
decision. They've filed a
petition with the California
Department of Health calling
for a ban on all further sales
and distribution of IUDs until
they can be further tested for
safety and the adoption of a
regulation that would require
manufacturers to take all
steps necessary to inform
women of the potential
dangers.

Patty Fulcher, chairperson
of the Coalition said, “Women
are tired of being used as
guinea pigs for untested
medical devices sold at
enormous profits by large
drug companies.”

Women’s Life and Work in
the Southern Colonies is a
fascinating and thorough ac-
count of women of the
colonial period. It is factual,
objective history, but by no
means dull or dry. Quotations
from the original sources are
liberally scattered throughout
the book. Women’s Life has a
huge bibliography of primary
sources and a complete index.
Its publication in paperback
makes it a welcome volume to
anyone seriously interested in
the history of the American
woman.

Women’s Liberation Coalition  
Begins Another Term  

The Women's Liberation  
Coalition at the University of  
Colorado has come to life  
again after summer vacation.  
Although some women are  
facing trial for their part in the  
demonstration and occupa-  
tion of a university building  
last spring over the issue of  
day care, the first meeting  
drew about seventy women  
who listened to the history of  
the coalition and got involved  
in making its history for this  
school year.  

The coalition has speakers  
who go into the Boulder  
community to talk about  
women’s liberation. It has a  
media and community con-  
tacts committee and intends  
to coordinate its activities  
with other women’s groups. A  
newsletter will be written to  
hopefully reach dormitories  
with new students who don’t  
understand or have miscon-  
ceptions of women’s libera-  
tion.  

As a result of the day care  
action last spring, the coali-  
tion maintains, the university  
has begun construction on a  
day care center for 60 children  
- hardly enough for the  
demonstrated need for child  
care. It won't be finished until  
March or April (it was  

supposed to open this month)  
and student housing fees are  
building it. Fees for married  
student housing and for  
Kiddie Kampus, the small day  
care center the University now  
has, have been raised to pay  
back the loan. There is also a  
conflict between the concept  
of a center for child care and  
private home child care. The  
University favors individually  
licensed child care homes.  
Future action around the  
issue is planned at the next  
Regent meeting sometime in  
October.  

Another area that affects  
women at the school is the  
struggle that workers in the  
student grill have had and  
continue to have with man-  
agement. According to one  
woman who was recently fired  
from the grill with no warning  
(contrary to State Personnel  
procedure that requires 3  
warnings, 2 of which must be  
written) the management is  
unorganized, has no com-  
munication with workers, is  
all male, although half of all  
workers are female. Last year  
university employees that  
didn’t belong to unions tried  
to organize but were satisfied  
with a small wage increase  
and more input into policy  
decisions.  

Another activity of the  
coalition is the Women's  
Crisis Project that would get a  
Women's Center established  
near the campus so that not  
only students but also com-  
munity women could use the  
facility. Self-defense, self-  
help, legal resources, career  
counseling and intramurals  
are some of the activities that  
the center would sponsor. A  
hotline for rape referrals and  
information would also be  
established. Money is cur-  
rently being requested from  
the student government. “We  
need to show that we are here.  
We're paying out money and  
now we want some back,”  
says one member.  

In the past the structure and  
organization of the coalition  
has been very loose. This year  
women in the coalition want  
to see a definite strong  
organization so that women  
will have someone there when  
they need help or communi-  
cation with other women who  
share their oppressed posi-  
tion.  

A three member steering  
committee helps coordinate  
the activities of the coalition.  
The office is in the student  
union across from the grill in  
room 181.

Pat Schroeder, D-US Congress - U.S. Representative Pat Schroeder (D-Colo.) told a very warm and accepting audience at the August 29th general meeting that the real problem for women today is the economy, because “women are the first shut out, and women are going to have hard times ahead because the economy is going to have hard times ahead.” She said that we, as women, must become, “much more economically oriented,” which is going to become tougher as the economic scene unfolds.

Representative Schroeder cited current Department of Labor statistics showing a 35% higher rate of unemployment among women than men. Women earn 40% less than men yet, she said, women don’t receive a 40% discount on the goods and services they buy. What we must fight, she said, is the old myth that women work not because they need to, but to pass the time away.

The women we must work hardest for—and NOW tends also to forget them, she said—are the young women who bought the American dream of the housewife’s role with husband and family and are now divorced or separated heads of households without job skills or the economic access to the good life. Representative Schroeder reminded her audience that our country has created this woman. We have convinced young girls that they don’t need economic skills, because, “if you're married, you don’t need a skill.” Our male-oriented society has taught our young women that “your main job is to troll and catch me.”

“We've got to figure out some way not to put people down,” she said, “but to allow them to participate. Why put down women who are 53% of our brainpower?”

Coven Gets Revenge; Ames, Iowa-- When Iowa State University
lent its facilities to the Miss Iowa Beauty Pageant two years ago,
the Women’s Coalition sought the help of a local witch coven -
DARC, the Des Moines Ames Radical Coven. It hexed the
pageant and its supporters, and the television station, KDIN. Within
an hour KDIN suffered a power failure. Part of the hex involved
laying a curse on ground earmarked for a football stadium. A
substantial portion of the construction was complete when lo! it
began to tilt and sink slowly into the ground. Barbara X of DARC
expressed surprise that it had taken so long. She said the coven is
willing to remove the hex in return for a 7.4 million dollar child
care center to be built in its place. (Off Our Backs, Aug-Sep. 74)

Widening Gap Reported in Earnings-- According to the latest
consumer income survey of the US Bureau of the Census, the
income of a typical full-time woman worker employed year-round
in '73 was $6,490- or 57% of her male counterpart in the work
force. The gap between the sexes has thus widened and was three
percentage points bigger in '73 than it was in '71. (The
Spokeswoman, Aug. 15, 74)

Indictment of Ms. Magazine-- “On behalf of six million Lesbian
women and hundreds of thousands of women-identified
Feminists in the USA...the Lesbian Tide magazine charges Ms.
magazine with: Gross neglect and psychic genocide against
Lesbian women, sexist and heterosexist representation of
women, and perpetuating anti-feminist attitudes and politics...”
The Tide went on to point out that in two years of publishing, Ms.
“has published 5 out of 505 major articles (.99%) by Lesbians
about Lesbians’ lives and needs; has printed 9 out of 537 letters
(1.7%) by, about, or relating to Lesbian women; has employed
one active, public Lesbian on its editorial staff; has printed
innumerable ads which consistently portray women in exclusive
relationship to men, in fashion model imagery and in
professional, classist roles." Also noting that Ms. is owned by a
male corporation, the Tide went on to resolve “that until Ms.
re-evaluates and begins to adequately represent the politics and
lifestyles of Lesbian radical Feminists, we the Lesbian Nation
cancel our subscription and support of a magazine whose pages
have cancelled our reality.” (The Lesbian Tide, Aug, 74)

Big Mama Rag had originally announced a poetry contest. A statement prepared by Adrienne Rich, Audre Lorde, and Alice Walker, all nominated for the National Book Award for Poetry, has encouraged us to join in a new feminist tradition not following the usual competitive standards of a contest. Part of their statement reads: “We can enrich ourselves more in supporting and giving to each other than by competing against each other; and that poetry—if it is poetry—exists in a realm beyond comparison.”

In this spirit, we have decided to acknowledge all of the entries and to share the prize money among the women in this community rather than selecting one winner for the announced prize money of $10.00, and so the amount will be offered to the development of a Women’s Center.

Sovereign of the Streets

Tonight

Picnics

Leaf eyes and leaf mouth

Pressed - no crushed -

so that green leaf juice

Smeared upon our fingers and stains our bodies.  
It won't wash out, mother always said,

And she was right.

It never did. Not a bit of it.

Soak it all you want. Scrub it.

Mother was right.

It's really rather embarrassing to be seen like this.  
Change my clothes.

All clean.

Oops. What about the fingers.

(Everybody will know where you’ve been)

That won't come out either.

Maybe it will wear away in time....

then I am afraid I will never come out

Women &

Emma Goldman

Emma Goldman was a famed anarchist and feminist whose
revolutionary ideas and outspokeness made her a legend in her
own time. She was born in czarist Russia on June 27, 1869. When
she was seventeen she left Russia and joined her sister in
Rochester, New York, fleeing a tyrannical father and an arranged
marriage. She went to work in a garment factory, as she had in
Russia, and soon married another immigrant. But after being
radicalized by the hanging of the Haymarket martyrs, she divorced
her husband and left for New York City where she almost
immediately began her career as a lecturer and organizer, at first
working closely with Alexander Berkman and Johann Most, the
well-known anarchists. But very quickly Emma was known, in her
own right, as a passionate speaker and dynamic organizer. She
spoke to the issues of draft resistance, feminism, the need for
birth control, “free love,” and anarchism. She was often arrested
as a matter of course when she was to speak somewhere — and
she claimed she always carried a book with her so if she was
arrested she would have something to read in jail.

The Homestead massacre led her to co-conspire with
Berkman in plotting the assassination of industrialist Henry C.
Frick. Berkman spent fourteen years in prison for the shooting
though Frick was only wounded and recovered quickly. Emma was
never tried for that plot but later was imprisoned for complicity in
the plot to kill President McKinley, though she was innocent of
that charge.

Emma Goldman was a nurse and midwife and so witnessing
the tragedy of poor women having more babies than they wanted
or could care for, she spoke and wrote about the necessity of birth
control methods and safe abortions. She expressed her own regret
at not being able to perform abortions herself but she knew of no
safe method to use. Perhaps what Emma is most well known for is
her analogy between marriage and prostitution, and she
contemptuously criticized the hypocrisy of those who harassed
and imprisoned prostitutes. Though she was disappointed in the
women's emancipation movement at the time, she expressed her
views of the importance of liberation in her essay “The Tragedy of
Woman Emancipation.” She wrote: “Emancipation should make it
possible for woman to be human in the truest sense. Everything
within her that craves assertion and activity should reach its
fullest expression; all artificial barriers should be broken, and the
road towards greater freedom cleared of every trace of centuries of
submission and slavery.”

“Red Emma,” as she was known, did speak and write in
support of Women’s Liberation but her movement work was
primarily with male colleagues, and she believed very much in an
integrated revolutionary movement. Her autobiography, which is
intriguing reading, communicates her insight, spirit, and most
impressively her incredible self-confidence.

Emma was deported back to Russia in 1919, and her
deportation hearing was presided over by J. Edgar Hoover
himself. As the boat pulled out she thumbed her nose at a
congressman who had come to watch the exit of the deported
anarchists. Once in Russia, which had experienced a revolution,
she criticized the repression she saw there. She left Russia,
traveled around, and finally settled in France where she died. Her
body was shipped to the US and she was buried in the same
cemetery with the Haymarket martyrs.

(reprinted from Uppity Women! A Legacy of Liberation.)

Lesbian Writers
Come Out of

Their Closets

Chocolate Waters and Sandia

Lesbian writers have often
had to come out of a very
different type of closet. Many
of them, plagued with the
self-doubt that has followed
women throughout history,
have hid their poems, stories,
chapters of potential books
and essays in bureau drawers.
Others, knowing their chances
of being published were
poor because they were
women or because they feared
repercussions if their real
names were known, hid under
masculine pseudonyms. Mari
Kuda, an organizer of the
Lesbian Writers’ Conference
held in Chicago September
13-15, stated that one of the
main purposes of the confer-
ence was to encourage and
support these very women.

The conference began Fri-
day night with a talk by Valerie
Taylor, an author in her 60s
who has published seven
novels about women. Her
speech was punctuated with
humorous and informative
disclosures about Lesbians in
the world of letters. Ms.
Taylor, herself a Lesbian
grandmother, noted the proud
inheritance from our cultural
grandmothers and empha-
sized how we could learn from
their experiences.

She traced Lesbian writers
from the beginning of the
twentieth century, focusing
particularly on the 50s. It was
during the early part of this
period that the market was
flooded with badly written,
sensationalistic Lesbian nov-
els (most written by men)
which depicted “a beautiful
butch in black lace underwear
who never gets out of bed
long enough to send the
sheets to the laundry. In the
end she renounces women,
finding true love with a male
instead.”

Long Impressive List

At the same time, Lesbian
writers were trying to incor-
porate the theme of women
loving women in a more
dignified and realistic way.
The list is long and impressive
although not well known to
most readers: Gayle Wilhelm,
May Sarton, Violette Le Duc,
Jeanette Foster, Djuna
Barnes, and Colette - to
mention a very few. It is
impossible to explain their
contributions in depth here.
For this reason one of the
most important outgrowths of
the conference was the
bibliography Woman Loving
Woman, compiled by the
Chicago organizers. (Ed.
note: now available at the
BMR office).

The 60s, according to
Valerie Taylor, was a turning
point in the history of Lesbian
Literature because of the
Women’s Movement and the
Gay Liberation Movement.

Women were now beginning
to realize that Lesbianism was
not only a viable lifestyle, it
was also politically important
in the context of a male-dom-
inated world. Out of this
realization grew such books
as Lesbian Nation, Sappho
was a Right-On Woman, and
Lesbian Woman.

Her speech ended with a
challenge for writers of the
70s to continue with this
proud inheritance and to
develop not only Lesbian
themes, but to “write about
the whole world.”

Writing Explored

On Saturday, several work-
shops explored different as-
pects of writing including
criticism, poetry, articles,
fiction, and getting published.
One unique idea viewed
writing as a collective expres-
sion and the fiction workshop
experimented with this idea
and composed a collective
story. The need for a feminist
aesthetic or a way in which
women can express feminine
values in their writing was a
theme which ran throughout
many of the workshops.

The conference, which end-
ed with women reading their
original works and singing
their own songs, was for the
most part quite successful.
The agenda was well organ-
ized and carefully planned
although structure did at
times prevent a free flow of
discussion. There also
seemed to be some underly-
ing political differences con-
cerning the relationship of art
to Lesbian Feminism, and
these unexpressed feelings
subtly inhibited the confer-
ence in some respects. The
organizers tactfully prevented
any disruptions from occur-
ring, but for the sake of the
Chicago women, we do hope
these differences will even-
tually be worked out.

Nevertheless, the Lesbian
Writers’ Conference demon-
strated that women all over
the country are indeed writ-
ing, and writing in a way
which is positively reflective
of the Lesbian in life and
literature today. Write-On!

One thing about class, that is painful but is important, is
that each woman is but one man away from the bottom of the
heap. Women derive their economic and social status from their
closest male relative, i.e. father, husband, or brother, in a
patriarchal society.

Any privilege a woman receives comes from her male
guardian. He may be the benevolent father that sends her to
college to learn middle-class values/actions, or he may be the
dictatorial husband that beats and keeps her because he brings
home a paycheck.

The way we think, act, dress and talk are all products of our
class backgrounds. There are no originals. There are only origins:
We must accept the responsibilities of our pasts, to change our
futures. Look at your friends. If you are college educated and
middle-class, lo and behold, so are your charming and clever
friends. Narcissism reigns supreme. If you worked your way
through school, I bet your friends are honest, hard-working, no
bullshit types. Since each tends to think their way is the way, we
women tend to laugh, disregard and belittle other women of
different ethnic, social or class backgrounds.

The patriarchy, the white men in power, love this horizontal
hostility. If women, who are despised by men, despise, gossip
and effectively destroy each other too, then the patriarchy has NO
enemies. To think of acting in a way that makes another woman feel
inferior to yourself helps men control both women. As long as we
keep each other down, we avoid overthrowing the real enemy,
white ruling-class men. Classist ideas are men’s hateful
classifications of all people other than themselves. Men think if
they can classify people as inferior, the people themselves will
believe this propaganda and begin to hate the person just below
them in the male hierarchy of things. “Keep the hens pecking at
each other. And keep the chicks off my back,” are the basic sexist
and classist axioms of the male strategy to divide and conquer
women.

So when we women begin to examine how we oppress
working-class women, what we are really doing is beginning to
examine how deeply the patriarchy has brainwashed us into
hating other women.

Only through a deep and honest probing of our thoughts,
actions and beliefs, can we begin to create honest and loving
relationships with each other. This love that transcends our
patriarchal pasts is the basis for a woman's place, that place in
ourselves, that is truly ourselves; the woman space, the place
where our woman soul resides.

knowledge about what insurance really is.

RAG to make you more aware of why a good insurance program is
essential and ways insurance can be to your benefit if you live, die
or quit.

with needs of singles. However, I will also include information
dealing with children and husbands as statistics say that they will
be a part of our lives at one time or another.

protection, estate planning, maintaining independence, retire-
ment income for yourself, trusts, endowments, hospitalization
coverage and special circumstances caused by marriage, divorce
and children.

These articles will be of interest to you in that most of them
deal with possible situations that can occur and the outcome if
you have or have not taken precautions against unfortunate
occurrences.

Good qualified insurance agents can inform you of various
situations that commonly occur and ways in which you can
protect yourself and those around you.

The core of all that has been
theoretized about class comes
down to this: the standard in
America revolves around what
is male and young and white
and middle-upper-class. Any
deviation from that ingrained,
mediated standard is sus-
pect. Any judging on that
basis is classist. Any pun-
ishment (mental, physical,
sexual, spiritual) is caste. Any
counteraction to that norm—
any word, gesture, thought,
institutional change—is
freedom. The one most
powerful counter is to change
the very ways we PERCEIVE
that norm: MEDIA.

With no apologies to
McLuhan, I would like to carry
his theories one step further
than he took them. Media are
extensions of our bodies
according to him (i.e. the car
is an extension of our feet, the
telephone an extension of our
mouth and ears, the computer
our brain). More important,
media are not just extensions
of reality, they have become
reality itself.

Since the moon flights,
simulation (models of reality)
has become a familiar con-
cept. We watched a simula-
tion of the moon walks and
landings on TV—reality
twice removed. Football re-
plays are simulations of a sort
and many people prefer
watching the game on TV to
the in-person event. At a
Three Dog Night concert,
people seated way the hell out
from the stage watched the
performance on TV sets.
Once, at Yellowstone National
Park, I watched a man taking
pictures of Old Faithful. He
never looked at the geyser
through the lens of his own
eyes. When the spouting had
died away, he turned to his
family with his Polaroid shots
saying, “Here it is.” The
pictures were for him more an
actual reality than the natural
phenomenon itself. In a
cartoon I read many years
ago, two children are in a car
that has a flat tire. It is
raining, and they are ques-
tioning their father who is
frantically trying to change
the tire. His response, the
caption, reads: “But I can’t
change the channel. This is
reality.” Indeed, reality de-
pends on what channel we are
on.

Does all this seem a bit

“There is no women’s movement in Denver.” She spoke
bitterly, as one does who has paid her dues and is weary of
promises made but unkept, issues debated but never resolved.

“But what about N.O.W.?,” I said, “What about YWCA?
There’s Big Mama Rag and C.R. groups and the Rape Coalition
and....”

“Intellectualizing. Words and Ideas, consciousness-raising
is done by and for middle-class white feminists. What is there in
Denver for working women? For someone like me—a divorced,
working mother of four? What help—real, concrete help—is there?
None,” she said firmly. I pulled my trump card.

“What about,” I cried triumphantly, “Women in Transition
House?”

“Oh, that place. I bet about half of the women that stay
there have other places to go. They don’t really need to be there.”

“Well, listen. I've spent some time at that house. I’ve seen
that they do refer women to doctors or lawyers or whoever can
help them. And I’m moving in there because I believe that they are

helping women and that’s what I want to do.”

That is the general gist of a
conversation I had three
months ago with the mother
of a friend of mine. Since
then, I have moved into WIT
House and staffed it, some-
times with other women,
sometimes alone. I have seen
five staffers burn out and
leave, and seen about 150
transient women and children
come and go this summer. I've
learned a lot about women,
politics, myself, and the
welfare department—and I've
found that the situation for
Denver women, though far
from ideal, is still not quite as
bleak as my friend's mother
said it was.

There is limited help availa-

ble for working women, and

divorced mothers. Emergency
food can be obtained through
the Food Stamp Department,
Salvation Army, and a few
churches and community ac-
tion centers. With alimony or
custody hassles, they may be
able to get free or cheap legal
help. Legal Aid will not handle
the actual divorce. The NOW
office, Big Mama Rag, WIT
House and the YWCA re-
source center have lists of
women and men lawyers that
sometimes take cases with
little or no fee.

If these women need
counseling and moral sup-
port, WIT House, Gilpin

House, Creative Divorce and
many individual therapists
counsel women or refer them
to someone who can give
them competent, sympathetic
help.

Warren Village, an apart-
ment complex, provides day
care for its resident single-
parent families.

If she is gay, there are
lesbian counselors and
groups in Denver. A national
Lesbian Mothers Defense
Fund is forming.

If she is Chicana and on
welfare, there is a community-
based help organization for
her (See July issue of Big
Mama Rag.)

Denver General Hospital
and Children’s Hospital pro-
vide free health care for
low-income mothers and
children.

If she has been raped, and
needs legal advice, moral
support, etc., she can contact
any of the groups listed in the
August “Rape” issue of Big
Mama Rag.

So on the positive side
there are individuals and
organizations that give time
and energy to help women.
Most of them are understaffed
and underfunded, or require a
lot of form-filling and hassling
with red tape, but they are
there if needed.

However, if a divorced
working mother is being

discriminated against in her
job, needs a bank loan or is
having trouble getting credit—
then she'd better get used to
her situation because, as my
friend’s mother said, there is
nothing. She can go to the
Civil Rights Commission. She
can hire a lawyer if she can
afford one or go to Legal Aid
and hope they take her case.
She can go to the American
Civil Liberties Union; and if
they are going to get a lot of
publicity and are pretty sure
they'll win the case, they may
help her. The last I heard of
Esther Goodyear, she is still
trying to get money together
for a lawyer in her three-year-

against Gates Rubber Com-
pany.

This important area is
where Denver women’s
groups are weakest. There is
no powerful, united women’s
group to help with class
action suits. If I am wrong,
please call at WIT House and
tell me, because we get three
or four calls a day from
frustrated, angry women who
are being discriminated a-
gainst.

And if this hypothetical
mother of four is crazy, she
and everyone around her had
better get used to that, too.
There is counseling and
day-care therapy available for
women who are still function-
ing in the community. But the
halfway houses and hospitals
are either expensive or have a
long waiting list. When she
attempts suicide or seriously
hurts someone, then she may
be hospitalized. She may also
have a hard time getting out if

for mental patients of any sex
is hideously inadequate.

So much for the traditional
resources that Denver women
have. Enter Women In Transi-
tion House. Yes, good old
much-maligned, crisis-ridden,
understaffed and underfunded

have never heard of it, the
house offers temporary shel-

mean a change of lifestyle,

The staff women make refer-
rals for counseling, food help,
legal help, etc., and do some
non-professional counseling
on their own. The house is
defined as a “safe place” so
women make a contract when
they come in not to harm
themselves or anyone else.
When they break this con-
tract, they are asked to leave.

Women and Therapy

a psychological adventure

Franci Candlin, Carol Lease, and Sandia

If it has been several thousand years that men have controlled the public lives of women, it has been nearly a hundred that the attitudes of Freud and his followers have commandeered our psyches. It is against their prescribed conventions of mental health and treatment that Anne Wilson Schaef has been devoting her practice, and her energies have been in the direction of women defining and establishing their own psychological models.

The process of unlearning traditional psychological theories began about six years ago for her. Although the change in Schaef has been evolutionary, the main catalyst was a workshop on Community Development sponsored by The National Training Laboratories. She relates that people in the institute quickly split along racial and sexual lines. On the second day of the workshop, the Black members caucused, a decision that the group as a whole respected. However, on the fourth day when the women decided likewise to caucus, their actions were met with disbelief, paternalism, and extreme defensiveness on the part of the male staff. The significance of this event for Schaef was to arouse in her an awareness of the negative reactions of men toward women who dared to step out of the White Male System (WMS).

Problem of Rage

Soon after, she decided to focus on formulating theories and techniques relevant to women. Following several workshops with women, she began to witness their intense, terrifying rage which she admits was a frightening experience for her. She realized that she had to deal with her own rage before she could help women with theirs. She illustrated the inability of many therapists to cope with their clients’ rage. They encourage patients to explore their feelings, but when these feelings are expressed as rage, then frequently they resort to tranquilizers rather than confront the existing emotions.

Such attitudes only heighten the alienation women already feel. Schaef refers to a recurring fantasy of women which exemplifies this isolating aspect of rage. In this fantasy, the woman pictures herself standing all alone in smoldering ruins following the explosion of a hydrogen bomb. Schaef interprets this imagery as meaning that women feel that if they allowed themselves to express the full intensity of their anger, they would be capable of devastating the whole world, leaving her totally isolated.

Schaef encourages women to get in touch with their rage using the modality of a group as their support system. She feels this is crucial as the main fear of women is isolation from men and later on estrangement from other women if they were to give vent to this rage. Thus the importance of groups in therapy. The group can be of assistance in this painful process because women know that the group will not desert them, and they can use the collective experience of the group to validate their own feelings.

One method for working through the rage phase which Schaef has utilized is a “rage room.” This is a place where the only guidelines are that the individual cannot directly harm herself or any other person. In the instance of one school teacher, she expressed her rage by chopping up a desk. Although this technique bears some resemblance to Primal Therapy, unlike Primal which has become a “belief” system providing an “answer,” and which contrives rage, this approach stays out of the way of the client and deals with what naturally emerges.

Following this emotional catharsis, the cognitive phase of therapy must begin. Now

Schaef encourages women to explore what she terms as her “Original Sin” theory. This derives from a woman's perception that she is born innately inferior to men by reason of her sexual class.

She seeks to rid herself of this second-class status by attaching herself to a man. However, much to her dismay, she fails to find the superior man who can be the outside intermediary that will make everything okay, and so the void continues. At this crisis point, women too often reach the conclusion that something must be wrong with them individually. Somewhere they must have personally failed. Schaef uses the group to help women distinguish for themselves which problems result from being members of a certain class—and most women take their identity from men—and which problems arise from their own personality patterns.

An Emerging Feminist Theory

Schaef has devised the following theoretical construct as a way of explaining the difficulties women have coping with the White Male System (WMS).

note: see graph

Schaef states that most traditional therapy focuses on either the intrapsychic level (problems within the individual) or at best on the interpersonal level (problems arising between family and friends). However, unless the pervasive influence of the WMS is recognized and accounted for, many problems will be erroneously viewed as primarily personal or interpersonal in nature rather than as a spin-off of the WMS refusing to accept or respect the beliefs and values of other subsystems.

The WMS comes complete with its own mythology and rhetoric. In part that reads: “The WMS knows and understands everything.” In other words, it becomes a belief system, too, assuming there is only one “rite” way. Like a religion convinced of the Truth, the WMS sees no need to look at any of the subsystems’ ways of perceiving reality. In actuality, those in the subsystems (Chicanos, Blacks, women, etc.) know the most about the WMS as they have had to scrutinize it closely trying to decide why they are never fully accepted by it. More important, they have had to know it as a survival tactic.

The thrust of the Women’s Movement has been the awareness that there are other systems, and they are not innately inferior. Moreover, each system comes complete with its own politics, its own philosophy, and in a sense its own religion. That is why it is impossible for a therapist to be apolitical or aphilosophical. And this is why women need to understand how they as part of the female system might operate necessarily different than men. One example of differentiating the female and male systems is our attitude toward time. Male time is measured, controlled, regulated by numbers. Female time is process. Rather than thinking in terms of clocks or intervals, women think in terms of completing one task and when that is finished or when a gestalt is completed, they move on; if they need more time they get it. This attitude toward time becomes especially valuable when applied to time segments allotted for therapy appointments. If a client needs more than the usual hour, she gets it and all of Schaef's clients share that understanding.

Schaef's model provides an alternative framework for viewing mental health as a process of problem solving rather than as a cure for an illness. She further explains that the word neurosis is also male-oriented and based on a traditional medical model which sees psychological realities in terms of such stereotypes as sickness and health. From this perspective, the relationship between therapist and “patient” is intrinsically authoritarian and hierarchical. The therapist diagnoses the sickness and prescribes the cure. A feminist orientation sees a problem as an opportunity for growth. When growth as a natural process is interfered with, then certain symptoms become manifest. What women must recognize is that people have the dynamics of maturing within them and need not be manipulated from without.

In feminist therapy, then, the role of the therapist becomes “a model for coping, not a perfected individual.” Thus, she shares herself and her problems with other group members and encourages them to relate to each other outside the sphere of the group. This sense of peer-direction can sustain a continuing network of support across the country.

Usual Money Bind

Her work is without conflict. As a feminist who sees herself in a primary commitment to women, Anne Schaef is caught in the “service/occupation” dilemma shared by many professional women. That is, as a professional and a working woman she needs to charge for her services though she is aware that some of the women who need her help the most cannot often afford to pay for it. Yet, she is keenly aware that women in this society need to be paid and recognized for their efforts. What does a woman do who has been working since sixth grade and has children to support and there are clients with outstanding debts that range into the thousands? She struggles. While there are certain fees, Schaef negotiates. Some women are capable of paying $30/hour, some are not able to pay anything. Schaef has had to resolve this problem of remuneration on an individual basis, working out with her clients their needs and hers. Since some women see her privately, or in groups, and still others for occasional weekend workshops, she tries to arrange sessions that suit the clients’ financial status.

Future Outlook

Schaef has not only trained women nationally on her views of therapy, but is presently working on a book which would delineate a feminist model. Letters Home to Mama

Dear BMR:

Opportunities to praise press coverage of Colorado’s incredible prison non-system are so rare that I'm certainly not going to pass one up. Your September issue was excellent -- from the standpoint of philosophy as well as content.

There is something profoundly wrong with a “correctional” system that teaches subservience and demands self-degradation as the price of day-to-day existence. Volumes could -- and, I hope, will -- be written on the dichotomy between what penologists claim to be doing in prisons and what is actually being done. Preserving a healthy sense of who we are and what being a
woman means in this society calls for a legal perspective that is
feminist. As the case of Inez Garcia illustrates, there are
differences in the way men and women view the law—and the law,
because it can support or destroy us, is one concept that women
should understand.

Under the terms of the law as now written, Inez Garcia is guilty.
The law does not see rape as an offense which justifies
self-defense even to the extent of killing one’s oppressor. All laws
reflect our values and feelings; what society feels is important.
The society is male, those who write the laws are male; therefore
the laws themselves are male biased.

If women were writing the laws, they would know internally the
significance of rape and the response that action justifies. Rape
violates the essence of women. As such, it is the ultimate threat to
our identity and self-worth. Under the laws of a matriarchy, rape
would be a primary transgression. Implied and stated by law
would be a respect for women’s autonomy and their inherent right
to control their bodies, their property.

The issue of property has been raised before in the feminist
analysis of rape. Over and over again the system has viewed
women as property—men’s property. Any attempt by women to
defend their bodies is struck down by the courts even though the
crime of rape has been shown not to be an act of passion, but one
of violence and transgression. This attitude reveals how the
system persists in viewing women: they are for the use of men.
There is either a conscious or covert conspiracy on the part of men
to keep women from being human beings with equal dignity. The
law as it stands supports the male violators because the essence
of the law is dedicated to supporting the patriarchy. Perhaps this
explains why rape is the fastest growing crime of violence in the
country.

The traditional assumption that the courts can be an objective
and impartial forum is a fallacy. If the convictions of Inez Garcia
and other victimized women are allowed to stand, they will
reinforce the demeaning stature to which women have been
reduced—everyone's property but our own. The law will not be a
precedent for the enlightenment and education of the country—it will
become license for men to use women as they see fit.

The laws on rape must be rewritten by women.

Discrimination against women, however and whenever it
occurs, no matter how subtle it may be, must be recognized,
confronted, and eliminated. The present existence of law and
legislative reform will never eliminate sexist politics, policies, and
practices. We will have to do it ourselves.

Sex discrimination is elusive. It is often so interwoven into
the very fabric of life that its opposition seems ludicrous or a
“waste of time.” Its opposition won't be easy. It can only be made
easier by the support of others... by people who refuse to see
women as “inferior” and helpless and powerless.

The fact that women have to pay more often to use public
facilities than men is being challenged by the Women’s Coalition
to End Pay Toilets. This practice, the coalition says, is in violation
of the Public Accommodations Act that ensures all people equal
protection under the law. The coalition may take the practice into
the civil courts, and they deserve the support of all women.

All women suffer in some way from inadequate, sexist, racist
health care. And if a woman is poor, it is very likely that her health
problems will be greater and her opportunities to receive good
care will be less.

This country spends billions of dollars a year on health care but
has one of the highest maternal mortality rates in the world.
Pre-natal care is almost non-existent in most counties and cities
in this country.

Preventive medicine is largely ignored in the medical system of
this country. Symptoms are treated while the rest of the body and
the mind are ignored. Germs, microbes, and viruses cause disease
in the minds of the healers. The social context is largely ignored.
Most large hospitals have impressive research programs and
focus on profit-making before patient care.

The treatment and cure of cervical cancer has been known for 15
years, but women continue to die from it. A simple test can detect
this form of cancer, but the medical establishment has a hard time
recognizing its responsibility toward providing health care and
health education inexpensively for all women.

Women as nurses and other medical care workers compose
75% of all health workers in the country and are restricted to the
most menial and lowest paying jobs in the system. Only 7% of all
physicians in the US are women. Exclusive policies of medical
schools and sexist education in general keep women and
minorities a small proportion of all doctors in this country. There
are fewer doctors per person than 50 years ago due to
“professional birth control” practiced by the medical profession
since the days of the Depression.

Sisterhood Express

Sisterhood Express is the future feminist newspaper of
Tucson, Arizona. At this time we do not have the people energy or
the financial resources to become a full-fledged publication on
our own. By joining forces with Big Mama Rag and becoming an
insert in this paper, we hope to become a reality while we are
gathering the strength and skills to fly on our own. Here is our
statement of purpose as formulated in July, 1974.

STATEMENT OF PURPOSE

Sisterhood Express is a group of Tucson women coming
together from varied places with much experience and
many skills to share equality in providing a common
forum for the voice of the Tucson Woman.

The goals of the newspaper are:

1. To publish news of the women’s movement from local,
national, and international perspectives.

2. To provide an outlet for expression of creative skills of
local women in literary and graphic arts.

3. To identify and document incidents of sexism, ageism,
and racism in our community.

4. To provide commentary on news and issues from a
feminist viewpoint.

ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE

At this time, Sisterhood Express (SHE) has no formalized
organizational structure. Because we are firmly committed to
developing a non-hierarchical organization (we view hierarchical
organizations as one of the vehicles of oppression in our society),
we have been reluctant to structurally define ourselves at all.

This does not mean that we are not organized. Right now
SHE is a loosely structured collective. Task-oriented committees
are formed and terminate as specific tasks emerge and are
accomplished. As we grow and develop, the committees will
stabilize and become our structure. As we see it now, each
committee will have a coordinator. When we incorporate, the
Committee Coordinators will become our Board. Coordinators will
serve for a specified time only, so that everyone will have a share
in the “leadership” of SHE and share in the responsibility.

We welcome all input about the pros and cons of non-
hierarchical organizations. We are interested in
hearing about any of your experiences or efforts in this direction.

BMR, SHE RELATIONSHIP

According to our present thinking, BMR and SHE will be
structurally and editorially independent and autonomous. BMR
will act as a support system for the birth and development of SHE.
In return, BMR will benefit from the increased distribution and the
infusion of energy from SHE.

We at Sisterhood Express are very excited about the liaison
with BMR. It is especially interesting from a political viewpoint,
since it represents one feminist newspaper giving birth to another.
This would seem to present an innovative alternative to the
standard competitively oppressive process of creating such an
organization.

PROSPECTIVE SHE CONTENT

The Sisterhood Express insert will cover a broad range of
material of interest to the women of Tucson and the southwest.
We want to keep our format very flexible so that we can
experiment with different ways of utilizing the space. We may
want to present a combination of news, features, and poetry one
month. Another month we may wish to utilize the space all for one
thing, such as an investigative report or graphics and
photographs.

Our main criteria is that material be of interest and value to
women in particular. News and features about Tucson women
and services for Tucson women will be given priority. We are
interested in educating, entertaining, developing consciousness,
and providing alternative self-images for women.

With these goals in mind, here is a list of some of the
material being gathered for publication in Sisterhood Express:
features on feminist activities and organizations in Tucson such
as the Lesbian Alcoholics Anonymous Group, The Rape Crisis
Center, Alternatives For Women; an article on mother-lesbian
daughter relationships; a mental health column called “How’s
Your Head?”, discussing such topics as “What is Mental Health”,
“The Effects of Oppression on the Mental Health of Women”,
“Feminist Counseling”, and “How To Choose A Therapist”; news
and features of women in sports; coverage of special events, such
as the WITCHES (Women in Tucson Celebrating Halloween)
Retreat.

MEMBERSHIP IN SISTERHOOD EXPRESS

SHE welcomes all material submitted by Tucson women.
Send your material to: Sisterhood Express, P.O. Box 27727,
Tucson, AZ 85726. We would also like to hear opinions from all
BMR readers on this idea and the items we eventually publish.

Tucson women who are interested in being a part of the
SHE organization are welcome at our weekly meetings. These are
held on Saturday afternoons, at 2:00 p.m. at the Tucson Women’s
Center, 912 East Sixth Street, Tucson, AZ. After attending three
(3) meetings, a woman can become a voting member.
