Chocolate Waters

Police Attack Women, Then Try to Charge the Women With  
Battery-- Two employees of the Woman's Building in LA were beaten  
up by three peace officers in an “unprovoked attack” early in Aug.  
The officers then tried to charge the women with battery at a  
hearing attended by 100 supporters on Sept. 12. Cheryl Swanneck,  
one of the feminists involved, gives this account: “I had been  
welding. A police car began to cruise alongside of us when we  
were locking up. We said we worked in the building and went in to  
get our things... We thought the police had left but they suddenly  
banged on the door and threatened to “break it down”... When  
they tried to take Marge Elliot out to the parking lot, I told her she  
didn’t have to go. An officer grabbed Margie and threw her face  
down and then began to strangle her. Another hit her on the back.  
I began to scream; they dropped Margie, lifted me off the steps,  
crashed me down on the steps, broke my glasses and began to  
strangle me. I passed out and fell down the steps. They tortured  
me with, “Are you going to cooperate now, little girl?” I was crying  
hysterically. * The police report of the incident said that two  
possible burglary suspects who “looked like men” were reported  
“looking suspicious.” The report further stated that one woman  
(Swanneck) was asked to step outside; she refused and struck the  
officer. A wristlock was then used on the woman. It was further  
reported in the police account that as a result of the struggle one  
officer sustained an injury to his right middle finger.” * The  
hearing determined that no charges should be brought against the  
women, but Swanneck and Elliot are filing their own civil suit  
against the three policemen involved. (Sister, Sept. and Oct. '74)

Jumping Rope May Be Hazardous to Your Health!-- Physicians  
say that the nerves of the limbs or of the spine may be paralyzed  
by jumping or skipping rope. The delicate nerves of the foot are  
also liable to suffer permanent injury from the jar of jumping, and  
the amusement puts a strain on other nerves of the body which  
may cause paralysis. (The Ruined Maid by Geoffrey Eley,  
England, ’70)

The Times Has A Limited Vocabulary-- Women in Washington  
recently protested the advertising policies of the Seattle Times  
after the newspaper singled out and removed the phrase “Lesbian  
literature” from a list of material advertised by the “Madwoman”  
feminist bookstore. The Times then charged the bookstore $2.50  
extra for the editing. About 50 women and children marched  
through the downtown area singing songs and carrying signs  
such as “Lesbians Are Everywhere-- But In The Times,” “The  
Times Has a Limited Vocabulary,” and “The Times Is Behind The  
Times.” (LNS and Pandora)

It Only Took Two Centuries-- After 210 years of publishing, the  
Hartford Courant in Conn. finally named a woman (Laura Johnson)  
as director. (Media Report to Women, Oct. 1, '74)

Creep of the Month Award-- goes to Red Fenwick for his recent  
column in the Denver Post called “Protestors Boil at Pay Toilet.”  
Proving his minimal understanding of the Women's Movement,  
Ridin’-the-Range-Red disparaged the WM by reducing the issues  
to matters of lighting cigarettes and integrating public toilets (a  
ridiculous notion promulgated by the male media for their own  
ends). Further demonstrating his total ignorance on the subject,  
Fen then went on to claim the movement had “reached a climax 2  
years ago.” A “believer in male equality” himself, Mr. Wick’s  
supposedly satirical column was replete with insults to women  
and was extremely offensive to anyone with intelligent  
sensibilities. Personally, I think the issue of pay toilets is a low  
level priority in relationship to the goals of the Women’s  
Movement, but to the male media the toilet issue was just their  
cup of tea. I’m not surprised--that’s usually where heads are at  
anyway. (Denver Post, Oct. 13, '74)

All Male Senate Hurts Women-- With not one woman in the U.S.  
Senate, the men voted 50 to 34 to deny Health, Education and  
Welfare funds to be used by women for abortions. With Bella  
Abzug battling in the House, however, a similar amendment was  
defeated. Voting to deny abortion funding were such “friends” as  
McGovern, Eagleton, McIntyre, Montoya, Pastore, Byrd, Church,  
Hartke, Huddleston, Mansfield, McGee, and Muskie. Other  
senatorial “friends” not voting were Tunney, Ribicoff, Bayh,  
Bentson, and Nelson. The bill will now go to conference to resolve  
the difference between the House and Senate votes. (The Woman  
Activist, Sept. 15, '74) Quotation marks around the word “friends”  
are mine. WA, oddly enough, did not see any contradictions in the  
use of the word to describe these senators.

NOW REFORMS MEDIA BROADCAST CODE

The National Association of Broadcasters (NAB) has agreed to revisions to its Radio Code as proposed by NOW, following a presentation on the image of women in the media by NOW Vice President/Public Relations Toni Carabillo. At an earlier meeting of the NAB Television Code Review Board, the broadcasters agreed to the “thrust and spirit” of NOW’s changes for the television code, also presented by Toni Carabillo.

The revisions, prepared by Joan Nicholson (National Coordinator, Image of Women Task Force) and Whitney Adams (National Coordinator, FCC Task Force) were aimed at stricter guidelines for broadcasters in portraying women in programming and advertising. Joyce Snyder of New York NOW was highly instrumental in arranging NOW’s participation in the NAB Code conferences.

NAB officials have now strengthened their organization’s commitment to the improvement of the image of women in the media, with “reaffirmation, wider and intensified publicizing, and more insightful implementation . . . towards accomplishing the goals affecting the dignity, among others, of women . . . ” NOW will contribute a guest column in the NAB’s monthly CODE NEWS, to be followed by national and local NOW action currently being planned by Whitney Adams and the FCC Task Force and Joan Nicholson and the Image Task Force. Please send your suggestions to the NOW Public Information Office, 641 Lexington Avenue, New York, N. Y. 10022. In addition, the NAB is distributing copies of Toni Carabillo’s presentations to all stations which subscribe to the radio and television codes.

L. |. NOW GAINS NEW MEMBER IN A VICTORY OVER “STAGS”

Nassau (Long Island, N. Y.) NOW came to the aid of a Long Island woman — with gain of a new  
member and victory over a ‘‘stag’’ dinner as its reward.

Petra Capon received an invitation to the $100-a-plate Pinter Tournament of Stars banquet, a  
charity event for the American Cancer Society emceed by Bob Hope. When she called to make  
reservations for 10 — a contribution of $1,000 — she was told the dinner was stag.

Ms. Capon contacted Nassau NOW. The case was taken to the New York State Human Rights  
Commission which ordered that women be allowed at the dinner.

Betty Schlein of Nassau NOW was among Ms. Capon’s guests. In all, about 100 women attended  
the banquet.

The many press reports quoted Ms. Capon’s intention to join NOW, “I never involved myself in  
any women’s liberation activities until it hit home,” she said. “I’m not against men, I'm for  
women.”

NOW AIDS N. J. WIN OVER LITTLE LEAGUE

A New Jersey court has ruled that the Little League in New Jersey must admit girls. The ruling  
was made November 7th following a long suit in which Judith Weis and Essex County NOW  
helped to refute testimony by Little League witnesses who claimed girls were not physically  
able to play baseball with boys.

Some reports say the Little League may take the case to the U. S. Supreme Court.

NATIONAL ACTION WILL HIT “CULT OF YOUTH”

December 19th is the date for actions by many NOW chapters throughout the country — all  
designed to combat the cult of youth as it applies to women.

According to Karen DeCrow, national coordinator for the action, “The tragedy of the cult of  
youth is not that men prefer young women, it is that we women begin to hate ourselves as  
we grow old.”

On December 19, 1853, Gerrit Smith, wealthy landowner, whose daughter Elizabeth first wore  
the bloomer dress, wrote to Elizabeth Cady Stanton: “So long as woman remains in her  
clothes-prison, she will be dependent and poor.” This year, NOW chapters will celebrate the  
100th anniversary of that letter.

Suggestions and background for this action have been sent to all NOW chapter presidents.  
For further information, contact Karen DeCrow, 116 Benedict Avenue, Syracuse, New York  
13210, (315) 474-1682.

CALIFORNIA NOW TASK FORCE TO COMBAT AGEISM

Is it “raging hormones” that make some menopausal women act out, or is it just plain rage?  
The need for feminist research in this area was stressed at the Workshop on Older Women at  
the California NOW State Conference, October 26-28. Job discrimination (both sexist and  
ageist), social security inequities and pension woes were also tackled. A task force was set up  
to “raise the consciousness of NOW members to ageism and the older women, as well as to  
implement programs to alleviate our problems.”

ABORTION  

ANTI-ABORTION AMENDMENT PASSES U. S. SENATE  

On October 2, 1973, Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC) introduced an amendment (No. 566) to the  
Foreign Assistance Act of 1973 which prohibits the use of funds for abortion services, research  
on abortion, and for abortifacient drugs and devices (which include menstrual extraction and  
IUDs the way anti-abortion groups define it). This amendment passed the Senate unanimously.  
(NOTE: There are no women Senators).  

ANTI-ABORTION AMENDMENT IN CONFERENCE  

This amendment is currently under consideration by the Joint Conference Committee on the  
Foreign Assistance Act. Members of NOW in the relevant states have already been contacted  
and urged to write, call, and/or telegram their Senators and Representatives if they are members  
of the Conference Committee.  

So far, we are holding our own and the mail is running 50:50. However, to make sure the Conferees  
are not persuaded at the last minute to support any anti-abortion language in either the bill or the  
Conference Report Statement, which accompanies the bill to explain it, and is often used as an  
alternative method of expressing “the Will of Congress,” NOW MEMBERS IN THE CONFEREES’  
HOME STATES SHOULD WRITE AGAIN EXPRESSING THEIR OPPOSITION TO ANY MOVE  
BY THE CONFERENCE TO DENY ACCESS TO ABORTION TO OUR SISTERS OUTSIDE  
THE UNITED STATES. NOW members living in these states should write to the designated  
person immediately: Senators Humphrey (Minn), Aiken (Vt), Fulbright (Ark), Church (Id), and  
Case (NJ); Representatives Tom Morgan (Pa), Zablocki (Wisc), Hays (Oh), Fascell (Fla), Mailliard  
(Ca), Frelinghuysen (NJ), and Broomfield (Mich).  

Furthermore, we cannot be sure that the Foreign Assistance Act of 1973 will contain no anti-  
abortion language until both the Senate and the House of Representatives have voted on and  
approved a Conference Report with no provisions against abortion services, research, and abortifacient  
drugs or devices in it.  

THEREFORE, ALL MEMBERS OF NOW ARE ASKED TO WRITE LETTERS, SEND PETITIONS,  
MAKE PHONE CALLS, AND OTHERWISE LET YOUR SENATORS AND HOUSE MEMBERS  
KNOW THAT WE WHOLEHEARTEDLY OPPOSE THIS ATTEMPT BY ANTI-ABORTION FORCES  
TO DENY OTHER COUNTRIES THE RIGHT TO PROVIDE GOOD HEALTH CARE, INCLUDING  
EARLY ABORTIONS, TO THE WOMEN NOW LIVING AND POTENTIALLY DYING IN THOSE

MANDATORY PREGNANCY LEAVES

Recently there has been a great deal of litigation by women challenging the various mandatory
pregnancy leave statutes, regulations and policies. Many courts have declared mandatory pregnancy
leaves to be unconstitutional. A definitive ruling is expected soon from the United States Supreme
Court in the case of La Fleur v. Cleveland Board of Education, (465 F. 2d 1184). NOW has filed
an amicus curiae brief in La Fleur.
The successful cases to date are as follows:

1. unmarried pregnant hospital employee —

a. Doe v. Osteopathic Hospital of Wichita Inc., 333 F. Supp. 1357 (1972, Kansas);
2. pregnant teachers —

a. Bravo v. Board of Education, 345 F. Supp. 155 (1972, Illinois);

b. Cerra v. East Stroudsburg Area School District, 299 A. 2d 277 (1973, Pennsylvania);

c. Green v. Waterford Board of Education, 345 F. Supp. 501 (1973, Connecticut);

d. Heath v. Westerville Board of Education, 345 F. Supp. 501 (1972, Ohio);

e. La Fleur v. Cleveland Board of Education, 465 F. 2d 1184 (1972, Ohio), pending
U.S. S. Court);

f. Pocklington v. Duval County School Board, 345 F. Supp. 163 (1972, Florida);

3. social worker —

a. Williams v. San Francisco Unified School District, 340 F. Supp. 438 (1972, California);
4. member of the armed services —

a. Robinson v. Rand, 340 F. Supp. 37 (1972, Colorado).

In all of the cases it was found that mandatory pregnancy leave statutes, regulations and policies
discriminate on the basis of sex. Selecting a certain indiscriminate period of time that a medical
leave must be taken for pregnancy is arbitrary and discriminatory because only pregnancy and
not other prolonged medical ailments were subject to these restrictions. Since pregnancy is a
physical condition exclusive to women, such restrictions discriminate on the basis of sex. The
courts held that medical leaves for pregnancy, like those for all other physical conditions, should
be determined individually based on a doctor’s evaluation. The selection of arbitrary dates has
no rational relationship to the performance of duties.

The arguments that have been successful in overturning these statutes, regulations and policies are:
that they are based on stereotypes that have no more place in our society than racial or religious
stereotypes; advance notice of when the woman plans to leave is as good as an arbitrary date to
allow provisions to be made for the person’s absence, and any emergency can be handled in the
same manner as emergency leaves not for pregnancy; There is as great if not greater continuity
when the leaves are not done by arbitrary dates; some of these provisions were based on outdated
concepts (children giggling at the sight of a pregnant teacher); administrative convenience or the
saving of money is not a defense when a constitutional right is in question. However, in the
Robinson case, the woman in the armed services, the court stated that a woman who was pregnant
and in the armed services could not be forced to resign, but could probably be transferred out of
a combat zone.

Most of these cases were based on the violation of the equal protection clause (some were based
also on the due process clause) of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. (The
Pennsylvania case (Cerra) used a state human rights statute and the armed services case (Robinson)
used the equal protection clause of the Fifth Amendment because it was a federal and not state
body being charged.)

When a person finds herself being affected by a mandatory pregnancy leave statute, regulation or
policy, she should take the following steps:
xy oe Continued on Page 7

1. Request that the mandatory leave not be enforced and provide evidence such as a letter  
from her doctor that she is physically capable of performing her duties until a given time.  
If there is a union, she should ask the union to assist her in challenging the pregnancy  
policy.

2. If the superiors do not answer right away or give a negative reply, she should file a  
complaint (or ask NOW or her union to file on her behalf) with the Equal Employment  
Opportunity Commission (E.E.O.C.) in her area and/or the State Fair Employment  
Agency, if one exists.

3. If the E.E.O.C. cannot settle the situation within 6 months, the woman, upon request,  
will be given leave to file suit in the Federal District Court. If her employer is a govern-  
ment body, she can file directly in Federal District Court without going through the  
E.E.O.C. or the state agency, challenging the policy on constitutional grounds.

4. The suit should be for reinstatement, back wages, any increase in salary which would  
have been forthcoming had the woman not been forced to take the pregnancy leave,  
any other damages incurred from the mandatory leave, court costs and lawyer’s fees  
and an injunction of any further enforcement of such mandatory pregnancy leaves.

SOME USEFUL ARGUMENTS AGAINST THE AMENDMENT

1. The Helms amendment completely ignores the U. N. Statement of Human Rights which
declares that it is a fundamental human right to be able to control the size and spacing of
one’s family; it further ignores the statement in American Jurisprudence which declares: if
the right to privacy means anything, it must include the fundamental right to decide whether
to bear or beget a child.

2. The Helms amendment seeks to impose a view on foreign countries which is neither held by a
majority in this country nor held constitutional by our nation’s highest judicial body, the U. S.
Supreme Court.

3. The Helms amendment further violates the sovereignty of other countries by ignoring the
fact that abortion is legal and included among the regular health services in many of those
countries which receive U. S. aid.

4. The Helms amendment ignores the basic health care needs of the women living in the less-
developed countries who rely quite heavily on abortion as a means of fertility control
because contraception and family planning services are not available.

See your chapter's Reproduction Task Force Coordinator for additional arguments. She should
have received them in a communication from the national coordinator by now.

CONGRATULATIONS!! AFL-CIO & NOW MEMBERS

On October 22, 1973 the AFL-CIO passed the following resolution:

RESOLVED: that the tenth biennial convention of the AFL-CIO endorses the Equal Rights 
Amendment to the U. S. Constitution as precisely the kind of clear statement
of national commitment to the principle of the equality of the sexes under the
law that working women and their unions can use to advantage in their efforts
to eliminate employment discrimination against women, and

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED: that state labor federations, in states which have not yet
ratified the ERA, urge their legislatures to act favorably .....

In a letter to George Meany, President of the AFL-CIO, NOW President Wilma Scott Heide and
Legislative Vice President Ann Scott wrote: “This is indeed a momentous day. (The) AFL-CIO’s
significant role in the democratization of the basic legal document of this land will be of historic
import; “As we have in other areas in the past, NOW looks forward to one more endeavor where
AFL-CIO will work with us in common cause for the completed ratification of the ERA. NOW’s
Legislative Office and the State Legislative ERA Coordinators will welcome cooperative arrangements
providing information to facilitate effecting speedy ERA ratification in at least a necessary eight of
the states where ratification has not yet been accomplished.”

The campaign for AFL-CIO endorsement was led by the women in the union movement and many of
the unions which had already endorsed. The AFL-CIO Constitution was also amended to read “To
encourage all workers without regard to race, creed, color, sex, national origin or ancestry to share
equally in the full benefits of union organization.”

Congratulations NOW members who lobbied so effectively for this tremendous endorsement. The
combination of the inside/outside alliance of women and men for ERA culminated in terrific victory!

ERA RATIFICATION COUNCIL RESOURCE CENTER

The ERA Ratification Council is composed of national organizations working for ERA. The Council
voted to establish a resource center to gather all materials on the ERA in one place, or at least a
reference card on each item. Common Cause offered to “house” the Center and provide some volun-
teers to help set it up. NOW Legislative Office has provided assistance in designing a cataloging system
which is complete with a cross reference. The cross reference will be able to indicate such things as:
Is there a study of sex discrimination in criminal law in Iowa? What kind of hearings were held in
New Mexico? N. H.? etc. NOW Legislative Office Intern, Connie Abrashoff (Trinity College) has
screened all our files and typed entry cards for the Center. An extra set of cards of our files will be
kept in our office. Upon request, the Center will answer inquiries and inform you of materials listed
in the Center and where you might obtain the material. The Center will not send materials or copies.
All member organizations of the Council will be able to make inquiries and to go to the Center to use
materials on file. This is a really big effort and every NOW member is needed to make it successful.
Please send us bibliographies of your personal collection — and, if possible, copies of your materials.
Connie will type entry cards and place them in the Center index. The Center plans to publish a
catalog of all entries. A notice will be placed in the Washington Blue Sheet when the catalog is com-
pleted and the Center is ready for use.

The 200th anniversary of the Boston Tea Party was celebrated in new ways by a number of NOW
chapters, all calling for ratification of the ERA. “No Taxation without Equality” was the 20th

reports great success with the chapter’s legislative questionnaire sent to candidates for local
office, with results having received wide coverage in the area press — the chapter is planning

a new questionnaire on abortion..... NOW National Compliance Task Force Coordinator
Lynne Darcy signed the complaint against the New Jersey State Division on Civil Rights for

a group of the Division’s women employees. The EEOC has found “reasonable cause” for the
women’s complaint of job discrimination ..... Tulsa NOW picketed the U.S. Jaycees’ national
training seminar to protest the awarding of federal funds to the organization which excludes
women from membership..... Columbus NOW reports many activities in addition to working
for ratification of the ERA, including an active Rape Task Force and recent actions protesting
discrimination due to sexual orientation ..... National Board member Karen DeCrow inter-
viewed psychiatrist Thomas S. Szasz in two programs televised in Syracuse, with Dr. Szasz
giving his first TV statement on the women’s movement. Copies of the tapes are available for
rent or sale from Karen DeCrow, 116 Benedict Avenue, Syracuse, N.Y. 13210..... Sexuality
and Lesbianism Task Force Coordinator Sidney Abbott announces new research on lesbian
mothers being conducted by Barbara Bryant, School of Social Work, California State University,

Payits Liyohi..... Oklahoma City NOW presented a Barefoot and Pregnant Award to a local
McDonald's with the result of improved hiring of women..... NOW Education Task Force
Coordinator Anne Grant has received an award from Mademoiselle magazine for her production
of “Our North American Foremothers”..... NOW member Adah Maurer, Berkeley NOW
notes that no women have applied for a position of Superintendent of Schools in Berkeley —
similar reports have been received from other areas — isn’t the news reaching NOW members?

to the station’s congratulations of the Elks for ending discrimination against minorities.

NOW POWER COMES TO THE STEEL INDUSTRY

In cooperation with National Compliance Task Force Coordinator Lynne Darcy and other NOW  
officers, Chicago NOW and Southwestern Pennsylvania NOW Chapters have initiated actions  
seeking to improve the status of women in the steel industry.

The actions followed closely press reports that the steel companies’ plans to correct job discrimina-  
tion within the industry did not include women. In discussions with the Justice Department,  
NOW Legal Vice President Judith Lonnquist was assured that the problems of women are and will  
be included in all negotiations with the steel industry.

“Since women are presently less than 5% of the workers in the steel industry, we are particularly  
concerned that the hiring goals for women at all job levels be set sufficiently high to redress this  
gross imbalance,” Ms. Lonnquist said. “We shall continue to watchdog the settlement and will not  
tolerate anything but the best possible pact. If the agreement is inadequate, we shall take what-  
ever steps we can to see that the rights of women are protected.”

Chicago NOW sponsored a public meeting in Gary, Indiana with women of United Steelworkers  
Local 1066 — “an important first step toward joint action of NOW and union women” (Chicago  
NOW newsletter, ACT NOW). The meeting, attended by many Chicago NOW members, National  
Board members Mary Jean Collins-Robson and Kathy Rand, as well as representatives of the EEOC,  
the Department of Defense, Gary Human Relations Commission, the Indiana Civil Rights Com-  
mission and the Wage and Hour Division, was highly successful. Over thirty union women of those  
in attendance responded to NOW’s call for a committee to take action on the job discrimination  
complaints aired at the meeting and to plan further actions.

Southwestern Pennsylvania NOW Chapters, in separate but related actions, have filed a complaint  
against U.S. Steel, following attempts at negotiation by the NOW Chapters.

In negotiation sessions, the Pennsylvania chapters report, officials of U.S. Steel stated that manage-  
ment policy is to award fringe benefits differentially on the basis of sex. When the NOW repre-  
sentatives pointed out that this is prohibited by Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, one company  
officer said, “The law is absurd.”

“This is the third major challenge to established discrimination against women in Pittsburgh  
that NOW has initiated. The Pittsburgh Press and the University of Pittsburgh ultimately  
learned that the laws against sex discrimination apply to them,” commented Jo Ann Evans  
Gardner, NOW Eastern Regional Co-Director, implying that the steel companies will also learn.

The Pennsylvania NOW members also met with officers of Jones and Laughlin Steel Corp. with  
more positive results.

Both Chicago NOW and the Southwestern Pennsylvania NOW Chapters received excellent press  
coverage resulting from the steel industry actions, with articles appearing in local press as well as  
Associated Press articles with national circulation.

ABORTION  
OPPOSITION ACTIVITIES  

The December 14, 1973 issue of “The Greene Sheet,” the National Right To Life Committee, Inc.  
newsletter, claims that three more Senators have announced their support for a “mandatory human  
life amendment.”  

The three Senators are: William Proxmire (D-Wis), Walter D. Huddleston (D-Ky), and  
Roman Hruska (R-Neb).  

TURNING THEM AROUND  

None of the three have publicized their support for a “mandatory human life amendment,” but we  
do believe “The Greene Sheet’s” claim that these Senators have promised some sort of support  

in response to constituent lobbying is a fact. However, none of the three are a lost cause for us  
and, in fact, prospects for turning them around are good if we put all of our efforts into it.  

Senator Huddleston has been supportive towards women’s rights in the past as a member of the  
Kentucky State Senate. Our feeling is that he is succumbing to the very intense pressure that  

the compulsory pregnancy people have put on him, such as the December 10th home office visit  

of a delegation of citizens and local officials. Senator Proxmire is known as a “liberal” in Congress.  
If we can flood their offices with mail, telegrams, and phone calls, we may be able to persuade  
them to support the Supreme Court decision. Likewise with Senator Hruska.  

ACTION  

IT IS URGENT THAT EVERY NOW MEMBER WRITE TO ALL THREE SENATORS IMMEDIATELY  
(GET A FRIEND TO WRITE TOO)! Don’t depend on a chapter letter to relieve you of the personal  
responsibility for writing, and don’t fail to write because you're not a constituent. We have the  

capacity to deliver over 50,000 strong if we each act. Sit down and write or telegraph today! AND  
SEND CARBONS OR OTHER COPIES TO YOUR OWN SENATORS AND REPRESENTATIVES  
WHILE YOU'RE AT IT. See September Blue Sheet for suggestions on arguments to use.  

LONG-RANGE ACTION  

The National Reproduction Task Force Coordinator, Jan Liebman, and the Legislative Office are  
developing an abortion kit which will be mailed to your chapter’s Legislative Task Force Coordinator  
and Reproduction Task Force Coordinator in a series of updated installments.  

1. Make sure (a) your chapter has coordinators for these two task forces and (b) that their names  
are on the national task force mailing list (if not, have chapter president send postcard to National  
and to Legislative Offices).  

2. Make sure that your coordinators keep you informed with the most timely info possible. The  
best way is to join your local Legislative and/or Reproduction Task Force and work with your  
coordinators on a local level. Help set up an abortion telephone tree to alert members as fast as  
possible.  

3. Visit your Members of Congress whenever possible and be persistent. We cannot be shy and we  
cannot allow ourselves to be put off with evasive answers. The opposition doesn’t.

NONDISCRIMINATION IN LENDING — TWO VICTORIES  
Two victories for women, one legislative, one regulatory, occurred recently in the area of lending.  

SMALL BUSINESS ACT  

On January 2, 1974, President Nixon signed into law a bill to amend the Small Business Act which included the following amendment introduced by Congresswoman Lindy Boggs (D-La):  

“In carrying out the programs administered by the Small Business Adminis-  
tration, including its lending and guaranteeing functions, the Administrator  
shall not discriminate on the basis of sex or marital status against any person  
or small business concern applying for or receiving assistance from the  
Small Business Administration, and the Small Business Administration shall  
give special consideration to veterans of the Armed Forces of the United  
States and their survivors or dependents.”  

Okay, budding businesswomen, let’s use this opportunity to get started.  

FEDERAL HOME LOAN BANK BOARD  

On December 7, 1973, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board issued the following statement of  
the Board's policy regarding nondiscrimination in lending by Federal Home Loan Bank System  
member institutions:  

“The Civil Rights Act of 1968 does not specifically prohibit discrimination  
in lending on the basis of age, sex or marital status, and the Board’s regu-  
lations are at present limited to the scope of that Act. However, such  
discrimination is contrary to the principle of, and may in fact violate,  
Constitutional provisions which guarantee equal protection of the law  
for all persons. In addition, such practices impede the achievement of  
the objectives of Federal laws intended to promote sound, economical  
home financing, fair housing opportunity and a decent home for every  
American.”  

This statement will affect Savings and Loans, the largest lenders of mortgages in the United  
States. It is only a partial victory because, being a statement of policy, it does not have  
real “teeth” when it comes to enforcement. Federal legislation prohibiting discrimination  
in granting of credit on the basis of sex or marital status is still needed.  

NOW members who do experience discrimination in obtaining a mortgage from a Savings  
and Loan should write to the Federal Home Loan Board in their region, with a copy to  
the discriminating institution and another to the national Credit Task Force coordinator,  
Sharyn Campbell, c/o the Legislative Office.

ANTI—ERA ATTACK ON FCC PROJECT

The NOW broadcast media project to upgrade news coverage of feminist events and to improve  
the image of women in programming is being subjected to a vicious attack from the far right  
as a means to obtain radio and TV airtime to espouse anti-ERA views.

DETROIT AGREEMENT TARGETED

In August of 1973, Detroit NOW reached an open agreement with its local ABC-TV station,  
WXYZ, which provided for an affirmative action plan for women and for a small amount of  
feminist programming. This agreement was submitted by the station to the Federal Communi-  
cations Commission, as a part of the station’s official public file, and was approved by the FCC.  
On September 26, 1973, the so-called ‘Center for the Public Interest’ filed a complaint against  
the station, alleging that the agreement it had reached with NOW was secret and unlawful.  
NOW and WXYZ both filed a reply defending the agreement.

DIRECT MAIL CAMPAIGN

Subsequently, a direct mail campaign was launched by CPI to raise money to fund litigation  
against NOW’s broadcast media project. The letter, signed by Congressman Trent Lott (R-Miss)  
and sent out on Congressional stationery, accuses NOW of blackmail and other crimes. It is  
being used by anti-ERA groups in both ratified and unratified states to attack NOW and,  

more importantly, to gain access to radio and TV airtime to promote their views against the  
ERA.

THE CENTER FOR PUBLIC INTEREST AND THE ERA

CPI is another typical far right wing front organization, whose Board is composed of known  
anti-ERA organization members. American Conservative Union, Human Events, Young  
Americans for Freedom, and of course Phyllis Schlafly are among those endorsing CPI’s  
anti-NOW program. Copies of its letter attacking NOW have turned up in Virginia, South  
Carolina, Montana and Florida so far. In Montana a state representative received a letter  

from a constituent alluding to NOW’s “secret activities.” He brought this to a NOW member’s  
attention who had the Legislative Office send him documentation refuting the charges. In  
Florida, Shirley Schellenberger of STOP ERA went on the air to tell about NOW’s “secret  
agreements” in Detroit. The station aired NOW’s rebuttal via a phone interview with Joan  
Israel, Detroit NOW President, who very convincingly refuted the charges.

ACTION

1. Call the NOW Legislative Office immediately if the Trent Lott letter is being publicized  
in your community, or if you learn that any of your local media have received any  
communications about the letter.

2. Your chapter president, Legislative and FCC coordinators will be receiving (in fact, may  
already have received) a packet of materials from the Legislative Office and the FCC Task  
Force which should be very useful in refuting this attack. Make sure your chapter has  
these before undertaking rebuttal.

3. If NOW is attacked on radio or TV, request that the station give your chapter airtime  
to defend NOW. If NOW is not attacked but the program espoused an anti-ERA point  
of view, you should request that the station air the opposing point of view.

POSITION AVAILABLE

A position is available for a Director of Legislation (lobbyist) in the Legislative Office, who  
will implement NOW’s legislative priorities. Salary is $13,200. Previous legislative experience  
desirable and membership in NOW (preferably of long duration) is required. Include in resume  
duration of membership in NOW, positions held in NOW, activities in NOW and membership in  
other feminist organizations. Also include education and relevant experience. A full position  
description will be sent upon submission of a resume.

NOW ERA TWO YEAR STRATEGY  
RAISING THE ISSUE  

Raising the Issue is the strategy NOW is using in primary/election politics for the ERA. NOW  
cannot endorse candidates because of our tax status. However, this strategy presents many  
ways and advantages for influencing elections by “issue” focus rather than “candidate” focus.  
The GOAL of the strategy is to influence all candidates to endorse the ERA. The TARGET  
selection is a “NO” district. That is, if there is an ERA voting record and the person holding  
the district seat voted “NO” you have a potential TARGET. Decisions on which districts  

to TARGET should be based on information from PAR: How close was the last election?  
How well organized is NOW in the district? What other groups that have endorsed the ERA  
are organized, or in large numbers in the district (i.e., especially labor)?  

HOW TO RAISE THE ISSUE: (1) Draw up a timeline like the one Chicago NOW has designed  
below; (2) Keep track of all candidate nights in the district and make certain NOW members  
attend and ask about the ERA; (3) Keep track of all TV talk show appearances, news interviews,  
etc. of the candidate and try to have the ERA listed as an issue to be presented to the candidates  
in each interview; (4) Each time a candidate endorses equal rights in any way, be sure to publicize  
their statements. A candidate may shift from total opposition to endorsing a State ERA —  

or supporting a state bill on equal credit; that is a wobble and indicates some change. Identify  
the “wobble” with growing awareness of inequality of women in law, and keep up pressure for  
full endorsement of ERA. If this candidate wins and still has not endorsed ERA, you can  

suggest win was result of “wobble” and continue to press for full endorsement. In other words,  
use the “wobble” as a save clause; (5) NOW can provide “voter information” concerning voting  
records on the ERA and public statements. Hand out sheets or small ads in suburban or rural  
weeklies, demanding “public accountability” of candidates on the ERA; (6) letter campaigns,  
telephone campaigns, door-to-door campaigns can be used to build grassroots support for the ERA  
and confront the candidates with constituency support; (7) Meet the candidates at their “shopping  
center” stops with placards — “Equal Rights by the 200th Anniversary of the Republic”, etc. —  
and possibly adopt a particular slogan or sign or other way of identification that is visible to the  
candidates, public and media (example: Florida met their “traveling” committee hearings at the  
airport with umbrellas painted with slogans).  

REMEMBER THAT THE GOAL OF THE STRATEGY IS TO HAVE ALL CANDIDATES ENDORSE  

THE ERA.

MONTHLY NEWSLETTER OF THE NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR WOMEN

CALL TO NOW’S SEVENTH CONFERENCE

Dear Sisters and Brothers in NOW:

Would you believe, NOW’s 7th Conference scheduled for May 25, 26, 27, 1974 in Houston, Texas,
is only about five months hence? As inexorable as time itself is the Theme (so far) selected for the
Conference: YOU CAN’T STOP NOW! Yes, it does have meanings for NOW members and non-
(yet) members.

Conference purposes include inspiration and (re) dedication; education and skills; policy and
strategy; feminist forum — personal and political (personal is political and vice versa); evaluation.
Whatever else, the Conference is our periodic opportunity to get together, to affirm, confirm our
commitment to and development of feminism that is central to any humanism. It’s experience
and a process as well as ‘happening(s)’.

This Conference will have some innovations. As always, we will choose people for particular respon-
sibilities and opportunities, i.e. officers, other Board members and 3 of the 7 next nominating com-
mittee. Unlike some instances previously, at least two nominees for each job will be presented to
the Conference attendees by the Nominating Committee. Other candidates will be possible and
welcomed. Also, campaigning will be more open and guidelines will be more liberal to facilitate
knowing candidates and their platforms. (Nominating Committees developing these NOW and will
publish in DO IT NOW). We also anticipate information on How NOW Works (something con-
stantly evolving), a Conference ‘Survival’ booklet, and Resolution guidelines so we can resolve
relatively less and strategize more to move from institutionalized sexism to institutionalizing feminism.
Chapters will want to discuss any really new resolutions pre-Conference after familiarity with the
institutions and policy we already have in considerable areas.

Opportunities to showcase chapter achievements; to see/buy feminist products; to share our sister-
hood and brotherhood for personhood; to laugh and commiserate; to create NOW’s development
and our own; to celebrate our viability and know our rising expectations opens us to vulnerabilities;
all of these and more are part of a NOW conference. As the largest unequivocally feminist organiza-
tion in the world and a vanguard in the profound universal behavioral revolution in this rebirth of
feminism: YOU CAN’T STOP NOW! We will define and reassign power for Life. Come to Houston!

Warmly,

Wilma Scott Heide.

Capsule Descriptions of NOW National Offices

All officers and board members of NOW, as all other members, serve as volunteers in elected positions.  
Annual membership dues income of the national organization now provides sufficient funds to reimburse  
most expenses.

NOTE: Regional Directors are not elected at National Conference. Each region is required to hold a  
conference within 6 months following to elect its own Regional Director and conduct other business.

** Chair-One of the Board. Calls and conducts meetings of the national board or executive committee;  
supervises chartering of chapters; represents the national organization to the public as necessary  
and otherwise promotes the purposes of the organization; cooperates with the President in performing  
internal administrative functions.

President. Presides at meetings of the National Conference; administers the day-to-day operations  
of the national organization between board meetings; appoints members of standing committees and  
special committees as necessary; travels extensively visiting chapters, testifying at hearings, and  
otherwise serving as the official spokesperson and representative of the national organization.

Secretary. Records and reproduces minutes and other appropriate records of the national executive  
committee, board of directors and National Conference meetings and actions; maintains some  
permanent files and carries on some correspondence for the national organization; reviews and  
reports on policy positions as necessary or requested.

Treasurer. Collects dues and other monies for the national organization and makes disbursements  
according to the national budget; files Internal Revenue Service tax information; prepares periodic  
financial reports to the board and an annual report to the membership and other records as required  
or requested; supervises chapter treasurers’ record-keeping.

REGIONAL REVIEW

From Jackie Frost, Southern Regional Director

November and December were months of frenzied feminist activity in the Southern Region.....
November 2-4, over 100 Alabama feminists gathered at Cheaha State Park near Anniston, Alabama.
Sarah Jane Stewart organized workshops on Marriage & Divorce & Family Relations, the growing
national Rape Crisis, ERA, Women in Politics, and Chapter Convening. Martha Baker of Alexander
City was elected State Coordinator, and Mary Weidler of Montgomery, State Legislative Coordinator.
In Shreveport, Louisiana, NOW members assembled on November 10-11 to adopt state structure

and elect officers, with Linda Martin of Shreveport elected State Coordinator, Janet Schori of

Baton Rouge, State Legislative Coordinator, and Josie Young of Monroe, State Finance Coordinator.
The next weekend, Texas NOW members from throughout the state held their first NOW Organizing
Conference in Dallas. The Lone Star State feminists established a model organizing plan by dividing
the state into five areas for development, each with a dynamic leader elected to direct the effort.
Martha Dickey of Dallas was elected State Coordinator.

REPORT ON BY-LAWS VOTE  
By Betty Newcomb, Coordinator, Mailed By-laws Ballot  

Your November issue of DO IT NOW contained the flash that both proposed National By-laws  
changes had failed. That neither received the 2/3 vote required by the National By-laws is shown  
in the detailed count below:  

Yes Votes No Votes Required Number Total  
for 2/3 Fewer Votes  
Than 2/3 Cast  
Delegate System 889 775 1110 221 1664  
Regional Elections 914 746 1106 192 1660  

A total of 1667 valid ballots were counted. (10 people voted on only one by-law). An additional  

120 ballots, declared invalid, were either unsigned, unidentifiable, or, when checked against the  
master membership list, were found to be cast by persons who had not paid their dues by July 31, ‘73.  
An additional 182 ballots were classified “challenged” for one of the following reasons: postmarked  
after 11/1/73, could not be found in the membership file, signatures were illegible with no other  
identifying marks. If all of the challenged ballots had been yea votes, both by-laws would still have  
failed because it would have been impossible for either by-law to receive the 2/3 yea vote necessary  
for a by-law change. If there had been any possibility that they might have affected the final vote,  
further efforts would have been made to validate the challenged ballots.  

The by-laws committee made absolutely every effort to run a fair, smooth, voting process. Inevitably,  
some problems arose. While the National By-laws do not require such, the committee worked out a  
plan to allow secret ballots. The original copy submitted to DO IT NOW describing the ground rules  
for the election, including provisions for a totally secret ballot, had already been submitted, when  
Jo Ann Gardner notified the committee that our system did not follow Roberts Rules of Order Re-  
vised (pp. 356-357), and that according to our National By-laws (Sect. 14) we had to follow Roberts  
Rules or the vote could be declared legally invalid. A hurried telephone conversation exchange  
followed between the three committee members, Eleanor Smeal in Pittsburgh, Judy Lonnquist in  
Chicago, and me in Muncie, Indiana. One alternative from Roberts Rules allowed for a secret ballot;  
another described the procedure that we agreed upon. We gave up the benefits of the secret ballot  
primarily for financial reasons. The weight of the DO IT NOW issue carrying the by-laws change,  
even using special lightweight paper, was at the limit of the 8¢ rate if we included the one standard  
envelope required by Roberts Rules for the non-secret ballot. The procedure allowing for a secret  
ballot would have required in addition to an intricate ballot folding procedure, inclusion of two  
standard sized envelopes. The additional cost to NOW for supplying 30,000 additional envelopes  
and 30,000 times an additional 8¢ postage rate would have been something over $2,500. We  
reluctantly agreed to go with the non-secret ballot.  

If any of you have not already surmised, the re-stickable address labels were not used, as originally  
planned. Among the amusing anecdotes we will remember are some of the comments many members  
made regarding the non-stickiness of the tapes. Most of them were truly restrained and polite —  
totally unlike the popularly held image of feminists. Thanks to all of you for your patience. We  
really tried to make it easier for you.  

All NOW members owe a special thanks to the many people who helped us in the ballot-counting  
process — a terribly tedious procedure of counting, recounting, validating envelopes against a  

master file, deciphering signatures, stapling envelopes to ballots — all done in a successful effort  

to prepare properly for anyone who wished to check the ballot-counting procedure.  

If any of you wonder why the hurry and last-minute decisions, I will accept responsibility. I was  
adamant that the by-laws be dealt with as soon as possible. The new by-laws committee had to know  
the status of those proposed changes in time to process necessary by-laws changes to be presented

at the 1974 National Conference.

Betty Newcomb, Coordinator,  
Mailed By-laws Ballot

ATTENTION: NOW MEMBERS  
Plea For Input To By-Laws Committee

The by-laws committee will meet sometime in January to prepare proposed by-laws changes for the  
consideration of the 1974 National Conference. For many of you, by-laws might seem incomprehensible,  
dull, irrelevant, or a drag. But they are very important. An organization’s by-laws shape the  
organization — its base of power, its flexibility or rigidity, and its constituency — that is, the kind of  
member it will attract. The by-laws committee will attempt to formulate proposals most nearly reflecting the wishes of the members. Please write to me and tell your views on possible NOW structure.  
You may want to direct your comments to any or all of the following areas:

Who should set program and/or policy for NOW — the members, the chapters, the board (total board  
or the executive board), the president? What number of persons should serve on the board — minimum,  
maximum? Should the board be primarily administrative, interpreting NOW policy and servicing the  
membership, or should it set policy, provide a forum for dissent? Should all board members be elected,  
or should some be appointed to provide regional or minority representation? Should some board  
members be elected regionally? What proportion mix — elected, appointed, regional, at large? Should  
regionally elected board members be representational only or should they be regional directors?  
Should regional boards be established? If yes, what functions should they perform? Should board  
terms be staggered? Should limits be placed on number of consecutive terms allowed? Should the  
vice-presidents be elected by responsibility, i.e. legal, legislative; PR, fundraising? Should those  

four responsibilities be given executive board status? Should other responsibilities be given executive  
board status? What should be the relationship between member, chapter, state, region, national?

Should budget priorities be set by the national board, or by the membership? What function should  
be served by the National Conference — reaffirmation of sisterhood, program setting, policy-making,  
attracting media attention? Should the voting at the National Conference be by delegates? What  
representation mix? Should the mailed by-laws ballot be preserved? If you voted against either of  
the recent by-laws changes, please tell us why you voted against them, what features of the proposals  
you rejected?

I have tried to present a broad range of possibilities for comment. If your pet cause has been omitted,  
truly, it was not intentional. The only bias the by-laws committee has is to attempt to reflect the  
wishes of the membership. The list above is a long one. Long responses will be appreciated, but not  
expected; nor will neatness count in the amount of attention your reply receives. Please let us hear  
from you. We cannot reflect the wishes of the membership unless we know them. Wilma Scott Heide  
will officially appoint the members of the new by-laws committee soon. Please send your replies to  
reach me no later than the end of the first week in February, 1974, for consideration by the by-laws  
committee.

Betty Newcomb, Coordinator,  
By-laws Committee

WOMEN AND HEALTH ACTION

A Report from Joan Goldstein,  
National Coordinator, NOW Women & Health Task Force

The National Task Force on Health defined as one of our goals the humanizing of physician  
attitudes towards women. In response to this concern, the Baltimore NOW Health Task Force  
has developed a program concept which attempts to open communication and dialogue between  
women and women physicians. During this experimental evening of panel and discussions,  

150 Baltimore women, many of whom were not members of NOW, but may have been later,  
were finally allowed to ask basic questions and receive unhurried answers on the all too  
mysterious body. Learning was a two-way street: physicians were surprised to hear of women’s  
experience with the profession and to recognize how little is shared between doctor and patient.  
This seemed like only a beginning. Requests were made for continuous sessions on a variety  

of subjects.

In recognition of the enormous need for health dialogue, information and education, the  
Baltimore County NOW Health Task Force has put together a kit of a model program on  
women’s health to serve as a guide for groups nationally. I see this as one prototype of program  
activities which NOW chapters could adapt throughout the country. If there are other concepts,  
please contact me so that we can share our experiences. Here’s the information:

A Model program on women’s health: How to organize a panel discussion on  
“Women’s Right to Health: Phases of Her Life.” Packet contains complete  
information on how to plan and succeed, step-by-step in 8 weeks, in sponsoring  
a panel discussion by four women doctors for an audience of 150 persons on  

a low budget. Kit includes sample letters to doctors, sample program, informa-  
tion on contents of discussion, moderator’s role, publicity, budget, and refresh-  
ments. Send $2.50 to Baltimore County NOW Health Task Force, P.O. Box 21,  
Sunshine Avenue, Kingsville, Md. 21087.

Nina Tassi, the Health chairperson, an energetic and creative woman, wrote in a letter to me:  
“I have an idea that you would find Baltimore refreshing to the spirit.” I did.

U. S. Supreme Court Reverts to Stone Age on Women & Public Accommodations

On November 5, 1973, the U. S. Supreme Court voted 8 to 1 (Douglas dissenting) to leave standing  
a decision upholding the right of a New Orleans hotel to refuse to serve women in its men’s grill.  
National Board member, Karen DeCrow, says, “This is a shocking and insulting decision for  
women. As the NOW Public Accommodations Week coordinator in 1968, I was convinced that  

in 1973, this was no longer an issue for NOW, for the women’s movement. I was mistaken.  
Apparently, the Supreme Court of the United States does not feel convinced that women are  
members of the public.

I suggest that every person reading DO IT NOW write to at least one, if not all eight, of the  
Justices who voted against our right to enter a place of public accommodation and be served therein.  
This is an unusual action to take — writing the court — and I suggest we keep the letters calm,  
polite, and short..... just to let them know how humiliated we are because of this decision.”  
For further information, write Karen DeCrow, 116 Benedict Avenue, Syracuse, N. Y. 13210.

ABORTION  
ANTI-ABORTION DEMONSTRATION  

Congressional offices are shoring up for an onslaught of 10,000 “right-to-lifers” coming to Washington  
for a January 22nd demonstration. On the anniversary of the Supreme Court abortion decision, they  
are planning a ring-around-the-Capitol to mourn aborted fetuses. They will flood the halls of Congress  
and deliver single red roses (to symbolize the fetus) to each Member of Congress.  

The “right-to-lifers” are building up momentum with their victories over the past year — victories  
attributable to a well-financed, high-pressure lobbying effort.  

ACTION  

It is urgent that we let Congress know that we feel just as strongly in favor of a woman’s right to  
choose as “r-t-l” does in opposition. VISIT YOUR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS IN THEIR HOME  
OFFICES WHILE THEY ARE HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS — ESPECIALLY DURING THE  
WEEK OF JANUARY 14-18.  

NO ABORTIONS FOR THE POOR  

On November 30th, Senator James Buckley (R-NY) introduced an amendment to the Social Security  
Amendments of 1973 which prohibited use of Medicaid funds for performance of abortions. The  
amendment was accepted by Senator Russell Long and passed in the Senate by voice vote. Since the  
House bill did not contain the language, the SSA’s will go to a conference committee for final  
version. The conference committee will be composed of members of the Senate Finance and House  
Ways and Means Committee. Latest word as of December 21st was that hearings on the Buckley  
Amendment will take place in February. See your Chapter Legislative Coordinator for more details.  

Little by little, the so-called “right-to-life” forces are hacking away at the hard-fought right to  
control our own bodies we won through the January 1973 Supreme Court decision. By prohibiting  
public funds (Medicaid and foreign aid) and legal aid services to be used for abortions and by allowing  
hospitals to decide whether or not to perform abortions, the opposition may succeed in eliminating  
medically safe, legal abortions to the poor both in this country and abroad.  

ACTION  

The situation is critical. We cannot afford another “r-t-l” victory. EACH AND EVERY NOW  
MEMBER SHOULD WRITE TO SENATOR RUSSELL LONG (D-La., Chairman, Senate Finance  
Committee) AND TO REPRESENTATIVES WILBUR MILLS (D-Ark., Chairman, House Ways  
and Means Committee) AND AL ULLMAN (D-Oreg., next in line for Mills’ job) TO PROTEST  
THE DISCRIMINATION AGAINST POOR WOMEN, THROUGH PROHIBITION OF FUNDS  
FOR ABORTION UNDER MEDICAID. SEND COPY TO YOUR OWN SENATORS AND  
CONGRESSPERSON.

FLEXIBLE HOURS EMPLOYMENT ACT

The Flexible Hours Employment Act (S 2022), a bill which would require that within 5 years of
enactment, 10% of the positions at each and all levels in all Executive Agencies of the Federal
Government be made available on a flexible hours basis has been introduced in the Senate by
John Tunney (D-CA). Bella Abzug (D-NY) has introduced a similar bill in the House (HR 9699).

Flexible hours is defined as part-time employment such as four hours per workday or one to four
days per week, etc. A flexible hours job is intended to be a permanent, responsible position with
standard civil service protections and prorated fringe benefits. Another section of the bill requires
the Secretary of Labor to promote expansion of flexible hours employment practices by all public
and private employers.

We feel the bill could especially benefit parents by making it possible for both to contribute to
the rearing of their children and to the income of the family.

TO 1974 NOW NATIONAL CONFERENCE ATTENDEES:  

The phenomenal growth of NOW in recent years has been exciting. The prospect of a national  
conference with over 3500 feminists in attendance is exhilarating. For conference coordinators,  
however, planning the conference can be quite a challenge.  

Our growth is a source of pride and strength; it is also the basis of tremendous logistical prob-  
lems. NOW is BIG — too big to be housed in a single hotel — too big to meet in plenary in a  
hotel ballroom — too big to leave the success of our conference to the mercy of last minute  
decisions.  

The headquarters for our conference will be the Rice Hotel in Houston, Texas. Everyone, how-  
ever, cannot sleep there. (The hotel’s not little — we’re BIG.) Overflow housing in other hotels  
is necessary. Whether you stay in the Rice or elsewhere depends on how soon you make your  
room reservations. First come — first served may not be a principle of natural law, but it seems  
the fairest method, and it’s the rule we'll observe.  

Workshops will be conducted in the Rice and plenary sessions in the Albert Thomas Convention  
Center three blocks away. (The hotel ballroom is not small — we're BIG.) We must get from  
one place to the other somehow, so walking is indicated. (Transportation will be provided for  
persons with physical handicaps.) Wear comfortable shoes, pray for sunshine, and bring an  
umbrella anyway.  

Child care, as usual, will be provided. To assure quality care for your children, and to facilitate  
planning which can make the conference memorable for the boys and girls who attend, you  
must pre-register for child care. We're too big to guess at the number of children to expect.  
Work must be contracted for and extensive arrangements made. So bring your children but  
please let us know how many.  

Your comfort, your convenience, your full enjoyment of an exciting weekend are our primary  
goals. Help us make this conference not just bigger, but better. We need your understanding  
and your cooperation. We pledge you ours. Don’t delay on your registration and hotel reserva-  
tions. DO IT NOW!  

See you in Houston,  

Helen Cassidy & Poppy Northcutt,  

Conference Coordinators

VETERAN'S BENEFITS AND THE SUPREME COURT  
FRONTIERO v. RICHARDSON  
93 S. Ct. 1764 (May, 1973).  

The Frontiero case arose when Sharon Frontiero, an officer in the Air Force, sought increased quarter allowances and  
medical and dental benefits to cover her husband. Frontiero claimed her husband as a dependent under the statutes providing  
for such increased benefits for spouses.  

These fringe benefits were instituted for members of the uniformed services in an attempt to attract career personnel.  
The statutes covering these benefit allocations provide that the dependent of a male member of the uniformed services  
is his wife; a female member, however, is allowed to claim her husband as a dependent only if “he is in fact dependent  
on the member... for over one-half of his support..."  

On the basis of this clause, Frontiero and her husband were denied benefits. They brought suit, claiming that such a  
statutory difference in treatment creates an unconstitutional discrimination in violation of the Due Process Clause of the  
5th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.  

The essence of their argument to the Court was that the 5th Amendment, though it does not specifically allow for  
equal protection, does forbid discrimination so unjustifiable as to deny one due process of law. The Frontieros’ contention  
was that if she were a male officer, the benefits would be granted her without regard to the actual financial dependency  
of her spouse, and that solely because she is a woman she has been denied those benefits. This, the Frontieros claim, is  
an unjustifiable statutory classification.  

They argued that classifications based upon sex, in the same manner as those based upon race, religion and national  
origin, are inherently suspect and should be subjected to close judicial investigation.  

The Supreme Court, in agreeing with the Frontieros, based the weight of its decision upon its earlier decision in  
Reed v. Reed (1971), where the Court ruled unconstitutional an Idaho statute providing if there are two individuals  
otherwise equally entitled to be the administrator of an estate, and one of the individuals was female, the male must be  
awarded the appointment.  

The Court had reasoned in Reed, as it did in Frontiero, that sex classifications were as suspect as those based on race,  
national origin and religion. The argument used in Reed which the Court chose to extend in Frontiero was that a legislature  
cannot make classifications based on arbitrary distinctions, solely for the purpose of legislative convenience (the argument  
of the defense had been that the sexual classifications were included in the statute merely to alleviate administrative paper-  
work by narrowing one class of people eligible). The Court determined the test of the arbitrariness to be that the classifi-  
cation distinction must bear a legitimate relationship to the governmental interest sought to be protected. In other words,  
the Court decided that legislative convenience, in and of itself, is not a factor which will support the constitutional  
validity of a statutory classification. If the classification is found to be patently arbitrary in relation to the objective  
of the statute, it must be found unconstitutional.  

In Frontiero, the Court reasoned that a sexual classification was in no way shown to have any correlation to the granting  
of benefits to service people and their spouses in order to increase career personnel, other than to save administrative  
cost and time.  

It is important to note, and the Court in both Reed and Frontiero was careful to point out, that it is not necessary that  
the statute in question deny women all rights under its provisions in order for it to be found that the statutory classifica-  
tions are discriminatory. More specifically, the fact that women were not automatically denied benefits (Frontiero’s  
husband would have been eligible for benefits if he had been found to be dependent) did not enter as a factor in the  
Court's determination that because Frontiero was denied employment benefits under different regulations from those  
applicable to her male peers, the statute was discriminatory.  

Justice Brennan, writing the majority opinion in Frontiero, looked back with considerable regret on the sexist history  
of the Court and noted that the courts have come a long way from the judicial sexism found in cases such as Bradwell v.  
Illinois (1873), where the Court concluded that:  

The harmony * * * which belongs * * * to the family institution is repugnant to the idea of a woman  
adopting a distinct and independent career from that of her husband. * * * The paramount destiny and  
mission of woman are to fulfill the offices * * * of wife and mother * * * .”  

With the backdrop of that quotation, the Supreme Court ventured again, not only to concur with its decision in Reed,  
but to expand it. The position of the Court articulated in Frontiero now seems to be only that it is a denial of a woman’s  
right to equal protection under the law to be denied a statutory privilege because she is a woman, but that any statute  
which makes a classification distinction based on sex is inherently suspect and should be held to close judicial scrutiny.  
Thus, Frontiero holds that the imposition upon a citizen of a disability based on that person’s sex on its face is a denial  
of rights guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution. Judith Lonnquist

1. Apparently resulting from my protests last year to Psychosurgery funding by the National Institute of
Mental Health, N. I. M. H., of the U. S. Department of Health, Education and Welfare, H. E. W., I was invited to
be a member of a consultant panel convened by N. I. M. H., 9/24/73. The issues are: no empirical evidence of
therapeutic effectiveness of psychosurgery (brain surgery); therefore it is human experimentation; denial of civil
liberties and civil rights of subjects who are often in no position to give ‘informed consent’; use of powerless
people — women, children, prison inmates, hospital inmates as subjects; criteria of mental health has documented
double standards that, for example, considers return/adjustment to ‘housewife’ (sic, no one marries a house) role
as success vis-à-vis women victims. N. I. M. H. knows my views and recommendations as a behavioral scientist,
as a NOW officer, as a civil libertarian citizen. If you are knowledgeable about this phenomenon, please write
Dr. Bert Brown, Director, National Institute of Mental Health, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, Md. 20852. Suggest
you insist on no public funding of Psychosurgery research, experimentation, subject selection, procedures without
additional continuous feminist consulting and monitoring. Communicate with Joan Goldstein, NOW Task Force
Coordinator on Women and Health for follow-up on these actions: E-14 Lakeview Terrace, Princeton, N. J. 08540,
(609) 452-1796.

2. Suggest each NOW member ‘recover’ at least one former NOW member who may have simply neglected to
renew, would like to know current exciting programs and progress, whose reason(s) for not renewing no longer
exist.

3. As long as I have breath and voice in NOW, I shall continue to observe, until the phenomena are eliminated,
that concepts, language and behavior that communicate: target, fight, enemy, barricades, ‘give ‘em hell’, male
chauvinist pig ~ m.c.p., etc. sound like the military, masculine mystique that is all too ‘Pentagonian’ and the
central ethos of our culture. I am as radical (getting to root causes), unequivocal, committed, vigorously feminist
as any other NOW member or other feminist; however, adversarial concepts, behavior and language are root causes
of the basic human inequality of sexism that feminism intends to cure. Alternatives to the above in sequence
might be: focus, work, beneficiary (though recalcitrants won't view or feel it that way just NOW), barriers, give
‘em heaven (again, some don’t know it yet), still normal male, i.e. sexist, etc. Indeed, the rebirth of feminism
means, in my view, that SHE IS RISEN to redefine and reassign power for life. May I suggest this be discussed/

Preparing Testimony

Sooner or later you may want to testify before your city council or a committee of your state
legislature on a bill of interest to NOW, or, if you have a special expertise, we may ask you to
prepare testimony and/or to testify for NOW before a congressional committee.

a. Ask to testify: Write or call the city council or the state committee which has jurisdiction
over the bill, find out if and when hearings are being held (if they’re not, you may want to
push for them), and ask to testify. Ask them to send you a copy of the bill. If you can’t
make the hearing or can’t get someone to present the testimony for you, ask to submit
written testimony for the record.

b. Form: Type clearly, double space. Provide enough copies for the entire committee and
the press (usually about forty). Get the testimony in, if possible, two days ahead, so the
committee members can read it. Use offset or instant printing for good reproduction.
Have a front page that says something like this:

Testimony on the Welfare Amendments Act of 1972 (S. 1234) presented

before the Poverty Committee of the Legislature of the State of California,

by Jane Equal on behalf of the National Organization for Women, June, 1972.
In your first paragraph, identify yourself by name and occupation and residence. State
that you are appearing only for NOW, and describe NOW briefly (i.e.):

The National Organization for Women was formed in 1966 for the purpose

of bringing women into full participation in the mainstream of American

life in truly equal partnership with men. With a membership of both men

and women, NOW is the largest feminist organization in the world, with

over 600 chapters, and with members in every state.

c. Content: Start out by stating NOW’s official position on the issue from our Bill of Rights
or from our resolutions taken at our national conferences. Don’t make your testimony
over 4 or 5 pages unless you have very complex, subtle, and relevant arguments. Don’t
cover the whole feminist movement — no legislature is quite ready for that — but just the
information, arguments and statistics that have direct bearing on the bill. Document
your research by citing the source in the text or in footnotes. You can append single
copies of documentation (tables, articles, letters, graphs) for inclusion in the record that
you may want to refer to but not read. Don’t be afraid of making a joke or a forceful
statement, or of using a good quotation. Stick to a few well-documented points rather
than scattering your shots. Make your strongest statements first before they fall asleep
and wind up with a succinct summary and a bit of wit if you can. (The NOW Legislative
Office can provide some model testimony if you write, or you can look in the hearings
record on the ERA).

d. Questioning: You may be cross-questioned. Take your time. If you are asked a legal or
statistical question you can’t answer, don’t bluff. Say frankly you don’t have that
specific information, but will get the answer in two days. Then do it!

e. Press Release: You should also prepare a news release, or have your chapter’s PR person
do it, of preferably one, no more than two pages, summarizing the main points of your
testimony. Distribute to the press for release the day of your testimony. See NOW’s
Press Handbook for suggestions.

RAPE CENTER BILL  

On September 13, Senator Mathias (R-Md.) introduced S. 2422, a bill which would establish a National  
Center for the Prevention and Control of Rape. Senator Mathias’ office worked closely with the NOW  
Legislative Office and with Mary Ann Largen, NOW’s National Rape Task Force Coordinator, in the  
drafting and tactics on the bill.  

BACKGROUND  

Written as an amendment to the National Mental Health Act, S. 2422 would, among other things:  

1. Authorize and fund study into the effectiveness of state rape laws, attitudes toward  
rape, treatment of victims, causes, motivations of rapists, impact on families, homo-  
sexual rape in prisons, effectiveness of existing programs. The wording of this section  
is careful to make organizations such as NOW eligible for grants in the event the bill  
is passed and funded.  

2. Act as a clearinghouse to compile continuing studies, conduct research and demon-  
stration projects and training programs for police and medical personnel, etc.  

3. Set a funding level of $10,000,000.  

NOW’S CONTRIBUTION  

NOW’s most important contribution to the bill was to advise the language defining rape, for the  
purposes of the bill, as “forcible, statutory, and attempted rape, homosexual assaults, and other  
criminal sexual assaults.” The usual legal definition of rape in the states’ laws is limited to “vaginal  
penetration” by a man against a woman’s will, and therefore does not include such acts as forcible  
anal or oral copulation, or use of an instrument. Our language would materially broaden the scope  
of the bill, and hopefully encourage adoption of a broader definition of rape at the state level.  
Crimes other than “vaginal penetration” are usually considered “sodomy,” and receive a lesser  
punishment.  

TACTICS  

NOW and Senator Mathias hope to get this bill through the Senate before the Christmas recess.  
Please write both your Senators urging them to co-sponsor, not just support, S. 2422.

YOU ARE NOW’S LOBBYIST: LOBBYING AS A CHAPTER ACTION PROGRAM

This is the month your chapter will probably be deciding on its program for the year. It is vitally

important that lobbying your Congresspersons be a part of that program. The lobbying that
really counts is the lobbying that you and your chapter do at and from home — not only indivi-
dually through letters and calls to your legislators’ offices, but as a chapter by meeting with
them at home. Our efforts in Washington depend on you.

What follows is a suggested program for your chapter to lobby your Representative. You may

want to adapt it for your state legislators also, with help from your State Legislative Coordinator,

who may also be arranging for meetings with your Senators. (We are grateful to the State
Legislative Coordinators from California — Geri Sherwood, Michigan — and Illinois for some
of the materials used here.)

This kind of lobbying is not only what makes our efforts possible in Washington, but is the kind
of service your chapter can and should provide for its members and prospective members.

PLANNING THE MEETING

Pre-planning the meeting makes for the best results. As a chapter, decide what the goals are
for your meeting (opening up communications with your Representative’s office, getting a
commitment to oppose the abortion amendment and discharge petition, supporting credit
legislation, childcare, etc. — your chapter legislative coordinator and other task force coordina-
tors will have materials from their task forces). Plan for several of you to go — four or five at
the most — your Legislative Task Force person, President, relevant Task Force Coordinators
might be your choices. Decide on what points you want to cover — probably no more than
three — and divide up the topics so that one person leads the discussion on each point. Get to-
gether or prepare materials on each point. If you are nervous, role-play the meeting before
you go, trying to anticipate questions or objections to your program your Representative may
have. (She/he may surprise you and be very receptive!) Try to have someone in your group
of the same political party as your Representative.

ARRANGE THE MEETING  
Call or write your Representative’s home office, explain who you are, and that you want to

have a meeting next time she/he is in town. List the topics you want to cover and who will be
attending from the chapter, and what their chapter functions are.

THE MEETING

1. *Take some literature with you: NOW’s Bill of Rights (especially), NOW’s goals, position papers on dope sheets from the National Task Forces on Issues of interest to you, a sample of your chapter newsletter or publication.

2. *Tell a little about your chapter — what its priorities are, its successes, mention briefly your newsletter and your speaker’s bureau so they know you get to a lot of people. Don’t say how large or how small your chapter or NOW is — instead stress our importance as opinion-makers.

3. *Limit your presentation to probably no more than three points, but make them good and forceful. Make sure they are all things on which federal action is required. Decide ahead what points you want to cover, and what your goals are for the meeting (opening up communications with their offices, getting a yes on extension of minimum wage or childcare, etc.) If there are several of you, divide up the topics so a different person leads the discussion on each point. [Speak for the Chapter or for NOW (Our chapter’s priorities are... NOW’s legislative program calls for . . . )]

4. *Ask their offices to do something for you — keep your chapter informed or provided with copies of bills, send your legislative task force person the Congressional Record. Ask to be placed on their mailing list for the newsletters they send to their home district.

5. “Let them know what you can do for them — support them on bills, ask if you can arrange for them to speak at a chapter meeting or rally when they're home (be sure you get a good turnout), mention anything good they've done in the chapter newsletter, get them information they could use on bills they want to introduce and support or put in the Congressional Record, etc.

FOLLOW-UP

Write a letter when you get home summarizing the points of the discussion and thanking them for meeting with you. Let them know your chapter will keep in touch.

* * * * *

The most effective way to lobby is to be informed, brief and efficient. Your Representative will not agree with you on everything, but remember that in lobbying today’s enemy is tomorrow’s friend. If you can’t get to them on this issue, you may get to them on the next. Confrontation is a tactic among other tactics — use it only when it may pay off for you, and only when you have carefully planned for it.
