STATUS REPORT ON ABORTION  

The last two Do It Now Blue Sheets have contained information on the Constitutional Amend-  
ment on Abortion from the Reproduction Task Force and the Legislative Office. The newest  
developments concern who will control the hearing process in the Senate Judiciary Committee.  
Senator James Eastland (D-Miss.) has recently decided to co-sponsor the Buckley Constitutional  
Amendment to guarantee the Right-To-Life of the fetus. As Chairman of the Senate Judiciary  
Committee, Senator Eastland could use his power to take hearing authority on the Constitutional  
Amendment away from Senator Birch Bayh (D-Ind.). (He has already bypassed Senator Bayh  
by holding hearings on the Constitutional Amendment on Busing.) Senator Bayh states that his  
mail is running very pro-amendment at this time and that other Senators are beginning to exper-  
ience pressure also.  

PURPOSES AND FOCUS:  

This local action outline has a target: we want our Congresspersons to oppose the Constitutional  
Amendments on Abortion and support the Supreme Court decision. Always keep that target in  
sight! NOW chapters should engage in as much local lobbying at the home offices of Senators  
and Congresspersons as is possible. We also need to identify and develop the strong community  
support of individuals and groups outside NOW for the Supreme Court decision on abortion.  
Remember, the opposition intends to do the same thing!  

TACTICS  

The opposition will be using all the emotionalism they can muster from the very beginning,  
through color slide shows, color picture books, and pickled fetuses. NOW should begin our  
present campaign by giving legal, rational arguments against the Amendment. All NOW educa-  
tional efforts — speeches, television appearances, flyers — should have the goals of generating  
mail to Senators and Congresspersons which demonstrates that community support exists for  
the Supreme Court Decision and against the Constitutional Amendment. Take stationery and  
stamps with you to meetings and get people to write on the spot!

LEGAL ARGUMENTS AGAINST CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT:  

(Because feminist arguments against the proposed constitutional amendment to prohibit  
abortion are often ineffective, it is important that we learn to use a broad range of reasons  
for opposition. The following are some suggestions which you might find helpful; learn  
to use them!)  

1. CONSTITUTIONAL PURITY  

Don’t junk up the Constitution — technology could make the abortion issue obsolete —  
opens the door to busing and school prayer amendments — establishes an absolute in  
a fluid, pluralistic society.  

A

. PRACTICAL PROBLEMS (PROHIBITION AGAIN?)

Will not prevent abortions — past laws, no matter how strict, have not prevented abortion —  
will generate lawlessness, black market increase — increase organized crime involvement.

. CRIMINAL LAW:

Abortion will be prosecuted as murder although never considered as such even under the  
strictest laws in the past.

Actions resulting in miscarriage would be considered a crime possibly resulting in a charge  
of manslaughter.

No pregnant woman could be jailed in the absence of a reason to jail the “fetus person.”  
A woman who took a drug for illness or for her health which inadvertently resulted in a  
spontaneous abortion could be charged with murder.

. TAXES

Would the fetus be counted as a dependent for tax purposes — from the moment of conception?  
How far could and would the IRS go to verify the pregnancy? Would Medicaid be available to  
fetuses? And Child-Welfare support?

. IMMIGRATION:

What would be the citizenship status of a fetus?

Could the fetus be a person and not a citizen? Would all children conceived by alien persons  
in the U.S. be citizens? Could a pregnant woman who is not a citizen be deported when she is  
“carrying a fetus citizen?”

. CHILD NEGLECT:

Could the state force the mother to comply with certain standards of care and activity for the  
protection of the fetus?

Could a pregnant woman be prosecuted if she smokes since this causes lower birth weight?  
Could drug-addicted women be prosecuted for more serious crimes — such as for pushing —  
due to addiction of the fetus to drugs?

- PRIVACY:

What would become of a woman’s right to privacy as the state expanded its efforts to protect  
the constitutional rights of the fetus? Would pregnancies have to be registered from the moment  
of conception?

Could state police be assigned as guardians to the fetus to ensure its well-being at all times?

The arguments are many and can be used effectively in discussing this issue with the neutral or  
uncommitted men who are lawyers, doctors, Senators, and Representatives. Good luck in putting  
them to use. Remember preservation of the right to choose is in our hands.

ERA NEWS  
MARYLAND STATE ERA  

Maryland voters approved a State ERA by Referendum in May 1972. The State ERA  
went into effect July 1972. The State Legislature re-convened in January 1973.  

SENATOR STEERS (voted Federal ERA) went through the Maryland Code with a computer  
and simply pulled out those sections of the law which referred to sex in any way. His  
strategy was to merely change the language throughout the entire code. In some areas this  
formula worked rather well, in others — notably domestic law — this method proved to be  
disastrous, resulting in anything but equality.  

The Steers Bills caused quite an uproar and immediately, everyone concerned began  
looking for other ways of implementation of the ERA.  

1) Delegate Charles Blumenthal, who had previously sponsored the ERA ratification  
in the House, came up with a resolution to give the Attorney General power of  
declaratory judgment over the ERA. For various reasons, such as slowness,  
inconsistency, and the basic illegality of such a resolution, NOW and other groups  
opposed this method. The resolution was killed in committee.  

2) The Women’s Law Center (Baltimore) and the Maryland State Commission on the  
Status of Women screened the “Steers Bills.” The Bills were separated into three  
categories: good, recommended; mediocre, not recommended; hopelessly  
inadequate, not recommended. NOW adopted these recommendations and with  
the coordination of Casey Hughes, State Coordinator, Sylvia Wright, State Legis-  
lative Coordinator, and Ellen Luff, NOW member and attorney. Basically  
speaking the goals were accomplished in regard to these bills.  

3) Maryland NOW reports that actually most legislators were anxious to support  
good legislation, but the Steers Steamroller caused considerable confusion and  
tempers grew short on all sides. The solution to this quagmire was to call a halt  
to legislation implementation and provide for a Governor’s Commission to study  
and recommend legislation for the January 1974 session.

MINIMUM WAGE BILL

BACKGROUND: As you know, the Minimum Wage Bill is NOW’s top Federal priority legislation this year.  
*The Bill has been passed by both houses,  
“has gone through Joint Conference,  
“came out with everything in it we wanted,  
(especially coverage of domestic workers)  
*and is now ready to go to the President for signing.  

All during the House and Senate debate, however, there were intimations from Republican leaders that the bill would be vetoed by the President as inflationary. That, of course, is  

a terrible irony. As Senators pointed out during the debate, inflation has so increased prices that a worker would have to earn $2.16 an hour right now to buy what he or she was able to buy for the $1.60 an hour minimum Congress approved in 1966 and that has been unchanged since then. What’s more, the $2.20 an hour minimum doesn’t even go into effect immediately. It will take till 1975 before all the non-farm workers covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act reach $2.50. Farm workers won't get there until 1976.

LABOR — HEW VETO THREAT — Coalition for Human Needs and Budget Priorities  

BACKGROUND: Confrontation over national spending priorities between the Congress and the President grows closer as the Senate puts the finishing touches on the Labor-Health, Education & Welfare Appropriation. At stake are numerous human needs programs that the Administration slated for demise in its FY 74 Budget Message.  

*******If the President chooses to veto the Labor-HEW package, as expected, the stage will be set for an effort to OVERRIDE THE VETO, which has only happened once so far!  

The House approved a Labor-HEW Appropriation package on June 26 that is squarely out of the range of Administration expectation — $1.25 billion over Mr. Nixon’s request. Included in the increase is funding for such programs as education for disadvantaged children, hospital construction and modernization, OEO Community Action Agencies, and Legal Service and Senior Citizens Programs, Regional Medical Programs and others — all programs the President wanted to eliminate or reduce in scope. The Senate is currently holding hearings and will finish work  

on the bill in early September. Early speculation is that it will increase funding for these programs — putting the entire Congress squarely on the line against the President.  

Mr. Nixon has repeatedly threatened to veto any bill he considers ‘fiscally irresponsible’. The HEW bill fits his definition. We can therefore expect a veto of the Labor-HEW bill in mid-September, after the Senate and House complete their conference report.

1534 EAST LAKE  

MPLS  

PEOPLE'S COMPANY

A Rape Crisis Center has opened  
in Minneapolis to aid victims  
of the "nation's least reported  
violent crime against a person,"  
according to Rita Gallagher of  
the Center.  

Headquartered in the Women's  

Counselling Service, the Rape  
Crisis Center will operate 24  
hours a day from the phone num-  
ber 824-RAPE.  

STOP  
RAPE  

Another rape center was opened  
last month by a group of south  
Minneapolis churches. But "they  
will just offer counselling for  
a short time," says Kathy Mc-  
Connell of the Crisis Center.  
"We will offer both immediate  
counselling and carry through the  
entire medical and legal pro-  
cess."  

"When a rape victim calls in,"  
Ms. McConnell says, “a volunteer  

will talk to her, give immediate  
counselling and determine if she  
needs transportation to safety or  
to a hospital. Volunteers will  
also see that the medical exam is  
correct, both medically and leg-  
ally."  

In addition, volunteers will  
assist the victim in pressing  
charges against her assailant, as  
well as offering pertinent infor-  
mation and personal counselling.  
Self-defense classes and a speak-  
er's bureau will also be part of  
the Rape Crisis Center's program.  

“Women should be aware that no  
local hospital considers rape an  
emergency situation," Ms. Gallag-  
her explains. "And women don't  
realize that the hospital is part  
of the legal process. In Minnea-  
polis, they'll check for traces  
of sperm to prove rape. The wo-  
man's body is checked for bruises,  
scratches and signs of assault,  
which are sometimes photographed."  

The Rape Crisis Center will  
provide referrals to selected  
physicians. “Few physicians will  
take rape cases because of the  
possibility of court testimony,”  
Ms. Gallagher points out.  

Statistics indicate that the in-  
cidence of this crime is rising,  
Ms. Gallagher says. "A woman is  
raped every 14 minutes. There have  
been 340,270 reported rapes in the  
U.S. since 1970--and that doesn't  
include attempts. And it is es-  
timated that ten times as many  
rapes occur as are reported."  

As for the legal aspects of the  
crime, Ms. Gallagher indicates,  
"Women don't realize that they're  
just a piece of evidence in the  
case, a material witness for the  
prosecution." Rape Crisis Center  
volunteers will provide victims  
with necessary information about  
the legal process as well as ac-  
companying the women through the  
courts.  

“Women's traditional attitude is  
that when you're raped, there's  
nothing you can do," Ms. McCon-  
nell says. "We are trying to  
change that."  

Trick Knees, (Continued from page 1)  

were not always easy tasks for a supposed  
feminist.  

For my job status did depend on how well I  
executed my tasks, and there were several  
times that, with good judgment but a begrud-  
ging sense of resignation, I was forced to  
give over tasks and responsibilities to men.  
At the same time, there were really no tasks  
that I performed that one of the male in-  
structors could not have done as well. It  
was simply, and in the most primitive sense  
possible, division of labor according to  
ability, which, in extreme cases of emer-  
gency and exertion, was of necessity measur-  
ed in highly physical terms.  

Beating a man in a game of squash is satis-  
fying, mainly because you are still playing  
and struggling with society's rules and pre-  
conceptions. Arguing with a man at a party  
can be satisfying because you are standing  
on nearly equal ground. But finding your-  
self in a position where you must be treated  
differently because you no longer have the  
equalizing benefits of intelligence and so-  
ciety at your side is a difficult situation  
for contemporary men and women to handle  
without a certain degree of patronization.  
Even having a close relationship with a man  
in the city is far different than thirty  
miles back in the hills. There, you are  
both nearer to the fundamental differences  
between the sexes, yet, at the same time,  
you are freer and farther removed from so-  
ciety's crippling perversion of these physi-  
cally-based differences.  

When I returned to the city this fall, I  
talked to a very physically active friend of  
mine about these realizations of the summer. —  
She understood immediately and said how glad  
she has been, in a way, to have had a trick  
knee most of her life. How much that freed  
her from any ultimate physical activity, how  
much easier it was to rely on a trick knee  
instead of having to admit to no longer hav-  
ing the strength or stamina to continue. I  
envied her, yet it also made me mad.  

For it is yet another aspect of society  
that makes physical women ashamed when they  
can no longer compete with men because of  
basic biological differences. It is just as  
important for a girl at camp to discover she  
can portage a canoe over a mile of twisty  
trails as it is for her to realize that a  
man can do it faster - and that she should  
let him do it in certain situations with no  
remorse or loss of self-worth.  

Society has done much toward the libera-  
tion of females, but it has also insulated  
them against a more fundamental and total  
acceptance of their physical selves in rela-  
tion to men and the tasks and crises of the  
physical world. A lack of this knowledge  
and/or experience results not only in a cri-  
tical naivete about the world and society,  
but hampers a full healthy contact with our-  
selves and our bodies.  

We will not all turn to organic farming  
and living off the land in our lifetimes. We  

may never suffer the horrors of war or flood,  

or disaster. Few of us will ever experience  
the frustration of female athletes competing  
in a world of male-dominated Olympics and  
record books.  

But we must, nevertheless, slowly begin to  
accept our bodies and their physical limita-  
tions, with or without trick knees, as sepa-  
rate from our feminist liberation. As a re-  
sult, women will end up feeling as strong  

and independent as ever, but simultaneously  

feeling free of the need to make apologies  
in whatever encounters they may have with  
the physical lives and abilities of the men  
with whom they work and live.

The Minnesota House of

ting as many hearings on the

ary.

The ERA states: "Equality

dged by the United States,  
or any State, on account of

The measure must be rati-  
fied by 38 states; at pre-

ERA is vital to women's

Get it in

BY PAT MONAGHAN  

"There's almost nothing you  
can do by yourself to fight man-  
agement," Frances Boelter main-  
tains. "Women have to take a  
united stand."  

Ms. Boelter, a personnel ad-  
ministrator at the federal De-  
partment of Housing and Urban  
Development (HUD), is one of  
several women who will speak at  
the Women's Employment Workshop  
this month.  

"The most important thing is  
to organize, then to document  

your efforts," the employment  

specialist claims. "Management  
has almost no recourse when pre-  
sented with official documenta-  
tion. Words and promises don't  
mean anything—it has to be in  
writing."  

Four employment specialists  
will define women's working rights  
at a midday workshop Jan. 27 at  
Sabathani Community Center, 24  
West 31st Street.  

Sponsored by Model City Women's  
Task Force, the information ses-  
sion is "designed to get women  
to realize how to make the laws  
work for them," says Frankle  
Quade, Model City staffer. "It's  
a practical workshop on how to  
make ‘affirmative action' work.  

"A lot of women," Ms. Quade  
continues, "are not even aware of  
what the words ‘affirmative act-  
ion’ mean. When I first read the  
laws I was amazed at the rights  
women do have."  

Registration begins at 9:30  
a.m. for the session, with the  
program beginning at 10 a.m.  

A formal morning session and in-  
formal workshops in the after-  
noon are planned, with a bagged  
lunch break. Workshops are sche-  
duled to conclude at 2 p.m.  

The idea for a workshop grew,  
Ms. Quade explains, from an em-  
ployment seminar sponsored last  
fall by Federally Employed Women  
(FEW) of St. Paul.  

“Ours will follow that model,  
concentrating on federal reg-  
ulations and particularly the  
affirmative action rules. It's  
vital that women learn about  
these regulations. There are  
many local businesses, like  
Honeywell and Control Data, that  
are covered."  

The regulations require that  
"affirmative action" programs be  
designed and maintained by any  
contractor holding $50,000 or more  
in federal funds. "That means the  
city of Minneapolis, with 4.6  
million in Model City funds a-  
lone," Ms. Quade asserts. "That  
means the Cedar-Riverside Devel-  
opment, South High housing, the  
Institute of Arts."  

Keynote speaker at the work-  
shop will be Mary Manning, re-  
gional director of the federal  
Department of Labor's Women's  
Division, who will describe the  
legal status of working women.  

Ms. Manning will be followed by  
Joan Munday, Federal Women's  
Program Coordinator for the U.S.  
Housing and Urban Development  
department (HUD); Ellen Dressel-  
hufs, local attorney specializing  
in equal employment rights; and  
Frances Boelter, employment spe-  
cialist from HUD's St. Paul of-  
fice.  

Afternoon workshops will cover  
such topics as federal garnish-  
ment laws, career ladders, and  
how to get an affirmative action  
program started. Resource per-  
sons will be available to dis-  
cuss employment problems with  
workshop participants.  

The workshop is aimed at "any  
woman who needs or wants infor-  
mation—women who are housewives  
and want to reenter the labor  
market, underemployed women, un-  
employed women," Ms. Quade states.  

The affirmative action regula-  
tions, with other employment laws  
of importance to women, are the  
focus of the workshop, slated  
for Jan. 27 at Sabathani Com-  
munity Center. There is no  
charge for the program, which  
will feature workshops on spe-  
cific employment problems.  

Ms. Boelter describes problems  
common to working women, particu-  
larly those in the clerical field  
from which she started. "Often  
a woman hired as a secretary or  
typist will do research, compile  
reports, and do other profession-  
al or paraprofessional duties—  
then when she looks for another  
job, she's just a secretary."  

For this reason Ms. Boelter  
stresses the importance of  
“position descriptions—usually  
a management tool, but extremely  
beneficial to employees." Such  
descriptions define the actual  
duties of each employee and  
are prepared cooperatively by  
employee and manager.  

Secretaries should be trained  
for professional or para-  
professional jobs, Ms. Boelter  
insists, so that there will  
be more mobility from clerical  
to higher ranks. "This is an  
important issue for women, be-  
cause 95 percent of the clerical  
force is women and minorities,"  
she comments.  

"Job restructuring—taking a  
professional position, breaking  
out some jobs that don't need  
professional education, and  
giving those tasks to para-  
professionals." Not only would this  
enable an agency or industry to  
hire fewer professionals, thus  
lowering costs, but "it would  
give clerical workers somewhere  
to go."  

Ms. Boelter suggests that col-  
lege-educated women entering  
professional fields have greater  
potential for upward mobility  
than do most secretaries. "But  
we also see a lot of college-  
educated secretaries," she says,  
remarking that her agency and  
others have adopted policies  
which disallow this "underhiring  
of women."  

"Career development is as  
important to the employer as to  
the employee," Ms. Boelter con-  
cludes. "It's not a matter of  
promising everyone a professional  
job, but of letting everyone work  

to their top capability, to get  

the best possible job from each  
person.”

play as the parents began to  
reinforce stereotypes, i.e.,  
the strong silent male, the  
bubbly little "daddy's girl".  

Mathematical skills develop  
at an approximately even  
rate as well, again until  
role reinforcement comes  
into play.  

In spatial visualization,  
the development in the early  
years proceeds at an equal  
rate in children of both  
sexes.  
However,  

and this, I felt  

was Maccoby's most telling  
point, and the crux of her  
lecture, in mathematical  
skills and in spatial vis-  
ualization, by age seven or  
eight, boys are ahead of  
girls in these areas and as  
the children grow towards  
puberty, and beyond, the  
distinction grows more mark-  
ed and in time becomes a  
permanent differentiating  
factor.  

Dr. Maccoby found a vital  
link between the different  
achievement rates in math  
and spatial visualization  
skills at the early-teen  
stage. Girls, she said,  

at this age are very aware  
already of the "feminine  
mystique". They have learned  
to be "smart enough to play  
dumb". Already they have  
forfeited their psycholo-  
gical equality to social-  
sexual expediency.

Feminist Historian “Stumbles  
Over Women” in History  

by MARY HASTINGS  

Scott read diaries of Southern women and  
discovered truths lying behind many Ante-  
Bellum Southern myths about women and  
slavery. She noted that Southern women bore  
no resemblance to the Scarlett O'Hara proto-  
type. Rather, they were shrewd plantation  
supervisors who shouldered the responsibili-  
ty for such “indelicate” tasks as yearly  
hog-killing.  

Feminist pressures are changing people's  
behavior, but a Southern feminist histori-  
an doubts that "people's assumptions (about  
women) have changed."  

Talking on "Feminism and History," Anne  
Firor Scott inaugurated a series of five  
evening lectures at 8 p.m. January 15 in  
Murphy Hall Auditorium on the University of  
Minnesota campus.  

Scott embarked on her feminist study  
some 20 years before women's studies were  
fashionable. She was a new kind of scholar  
who brought new insights into the record.  

The evening series is part of an Ameri-  
can Studies course called "The Effects of  
Feminism on American Intellectual Life."  

"My emotional involvement in this work  
kept me going," she explained. She learned  
that "just because something isn't in the  
books doesn't mean it didn't happen."  
"I am now learning to study the lives of  
obscure people," she said. “Women in Amer-  
ica have lived, to a great degree, in pri-  
vate, so there are many private records  
people must use to find out about women."  

Prof. Elsa Green, coordinator of the  
course, introduced Scott to approximately  
275 persons. Scott is Senior Fellow at the  
Johns Hopkins Institute of Southern History  
and a specialist in the history of southern  
women.  

In assessing the effect of feminism on  
history, Scott noted that although "femin-  
ist tactics" have affected the atmosphere  
in American intellectual institutions, the  
proportion of women in them hasn't changed  
"since the agitation began."  

In the early 1960s, Scott continued,  
"feminism--long latent--again burst on the  
scene."  

She added that we are only half-way  
through the task of redefining the social  
history of America.  

Today a "considerable number" of young  
women have elected to become historians to  
find out more about themselves and "these  
women have begun to redefine the whole fo-  
cus of historical inquiry."  

"What we don't study reveals as much  
about a culture as what we do," Scott de-  
clared. And American historians--largely  
upper-middle class, white Protestant males--  
haven't studied women until the last few  
years.  

She added that the most striking aspect  
of this new group of women scholars is  
their "extraordinary cooperation with one  
another--this cooperation makes knowledge  
grow faster."  

Scott, a native Georgian, attended Har-  
vard University in the early 1940s and en-  
countered a "pervasive anti-Southernism."  
In reaction to this bias, she determined to  
write her thesis on Southern Progressives.  
And as she perused the records of the South  
since 1890, she "kept stumbling over women"--  
women who were effective leaders and organ-  
izers of such causes as child labor laws.  

Following Scott's lecture the audience  
engaged her in a half-hour question and  
answer period.  

Prof. Mary Turpie, head of the American  
Studies Program, was also at the podium.  

"I was puzzled at first because I hadn't  
encountered women much in my graduate stud-  
ies. Male historians simply hadn't noticed  
women."  

The next evening be January  
31 at 8 p.m. in Murphy Hall Auditorium.  
Carroll Smith Rosenberg, assistant profess-  
or of history and psychiatry at the Univ-  
ersity of Pennsylvania, will discuss the  
history of psychiatric thought.  

Her curiosity aroused, Scott set about  
discovering why Southern women had been so  
intent on remaining "invisible and ladylike"  
while being "quite revolutionary."  

The evening lectures are free and open  
to the public.

Contraception  

A variety of techniques is  
employed to prevent pregnan-  
cy when sexual contact oc-  
curs. These all share the  
label "contraceptive," but  
they differ widely in the  
way they work and in their  
convenience, cost, and ef-  
fectiveness. Table 1 shows  
the degrees of effectiveness  
of the contraceptive methods  
discussed in this manual.  

In this section several  
methods are discussed along  
with their advantages and  
disadvantages. Furthermore,  
some "nonmethods," or tech-  
niques that are employed for  
the purpose of contraception  
but are ineffective, are de-  
scribed.  

The Dilemma of Preplanning  

Frequently high-school-age  
and college-age women are  
just beginning to be sexual-  
ly active. Moreover, they  
are at a time in their lives  
when they often have not ar-  
rived at a stable relation-  
ship and, therefore, may not  
have a single, permanent  
sexual partner. These two  
conditions combine to create  
a situation wherein many wo-  
men do not know whether they  
will be engaging in sexual  
intercourse the following  
month, week, or day. Some-  
times women conclude from  
this uncertainty that they  
should not prepare them-  
selves for, or protect them-  
selves from the results of,  
sexual intercourse, because  
it would somehow indicate  
that they are promiscuous.  
Tied in with this concept is  
the notion that "nice girls"  

don't voluntarily submit to  
sexual relations, that they  
are pressured into them. In  
response to this, one can  
only say that in our society  
the burden of contraception  
typically falls on the fe-  
male and that women who do  
not assume this burden are  
usually women who get preg-  
nant. It is, of course,  
true that a few women may  
engage in intercourse the  
first time without having  
any idea beforehand that in-  
tercourse would take place,  
but after the first sexual  
act if not before, a woman  
should inform and prepare  
herself for future contra-  
ception. Preplanning may be  
temporarily damaging to  
one's self-image, but preg-  
nancies out of wedlock,  
which accounted for one-  
eighth of the children born  
in Seattle in 1968, are of-  
ten damaging to lives in  
more permanent and costly  
ways.  

This is not to imply that  
the burden of contraception  
should always fall on the  
female. Morally, men have  
an obligation to protect  
themselves and their partner  
and they should share the  
effort involved in success-  
ful contraceptive planning.  
(But don't count on it!)  

Birth Control Pills  

"The pill," which is al-  
most 100 percent effective  
when taken as instructed,  
produces a state of pseudo  
(or false) pregnancy in the  
body and thus prevents ovu-  
lation. There are two types  

of oral contraceptives, and  
with each the woman takes  

pills for twenty or twenty-

name derives from the fact  
that for the first fifteen

The sequentials have been

The pill frequently has

It may clear up the complex-

The second type of disad-

Intrauterine Device (IUD)

The intrauterine device is
a loop, ring, coil, or

Diaphragm

The diaphragm is a rubber, dome-shaped device that is inserted into the vagina before intercourse to cover the cervix to prevent sperm's entering it. To be effective, it must be used with a spermicidal cream or jelly, which is placed on both the inside and the outside and around the edge of the diaphragm. The diaphragm must be specially fitted for each woman by a physician. Refitting is sometimes necessary. For effective contraception, refitting is recommended if the original fitting was before or shortly after the loss of virginity, after a miscarriage or childbirth, after an operation, or after a weight gain or loss of at least ten pounds. A diaphragm will last for several years before it must be replaced.

The diaphragm can be inserted up to three to six hours before intercourse and shouldn't be removed until at least six hours after ejaculation. It may be left in place as long as twenty-four hours.

The diaphragm is less effective than the pill or the IUD. Out of every hundred women who use diaphragms for a full year, about twelve are likely to become pregnant. This failure rate, however, is largely due to improper use, and it is reduced to about three per year per hundred women if the diaphragm is carefully used with ample cream or jelly.

The main advantage of the diaphragm is that its use is completely safe. No side effects or long-range health hazards are associated with its use. A further advantage for those who have intercourse only occasionally is that it is used only at the time of intercourse and does not require taking medication for weeks or months when no intercourse is taking place.

The primary disadvantage of the diaphragm is that it must be inserted just before intercourse. Some feel that this action reduces spontaneity of the sex act. Also, it can become dislodged during intercourse. Masters and Johnson found that displacement occurs most often when a coital position other than the face-to-face, male-above position is used.

Condom

The condom, also called the rubber, the prophylactic, or the safety, is a thin rubber or animal-tissue sheath that is worn on the penis during intercourse. When used properly, it is about as effective as the diaphragm. The condom is unrolled onto the erect penis so that there is enough space at the tip for the ejaculate. Reservoir tip condoms are recommended. The penis must be withdrawn from the vagina immediately after the male ejaculates, while it is still erect.

The condom should be carefully removed, and the hands and the penis should be washed, particularly if the couple is going to continue to be in close physical contact.

A major advantage of the condom is that it is the only really effective means of contraception that can be purchased without a prescription. Another advantage is that, if used conscientiously and throughout the entire period of sexual contact, it may provide protection against venereal disease. Condoms are especially suited to those couples who have intercourse only occasionally and do not wish to go to the trouble and the expense of using the pill during periods in which there is no intercourse. Some problems with using the condom can be alleviated by careful selection. Condoms made of animal skin, while slightly more expensive, will minimize loss of sensation to the male. "Wet," or lubricated, condoms that will aid vaginal entry are also available.

A spermicidal cream or jelly can be used both to improve effectiveness and to aid in entry. One of these is applied to the condom after it is put on the penis. It should never be applied to the penis itself, because this could cause the condom to slip off during intercourse. Vaseline and other petroleum jelly should be avoided, because they can cause the rubber to deteriorate and tear.

Although condoms are 98 percent effective when used properly (put on before any penile penetration), even greater protection can be obtained by using the condom in combination with a spermicide, such as foam. This increases the protection to the same level as provided by the pill (100 percent).

Condoms are available at most pharmacies. The price varies by brand and by particular features, e.g., lubrication, and ranges from 30 cents to 75 cents each (10 cents each at Planned Parenthood).

Vaginal Spermicides

All spermicidal contraceptives consist of two components, a spermicide and a nonreactive base. The latter provides most of the substance and functions as a diaphragm to block mechanically. (See Figure 3.) Spermicidal contraceptives include aerosol foams, gels, creams, and suppositories. Each must be used immediately prior to intercourse, the time varying from type to type but ranging from fifteen minutes to one hour preceding intercourse.

Of all the types, the aerosol foam is probably the easiest to use and the least messy. It is also more likely to provide sufficient substance to cover the cervix and thus to prevent conception. Spermicidal suppositories are somewhat less effective. They should not be confused with "feminine hygiene" suppositories, which do not prevent conception.

The major disadvantage of using such contraceptives is that foreplay must be interrupted to apply them. Also, women may not urinate or walk around after they have been applied. Women who prefer to douche after intercourse must wait at least six hours. Spermicides must be reapplied if intercourse is to be repeated.

Vaginal spermicides are somewhat less effective than the diaphragm. Their effectiveness can be improved to 100 percent by using them in combination with the condom.

Spermicides can be purchased without prescription at most pharmacies. Aerosol foams are slightly more expensive than tablets or gels. Monthly contraceptive cost for this method would run between $1 and $...

FEET

by Jan Jirak

A woman's rising conscious-
ness in the liberation move-
ment can be compared to the
instance of someone standing
on your foot. At first you
say, "Excuse me, but you're
standing on my foot." In
rare instances, the offender
will say, "Oh, I'm sorry--"
and get off. More often,
through blindness, he will
say, "No, I'm not--you must
be imagining things." Recog-
nizing his myopia, and trying
to be sympathetic, you say,
"Pardon me, sir, but you are
standing on my foot, and it
does hurt." This exchange
will probably repeat itself
several times with increas-
ing emotion on both sides
until finally the offender
backs off.

Too often the stander's
nose is too high in the air
to let him notice the stand-
ee. This calls for action.
Sometimes you must push him
off. He gets hostile and
complains about how "women's
libbers" make everything in-
to a power struggle. Usual-
ly the support of other wo-
men is needed to get him
off.

Since women have been step-
ped on for so long, many
of them, not knowing any
other state of affairs, ac-
tually think they like it.
They even "invite" such ac-
tions by exposing their feet
and embellishing them until
they look good enough to
walk on. Of course, most
men take the mere presence
of female feet as an invita-
tion.

Women, too, are accomp-
lices in the assault. They
encourage it by treating
themselves and other women
as though they were capable
only of being stepped on.
"Anatomy is destiny"--you
were made with feet, so they
were made to be stepped on.
(Men have feet, too--I won-
der why their anatomy gives
them a different destiny.)

As a result of a long his-
tory of being stepped on,
many women are "flat-footed"
--and as much as they'd like
to walk on their own two
feet, they limp. Even if
their powers haven't been
damaged, everyone thinks
they have; so they have to
walk twice as fast as a man
to keep up with him. Em-
ployers don't trust her to
keep walking; they think
she'll just get married and
go back to being stepped on
again.

And so, until we all get
back on our feet again, I
recommend supportive shoes
to help us walk (women's
organizations) and a little
foot powder (women's publi-
cations) to make the walk
easier.

: Praxis School

Beginning January 17, the
"Socialist Feminism"
The Praxis School will enter
its second quarter. The
class has three parts; "His-
Story," which was covered in
the fall; "Theory" which will
be covered this quarter; and
"Strategy," which will be
tackled in the spring. Each
quarter, and indeed each
class meeting, however, is
open to all.

: Freedom and Justice

We felt that when we were
on more solid ground in the
history and theory of femin-
ism, we could develop a use-
ful strategy to liberate
both women and the oppress-
ed.

For the title "Socialist Fem-
inism" is in earnest: we re-
ject the notion of women
simply receiving a bigger
piece of the American pie;
we want a just society.

Fusion in the Maze
The attempt to fuse femin-
ism and socialism is not as
yet finished, and in most
ways has, as yet, been far
from successful. But the
need remains: our daily ex-
perience can rarely tell us
whether we should be a lib-
eral feminist, or a social-
ist feminist. 

Understanding the varying view of real-
ity each kind of feminism
assumes, and looking at our
own experience in light of
such a view, can help us
find our way through the
maze. It is for this reason
that the theory course
offered this quarter seems
so crucial. Many of us have
read various feminist works
(Beauvoir, Firestone, Greer,
etc.) as they stimulated us
to change our lives, to be-
come feminists at all. Most
of us also have predilections
to various positions on the
political spectrum, usually
from extreme left to
liberal. But few of us have
read these same feminist
works critically and compar-
atively, with an eye to
their broader political per-
spective. It is this task
we plan to begin this quart-
er. As a special treat, we
will also be reading the new
theoretical works put
forward by various women's
groups: The Chicago Women's
Union political statement;
The NAM (New American Move-
ment) sexual politics paper;
papers read at the Socialist
Feminist Conference held
over Thanksgiving in Durham,
N.C.

The Praxis School is spon-
sored by the Mpls. chapter
of the New American Movement,
a new national organization
struggling for democratic
socialism in the U.S. Other
NAM projects include The
North Country Peace Campaign,
a political education and
action project, and The Met-
ropolitan Taskforce, a group
researching and struggling
to change the local balance
of power. The "Socialist
Feminist" class meets Wed-
nesdays from 7:30 to 9:30,
for six weeks. Tuition is
by donation.

Deborah Hertz

As Gloria Steinem pointed out during her  
recent Midwest visit, every woman is a poten-  
tial welfare case, often “just one man away  
from welfare."  

It is an unpleasant economic fact that few  
women can earn enough to support a family  
without financial aid, either from a man or  
from the state. And it is an unpleasant so-  
cial fact that women who are forced to obtain  
the latter form of aid are castigated in pop-  
ular stereotype as "welfare loafers" despite  
the lack of daycare centers and adequate jobs  
that would make employment possible for them.  

Public aid, usually in the form of Aid to  
Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) per-  
mits single mothers to devote themselves to  
child care, but women are stigmatized by re-  
ceipt of such aid. In light of a recent  
University of Minnesota study which proved  
stereotypes of the "welfare mother" to be  
without foundation, GOLD FLOWER interviewed  
three such mothers who described their lives  
on AFDC; their names have been changed in  
the following story to protect their privacy.  

The UM study of 100 randomly selected AFDC  
mothers in Hennepin County revealed that one-  
third of welfare mothers are employed at  
least part-time, and that 80 percent desire  
to work despite the difficulties employment  
would present. Only one recipient in 20 has  
never been married, while three-quarters  
have been married only once. Most welfare  
mothers are white; few have received aid for  
more than three years. The three mothers to  
whom we spoke provide a representative cross-  
section of these women.  

Rhonda is in her early twenties. The mo-  
ther of two pre-school children, she works  
part-time at a day care center. She enjoys  
her job but worries over the children, es-  
pecially her son who demands daily reassur-  
ances of her affection.  

Annie, a 33-year-old former social worker,  
has an infant daughter. Her four older chil-  
dren live with her former husband, but Annie  
sees them frequently. She is active in com-  
munity affairs and is anxious to return to  
work when her child is older.  

Three of Sally's children live at home; her  
oldest son lives in California. Poor health  
has prevented her from working for two years  
but recent surgery, she hopes, has corrected  
her ailments. She too is eager to return to  
work; in her 40 years she has held jobs ran-  
ging from domestic worker to secretary.  

To Rhonda, who separated from her husband  
recently, finances pose the biggest problem.  
"I get $125 for rent, for a two-bedroom fur-  
nished apartment, $60 for food stamps--that  
means about $105 worth of food for the month  
--and about $6 for phone," she says.  

"Of course we get medical and dental care,  
too. But there's no allowance for a damage  
deposit on an apartment, or for deposit or  
installation of a phone. So many people  
that you run into don't understand how much  
-or how little--money we really get.  

"I'm getting bitter," she admits. "It's  
really more hassle to work than sit at home."  

Because of her part-time job, she must pay  
babysitting and carfare costs out of her al-  
ready pinched budget. She estimates that  
she has "about $10 a month" left after she  
pays her family's basic living expenses.  

"I don't even have enough to buy baby as-  
pirin," she sighs.  

Her parents, she says, live far away and  
"don't have money themselves to help." They  
feel that she “shouldn't be living off the  
state, that the kids' father should support  
them." Rhonda's husband is an unemployed  
craftsman.  

Rhonda maintains that she has faced dis-  

Hope, Money Equally Scarce  
For Women on Welfare  
BY PAT MONAGHAN  

crimination because of her financial status.  
"I've called up apartments where they wouldn't  
rent to me because I'm on AFDC. One  
landlady even told me not to report her,”  
she exclaims. "And the neighbors are often  
unsympathetic--they always seem to know if  
you're on AFDC or not.  

"So many people think we're lazy, that we  
don't want anything else," Rhonda says. "I  
have talked to so many welfare mothers, and  
I know this is untrue. Or landlords will  
say, the ‘last AFDC mother I had here was no

She worries about her children and how  
their financial plight will affect them.  

"I'm torn between my children and working.  
I really love my job. I feel useful and  
feel I'm helping the city--but every morning  

"Are you coming home, aren't you, mom?"  

Rhonda's eyes fill as she speaks of her  
son's uncertainty.  

"I understand what the name ‘welfare moth-  
er' means and what you go through. I try my  
best to help people to change their mind,"  
Rhonda says.  

Annie is wryly amused at her current situa-  
tion. "I worked with AFDC mothers for

work with AFDC mothers in 1958."  

She and her second husband separated while

Sally, a middle-aged black mother, lacks

Minneapolis, Minn.  

Dear Editor:  

The December 26 article by  
George Vessey, "More women  
hitchhike; more are assault-  
ed," exposes some often-  
heard biases. Considering  
that U.S. females earn lit-  
tle more than half of what  
males do for regular employ-  
ment, that we are systemati-  
cally discouraged and kept  
from access to the technolo-  
gy of automobile maintain-  
ance (and of weapons by the  
way), and that walking and  
mass transit dangers can  
leave one quite vulnerable,  
is it not surprising young  
women have become only a  
quarter of those resorting  
to hitching to make their  
way around? (I assume an-  
other fourth is not old  
women.)  

Though I've had some won-  
derfully good experiences  
while thumbing (usually a  
neglected aspect), I really  
wouldn't have minded being  
able to own and transport  
myself in the white busi-  
nessman's late model Buick  
in which I had the most  
fearful experience. I've  
read that in a European  
country (Czechoslovakia?)  
those who take the opportun-  
ity to drive cars are ex-  
pected to report the number  
of people to whom they give  
rides for the gas that's  
used. Those here who once  
abuse the privilege of shar-  
ing should be banned from  
the roads, not the needy  
travellers.  

If young women are statis-  
tically more subject to vio-  
lent crimes, the response  
should be training in self-  
defense and in practical  
hitchhiking skills, rather  
than legitimizing them as  
objects of violence. This  
seems to be happening when  
young men see a police cap-  
tain quoted as saying we  
(female hitchhikers) "prac-  
tically invite rape"—by our  
very existence apparently.  
When you see that the  
streets belong to the men,  
cars belong to the men, law  
enforcement also, and news-  
paper stories, you realize  
you have a place someone is  
trying to keep you in.  
"They placed themselves in a  
position where it could hap-  
pen to them," another police  
quote. Let's then name the  
game when I do retreat to  
the safety of one man's side  
—in his car or his house.  
How much protection racket  
and how much free choice in  
an atmosphere of justice and  
equality?  

Marie Kochaver  
2410 10th Ave. S.

A Glad  
Goodbye  

BY SUSAN CUSHMAN  

?  

There are men who muse about making accep-  
tance speeches, but letters of resignation  
are more often the stuff of women's dreams.  

Shortly after my initiation into the ranks  
of scurrying working women, I too adopted a  
characteristic preoccupation. It was not  
"How to beat the Boss," a little too opti-  
mistic for us in those days. Rather, and  

sadly, it was "How to keep the Boss from  
beating you."  

And really, there was only one way - to  
quit. Sure, you might see him on the street  

and be free to grin and disappear. Sure,  
you could do your slave bit for him at the  
office with a manufactured irony, hoping  
that he would notice and be ashamed.  

But these private tactics were too subtle  
to take any effect, and I repeatedly found  
myself imagining that I was not typing his  
letter, but my own, whooping out my glad  
goodbye.  

I didn't get around to actually doing it  
for months. There were bad days, and then  
not-so-bad ones, depending on how fast the  
hours went. When a better job loomed up,  
quite unexpectedly, I found that writing a  
resignation letter took only a few minutes,  
and didn't really resemble my precipitous  
practice runs.  

Riding on a small backwash of conversa-  
tional confidence, I thought I could say my  
parting views best in person, believing that  
a blood and flesh human being would be hard-  
er to ignore than a piece of paper. But it  
all depends on what kind of flesh that human  
being wears; the girl-flesh I was wearing  
did not exactly strike dangerous honesty in-  
to the heart of my well-protected Boss.  

Our Man in Personnel hesitantly accepted  
my request for an exit interview. I had the  
backing of several women who were not leav-  
ing, who hoped I could ease their coming  
days by dredging up their multiple discon-  
tents from the depths of the corporate con-  
science.  

As I was escorted into his office, I deci-  
ded to assume a tentative approach and  
phrased the broad problems of working women  
in the narrower terms of educated women  
within his company.  

I could have spared him my delicacy. One  
thing frontrunning feminists have brought on  
all of us is instant visibility; experienced  
men like this personnel Boss now scent out  
"liberated women" as eagerly as government  
committees once tracked down past, present,  
and future Communists.  

So the statistics flew from his corner of  
the room into mine, followed shortly by apt  
comparisons. We spoke “relatively“ for a  
time. Despite my lowkey opener, he hit me  
with the high notes, sounding out the cor-  
porate defense with rapid-fire trills of in-  

nocence: "We try...you just don't know...  
other companies...this is a business world.  
growth...you can't expect..."  

I sat tight, maybe too tight. I suggested  
that we not talk about the triumphant ap-  
pointment of a woman to head teller after  
she had held the job for five years but not  
the title. Maybe we should consider what  
happened to the average woman in the com-  
pany, I said, as compared to the average  
man.  

Not a valid comparison I was told. Let's  
compare women's positions in our institution  
to those of women in other companies.  

It wasn't as if I hadn't been in circles  
before. But my ears began to churn and my  
throat swallowed when I didn't want it to.  
How could all my forthright intentions and  
painfully acquired knowledge be swallowed so  
effortlessly, without even riling the Boss'  
digestion? We were both in corners of the  

room, but it was easy to see who had trapped  
who.  

I didn't get anywhere that afternoon, and  
I lost a dose of confidence somewhere in  
that predictable contest. We still cannot  
take men on in their own territory, where  
their rules go, and ours stay hidden or mis-  
understood.  

In parting, the Boss said, "I don't have  
to listen to you because you're atypical,  
coming here and talking to me like this."  

I said, equally in parting, "If I had been  
typical, and not come to talk to you, then  
you'd have to listen to me? Is that what  
you mean?"  

"Yes, that's about it."  

And so it was.

Psycho-Historian:

b]

History’s Muse Reveals 19th
Century Women’s Rebellions

BY MARY HASTINGS

The liberation of Clio, muse of history,
and Sigmund Freud has loosened the grasp of
male chauvinism on the study of history and
psychiatry.

Carroll Rosenberg, psychiatrist and historian,
traced the roots of women's rebellion
against male control to Victorian America in
the second lecture of the "Feminism in Amer-
ican Intellectual Life" series.

Rosenberg, a "psycho-historian" special-
izing in 19th century American history,
addressed approximately 150 persons at 8 p.m.
January 31 in the University of Minnesota's
Murphy Hall Auditorium.

She is on the staff of the University of
Pennsylvania.

Rosenberg conceded that she began her
studies as a general social historian, not a
feminist.

But then she "came across the Women's
Moral Reform Society of New York." In the
activities of this Society, Rosenberg found
repudiation of the "male slant" on history
and psychiatry.

Rosenberg declared that the "strength and
tenacity of sexual roles in society" has far-
ranging effects on history and psychoanalytic
theories.

She admitted that this was a "rash" con-
cept in the academic world but the power re-
cumbent in the Women's Moral Reform Society
made her re-evaluate the male point of view
in history.

"Historians have traditionally viewed the
Women's Moral Reform Society as amusing,
Quixotic or neurotic," she noted.

But the organization fulfilled a number
of female needs in the 19th century—a per-
iod of major change in women's roles, when
they were moving to urban areas and begin-
ning to seek roles outside their homes and
families.

The Reform Society was an outgrowth of
the 19th century's philanthropic, religious
movement, which "showed a deep-seated anger
toward men."

The Society offered women an exclusively
female group, which demonstrated female sol-
idarity. It provided a newspaper for comm-
unication among women and allowed them to
"save male sinners," thus giving them an
opportunity to control male behavior.

By the 1840s and 1850s, the Society had
chapters in most states of the Union.

Carroll Rosenberg

With Clio freed from the strictures of
male history, Rosenberg dealt with the lib-
eration of Sigmund Freud and the violence
done to women by the 19th century concept of
acceptable female behavior.

Freud's model for the libido was a male
model, Rosenberg said. "Although his first
and most important patients were women, he
based his theories on his own insights rath-
er than on those of his female patients."
Because of Freud's concepts, for three-quar-
ters of a century women have been viewed as
variants from a male model.

"They have been characterized by passivi-
ty, masochism, narcissism and envy," Rosen-
berg added. "Only through child-bearing and
rearing could women be fulfilled."

Today, psychiatrists are starting to ask
new questions, largely because of the Women's
Movement," she continued.

One of the most important new questions
being asked centers on the question of hys-
teria as female role socialization in the 19th

Hysteria as Protest

century America.

"Hysteria was considered to be a quintessentially female disease, linked to the reproductive system. It had an infinity of symptoms with no physical basis."

Rosenberg suggested that hysteria may have been a protest against the traditional role of women in the Victorian era.

"Women chose to be sick instead of overtly deviant." But doctors displayed a significant level of hostility toward hysterics. "They felt women weren't acting as women should—the doctors were baffled as physicians and men.”

How did hysteria relate to the way 19th century women were raised?

"Many 19th century women reached maturity retaining a child-woman mentality; women were discouraged from displaying competition or mastery of 'male' skills. Overt anger and violence were forbidden to women.

These strictures resulted in women having weak ego structures and forced them into menial functions.

"Such character formation would be considered dysfunctional in a man," Rosenberg noted.

Because of the weak ego structures of many 19th century women, they often adopted hysterical behavior patterns to deal with stress.

Rosenberg dealt with one final issue previously obscured by the male historical viewpoint: The question of intimate friendships

“Choisir” Leaders to Participate in

International Women’s

Women throughout the world will gather in New York City Saturday, March 19 for a solidarity meeting in observance of International Women's Day.

Claude Servan-Schreiber, French journalist for "Le Monde", will attend the meeting. Giselle Halimi, leader of "Choisir", a French abortion rights group, and defender of Marie-Claire Chevalier, will also attend. Marie-Claire is a 16-year-old French girl who was recently tried for undergoing an abortion. Marie-Claire's mother, Michelle Chevalier, a defendant in the trial, will participate in the Solidarity meeting.

Barbara Mutnik, staff member of the Women's National Abortion Action Coalition in New York City, said she expects 500 to 800 persons to attend the meeting.

"Some critics have called these friendships latently homosexual,” Rosenberg said. "But they have not taken 19th century structures into account. A study of such friendships can help us to understand bisexuality and homosexuality."

Rosenberg explained that there was a widespread, culturally accepted behavior pattern of intense friendships between members of the same sex in the 19th century. She focused on intense friendships between women.

"Correspondence could play a large role in women's emotional lives at that time.

An emotionally viable female world emerges from these letters, in which men play only a shadow role." Nineteenth-century women lived in an all-female world and men even more so in an all-male world.

Relations between the sexes were difficult because of sexual taboos.

She noted that the 19th century pattern of intense friendships could help us to view sexuality as a continuum affected by social norms and cultural environment.

"The 19th century permitted easy movement across these sexual boundaries."

Rosenberg interprets such friendships in light of Freud's belief in all people's bisexuality and the sexual nature of all love.

As paradoxical as it may seem, Rosenberg concluded, perhaps the Victorian sexual structure was more supportive of individuals than our sexual mores. The meeting will center on the international struggle for abortion rights. Mutnik said participants can also use the meeting as an opportunity to draw together reports about how the Supreme Court decision on abortion is being implemented throughout the country.

The March 10 meeting will convene in lieu of a previously planned weekend-long International Abortion Tribunal.

deny those tender qualities that char-  
acterize this sign; many a Pisces man  

has escaped into drink, drugs or self-

Saturday nights were B.D.'s most interesting and wild nights. They were the nights she drank the most, danced the most, smoked the most, and laughed the most. She was laughing now, as she sang along with a song blaring from the jukebox.

"Nope, Billy, only my-  
self," she said, almost in-  
audibly, her eyes toward the  
window, gazing into the dark  
night beyond.  

Everyone had left the bar  
by closing time. And B.D.  
put out her last cigarette  
for the night. She automati-  
cally, almost mechanically,  
emptied the ashtrays, then  
rinsed out glasses left on  
the counter. She looked at  
the clock. 2:00 A.M. A  
faintly discernible sigh  
escaped from her as she  
looked around, before walk-  
ing out the door and lock-  
ing it. Another Tuesday  
night at the Seafish was  
over.

Anthropologist Elaine Mor-
gan has written a book de-
tailing her theories about
human evolution. Her ideas
are marked by refreshing
clarity and insightful cur-
iosity. This is in marked
contrast to books by most
male anthropologists, whose
premises seem to be based on
the common preconception that
all results of human evolu-
tion occurred either for the
purpose of making the Mighty
Hunter mightier or to make
the sex object sexier. Mor-
gan states, "The longer I
went on reading his own book
books about himself, the
more I longed to find a vol-
ume that would begin: ‘When
the first ancestor of the hu-
man race descended from the
trees, she had not yet devel-
oped the mighty brain that
was to distinguish her so
sharply from all other spe-
cies.'"

The Descent
of Woman

Morgan explores the one-
sidedness of most anthropo-
logy, beginning with a dis-
cussion of androcentric
speech, and leads into the
manly myths that dominate
the science.

She disputes the idea that
"woman is a distorted ver-
sion of the original blue-
print.”

For example—most male
anthropologists agree that
men became bipedal for pur-
poses of speed in the hunt,
even though quadrupeds run
faster than bipeds. Morgan
maintains that with the
drought of the 12-million
Pliocene era, the prehomin-
ids, former tree-dwellers,
took to the sea for protec-
tion when there were no more
trees to climb. They stood
upright to keep their heads
above water.

The Pliocene era is a
blank page in history; there
is little archeological ev-
idence pointing out where
prehominids were during that
time. Morgan submits that
they became sea dwellers.
There is little evidence be-
cause the weapons, pebbles,
were common on the beach and
worn by the water, and bones
washed to the sea.

Further evidence is that
we lost our furry hair to
aid rapid swimming (we would
have needed it to protect
our tender skin on land).

Also, we developed layers of
subcutaneous fat to keep us
warm in the water (it would
have added to the unbearable
heat on land). Similar hair
and fat evolution can be
seen in other mammals: the
walrus, porpoise, and hippo.

The reason she gives for
long hair remaining on the
human's head is that the
head would be the only part
of the body out of the water
and exposed to the sun; also,
a baby could grasp the mo-
ther's long hair and float
in the water.

Morgan explains why wo-
man developed larger
breasts than their primate
ancestors: with the loss
of chest hair, children
would have nothing to

hang onto. Babies whose
mother's breasts were lar-
ger survived more often,
and that physical trait be-
gan to predominate. We did
not develop larger breasts
to attract the Mighty Hunt-
er!

That idea, as she says,
is "a circular argument...
It's like saying that a wo-
man walks with a wiggle be-
cause this is attractive to
a male. In fact, she only
walks with a wiggle because
her children are so intell-
igent. The necessity of
passing a large-skulled in-
fant's head through her pel-
vic ring has prevented her
skeleton from adapting to
bipedalism quite as grace-
fully as that of her bro-
thers; and males only find
this defect attractive be-
cause they associate it with
femininity."

Other traits developed as
our aquatic visit length-
ened: webbing between fin-
gers and toes (we still have
vestigial webbing between
thumb and forefinger). Our
noses became streamlined to
keep out excess water. We
developed tear glands to

secrete salt. The ability
to frown began to protect our
eyes from the glare of
the sun on the water. 
Something else happened—

we developed large buttocks.
Contrary to androcentric
thinking, it was not for the
purpose of sexual attraction.
Females would sit on the
beach to nurse their babies.
The fatty tissue built up
and the vaginal orifice
moved in and forward for
protection from the sand.
This point introduces
three interesting chapters
in the book: orgasm, love,
and aggression. Morgan says
that as the buttocks built
up, the male could no longer
reach the vagina in the nor-
mal rear-mounting position.
In order to achieve coitus,
he had to switch to a front-
al approach. This had two
immediate consequences: the
female was terrified; and
she was unable to reach or-
gasm. Her body was designed
for sexual approaches from
the rear; a frontal approach
was understood as an attack.
Her sexual initiative was
met by violence and she was
confused.

Also, the penis was no
longer entering the vagina
at the best angle to
"scratch the itch," and she
experienced sexual frustra-
tion for the first time.
The third result of the
switch to the frontal ap-
proach: sex and aggression
became linked in the human
mind. For the male, sex
became associated with ag-
gression, for the female,
with terror. Also, more
aggressive males had more
offspring since they
achieved coitus more often,
and aggression spread in
the species.

Morgan concludes her book
with several chapters in
which she traces facts of
everyday life to prehistory
things like race memory,
the development of speech,
sex roles, the Tarzan myth,
and differences in politi-
cal inclinations of the
sexes. The last chapter
sums it all up with her
“state of the movement"
evaluation. She ends on a
hopeful note:

A DIVINE COMEDY .......

I hear lots of men saying  
there's no humor in the wo-  
men's movement. They seem  
to think that when a woman  
becomes a feminist, she for-  
gets how to laugh.  

That propaganda is another  
boring example of male opaci-  
ty and American double-think.  
It is, in fact, the women's  
movement that allows us to  
laugh. Men who mourn the  
dearth of humor are too dense  
to know when they're being  
laughed at.  

In the old days before the  
second wave, women had one  
alternative to choose from in  
responding to her situation:  
insanity. Thinking women did  
go insane: Sylvia Plath at  
one extreme, and women who  
resigned themselves to the  
quiet madness of everyday  
life at the other. Psycholo-  
gists still accord qualities  
of an unbalanced person to a  
"normal woman"—dependence,  
weakness. Now, the women's  
movement encourages a second  
alternative: laughter.  

Humor lies in the incongru-  
ity of situations. During a  
recent TV documentary on H.L.  
Mencken the narrator said,  
"Sally's (the college English  
professor Mencken married) in-  
telligence was very real—but  
so was her femininity!" Some  
jokes, such as the poster of  
Golda Meir entitled "But can  
she type?" take a sadly com-  
mon situation and carry its  
incongruity one step further  
into humor. Everyone knows  
women who hold master's deg-  
rees plus years of experience  

But can she type?  

who are stuck in secretarial  
positions. The joke about  
the want ad requesting a per-  
son who can walk on water and  
type 60 words per minute is  
by now an old one. Perhaps  
if males do not think those  
jokes are funny it is because  
they see no incongruity in  
those situations; after all,  
drudge work is woman's natur-  
al domain no matter how qual-  
ified she is.  

“Hire him.  
He’s got great legs.”  

Sometimes feminist humor  
ridicules situations common  
to women. By placing a male  
in a woman's situation, we  
see how ludicrous the situa-  

tion is. For example, the  
"Hire him. He's got great  
legs." poster. A similar ex-  

ample was aired on the Mary  
Tyler Moore show recently.  
Resident oaf Ted Baxter wore  
a pair of platform shoes  
which gave him a precarious  
and awkward walk. The scene  
was the funniest of the whole  
show. I wonder how many peo-  
ple realized that it's just  
as ridiculous for women to  
wear such handicapping cloth-  
es—and by extension, dress-  
es, girdles (I saw an ad for  
girdles the other day, so I  
assume some women still wear  
them!) and to practice such  
self-mutilation as shaving  
and eyebrow-tweezing.  

"If Michelangelo had been  
a girl, her mother might have  
said, 'You draw nicely, dear.  
Now wash the shirts, give the  
baby his dinner, and sweep  
the kitchen for me, there's  
a good girl.'"  

Laughter is Powerful  

Men know the power of laugh-  
ter and have used it against  
women for centuries, making  
us ashamed of things to which  
no shame should be attached  
to keep us insecure and pow-  
erless. They made us ashamed  
of being strong, of being in-  
dependent, of having hair un-  
der our arms. Now that we  
have self-respect, we no long  
er laugh at those things. We  
do not admire the self-depre-  
cation of Lucille Ball, but  
turn rather to Lily Tomlin,  
who only does characters who  
like and respect themselves.  

Laughter is used as a wea-  
pon in the women's movement,  
too, to strip men of that mys-  
tical aura of power with  
which they surround themselv-  
es. A group of women talked  
recently about the difficulty  
of getting jobs, the insin-  
cerity of the business world,  
the way revealing one's true  
self would preclude any pos-  
sibility of employment. The  
discussion generated into a  
hilarious listing of "How not  
to get a job." The ideas  
ranged from wearing jeans to  
the interview to revealing  
one's involvement in radical  
feminism, each suggestion  
funnier and truer than the  
last. Finally a quiet woman  
said, "Just take a copy of  
Lesbian Nation with you to  
the interview—you'd never  
get hired!"  

This comment would not be  
funny if it were not based on  
some very tragic facts: the  
stifling conformity of busi-  
ness and the blanket practice  
of discrimination against  
gays.  

On the other hand, this  
joke makes us forget for a  
moment the excessive power  
personnel recruiters wield  
and puts them into proper per-  
spective. You can't help  
seeing, in your mind's eye,  

a self-important, blue-suited  
male, mouth open, eyes roll-  
ing, and for once, speechless.  

And finally, if men cannot  
see beyond their usually sim-  
ple-minded and often cruel  
definitions of humor to the  
more mature women's humor, I  
must remind them that the  
women's movement was born of  
a truly unhappy situation.  

It is a serious attempt to  
eradicate unnecessary misery  
from human life. There is  
nothing funny about being  
oppressed.”

The National Black Feminist  
Organization held its first  
meeting in New York City in  
December. The information  
below expresses viewpoints  
from that conference.  

Statement  
of Purpose  

The distorted male-dominated  
media image of the Women's  
Liberation Movement has  
clouded the vital and revol-  
utionary importance of this  
movement to Third World wo-  
men, especially Black women.  
The Movement has been char-  
acterized as the exclusive  
property of so-called "white  
middle class" women and any  
Black women seen involved in  
this movement have been seen  
as "selling out," "dividing  
the race" and an assortment  
of nonsensical epithets.  
Black Feminists resent these  
charges and have therefore  
established THE NATIONAL  
BLACK FEMINIST ORGANIZATION,  
in order to address ourselves  
to the particular and speci-  
fic needs of the larger, but  
almost cast aside half of the  
Black race in Amerikka, the  
Black Woman.  

Black women have suffered  
cruelly in this society from  
living the phenomenon of  
being Black and female, in a  
country that is both racist  
and sexist. There has been  
very little real examination  
of the damage it has caused  
on the lives and on the minds  
of Black women. Because we  
live in a patriarchy, we have  
allowed a premium to be put  
on Black male suffering. No  
one of us would minimize the  
pain or hardship or the cruel  
and inhumane treatment ex-  
perienced by the Black man.  
But history, past or present,  
rarely deals with the mali-  

cious abuse put upon Black  
women. We were seen as  
breeders by the master; de-  
spised and historically po-  
larized from/by the master's  
wife; and looked upon as  
castrators by our lovers and  
husbands. The Black woman  

has had to be strong, yet we  
are persecuted for having  

survived. We have been  
called "matriarchs" by white  
racists and Black nation-  
alists; we have virtually no  
positive self-images to vali-  
date our existence. Black  
women want to be proud, dig-  
nified and free from all  
those false definitions of  
beauty and womanhood that  
are unrealistic and unnatur-  
al. We, not white men or  
Black men, must define our  
own self-image as Black wo-  
men and not fall into the  
mistake of being placed upon  
the pedestal—which is even  
being rejected by white wo-  
men. It has been hard for  
Black women to emerge from  
the myriad of distorted imag-  
es that have portrayed us as  
grinning Beulahs, castrating  
Sapphires and pancake box  
Jemimahs. As Black Femin-  
ists we realized the need to  
establish ourselves as an  
independent Black Feminist  
organization. Our above  
ground presence will lend  
enormous credibility to the  
current Women's Liberation  
Movement, which unfortunate-  

ly is not seen as the  

serious political and econom-  
ic revolutionary force that  
it is. We will strengthen  
the current efforts of the  
Black Liberation struggle in  
this country by encouraging  
all of the talents and crea-  
tivities of Black women to  
emerge, strong and beautiful,  
not to feel guilty or divis-  
ive, and assume positions of  
leadership and honor in the  
Black community. We will  
encourage the Black communi-  
ty to stop falling into the  
trap of the white male Left,  
utilizing women only in terms  
of domestic or servile needs.  
We will continue to remind  
the Black Liberation Movement  
that there can't be libera-  
tion for half the race. We  
must together, as a people,  
work to eliminate racism from  
without the Black community  
which is trying to destroy us  
as an entire people, but we  
must remember that sexism is  
destroying and crippling us  
from within.

New Tomorrow

Audrey Colom Speaks  
To Minnesota Women’s

BY SHIRLEY HEYER  

Audrey Colom, vice chair of the National  
Women's Political Caucus, spoke on the “Myth  
of Black Women and Feminism," at the annual  
meeting of the Minnesota Women's Political  
Caucus at Hamline University Nov. 17.  

"Feminist issues are clearly relevant to  
us," she said. "Our double jeopardy--based  
on sex and race--places us at the bottom.  

"For example, the annual median income for  
individuals places black women at the  
bottom, white women third, black males sec-  
ond, and white males at the top."  

In the struggle for equal rights, she  
said, "We need to avoid the 'd&c' (divide  
and conquer) tactic.  

"The civil rights movement and the femin-  
ist movement are addressing the white male  
club--with all women and minority men at the  
bottom. We, all women and minority men, are  
the majority in this country."  

The “myth” of black women and feminism,  
Ms. Colom said, is caused largely by false  
stereotypes, many of which are perpetuated  
by the media. These stereotypes are, she  
said:  

1) trying to "divide our loyalties.  

Telling us that we are black first and  
women second, or as Margaret Sloan, black  
feminist from Chicago, said, ‘That means on  
Mondays through Wednesdays they'll mess you  
over because you're female and Thursdays  
through Sundays they'll mess you over be-  
cause you're black."  

2) "the women's movement is a middle-class  
movement. Some of us accept the stereotype  
that the women's liberation movement is  
‘middle-class women trying to escape the  
home.' We don't need to be liberated to escape  
the home. Work in the home and child care  
are valid. Who says liberation is getting  
up at five, taking care of the family, going  
to a job and then coming home to take care  
of the family again? This is not women's  
liberation."  

3) "the black woman's place is behind her  
man, pushing him into his manhood. ...32%  
of black families are headed by women.  
Where are the men they are supposed to push  
into manhood? Don't lay the emasculation of  
black men on us black women. Bobby Seale  
said, 'Real manhood is not the subjugation  
of anyone.'"  

4) "this is a white/racist women's move-  
ment. A media cliché. The women's movement  
is actually as diverse as the black movement  
is. Just as there are sexists in the black  
liberation movement, there are racists in  
the women's liberation movement.  

"We need the Coalitions, such as the one  
between the Urban Coalition and NOW in the  
boycott against General Mills, or the action

(A TRULY ORGANIC ACCUMULATION)  
by Monica Manning  

A naked woman laying on her side showing large curvy hips, long legs split from not touching and a sphere in her crotch caught my eye. The sphere held  

New York City and the woman had a smile on her lovely face. A sense of admiration swelled within me as I continued to stare at the drawing performed with red ink and black felt tip pen. Ah, the walls of women's rooms never cease to amaze me. I spotted this particular drawing at the Black Forest Inn along with memorable verse such as,  
'Fuck Indians  
that's what whites

sisters unite  
brothers let's fuck

Flash, flash - the awareness of words on bathroom walls.  

I remember a time I was placated upon the toilet in that place. The walls were sterile white with fresh paint. I  

was not only constipated, but mortified in my search for something to read because there was nothing. As I reached for the T.P. I noticed a scrawl. My mortification turned to gratification as I read 'what happened to all my  

reading material?' That satiated me like a good grunt... bringing to mind another public bathroom.  

In July of 1973 on a hopping Friday evening I wandered into the Dibbo Hotel on Main Street in Hudson, Wisconsin to hear a friend play music. Time was about 7:30 p.m. as I entered the can to make my bladder gladder. The walls were barren so I made my way to  

the bar. There was a smoky aura out there but I stayed true and listened to the music. Round about closing time (1:00 a.m.) I ventured back into the head finding the walls plastered with jabberwocky. Since I was hassled by the local police to get my rear in gear I didn't have time to read it all so I took note of the biggest boldest writing which was glaring on the door leading out. DEAD NIGGERS SUCK. Such was the consciousness of the Dibbo. My friend got sick on the way home.  

Seems to me that women's poddies have been the place to let it all hang out. Brenners Pub is a good example.  

'Lesbians! women unite, Gay  

is good.  

Love is what you feel not who

(Yeah I think he's pretty good too)' or 'Why do all these good gay women write on anonymous bathroom walls? I wish I could meet you all / Lesbian love is beautiful... if it's so beautiful then why is it on a wall?)  

I wonder if Venus kept herself above arousal or did she merely rain her assessments downward as a lady cleaning a toilet may lift her eyes to the mixture of madness gushing forth a streamlined flush of mastered manure mixing feces with faces.  

Once when I was sipping hot cider in the Riverside Cafe the natural urge got to me so I strolled through the kitchen to a communal toilet. The surrounding walls were confining but not the writing. 'Rejoice Sisters  

God is a beautiful  

black lesbian'  

retort and he's dead!'
