THE HOUSE OF ELIMA

BY MARY ELLEN SHAW

HE SAYS: There haven't been any women of  
real genius.

SHE SAYS: You never see the mountain rising  
up behind your back.

"Elima" is a new magazine of poetry, jour-  
nals and reviews edited by Annie Gottlieb.  
An elima, she explains, is a house in a  
pygmy tribe set aside for the young girl/  
woman just unfolding into maturity. All of  
the women in the village, old and young,  
join together to sing and celebrate; the old-  
er women teaching lessons of an adult life.  
"Day after day, night after night, the elima  
house resounds with the throaty contralto of  
the older women and the high, piping voices  
of the youngest. It is a time of gladness  
and happiness, not for the women alone but  
for the whole people."

In “Elima," the same singing, the same  
unfolding takes place. The women writers  
speak from different backgrounds and decades:

. practiced poets of vision and sparse words;  
young poets raising up words like torches;  
women exploring the fragments of their  
childhoods and collisions with society.  
“Elima" incorporates journals, letters,  
poems and sympathetic quotes from estab-  
lished (male) literature. The magazine em-  
phasizes communicating what the experience  
of women has been, experimenting and prob-  
ing new ways of writing, and the process of  
fully-sexed, adult and potent.

In future issues, I would like to see some  
variety in format. The typesetting is  
blocked and unvaried, not inviting immediate  
or easy access. Another thing to look for-  
ward to is the tightening up of style. Work  
which is a beginning and exploration is nec-  
essary, but can't be kept up forever. If it  
were, it might put the magazine in that un-  
comfortable position so familiar to women's  
work, i.e., as an auxiliary and interesting  
sideline, but nothing to be taken seriously.  
There is a danger, on one hand, in bending  
too far to outside pressure, thus losing vi-  
tality and originality. But there is a  
greater danger, on the other hand, in not being  
as tough and demanding toward each other  
as the world will be.

There is an earthiness about much of the  
work, a focus, contact with the landscape on  
intimate, if sometimes brutal, terms. Tex-  
tures, plant life, paints, pots, glass, me-  
tal, body, animal. A child in Mexico with  
ulcerated eyes. The reality of bare walls  
in a New York prison cell, and the real wo-  

men who talked and fought and loved and  
lived there.

The journal fragments are personal and un-  
selfconscious. Each of them transfers a per-  
sonality, a person; someone known from years  
of late night word-fests; or that familiar  
voice in every woman's mind which tallies  
lists of betrayals and confusion. There is  

a concern with girlhood, of recreating the  

past to see what was forced, wheedled and  
conned; what was wasted and thrown away;  
what might have been possible.

Each poet gives us a handful of her voice.  
Styles and concerns vary, and there is a de-  
liberate range of deftness and facility.

Juli Loesch is flamboyant, outre, right-on  
and gentle:

Opened by a mailed fist  

on the carapace  
Opened by a  
tender craziness  
We open and open  

Roa Lynn has a terse, finely-sharpened  
bitterness, and she, too, is gentle:

So over the years  

The whole female world fragilely falls  

Into two groups, those that have, and  
those that haven't  

Got the courage to pierce their ears; a  
little American girl  

From Pittsburgh unexpectedly thrust her  
freckled cheek forward.

April Murphy speaks body-talk and cele-  
brates the rarely spoken-of phenomenon of  
active female sexuality:

lithe animal of my center, playful as an  

otter with her inside-out body.

Carol Muske speaks with a bony vividness.  
She uses images in a private, almost mythic  
vision:

My body moves bladelike through mirrors  

My head turns, a spool winding down  

To the last great ring of bone at the  

throat.

In this dark season  

I have grown a rough coat for winter  
Feel my hand budding with hardware  
My sweet smile  

Moving quiet through stone  

Like a new species.

There is a review of "Women and Madness."  
Marge Piercy is the reviewer; she is urgent  
and a bit frightening: what is being built/  
born/explored has to be done for survival.  
"Women can't yet believe we can be enhanced  
and protected by the achievements of any  
other women." "Women must feed one another  
emotionally, sexually, and intellectually,  
must support one another if the loser's  
cycle is to be broken.

I'm not sure absolute retreat and exile  
are necessary, but there is surely a need  
for a time of withdrawal and renewal. The  
house of elima is a good place to start;  
trading stories and songs, sharing harsh  
lessons if necessary, learning the duties  
and joyous freedom of maturity. A sounding  
out, a stretching, a testing begins here, as  
well as a ripening sense of community.

Before the door opens, the house of elima  
will rock and rock with laughter and song -  
and loud anger. And when the door does  
open, we will emerge in strength with full  
hands.

Sally Hughes Makes Student  
Government ‘Women’s Work’

I've grown accustomed to positing all my  
hopes for female equality and a humane soc-  
iety in terms of a very distant future.  
Indeed, I've grown rather sour on occasion  
when I concede that only the dust of my sis-  
ters and I will witness a feminist/human  
millennium.

But in the midst of my latest pessimism, I  
met Sally Hughes, who is a living measure of  
the progress women have made in the past 10  
years.

She is a freshman at Metropolitan Commun-  
ity College, its first female Student Senate  
President and a leader of a late-February  
student protest against poor facilities and  
an unresponsive administration.

Breach of the Peace

In that protest, Sally was arrested for  
"breach of the peace" and "placing injurious  
materials in the streets."

My interest was piqued at the outset—un-  
accustomed as I am to newspaper photos of  
young women being hauled off by police as  
leaders of protests. And upon reading the  
"Minneapolis Tribune's" account of the dem-  
onstration, so much remained unsaid that I  
phoned Sally for an interview.

She readily agreed and a day later I  
arrived at Metropolitan's Memorial Hall,  
a building whose WPA drabness has been only  
slightly relieved by neo-psychedelic wall  
colors.

I presented myself at the basement-level  
Student Senate office, expecting to find one  
or two students at their leisure. But I  
walked into a working organization's office.

Seven or eight men and women were gathered  
around a desk and I caught conversational  
tailings: "...I told him we'd completed  
that ..." "I've set up a meeting with them  
on Monday..." "The parking lot's been  
taken care of...."

In another corner of the room two young  
women removed scarves and gloves and attend-  
ed to an infant.

I realized I had encountered people ser-  
iously involved in their work and, conscious  
of my interruption, asked for Sally Hughes.

"She's right there..." indicating the wo-  
man holding the baby.

She gave the child to her sister and led  
me to the quietest corner of the office.

Sally is tall and sturdily slender, her  
long, ash-brown hair hangs straight. She  
speaks directly and naturally.

"There has been a real communication ga-  
p between the administration and students,"  
she said, explaining the basis of last  
month's protest.

To dramatize their plight, 30 to 40 stu-  
dents gathered in front of the college be-  
fore dawn on February 1.

Sally and the other demonstrators handed  
out informational leaflets and dragged sev-  
eral of the cafeteria's uncomfortable-look-  
ing table-stool units onto the walks to  
illustrate their claims of poor facilities.

Police arrived shortly after the demonstra-  
tion began. "At first they were directing  
traffic out of the area," Sally explained.

“Swooped Up”

But when the tables and stools appeared, a  
struggle ensued.

"We had a lot more participation once  
the police came," Sally said. Evidently the  
police recognized her as a central figure  
in the demonstration.

"I heard them yell, 'Get her.' It was  
really strange the way they swooped me up."

and Arrested

She was the only student arrested. She  
has retained an attorney to defend her and,  
at this writing, is scheduled to appear in  
court.

However, Sally said she understood that  
Metropolitan's president, Howard Bergstrom,  
would negotiate with the District Attorney  
to drop charges against her. Bergstrom will

Research into eligibility re-

The students also demanded

The fact that so many of the demands had

Taking Your Chances

by Susan Cushman

When I was growing up my father had a ram-
rod policy about young women and travel. He
combined the interests of respectability and
safety in his edict that my sisters and I
could not travel alone or with female
friends because that was dangerous. We also
could not travel with male friends for fear
of losing our real or figurative virginity.
In short, trips were to be made with our
parents or not at all.

Many parents enforced similar stifling
rules which drastically curtailed our young
movements. Colleges and universities fol-
lowed the parental lead in establishing
hours for women while the men did as they
liked. “In the small midwestern town where
I was in undergraduate school, the dean of
women warned us many times about the "tran-
sient perverts" who unaccountably stalked
the cornfields. She advised us to have es-
corts after sundown, yet for four years I
took a nightly walk expressly for the soli-
tude, without encountering anything more
than an occasional overzealous dog.

It took a few months in a truly dangerous
city (St. Louis) for me to realize that
these authority figures had been right about
one thing - women are favorite targets of
most crimes. The question is what to do
about it. Each individual, it seems, must
find a comfortable balance between personal
safety and personal freedom. If the danger
is greater for a given group of people, the
freedom must apparently shrink to maintain
comparable survival odds.

A recently published book supports this
conclusion while at the same time offering
some useful suggestions for increasing fe-
male safety without seriously limiting li-
berty. "Lady Beware" by Peter Arnold (Dou-
bleday, 182 pages, $5.95) is written in a
somewhat annoying fashion, frequently speci-
fying times when a woman is alone as times
when "your man" is away. Nevertheless, the
book is valuable because it explicitly des-
cribes crimes against women and possible
preventative measures.

Some of these measures, such as installing
effective locks, can be taken infrequently
and require just one burst of determination
and concern. Others necessitate a change in
daily habits. Arnold presents everyday ways
of carrying a purse so as to discourage
purse snatchers, leaving an apartment so as
to discourage burglars, and walking so as to
discourage prospective muggers or rapists.

Perhaps the most helpful advice comes from
convicted men who describe their selective
attitudes when choosing victims. In many
cases the enticing combination is solitude
and preoccupation - a woman alone who does
not appear to be paying attention to her
surroundings. By making herself an easy
mark, a woman seemingly invites the most
simplistic and even half-hearted crimes.

The solution, of course, is not to cower
indoors with a cadre of male protectors.
Rather, each woman should analyze the way
she lives and then make that particular way
as safe as possible. If you frequently walk
at night, you'll be safer if you carry a po-
lice whistle. If you get around mostly by
car, it's a good idea to check the back seat
floor before you get in and to keep your
doors locked while driving to protect your-
self from unwanted passengers. Habits like
these improve your safety without interfer-
ing with your movements or compromising your
independence.

If you do suspect that someone is sizing
you up in an unfriendly manner, don't be re-
luctant to do something about it before you
are proved right. Policewomen who were
interviewed in "Lady Beware" agree that most
women who are attacked have a premonition
of danger but don't do anything about it.
Alertness doesn't help if women don't act
decisively on their perceptions. Stepping
into a lighted store or out of an uncomfor-
tably intimate elevator won't implicate a
possibly innocent person and can perhaps
save you a bad experience.

Chances

Another point that policewomen make is  
that forethought is in itself a safety  
measure. "A woman who never thought about  
being mugged or raped would be in great  
trouble if it happened. If a woman just one  
time thinks, "What if a man attacked me?”  
she'd be much safer. Just so she has some-  
thing to fall back on.

"If you've thought about it before, your  
thought will flash into your mind. If you  
haven't thought about it before, nothing  
will come to mind and you'll do nothing or  
you'll panic."

Once a woman is unavoidably in a danger-  
ous situation, she can often escape if she  
stays calm. Attackers usually have the  
edge because they take their victims by  
surprise. But many criminals underestimate  
female resources and can be surprised in  
turn quite easily.

With an unarmed attacker, the best method  
is probably to fight back immediately, mak-  
ing as much noise as possible. Since most  
men don't expect women to struggle seriously  
and women in danger are usually quite  
strong, the chances of escaping are reason-  
ably good.

A woman confronted by an armed assailant is  
better off pretending to comply with him un-  
til a chance for escape opens up. The im-  
portant thing is to remain calm enough to  
seize whatever opportunities are offered.

"Lady Beware" describes these situations  
and many others, following the "what if" for-  
mat suggested by one victim.

Handbooks can be distasteful, because they can make it seem  
as if genuine safety is only for fanatics  
who are willing to devote their lives to it.  
"Lady Beware" recognizes that safety is a  
desirable condition of life, but not the  
whole point of it. Arnold presents a range  
of preventative measures so that a reader  
can choose the ones that suit her. For  
instance, he starts out a chapter on hitch-  
hiking by saying women should never do it,  
and then proceeds to discuss women thumbing  
it, on the assumption that many nevertheless  
will. This kind of realism makes the book  
palatable.

We can't avoid taking chances in our daily  
lives and probably don't want to. But we  
should have a pretty fair idea of what  
chances we do take and how to handle the  
consequences. A book like "Lady Beware"  
can help.

Battles Won

PSYCHOLOGY and WOMEN

AT MARSHALL 'U' HIGH SCHOOL

Dr. Lois Erickson at the
University of Minnesota has
developed a curriculum to pro
mote psychological maturity
in women using a developmental
framework derived from the
theories of Jane Loevinger
and Lawrence Kohlberg.

Loevinger's theory postulates
that an individual's ego develops
from a young child's differentiation
between self and non-self
through various stages of emotional
and social development to a possible
"integrated" stage in which complexity
of thought, perception of choices,
respect for others' autonomy, and a
valuing of justice are predominate.
Kohlberg's position is that moral
development progresses along stages
of growth which increasingly integrate
the concept of justice—from a
"what's in it for me" instrumental
hedonism orientation toward a possible
stage of moral decision-making based
on principles of universal justice.
Thus, they both see human growth as
progressing along stages—which direc-
tion can provide a goal for education.

This goal, movement along the
developmental stages of growth has
become the major objective in Erickson's
curriculum for women.

Extensive research indicates that
American men are more likely to reach
higher stages of development than
American women. Most women remain
on stage 3, social conforming orientation,
while about four times as many men
move ahead toward the more complex
modes of thought. Of importance, it has
been found that no difference in moral
maturity exists between the sexes until
adolescence, at which time girls plateau
in psychological growth while boys
continue the movement toward higher
stages.

Dr. Erickson said several studies
demonstrate that girls "sell out" their
competency motivation sometime in high
school and get anchored in a lifestyle
that reinforces the middle stages of
growth, the social compromising stage.
The theories acknowledge this inconsistency
will lead to an erosion of women's maturity,
and the research bears this out.

"We've talked about it so long, now we
must do something about it!" is Erickson's
position.

The curriculum model developed by
Erickson used a "Learning Psychology
by doing psychology" format first set
forth by John Dewey. Field interviewing
of girls and women across the life span
provided a means of viewing the process
of female development through different
ages, stages, and tasks. In the seminar
sessions the high school women reflected
about and integrated their interview data
and also focused on current articles on
the women's movement and related literary
works. A continuous thru-way focus was
maintained between the interview experiences,
the works of literature, and the examination
of "the self." Multiple assessments were
run on the class and on the Loevinger
measures of ego maturity and on the Kohlberg
measure of moral maturity.

This curriculum is the first in a series
of classes being developed to examine
sex roles and personal growth. A two-person
relationship class and a parenting class
(both with males) are now being piloted
and researched.

"Talk of American Spacewomen

Makes Me Sick”

Well, what do you know?

The National Aeronautics and  
Space Administration (NASA)  
recently announced that women  
appear no less able than men,  
physiologically, to withstand  
the rigors of space flight.

This remarkable fact was an-  
nounced following five weeks  
of testing eight Air Force  
nurses at NASA's Ames Re-  
search Center.

According to an account from  
the “Los Angeles Times,” NASA  
spokesmen stressed that these  
results "should not be taken  
as a back door commitment to  
put women into orbit, however."

No, the facts were just spun  
around cathode ray tubes and  
the story broadcast over ra-  
dio and television and clack-  
ed over wire service tele-  
types. You see, these tests de-  
termining the fitness of women  
as astronauts have already  
been run—14 years ago.

Thirteen women, several with  
more credentials than John  
Glenn and Scott Carpenter,  
were tested and found to be  
superior candidates for the  
astronaut program. Twelve  
more were slated for testing.  
But all have turned to other  
jobs after waiting for the  
space program to make use of  
their training, talents, and  
energies.

This latest "women are mak-  
ing progress" smoke screen  
was beautiful. The lovely  
Air Force cuties lined up to  
be panned by the television  
cameras—slowly. Yep, they  
were treated just like the  
guys and even did without sex  
during the five-week testing.  
And they all were single.

Interestingly, the publicity  
came after a well-done cover  
article on the first women  
astronaut candidates publish-  
ed in "MS" magazine last  
September. It was even more  
interesting that no one men-  
tioned the original women  
astronaut candidates in the  
latest coverage of women's  
progress.

By Heidi Reidel!

But women's news is seldom  
covered in detail by mass  
media, so what is well done  
is worth repeating.

Joan McCullough wrote of  
"The 13 who were left behind"  
in September's "MS," recount-  
ing the testing of women be-  
gun in 1959.

We all know about one small  
step for man and recognize  
the names, John Glenn, Neil  
Armstrong, Scott Carpenter.  
But what about Jerrie Cobb?

In 1959 Cobb had logged  
10,000 hours in the air,  
more than any other candidate  
being tested at that time. Cobb  
was the woman whose test re-  
sults would determine wheth-  
er other women would be test-  
ed. Her test results were  
exceptional and twelve other  
women were tested—

They, too, were found to be  
exceptionally qualified can-  
didates. In some ways, they  
were superior to men, accord-  
ing to McCullough's article;  
they weighed less on the av-  
erage, a potential saving of  
$1,000 a pound for cargo and  
human weight, for they also  
consumed less food and oxygen  
and could use a smaller cap-  
sule. They were more radi-  
ation-resistant, less prone  
to heart attack, and more dur-  
able in the event of heat,  
pain, noise, and loneliness.

Despite the flying color  
test results, NASA abruptly  
halted testing in July of  
1971, after 13 of the slated  
25 had been tested.

NASA had given no warning,  
no explanation, and no comment.

The women took the matter up  
with a specially convened  
Congressional subcommittee.  
The hearing lasted two days,  
with one NASA spokesman say-  
ing, "Talk of American space-  
women makes me sick to my  
stomach," and others insisting  
the program would be impeded  
if they were forced to in-  
clude women.

And John Glenn, for whom  
qualification regulations had  
been waived, said magnanimous-  
ly, "If we found women who  
could prove that they had  
more capabilities than the  
men, we'd welcome them aboard  
with open arms."

Once again women had to be  
more equal to be equal and the  
subcommittee admonished the  
"good ladies" to be patient.

Fourteen years have stretched  
on. Hans Mark, presently  
directing NASA's Ames Research  
Center, says, "So far we see  
no reason to believe there  
are any inherent problems to  
women flying in space." It is  
a little hard to swallow. And  
the American taxpayer should  
find that kind of repetitive  
song and dance intolerable as  
well.

These recently tested Air  
Force nurse volunteers are be-  
ing used to set medical stan-  
dards for women who may be  
included on American Space  
shuttles in the 1980s.

NASA administrator, Chuck  
Berry, told a recent space  
medicine conference, "For a  
long-duration flight such as  
to Mars, the crews would be  
confined inside their space-  
craft for nearly a year.  
With so much time on their  
hands, they'd react like oth-  
er normal human beings; they  
would want sexual diversion.  
It is therefore unrealistic  
to plan future flights with-  
out coming to grips with the  
problem of women. Naturally,  
the women would be fully-op-  
erational crew members...not  
only there for sex."

Gotcha, Mr. Berry. Over and out.

Malvina Reynolds is a songwriter with an  
active conscience and a perpetual overabun-  
dance of material. "I have to fight off sub-  
jects," she says. "People are always sug-  
gesting them to me. ‘Have you written any-  
thing about the Aswan Dam?' It bugs me;  
they don't know anything about songwriting."  

When I met Malvina at the Walker Art Cen-  
ter last month, she had just given in to the  
urge to write about Watergate. Having re-  
sisted the issue for months because "you  
can't satirize the satire," she had suddenly  
been taken by the phrase, “meet me at the  
Watergate." Soon she was singing the new  
song over the telephone to Walter Cronkite,  
and a few days later, appeared with it on  
the CBS Evening News.  

As with the Watergate song, "Songwriting  
happens when it happens." Most often, she  
is struck by something she sees or hears and  
the song forms on the spot.  

"I can't write sitting down quietly in a  
room. Usually I'm moving, riding in a car  
or on a bus."  

The 72-year-old resident of Berkeley,  
California, spends most of her time song-  
writing and performing. She has been at it  
for 30 years, after discovering that her doc-  
torate in literature was helpful when solving  
crossword puzzles, but not when looking for  
jobs.  

"I never could get a job teaching. Nobody  
told me why, but I have my own ideas on the  
matter."  

Malvina's songwriting began when she "fell  
in with people like Pete Seeger, Earl Robin-  
son, and Woody Guthrie who were interested in  
our folk heritage."  

"They brought in powerful music, understa-  
ted musically and lyrically. I got a guitar,  
learned a few chords and that's all I know  
now."  

At first Malvina's work was performed by  
others - Seeger, Judy Collins, Joan Baez,  
Harry Belafonte - which accounts for our  
close familiarity with her songs but not her  
name.  

She comments, "Other singers kept doing my  
popular songs over and over. I had other  
good songs no one knew about. So I decided  
to do it myself.  

"I am not a great singer by any means. But  
nobody minds. If I had a better voice, I  
would have gone in a different direction,  
not as good a direction. I would have shown  
off my voice."  

Malvina Reynolds Sings  
for People who Agree  

An Interview  

By Susan  
Cushman  

Instead, Malvina has become an irresistible  
social and political critic whose beliefs are  
so tunefully presented that one can't help  
but hum along.  

Malvina frequently denies that her own  
songs are folk songs, because one person  
can't write an instant tradition. Rather,  
she says she writes what sounds like folk  
songs.  

Folk songs have a durability which sur-  
vives countless renditions, and perhaps Mal-  
vina's songs sound folkish because you never  
really get tired of them. Before I attended  
her concert at the Walker, I was sure that  
my capacity for “Little Boxes" had been fil-  
led years ago. But Malvina knew better than  
I what effect the well-known words and tune  
could have on an audience.  

The fun is in the knowing  

The song was flawlessly funny, mostly be-  
cause of the exact fit between the knowing  
delivery and the equally knowing reception.  
Most of us had grown up with this song,  
singing it at our concerts, around our camp-  
fires, in our avant-garde church services,  
and unanimously confirming its complaint.  

As Malvina sang it, I realized that was one  
agreement we never quite outgrew; ten years  
later and we still didn't like those houses,  
much less, their way of life:  

Little boxes on the hillside,  

Little boxes made of ticky-tacky,  
Little boxes on the hillside,  

Little boxes all the same;  

There's a green one and a pink one  

And a blue one and a yellow one  

And they're all made out of ticky-tacky  
And they all look just the same.  

Speaking before the concert, Malvina men-  
tioned that a breakfast cereal manufacturer  
had once approached her requesting permission  
to use "Little Boxes" in a commercial. She  
refused.  

Most of Malvina's work has a laugh in it  
which surfaces in more or less painful ways.  
She comments that her songs are "largely  
satire. Something can't be funny unless it  
has bite in it that hurts, that matters.”  

One of my favorites is "We Hate To See  
Them Go," a wry tune describing a dream  
about sending "the gentlemen of distinction  
in the Army."

By Kathy McConnell

First of Two Parts

Ten per cent of Minnesota
women belong to one of the
most unprotected minorities
in the state. Ten per cent
is the amount of Minnesota
women who are lesbians, esti-
mates Karen Browne, founder
of the Lesbian Resource Cen-
ter, 710 W. 22nd St., Minnea-
polis.

Lesbians are doubly defined
as "second-class citizens" by
society because they are wom-
en and because they prefer
members of their own sex.

Historically, lesbians have
been condemned by law in ev-
ery state. Descriptions of
homosexuality as "lewd and
lascivious behavior" and “a
crime against nature" are
used by several states in
their statutes. If female,
as well as male, homosexuals
aren't specified by some
states' laws, it has been be-
cause females were considered
less important socially.

In Minnesota, terms against
homosexuality aren't quite so
harsh but the lack of civil
rights for gays is the same.

Legislature Says ‘No’

In May, in the final
squeeze of the state's leg-
islative session, a confer-
ence committee from both
houses rejected a provision
to the Human Rights Act pro-
hibiting discrimination in
employment to homosexuals.

The gay provision, which
was introduced by Sen. Nick
Coleman, had passed earlier
in the Senate. Coleman's
original proposal, which
passed in the Senate's Sub-
Committee on Judicial Admin-
istration in mid-April and
the Senate Judiciary Commit-
tee a few weeks later also
protected gays in housing.

The gay provision itself
was an amendment to a broader
bill drafted by Sam Richard-
son, State Commissioner of
Human Rights.

Richardson's original draft
did finally pass through the
conference committee. It
prohibits discrimination in
the areas of housing, employ-
ment, education and public
services because of marital
status, physical or mental
disability, or status as a
welfare recipient.

No other state has passed
civil rights legislation for
gays. However, in New York
City an executive order was
issued forbidding discrimina-
tion against gays in govern-
ment employment. An Ann Ar-
bor, Michigan executive order

expanded the prohibition to
private employers.

In the Minnesota House,
gays have suffered defeat
this session in another piece
of legislation. The "Sodomy
Bill" would have legalized
homosexuality among consent-
ing adults. But Steve
Endean, lobbyist for the
Minnesota Civil Liberties
Union (MCLU) believes that
the defeat is just temporary
and that the bill will be
brought up again when the
legislature re-convenes next
January.

If the "Sodomy Bill" ever
becomes law, Minnesota will
join only seven other states
which have similar legisla-
tion.

Illinois pioneered legisla-
tive acceptance of homosexua-
lity between consenting
adults in 1961. Connecticut,
Colorado, Delaware, Ohio and
Hawaii all approved similar
legislation within the last
one and one-half years.

In Florida and Washington
D.C. restrictive laws simi-
lar to the present Minnesota
law were thrown out by the
courts as unconstitutional.

Mike Weatherbee, co-ordina-
tor of MCLU and Browne
acknowledge the importance of
the Human Rights Amendment as
a legal precedent.

The only national basis for
civil rights now is the 14th
Amendment to the US Constitu-
tion which prevents the gov-
ernment from discriminating

unless there's a rational rea-

son. "Housing isn't a case
here, though, because most of
it is privately owned. And
the amendment doesn't protect
against private employers,
either," Weatherbee pointed
out.

Because of the lack of
jurisdiction, no cases have
ever been brought against a
private employer or landlord
in Minnesota. "We (the MCLU)
frequently have to turn down
cases because there is no
law," said Weatherbee.

Landlords Discriminate

There are many cases in
Minneapolis where landlords
and employers have discrimin-
ated against lesbians, how-
ever.

Browne and her roommate,
Cindy Hanson, a former direc-
tor of Gay House and founder
of Gay Community Services
spent two months trying to
find an apartment. But after
each landlord asked where the
women worked, Browne and Han-
son were always turned down.

“Finally, we just told a
landlord that we worked in a
‘straight’ place and we got

an apartment," said Browne.

For the professional woman,
a major problem is hiding the
fact that she is a lesbian.

Helen Livingston teaches
first grade in a Catholic
grade school. Because of the
small size of the faculty,
she finally felt that she
couldn't keep her lesbianism
a secret anymore.

The school didn't fire her
directly but "ambiguously"
refused to renew her contract
for next year because of
“conflicting philosophies."

"Professional women who
come into contact with people
more than factory workers are
more likely to get fired,"
said Livingston.

Organized religion, espec-
ially the Catholic Church,
remains one of the main ob-
stacles to lesbians. Tradi-
tionally, religion has con-
demned everything but pro-
creative sex. Anything else
was "sinful" and "perverse."

But some branches of Pro-
testantism are changing.
Browne notes that a few city
churches are helping to fund
the Lesbian Resource Center.
(Other funds come from priv-
ate foundations and personal
contributions.)

Religion and government are
the main institutions which
prolong basic societal beliefs
against homosexuality. Even
if a lesbian can overcome the
religious obstacle by removing
herself directly from the
church, there are always more
concrete and visible barriers
within the government.

Government Says ‘No’

According to a 1969 issue of
Humanist magazine, "Federal
government serves to set the
tone and example of the syste-
matic exclusion of this sig-
nificantly large minority of
its citizens from full parti-
cipation in the society in
which they live, and their
systematic relegation to sec-
ond class citizens."

The "significantly large
minority" of lesbians in the
country is about 10 million,
estimate Del Martin and Phyl-
lis Lyon, co-founders of the
national lesbian organization,
Daughters of Bilitis.

The federal government's
disapproval of lesbianism is
expressed mainly in the civil
service.

The government still treats
homosexuality as an emotional
disturbance and emphasizes
psychoanalysis as a "cure."

“Homosexuality has been de-
fined into a sickness or dis-
order through subjective, per-
sonal, social, moral, cultur-
al and religious value judge-

No One

ments...the ones who accuse
don't do adequate scientific
study to validate what they
say," states the Humanist
article.

However, the Kinsey report
on Sexual Behavior in the
Human Female documents studies
of both sexes substantiating
that homosexuality is not a
"sickness" but a "preference."

The civil service prejudice
is stated in its list of gen-
eral qualifications. "Persons
about whom there is evidence
that they have engaged in...
homosexual...acts, without
evidence of rehabilitation,
are not suitable for Federal
employment." This rule is
without regard for the per-
son's individual qualifica-
tions for the job.

Stemming largely from the
McCarthy period of the 1950's,
the civil service's opinion
is that homosexuals will have
a "disrupting effect upon the
morale and efficiency of any
organization." Yet the rela-
tion between a worker's off-
the-job behavior and her on-
the-job efficiency is never
explained.

There is an obvious incon-
gruence in the government's
position. While civil service
is fearful of placing a homo-
sexual in an office of hetero-
sexuals, "The government
wouldn't hesitate to put a
Negro in an office of racists
or a Jew in an office of anti-
Semites," concludes the Huma-
nist article.

Currently, the government
is able to fire workers
because in the government's
definition, homosexuality is
a "rational basis" for firing,
said Weatherbee.

Again, the professional

lesbians are the ones most
affected by this policy.
This includes teachers, women
in the medical profession and
any other profession licensed
by the state.

The Human Rights amendment
could locally challenge gov-
ernmental hiring practices.

Courts Say ‘Maybe’

Discrimination in housing
and employment are problems
faced by both lesbians and
male homosexuals. Yet, gay
women are faced with another
legal problem--of having to
prove that they are "fit"
mothers.

Weatherbee said that there
have been several MCLU cases
where an ex-husband or rela-
tive has tried to get the
children taken away from
their lesbian mother.

Browne explained the only
"semi-victory" in the nation

(continued on page 4)

people change, you told me
and it isn't right for us

to stay in each other's arms
there is more for each of us
somewhere else

we will be stronger apart

we will find new energies
and I say I understand

we have gone through our
changes

I hate that word

I let you pack

we laugh, we are happy

for what has passed between
us and we have shared love
and I say I understand

it is not good to be together
if we need someone else
someone new and different

yet that night I reach across the

emptiness searching for your
warmth and I am cold and
alone

I scream and no one hears me

that no one ever hears

Reprinted from "So's
Your Old Lady," a bi-
monthly magazine pub-
lished by women from
the Lesbian Resource
Center in Minneapolis,

Issue No.

1.

Lesbianism == continued from page 3

for a lesbian mother regard-
ing child custody.

Two Washington men chal-
lenged their ex-wives who
were living together with
both women's children. With
the aid of a woman lawyer and
favorable testimony by sever-
al social workers, the women
retained custody of their
children.

But the women were ordered
by the court to no longer
live together nor even see
each other in the presence of
their children.

The MCLU has never had a
call concerning attempts by
the Welfare Department to
gain custody of children just
because their mother is a
lesbian.

Welfare tries to gain cust-
ody only if there is also a
reason to believe that the
mother isn't caring for her
children properly.

If a mother has to go to
court to retain custody of
her children, "most attorneys
will tell her to hush up her
lesbianism," said Browne.

Discrimination of lesbians
appears in written and un-
written forms.

Browne had much difficulty
in trying to find a landlord
that would rent to a "Lesbian
Resource Center." And once a
location for the center was
found, the telephone and pub-
lic utilities companies were
reluctant to connect their
services.

Browne, who is one of the
three women at the Lesbian
Resource Center who split a
$500 a month salary, predicts
difficulties the center might
have when it applies to the
state for incorporation.
"It's just hard for any gay
group to get a tax-exempt
status," she said.

The Lesbian Resource Center
as a whole has no definite
political philosophy so that
“all sorts of people feel
comfortable here," said
Browne.

"Yet, most lesbians are
obviously feminists," con-
cluded Livingston.

Few Alternatives

Before the Lesbian Resource
Center opened in mid-January,
Twin City lesbians had only
two places where they could
socialize as lesbians, Gay
House and "the bar."

But Gay House is male dom-
inated and never really at-
tracted that many women, said
Hanson.

Livingston continued,
"There was a lot of solidari-
ty at first but things kind
of died out. More women come
to the center than ever would
have come to Gay House."

In Minnesota there aren't
any laws, such as those in
California, which prohibit
kissing and handholding by
members of the same sex in a
bar. "Or if there are, no
one ever enforces them,"
Browne said.

Gay bars in the Twin Cities
are managed by "straights"
who can take advantage of the
fact that homosexuals have al-
most no place else to go to-
gether.

Hanson implied that the gay
bars are Chicago-syndicate
controlled and can afford to
"pay off" police so that the
bar's clientele won't be has-
sled.

If this is true or not,
Browne said that "the police
haven't given us any trouble
at the bars or the center."

Hanson thinks that a
"straight" syndicate can mo-
nopolize gay bars because the
high price of a liquor
license makes it impossible
for most gays to buy their
own bar.

Policeman Causes Trouble

Besides, owning a gay bar
can be a risky business.

A couple of years ago a
lesbian woman owned a gay bar
in a St. Paul suburb. One
night an off-duty policeman
came into the bar, allegedly
caused some confusion, then
called into his station with
false reports about what the
women were doing in the bar.

Upon closer examination of
the incident by a senior of-
ficer it was determined that
the policeman was at fault
for the disturbance and he
was subsequently discharged
from the force.

But the fear of being
exposed through publicity of
the event made most of the
lesbian patrons stay away
from the bar after that. The
bar soon closed.

Twin City lesbians' rela-
tive freedom from problems
with the police is a contrast
to Martin and Lyon's reports
in Lesbian/Woman of the con-
stant harassment of Califor-
nia police towards lesbians.

For women who don't care to
go to the bars, the Lesbian
Resource Center offers a
variety of activities. Dis-
cussion groups, theater,
films, dances, a coffeehouse
and softball team give les-
bians a chance to be in con-
tact with other lesbians.

Radicalesbians

The level of organized po-
litical activity varies among
lesbians of the Twin Cities
as it does among lesbians of
the country.

"Radicalesbians" are usual-
ly younger women who identify
politically and socially with
their minority. At the other
end of the spectrum are wom-
en, usually older, who are
so well established in their
communities and jobs that
they feel they stand to lose
too much personally if they
become politically active.
But all lesbians agree that
their rights are essential.
As Martin and Lyons state in
Lesbian/Woman, "No longer is
toleration acceptable. The
lesbians, along with all op-
pressed people, want freedom
and we want it now!"

Malvina does not intend that her songs  
carry messages. "I sing what people have  
formulated anyway. I address myself to  
those who agree with me or are in a fringe  
limbo."  

Since many of her concerts are benefit  
performances for causes such as the women's  
and peace movements, the Ellsberg defense,  
and the American Indian Movement, her  
audience is naturally selected for her en-  
lightened and engaging point of view.  

Malvina's interest in women's issues is  
long-standing, as evidenced by her equivocal  
"We Don't Need the Men" written in 1958.  
The chorus chortles:  

We don't need the men, We don't need the  
men,  

We don't need to have them around, except  
for now and then.  

They can come to see us when we need to  
move the piano,  

Otherwise they can stay at home and read  
about the White Sox.  

Blind Justice  

Local Style  

(Cont’d)  

Fifteen years ago, Malvina considered this  
song a tongue-in-cheek exercise; the raucous  
enthusiasm it produced at her concert sug-  
gests that today the song carries more ser-  
ious implications.  

With a little less good humor, "No Room"  
recognizes the rise of world hunger and over-  
population:  

No room! No room! No room!  

Holy is the fetus,  

But babies once born are simply human,  

And if they die in the streets of  
Calcutta  

No one will notice but their ma,  

And ain't that just like a woman.  

The wider the grin, it seems, the deeper  
the bite.  

I seldom meet people who are satisfied  
with their lives, and it surprised me to so  
easily recognize a contented person when I  
saw her. Malvina Reynolds truly likes her  
life, and with good reason. She lives by  
her talents and her convictions, supporting  
herself by doing what she likes best on her  
own terms.  

Malvina Reynolds works without an agent.  

If you are interested in having a concert  
with her, write her at 2027 Parker St.,  
Berkeley, Cal. 94704, or call (415) 843-2365  

When I moved to Minneapolis last year I  
was surprised and gratified to see a public  
feminist display not far from my door. A  

larger than lifesize statue of a woman tak-  
ing notes prominently sat on the lawn of the  
Metropolitan School of Law a few blocks away  
from my apartment. "What a way to advertise  
for female law students," I cheerfully  
thought to myself, and if the door of the  
building had been open, I would have gone in  
to compliment the school on its ingenuity  
and enlightened politics.  

That locked door saved us all some embar-  
rassment. Only days later, I read in the  
morning paper that the statue was a throw-  
back to the fairly recent days when the  
building had housed a school for medical  
secretaries. Since that educational enter-  
prise had failed, the same founder was now  

attempting to establish the law school. Once  
the building had been relabeled, the statue  
was naturally considered inappropriate.  
Sculptural alteration was scheduled and soon  
came in the form of a black painted blind-  
fold and a pair of ironwork scales. Presto,  
and we viewed that great feminine character  
Blind Justice. So what if she was hunched  
over a desk and who cared that the notebook  
was a misplaced prop? At least she couldn't  
be mistaken for a prototypical law student.  
The school never got off the ground, and  
a "Space Available" sign eventually appeared

Weather and the Real Woman

The women of Alexandria,  
Minnesota have come a long  
way.  
A discussion class on the women's  
movement brought local feminists together.  
Alexandria hasn't been the  
same. After the class was  
over, they decided to keep  
meeting as a consciousness-raising group.

Trap Door and T.V.

One of the women is Wendy  
Wallace. On weekdays, she  
pulls open a trap door in a  
building downtown and descends to a shop called "The  
Trap Door" where she and her  
mother sell carved gourds,  
silver rings, wicker baskets,  
wooden boxes, and other gifts.

On weekends, Wendy enters  
another door, that of the  
KCMT-TV station in Alexandria,  
and does the weekend weather.

Wendy has a long history  
of television work. When she  
was 15, she read the weather  
on TV in Fargo. Later, she  
did Unguentine and All-State  
Insurance commercials in California.

Women’s Work

She met little resistance  
when she applied for the job  
at KCMT; the job had already  
been pegged as "women's work"  
--the former weatherperson  
was a woman. Now, she says,  
if one of the talent is absent  
during the week, she substitutes in the weather slot,  
but never in any other. If  
the anchorman is gone, she  
will replace the weatherman,  
who replaces the sports announcer, who replaces the  
anchorman...

Unsatisfied with these conditions, she conceived a plan  
for another show, a show on  
women, and approached the  
station director with her  
idea. “I was shocked when he  
approved it," she said, and  
since February, Wendy has  
been hosting a 15-minute show  
called "What's New with Women"  
on Sundays at 12:15 pm.  
She has reported on such topics as welfare, divorce, and  
abortion, and has interviewed  
Carol Jetland, of the Minnesota  
Education Association Committee on Women.

Last fall an adult education  
class on the women's movement  
brought local feminists together,  
and since then Wendy's radicalization seems  
to have been prophesied in  
the name she and her husband  
Patrick gave to their 19-month-old daughter, Erin  
Pendrick. "Pendrick is a  
phonetic combination of our  
names...We took the 'end'  
from 'Wendy' and the 'Prick' from 'Patrick.'"

Viewers and Colleagues

Viewer response has been  
disappointing. No one has  
written with comments on the  
issues she has presented.  
Several people have admired  
her hair. A couple of men  
have written her that they  
have fallen in love with her.  
Once, in a spirit of irony, a  
woman sent a poem (reprinted  
below) about motherhood "from  
her collection." Wendy said,  
"I read it as straight as I  
could and wanted a copy of the  
poem."

What is a mother?

A mother is soft hands and a  
warm heart.

A mother has lots of tears,  
She never runs out of them.

A mother is different.  
She never takes the last chop  
on the plate.

She likes chicken backs and  
necks.  
Dad and the kids don't.

When a mother dies, she goes  
to heaven.  
The coveted job of all:  
Sitting on soft, white,  
fluffy clouds  
Holding the angelic babies  
And wiping away their celestial tears  
With the corner of her apron.

Wendy feels she is not taken  
seriously by the men at  
the TV station and says she  
is not treated as a regular  
part of the staff. She is  
never invited to office parties  
or get-togethers, and is  
not treated with friendliness  
"as though it would not be  
proper." But, she says, "any  
time I pull a goof they all  
love me." Wendy says she  
"detests dresses," but one  
week when she substituted on  
another show, her clothes  
were supplied by a local  
dress shop. One day she wore  
a light blue dress complete  
with ruffles and lace. She  
wore her hair in pigtails.  
She says she felt like a 5-year-old  
on her way to a birthday party.  
When she arrived at the station, one  
of the men said, "Now you  
look like a real woman."

Three people wrote in.  
And there she gets the most.

Terminal Island, Calif.  

Eleanor  
Antin, has earned herself an  
exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art  
(MOMA), New York, through an ingen-  
ious ongoing mailwork.  

100 Boots, a series of 50 postcards  
showing black rubber boots in drama-  
tic situations, is on view at MOMA  
through July 8—when the boots them-  
selves conclude their peripatetic ad-  
ventures with a stay in New York. In  
addition to the entire set of post-  
cards, the exhibition includes photo-  
graphic blow-ups of the boots' New  
York “crash pad."  

Executed over the past 2 1/2 years,  
Antin's 100 Boots was conceived as a  
means of circumventing the limitations  
of the gallery system. The postcards  
have been mailed at irregular inter-  
vals—ranging from 3 days to 5 weeks  
—to some thousand persons and insti-  
tutions around the world.  

As Antin describes it, she origin-  
ally thought of the work as a picar-  
esque novel, but later began to view  
the photographs as highlighted frames  
from a movie serial. Each postcard in-  
cludes a photograph of the boots,  

a title and data on the place and time  
of the photographs. All photographs  
were taken by Philip Steinmetz.  

The postcards were not necessar-  
ily mailed in sequence of occurrence.  
Instead, Antin reordered the events  
into a continuous narrative, which be-  
gins with the boots in conventional  
society, leads through their first  
crime ("100 Boots Trespass") and  
thence to a series of adventures, odd  
jobs and even an unhappy love affair.  

While most of the boots’ adventures  
have taken place in California (where  
Antin lives), their exploits will con-  
clude in New York when the MOMA ex-  
hibition closes. Jane Necol of the  
MOMA staff directed the exhibition,  
which is the first time the boots'  
wanderings will be fully displayed.

Part V: Disease

Venereal Diseases

A venereal disease is one that is transmit-
ted only through sexual contact, genital,
oral, or anal. Both major types, syphilis
and gonorrhea, can be cured easily if treated
in the early stages, but both can result in
permanent disability or death if untreated.

SYPHILIS

Symptoms: A symptom of the primary, or
first, stage of syphilis is the appearance of
a small sore or "chancre" on either the geni-
tal area or the anus, or even on lips, tongue,
and fingers. It appears from ten days to
three months after exposure to the disease
and may disappear without treatment after a
few days. This does not mean that the disease
has gone away; it has entered a secondary
stage, where it is highly contagious and can
do crippling damage to the body. In the sec-
ondary stage, symptoms include rashes, sore
throat, sore joints, headache, fever, and en-
larged glands. These symptoms may come and
go over a period of years. These symptoms
also eventually will disappear without treat-
ment. In the final stage of the disease, no
visible symptoms exist. However, untreated
syphilis will persist and ultimately can lead
to blindness, insanity, paralysis, heart dis-
ease, or death. A pregnant woman who has
syphilis can pass it on to newborn children,
who may be stillborn or blind.

Diagnosis and treatment: Certain diagnosis
can only be made through blood tests. These
are available without charge through public
health agencies in Seattle and most other
large cities. Through the use of penicillin,
syphilis can be successfully treated in its
early stages, and in the later stages, the
destructive processes can be stopped by treat-
ment.

GONORRHEA

Symptoms: Gonorrhea ("the clap") is usually
limited to the genitourinary organs, and it
is in these organs that the symptoms appear.
Female symptoms include pain upon urination,
inflammation of the rectum, swollen glands in
the genital area, and vaginal discharge.

More serious symptoms may occur, such as in-
flammation of the reproductive organs. How-
ever, a woman may have no symptoms at all,
except for slight discomfort while urinating,
and still be a highly contagious carrier of
the disease. The symptoms in males are more
obvious and include a burning sensation during
urination and a discharge of yellow pus. Fur-
ther complications include bladder infections
and a hard, tender swelling in the scrotum.

In both males and females, the untreated dis-
ease can lead to peritonitis, sterility, ar-
thritis, or irritation of the joints, and it
can affect the heart. Women can experience
additional complications that include a gen-
eralized infection of the uterus and ovarian
tubes called pelvic inflammatory disease.

This is associated with pain, fever, and ab-
cesses in the tubes, sometimes known as "pus
tubes."

Diagnosis and treatment: Gonorrhea is
usually diagnosed by use of laboratory tests
performed on discharge from infected organs.
Treatment at an early stage can cure the in-
fection. Women who are sexually active should
request an intracervical smear test for
gonorrhea at the same time they have a Pap
smear test.

PROTECTION FROM VENEREAL DISEASES

Venereal diseases are highly contagious and
highly dangerous. The only device that pro-
tects against venereal diseases is the condom,
and this does not offer complete protection!
Previous successful treatment for a venereal
disease is no protection against reinfection.
Since no immunity develops, people can be re-
infected. The only reliable protection
against a disabling venereal disease is infor-
mation and prompt treatment when symptoms are
present.

Although the symptoms of syphilis and gonor-
rhea have been described above, it is impos-
sible to diagnose oneself. Laboratory tests
are necessary. If you have any symptoms or
have reason to believe that you have been ex-
posed to venereal disease, see one of the

Because of the severity of venereal disease
epidemics in some cities and because of its

people who are "unclean," "unhealthy," or

A final note: If you acquire a venereal

Infections
VAGINITIS

Vaginitis is any inflammation of the vagina—
inflammation due to irritation, to infection,
or to some process that disturbs normal phy-
siology. Anything which interferes with the
protective mechanism normally present in the
vagina causes vaginitis.

The most common complaints associated with
vaginitis are pain, vaginal discharge, itch-
ing, and burning.

VAGINAL DISCHARGE

Some vaginal discharge is normal. This
normal discharge may increase with the use of
the birth-control pill, especially sequen-
tials, and with emotional stress. However,
vaginal discharge also may be caused by in-
fection or chemical or mechanical irritation.
These are listed below.

Infections that cause vaginal discharge:
gonorrhea, trichomonas, monilia, mycoplasma,
and mixed infections.

Chemical and mechanical irritants that cause
vaginal discharge: douches, if too often or
too strong; feminine hygiene sprays; foams,
vaginal creams, and gels (occasionally);
soaps and bubble baths (sometimes); and
foreign objects, such as lost tampons or
dirty fingers.

As a general rule, to guard against vaginal
irritation, don't put anything in your vagina
that you wouldn't put in your mouth.

TRICHOMONAL VAGINITIS (“TRICH”)

Trichomonas vaginalis is a parasite (proto-
zoa) that is spread by sexual contact. In
males, the organism may live under the fore-
skin, in the urethra, or in the prostate
gland. In women, the organism may be found
in the vagina or the cervix and sometimes in
the urethra or the bladder.

Men often have no symptoms. Women have
itching and usually a discharge that is thin,
yellow-greenish, frothy, and smelly.

Since the infecting organism is transmitted
by sexual contact, both female and male part-
ners must be treated. Treatment is an oral
medication, Flagyl, which is expensive but ef-
fective. Vaginal suppositories also may be
prescribed. Like other sexually transmitted
diseases, prevention depends on infected
people being treated. Men who have been ex-
posed but not treated can protect their part-
ners by using a condom.

MONILA VAGINITIS (CANDIDA, YEAST)

Monilia vaginitis is caused by a yeast-like
organism, candida, that is normally found in
the bowel and on the skin and is commonly
found in the vagina.

Many women harbor candida without symptoms.
Symptomatic yeast infections are common in
pregnancy, in diabetes, in women using the
pill, premenstrually, and sometimes after
diarrhea. In women, the symptoms include
vaginal itching and a discharge, which is us-
ually white, may be thick or thin, and is
sometimes curdy like cottage cheese. It is
usually not smelly. Men will occasionally get
a rash or irritation on the penis.

Treatment with specific antimonilial creams
or suppositories may be prescribed. Sometimes
an at-home use of a vinegar douche (one table-
spoon of vinegar in a pint of lukewarm water
is sufficient). Symptoms often recur, even
after treatment. Continuous good hygiene is
helpful in preventing monilia. Cotton under-
pants that absorb moisture may prevent symp-
toms. However, yeast infections can occur
even when the best rules of hygiene are prac-

*Syphilis may be transmitted congenitally
if the pregnant mother has venereal disease
and is not treated. It also can be trans-
mitted by contact to small children and

Almost 80 percent of infected females
are asymptomatic carriers; that is, they
are contagious and transmit the disease
but have no symptoms.

While women who carry the infecting or-
ganism, mycoplasma, usually do not have
symptoms, mycoplasma can produce vaginal
discharge in women. This condition is very
difficult to diagnose in women. It must be
diagnosed in the male partner, who then
brings the infected woman for treatment.

PENILE DISCHARGE

Urethral discharge can occur in men. Com-
mon causes of penile discharge are gonorrhea,
occasionally trichomonas, and non-specific
urethritis (NSU).

Nonspecific urethritis occurs primarily in
males. It usually is caused by an organism
called mycoplasma. It is sexually transmit-
ted, often from asymptomatic females. The
symptoms are burning on urination and a dis-
charge that is similar to that of gonorrhea.
Since the organism producing NSU is difficult
to detect in a laboratory test, diagnosis of
NSU is made by ruling out gonorrhea. However,
when it is correctly diagnosed, NSU responds
well to treatment by antibiotics. A seven-
to-ten day treatment is usually successful.

BLADDER INFECTIONS (CYSTITIS)

Cystitis is usually caused by bacteria
found in the lower gastro-intestinal tract
(the rectum), the skin, or the vagina. The
major symptoms are burning sensation during
urination with high frequency and urgency,
and, at times, bloody urine. Cystitis often
occurs in otherwise healthy young women who
recently have become sexually active; hence,
it is sometimes called "honeymoon cystitis."
It may be caused, in part, by the swelling
and irritation of the urethra during inter-
course, with resultant bacterial contamination
of the bladder. If the infection is not
treated with antibiotics, it may progress to
involvement of the kidneys. However, it is
easy to diagnose and responds well to treat-
ment.

Pubic Lice

Pubic lice, also known as "crotch lice" or
"crabs," live in the pubic hair of human be-
ings and feed on blood. They also can survive
in the underarm hair, in the hair around the
nipples, in beards, or in eyebrows. Pubic
lice are transmitted through sexual contact.
Often, the first sign of their presence is
itching in the affected areas. Furthermore,
if you look for them, they are not hard to
see. The eggs (nits) look like small freck-
les. After they have hatched, they can be
recognized as tiny vermin. The nits are
visible as tiny translucent lumps attached to
the base and shaft of the pubic hairs, which
look like pussy willows. After they hatch,
they are mobile. (See drawing.)

Pubic lice are easy to exterminate. Two
applications of gamma benzene hexachloride
(Kwell), which is available by prescription,
should be shampooed into the affected areas.
The preparation begins to work quickly and
will eliminate the lice within a day or two.
Since lice cannot live apart from their human
host, any lice on clothing or linen will die
in twenty-four hours. But to be on the safe
side, you should launder clothing and linen
after treatment has started.

Herpes Simplex  

Herpes simplex is a virus which can be  
spread by sexual contact (oral, genital, or  
anal). It is characterized by blisters on  
the skin or mucous membrane. These may itch  
when they are erupting and later become pain-  
ful. The blisters look like and are related  
to cold sores.  

In women the sores occur primarily on the  
labia but also within the vagina. In men  
they can appear on the penis or scrotum. The  
blisters last eight to ten days and do tend  
to recur.  

There are no known cures for herpes simplex.  
However, the discomfort can be reduced through  
Burrows soaks, ice pack, or heat. The sores  
should be encouraged to be dry. Some  
physicians also recommend Glyoxide or Orabase  
(a medication for canker sores), which can be  
purchased at drugstores without a prescrip-  
tion.  

Pap Test  

The Pap test is a laboratory test of a  
sample of cells from the cervix and the upper  
vagina taken during a pelvic examination. This  
test is a valuable diagnostic tool and can  
give early warning of cervical or uterine can-  
cer. Contrary to public opinion, cervical and  
uterine cancer can occur in young women. Can-  
cer is more apt to occur in women who are  
sexually active than in virgins, and it has  
been shown to be associated with having multi-  
ple sex partners, starting at an early age.  
However, cervical and uterine cancer can  
occur in sexually inexperienced women as  
well. All women should have a Pap test once  
a year. If tests for two consecutive years  
show no disorder, however, young women can  
skip two to three years before being retested.  
Tests are given free at many public health  
facilities.

— Robin Morgan

by Diana L. Antolik

I want a women’s revolution like a lover

I lust for it, I want so much this freedom
this end to struggle and fear and lies

we all exhale, that I could die just

with the passionate uttering of that desire,

Robin Morgan
Monster

May 30 and other notes; My mind has
been whirling ever since I left the Robin
Morgan Lecture. Lecture is not the word.
The word is some never-ending infinitely
high-pitched scream,

Tonight in a packed auditorium, a
gigantic auditorium, I felt something I
never had before. A super-consciousness of
energies, of emotions, of minds coming to-
gether.

I don't know if it was a lecture. Even
though it was labeled by the University 100-73-
803 The Emergence of Feminist Culture by
Robin Morgan. It seemed like a CR session
with over five hundred people.

Poet in Chem Lab

At seven thirty there was only a small
group of women in the Murphy Hall Auditor-
ium but more and more came. First in small
groups and finally in a flood. Every seat
was taken and there were women sitting two
abreast in the aisles and still more people
coming in. An advocacy for a spirit of love
and sisterhood to put up with the cramped
conditions until something could be worked
out was made. The request was unneeded.
The spirit existed from the start. Finally
the lecture was moved to a Chemistry hall
and there were still people sitting in the
aisles.

Morgan made comment on the setting in
the opening: "There are a number of chapters
in Shulamith's book," (Shulamith Firestone's
The Dialectic of Sex) "in which she talks
about the patriarchal style compartmental-
ization. That is you have art over here and
science over there. It is very apt given
the theme I am trying to talk about under
all that. It's strange but it's apt."

Illness Due to Split

The lecture progressed too swiftly.
Morgan started threading her loom in the beg-
inning in which she was weaving the radical
ideas.

"On the relation of feminist culture and
feminist politics to me the relation between
feminist culture and feminist politics
doesn't exist because feminist culture and
feminist politics are inseparable and in-
deed synonymous.

“The feminist movement is about bridges
between things. At one point there was no
difference between art and science, between
thought and feeling, between intellect and
action. And that profound and deep illness
of our society and not just our society
but the patriarchy globally is due I would
say primarily to that split."

Reactions....

Spending the rest of the night after the
Robin Morgan Lecture awake and writing I
started to wonder around dawn how other women
had reacted during the night hours. So I
started to ask some of the feminists that I
was coming in contact with during the day.
Few of them said that they didn't go and the
reason then was because of work. But those
that did attend were shaken to say the least.

"I sat up and played two or three games
of chess. I hardly ever play chess," was the
reaction of one woman.

"I just sat and thought. Like I was in
a trance," was another woman's reaction.

"Some friends and I sat up most of the
night rapping --- there was so much there,"
was another's statement.

Some of the women could not utter the
thoughts inside of them. Others talked. Some
could not relate to any questions asked by
males they were in contact with. Others
rapped with friends until the grey hours of
the morning.

Through other sources, though (male) I did
find one middle-aged, balding pervert who
explained, "Oh, yeah, Gloria Steinem, naw, it
was Robin Morgan this time, yeah I saw her.
She's the one who talks of castrating men.
Well she's "funny" (I have the feeling that
he meant a Lesbian since there was that
ringing "you-know-what-I-mean-so-I-don't-
have-to-say-the-word" quality in his voice.)

And this whole women’s thing -~- it'll never
make it."

Personal = Political

And later Morgan progressed further
with her point by continuing, "I think one
of the primary places where the reintegration
has begun, and that is another pulse
beat of the feminist movement, is now the
classic phrase 'the personal is political.'

"For women who have been confined to
the ‘personal sphere' the personal is very
political. I could cite ten million
examples as could any woman in this room.
Just a few bases to touch. The housewife
is considered by the establishment a non-
worker. On a quiz show they say, ‘Honey
do you work or are you just a housewife?'
The average housewife works a 99.6 hour work
week."

Not After Equality

And finally after progressing through
many more examples of both the male right
and the male left she brought together the
heart of the thought. "And then there is
the area which I would call radical femin-
ism where there is one priority and that is
women. All women. We are not after equal-
ity with men. The notion makes me want to
throw up. We are not interested in becoming

more like men, or doing what it is men do  
in this culture. But on the contrary  
changing that whole concept as well.  

"We are not after equality or tokenism  
whether it is Margaret Chase Smith or  
Bernadine Dorn. We are, in fact, after  
power... 5"  

"I am not talking about reforming the  
system or revising the system or making the  
patriarchy nice or some kind of wonderful  
humanistic glow. I am talking about a world-  
wide feminist revolution. And in fact a  
gynocracy in which women own all secular and  

Robin Morgan Continued  

I am talking about rage which is right and  
justifiable and firm and beautiful. A right  
to 'man hating' as a class. Because the  
class of men, as oppressors, hurt and the  
class of women, as oppressed, have a right to  
hate where that hurt is coming from. Taking  
one's own feelings seriously enough to go as  
far as they will take one. And you can't do  
that alone because you will think that you  
are going mad in the old way. That is why we  
need each other and that is why we need a  
feminist culture."

Happy Hooking  
Prostitution Two Views  

Diana L. Antolik  

When two authors approach any subject, be it brushing teeth or doing wash; to solving  
world economic problems or the evolution of a species there are bound to be differences.  
Differences of style, viewpoint, and understanding of the subject matter the author is  

to get across.  

This is an accepted fact in writing. If not there wouldn't be so many books in exist-  
ence today. But when both of the authors are women dealing with the same subject, in this  
case prostitution, one of them is most likely to come out of the acceptance duel with a  

black eye.  

Hollander  

Xaviera! How well such a strange name  
is remembered! And how most of us remem-  
ber the first book Ms. Hollander brought  
into being, The Happy Hooker.  

"Xaviera! Her continuing adventures..."  
“The Girl Who's Gone Wrong--And Loves It  
-~-Is Back!" Xaviera Hollander is back  
with another scorcher, is only because of  
the electric pink cover and title Xaviera  
(Warner Paperback Library, 428 pp. $1.50)  

"As in The Happy Hooker I've written in  
the first person as though I am talking to  
the reader as a friend; a personal inti-  
mate conversation," Hollander states in a  
blurb on the back of her book. It is an  
intimate conversation, but I have the feel-  
ing that the most intimate thing that passes  
between the two of us is my money.  

The dealings in  
prostitution that  
Hollander writes  
about is a life  
style that is very  
easy, relaxed, and  
very profitable.  

There is no real  

reference to drugs,  

except in passing,  

pimps, "underworld  

dealings", or the  

real hassles with  

the police or the legal systems.  

these omissions which gives the book an un-  
realistic fantasy-like glow. For with all  
the fun and games logic tells anyone that  
there should be a little rain falling some-  
where.  

The tone of the book is light and there  
are many incidents where, (since this is a  
personal story it is all quite possible)  
the people and interactions do not follow  
any sequence. The only help the reader has  
in solving her "what-is-really-happening"  
bafflement is an Editor's note that states:  
"The material in this book is not being  
presented in any specific chronological  
order. Some of the things occurred at the  
same time. Such is the style of Ms. Hol-  
lander's life." And such, also is the style  
of her writing. Disjointed to a point of  
distraction.  

The book takes life, women, relation-  
ships, and men with a grain of salt. There  
is not even the slightest indication that  
any of it is real. There is no substance  
to any person besides Hollander herself.  
So one can begin to wonder about the val-  
idity of the book by the second chapter.  

If joking prostitution and pink covers  
and shocking come-ons are sellable to  
the public then Xaviera will sky-rocket.  

Millett  

"I also found that the knowledge of an-  
other's experience places vast moral re-  
sponsibility upon you, since the very  
knowledge of another if deep and authentic  
constitutes great obligations.”  

"...So that the experience of all women  
everywhere becomes, in a sense, our com-  
munal property, a heritage we bestow upon  
each other, the knowledge of what it has  
meant to be female—a woman in this man's  
world."  

With these two passages as with the rest  
of the introductions in Kate Millett's  
The Prostitution Papers: A Candid Dialogue  
(Avon Books, 160 pp. $1.25) are laid the  
basic groundwork for what I feel is one  
of the most honest works on prostitution  
to be written in a long time, if ever.  
The book is divided  
into four sections  
with a different  
woman speaking in  
each.  

Though the variat-  
ions presented by  
each woman is dif-  
ferent because of  
the diverse in-  
volvement there is  
a very strong under-  
current that affirms  
that for each woman the basic script remains  
the same while the sets and specific dia-  
logue changes.  

Unlike most books that deal with "touchy"  
areas Millett does not hide what either  
herself; Liz Schneider, a lawyer; or "M" and  
"J", two former prostitutes have to say be-  
hind some high-falutin academic rhetoric of  
charts and figures. But instead deals with  
the women involved and their reactions at  

a personal level.  

Millett serves as a buffer, sounding board  
and reporter. Even though this is "her" book  
she keeps her personal insights and comments  
well out of the way of what the story of  
the other women is. Her reporting is of  
a recognizable style, editing down the  
"authors" until the written language is similar  
to what was actually spoken.  

And what is spoken by all women is grim.  
Yes, at one time in the lives of both "J"  
and "M" there was a time when selling your-  
self was not all that bad, as they both state  
it was even slightly rosy for a time. But  
it all changes into the "underground" of  
drugs, police and total alienation from al-  
most every part of a somewhat normal daily  
existence.

by Julie Landsman

QUESTION: "Since you have written 'I am Woman' and since you seem to represent the women's liberation movement, what is your true opinion of us male chauvinist pigs?"

REPLY: SOUL

"Oh, I think there is some hope for

Breakthrough

The Helen Reddy Show included this kind of exchange every week it was on the air. Like Ms. magazine, the show was slick, controversial and extremely well done. And, hopefully, like Ms. magazine, it got to more and more people as the summer wore on. I am not one of those who feel that because something is popular, then it must be of poor quality. I do have friends who refuse to read books on the best sellers list simply because “everyone" is reading them. (“Everyone" in this context sounds kind of like "the plebians"). The more people who saw the Helen Reddy Show, the better. As I watched Ms. Reddy hold up her fist and say something like "keep fighting, sisters", I felt that an important development had occurred in the history of the media. Beside the fact that the show had a woman producer and a large number of female crew members, which are notable breakthroughs in themselves, what actually went on in front of the cameras seemed even more remarkable.

Natural Style

There was Helen Reddy herself. She appeared in marked contrast to every other singer or variety show hostess I've seen on similar productions. Unlike Cher, of Sonny and Cher, she did not depend on fantastic clothes or wild hairstyles or undulating movements for her appeal. She was natural in every sense of the word, from her straight hair, to her quiet singing style, to the way she held her body. Ms. Reddy spoke directly to the audience without a hint of coyness or pretension. As I listened to her musical speaking voice, I wondered if an American performer could do as well. Perhaps, there is something in her Australian background that enables Helen Reddy to have her own show without becoming encumbered with false glamour, flashy sets or the skin-tight gowns of almost every other female singer.

Women Get Together

The show itself was different from any other. It was warm, chatty, funny and touching, and it was nothing like the sappy sugary stuff that characterized the Glen Campbell approach on a similar set. The guests included Brenda Vaccaro, the Pointer Sisters, Ruth Buzzi, and, in what seemed a historical event, Gloria Steinem. As I sat watching Ms. Steinem read a biting feminist newscast (When the Republicans hired call girls to infiltrate the Democratic Convention as spies, they increased their female employment rate by 150%) I had to keep reminding myself: this is prime time TV: As I sat watching Betty Wright singing "I Am Woman", I kept thinking how beautifully this defied all those tiring articles about how black and white women couldn't get together.

Questions

But the part of the show that seemed unusual to me was when Helen and her guests sat on the stage and answered questions: "When did you stop wearing a bra?" "Don't you think women want to stay in the home?" Ms. Reddy and her guests answered these questions directly and without embarrassment. On the final show, during this part, a pimply-faced boy asked, nervously, if he could come up and kiss each of the women. He was told he could do so and, somehow as I watched him kiss each woman on the cheek, it was not a corny scene or an obscene one.

Touching Lives

I'm not sure a TV show can ever reach people or touch them deeply. That screen separating us and the performers prevents us from experiencing anything live, as in a theater. I am sure that this particular show made me laugh a lot, made me feel better about myself, and a few times, moved me. I admit I am biased. I have been strongly influenced by the women's liberation movement. I support it wholeheartedly. Finally, a show came along that appealed to this bias. It's about time! Sparkling kitchen floors, spotless dishes and giggling sink scrubbers never have appealed to me. So, I guess I deserve this show. All women and men deserve more shows like the Helen Reddy Show. She has come the closest to using television in a non-manipulative way. This demonstrates, to me, that when strong, independent women get some power in this media, they can humanize it, using it in creative ways, perhaps even to touch people's lives.
