How to Have Intercourse...
Without Getting Screwed

Part VII

Female Sexuality: A Feminist
Perspective .,

This treatise is the outgrowth of my fem-
inist curiosity about the quality of hetero-
sexual relationships in Western society.
What is the fundamental nature of male-fe-
male relationships as enacted too often
through sexual intercourse? Why do women
engage in coitus?

Substantive factors differentiate the
coital experience for men and for women. In
coitus, men experience a definite physical
release that is usually accompanied by a
more intensive orgasmic release. In short,
men come. Women, on the other hand, do not
necessarily experience orgasm, do not always
come. Statistics vary from the initial Kin-
sey study, which reports that only one-third
of American women experience orgasm during
their first year of marriage, to a recent
study published in Psychology Today of a
supposedly enlightened, sexually free audi-
ence, which reports that 20 percent of the
women never achieve orgasm during inter-
course and another 10 percent achieve orgasm
in only one of four coital experiences.

Further heterosexual discrepancies include
contraception, pregnancy, abortion, and
child care. When and if contraception is
practiced, women are generally responsible.
Women, not men, become pregnant. Women can-
not get legal, medically safe abortions, ex-
cept at unreasonable emotional and financial
costs. Finally, if a child is born, women
bear the primary responsibility for its
care. In sum, in coitus, women do not
necessarily experience physical release or
pleasure; whereas, they do bear tremendous
responsibility.

Sexual attitudes and behavior reflect the
attitudes and behavior that govern any cul-
ture or society. Sexual behavior is symbo-
lic behavior. As Kate Millett puts it in
Sexual Politics:

Coitus can scarcely be said to take
place in a vacuum; although of itself
it appears a biological and physical
activity, it is set so deeply within
the larger context of human affairs
that it serves as a charged microcosm
of the variety of attitudes and
values to which a culture subscribes. 
American society subscribes to the patri-
archy. Its most pervasive ideology is sex-
ual dominion, specifically male supremacy.

Two principles are paramount: (a) male
shall dominate female, and (b) elder male
shall dominate younger.
Sex is a status category with political

implications. Sex defines a relationship

of dominance and subordinance; it defines
power-structured relationships in which
one group, men, controls another, women. As
such, it is a model for all other exploitive
systems, for the larger schema of American
politics. The domination of women by men

is a prototype of the control men have tried
to exercise over other men, that groups,
e.g., racial, have tried to exercise over
other groups, that America as a nation has
tried to exercise over other nations.

According to Hannah Arendt, there are two
ways of maintaining or perpetuating any
power structure: by force or by condition-
ing. Through socialization or "internal
colonization,” most men and most women ac-
cept three basic patriarchal polities or
structures:

1. The first is status: Men are ascribed
superior status; women, inferior status.

2. The second is temperament: The develop-
ment of temperament is based on the needs

of the dominant group (men) and dictated by
what they cherish in themselves and find con-
venient in their subordinates (women). Ac-
cordingly, men are supposed to be rational,
aggressive, intelligent, forceful; women
are supposed to be emotional, passive, ig-
norant, docile, virtuous.

3. The final, and codifying, structure is
role: Women are relegated to menial, domes-
tic labor and to attending children. The
rest of human interest and achievement is
the legitimate concern and dominion of men.

In short, we subscribe to a male supremacist
value system in which the function of the
norm is unthinkingly dictated by, and dele-
gated to, the man; it is a value system
based upon the perpetuation of that which is
convenient for men.

It logically follows that that which is
not convenient for men is not acceptable.
Behavior that is not complementary to male
behavior—normal behavior—is abnormal.
Hence, authentic female behavior (not
defined by, or necessarily in accordance
with, or dependent upon male behavior) is
a priori abnormal. The result is alienation
on the part of most women: alienation from
themselves, in intimate relationships, from
society in general. Women are not rewarded
for being independent, self-determining,
whole human beings. Further, those who dare
to deviate from the norm, those who resist,
or by some accident, miss socialization, are
dealt with by force, the second means of
maintaining the power structure.

(continued on page 8)

Feminist Perspective and Cave 3

Within the man's system, coitus blatantly exemplifies sexual politics on an individual or personal level. Women's sexuality has been defined by men to benefit men until women have learned to believe in their own sexual inferiority.

A long-standing myth of western patriarchal society contends that women have a lesser sex drive than men. Krafft-Ebing, a well-known sexologist of a generation ago, said of women:

"...if she is normally developed mentally and well-bred, her sexual desire is small. If this were not so, the whole world would become a brothel and marriage and family impossible. It is certain that the man that avoids women and the woman who seeks men are abnormal."

A 1869 marriage manual read:

"...There can be no doubt that sexual feeling in the female is, in a majority of cases, in abeyance, and that it requires positive and considerable excitement to be roused at all; and even if roused (which in many instances it never can be), is very moderate, compared with that of the male."

The correlate to this thought is that, since women have a lesser sexual desire, they do not require as much sexual gratification.

Sexual politics was probably most severely codified by Sigmund Freud. I don't believe he was consciously malicious, but rather the confused legatee of a Jewish Viennese patriarchy. He lamented, on one hand, his inability to understand women, while, on the other, he continually diagnosed, defined, and labeled them: less than men.

According to his psychoanalytic perspective, women were not whole human beings, but mutilated males who longed all their lives for a penis and must compensate for its lack. Further, women did not possess a libido, or sex drive. Libido belonged to men. Hence, women were innately passive; men, active.

Freud believed that during the phallic phase of psychosexual development, both boys and girls shift from a primary focus on the mouth and anus as sources of erotic pleasure to their genitalia, the penis for boys, the clitoris for girls. He considered the clitoris to be an atrophied penis, and he defined girls as "little boys" who had literally come too short. However, as the little girl grows up, she must transfer any pleasurable sensations from the clitoris to the vagina, which she discovers later:

"The clitoris in the girl...is in every way equivalent during childhood to the penis....The transition to womanhood very much depends upon the early and complete relegation of this sensitivity from the clitoris over to the vaginal orifice."

The superiority of vaginal over clitoral orgasm was a particularly useful theory. Clitoral women were labeled immature, neurotic, bitchy, masculine, infantile. Vaginal women, on the other hand, were maternal, feminine, mature, normal. Normal, because it was, and is, convenient for men: Vaginal insertion facilitates, both physiologically and psychologically, orgasm for men. Also, to the degree that women believe in vaginal orgasm, they are dependent upon an erect penis, upon a man. Clitoral orgasm affords sexual pleasure independent of the male.

Vaginal orgasm is a myth. Anatomically, all orgasms are centered in the clitoris. This is not to imply that women do not, and cannot, learn to experience orgasm through vaginal insertion, but that the vagina itself is devoid of nerve endings. Dr. Judd Marnor, representative of one of the newer schools of psychoanalysis, frankly admits:

"...The chief sensory area for erogenous sensation in women is localized in the glans clitoris, just as in men it is localized in the homologous glans penis. (The shaft of the penis, like the vagina, is lacking in genital corpuscles.)...Strictly speaking, there is no such thing as vaginal orgasm in the female, any more than we might speak of scrotal, anal, or prostatic orgasm in the male."

Even the adjectives vaginal and clitoral create unnecessary confusion. We must eliminate them. Women, like men, experience orgasm.

One final Freudian myth deserves explanation: penis envy. The penis has served for Freud and his followers as the "unalterable determinant of maleness which women could symbolically envy instead of the power and prestige afforded men in society." And, this plight was conferred on her, not by men but by God, who created women without a penis. Further, the lack of a penis legitimized her role as wife and mother: She transferred her desire for a penis to a desire for a child, and she was especially fortunate if it were a male child. Hence, she was kept home and in a family way. (The Roman etymology for family, familius, means domestic servants.)

Anthropologists have shown that women's sexual response is culturally conditioned. Margaret Mead contends that whether or not a woman experiences orgasm depends not only on physical factors, but even more on where she happens to have been born and reared:

"...Clearly those societies which believe in orgasms for women and produce orgiastic behavior in them are also the ones which employ effective stimulation techniques..."

The ability to achieve orgasm is a potential; it is a learned response. Almost any woman can experience orgasm if effective stimulation is applied in a favorable social and psychological milieu.

Interestingly, the phenomenon of orgasm as a learned response is applicable to men as well as women. According to Doctors Eberhard and Phyllis Kronhausen, ejaculation does not a priori spell orgasm in men. Ejaculation may produce a physiological tension release, but it is not as great as when ejaculation and orgasm coincide. Because ejaculation and orgasm have several aspects in common and outwardly resemble one another, they have been confused as the same thing. This also suggests that some men may be nonorgasmic. In men we call it impotence, implying an unwillingness to act, rather than frigidity, as in women, implying an inactive passivity that simply froze over.

Historically, however, women have learned from, and deferred to, whatever model of sexuality was prescribed by men. Within the

*Recommended reading: "The Myth of the Vaginal Orgasm,” by Ann Koedt. Published by New England Free Press, 791 Tremont Street, Boston, Mass. 02118.

patriarchy, male dominance must be  
maintained, at any cost. The traditional  
"Missionary position," still the only legally  
acceptable position in some states, provides  
a striking example. The man lies on top of  
the woman, placing himself literally in the  
superior position and in control of the sex  
act, making it difficult for her to discover  
her own sexuality and, hence, perpetuating  
the notion of female frigidity.  

Female pleasure or satisfaction is not  
intrinsic in the coital act. Too often it  
is founded in pleasing the man. Isn't that  
why he chose her? His romantic love, if it  
does not disguise the injustice of her social  
position, at least makes it palliative.  

Joan Baez referred to these same politics in  
the Resistance when she said: "Girls say  
'yes' to the boys who say 'no'." Women are  
dependent upon men to win them social status  
and to determine the way they are viewed by  
the world. Survival for a woman, within the  
power structure, is to please, and hence to  
be chosen by a man. He is the conqueror;  
she, the conquered.  

The woman who does not play sex according  
to the rules, who is not conquerable, is  
dealt forceful or violent treatment. Consider  
the verbal abuse women receive. Women  
who are not ladies (the societal ideal:  
virgins or lawful wives) are bitches, whores,  
sluts, pigs, loose, easy; women who are not  
willing on the spot are uptight, frigid,  
cold, square. Consider the act of rape.  
Rape is a form of violence involving the per-  
sonal humiliation of the victim. Whether  
the male supremacist commits the act in fact  
or fantasy, he participates in and perpet-  
uates the prowess myth of rape. The man who  
verbalizes, "She makes me so mad I want to  
fuck her to death," is as guilty as the man  
who penetrates against a woman's will. In  
this category, I include husbands and lovers.  

Kinsey, Ruth Herschberger, and, more  
recently, Masters and Johnson, have challeng-  
ed the aforementioned sexual myths and misin-  
formation with reason and substantive clini-  
cal data. Nonetheless, the liberating po-  
tential of authentic sexual behavior cannot  
be realized as long as politics, i.e., domi-  
nance-subordinance behavior, characterize  
male-female relationships, as long as a  
male-dominated society insists on keeping  
women down. As Germaine Greer points out,  
for example:  

It is not...beyond the scope of...  
theorists to argue that all the women  
tested by Masters and Johnson were  
infantile products of improper condi-  
tioning, and that the fact that all  
orgasms in their samples were clitoral  
does not disprove that vaginal orgasms  
ever existed, could exist, or ought  

to exist....Facts are irrelevant to  
what is basically a value system.  

I believe the challenge to the sexual  
status quo must come from women. To ensure  
physical and psychic survival, we must  
demand new definitions of masculine and  
feminine that do not require dominance of  
one sex over the other, or better yet, do  
away with such antiquated notions completely.  
We, as women, must first get at the roots of  
our own oppression. As we develop self-  
determining, healthy self-concepts and sexual  
expectations, men will change in response.

establishing residence in  
Minneapolis, I am struck by  
the potential power of my eco  
nomic decisions. I must find  
a dentist, a bank, a reliable  
auto mechanic, a veterinarian,  
etc. And women with estab-  
lished families have far more  
diverse needs than I have,  
and thus far more power. I  
believe we are now largely  
wasting this power.

Supporting Women

Personally, I would put up  
with some inconvenience to  
patronize a woman dentist,  
mechanic. I would boycott  
any local business which I  
knew practiced sexism, and I  
would walk to St. Paul, if  
necessary, to avoid placing  

my money with a financial  
institution which denied wom-  
en credit. Not only that,  

but I believe that my mother  
would also! That is, I sus-  
pect that a great many wom-  

en who do not feel committed  
to the Women's Movement, as  
such, would cooperate in a  
venture like this if the nec-  
essary information were read-  
ily available to them at the  
right time. The meat boycott  
showed the economic power that  
women can wield when they are  
angry enough and organized  
enough. The problem is mainly  
one of information. Which  
local taxicab services refuse  
to hire women drivers? Is  
there a local women's carpen-  
try group? Which financial  
agencies and which insurance  
companies are the worst?

What local businesses are  
owned by women?

A clearinghouse of such  
information, if widely pub-  
licized, could help fill this  
need. A Women's Grapevine co.  
could help Twin Cities women  
organize their potential eco-  
nomic power to help other wom-  
en who are struggling to est-  
ablish an economic base, and  
to boycott businesses that are  
hindering such efforts. It  
would act as a better business  
bureau for women. It could  
also function as a clearing-  
house for information about  
local services such as career  
counseling, day care, etc.  
and thus help women take ad-  
vantage of already existing

Economic Grapevine:  
Women - Power

How can we gather the nec-  
essary information and how  
can we keep it current? I  
propose that someone or some  
dedicated group volunteer their  
telephone. Sympathetic  

sisters who are less comm-  
itted could chip in to pay  
the phone bill. Then, women  
with information or complaints  
or services to render should  
be solicited to call this  
number and share their inform-  
ation. The telephone number  
would have to be well publi-  
cized initially. There are  
several papers in the Twin  
Cities which might be very  
eager to provide the Women's  
Grapevine with some free pub-  
licity—Changes, for instance  
or perhaps "The Minnesota  
Daily". I suspect a little  
bit of brainstorming on our  
part could find a newsworthy  
"angle" for the 'Tribune.'  
Certainly, every women's or-  
ganization in the Twin Cities  
should be called and informed  
of our telephone number. Some  
interesting bumper stickers  

could be printed up to adver-  
tise the Women's Grapevine.

Clearinghouse

All the information re-  
ceived would have to be ver-  
ified and filed. Once a fair  
amount of information was col-  
lected, other women could call  
the number and receive the  
information on file and be  
urged to verify it. After  
operation had begun, the na-  
ture of the questions re-  
ceived would help the Wom-  
en's Grapevine to define  
areas in which more inform-  
ation and services were need-  
ed. It might, for instance,  
spur the formation of a car-  
pentry collective, or help a  
struggling band survive. Or  
alter sexist hiring practices  
in a specific business.

A Women's Grapevine would  
be a helpful clearinghouse  
for information, but its use  
would probably still be lim-  
ited to the counter culture.  
A regular column in "Gold  
Flower" could be started to  
publicize what we knew and to  
encourage more women to vol-  
unteer information. The next  
step would be to publish a

Yellow Pages which is publi-  
shed in Chicago as a direct-  
ory of Black businesses.

Mobilizing

The publishing of the Dir-

dividuals and businesses which

reciative of the business

Grapevine and would be eager

ectory. Thus it should be

help with distribution. For

effectively distributing the

Although most women who are  
reading this paper are comm-

of our society, our ability  
to attack it at its economic  
base is being limited by our  
lack of organization and in-

for the Twin Cities are rel-

which could help us mobilize  
more of our resources to  
help our sisters, to pressure  
our oppressors, and to alter  
sexual power relationships.

The success of this project  
depends entirely on the real  
dedication of a large number  
of women. We need a phone.  

We need all the committed vol-  
unteers we can find. We need  
money. We need the active  
support of every woman who  

has experienced discrimination.

One is the public accommodations section which is 363.03 subdivision 3: "It is an unfair discriminatory practice:  

To deny any person full and equal enjoyment of the goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, and accommodations of a place of public accommodation because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin or sex."  

In the view of the department of human rights, public accommodations includes any credit or loan granting.  

But there is a more specific provision which is in subdivision 7 of that same section and that plainly says: Credit Sex Discrimination: “It is an unfair discriminatory practice to discriminate in the extension of credit to a person because of sex."  

So hopefully these two provisions will alleviate a lot of this real hardship. You know, the attitude of some credit grantors...I've even known of bank officials to say, "I don't want my wife going around town running up charge accounts." This was actually said by a bank official to a woman seeking to  

set up an independent checking account. Now this was an appalling statement for him to make.  

You must understand that these new provisions don't mean that every woman is going to be granted a charge account, credit card or a loan. She will be subject to the same criteria that a man is, but this is fine. Many times, in fact it's almost  

been universal, the criteria for extending credit has been different for men than for women. This is what the law intends to remedy. If a person is credit worthy under a certain set of circumstances, that is, has a certain job, a certain amount of assets, a bank account, home ownership, a car, then that person, whether the person be male or female, should be judged as a credit risk on an equal basis with all others in the same group.  

WHAT SHOULD A WOMAN DO IF SHE FEELS SHE'S BEEN UNFAIRLY DENIED CREDIT?  

Of course, being affiliated with the Department of Human Rights, I believe that the first thing she should do  

would be to contact our department with an accurate description of what has happened and file a charge of discrimination. Now you know discrimination on the basis of sex in credit has been banned prior to August 1 in the cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul. Now, however, the state has the same provision. Our enforcement procedures  

in my opinion work a little more efficiently. I'm sure that if any of the representatives of the other departments read this they will challenge that. But it is  

my opinion that we do have a more protective investigation and complaint handling procedure so that we could get faster, equitable relief.  

Why I Didn’t Review Mailer  

When I was in high school, I often engaged in a characteristic fantasy of the oppressed. I imagined myself a famous writer, embarking on a long-awaited autobiography. One day I would stroll into the office of the assistant principal, who was the discipline officer, and ask for permission to tour the school. My reason, I would drawlingly explain, was that I was writing this autobiography, but unfortunately could not remember a thing about my years at his school. I hoped that a short walk about would spur my reluctant memory.  

I had the same kind of fantasy when I began reading  

The “Liberal”  

or  

“OK, So you’re getting screwed--you don’t have  

It happens every time. I meet a man who bears all the "right" signs--longish hair, faded jeans, McGovern sticker on his VW. His conversation puts me at ease (making yogurt at home, corporate waste, Nixon's latest incredible move) and before I know it, I find myself relaxed, opening up, trusting him.  

"My wife used to be in Women's Advocates."  

"Oh, really?" I ask excitedly.  

"Yes. A lot of those women were quite upset when she picked up with me." Soon I find out why. "Some of them would rather hate you than look at you," is the beginning of a long and increasingly insensitive succession of complaints about reverse discrimination. I am unprepared, my defenses down (I had trusted him), helpless. I manage, "People can get bitter when they've been kicked around enough." Both he and my liberal female (male-identified) friend miss the understatement. She speaks, not of the immeasurable destruction that women have suffered at the hands of men, but of the alienating effect of women's bitterness.  

Why is it that no self-respecting liberal would speak of how "alienating" black hatred of whites is, yet would seek to rob women of one means of regaining self-respect, righteous anger? My female friend fears anger, because she sees only its destructive potential, and because it's not “nice.” Men fear anger in women, because they fear that once women regain a healthy  

sense of themselves, they may no longer need men—and they are right.  

I, too, agree that an excess of bitterness can be destructive (though my concern is for the woman who feels the bitterness). But the way for men to deal with that bitterness is not to criticize (a very male reaction, and the way the bitterness started in the first place) but to understand and empathize. The feminist revolution is more than equal rights for women. It is a triumph of creative "female" values over destructive "male" values. And when our revolution is accomplished, I, a woman who trusts over and over and over again, will no longer have to listen to men lecture on female bitterness.  

— Susan Cushman

University Women's Liberation. There were

and the group operated in a vacuum,” began  
Jackie Byrd, spokeswoman for Minnesota  
Feminists.  
“The organization was formed because a num-  
ber of members in University Women's Lib-  
eration felt that the organization had be-  
come unhealthy and needed changes. The  
organization had become unhealthy in our  
minds because we felt that the number of  
women's needs being met were almost nil.  
And it was really important to the women  
that were discussing the problems of the  
organization that more women's needs be met.  
"Some of the problems that we felt were  
happening were political ideologies were  
infringing on various women's rights. Fem-  
inism we felt should become the ideology.  
That women should come first and be the prim-  
ary focus. And the issues worked upon  
should be woman-oriented and we found in  
University Women's Liberation this wasn't  
happening and the changes were really nec-  
essary in order to make feminism the prime  
factor in a feminist organization.

A Positive Name

"First off we changed the name from Uni-  
versity Women's Liberation to Minnesota  
Feminists. Because we felt that University  
Women's Liberation was a name that had come  
from that past. And we are now moving for-  
ward in a positive direction. Which means  
that feminism is a positive name, a pro-  
active name, a name that is right now and  
that is very productive. Whereas women's  
liberation is a negative name. Liberation  
from something as opposed to feminism which  
is moving towards something. With a new  
name we could change the image and we could  
change a great many of the problems that had  
developed in University Women's Liberation.  
So out of the new name grew—one: a philos-  
ophy; two: a structure; and three: a pol-  
icy," continued Jackie.

"Feminism the pro-active versus the react-  
ive. We see ourselves as a pro-active, pro-  
women and positive directed organization.  
This is what we need to keep. And to do this  
we have to meet the needs of more than four  
or five women.

Feminist Philosophy  
"When we were discussing the change in  
the organization's direction we discussed  
philosophy a great deal. What we discovered  
was feminism is what each one of us lived  
day by day. It is integrated into our day-  
to-day behavior. Since it is integrated in-  
to our daily behavior, it also has to be  
integrated into the organization. It is done  
by implementing the things learned, the  
things we experience day by day, into the  
organization, which is very difficult. When  
we espouse feminism, it means we are willing  
to care about other women, to help other wo-  
men, not to stab other women in the back,

"To have input that is total we have set  
up a unique organization," Jackie started  
explaining the structure of Minnesota Femin-  
ists. "It involves the large group which  
is divided into awareness groups, specific  
task-oriented groups, ongoing groups and a  
steering committee.

"We had all read a number of articles and  
specifically 'The Tyranny of Structureless-  
ness' by Jo Freeman in MS (July 1973) and  
decided that one of the basic problems with  
University Women's Liberation was this tyr-

port of a woman involved in feminism for a  
long time or just starting out to continue

“The task forces—women's studies,

cerning women.

esota Daily" page for contact inter-univer-  
sity, a finance committee, a public relations

DULUTH WOMEN

by Pat Monaghan

Down the alley behind the  
Duluth YWCA, there is a small  
building—no more seedy-look-  
ing than most in that time-  
worn neighborhood—with a  
barn-red door.

Inside, stairs lead to an  
airy office and lounge. The  
freshly-painted walls are  
still bare; a desk, several  
chairs and a few bookshelves  
are scattered across the  
wooden floor. The high win-  
dows look over grey downtown  
Duluth to the historic aerial  
bridge.

Because Duluth is a city  
where I spent some important  
years, and because I still  
have a sore spot in my heart  
for that unfashionable old  
city, my curiosity had been  
piqued when a friend (dis-  
dainfully noting that she  
"didn't need that sort of  
stuff") told me that Duluth  
had a struggling women's cen-  
ter. So on my next northern  
visit I located the center  
and its coordinator, Kay  
Slick.

She began apologetically,  
explaining that things had  
"just been a mudpie" all sum-  
mer, and that the center was  
just beginning its fall pro-  
gramming. At her office in  
a corner of the center's  
front room—the rest is work-  
space and a rudimentary li-  
brary—Kay described the  
center's history and plans  
for the public opening next  
month.

It has been nearly two  
years since Duluth women  
first recognized a need for  
a women's center, Kay related.  
The idea was tossed around by  
local women’s groups and  

concerned individuals; a  
successful women's confer-  
ence last year gave added  
impetus to the proposal.  
Then, last year, activist  
Kris Nelson began organi-  
zing the center through EPI  
EPIC (Educational Project  
Involving Consumers), a fed-  
erally-funded program oper-  
ating out of the Duluth med-  
ical school. When Kris left  
EPIC, Kay took over the po-  
sition and continued agita-  
ting for a center.

Last spring the YWCA of-  
fered use of the roomy but  
run-down Decker Building on  
a rent-free basis for a year,  
with rent to be negotiated  
thereafter. The building  
seemed too big for the pro-  
posed center, but another  
group volunteered to use the  
downstairs for a day-care  
center, and the Duluth Wo-  
men's Center became a tan-  
gible reality.

Repairs—originally esti-  
mated at nearly $1600 for  
materials and labor—were  
executed at enormous saving  
by Duluth women who sanded  
floors, painted and other-  
wise assisted the renovation  
effort. Since that flurry  
of activity, however, the  
center has been struggling.

"I wouldn't say there's a  
high feminist consciousness  
in Duluth," said Kay Slick  
wearily. "There's a need for  
advocacy, a need for rape  
counseling, a need for var-  
ious referrals. But there's  

nothing here yet that women  
can identify with as a wo-  
man's thing."

Kay sees the Duluth Wo-  
men's Center as offering “an  
alternative to women who  
see themselves as being  
locked in" to traditional  
female roles, but admitted  
"it's hard to reach those  
women—they're still afraid  
to come here."

To Kay, part of the prob-  
lem in generating support is  
"the exceptional woman thing.  
I know a lot of women who are  
personally strong, but they  
don't see themselves as need-  
ing the center." Nonetheless  
she feels that “the city does  
need a women's center. We  
just don't know who the wo-  
men are that need us, or wh  
where they are."

Projects begun by the cen-  
ter, in addition to con-  
sciousness-raising sessions  
and related groups, include a  
weekly radio program, a dance  
class, and an ad hoc referral  
service for lawyers and doc-  
tors.

Kay described abortion  
counseling as "shallow,  
fragmented and underground”  
in Duluth, pointing out that  
only one abortion had been  
performed there since the Su-

AN INTERVIEW  
WITH  

KAY SLICK

preme Court ruling last win-  
ter. Duluth women must seek  
abortions in the Twin Cities  
area; younger women have dif-  
ficulty finding birth con-  
trol services as well.

Kay Slick feels isolated,  
"bleak but not really dis-  
couraged," she explained.  
"Women here still see the  
women's movement as being  
external to their lives. Right  
now we're still really into a  
self thing, heavy self-exam-  
ination, thinking about how  
being a woman is affecting  
our lives. But we need the  
women's center, even if its  
function is confined entirely  
to offering personal support."

STAR? FEMINISM HAS NO STARS!

Two Letters Respond to  
Minnesota Feminist Article

IDEALS OF FEMINISM DIE

Dear Sisters:

I read with interest the article "Pro-active  
Women--Minnesota Feminists Born" in the  
August issue. As an active member of Minn-  
esota Feminists (formerly University of  
Minnesota Women's Liberation) who is also  

in the Young Socialist Alliance, I feel I  
must counter certain biases presented.

The spokesperson for Minnesota Feminists  
stated Minnesota Feminists was formed be-  
cause "there were the negative feelings of  
the group (Women's Liberation) being a YSA  
front, a clique that was meeting the needs  
of only four or five women." There were  
several allegations in the article that Wom-  
en's Liberation was not responsive to the  
needs of women. A brief review of last  
year's activities is needed:

University of Minnesota Women's Libera-  
tion won the fight with the University  
Health Service, winning pap smears and preg-  
nancy tests at no extra charge, abortion re-  
ferrals and counseling, an ombudsperson, and  
in-service staff training to make health  
service employees more sensitive to women  
and the need to treat us in a non-sexist,  
non-patronizing manner.

We continued our work with women's stud-  
ies--an idea that originated in our group  
and grew into the existing women's studies  
program.

We picketed two public hospitals which  
refused to give women abortions.

We sent speakers to high schools, college  
classrooms and community groups.

We sponsored "The New Feminism Conference:  
Cultural, Political and Educational Impli-  
cations", which involved almost 30 pro-fem-  
ale groups in the city--10 of which directly  
participated in planning meetings, along  
with individuals from high schools and the  
community. Over 300 people attended the  
conference.

We sponsored a women's fair and film fes-  
tival with over 100 people attending.

We presented various educationals through-  
out the year.

Now, just whose needs were not being met?  
Certainly, Women's Liberation was responsive  
to the needs of campus and community women  
by leading struggles for better health care,  
better education and abortion rights.

To say "the number of women's needs being  
met were almost nil" implies a serious dis-  
agreement on what the needs of women are.  
The "needs" of women can only  
be interpreted, in light of the article, to  
mean the individual needs of women in deal-  

ing with personal problems that arise from  
living in a sexist society. Individual  
needs are important--no one wishes to deny  
that. Women's Liberation has always made  
attempts to include consciousness-raising in  
the organization--some were successful, oth-  
ers were not.

C-R and self-awareness groups are important  
factors in developing an understanding of  
our oppression, but they must not become  
isolated from activity--activity which also  
leads one's consciousness to higher levels.  
No woman, no matter how high her conscious-  
ness, or how deep her self-awareness, is  
free in a sexist society. Society's insti-  
tutions, be they religious, judicial, legis-  
lative, educational, medical or commercial,  
discriminate against women and promote the  
myth of our inferiority. To attack women  
(such as women in the YSA) who focus most  
of their energy on the broad, societal iss-  
ues that face us, is to lack perspective of  
the scope of the feminist struggle. Our  
fight goes beyond the level of individual  
solutions of coping in a sexist society: A  
tremendous amount of power must be generated  
to make society meet the needs of over one-  
half of its members.

This is the basic issue of disagreement:

How do we best build the women's movement?  
Is it by C-R and self-awareness groups or by  
organizing women around the issues that aff-  
ect our lives. Certainly, women who support  
the former are sincere in their beliefs, but  
I believe history will prove the latter stra-  
tegy correct--as it has in other struggles  
of the oppressed, such as the suffragist move  
ment.

It is absurd to think that women who want to  
build a powerful women's movement would dis-  
courage anyone who is interested in belong-  
ing to a feminist organization and anyone  
who wants to develop organizational skills--  
skills that are vital in building a movement.  
Every woman is desperately needed to be a  
leader.

Anyone who has taken on organizational re-  
sponsibility will understand problems org-  
anizers have: getting people to share re-  
sponsibility, to follow through with their  
commitments and to actively participate in  
the boring day-to-day survival responsibil-  
ities. People who have had such experiences  
will recognize the fallacy in the argument  
that organizers won't reach out to new  
people and won't teach new people skills--  
be they making leaflets or spending evenings  
on the phone raising money to writing press  
releases and holding news conferences. I  
was not born with any of these skills. I  
learned them from "older" members in Women's  
Liberation who were eager to develop new,  
continued on page 5 :

LETTERS — Entitled from pre 4

young leaders. Sharing organizational skills
and responsibilities is a two-way process—
people must want to learn. That desire
comes from a very real sense of the magni-
tude of the feminist struggle and the will-
ingness to dedicate much of one's time and
energy to tedious chores. That, in essence,
is the key to leadership. People who do not
fully understand the pressures and intrica-
cies of organizational work (because they
have not been in that position) obviously
cannot appreciate the perspective of active
organizers. The only way for them to learn
is to get their hands dirty with the chores
of responsibility—not just talk about ideas.
Implementation is the only standard by which
to judge the correctness of ideas and cor-
rectness makes for respected leadership.

Minnesota Feminists has inherited a fine
history of activism from Women's Liberation.
Strength and the ability to work effectively
around the issues that affect campus and
community women come from unity, not from
divisiveness on personal and political diff-
erences. My feelings at this point are ones
of extreme sadness. The feelings of many
women have been hurt. Some are YSA or Soci-
alist Workers Party members; others are wom-
en who also have been excluded from two
months of Minnesota Feminist meetings be-
cause they were considered to be too close
to members of the YSA on either a personal
or political level. That is not my defini-
tion of sisterhood. I think it's time this
divisiveness stops. We must concentrate our
efforts and energies on our real enemies,
not on each other.

Sincerely,

Becky Bohan

IDEALS OF FEMINISM DIE

I am not and have never been a member of
the Socialist Workers Party. Nonetheless,
I was lumped with the arbitrarily chosen
scapegoats, boxed in, and shoved out. I am
the victim of a purge of University of Minn-
esota Women's Liberation. My hopes about
sisterhood and the moral superiority of wom-
en have flown out the window. One whom I
once saw as a beloved sister, I now see as a
tragic power tripper.

The organization now called Minnesota Fem-
inists was not started this summer by twenty
dissatisfied women, as Jackie Byrd alleges.
It was started in 1971 during the student
strikes, under the name of University of
Minnesota Women's Liberation. Its purpose
was to meet and discuss the special needs of
women, which were not being met by the male-
dominated New Left, which Robin Morgan ref-
ers to as "The Boy's Movement." The organ-
ization has been extremely active and has
maintained its radical feminist line during
apathetic and hellsapoppin' political times.

One cannot accurately claim we met the
needs of only four or five women; or the
Socialist party. We have sponsored speak-
outs on rape, abortion, and day care. In the
1972-1973 school year we held campaigns for
legal abortion and exposed some of the
incompetent and dehumanizing gynecological
care women were getting at the University
health service. We demanded and got, with
the help of hundreds of righteously angry
women, pap smears at no additional charge,
pregnancy tests at no additional charge, and
an end to moral harassment at the hands of

certain gynecologists in the employ of the
University. In the same year, we sponsored,
with MWAAC, a conference and march for legal
abortion, both of which were attended by
several hundred people.

This past year our area of concentration
has been Women's Studies. Another victim of
exclusion, also not a socialist, developed
the idea for a course called "Feminism and
American Intellectual Life." The course
reached large numbers of women both in the
classroom and at the public lectures. One of
the seven speakers at the lectures was Robin
Morgan. Women's Liberation obtained a
Women's Studies Program at the University of
Minnesota, and we are determined to remain
available to agitate for more classes.

Women's Liberation has organized CR
groups and Women's Coalitions to lead anti-
war marches. Individually, we have been
involved in lobbying and letter writing cam-
paigns for the ERA, abortion, and we have
been involved in the political campaigns of
candidates from the Democrat and Socialist
parties. This spring we sponsored a confer-
ence featuring the great Flo Kennedy. (Who,
by the way, told us, "If you want to kick ass,
you've got to learn to aim high." She warned
us about "horizontal hostility," that is,
hostility toward one's equally oppressed
peers.) We also put on a Women's Fair and
Film Festival, providing an outlet to many
local female artists.

The activities we have sponsored have been

Only six men and many more women came to
the performance of “Lysistrata" which I saw
at Dudley Riggs' Experimental Theater Co.
on Washington Ave. A pity for both sexes.
More men should have come to enjoy the fami-
liar male buffoonery which clutters our mo-
dern stage. The women should have skipped
this chance to see a mythical heroine in
action, and rather stayed home that evening
to watch a very real Billie Jean King dis-
patch another Riggs.

For those few readers who are curious
about what "Lysistrata" is like as a man's
play, I'll recite the transformation. The
men are introduced as crippled, yet still
operative wind-up soldiers in an extended
scene which opens this adaptation. (In
Aristophanes' "Lysistrata," the opening
scene belongs to the women.) When the women
are finally brought on in this misbegotten
production, Lysistrata talks like a carni-
val barker, a female Professor Harold Hill.
The rest of the women are twittering cheer-
leaders. Remember, I recite; I don't ex-
plain.

The women agree to deprive the men of
the sexual access until the men settle on
a peaceful compromise. Lysistrata incites
her unlikely troops to storm the Acropolis.
They throw the men out and the separation
begins.

The rest of the performance concentrates
on the men's sexual agonies as they attempt
to wrest their women from the seat of power
and hustle them back to hearth and home.

A sausage-shaped pink balloon is used as a
battering ram and returns limp from the
fray. The men clutch their crotches, wail
out their desires, and beg for a normal life
in which women and war are compatible plea-
sures.

This clowning was intermittently funny,
but these laughs should not have belonged to
the men. It is the women who recognize
their husbands and protectors as comedians.
The comedy is sharpest when the women dis-
parage their men's military pretensions.

By Susan Cushman

A Review

Referring to Rogers' translation of the
Greek comedy, I find the lines:

LYSISTRATA. Now in the market you see them
like Corybants, jangling about with
their armor of mail.

Fiercely they stalk in the midst of the
crockery, sternly parade by the cabbage
and kale...

STRATYLLIS. Lately I witnessed a captain
of cavalry, proudly the while on his
charger he sat,

Witnessed him, soldierly, buying an omelet
stowing it all in his cavalry hat...

Off runs a shop-girl, appalled at the
sight of him, down he sits soldierly,
gobbles her fruit.

The women in the Experimental Theater Co.
production have no lines like that. They
are continually and deliberately upstaged
by the men. Lysistrata is nearly a minor
character. I can only suppose that the
director, James Monitor, slanted the pro-
duction toward the only kind of humor and
heroics he understands. "Lysistrata" is
simply not his play, and once he got his
hands on it, it could not be ours either.

By the play's end, the antiwar humor has
been drowned out by a deluge of sexuality.
The men are "hot" and a painted sun glowers
down on them. What do they do on this
sweltering day? They eat donuts -- linger-
ingly, lovingly. No doubt every hole is
supposed to be a vagina, but as I watched
one soldier shove his staff through this
tight little pastry, the resemblance to an
asshole was unmistakable. Monitor's over-
zealous attempts to emphasize a heterosex-
ual tension sometimes take strange turns.

"Lysistrata" ends, of course, with peace
and a nominal victory for the women. But
it's the men, always the men, who are
smiling.

Feminist Poets to Read in October

The Women Poets of the Twin Cities, a  
loose confederation of local poets which  
sponsors readings of women's work and  
poetry workshop sessions, will host two  
readings this fall. One, to be held in  
mid-October, will feature poets Jenne  
Andrews, Patricia Hampl, and Carolyn Vo-  
gel. At the other, local women will read  
poetry concerning women's fears of, and  
reactions to, the crime of rape; the  
reading is a benefit for a member of the  
organization who was attacked and beaten  
this summer. Dates and places of the  
readings have not yet been announced.

Jenne Andrews, whose book "In Pursuit  
of the Family" will be published soon,  
grew up in New Mexico and studied  
creative writing at Colorado State. Dur-  

ing her two years in Minnesota, her work  
has been published in Ms. and many poetry  
magazines.

Carolyn Vogel of Red Wing majored in  
writing at Vassar, then turned to teach-  
ing high school English and speech. Until  
moving to Minneapolis last year, Vogel  
was an investigative reporter and women's  
editor for the Red Wing newspaper.

Patricia Hampl edits the KSJN publica-  
tion "Preview" and co-edits the poetry  
magazine "The Lamp in the Spine." A St.  
Paul native, she studied creative writing  
in Iowa and is currently at work on a  
series of essays on women writers and an  
article on Minnesota feminist Meridel  
LeSueur.

by Mary Hastings  

Deeply-felt farewells are always eloquent to  

Lee Allen as Bunty Brads essays an energetic,  
the lover and the beloved.  

if drunken, roller skate dance.  

However, outsiders rarely can perceive the  
private beauty of these leavetakings and of-  
ten grow restive, embarrassed and, sadly,  
bored.  

After the "Montage," however, the play loses  
its vitality. Ms. Havoc's characters suffer  
human weaknesses and are victims of cosmic  
cruelties. But the author does not engage  
the audience's sympathies.  

Such is the case with June Havoc's farewell  
to vaudeville, "I, Said the Fly," which had  
its world premiere September 20 at the Guth-  
rie Theater.  

Alma Marvel is pregnant and can't stop  
taking dangerous pratfalls because her hus-  
band/partner can't carry their act alone.  

The play, subtitled "A Souvenir," consti-  
tutes Ms. Havoc's remembrance of her life  

in vaudeville, which began when she was two-  
year-old "Baby June" and continued through  
her incarnation as "Miss Dainty June, the  
tiniest toe dancer in the world."  

Fanny Brad agonizes over Bunty's increasing  
dependence on the bottle.  

But I could perceive these dilemmas only at  
one remove—as though the author had anes-  
thetized her characters' pain.  

Vaudevillians and Geeks  

In "I, Said the Fly," Ms. Havoc presents the  
plight of a company of shopworn vaudevill-  

ians—Fanny and Bunty Brads, Big Gurn, Harry  
and Alma Marvel "And Company."  

Only Kenneth Welsh reached me in his por-  
trayal of Big Gurn, a second-rate performer  
who sadistically brutalizes "And Company,"  
the untalented young woman who assists him  
with the rats and guinea pigs who co-star  
with Big Gurn.  

The group is stranded in a mid-western tank  
town, struggling to avoid the fate of "geek  
acts" (performances in which animals are tor-  
tured and killed for the audience's edifica-  
tion).  

Welsh is repellant and convincing when he  
taunts "And Company" with her inability to  
commit suicide.  

Moths and Acrobats  

The group receives notifications from their  
agents that booking offices are closing:  
vaudeville is dead.  

The author mixes the dreamy, rather abstract  
quality of the "Montage" with the melo-  
dramatic "realism" of the second act.  

The finest moments in the production come at  
the beginning. A "Montage" of vaudevillians  
parades before the audience before the story  
begins.  

From time to time, silent tumblers and  
acrobats appear and mime a routine while  
the play's action goes forward. These  
attempts at surreal symbolism fail, as does  
the introduction of a moth-like figure in  
pink gauze who wafts across the stage dur-  
ing scene changes.  

Meet the Family  

The audience meets Bunty Brads and Family  
(Ms. Havoc plays Fanny Brads). In this re-  
creation of an old vaudeville routine, Ms.  
Havoc gives the audience the most fulfilling  
moments of the evening. Although she is  
well into middle age, she retains an econom-  
ical dancer's body and the confidence that  
must come from performing since infancy.  

Although "I, Said the Fly" is only as good  
as the "Montage" which opens it, the appear-  
ance of June Havoc is impressive.  

Seeing this talented, widely experienced  
woman was justification for my evening. I  
hope her next play is worthy of her.  

The "Montage" has a cinematic, "Felliniesque"  
quality. And, Barbara Byrne intensifies  

this mood as Alma Marvel, a sweet clown in  
baggy pants—very reminiscent of Giulietta  
Massini.  

Performances of "I, Said the Fly" continue  
with matinees and evening performances  
through September, October and November.

"I mean, do you know any-
thing about your car?
Beyond how to start it?"

--St. Paul administrator
to "Gold Flower" reporter

KKK KKK KK kkk

The fall I turned sixteen, my
father took me out to the gar
age and made me change a tire
on the family station wagon.
If I was going to drive, I had
to be able to take care of
the simple emergencies. The
fall I turned 22, I bought my
first car and my father and

I spent another session in
the garage reviewing jumper
cables, carburetors, spark
plugs, and heater hoses.
Which was not much in terms
of the infinite number of
things that can go wrong with
a car, but it was more than
most men and women know about
the vehicle they depend upon
so heavily.

Peculiarities

It always seemed peculiar to
me that in a school system
which taught me how to brush
my teeth, use a compound mi-
croscope, and shoot a bow
and arrow I was never taught
how to do something as sim-
ple and essential as change a
tire on a car. But then,
neither was my brother. Auto
repair and maintenance essen-
tially remains a mystery to
us both.

Male Fantasies

That's why most Auto Mechan-
ics classes in the Twin

Cities area assume at the be-
ginning that students don't
know anything about cars "and
most of them don't." And,
according to South Community
School Director Gary Soule,
automobile classes designed
specifically for women oper-
ate on an assumption that is
totally erroneous. "The idea
that boys start in Auto Mech-
anics with more background
than girls is just not true
as far as we're concerned."
Apparently, men just bring

in a few more pet fantasies;
fantasies which are quickly
dispelled once work on cars
really begins.

Courses in the Twin Cities
to help people better under-
stand their automobiles range
from elementary classroom in-
troductions to full scale
work on a variety of engines
and specialized problems.
Offered at a reasonable cost
in well-equipped facilities,
such night courses are popu-

lar among both sexes and
appear well-organized and re-
sponsibly taught.

The interest and ability of
women to work on cars is
accepted, respected, and
highly encouraged at most
community schools. Although
some schools like South teach
all coeducational courses,
other schools offer a few
courses exclusively for wo-
men to encourage them to en-
roll. And although no wo-
man has ever been used as an
instructor, Stan Baraga, Dir-
ector of the Minneapolis Adult
Education Program, states
emphatically that "if we had
a good female mechanic, we'd
use her for sure."

Top People

In general, "women are sur-
prised by what they can end
up doing," reports David
Barkmeier, Auto Maintenance
Instructor at South High.
According to Barkmeier, women
tend to take the course more
seriously and are therefore
more meticulous and successful
in their work.

"Three women were my top
people in last year's Auto
Maintenance class. Between
them, they tuned up eight
cars--they brought in the
cars of neighbors, friends,
everybody."

Fun Tune-Ups

Barkmeier tries to not only
teach the basics of Auto
Maintenance in his course, but
give students a feeling for
reasonable repair charges and
suggestions for cutting costs.

Nancy Moody, one of Bark-
meier's star pupils, was also
glowing in her description of
the course.

"My girlfriend and I de-
cided to take the course be-
cause it was so expensive to
have the car fixed all the
time. My husband did a lot
of our car work and had some
of the tools, but I was tired
of just helping him. I wanted
to get beyond just tagging a-
long."

"It was really fun. We got
into doing tune-ups, install-
ing new shock absorbers, and
packing wheel bearings. I
learned some things that my
husband didn't know and we got
good advice on tools and eq-
uipment to invest in."

"There were 15 people in the
course and maybe half were
women. Some girls tended to
play down their ability and

Auto Mechanic, cont.

ask guys for help; other wo-
men wanted to do it on their
own and resented help. On
the whole, though, women
seemed more patient and thor-
ough!

"I guess the best thing I got
from the course was the confi-
dence that if something went
wrong with my car, I was not
at the mercy of someone else.
Even if I don't want to do
the work myself, I know what
is involved and what to ex-
pect from a garage."

Instructor Barkmeier echoes
Nancy Moody's thoughts. "Most
of the women we get really
want to learn how to do it
themselves. They don't want
to rely on husbands or boy-
friends and they don't want
to be taken in by filling
stations and ripped off every
time they have to take their
cars into a garage."

95% Curious

Girls are also enrolling in
high school Auto Mechanics
courses during the day. As I
talked with Barkmeier and a-
nother instructor at South
High, three girls in the back-
ground were taking a test on
ignition systems, along with
fifteen high school boys.

"I suppose 95% of the girls I
get here during the day are
just curious," stated Bark-
meier. "They think it's a fun
class to take. But at the
end of the course, I'll make

recommendations to anyone who
I think has the capability to
become a good mechanic." So
far, he hasn't run across a
woman with such aspirations,
but he feels there have been
a few who had the ability.

Options, Options

Another option open to Twin
Cities residents who wish to
work on their own cars are
do-it-yourself garages.
Community Garage, 344 East 19th
St. (335-0663) is a
loose club-school organization
of about 150 people, almost
50% of whom are women. For
$10 a year, members are free
to use garage space and equip-
ment and enlist the services
of their personal mechanic.
Do-It-Yourself Auto-Repair at
701 West Excelsior Blvd. also
offers garage space and tools
on an hourly rental basis. A
mechanic consultant is avail-
able, as well as the service
of analyzing a potential used
car for a buyer.

Despite the fact that I still
wouldn't know what to do if
smoke started billowing out of
my engine on Highway 94 during
rush hour, it is comforting
to know that in terms of opp-
ortunities, Twin Cities real-
ity is far more encouraging
than the myth.

A Funeral

It was the first funeral I had ever been
to in my life. People I have known have
died before, but no one this close, and so
I took a day off work to go to her funeral
and to try and work into my system the fact
of her death. She was only 33. The thing
about death is, you can't take it piece by
piece and absorb it gradually. It has to

be swallowed whole. I have never seen a
dead person before either, so the shock of
the open casket was hard for me. I hadn't

really cried about her death yet, but when
the man in a grey suit carefully closed the
lid over her face, I did cry... And as I
looked around I saw many old friends, men
and women, crying. The whole service was
full of moments like the closing of the cas-
ket -- triggering off sobs or muffled weep-
ing. The principal of my old school spoke
for the majority of the time, and he calmly
recalled events, characteristics, jokes
about her life in the school and in the
world. And there were moments during the
service when we laughed, too. Maybe this
was one of the finest tributes to Barbara --
we couldn't think about her without smiles
because she brought so much humor into our
lives.

When I think back on the funeral and the
hours I spent afterwards in the Junior High
where I had taught the year before, I am
struck by a new warmth and tenderness in the
experience which never existed so strongly
and openly before with those same people.
And when I narrow it down even further; I
think it had to do with the fact that men
cried openly, touched more and expressed

all ranges of emotion without self-conscious-
ness. Funerals and deaths appear to be the
only times men are given the freedom to cry
like this, to sob openly, to put their arms
around one another, or women, without feel-

When I went into the school, I also felt

luck we had in marrying the men we did, and
the principal understood.

I walked out of the school sensing that
something very fine had been let loose in
everyone there. And I guess, the sight of
the tear-streaked faces of the men stays
with me most vividly. At the time there
were no behaviors assigned to men and women.
We held each other that day. We often
touched and we talked a lot. I hope it
does not take a funeral or a death to bring
about this kind of openness and freedom, but
that men and women can experience it simply
because it is the richest and fullest way
to learn about ourselves.

On Fighting Sex Discrimination, Or ----

A Three-Part Series

“YOU’RE NOTHING BUT A

PACK OF CARDS”

The author was, until re-
cently, employed by a Twin Cities firm. In
May 1972 she filed a sex discrimination
charge against the corporation with the Minn-
esota Department of Human Rights. Subse-
quently, she also filed a charge of race and
sex discrimination against the corporation
with the federal Equal Employment Opportuni-
ties Commission (EEOC).

The State Commissioner of Human Rights, in
January 1973, returned a decision of "no
probable cause” to assume the corporation
was discriminating against women. The auth-

PART I

"No, no:" said the Queen. "Sentence first--
verdict afterwards."

"Stuff and nonsense!" said Alice loudly.
"The idea of having the sentence first!"

"Hold your tongue:" said the Queen, turning
purple.

"I won't," said Alice.

"Off with her head!" the Queen shouted at the
top of her voice. Nobody moved.

"Who cares for you?" said Alice (she had
grown to her full size by this time).
"You're nothing but a pack of cards!"

--Alice in Wonderland, Lewis
Carroll

In the past four years, women have begun to
use the legal tools at their disposal in eff-
orts to attain jobs that pay fairly, promo-
tions they deserve and expanded educational
opportunities. Today, news of sex discrimi-
nation charges and lawsuits regularly appear
in urban newspapers. Indeed, women have won
spectacular victories against bigoted emp-
loyers--American Telephone and Telegraph,
General Mills and General Motors are three of
the most famous offenders.

But the newspaper accounts don't tell one

what to expect day-to-day from co-workers,
superiors and state functionaries after fil-
ing a sex discrimination charge. I have been
through this process; my experience is sig-
nificant because it mirrors that of so many
women. I have learned what can and cannot
be accomplished by fighting bigoted employ-
ers through a State Human Rights Department.

“Down the Rabbit Hole”

In 1971 the job market was tight. I had just
completed graduate work for a Master's Degree
in American Studies at the University of
Minnesota. I had a Bachelor's Degree in
Journalism and approximately 3 1/2 years’
professional experience (much less than most
college graduates of 31, but I had spent an
inordinate amount of time traveling about the

by Mary Hastings

and her attorney appealed that decision
to the State Appeal Board. It overturned
the Commissioner's decision and sent the
charge back for reinvestigation. The State
Department of Human Rights has been in the
"reinvestigation" process since April 1973.
The author has received no information con-
cerning this process and the State is under
no time limit. (The EEOC awaits the out-
come of the state charge before taking jur-
isdiction.)

"field" and "taking courses"

I was over-qualified for beginning journalism
positions and not at the “managerial” level.
I was in deep debt for my graduate education.
In November I accepted a position as editor
of an audio-tape program in the education de-
partment of a Twin Cities firm. I was seri-
ously underpaid, starting at $8,400 per year.
A man with the same job title and far less
education and responsibility started at
$10,000 per year and was raised, in six
months, to $11,000.

My first mistake was not negotiating for an
acceptable salary. My reasons for accepting
the low salary illustrate the confused state
I had been brought to by societal pressures
on and expectations of women. I needed money
but more pressing were my intense feelings
of failure. Most of these "failure pangs"
sprang from my male-oriented view of the
world. I had been trained, like my male
peers, to measure my worth in "impressive"
jobs, degrees and lifestyles--in a word, to
be a materialist.

Thus, I made a grave error even before I

was issued my employee I.D. (Later in my
battles with the company, the male attitude
was manifest: "Well, why did you take the
job if you didn't like the salary?" That
is, "You had a choice--take the job and
shut up or go elsewhere. It is unnatural
for women to make demands.")

continued on page 3

sex discrimination, Continued from page

Having started on an unhappy note, I found  
that my job was a source of pain from the  
first day.  

I should note factors that made this most  
recent job different from others I have  
held:  

--I had begun to take a serious  
interest in feminism: Know-  
ledge of exploitation brings  
pain.  

--I was working for a private corp-  
oration. Previously I had either  
worked for a newspaper (a pri-  
vate corporation masquerading  
as citizens' advocate) or a  
university where certain degrees  
of nonconformity are tolerated,  
even applauded.  

--I was now working in an atmosphere  
of such stifling conformity that  
nothing I'd ever read, heard of or  
had nightmares about prepared me  
for the reality of it.  

Wonderland  

For seven months, I performed my duties.  
There was a mad, Hieronymous Bosch quality  
to my days. Males high and low in the corp-  
oration were feuding for reasons I could  
not fathom. (I am neither naive nor unin-  
telligent but to this day I cannot divine  
the motivation for the excess of savage com-  
petition and hateful behavior displayed by  
these men.) I, mindful of my debts and sec-  
retly ashamed of my cowardice in not quit-  
ting the job, struggled--swimming in the  
murky waters of departmental rivalry and  
I was tagged "efficient”  
- That is, I was competent and,  
to my shame, willing to tolerate brutal rude  
ness and stupidity that made my teeth ache.  

Unfortunately, too, I could take little sol-  
ace in the work I produced. I had not ex-  
pected the job to be absorbing, but I had  
hoped to be allowed to perform as a compe-  
tent writer/editor. This was not to be.  

The program became a "political football”  
(as do all projects in such a structure)  
and after many "reviews" and constipated con-  
ferences, I would have left the shards of my  
work--a program that said little and deeply  
embarrassed me.  

“Pig and Pepper”  

After seven months, however, I was transfer-  
red to the communications department. My  
transfer was by fiat of a high executive who  
had decided she liked me. I was happy to  
comply, as the education department was un-  
dergoing a "shakeup" that resulted in an at-  
mosphere just this side of the Gaza Strip. I  
also had a choice between two male supervi-  
sors--whether I stayed or transferred--men  
who I knew were no friends of women. I  
cast the die and chose the one I felt would  
be less obnoxious.  

The communications department was a male  
bastion. I was never welcomed in any way.  
And as time passed, I was very glad for  
that. It made my course uncomplicated. In-  
itially, of course, my silent isolation was  
difficult. I had always been in an atmos-  
phere where at least 50% of my peers liked  
me. Men who work in academia or "quasi-  
creative" occupations seemed better able to  
disguise their prejudices. Or, perhaps I  
had started to view males with a cold eye  
and they reciprocated.  

The move seemed providential, despite the  
cool reception. My new supervisor left me  
entirely alone to work as I saw fit. I  
was pleased and chose to regard this free-  
dom as a permanent state. (Alas, innocence).

Rules of the Game  

If you feel you have just cause to file a  
sex or race discrimination charge against  
your employer with the Minnesota State Hum-  
an Rights Department (or your state’s coun-  
terpart):

She can give you valuable  
information and advice about

Tell NO ONE connected with your

standing when the charge is

Make a careful judgment as to

about joining race and sex dis-  
crimination in your charge. One  
of the saddest aspects of minor-  
ity struggles for justice is the  
white male's cunning attempts  
to set us at each other's throats.  

Resist the impulse to confide in  
male co-workers at any time.  
There are many sensitive men, but  
my experience tells me they are  
not yet ready to be involved  
in women's liberation.  

It is now Minnesota law that the  
State Department of Human Rights  
must conclude its investigation  
of your charge within 90 days of  
your filing. (The 90-day limit  
does not include "conciliation"  
and/or appeal time, however.)

On Monday morning, I arrived at work, attended to some details and informed my supervisor I would be “out of the building” for a time. I proceeded to the Minnesota Department of Human Rights in St. Paul. I had little hope that my claim could be accepted for investigation. I was interviewed by a very intelligent young woman.

“The Pool of Tears”

Also, over my seven months' employment, I had discovered I could work very well with women. This statement comes from one who had always been hostile to "female subordinates," fearing association with them, and separating myself from them as much as possible. But having embraced feminism, I developed rapport with my female co-workers. Ninety-nine percent were secretaries.

(There were several other women professionals in the company, but we all had "service-oriented" jobs.) I grew to understand that I worked with a female secretary. She did not work for me; she was not my secretary.

Shortly after my transfer, I enrolled in a two-week seminar and was absent from the communications department.

Upon my return, a corporate executive gave me the greatest gift I have ever received—the opportunity to free myself forever from male standards.

The executive—for reasons still unclear to me—complained to my supervisor that I should not produce a program dealing with "technical" endeavors exclusively the province of males. My supervisor who—consciously or unconsciously—had been awaiting an opportunity to curtail my activities had a "heart-to-heart" talk with me in which he informed me it was not appropriate for a woman to take a large role in a "technical" field. He declaimed for some time, quoting Scripture and recalling the natural order of things. He concluded in a patronizing tone that I would be allowed to "coordinate" the program but would no longer play a major role in it.

During this amazing interview, I responded in a passive, non-involved manner. I had just had a job review that rated me an excellent employee. Needless to say, I was nonplused.

“The Rabbit Sends in a Little ‘Bill’

That hot May weekend I made the decision to file a sex discrimination charge against my employer. I was frightened but did not want to be humiliated further by the male who heard my nervous but factual account of my supervisor's sermon. She informed me that the case was "difficult" but the State could investigate.

Following the interview, I signed a form and dated it. Within a week or so, I would receive a copy and the company would be served with a copy by mail. The charge was addressed to the President of the corporation and my supervisor.

(I had not retained an attorney and did not plan to.) This is a grave error. Consult an attorney immediately if you feel you have just cause to file a sex discrimination charge. Because I had not consulted an attorney at the outset, I did not know that I could have filed a charge with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunities Commission at the same time I filed the state charge.

I fear that initially I viewed the State Department as a "protector." Nothing is further from the truth. This Department should be absolutely neutral in investigations—it is neither an advocate for complainant (myself) nor respondent (the company). The Minnesota Department of Human Rights is also understaffed and overworked. And I regard its male employees as a fair cross-section of male attitudes toward women.

If you need an attorney and are in the Twin Cities area, contact Women's Advocates: 227-2504 (St. Paul) for attorney referral.

I returned to my office and proceeded for the next week and a half to work in the mode dictated by my supervisor.

Nothing changed—on the surface. My supervisor did, indeed, treat me with more kindly condescension than had been his wont. (I found I preferred the wary measuring of two weeks past.) I behaved in my usual manner. I had been a most accommodating, soft-voiced woman. I had never visibly lost my temper, although it cost me many stomach pains and tight lines at the mouth. I had never demanded what was my due, had never insisted on cooperation or timely performance of interviews, "reviews" or conferences.

Sister Annabelle Raiche,  
Chair of the Education Depart-  
ment at the College of St.  
Catherine, St. Paul, went to  
the University of San Francis-  
co for a Symposium on Ignatian  
Spirituality July 15-31.  

July 31 she went to jail.  

It started out as a day of  
solidarity with the United  
Farm Workers for the partici-  
pants in the symposium. Ninety-  
five priests and nuns went  
to Parlier to support the UFW  
as observers. They were greeted  
by Cesar Chavez, who asked  
if they had the time and the  
commitment to join the picket  
line.  

"That's when I decided I  
would join them," Sister Anna-  
belle said, even though they  
knew they would be imprisoned  
for an indefinite period of  
time. Sixteen sisters and  
sixteen priests joined about  
300 other people to form pick-  
et lines on two nectarine  
ranches.  

The picketers formed a line  
facing a line of ranch owners.  
"You could tell they were very  
frightened men," Sister Anna-  
belle said, by the sticks,  
crowbars, and rubber hoses that  
they carried, and by the two  
unleashed dogs with them. The  
picketers carried nothing.  
They were silent, sang hymns,  
or chanted prayers. From time  
to time they spoke to the  
scabs working in the fields,  
trying to call them out. They  
persuaded four of the workers  
to leave.  

After about four hours, the  
police began arresting them.  

A policewoman began reading  
the women their charges. The  
Chicanas, experienced in be-  
ing arrested, shouted during  
the reading so they would not  
hear their charges, and would  
be illegally arrested.  

The picketers were taken to  
the Fresno County Industrial  
Farm where they were frisked,  
fingerprinted, and photographed.  
After two days of waiting,  
they were arraigned for  
"riot, rout, disorderly con-  
duct, and unlawful assembly."  

by Jan Jirak  

The UFW's lawyers pleaded “not  
guilty." They were judged not  
trustworthy to be released on  
their own recognizance. Bail  
was set at $400.  

In the prison, "we set our  
own pattern of life; no day  
ever dragged." There was al-  

ways cleaning, praying, read-  
ing, or some sort of activity  
in progress.  

Cesar Chavez  

Sister Annabelle Raiche  

had told the nuns, “Ask the  
women what their life is  
like." Sister Annabelle took  
his advice.  

There was Petra. She was 29  
years old and had seven child-  
ren. Her day started at 3 a.m.,  
when she rose to do the clean-  
ing and cooking. After break-  
fast the family went to the  
fields. When supper ended the  
long day, it was time for bed.  
Petra said, "The only time we  
have together is on Sunday af-  
ter Mass."  

The strength of the farm wor-  
kers is exemplified by a woman  
named Estafana. She is the  
mother of 8 children, the  
youngest 6 months old. She  
was feverishly ill when she  
was in jail. The Farm Workers  
doctor told her she should go  
straight to bed and stay  
there. After the doctor saw  
her, the prison officials  

brought her to their office  
and tried to convince her to  
leave the prison. (Everyone  
had agreed that, as a sign of  
unity, no one would leave the  
prison unless they all did.)  
Estafana, in spite of her ill-  
ness, in spite of her child-  
ren, withstood twenty minutes  
of persuasion and refused to  
leave without the others.  

Sister Annabelle and the  
rest of the prisoners were re-  
leased on August 13 at 12:30  
a.m. A sister from her commu-  
nity in the Los Angeles pro-  
vince met her in a park and  
drove her to her convent where  
she spent the rest of the  
night.  

Sister Annabelle says,  
"It's left its mark on me,"  
and is still leaving its mark.  
As an educator, she noticed  
that although the Chicanas  
were largely illiterate, they  
were in many ways more educa-  
ted than she was. This was  
first brought home to her by  

the realization that she  
could not speak to them in  
their language, but they  
could speak to her in hers.  
About half the women were bi-  
lingual.  

She said the women knew a-  
bout the movement they were  
involved in ("la causa") and  
could speak about it articu-  
lately. Their leader was 19-  
year-old Gloria, who could  
translate instantaneously,  
and did so when people of ei-  
ther language visited.  

Although there were 54 wo-  
men in one barracks where they  
lived in dormitory style with  
little physical privacy, the  
Chicanas afforded each other  
an adequate measure of "psy-  
chic privacy." "I never felt  
crowded or that my privacy was  
being infringed upon," said  
Sister Annabelle.  

The experience made her  
think about the strength that  
comes from powerlessness. It  
is the will to make a better  
life, the freedom from mater-  
ial possessions. It is the  
strength that comes from hav-  
ing nothing to lose.
