I happened to visit the Women's Erotic Art  
Show in the company of a man who joked about  
his nervousness at the prospect of being  
made into a sex symbol. As it turned out,  
nothing of the sort was in sight when we ar-  
rived at the Guild of Performing Arts where  
the show was held. I suspect that it will  
be some while before more people understand  
that feminists are not particularly interes-  
ted in mirror views, except perhaps as in-  
structive examples. We have too many objec-  
tions to the structure of society to blithe-  
ly do unto men as they have done unto us.  

So what constitutes female eroticism if  
not images of nude men with genitals waving?  
The women have put together a highly cere-  
bral collection which sees sexuality as a  
part of a social continuum, rather than a  
prurient pause. The almost formulaic attrac-  
tion of exposed organs topped by steamy  
glances plays a small role in this exhibi-  

tion.  
Humor rears its unpredictable head more  

than once, although I do not think every-  
body will laugh on cue. Take Susan Fiene  
Brown's ceramic "Adjustable Tit-Tureen" with  
its large breast demurely balanced on paw-  
like legs. The gears protrude from the base  
of the breast which is surrounded by a move-  
able shell. The idea is that the gears con-  
trol the position of the shell so that the  
viewer may have a breast of exactly the de-  
sired size.  

Another comic achievement is "What More Do  
You Want?" a cartoon by Marcella Williams.  
Somewhat in the Steig tradition, this simple  
drawing shows a naked woman reclining on her  
elbows. She is casting a wanly ironic gaze  
at a fierce little man who has entered her  
and lies engulfed to his shoulders. He has  
tossed the title question at his conqueror  
with such irritable ill will that I couldn't  
help but side with her. I imagine that  
other viewers, feminist or not, will enter  
much the same allegiance.  

These jocular approaches to the human body  
will probably arouse little erectile tissue  
in passersby. Eroticism has traditionally  
been a method of "getting away from it all,"  
and there has been no place in it for annoy-  
ing social commentary.  

The Women's Erotic Art Show changes all  
that. In practice, thought usually enhances,  
rather than inhibits, sexual pleasure. It's  
time that erotic artists appreciate the  
spice that comes from mental additives.  

Two related entries concentrate on female  
genitals. Debra Lorensen's fabric "Refuge"  
is a white cylinder with a warm red interior.  
Deep in the interior is a small, provocative  
button.  

A mixed media piece by Patricia Kerr exhi-  
bits a similarly impassive sensuality. A  
wooden carton with “Danger...Fuzes" marked  
on the sides is filled with white fur. A  
large, luminous red globe extrudes through  
a zippered opening in the furs and appears  

A Review  
by Susan Cushman  

almost to throb.  

I was not surprised at this interest in  
female bodies. The male body has been so  
diligently protected from the exposure which  
eroticism demands, that there is little  
groundwork for artists to share if they in-  
cline toward the subject. After all, do you  
show them up or down? How do you keep them  
from looking just a bit silly?  

Naked women, of course, never look silly,  
because we are too used to seeing ourselves  
portrayed that way. But women artists do  
have an obligation to invigorate some tired  
old conceptions that have been around too  
long. When women turn appreciative, knowing  
eyes on each other, the manmade artistic  
stereotypes are bound to slip out of view.  

The Women's Erotic Art Show is intimate,  
with 47 entries, and recommended. It con-  
tinues at the Guild of Performing Arts,  

504 Cedar Avenue through October 31.  

The gracefulness of Libra, it has been  
remarked, is like that of a Gothic arch:  
beauty based on balanced stress.  

Venus rules this sign: Venus, planet of  
love and art, representative of the des-  
cent of spirit into matter. For Venus-  
ruled Taurus, this manifests itself as  
earthy sensuality. But for Libra, the  
Venusian qualities are revealed as an  
abstract arrangement of opposing forces:  
hence the stereotypical disputative Libran  
always ready to take the "other side."  

The critical Libran consideration is  
the appropriate division of energy between  
social and personal needs. Born near the  
autumn equinox--when the light-ego is fast  
losing hours to the darkness-collective--  
Libra tends to overemphasize social  
demands. But the still-strong ego asserts  
itself regularly. Like its opposite, asser-  
tive Aries, the Libran perches on an un-  
easy edge between the demands of the inner  
self and those of the outward society. In  
contrast to Aries, however, Libra argues  
for the larger view, never using conflict  
to define personal territory.  

That Libra is often praised as a "femi-  
nine" sign--while it is actually an out-  
ward or "masculine" sign--is an interest-  
ing phenomenon. The rulership of Venus no  
doubt accounts for some of this attribu-  
tion, but Libra's tendency towards ex-  
cessive acculturation could as well be  
cited as cause. Luckily for Libran women,  
this balance between inward and outward  
represents a kind of androgyny, in that  
the Libran--always looking at both sides--  
is usually able to accept both her "male"  
and “female" qualities.

“Women Either Cope or Build”

I have always thought soli-
tude essential in order to get
in touch with oneself and be-
come a strong, autonomous per-
son. Solitude can be peace-
ful, an inward-tuning time of
self-exploration.

For most people in the west-
ern world, however, solitude
is feared and avoided. They
do not know how to make con-
structive use of solitude,
and this is especially true

of women.
A woman is taught from the

earliest moments of infancy
that she will never be alone.
Indeed, she is taught that a-
loneness is a lack rather than
an opportunity. She expects
to marry, have children, grand
children. She is trained to
find escape from loneliness
not in herself, from whom she
could learn the most, or from
other women, with whom she has
the most in common, but from
men, who have shared and un-
derstand few of her vital exper-
iences and feelings, and from
children, who are unequipped
for adult relationships.

loneliness

In her book The Woman Alone

(The New York Times Book Co.,
278 pp., $7.95) Patricia
O'Brien tells that she lived
just such a life for most of
her years. She spent her
childhood and young adulthood
dreaming of marriage, which
materialized after her sopho-
more year in college; she
dropped out and bore four
children.

In spite of her fulfilled
dreams, she was unhappy. She
began to learn some lessons
about loneliness. "I could
not understand what was hap-
pening. I had everything I
was ever supposed to have
wanted, yet I would find my-
self crying while I folded di-
apers. Was it loneliness I
felt? But how could I be
lonely? People were around
constantly. My life had shape
and direction and substance—
what was wrong with me? In
fact I had been alone only one
time in my life, a night short-
ly after my fourth daughter
was born. I remember twice
turning off the lights and try-
ing to go to sleep, each time
getting up and turning them on
again, irritated with my cow-
ardice but too filled with

nally I settled down in the
living room to wait out the
night, sleepless, a butcher
knife beside me. I was then

twenty-seven years old."
wings

She decided to finish col-
lege with a major in journal-
ism. "We bought an old Ply-

After graduation, she took a

After a year of futile coun-
seling, she decided to leave.
She took a job on the Chicago
Sun-Times, 80 miles away, and

the first real solitude she
had ever known. During that
time she met and conquered
loneliness, came to know and

itude and by seeking out
other women alone.

O'Brien recounts the devel-

with other women. She re-

all part of the collective

Ms. O'Brien tells these sto-

Power  

O'Brien learned to under-  
stand the powerlessness of wo-  
men. "I sometimes have felt  
painfully inarticulate in work  
situations, usually when they  
are of particular importance  
to me. One day I went into  
my editor's office with an  
idea for a story, first care-  
fully preparing what I wanted  
to say, defensive about how  
good it might be and afraid  
he would think it was terri-  
ble. In the midst of our un-  
derstandably stilted conversa-  
tion a male reporter strolled  
in, greeted the editor, and  
casually talked about a pro-  
ject that interested him,  
throwing in a request for  
time off. The two men, both  

outwardly relaxed and easy,  
negotiated a bit and settled  
the problem within a few mo-  
ments. I sat there, my  
speech out the window, envi-  
ous and frustrated, wondering  
why that type of encounter  
came so easily for the man  
and so hard for me.  

"David Riesman has sugges-  
ted that a basic problem for  
working women is they do not  
know how to make use of the  
informal structure that men  
use in the process of advan-  
cing their careers. Women  
are not and never will be  
casual members of the undefin-  
able but always present male  
circle, whether in the office,  
the city room, the factory,  
or the university, which is  
why, if they want to achieve,  
they must work twice as hard  
as their male counterparts.  
Men no longer believe in Hor-  
atio Alger, but it seems many  
women do, and they have for-  
gotten he was a man."  

O'Brien emphasizes that  
seizing power means a willing-  
ness to risk, whether it be  
failure or unpopularity.  
Choosing solitude means risk-—  
ing loneliness--but success  
is impossible without risk,  
and is the beginning of liber-  
ation.

Midwifery Frees Women From

By Heit Kemper.

A quiet revolution in maternity care is
taking place in the Twin Cities.

Pregnancy and childbirth are functions of
normal, healthy women, but until recently,
illness-oriented care has been given to the
99.9 percent of women who give birth to
their children in hospitals. Obstetricians
and nurses agree that 90 percent of births
are normal and could be safely attended by
trained midwives in a more comfortable set-
ting.

Now that advances in medical technology
have made a safe birth experience almost a
foregone conclusion, people are now turning
their attention to making childbirth exper-
ience emotionally satisfying as well.

This revolution is quiet for several rea-
sons. There is a real need for caution while
developing alternative childbirth methods
that are necessarily dependent on the estab-
lished medical community for back-up assist-
ance in case of emergency. With the lowest
birth rate in recent years, an alternative
style of childbirth is seen as a threat to
the general practitioner and obstetrician's
bread and butter.

But what is bread and butter to the ob-
stetrician is meat and drink to the midwife,
according to a local pioneer in family-cen-
tered childbirth.

Control and Choice in Childbirth

This is also a revolution—manned by
consumers demanding control and choice in
what can be a most interesting, joyous phys-
ical experience.

Changes in childbirth are being influ-
enced from outside as well as inside the med-
ical professions. Private groups like the
Childbirth Education Association have grown
at a spectacular rate. And this has happen-
ed at a time when the birth rate in the
Twin Cities has dropped from 134 births per
1,000 in 1960 to 20 births per 1,000 in 1968
(the last available figure).

Last year the Childbirth Education Assoc-
iation (CEA) trained more than 1,300 couples
in prepared childbirth techniques. The CEA
now has more applications than it can hand-
le.

Men are re-entering the ceremony of birth
to be with their women in the delivery room.
A few years ago, this was unheard of and e-
ven prohibited by hospital regulations.

Less than ten years ago, a man in California
chained himself to his wife so they could
experience their child's birth together. The
hospital attempted legal action against him.

Women can have babies in a variety of
ways. Ether and forceps were an advance
that had women being delivered of their
children, rather than actively taking part.
You can still have a "knock ‘em out, drag
‘em out" delivery or you can be temporarily
paralyzed by spinal anesthetics or be eased
by gases to inhale. There are anesthetics
(per-cervical block) that can numb the uter-
us for a short period of time and provide
a helpful rest during labor. Breathing ex-
ercises and learning how to ride with con-
tractions rather than fighting against them
can ease a labor considerably.

Childbirth’s “Chains”

With knowledge of the variety available
to them, couples are choosing obstetrical
care according to their own personal phil-
osophies, even if it means shopping around
for the right doctor or midwife. And you can
be sure that patients taking their bus-
iness elsewhere will have an effect on the
kind of care offered in the future.

Changes in childbirth style have been
happening faster than the medical profession
or individuals can keep track of. One ma-
jor change is the demise of the traditional
granny midwife and the rise of a new pro-
fessional—the nurse-midwife.

Granny midwifery (rhymes with sniffery)
in Minnesota is not far behind us. Mrs.
Ebba Kirschbaum, the last midwife licensed
by the Minnesota Medical Board of Examiners,
retired last year after aiding the birth of
almost 1,700 children. Her retirement also
brought an end to home deliveries, at least
for the time being.

Lucy Cutler was one of the last women
Mrs. Kirschbaum attended. Ms. Cutler has
experienced both hospital and home deliver-
ies and is vocal about the differences. She
had her first child in a hospital.

"Hospitals are geared to curing the prob-
lems they cause," says Ms. Cutler. She and
her husband, Bruce, figure they spent $70
per hour for a doctor to endanger two lives
and ignore their wishes.

Ms. Cutler says her obstetrician's manner
was deceptive. They had discussed her wishes
for no anesthetic or restraints during del-
ivery (women are routinely strapped down
for delivery in modern hospitals).

"He seemed to go along with my ideas,
he didn't disagree with me. He was very
relaxed and casual, which I liked," she
continues.

Her confidence was shaken when she asked
for advice on labor and delivery during an
office visit near the end of her pregnancy.
Her doctor told her not to worry, that it
was too early to discuss it. She went into
labor the next week.

During her labor, Ms. Cutler was given a
"routine anesthetic" despite her protesta-
tions—a spinal block (which deadens feel-
ing from the waist down, interfering with
the control women had up to that point).

Her legs were restrained in stirrups against
her wishes.

When her child was born, she thought it
was someone else's child crying—she did not
feel the birth she had so happily antic-
ipated.

"It was worse than a rape," she says.
"At least with a rape you have many other
opportunities to have a positive experience.
But you don't have too many chances to ex-
perience birth."

Angered by their experiences with hospi-
tal delivery, the Cutlers sought out Ebba
Kirschbaum to deliver their next child at

continued on next

KNOCK ‘EM OUT DRAG ‘EM OUT ETHIC DYING

home. Lucy Cutler embroidered a special  
birth dress for the occasion and consulted  
Mrs. Kirschbaum frequently during her preg-  
nancy. When labor began, Mrs. Kirschbaum  
went to the Cutler home to attend the birth.  

"She was like a wedding attendant who  
arranges the bride's hair," says Ms. Cutler.  
"In my own home I was free to yell without  
disturbing anyone or getting medication  
against my will. It felt good to yell.  
Kirschbaum asked me if I wanted gas. I said  
no and that was it."  

Was she afraid of the dangers of home  
deliveries?  

"If you die in a hospital, it's OK," says  
Ms. Cutler. "But if you cough at home you're  
taking a risk! I'd feel guiltier if I went  
to a hospital and something went wrong."  

Lucy Cutler doesn't have much faith in the  
family-centered maternity care being offered  
by hospitals in the area. "To me that means  
when the nurses and staff have nothing else  
to do they will attend to my needs," she  
says.  

When General Hospital was asking public  
feedback while planning the new maternity  
wing, Cutler submitted a plan that reflects  
her professional background in wildlife  
management.  

Her plans consider the instinctual de-  
sires of women in labor, patterned after  
the universal behavior of animals in labor.  

Her facility would have as little to do  
with illness as possible. It would have  
lamps and double beds and be similar to a  
motel where "you could kick off your shoes  
and close the door-- a place where you could  
come with your chosen companions, your own  
blankets and other nesting equipment and  
stake out your territorial claim." Cutler  
says a woman in labor who knows what is  
going on should be the final authority re-  
garding her care during childbirth.  

Private room at Hennepin General  

Margaret Hewitt, a nurse-midwife at  
Hennepin County General Hospital, agrees.  
She informs us that there is now one room  
at General where patients can labor, deliv-  
er and recover and return home soon after  
birth.  

"This is a pilot thing to see if this is  
what women really want. But how many come  
to General to have their children?" says  
Ms. Hewitt who delivers about one baby a  
week herself.  

If women make use of this alternative,  
there are ten other private rooms that  
could be used this way.  

"If we found this was an up and coming  
thing we would have them available too,"  
says Ms. Hewitt.  

Hewitt sees no medical support for home  
births. "I would prefer that couples att-  
empting home births do it alone rather  
than depend on untrained attendants," she  
says. "At the first sign of trouble, the  
couple would be more likely to seek medical  
help."  

Ms. Hewitt sees benefits in women's re-  
newed participation in their birth exper-  
iences, "In the last 70 years, birth has  
been taken over by men and the benefits of  

that system have run out," she says. "The  
highest reproductive act for the male  
is orgasm. Childbirth is women's highest."  

"Doctors say I will take over and de-  
liver you of your child. I will give you  
knowledge, be technical advisor and inter-  
vene for your safety," she continues.  

"But men cannot understand women's sex-  
uality any more than women can understand  
the nature of man's."  

Another energetic woman making changes  

in the local childbirth experience is  

Sharon Rising at the University of Minnesota  
School of Nursing.  

Her plan for a master's degree program in  
nurse-midwifery became a reality this fall.  
Ninety women applied for entrance into the  
two-year program. Six full-time and ten  
part-time students have begun training.  

This is not granny midwifery but an  
extension of the nursing function with the  
backup of modern medical expertise and fac-  
ilities in case of emergency. The training  
will emphasize the comfort and emotional  
needs of pregnant women through a contin-  
uous woman-to-woman relationship.  

Rising has been working on plans for a  
separate child-bearing, child-rearing, fam-  
ily planning clinic. It would be an altern-  
ative to existing family care, providing a  
place for home-centered childbirth and t  
training for nurse-midwives. It could also  
be the base for a group midwifery practice,  
in which women would have one midwife for  
primary care but know them all in case her  
primary midwife was unable to attend her  
birth.  

Other health care professionals, ped-  
iatricians and child psychologists are in-  
terested in Rising's clinic, but until fund-  
ing is available, it will remain a plan.  
Funding is particularly difficult, says  
Rising, because this community is consider-  
ed to have good existing health care facil-  
ities. It requires active lobbying on the  
part of consumers to support alternatives.  

And pressure from consumers brings al-  
ternatives into existence. When Sharon Ri-  
sing completed her training at Yale less  
than five years ago, there were few places  
where she could practice her profession. Be-  
cause of women's interest in woman-to-  
woman childbirth care, hospitals are now  
looking for nurse-midwives and private ob-  
stetrical practices are wanting to include  
midwifery in the services they offer pati-  
ents.  

But it will be vital to the establish-  
ment of midwifery as an alternative for mid-  
wives to be accepted as colleagues, not sub-  
ordinates on these staffs, Rising warns.  

Renewed interest in midwifery parallels  
the women's movement of the past few years.  
The mystical role of the male doctor dimin-  
ishes as the woman-to-woman relation-  
ships grow stronger. But change will be  
necessary from inside the medical commun-  
ity.  

The image of the midwife as a crafty,  
backwoods woman operating in crude con-  
ditions still hangs on. But according to  
Sharon Rising, this is the reverse of what  
it should be. The trained nurse-midwife

it  
Midwifery Time  

should be handling the uncomplicated birth  
in a medically sound environment and the  
specialist with training in the complica-  
tions and diseases of pregnancy should be  
reaching patients in outlying areas.  

"The most significant changes in mid-  
wifery will have to come within the estab-  
lished systems," says Rising. "Midwifery  

has existed outside the medical community.  
Doctors have seen only the negative side of  
it when something goes wrong."  

This is unfortunate since midwifery  
requires the backup of established medical  
institutions to function properly. Mid-  
wifery is for healthy normal pregnancy and  
the value of the obstetrician's skill and  
expertise in an emergency are not to be dis-  
counted.  

But obstetricians rarely take the time to  
deal with the pregnant human being and this  
is an advantage of continuous woman-to-woman  
care by a midwife. An office visit en-  
compasses the woman's feelings and fears  
as well as her physical condition. And a  
midwife helps guide the patient's labor  
rather than arriving in the nick of time  
to catch the baby.  

Utilizing midwives could lessen the  
cost of OB care. The care would be more  
extensive in terms of time spent with the  
patient, but the expensive emergency  
equipment used in every hospital delivery  
room could be limited to one emergency  
room, bringing down the overhead.  

Another factor in the cost of midwife  
care is insurance. At the present time,  
midwifery is not recognized as medical  
care by insurance companies. This is an-  
other area where consumer pressure must  
bring about change.

of Minnesota Hospitals is also sticking her  
neck out on behalf of women.  

Rules and regulations which interfere  
with satisfying childbearing are being ov-  
ercome by Ms. Sonstegard's carefully laid  

groundwork.  

Many women wish to nurse their newborns  
immediately after delivery. Knowing  

this is psychologically and emotionally ben-  
eficial to mothers and infants and also know-  
ing that it was against hospital policy,  

Ms. Sonstegard allowed it anyway.  

After a period of time, she proposed a  
change of rules to her superiors. When met  
with negative reactions and concern for the  
risks involved, she produced evidence that  
the risks were negligible and were far out-  
weighed by the satisfaction of the patients.  
The rules were changed and parents can now  
hold and nurse their newborns before they  
are taken to the nursery for routine tests  
and observation.  

Another disadvantage of hospital delivery  
is a mother's separation from her other chi-  
ldren. Sonstegard is instituting a chil-  
dren's visiting hour to ease the separation  
for both mother and child and give the fam-  
ily a chance to adjust to a new member.  

"The goal is the most satisfying child-  
birth experience for the people concerned,"  
said Ms. Sonstegard. "There should be no  
feeling of guilt or disappointment or won-  
dering ‘how did I do'," she continued. "  
"When medical care is safe, better care for  
the whole person is important."  

And women all over the Twin Cities area  
are making that happen.

Women’s Magazines: A Cursory Review

Time was, about a year ago, when every-
thing would stop once the newest issue of Ms.
magazine hit the supermarket magazine rack.
Projects, work, and plans for the day were
all pushed aside until the magazine had been

read cover to cover. 

But things change. And so do people.

Many of my friends are finding Ms. less in-
teresting this fall. Is the magazine fading,
or are we just finding other forums for
feminist debates? Are other magazines pick-
ing up the cause? Do new magazines like
Playgirl and New Woman have any implications
for the women's movement? And are the old
newsstand (un)reliables to be trusted any
more than before?

New Woman competes well with Ms. from the
looks of the cover. But there the similarity
ends. While the flashy headline "What About
POW Wives?" on the cover of Ms. belies a more

serious article within, "The Three Faces of
the Single Parent" on the cover of New

Woman leads to little more than scant copy
and photographs of a fashionable bleached
blonde running through parks with her kids
and standing in the moonlight on the shore
of Lake Michigan with her lover. Topics that
deserve in-depth treatment ("Why Women Go
Winky-Wonky Over Homosexual Men") are given
a flip review which is more infuriating than
disappointing. Columns for the trendy hos-
tess on "What's In and Out in Food" are more
boring than most, and reprints from Reader's
Digest about "How a (Female) High School
Dropout Built a Business That Does More Than
$150 Million a Year" simply do not interest
me. But the main quality which makes New
Woman by far the most offensive women's maga-
zine on the market is its guise of not only
showing a very glamorous swinging lifestyle
which is as unrealistic as ever, but daring
to call it that of the "new woman." Heaven
forbid.

A Pleasant Relief

A new crop of magazines dealing with the
life of single persons is encouraging and
generally aimed at both sexes. Singles is
written for the swinging crowd with neither
the pretensions nor pocketbooks of the Playboy
crew. Although it promotes a classic stereo-
type of dating and socialization on the way
to marriage, it is no more condescending to
women than it is to men. Single (without the
"s") has a few shallow articles, but attempts
to confront the subject of living alone more
realistically than any other periodical. For
one thing, it accepts the situation as being
normal and even desirable for most adults at
some stage in their lives. Articles like
"Why Should Singles Pay 20% More in Taxes?",
"Sex When You're Alone," and a story on the
National Organization for Non-Parents raise
some important questions, but unfortunately
gloss over the answers. The magazine simply
lacks sufficient depth in its reporting.
Although its bias is clearly towards the
"unmarried, divorced, widowed and unattached"
of either sex, it also reflects positively
on the female single which is a pleasant
relief.

The Playful Penis

For people who get off on penises bathed
in red-gold light, Playgirl, Viva, Venus
and a good slug of companion magazines are
stylishly filling a void of sorts in the
pornographic world. At least women now have
the chance to participate legitimately in

by Kate Ligare

the drugstore ritual of paging through maga-
zine racks with all the nonchalance one can
muster. If you're curious, you won't be dis-
appointed.

Playgirl has a four-page fully phallic
foldout which is stunning, although the man
looks about as comfortable as the cougar on
top of the Lincoln-Mercury sign. The lucky
lad who is the “Discovery of the Month" is
pictured building a house in the nude. His
body looked fine, but an electric saw and
sawdust are not my idea of the most erotic
things in the world. Viva's editor, Bob
Guiccone, declares that "Viva will be a
woman, my kind of woman," and the same trend
continues through all of these male-edited
and produced pornographic magazines for
women. I found myself flipping through a 15
page color erotic version of an Elvira Madi-
gan picnic with the same detached fascination
I used to have when I looked at Playboy; I
wanted to see what kind of body they thought
was sexy and what kind of photography they
thought was erotic. But as far as arousing
my sexual desire in Woolworth's, Playgirl
and friends have a long way to go.

The Pornographic Ultimate

Far more pornographic for women in a cer-
tain sense are the stories in Good House-
keeping, Ladies' Home Journal, and McCall's.

The exact female counterpart to the stereo-
typed "pulsing virile man beating his way
into the woman and driving her into fits of
ecstasy and sobbing relief" is to be found
in the sweet stories of dreams at the kitchen
sink as "petite, blue-eyed Angie watched Jim
come home from the office and remembered
their first date at the beach and how hand-
some he was that Christmas, and how proud
she was to be his girl." Unfortunately,
little has changed.

Hairdos, diets, recipes, do-it-yourself-
budget-decorating, and unreal fashions that
are guaranteed to make you feel hopelessly
dumpy and unattractive still fill the pages
of all the traditional women's magazines.
Sophia Loren, Elizabeth Taylor, and Pat Nixon
are still on the cover, "The World's Most
Famous Hairdresser (male) Talks About the
World's Most Famous Women" inside, and one
column on the "Working Woman" by Letty
Cottin Pogrebin of Ms. does little to stem
the tide. Women's lib is a curio like yoga,
but husband, children, and home still come
first. The only commendable thing about
these magazines is that they are consistent
and they deliver exactly what they promise.

Fluff Holding at 20%

Ditto for fashion magazines. Ditto for
high school and college magazines for fe-
males. (The New Ingenue still advocates the
virtues of being an ingenue.) Ditto for
needlework and craft magazines which refuse
to respect the craft that they are promoting.
Ditto for bridal magazines. And baby
magazines.

Women's magazines and those with a female
orientation are one of the largest topical
sub-groups of magazines in the country.
Nearly one out of five popular magazines
carried in the Minneapolis Public Library
Branch system are for women. However, with
one exception (Ms.), obviously none are meant
to be taken at all seriously. Certainly
nowhere near 20% of the entries in the
Reader's Guide to Periodical Literature are

from women's magazines.

Another Slice of P.I.

Halfway House Helps

By Merry Urbia

Shakopee Women Get Just Desserts

Women in our prisons face
many problems today, not
the least of which is that
the general public remains
unaware of female offenders
and the ineffectiveness of
most of the rehabilitation
offered them. A promising
answer to this complicated
situation may be as simple
as P.I. (in this case a Twin
Cities group called Project
Interaction).
Springing from an Indian
culture class led by Dorothy
Anderson and Molly Ramon at
Minn. Women's Correctional
Institute at Shakopee, a
weekly discussion group was
formed which was open to all
inmates. As more volunteers
became interested, an uncen-
sored newsletter was started
to allow inmates feedback
into the community and a bou-
tique opened so women could
wear regular clothes rather
than uniforms. Legal aid, vo-
cational and personal assis-
tance was made available,
and Project Interaction was
incorporated into a nonpro-
fit organization composed of
both inmates and volun-
teers dedicated to the con-
cept of community correction.
Community corrections—not a
term that means much to most
of us not directly involved
with the prison system; but
to the women of Shakopee
prison and those who are hel-
ping them rediscover their
potential through Project
Interaction it can mean sig-
nificant change in their
lives both in and out of the
institution. It means a grass
roots movement that allows
ordinary citizens to provide
much needed, no strings at-
tached help to people in our
prisons, and a chance for in-
mates to develop useful per-
sonal and professional skills
within the community they
face in the future.

One of the most promising
examples of this kind of pro-
gram is Project Interaction's
halfway house for the women
of Shakopee; the only one in
Minnesota, and one of only
nine in the entire country
for women. Although statis-
tical studies in the state
indicate the first ninety
days of re-entry into society
are the most critical for re-
adjustment, most women find
themselves left unprepared
by a correctional system
which has encouraged only
regimentation and alienation
from the community—traits
convenient for prisoners
but not for free functioning
adults. In response to such
a situation, Pi House was
organized with an emphasis
on individual needs and
community interaction.
Operating since January of
1973, at 581 Portland Ave.
in St. Paul, Pi House re-
cently had its open house
to show the community the
results of work by staff,
residents and volunteers
restoring an old three-
story brick house to a cot-
fortable place with a capa-
city of 14 residents.

Through individual and
group counseling, resource
referrals (job, education,
cultural, special treat-
ment) and in-house programs
Pi House deals with three
main areas of concern:
rehabilitation—geared to
positive decision making,
getting residents aware of
their own potential,
individualized program—to
re-establish family-commu-
nity ties and speed tran-
sition back into society,
release—helping people re-
gain personal autonomy, suc-
ceed in establishing inde-
pendence.

Most often these are impli-
mented through a contract
between a resident and Pi
House, specifying personal
commitments and general
rules. Infractions usually
result in loss of privileges
but specific cases are de-
pendent on the judgment of
the counselor assigned. All
residents are required to
attend regular house meet-
ings and report to their
house counselor and parole
officer at scheduled times.
Each resident prepares her
own lunch and breakfast and
is on a rotating schedule
of tasks helping with the
evening meal at which every-
one eats together. Learning
experiences in food prepa-
ration, family planning, bud-
geting and child care are
emphasized within the house,
as a practical consideration
not reinforcement of a fem-
inine stereotyped role. Res-
idents are generally unre-
stricted as to the outside
organizations and groups that
they can take part in, and
may have their children in
for short stays at the house.

It is hoped that the combi-
nation of an individualized
program with a home-like
supportive situation will
result not only in social-
vocational goals but the
development of self-esteem
and personal independence
as well.

Women living at Pi House
are generally young, (the
oldest has been 34), many
have children. To get there
they must be eligible for
parole, go through several
interviews at the prison
and may arrange a pre-
release visit to see if Pi
House is for them.

While the final decision is
up to the parole board,
the halfway house itself
is funded through a State
Crime Commission grant, the
program itself is not organ-
ized by the Minnesota Depart-
ment of Corrections. "The
Corrections Department
doesn't dictate policy at
Pi House," stressed Wanda
Beale, Assistant Director
of the house. Project

Pi House cont.

Interaction, which created  
the program is a non-profit  
group concerned with "encouraging  
innovative solutions and is  
dependent on private donations  
and community support.

If women living in a sexist  
society face day-to-day problems  
that are hard to overcome, it is  
even harder for those who are  
re-entering it from a prison  
situation. Ms. Beale, who is a  
former head of Minn. Women's  
Political Caucus, feels that the  
rights and problems of women  
inmates are generally overlooked  
by the feminist movement and this  
must change. I agree. It's perhaps  
one of the best examples of how  
standing up for your sisters is  
important for the good of society  
as a whole, as well as for the  
progress of women in society.

If you wish to help, there are  
several areas that need  
volunteers—especially people  
who can escort inmates on trips  
out of Shakopee and offer skills  
or friendship. Fundraisers are  
also welcome; donations of clothing  
for the boutique can be left  
at Pi House.

“We are trying to get things  
to happen in a real way,"  
commented Ms. Beale. But that  
only happens when people reach  
out to people in a real way—not  
just through talk, but action.

Women’s Studies Dot Minneapolis  
High School English Curricula  

Ars Reveal Sexism  

"This is the most exciting  
course I have ever taught,"  
said Martha Harris, an Eng-  
lish teacher at South High in  
Minneapolis. The class is  
called "Man/Woman." Its pur-  
pose was to examine male-fe-  
male relationships, roles,  
and attitudes expressed in  
various literary forms. It  
was a sexually mixed class,  
though women outnumbered men  
three to one.  

To promote understanding a-  
mong the students, Harris us-  
ed consciousness-raising exer-  
cises prescribed by the Emma  
Willard Task Force on sexism  
in education. For example,  
she asked the class to com-  
plete the sentence(s), "I  
would (not) like to be a wo-  
man (man) because..." This  
exercise revealed that the stu-  
dents held traditional views  
of sexual roles: I would not  
like to be a man because men  
have to be tough and support  
a family, or I would like to  
be a woman because they are  
soft and expressive.  

Another exercise was to com-  
pare derogatory slang words  
for women and men. The list  
for men was noticeably short-  
er. Harris reports that this  
exercise was particularly ef-  
fective. "The lights went  
on like this!" she said, ex-  
tending her fingers with a  
snap.  

To begin their study of li-  
terary expression, the stu-  
dents studied song lyrics and  
discussed the attitudes  
found in them. They found a  
lot of negativism about re-  
lationships in the songs.  

As Ms. Harris said, there was  
a lot of "I can't live with-  
out you" rather than "I can  
live without you but it's  
nice to have you here."  

The class examined myths--  
Greek, Roman, Oriental, and  
Native American. They found  
traditional sexual roles: wo-  
men in the domestic role and  
men in the hunter role.  

They examined contemporary  
short stories, including J.  
D. Salinger's "Pretty Mouth  
and Green My Eyes," Joyce Car-  
ol Oates' "Where Are You Go-  
ing, Where Have You Been"--and  
found few healthy characters.  
Harris, hating to have every-  
thing seem so negative, intro-  
duced the story, "X--A Fabu-  

BY JAN JIRAK  

lous Child's Story," Ms. Mag-  
azine, December 1972. It is  
a story of a child whose sex  
was concealed. All the stud-  
ents enjoyed reading it but  
insisted that X had to be a  
boy--apparently boys can do  
girl things, but girls can't  
do boy things.  

The class read one novel:  
Temple of God by William Gold-  
man. It is the story of a  
desperately vacuous man who  
exploits a series of desper-  
ately vacuous women. By the  
time they read this book, the  
end of the trimester was imm-  
inent, and their conscious-  
nesses had been raised--they  
"got very angry at the male  
character," Harris said.  

The class will be offered  
the rest of this year and  
next year since student inter-  
est is so high, and Harris  
feels the class she taught  
were fairly open to discus-  
sion about women's liberation.  
During a brief discussion on  
the subject, she notes with  
satisfaction, one of the  
young men said, "That's just  
as much for men, then, too."  

Communication Skills  

The title of Phebe Hanson's  
class changes daily. The  
Minneapolis Vocational High  
School class' formal name is  
"Woman/Man," but "on alter-  
nate days we call it, 'Man/  
Woman'." The men had com-  
plained--they felt discrimin-  
ated against.  

Phebe's honest humor peppers  
conversation about the class.  
She says she used Carole King  
's "You Make Me Feel Like  
a Natural Woman" and Cat Ste-  
vens' "Hard Headed Woman" to  
compare attitudes about women.  
"They (the students) weren't  
as excited about the songs as  
I was--I thought they were  
great.”  

She seems to tap the Univer-  
sal Energy, presenting a mul-  
titude of projects to her  
class. Looking through my  
notes, I find over 15--not  
bad for 12 weeks.  

For example, the class drew  
up lists of good/bad things  
about being a woman/man, put-  
ting the woman lists on a  
blue sheet and the man things  
on a pink sheet. Examples of  
bad things about being a man:  
Having to pay for dates.  

Cops like to pick us up.  

Good things: Not having to  
wear a shirt. Getting intox-  
icated more slowly than women.  
Bad things about being a wom-  
an: Being stared at. Being  
called the weaker sex. Good  
things: Being able to get in-  
to bars at 16 'cause you look 18.  
Being the gentler sex.  

The students wrote essays  
on "What I Have Learned from  
My Mother/Father about Being  
a Woman/Man." In some cases,  
this assignment resulted in  
unprecedented communication  
between parents and offspring  
and one father even showed  
his son a love letter he had  
written to his wife during  
their courtship.  

Ms. Hanson used the work  
of photographer Diane Arbus.  
She gave each student a photo  
and asked them to write a  
character sketch for the per-  
son in the photo. At first  
they did not like their char-  
acters, but as they wrote,  
they developed compassion for  
them. The students then sep-  
arated into small groups and  
wrote plays with the charac-  
ters they had developed.  

The students wrote imagin-  
ary letters to Ann Landers,  
describing problems with the  
opposite sex. Exchanging let-  
ters, they answered each oth-  
ers questions, thinking  
through problems and develop-  
ing writing skills at the  
same time.  

The class viewed several  
films, among them one about  
role reversal called Mascu-  
linity/Femininity. Exploring  
the ideas in it, they wrote  
essays on what would happen  
if their parents switched sex-  
ual roles.  

The class learned interview-  
ing skills from the documen-  
tary Growing Up Female. They  
interviewed students in other  
English classes, some went  
downtown to talk to people,  
some looked for certain peo-  
ple, like the elderly, and  
some tried to get a cross sec-  
tion of the population. The  
students also interviewed  
each other. They thought up  
ten questions they would ask  
someone of the same/opposite

By Heidi Reidel!

Finding the perfect obstetrical care took a lot of shopping around, but for Rebecca and Jose Barreiro of St. Paul, it was worth it. Rebecca explained their search and its fruits.

"I didn't want to have a doctor," said Rebecca. “I went to several but they didn't please me. They had an abrupt manner and I didn't feel they cared at all about me. I thought there had to be something else.”

Rebecca learned of Sharon Rising, a nurse midwife who teaches nurse-midwifery at the University of Minnesota School of Nursing. Rebecca said the way Rising treated her over the phone was a 100 percent improvement over the doctors she had seen.

"I decided I would go through with it. I'm a foreigner (she's from Cuba) and midwives were common where I came from. I wasn't scared of a midwife, but a lot of my friends said how could you do it? They think of midwifery as really medieval and spooky."

“I was her patient for four months before the baby was born. I liked the office visits a lot."

She said they were usually one-half hour to forty-five minutes long.

"Most doctors saw three or four patients in the time she saw me. She was not hurried and said I could call her any time. I didn't call. I'd save all my questions and take my time during the visit."

Rebecca spent the early part of her labor at home and didn't go to the hospital until her contractions came 30 seconds apart.

"She didn't rush me," continued Rebecca. "I checked with her all day long. I was educated as to the process so I could inform her fairly well about the timing and everything else."

Rebecca was glad to be home during her early labor. She thinks the bustle and confusion of a hospital would have detracted from the labor. "The sterility...the uncomfortable bed...the environment is not conducive to a relaxed labor," she explained.

When Rebecca, who hates the thought of hospitals, arrived, “it was great. When I was wheeled in, there was Sharon. She stayed with me all the time," said Rebecca. And that "all the time" amounted to seven more hours.

Like A Family Affair

"I'm a very high control person, I have to know what's happening to my body," Rebecca continued. "I had enough confidence in Sharon that I trusted what she said to me."

Sharon Rising's constant care had a special advantage for Rebecca. "I didn't have a whole barrage of nurses I didn't know coming in and out," she said.

Rebecca's exceptionally long labor had left her dehydrated and her muscles tense. Sharon decided she needed fluid intravenously and a muscle relaxing injection.

Rebecca didn't want the IV but, "I accepted it with Sharon, I wouldn't have with a nurse. She used a muscle relaxer that would leave me in control. She took a long time to explain it to me. Some just do, they don't explain. It was such an improvement over what my other American friends have told me."

"The whole thing was like a family affair. I didn't feel like I was sick. I had the best I could get," concluded Rebecca.

Midwifery Delivers Promises

Rebecca's and José's son should have been whisked off to the nursery because his temperature was 1/2 degree below normal. But Sharon let him stay with his new, excited parents to be nursed, photographed and played with for the first time.

Rebecca was ravenously hungry after 27 hours of labor. "No one eats at 3 a.m.," said Rebecca and all she got was toast and water. She fell asleep in the recovery room.

"When I woke up, Sharon was there. The hospital food wasn't enough to satisfy. She helped me a lot,” said Rebecca. "All the other women were getting shit."

"Sharon came to see me twice a day,” continued Rebecca. "Most other women saw their doctors once a day or every other day and had no one to answer questions. Sharon came to visit me twice at home, too.”

After she had been home for several weeks,  
Rebecca was still disappointed about the for-  
ceps delivery.  
"I wondered if by squatting  
or sidelying I could have dislodged the baby  
myself."  

She and Jose went to Sharon's office with  
their questions and went through the whole  
birth experience step-by-step. They questioned  
each other as to things they could have  
done differently or how they could have mis-  
read the situation.  
After their discussion,  
"I felt tremendously better, this big thing lifted off me."  

As to Rebecca's impressions of how they  
could have avoided the forceps episode, Re-  
becca said that Sharon wasn't condescending,  
she didn't have the "how dare you question  
me" attitude I've gotten from other doctors.  
"We reached conclusions together and that  
made her feel a part of us.  
It was really good."  

The Barriero's plan to leave the country  
next year, but Rebecca plans to return to  
Sharon for the birth of their second child.  

And the doctor with his handy forceps  
didn't recognize Rebecca when she went for  
her five-weeks checkup.  
"He thought I was a new patient."  

Twin Cities Obstetrics  

With all there is to  
choose from, a woman can either  
find exactly the kind of  
obstetrical care she wants or  
make a lot of mistakes. Here  
are some suggestions for  
choosing wisely.  

1. If you are interested  
in having a midwife attend  
you, there are two nurse-mid-  
wives in the Twin Cities who  
have private practices, Mar-  
garet Hewitt of Hennepin  
County General Hospital and  
Sharon Rising of the Univer-  
sity of Minnesota School of  
Nursing. Sharon has some  
friends who will soon be set-  
ting up practices and either  
woman would know if other  
midwives are available.  

2. The time and establi-  
shment honored ways to locate  
a physician are to call the  
local medical society or med-  
ical school.  

With the Hennepin County  
Medical Society, you are tak-  
ing pot luck. When one of  
the Society's 2,000 physi-  
cians has an opening, the cen-  
tral desk is notified and you  
get the names of three doc-  
tors in your area.  

The AMA advises prospective  
patients to call their  
local university or medical  
school and describe the  
kind of care you want.  

3. The Childbirth Education  
Association (CEA) has de-  
vised a more personal app-  
roach. By calling the CEA  
class registration number, you  
can also obtain a list of doc-  
tors supportive of prepared  
childbirth and couple parti-  
cipation. The doctors are re-  
commended by those who have  
taken a CEA course. You will  
also be given the home phone  
number of a person who reco-  
mmended that doctor. Call,  
chat with a satisfied customer  
and see if their philosophy a-  
grees with yours. Thus, you  
can save yourself the hassle  
and cost of an office visit  
and get a personal view.  

4. The La Leche League  
does the same kind of referral  
in a less extensive, less or-  
ganized way. They can help  
you find a doctor supportive  
of breastfeeding, however.  

5. Call the individual doc-  
tors you are interested in.  
If they don't inspire confi-  
dence or if you disagree with  
their approach, hang up and  
try again.  

6. Referral agencies such  
as Community Line can give you  
names of agencies and hospi-  
tals but make no individual  
recommendations.  

Sister Mary Meyer of St.  
Joseph's Hospital in St. Paul  
recently completed a survey  
of hospitals offering OB ser-  
vice in this area. She found  
that there are 20 hospitals  
with maternity wards opera-  
ting at 40 percent occupancy.  
In order to economize, some  
are combining gynecological  
departments with OB depart-  
ments.  

According to Sister Meyer,  
both kinds of patients are  
not getting the kind of care  
and attention they deserve.  

So be mindful that when  
you choose an obstetrician or  
family doctor or midwife,  
you are also choosing the hos-  
pital he or she practices in.  

Hospitals are competitive,  
consumer facilities--business-  
es. You are the consumer and  
have every right and an obli-  
gation to yourself to ask que-  
stions.  

Feel free to call the mat-  
ernity wards of individual  
hospitals to ask about facili-  
ties. Tour several and com-  
pare them. Remember, you are  
paying them for their serv-  
ices. If you don't like what  
you see, you probably don't  
live far from a hospital more  
to your liking.  

Feel free to question your  
doctor or midwife about hosp-  
ital and personal policy, too.  
Are fathers allowed in the  
delivery room? On whose  
terms--their permission or  
your request? Can you have  
rooming-in (having your baby  
in your hospital room with  
you)?  

You have the right and an  
increasing opportunity to get  
the kind of childbirth care  
you desire. Don't stop look-  
ing until you are satisfied.  
Having a baby isn't a time for  
worry or questions. It is a  
time to celebrate.

“We Want to Help You, Dear”

by Mary Hastings

NOTE TO READERS: The author was, until recently, employed by a Twin Cities firm. In May 1972 she filed
a sex discrimination charge against the corporation with the Minnesota Department of Human Rights. Sub-
sequently, she also filed a charge of race and sex discrimination against the corporation with the federal

Equal Employment Opportunities Commission (EEOC).

The State Commissioner of Human Rights, in November 1972, returned a decision of "no probable cause" to

assume the corporation had discriminated against women.

The author and her attorney appealed that decision

to the State Appeal Board. It overturned the Commissioner's decision and sent the charge back for reinvesti-

gation. The State Department of Human Rights has been in the reinvestigation process since April 1973. At this
writing, the author has received no information from the State concerning the disposition of her charge. (The
EEOC awaits the outcome of the State charge before taking jurisdiction.)

Part I of this series outlined events leading up to the filing of a sex discrimination charge, the filing pro-
cedure and the confrontation of the author and her supervisor after he was served with the charge.

Part II covers the three weeks following this confrontation:

Corporate Persuasion

peers, even though you have the only
Master's Degree in the room, are demon-
strably the most intelligent and are
supposedly equal to the males?

* You attempt to introduce an equitable

- system of housekeeping to your husband,
but clean the toilet, wash the dishes
and carry out the stacks of newspapers
collecting dust in the hall closet, after
you have been subjected to a week-long
silent treatment, accompanied by slamming
doors and crashing pots and pans.

* You are huffily asked if you've read
Henry Steele Commager's history of
American expansionism after you've shot
holes in a man's sophomoric political
vaporings.

You are on a guided tour of the male
arsenal, bristling with weapons to keep an
aberrant woman in her place. In the three
weeks following service of my charge against
the company, I took the first conscious steps
on my year-and-a-half tour of that arsenal.

Two hours after my supervisor acknowledged
my charge, I received a call from the
Vice President of Planning and Administra-
tion, a woman. She asked me if I would meet
her to "discuss this charge." I agreed and
met her late that afternoon at a downtown
motel where she and other top management
were in a "planning session." I was treated
to dinner on the corporate expense account
and the threat (larded with "concern") that
if I did not drop my charge my working life
would be--at best--unpleasant.

I said little, realizing that silence was
my proper state. I discounted much of the
menace underlying her "sisterly concern."

I knew that the woman was, unfortunately,
ignorant, with little understanding of the
issues involved in my charge.

Thanks to her, I had a first painful
glimpse of the limitations of sisterhood. I
had hoped--because of our common womanhood--
for an unguarded exchange. But I believe
that anyone involved in a sex discrimination

charge will encounter such untrustworthy wo-
men. They are "shills," to be dealt with as
a man, except for a measure of pity.

I also was introduced to the venality of
the company's top executives. She regaled me
with a sordid account of the personal doings
of her colleagues. She vilified my su-
pervisor and expressed considerable satisfac-
tion that my charge would "put him in his
place." I gathered that this outpouring
sprang from her personal frustrations and a
misguided attempt to disarm me.

When we completed our very brief dinner,
she announced that personnel representatives
would contact me in an effort to resolve
this "misunderstanding."

As I left the dining room, I noticed four
of her male colleagues at a back table. I
imagined that they already knew their "stalk-
ing horse" had failed.

Sinister Silence

When I arrived at work the following morn-
ing, I expected to be the object of whispered
conversations in the cafeteria and stares in
the hallways. Any other bad news traveled
rapidly at the company. Indeed, it seemed
that the prevailing management technique com-
bined general gossip and specific character
assassination. But, oddly, nothing changed in
my co-workers' attitudes toward me. For the

Sex Discrimination, continued

Next week, I expected momentarily to be os-
tracized. This never happened on a wide
scale. Certain selected males were even-
tually told of my heresy. Interestingly,
these men were in positions to adversely
affect my ability to do my job. But news
of my charge was never generally bruited a-
bout. It was the special hope of the com-
pany's personnel people to guard news of my
action from women, who might be emboldened.

A week and a half following my dinner
with Q, the Personnel Director summoned me
to his office. J was a suave, wolf-like
man with iron-tinted hair, black bullet eyes
and a reputation for canniness in "employee
relations." I had heard from my male
friends that he was a shouter and desk poun-
der when confronted with problems he could
not smother with unction. Naively, I assum-
ed I would have to face such violence. I
didn't realize that this approach was reser-
ved for males—full-fledged members of hum-
anity. Women could be gotten around with a
minimum of energy.

J introduced me to the most important and
pervasive weapon men use against women—
AUTHORITY.

As I sat opposite his laminated walnut
stain desk, I became 10-year-old Mary again,
a straight-A student who rarely misbehaved
in school but who nonetheless chafed at the
Calvinistic hypocrisy of the teachers—
indeed, who felt secret kinship with a
fourth-grade reprobate named Clarence who
was the object of our teacher's shocking
cruelty because the unfortunate boy didn't
have the ability to stud his report cards
with A's and to confine his rebellion to the
perimeters of his mind.

J, of course, knew nothing of Clarence and
10-year-old Mary. Before him sat a strange,
"wrong-headed" woman who needed setting
straight.

"I wish you had come to us first," he de-
clared. "I'm sure we could settle this mis-
understanding within the company, without a
formal, legalistic structure."

J hoped I would seriously consider drop-
ping the charge and "working with the Per-
sonnel Department to correct any misunder-
standing."

He had been in touch with the State Depart-
ment of Human Rights. He had vast experi-
ence in minority employee problems. He was
a friend of the State Commissioner of Hum-
an Rights. These credentials presented, J
launched a monologue about his daughters,
who were track stars, and could compete as
fiercely as any man. Women were, naturally,
equal to men. (I privately wondered if he
felt the appropriate female costume to be a
brass-buttoned jacket and tin cup.)

All a Misunderstanding

While the edge of my mind accompanied J's
daughters around the race track, the core of
my thoughts rested on the mildly ominous word
"misunderstanding." Q had also used it. I
had anticipated many unpleasant consequences
of filing the charge. But I had expected
the company to defend itself against that
charge of sex discrimination. It devolved
upon Q, and especially J, to point out that
there had been no discrimination, only "mis-
understanding."

There is nothing so characteristic of late
20th century Americans as their practice of
denying a problem, a crime, a wart on a
backside. And since America is male, I
should not have been surprised to discover
that my problem with my employer lay in faulty
understanding, not oppression.

I hope you will agree to meet with

I was drawn from my sociological rumina-
tions to J's conciliatory smile.
"Of course," I responded guiltily. Guilt?
Why that? Because of that female burden, I
made the error of ever seriously countenan-
cing the company's empty blandishments. But
I had been raised to strive toward honesty
and empathy with my fellows. I should have
approached the Pandora's Box of conciliation
more cautiously. (See box, page <p)

J relaxed as he read the familiar signs
of female hesitation and guilt at creating
"obstacles and unpleasantness."

As far as I was concerned, our meeting
was over. (Although yet afflicted with many
"female weaknesses," I had already allowed
my naturally strong personality to assert
itself by terminating meetings when I chose,
rather than awaiting dismissal from the pa-
triarch/male.) Accordingly, I arose, in-
formed J I would contact the State Investi-
gator on my case about a "conciliation meet-
ing" and left.

On returning to my office I called the
State Investigator and we settled on a meet-
ing date two weeks distant.

I then had 14 days to analyze my situa-
tion. As the gears of American due process
missed and meshed, I became aware of a pat-
tern forming in my relationship with the com-
pany:

Discrimination, continued

@Personnel and top management would keep my action quiet and I would abet them because of a personal dislike of notoriety.

@I would not be dramatically dismissed, as I had thought. (Nothing so clean or kind lay in store for me.)

®The company would attempt to appease me in the initial phase of dealing with my charge.

@The company would try to wear me down. Less than a month had passed since I filed the charge, and already I was tired. Now I realized that my anticipation of confrontation and resolution was illusory. I still only dimly perceived, however, the difficulty of watching my every word and act, of performing my job satisfactorily and of somehow finding the mental and emotional reserves to withstand the company's onslaught.

This pattern would undergo some significant modifications in what I think of as "Phase II and III" of the prosecution of my charge, but the basic pattern—set less than one month after I filed—remained in force until I quit my job two months ago.

The Art of Conciliation--- or What Every Trojan Should Know About Greeks

If you file a sex discrimination charge against your employer in Minnesota, you are required to partake of "conciliation" if the respondent (your employer) so wishes. Thus, you should be prepared to abide by the law, but always remember that a sincere employer is as rare as a rich man in heaven.

Your employer will be ever so eager to have you drop the charge so that you and the company can "work together" to clear up the "misunderstanding." Never, never drop your charge. You will have wasted all the pain and energy it cost you to file. And your employer will simply wear you down until you quit or, in a few months, a plausible reason will be found to fire you.

As I noted in Part I of this series, it is best to retain an attorney before you ever file a charge. But certainly, if you are approaching "conciliation" and do not have legal counsel, hesitate no longer. Do not go into conciliation meetings without prior advice from an attorney.

Be sure to limit your employer's "conciliation" attempts. Do not allow it to postpone action with sharp maneuvers.

Your employer will, of course, make fulsome promises. In my case, the only concrete result of conciliation was an inadequate salary adjustment. (See details of my first conciliation meeting in Part III of this series next month.) My salary was adjusted back several months—NOT to my starting date. Thus, I could not claim my employer had admitted that I was treated unfairly at the outset.

All other promises revolved around my completing "career counseling" and "job clarification" with my supervisor. It is interesting to note that, once again, the female was assumed to be lacking in some way. I was forced into these ridiculous exercises, even though I was the aggrieved party. This "turning the tables" on women is the second important weapon men have.

I spent many hours listing my job functions, categorizing them on 3 x 5 note cards and assigning a mysterious "A, B or C" authority rating to each task. These exercises were a burden on me and detracted from the time I could spend doing my job. Meanwhile, my employer was hiding in the blizzard of note cards, thoughtfully planning its next step.

(The company's enthusiasm for making me happy in my work declined precipitously when they realized I would not drop the charge.)

You should understand that while your employer is tiring you out with countless interviews and heaping insulting "concern" on you over your “unhappiness” with your job, it is busily marshalling its defenses. And they are impressive.

Your employer has unlimited money. (Relatively speaking)

Your employer either has its own legal staff or the ability to retain legal experts.

Your employer has reams of statistics that can be molded like hot gold to present an innocent face.

@YOUR EMPLOYER HAS RESPECTABILITY.

And you have:

™ the right to retain an attorney. Do so, for your peace of mind and the proper prosecution of your charge.

Your employer's fear of publicity. I could not exploit this, because of personal squeamishness. But carefully consider the value of this fear. I think that group actions might be particularly aided by public exposure of your employer. (Your employer will, of course, find your perverted love of publicity morally repugnant.)

Female Co-workers. Supposedly "non-feminist" women can be extremely supportive of a woman involved in a sex discrimination charge. I made the mistake of hiding my action from most of my female colleagues. Although it is not advisable to aggressively proselytize "non-political" women, it is wise to tell them about your action and how it can affect them.

SELF PORTRAIT BY JOAN JOHNSTONE

Hand-tinted photographs reminiscent of
early 20th century postcards are featured
in an exhibition on view through December
30 at the upstairs gallery of the Afro-
American Cultural Arts Center, 24 S. 31st
Street, Minneapolis.

The photographs are the work of a young
woman artist, Joan Johnstone, whose work
has been seen before in University exhibi-
tions and who worked as a portfolio artist
with Lee Strasberg's Actors Studio in New
York before returning to Minneapolis early
this year.

The technique is an original one, invented
by Johnstone through experimental attempts
to reproduce the delicate colors of the old
postcards she collects. Working on matte
paper, she creates smooth surfaces with oil
color, brilliant highlights with water dyes.

Johnstone points out that her work, al-
though experimental, is an enlargement of
traditional photographic techniques and
is not done merely for the sake of exper-
imentation. "My technique modifies the
black-and-white photograph, and gives it
more impact," Johnstone says. The photo-
graphs are painted in a careful process
that may take up to ten hours.

Nothing happened.

nostrils twitching at unexpected scent,
then jet-glow eyes go red in shock when

Portrait of a Marriage § ,

| Book
Review

‘Vita, Violet

by Susan Cushman

My acquaintance with Vita Sackville-West
has been a gradual and increasingly pleasant
experience. I first noticed her while read-
ing about Virginia Woolf; Vita was a writer-
ly friend who lagged somewhat behind Virgin-
ia's literary tastes, yet thoroughly satis-
fied her as a companion. Virginia wrote, "I
like her and being with her and the splen-
dour...There is her maturity and full breast-
edness; her being so much in full sail on
the high tides, where I am coasting down
backwaters; her capacity I mean to take the
floor in any country...her being in short
(what I have never been) a real woman. Then
there is some voluptuousness about her; the
grapes are ripe; and not reflective."

Virginia expressed her liking for Vita
more fully in Orlando, a rambunctious, gal-
lant novel about a hearty human being whose
life spanned several centuries and encompas-
sed an abrupt and final sex change. The
book was dedicated to Vita and contained
some curious photographs of her.

Orlando was perhaps the first positive
public commemoration of a tumultuous, sexual-
ly ambivalent period in Vita's life. The
second public recognition has come in the
recently published Portrait of a Marriage
(Atheneum, 249 pages, $10) by Nigel Nicolson,
Vita's youngest son.

The book has five sections - two by Vita
and three by Nicolson. Vita's are autobio-
graphical, written when she was 28, married,
and dramatically involved in a love affair
with another woman - Violet Trefusis. She
begins with her aristocratic heritage, pas-
ses through her apparently unhappy child-
hood, and finally concentrates on the con-
flict which arose when she could not deci-
sively choose between Violet and her husband,
diplomat Harold Nicolson. Her account gains
momentum as she catches up to events in the
final entries, which take on the immediacy
of a diary.

“An Absurd Circumstance”

Nicolson's portions serve as commentary
and contextual filler, as he attempts to
place Vita's incomplete autobiography with-
in the framework of her entire life.

Vita had been married to Harold Nicolson
for five years when she was reunited with
Violet, a childhood friend, in a suddenly
erotic relationship. It was not Vita's
first homosexual involvement; prior to her
marriage she had been offhandedly conducting
an affair with Rosamund, another childhood
friend. Because she had not been seriously
taken with Rosamund, whom she quite brutally
shucked off after her wedding, Vita evident-
ly considered sexual love between women a
frivolous, easily controlled hobby.

But her love for Violet was powered by an
irresistible impetus, for with Violet, Vita
became a new, strangely exuberant person.
Two years after the affair had begun in
earnest, she wrote: "An absurd circumstance
gave rise to the whole thing; I had just got
clothes like the women-on-the-land were wear-
ing, and in the unaccustomed freedom of
breeches and gaiters I went into wild
spirits; I ran, I shouted, I jumped, I climbed,
I vaulted over gates, I felt like a

& Harold

schoolboy let out on a holiday; and Violet
followed me across fields and woods with a
new meekness, saying very little, but never
taking her eyes off me...it was simply the
drunkenness of liberation - the liberation
of half my personality. She opened up to me
a new sphere.”

After the sphere had lost its newness, it
became infinitely complicated. Violet and
Vita spent a passionate summer together,
going off on small trips whenever they could.
In late fall, they left for France with
plans to return to England before Christmas.
But in Paris, Vita took advantage of a newly
discovered excitement.

The Boy Julian

"I dressed as a boy. It was easy, because
I could put a khaki bandage round my head,
which in those days was so common that it
attracted no attention at all. I browned my
face and hands...My height of course was my
great advantage. I looked like a rather un-
tidy young man, a sort of undergraduate, of
about nineteen...Violet used to call me
Julian. We dined together every evening in
cafes and restaurants, and went to all the
theatres. I shall never forget the evenings
when we walked back slowly to our flat
through the streets of Paris. I, personally
had never felt so free in my life. Perhaps
we have never been so happy since."

The two lovers did not return at Christ-
mas. By the time Vita and Violet meandered
into London at the end of March, the "scan-
dal" had become semi-public and Vita was ur-
ged to give Violet up to an impending mar-
riage of her own.

Violet wanted to make a complete break and
live with Vita in unhampered female freedom.
Vita vacillated. Then Violet married, pro-
bably in an attempt to stir Vita into jeal-
ous action. The two rejected husbands con-
ducted a united campaign in their efforts to
separate their wives. In the end, after
chases back and forth across Europe, the hus-
bands were triumphant and the women parted
in the spring of 1920. Their affair had
lasted three years.

Soon after Vita's death in 1962, Nigel Ni-
colson found her short, handwritten autobio-
graphy locked away in her writing room. He
waited until his father also died, and then
a few years more, ten in all, before bring-
ing the manuscript to light. Apparently, he
feared that readers would condemn Vita and
disregard the eventually stable and long-
lasting marriage between his mother and

father. As the title indicates, his commen-
tary in Portrait of a Marriage reduces the
affair with Violet to an episode within a
larger, insulating framework.
Harold Nicolson, also a homosexual,
did not begrudge Vita an extramarital es-
cape for he conducted some himself. But he
was not prepared to let them permanently inter-
fere with the continuum of his life with Vita.
Though Vita had much the same attitude,
the intensity of her relationship with Vio-
let took her by surprise. She wrote to
Nigel in 1960:
"When we married, you were older than I
was, and far better informed. I was very

young, and very innocent. I knew nothing  
about homosexuality. I didn't even know  
that such a thing existed either between men  
or between women. You should have told me.  
You should have warned me. You should have  
told me about yourself and warned me that  
the same sort of thing was likely to happen  
to myself. It would have saved us a lot of  
trouble and misunderstanding. But I simply  
didn't know.”

What Vita didn't know, or Harold either,  

I think, was that sexual love of any sort  
could be an overwhelming, sustained exper-  
ience. While they had been sexually inter-  
ested in each other at the beginning of their  
marriage, this facet of their relationship,  
which was probably never too enthusiastic,  
was eliminated after the birth of their  
second son. Harold's involvements with men  
were brief and inconsequential. No doubt he  
assumed that Vita's would be the same; and  
once her ardor for Violet had been stilled,  
Vita did in fact conduct subsequent affairs  
lightheartedly.

Portrait of a Marriage is both provocative  
and unyielding. Vita's account was written  
during an emotionally turbulent time, when  
she believed that her life was "a morass...  
a bog, a swamp, a deceitful country” and her  
writing seems hurried and incomplete. She  
began the story because she wanted to tell  
the truth about a habitually secret sort of  
relationship and "because I hold the convic-  
tion that as centuries go on, and the sexes  
become more nearly merged...such connections  
will to a very large extent cease to be re-  
garded as merely unnatural, and will be un-  
derstood far better...I believe that then  

the psychology of people like myself will be  
a matter of interest, and I believe it will  
be recognized that many more people of my  
type do exist than under the present-day  
system of hypocrisy is commonly admitted."

Vita went on to say that even if homosex-  
uality is an “evil” it should be treated  
with candor. Her ambivalence toward homo-  
sexuality was never resolved.

Sympathy, Neutrality & Flatness  

In his chapters, Nicolson alternates be-  
tween sympathy and neutrality toward his  
mother's private life. However, his collec-  
tion of surrounding facts, while no doubt  
carefully gathered, serve to flatten, rather  
than illuminate Vita's recollection. Be-  
tween the two of them, Violet remains a  
shadowy figure and the sequence of events an  
undeciphered jumble. Still, the book is a  
breakthrough of sorts, since the very pri-  
vate lives of famous people are not often  
revealed when homosexuality is a significant  
factor. Portrait of a Marriage would have  
been a more satisfying book, however, if  
Nicolson had not been so concerned with the  
reticent dictates of "good taste."

Vita's best writing describes her exuber-  
ant transformation into “Julian." The  
switch had cultural, as well as sexual, con-  
notations. Vita wrote: "I never appreciated  
anything so much as living like that with  
my tongue perpetually in my cheek, and in  
defiance of every policeman I passed."

Nigel Nicolson assumed that Vita was re-  
lieved to have emerged from the Violet/Ju-  
lian period to settle down to a calmer 40  
years as Harold's definite wife. I wonder  
about that, particularly when I read Vir-  
ginia Woolf's knowing passage in Orlando  
where she describes a change from male to  
female. Orlando is sailing for England and  
ponders the thing that has taken place.

"{It is a strange fact, but a true one that  
up to this moment she had scarcely given her  
sex a thought...it was not until she felt  

“These skirts are plaguey things”  

the coil of skirts about her legs and the  
Captain offered, with the greatest polite-  
ness, to have an awning for her on deck that  
she realised, with a start, the penalties and  
the privileges of her position..."Lord," she  
thought, when she had recovered from her  
start..."this is a pleasant, lazy way of  
life, to be sure. But," she thought, giving  
her legs a kick, “these skirts are plaguey  
things to have about one's heels"...Here  

she tossed her foot impatiently, and showed  
an inch or two of calf. A sailor on the

started so violently that he missed his foot-

humanity, keep them covered," Orlando  
thought..."A pox on them!" she said, realis-  
ing for the first time, what, in other cir-

bilities of womanhood..."All I can do, once  
I set foot on English soil, is to pour out  
tea and ask my lords how they like it. D'you  
take sugar? D'you take cream?" And mincing  
out the words, she was horrified to perceive  
how low an opinion she was forming of the  
other sex, the manly, to which it had once  
been her pride to belong."

Orlando the man into Orlando the woman,  
Julian back into Vita, and I somehow see  
this passage Virginia Woolf wrote for Vita  
Sackville-West as one of the finer tributes  
one woman has ever paid another.
