Toward A World Without Labels

by Dianna Hunter

I've been thinking a lot lately about how I,  
a lesbian woman, can love women who choose  
to live with and love men. By this I mean  
both the so-called "straight" woman whose  
most intimate energies go into men and the  
so-called “bisexual” woman whose most inti-  
mate energies may also go into women.

It's been about two and a half years since  
I realized I was a lesbian and came out in  
my consciousness-raising group. And now  
I've had about two and a half years of  
problems in dealing with "bisexual" and  
"straight" women.

When I came out, I was living with four other  
women. We had gotten together by chance  

to rent a professor's house, which turned  

out to be the perfect setting for my coming  
out. Two of the other women and I were  
involved in feminist consciousness-raising  
groups. We talked about women, sexism,  
sexuality, lesbianism, and other feminist  
issues at length, both inside and outside  

the groups. For me, this was a major part  

of all that I learned from those women. I  
also learned about cooking, painting, weav-  
ing, and pottery. I felt this time was a  
vibrant time, a time pregnant with personal  
growth. The feminist ideas, my relationships  
with the women of my house and with one  

other close friend, my friends' work in  

the arts—all these influences moved me to  
realize the deep love I had for other women.

I was coming out slowly, learning new ways  
that I could touch women with my body, my  
feelings, and my ideas—in other words, with  
my intimate self. I was loving this inti-  
macy, and wanting more. I guess the point  
at which I decided I was a lesbian was when  
I realized I wanted to make love to other  
women, not just hug them hello and goodbye  
or catch a quick pat on the back. At that  
time I felt defenses going up between me as  
lesbian and them as straight. I sensed a  
definite limit in how much they would give  
to me. Because I loved them, I wanted to  
sleep with them. They loved me but did not  
want to lead me on or give me any false im-  
pressions of their affection for me. They  
did not want to sleep with me. I began to  
feel one major difference standing between  
them and me: They wanted to sleep with men;  
I wanted to sleep with women. This dif-  
ference gave each of us her label. I became  
"lesbian." They became "straight women."

Women have asked me, "Don't you want to get  
rid of labels?" Yes, of course I do. But  
first I want to get rid of the things that  
cause us to use labels. For now, “lesbian"  
and "straight woman" have meaning to me.  
With a lesbian, I feel our love for one anoth-  
er could advance to any level. This is not  

to say that love between lesbians is perfect,  

always advancing on to higher and higher  
levels, both women desiring the same love  
experiences. It does mean that with each  
lesbian I meet, there is a chance that we  
may make love. I know that I cannot sleep  
with a straight woman. Consequently, I  
have felt that I could not put much energy  
into a relationship with a straight woman.  
Whatever ways we found to love one another  
would be blocked at a level which I have  
found fulfilling. Joni Mitchell wrote,  
"making love is touching souls." I was  

afraid I would fall in love with a straight  
woman, and we would not be able to touch  
souls.

I envision a world where there will be no  
labels "straight woman" or "lesbian." There  
we will relate on all levels that feel right,  
at the time that they feel right. We will  
touch souls if you and I both desire it. I  
will be true to myself. I will do the things  
that I want to do. You will also act as you  
truly wish. We will be honest with one  
another about which ways we want our relation-  
ship to grow. When we stop growing together,  
we will part without fear, still loving and  
respecting one another. For now, though, I  
do see fears in the way of our loving one  
another. I want to identify my own fears of  
straight women (By this term I also mean  
bisexual women.), so I can work through the  
fears. I think identifying them will help  
begin the process of eliminating them.

When talking to straight women, I feel fear,  
in both myself and them, associated with  
the question of men. I am a member of the  
Twin City Women Poets. Recently, in that  
group, we hassled because another lesbian  
and I wanted the group to sponsor a woman-  
centered poetry reading. By this we meant  
the poems would be about women, and only  
women could attend. The straight women  
poets said they would accept the idea of  
reading poems about women. But they would  
not accept keeping men out of the reading.  
I do not want to relate to men. I do not  
wish to read my poetry to men. I don't  
wish to deny other women the option of re-  
lating to men, but I want straight women to  
recognize my need not to deal with men.

As soon as the argument over the woman-cen-  
tered reading began, I felt my defenses  

go up against the straight woman poets.

Just to know that a woman has a man in her  
heart frightens me. I have tried to carry  
on sexual relationships with two women who  
considered themselves bisexual, and in both  
cases, I felt very threatened by the other  
woman's relationships with men.

The first woman and I knew one another for  
about six months before we made love. We  
had kissed a lot one night at the bar, and  
she had invited me home and then decided  
that she didn't want to make love with me  
because of a relationship she was having  
with a man. After we did finally consum-  
mate our relationship, we spent approxi-  
mately another six months of being friends  
and lovers, sometimes sleeping together and  
sometimes not. I felt that I was in a more  
vulnerable position than she because I saw  
myself as a lesbian. I was stuck there, as  
a lover of women, loving her in particular.  
She was free to abandon her lesbianism, and  
me, and to go on relating to men. She was  

never very comfortable thinking of herself as  
a lesbian, anyway. She once told me that  

she formed her closer and more honest re-  
lationships with women, but that she just  
liked sleeping with men.

The other straight woman whom I really cared  
for never was my lover. We talked a lot,  
kissed and hugged, fondled, and slept to-  

gether. But we never made love. She was  

continued on next page

feeling that she might be a lesbian. She  
said how beautiful women are. She talked  
about experiencing sensuality in what she  
thought would be a woman's way—not per-  
forming pre-established acts, but exploring  
sensations, textures, tastes. I learned a  
lot from this friend, and I would like to  
know her better. I hope our relationship  
can one day grow so that we can touch and  
give to each other on new levels. But for  
now, it has stopped growing. We do not  
even see each other as friends, only at  
meetings. I feel that the sexual pressure  
ruined our relationship. She was wondering  
whether she should sleep with me, while I  
wondered whether I would sleep with her. I  
was frustrated by not being able to show  
her, physically, my feelings for her. And  
she was not able, or ready, to consider  
herself a lesbian.  

One thing I've learned is that making love  
is not possible with all lesbians, not even  
with every lesbian that I care about. Each  
friendship seems to have a different physi-  
cal level. With some lesbian friends I  
barely touch. We hug hello and goodbye,  
and kiss on the cheek, or quickly on the  
lips. With other friends, I can walk hand-  
in-hand, rub noses, rock in one another's  
arms, and sleep face-to-face, embracing.  

I love each woman on a unique level, and I  
am learning to express my love for each  
woman in a unique and appropriate way. For  
one thing, I am learning that "sleeping  
with" doesn't necessarily mean "making  
love." And neither does kissing, fondling,  
or loving glances necessarily mean that I  
want genital sex from the relationship.  

I was so happy after the last women poets'  
meeting when an old friend and I cuddled.  

I hadn't seen her for a long time. I was  
glad to see her. I was loving her. And  

I felt like being hugged, so I sat on her  
lap. She put her arms around me. We  
rocked, and patted, and fondled, and talked  
for a while. I have been touching my lesbian  
friends in that way, but this was the first  
time I had had such a positive and easy phys-  
ical experience with a straight woman.  
Usually I feel unsatisfied by the physical  
affection straight women show me. It often  

comes as a quick pat, halting, and with the  
hand quickly jerked away. No lingering  
touches. I like to be warmed by being  
touched. I like to warm other women by  
touching them. And the part of touching  
that seems to warm me best is the lingering  
kind of touch, a touch that conveys a feel-  
ing of comfort and acceptance. I hope that  
straight women and lesbians will learn to  
touch one another warmly, and without fear  
of what that touching means.  

Such open relationships will take hard work.  
We are going to have to be honest with one  
another, and talk to one another a lot about  
our different lifestyles. For me, it is  
difficult to understand the reality of a  

straight woman's life. I can't really pic-  
ture what she feels as she relates to men.  
I don't know what kind of changes or growth  
she expects to experience with men.  

Married women, family women, women living  
with men and doing the housekeeping, even  
women living with men and working to improve  
the relationship between men and women,  

all these are lifestyles which are foreign  
to my experience. Since I left my parents'  
home in 1967, I have shared a home with a  
man only once, for three months, more than  
two years ago. Since then, my closer  
friends and my roommates have all been  
lesbians.  

To straight women my experience is foreign.  
When I told the Twin City Women Poets that  
I was living in a women's culture, one  
woman said, "but that's not reality." We  
each have our own reality. Part of me  

goes to work forty hours a week at an alien-  
ating job. Part of me pays rent to a male  
landlord. Part of me spends money at  
capitalist food stores when I don't feel  
like walking six blocks to a food co-op.  
But there is a large part of me that works  
as fast as I can to learn about women.  

That means to learn about myself, too. It  
means looking for my roots in the history  
of the Matriarchy. Woman-centered cultures.  
Goddesses. Witches. Herbalists. Midwives.  
Hecate. Artemis. Diana. Athena. Joan  

of Arc. Amelia Earhart. Wonder Woman.  
Billy Jean King. All of our past and  

Our strength  
that never has been completely buried,  

that was here all along. I want to be  
strong, and I want to be able to give  
strength to other women.  

I see our strength building. I spent  
Thanksgiving on a farm in Wisconsin. Four  
women friends of mine live there, and two  
children friends. The women are raising  
the children, seven horses, chickens, ducks,  
three dogs, two cats, bees, and one another.  
They have cut a pile of wood bigger than  
their house. They eat their own bees'  

honey and use the beeswax in a salve for  
their horses' hooves. As for dreams, one  
of the finest I've known was a reality:  
White Mare galloping across a crisp, frosty  
field with Marea astride. The horse is all  
white, muscled, the most spirited of all  
their horses. Only Marea can handle her  
riding bareback. Marea's hair and White  
Mare's magnificent tail were flying behind  
as they galloped. Marea looked serious,  
resolute, not at all frightened. I thought  
of Joan of Arc. Heroines. A dream living.  

There are lots of women's farms. I have  
heard of them in Washington, Oregon, Cal-  
ifornia, Colorado, Arkansas, and Minnesota.  
I see women learning to become self-suffi-  
cient for food and energy. I see this  
learning as a reality which will help bring  
about the larger reality of a woman's cul-  
ture. I see dreams growing in the city,  
too. The Lesbian Resource Center, Twin  
City Women Poets, Goldflower, So's Your Old  
Lady, the Elizabeth Blackwell women’s health  
clinic, Women's Counseling Service, the  
food co-ops, and the North Country dry  
goods store have all grown from the dreams  
of women.  

A good thing that happened recently at a  
women poets’ meeting was one woman saying  
we need to write more about our hopes and  
accomplishments, and less about our trouble  
and shortcomings. I agree. I think we  
will truly begin to love and energize one  
another when we start giving other women  
our dreams. Goodbye to Sylvia Plath. I  
don't want to listen to her madness any  
more. And as for Virginia Woolf in the  
river, I'd like to see her come wading back  

out, unburdening herself of stones by throw-  
ing them at her oppressors. I don't want  

to think about her sinking. I won't give  

in to madness or suicide, as long as there  
are women to love me, touch me, and feed me  
dreams.

by Eleanor Vincent

Louise Nevelson has been a working artist  
for 53 years. For three decades, although  
she produced work in a variety of media, she  
never made a sale. During those years she  
was ignored and sometimes treated with out-  
right hostility by what she calls the "art  
Mafia."

Now art critics are calling her the greatest  
living American sculptor. Despite her hard  
won fame and wealth, Nevelson remains a warm,  
gracious person. There is no pretense about  
her. She speaks openly about her commitment  
to feminism on a global and personal scale.

Nevelson has faced many difficult situations  
in her life, but her marriage and her aff-  
iliation with the Sidney Janis Gallery rank  
in her mind as the most destructive.

She was the first woman and the first Amer-  
ican sculptor ever shown by New York's pres-  
tigious Janis Gallery in the early sixties.  
She constructed three huge walls to be shown  
by Janis. The show was well received, but  
none of the pieces were sold. In debt to  
Janis for $20,000, she had to sell her  
studio-home in order to raise the money.

In the meantime, Janis held her works as  
collateral.

She succeeded in ransoming the wooden hos-  
tages, but the experience took a tremen-  
dous mental and physical toll. Years earl-  
ier she had been able to claim her total  
being by breaking up her marriage to con-  
centrate fully on her art.

The capacity to free herself from domination  
has played a crucial role in developing her  
individual and artistic consciousness. She  
and her work become stronger and more beau-  
tiful with age.

QUESTIONS and ANSWERS

Q: How have you escaped or redefined the role  
society creates for women?

A: For thousands of years, way back in the  
Bible, men controlled the universe. We speak  
about—and I do too, I forget and speak  
about—he, the he. God is he and right from  
God down and before God there was he. So  
naturally where there's the greater power  
you're going to have the rest subservient to  
it.

But I think some people are born with a feel-  
ing of independence; that they belong to them-  
selves. And then there's a conflict, because  
if you belong to yourself when you step out  
over the threshold into the so-called world,  
you're hit back. You're smacked this way,  
you're smacked that way, because you're not  
in the dominant position.

At this point, there are women in the high-  
est positions. They're given their jobs by  
men; say, even politically. Now you know I  
can't stand that president—that isn't it.  
But the president has given positions to wo-  
men. Of course those women he selected are  
worshipers of him. They support him. So  
those women, whom we would expect to be em-  
ancipated and help humanity just turn right  
around and are slaves again. In principle,  
if you are a lowly slave or a high-class  
slave, you're still in the process of being  
a slave. You see?

I think in our time, through awareness, the  
schools and education things are changing.  
No matter whether you accept or reject the  

conventional education, it does something.

It opens. I don't say it opens all areas,  
but it does enlighten you somewhere. So why  
would anyone expect women that go to our best  
schools to go into the kitchen and be satis-  
fied? It's utterly ridiculous.

If you are trained and you're equipped to be  
a great opera star, you're not going to give  
that up, because you like to sing and work  
at it and that's your life. You're not go-  
ing in the kitchen. So we have many more  
trained women and the sum total of the pool-  
ing of the consciousness of the awareness of  
all these things—not only in America, but  
the world over—causes them to awaken. I  
don't think it's easy, but there are some  
good heads that are battling and I'm very  
optimistic that it will change. It's grow-  
ing into it, it's bound to.

Now we had women's suffrage, we had other  
things, but never was there a group that saw  
it through. And even now there's a bit of a  
lull from a few years back. But it's es-  
tablished and we can all look forward to it  
being part of our way of life.

Don't forget that when there's a master and  
a slave, the master is also enslaved. So  
men will never be emancipated until they  
accept that every human being is a human be-  
ing and not be caught in just one part of  

the body.

Q: But you were not saying these things, but  
at least thinking them many, many years ago.

A: Well, I took them.  
I didn't think them. I had to take them for  
what I wanted to do. I knew I was gifted.  
Now you see we're taught to be modest and to  
be ladylike. Well, that's deadly. And es-  
pecially if you have this thing that I wanted  
so badly. And not only that, that's the way  
I wanted to live. And I didn't want to be  
hemmed in by anybody. I don't think the  
world's that big. So I just had to break, if  
you call it traditions, but I didn't even con-  
sider them. I just did.

I didn't say them and

Q: Was the price you paid to break out worth  
it?

A: I needed to claim my total being. That  
means time, thought, you know, it means that I  
wanted to be in control of myself. So that  
I'd be free to live my life as I could under-  
stand it.

Q: Well, you paid some kind of price for that.

A: Of course, you pay, but you see, darling,  
if you don't do that you pay a price that's  
probably more. I was married, I was  
getting abscesses and boils. The blood  

boils just like on a stove and you get these  
things. I got sciatica and I was crippled.

I left, I was miserable, and I went to Eur-  
ope to study and just crossing the ocean and  
having the lid taken off my head, they dis-  
appeared. But what would have happened if  

I was confined?

Now, when I say confined, it was a time of  
affluence and nice surroundings. So, there's  
something about us, that demands what we are.  
And it doesn't really matter so much our  
surroundings in a case like that, an extreme  
case. Because I knew my capacity I was itching  
all over because I was bottled up.

Q: So in other words, the price you would  
have paid by not doing it would have been  
worse.  

A: I would have committed suicide. I would  
have cut my throat. And I would have wished  
the throat was a little bigger so I could  

cut it more.  

Q: What role does anger as a catalyst play  
in your work?  

A: I feel in retrospect that anger was very im-  
portant in my development. I used anger for  
my unfolding to the place I am. Yes. I  
don't dismiss it. I also think—now don't  
say that I said I was a drunkard—but I used  
alcohol in a medical way. Because when I  
was psychically so fatigued I found that I  
would never dismiss what liquor did for me.  

Now I don't say that I was alcoholic, but I  
think that it helped me. It was like if I  
was in a high spot and I wanted to really  
jump out of the window, then you land on a  
rope and then you don't touch bottom. Well,  
alcohol was able to do that for me. You see  
there were not as many pills, or I didn't  
know about them. Now we know in recent years  
about chemistry. Say people that go off.  
They give them things and they find it’s an  
imbalance in chemistry in the body.  

Maybe when you think and work as I did—I  
depleted the body. Now I would probably go  
to a doctor and get a shot. Or I would go  
to a doctor that would give me these things  
that would quiet me. But at that time I  
don't think it existed and so I did it an-  
other way, maybe a more primitive way.  

Q: If you were angry about something, would  
that help you to work or drive you to work?  

A: I think it did. You see your glands are  
very stimulated and you're in a pitch where,  
yes, you have to work it off. Some people,  
like in the country, would probably chop  
wood in order to relax. But I did it my way  
which included a great deal of physical  
labor. No one has said it to my knowledge,  
but I maintain that there's great intellect  
in physical labor. I'm sure that I learned  
a great deal out of physical labor in my  
work. I would not dismiss it.  

In our times in sculpture we can make a  
little drawing or a little cardboard ma-  
quette and then it is blown up in a foundry.  
Now, I do my work myself to a great degree  
because I like it and I identify with it.  
It's very living for me; I live with it.  

And having studied modern dance, when I move  
with it the rhythms and all of that plays a  
very important part in my consciousness.  
That for me is living.  

Q: Do you still dance at all?  

A: Oh, yes, yes. I do the whole works.  

Q: How do you get into your work? What sort  
of process do you go through?  

A: Every time I approach a project I shy  
away like a horse, because it is a new  
thing. You've lived another day. Even  
from one minute to another, we're changing.  
If you sit here 24 hours a day or a life-  
time, every second there is a change.  

Night doesn't come in a minute and a dawn  
doesn't come in a minute. It's gradual.  
Through the day it's moving a little bit.  
You don't see it, it's so slow to our eye.  

Our consciousness is the same. Let me say  
that I finished something and sat down to  
have lunch. I went through a whole thing of  
lunch, picking up the cup, the fork and so  
forth. There's great activity. By the time  
I come back (to work) I'm already an hour  
older. And already, I'm not quite the same.  
People never think about that—they miss,  
they jump, they don't think.  

And say, you, or whoever; I've had a dozen  
television and radio and newspaper inter-  
views here. Do you think I'm the same per-  
son that left New York? Don’t you think  
that that's already a world of experience  

in a few days? If you think of the phil-  
osophical things, the creative things, going  
to the museums and seeing things and being  
here. You could write ten volumes on what  
I've done here just by coming.  

So when I come to the work again I'm always  
I, but I've added to the consciousness.  
Every minute you get a little older so you  
touch it a little differently. And anyway,  
don't the books promise us that the compen-  
sation for old age is wisdom? You see?  
So, you don't get old in a minute and you  
don't get wisdom in a minute.  

A WOMAN’S MIND  

Q: You've said that your works are defin-  
itely the product of a feminine mind and  

that there's a difference between a man's  
mentality and a woman's mentality and the  

way a man's works and the way a woman's  
works. How does your work reflect that diff-  
erence, that woman's mind?  

A: Well, first, let me say that there are  
women, there are artists, that will not acc-  
ept this. But I only think I'm  
a woman. I'm not a man. I have all the or-  
gans that belong to the female sex and I've  
executed them from that point of view.  

Look, a man and a woman get together. The  
very position...or two people get together.  
Say I was standing up and facing you this  

way. You'd be looking here and I'd be look-  
ing there. Already we have a different per-  
spective. And it cannot be the same perspec-  

tive because of our whole makeup.  

And if you happen to like being a female,  
and if you're attractive and you get the  
attention you want and you've had a ball on  
that level, then you want to retain that fem-  
ininity. It's only, well, people that have  
not been successful somehow being female  
that want to switch and vice-versa. But I'm  
not going into the sex problem at this mo-  
ment. I rather like all the exposure of sex  
because I think we were educated so badly.  

Now, another thing, before I finish. For in-  
stance, I'm a great-grandmother and I'm not  
going to change because I've lived with this  
so long. But why should we be self-conscious  
of certain parts of our bodies? Why can't  
we claim our bodies? But we don't, I don't.  
With all my awareness and all my promiscuity,  
there's still something I don't claim. And  

I resent it in myself. It's too late for me  
to encompass it. But I would like to see

Competition Sickness” Pervades -- - -  
Legal Education  
Will Women Humanize  
by Jane Prohaska  

Rumor has it that the following exchange  
took place at that most prestigious center  
of legal education, Harvard Law School:  

Professor: Miss Smith, will you please  
state the holding of the case assigned  
for today?  

Woman Student: I would prefer to be called  
"Ms." from now on.  

Professor: Miss Smith, I will call you  
damn broads anything I choose, if I  
choose to call on you at all.  

Whether or not this accurately represents  
the status of women at Harvard Law, I cannot  
say. If such were representative of the  
University of Minnesota where I am a first  
year law student, making the usual indict-  
ments of sex discrimination would be all too  
easy. However, the situation here is a com-  
plex one due to certain concessions already  
made by the University law school, due to  
the women law students themselves, and most  
of all, due to the structure of legal educa-  
tion and the legal profession itself.  

First of all, it is important to realize  
being a first year law student - male  
or female - is an overwhelming situation.  

My first reaction when asked if I would be  
interested in writing about women and law  
school was that I couldn't possibly find  
time. After all, my first final exams are  
only ten weeks away. The object of law  
school, as I view it, is to keep you so busy  
studying and so confused about the materials  
you are studying that you have no time at  
all to reflect on the situation thrust upon  
you. For not only was I too busy to write  
this article, but I didn't have the proper  
perspective. I am merely a confused first  
year student and don't yet understand the  
workings of the legal field. This evalua-  
tion of law school as it relates to women is  
highly prejudicial, as is any individual's  
critique of an institution with which they  
are not fully satisfied, but I do not be-  
lieve that makes it invalid.  

Not Blatant  

I have never been faced with a situation  
such as the Harvard anecdote. In fact, I  
have not run across blatant institutional  
discrimination at the law school at all. The  
admissions committee has made fairly impres-  
sive moves with women comprising 20% of my  
class, or about 50 of 250 students. This  
is remarkable only when considering that  
in the third year class of the same size  
there are less than 20 women.  

Since all of my classes consist of first  
year students, women do not seem out of  
place. They are not noticeable; they belong  
as much as any other student. Women are not  
singled out for abuse or neglect during  
class discussions, as I have been told they  
had in the past.  

It is assumed in law school that all stu-  
dents have only surnames and this uniform  
policy has led to some confusion for pro-  
fessors who wonder how to refer to women.  

Law School ?  

Most have resorted to "Miss" despite the  
fact that a large number are married. One  
professor went to great pains to explain  
to us that he really would like to call us  
"Ms." but the other was so ingrained that  
he used it unconsciously. He sincerely  
apologized if anyone was offended. As a  
sort of compromise he merely points at vol-  
unteers and says "Ma'am?" There have been  
no confrontations so the name remains uncon-  
tested.  

There are still problems. There is only  
one woman on the teaching faculty, although  
attempts are being made to secure one or two  
more for next year. The problem, as explained  
by one faculty member, is that competent  
women law professors are in such demand that  
they are hard to come by. Using competent  
women lawyers on a part-time basis has not  
been an alternative I've heard under discus-  
sion.  

In the area of placement, there is a great  
deal to be done. Interviewing firms don't  
ask men if they intend to have a family.  

Nor do they tell them that in front of a  
jury with a majority of women, their case  
won't stand a chance, especially if they are  
attractive. But the placement office is  
working with women to find out what their  
major complaints are so that these can be  
collectively expressed to interviewers to  
help further their enlightenment.  

“I Wouldn’t Want to Marry One”  
The social atmosphere in the law school is  
a somewhat different situation. Academically,  
women are well-respected by male stu-  
dents, or perhaps feared because they do  
better percentage-wise than their male  
counterparts. One male second year student  
was particularly pleased with me because  
upon exchanging law board scores - a con-  
stant pastime many law students engage in  
to reassure themselves that they are more  
intelligent than the next - he “finally dis-

covered a girl who has lower scores than I  
do." There is not disdain for the brighter  
women - merely an attitude of "I wouldn't  
want to marry one."  

There is a sort of fraternity atmosphere  
around the law school, complete with foot-  
ball pools and poker games. In fact, there  
is an actual law fraternity with "Mixers"  
with undergraduate sororities so "the guys  
in the house can get to meet some girls."  
Signs advertising such an event read "Law  
Students $1.50; Girls 50¢." In an attempt  
to remedy this inadvertent error - as it was  
explained to me - the word "male" was inser-  
ted after "Law Students."  

To be fair to the law fraternity, though,  
while it houses only men at the present time  
I was told by the president that any woman  
who wanted could move in. It strikes me as  
not in the least surprising that no one has  
yet jumped at the opportunity.  

Of course, it is not fair to let the as-  
sumption be made that all men in law school  
share the above outlook on life. The truth  
is that most law students ignore the whole  
issue and just keep on studying.  

My real dissatisfaction with law school is  
not so much based on the personal attitudes  
of my "colleagues" or the gaps in the insti-  
tutional attempts to promote equal treatment  
of men and women. In fact, my discontent has  

but with the basic attitudes, pressures, and  
practices of law school which affect all  
students and with the lack of any collective  
effort by women to counteract these tradi-  
tions of legal education.  

Humiliation & Razor Blades  

I have already commented on the amount of  
time consumed in study.  
that there is a large amount of work to  
be done, but that there is the constant feel-  
ing that no matter how much you do, you  
should be doing more. I cannot pinpoint the  
source of the pressure - much of it is from  
the teaching technique of randomly calling  
on students in class and questioning an in-  
dividual until confusion reigns supreme. The  
result is that students must constantly over  
prepare to avoid total humiliation should  
they be the victim of the day.  

A great deal of pressure comes from the  
students themselves. The fierce sense of  
competitiveness that prevails is frighten-  
ing. Books disappear, articles are razor-  
bladed from journals - not because a student  
needs such materials - but in order to keep  
other students from using them and possibly  
getting better grades. For after all, bet-  
ter grades, better jobs, and more money is  
the point of all this, is it not?  

Cooperation sometimes exists, but the  
school's honor code prohibits it, even  
while doing research. For cooperation works  
against the grain of the adversary system -  
a system based on two people taking opposite  
sides of an issue, each arguing one side of  
the issue to its logical/illogical extreme  
and then, somehow in the process, "justice  
will be achieved."  

My hope for the women's movement at large  
is that not only will it help to raise the  
level of consciousness and remove inequality  
but that it will also help remold the opera-  
tion of those institutions in which women  
are demanding equal acceptance.  

Caucus & Competition  

This is unfortunately not the case at the  
University of Minnesota law school.  

There is a caucus of Law Women which has  
developed programs to encourage women to  
attend law school, brought feminist speakers  

nothing to do with sex discrimination at all,  

It is not so  

to campus, and even purchased a subscription  
to MS magazine for the library. But so far,  
the Women's Caucus has been unable to produce a  
spirit of cooperation, even among women,  
which might begin to counterbalance the com-  
petitive emphasis faced by all of us. What  
really bothers me is that the women at the  
law school are every bit as competitive as  
the men. And no one seems to have the time  
to contemplate change.  

The reasons are not obvious, but they are  
easy to understand. In the past, women in  
law have had to work much harder than men  
to receive equal recognition, and somehow,  
once they have received that recognition, it  
is easy for them to forget the means by  
which they had achieved it. At the present,  
a number of women at law school have made  
careful and deliberate decisions to enter  
the legal profession and they are highly  
goal oriented. Doing a good job in their  
chosen field is more important than attempt-  
ing to reform the process. Similarly, a  
number of married women with children have  
a hard enough time carving out the time  
necessary to study without contemplating  
change.  

In addition, the fact that the administra-  
tion at the law school has taken the steps  
it has in some of the major issues means  
that there are no well-defined causes or  
grievances around which women might rally  
together. Without such a base, it is much  
more difficult to form a cohesive group to  
fight the more pervading atmosphere of law  
school itself.  

I do not mean any of this as a condemna-  
tion of women in law school, and I certainly  
cannot exempt myself from the syndromes I  
have explained. Many of the women I meet  
are very strong individuals who are quite  
used to running - achieving on their own,  

common practice base, even if it were to  
concern itself with changing the style of  
legal education. Many are quite content  
with the status quo, but a great number of  
men are also upset with the excessive empha-  
sis on competition.  

Women have gained much through legal chan-  
nels in establishing their rights. And  
within its own structure, women are gaining  
status in the legal world. But these accom-  
plishments and the concrete increase in the  
number of women law students should not lead  
women to think that all is over and we are  
on our way.

onymous and protected from

qual Employment Opportunity

have to be alert and un-  
derstand that they are enti-  
tled to be recognized for  
their abilities."

— Kav BES)

Lesbian Separatism--  
A Straight View  

Dear Sisters:  

I am writing in response  
to some real concern I felt  
and still feel about certain  
political views expressed at  
The Season of the Witch--  
namely--"Lesbian Separatism."  
It's not that I hadn't been  
exposed to it before or hadn't  
been in groups that dealt with  
it before, but I  

think hearing the ideas so  
strongly presented at the  
same time we were feeling  
such pride and sisterhood  
and power threw me off bal-  
ance and I still feel the  
need to share my feelings  
with my sisters.  

In order to identify my  
concern, I guess I need to  
state that I have no objec-  
tion to a separatist philoso-  
phy that removes gay women  
from association with men. I  
have no objection to a separ-  
atist philosophy that encour-  
ages gay women to occasional-  
ly withdraw from straight wo-  
men to gain strength and sup-  
port from each other. But I  
do object to a separatist  
philosophy that completely  
withdraws from straight wom-  
en as a matter of political  
principle and further casts  
straight women into the role  
of collaborator and states  
that straight women aren't  
honest in their politics.  

I guess what's moving me to  
write is fear. I see too  
many of my sisters steering  
themselves toward something I  
was raised in--namely a reac-  
tionary fundamentalism that  
refuses to allow anyone else  
their portion of truth.  

It's not that I can't under-  
stand the idea of complete  
separatism. The logical, al-  
most mathematically precise,  
extension of the feminist  
movement, given the present  
patriarchal capitalistic sys-  
tem we live in, is separatism  

(with, hopefully, some way  
to achieve spontaneous gen-  
eration.)  

But I am not yet persuaded  
that the reason for men's  
differences is solely physi-  
cal in origin and not more  
sociologically and psycho-  
logically based. If the pro-  
blems are caused by physio-  
logical differences then we  

can have no hope and I will  
end my letter here and be-  
come celibate. But if, as I  
suspect, the problems lie in  
programming and conditioning  
then the problems can be o-  
vercome by education and con-  
ditioning of a different na-  
ture. This generation of  
men and probably the next  
several generations are ir-  
revocably lost. It's the  
future generations who can  
be liberated from the kinds  
of roles men have created  
for themselves and for us.  

If you choose to separate  
yourselves from this genera-  
tion of men I see that as a  
legitimate choice and I do  
not quarrel with it.  

But I am tired of seeing  
women who are working for fu-  
ture generations cast in the  
roles of oppressors them-  
selves or at best as colla-  
borators because they don't  
fit into what is to you an  
acceptable mold.  

I am also tired of sarcas-  
tic remarks about trying to  
find "The Exceptional Man."  
Let me put it on the record  
right now--there is no such  
thing as an exceptional man.  
They are all too bound up in  
their own conditioning. At  
best, what a man can be right  
now is someone who knows what  
is--an oppressor--and doesn't  
like it. At best, what a man  
can be right now is someone  
who will admit he is confused  
and threatened by women but  
wants to keep the lines open  
for an attempt at compassion  
and hopefully love. At best,  
what a man can be right now  
is someone who will try not  
to say--"I understand," be-  
cause he knows he never can.  
This is the best a man can be  
right now; but exceptional--  
no way! So let me call off  
the search for this mythical  
beast.  

I'm not into devoting my  
energies to changing today's  
man either. That's his own  
job if it can be done. I  
guess my hope is for our sons  
and daughters to live as per-  
sons, not role players.  

Why do I live with a man  
then? The purpose of this  
letter is not to give apolo-  
gies for my own lifestyle so  
an explanation as such will  
not be given beyond this:  
the relationship we have is  
based on our common humanity.  
I refuse to devote my ener-  
gies to fighting roles in  

this relationship and that  
is well understood. And, as  
you are probably discovering,  
once roles are removed the  
possibility for a relation-  
ship based on human values  
can be realized. Further, I  
refuse to deny my own sexual  
preferences just as I support  
my gay sisters in their re-  
fusal to deny theirs.  

You may ask why I even con-  
cern myself with this ques-  
tion then. Why don't I just  
ignore the whole issue? I  
guess the love I felt for all  
my sisters in that room dur-  
ing The Season of the Witch  
is part of the reason I re-  
fuse to ignore it. I refuse  
to remove myself from any of  
my sisters who are struggling  
against oppression. If a se-  
paration occurs, it will be  
my gay sisters who will ini-  
tiate it. And the more I  
read, the more conferences I  
attend, the more workshops  
etc. I sit through, the more  
I realize that such a split  

is becoming inevitable.  

It may be understandable  
but I have always felt, I  
felt that night, and I will  
always feel that we are wom-  
en--sisters truly--and all in  
this struggle together. We  
need each other. Any denial  
of our commonality hurts us  
all and drains power from the  
whole of the body of woman.  
That lost power doesn't drain  
off to any of the segments  
either. It drains from us  
directly to our oppressors.  

I guess the most painful  
outcome of this split will be  
the loss of too many real  
friends. That kind of loss  
leaves holes and I don't want  
that to happen.  

But if it does happen; if  
you must go to the Lesbian  
nation; if you must remove  
your support from me and re-  
fuse to take my support, then  
at least drop me a postcard  
now and then. Because I need  
you and I love you.  

Rachel

Clinic Regroups

Now that it's midwinter we
have found that our way to
achieve our goals needed some
changing. Within the last
few weeks, through hours of
discussion, we have come to
some new conclusions. We
would like to establish a wo-
men's health center for edu-
cation, self-help, counseling
and discovery. This is a
change from what we have
struggled to become for the
last 9 months.

Our goals, as a refresher, 

are still the same. They are
grand and glorious, and yet
we have hope that we can
start to tackle them. We
wish to change the way health
care is delivered by consumer
control, alleviating the hier-
archical structure of health
care workers, undermining the
drug companies' power, giving
women knowledge and control
of their bodies! (How about
that!)

In the past we felt that if
we opened a clinic we could
be an example of how these
changes could affect delivery
of health care. But after
many long hours of discussion
we felt that to do x-amount
of Pap and x-amount of VD
cultures we would end up
draining all our energies
just on service. There are
a lot of facilities that peo-
ple can use, granted none are
giving "good" service. But
by using our energies to put
the education of women and
health care workers on top of
our list we feel we might
accomplish more (to change
existing service for all wo-
men).

So the Center now has a pro-
gram which started with our
education. We have broken
ourselves up into five major
work groups. Each group
takes its own responsibility
for one facet of the center.
They are as listed:

Funding--a never-ending pro-
blem. The group is busy
learning new language and
writing an “in-house" purpo-
sal. We also have a video
tape to use at the funding
boards. Any ideas for places
to go are welcome.

Classes--We would like to
offer classes, probably 5
sessions at the Health Center
on women's health.

We start our first health
class February 6 at 7:30.
There will be a fee, as yet
unknown. This is an intro-
duction and a general class
on health and women. From
this class we hope people
will go into collective study
groups on individual smaller
topics. We feel this class
will give a broad base for
women to continue to learn
from. The class topics are
as follows:

1) feminism and politics

2) anatomy and self-help

3) hormone system and men-
opause

4) birth control and abor-
tion

5) VD and vaginal infec-
tions

6) sexuality

7) birth and children

8) health care issues

9) preventive medicine and
Eastern medicine

We want to limit the class
to 15 women and hope that
people will attend all nine.
If the registration is high
we will start a second class
on Tuesday at 7:30. All classes
at 2000 South 5th St, the
People’s Center.

Introduction and Speaking
Gigs. We hope to do a lot of
speaking gigs and do some
teaching on self-help. Any
group can call and ask for
this.

Each Wednesday night there
is an open-ended introduction
session about the Center, fem-
inism, and an opportunity to
learn self-help. The direc-
tion of these discussions
will be determined by the
needs and feelings of the in-
dividual women present.
Please come and see what we
have to offer.

Counseling--There will be
counselors trained for coun-
seling or for referral. Op-
portunities for referral are:

1) health classes

2) an open-ended support
group

3) women's rap groups

4) counselors with a fem-
inist perspective will
be available for long-
term counseling.

Evaluation--As a feminist
group we feel the need to
also evaluate what we do, and
how we accomplish our objec-
tives. The group is develop-
ing a framework within which
we can evaluate ourselves.

We believe it is necessary
to have a structure which
still allows us to be human
and free. We hope this is
informative and lets you know
where we are at. If you want
any further information please
contact us. Someone
is at the Center all day M-F.
335-7669.
In sisterhood,
EBWHC

We are anxious to involve
more women in our center.

Women Poets:

Seeking Community,  
Exploring New Sensibility  

Collecting information on the Women Poets  
of the Twin Cities, I felt like the prover-  
bial blind men trying to understand an ele-  
phant by touch. It is a writer's workshop,  
I exclaimed, grabbing at one end. It's a  
feminist consciousness raising group, I  
thought, checking out another part. It  
exists to sponsor readings. No, its pur-  
pose is to establish critical standards.  
Each time I explored another aspect of the  
Women Poets of the Twin Cities, it seemed a  
different organization--and the whole makes  
up quite as unlikely an animal as that pro-  
verbial elephant.  

Undefinable and All-Embracing  

The Women Poets themselves are as undefi-  
nable as their organization. Looking at  
Phebe Hanson, one sees a Woman Poet to be a  
fortyish professional woman and mother who  
began writing recently after a long silence.  
But then, a Woman Poet seems to be academi-  
cally trained, published in literary maga-  
zines and involved in Minnesota publishing  
ventures, like Jenne Andrews. Or a faculty  
wife and mother long active in local liter-  
ary activities (like Beryle Williams), or  
a dedicated and experienced public reader  
(like Mary Ellen Shaw) or a college drop-  
out and former resistance worker (like Mary  
Pat Flandrick). Or some 30 other possibili-  
ties, one for each member of this amorphous  
organization.  

The Women Poets themselves are perhaps  
best described by the continuums upon which  
they fall: from teen-aged to middle-aged,  
from counterculture to middle-class, from  
gay to straight, from politically radical to  
moderate, from just embarking on a literary  
career to semi-established. Their rather an-  
archic organization slides across other con-  
tinuums, from private to public, from per-  
sonal to political, from poetic to polemical.  

The generic name is a symbol of the in-  
clusiveness and diversity of the group: to  
be a Woman Poet of the Twin Cities is to be  
just that. Patricia Hampl, who's too busy to  
attend meetings, still feels part of the  
group, saying, "I'm a woman writing poetry  
in St. Paul. By definition I'm a Woman Poet  
of the Twin Cities." There are active members  
and inactive members, and members who haven't  
yet joined.  

by Pat Monaghan  

Invisible Women Poets  

Doubtless, two years ago there were women  
poets in the Twin Cities. There were numer-  
ous poetry readings and a burgeoning sense  
of literary community. But women were rare  
on the platform and in local publications.  
They were excluded from speaking at poetry  
seminars and other educational events, or  
represented by a token few. There were  
women poets here, but no one knew how many,  
or who they were.  

Then at a reading featuring men poets,  
Penny Seuss abruptly turned to Beryle Willi  
ams and demanded, "If I have a reading, will  
you read?" Four women organized the first  
reading, held in November, 1971, that drew  
what Williams calls "a devoted audience."  

"We organized because we weren't hearing  
any women's poetry, and weren't getting ac-  
quainted in private ways,” Williams explain-  
ed. "It grew out of our need. We needed to  
write and share and have it heard."  

An open reading at the end of the program  
brought more women poets into evidence. A  
meeting soon after brought out even more,  
and the Women Poets of the Twin Cities (WP-  
TC) was launched.  

Some of the women are harsh on the poetic  
establishment that drove them to organize a  
separate group. "Men were turning poetry  
readings into wakes,” grimaces Flandrick.  
"Now, wakes can be very moving. But I want  
to go to poetry readings and find poets who  
excite me."  

Shaw, who organized the first meeting of  
the WPTC, deplores "the club of poets who  
were reading private jokes and disserta-  
tions." She remembers the "exciting vision"  
that led to the organization of the Women  
Poets. "We felt we could be a great new  
force in literature, writing not against but  
for each other. We felt that we could build  
a community of artists. We wanted to write  
closer to the life of people and to our own  
life, to speak to an audience that had been  
turned off by poetry. We felt that we could  
change the ideas of women and their lives."

Since its formation, WPTC has held more-or
less weekly meetings, at which any of a va-
riety of activities can take place. Some-
times the evening is devoted to considering
the work of a major woman poet, sometimes

to a visit with poets of the reputation of
Diane Di Prima or Eve Merriam. There are
intensive individual critiques of the work
of individual members. There are open read-
ings, each poet presenting her latest work.
And sometimes WPTC holds business meetings
to plan an upcoming public reading and other
projects.

WPTC -- Public and Private

Shaw calls the group "organized anarchy,"
while Hanson suggests the milder term "re-
latively unstructured organization." Leader-
ship is fluid. "The leadership is passed
from one to another for brief periods. Any-
one who happens to have a project in mind is
leader for the moment," Hansen explains.

For a group which has no formal structure
--"We'll never be a 'proper' organization,"
laughs Hanson--WPTC has sponsored a remark-
able number of activities: six large-scale
public readings, 15 smaller readings at
such places as the St. Paul Open School and
Stillwater State Prison, a dozen mixed
readings in which women poets participated,
and six chapbooks featuring women poets. An
anthology is in progress.

Public activities reveal only one side
of the group's purpose, for WPTC functions
as much as a support group and critical
workshop as it does as a voice for women's
literary rights. This duality of function is
reflected in the different attitudes WPTC
members have about the organization, and
about their work. "Some of us are primarily
concerned with writing; our primary aim is
to be as professional as possible," says
Shaw. “For others, the writing is tangential
to political aspirations of liberating wo-
men." “Everyone comes to the group with dif-
ferent needs and expectations," Flandrick
explains.

Despite this, WPTC attempts to support
each woman's struggle to define an artistic
identity. For some, such support is a heady
experience. "I still feel like I'm giving
religious testimony when I talk about the
group," says Hanson. "Starting to think
about myself as a serious poet was an ec-
static experience. At first I was so fragile
and it was so scary. The Women Poets have
made me feel that what I have to say is im-
portant, that my experiences, however li-
mited, are valuable. It took me 25 years to
find that out." Women, Hanson claims, are
conditioned "to put ourselves and our own
experiences down. I remember, not long ago,
half-apologizing to a man for liking Joan
Didion."

Public and private activities merge, Wil-
liams feels, in the growing public aware-
ness of WPTC and of its members. "You never
heard of us as individuals. We have each
gained more public notice than we would have
without this group."

In addition to offering encouragement,
the group attempts to provide critical
analysis for the emerging poets. A problem
arises, however, in determining what stand-
ards to apply. Some women poets feel their
work has been judged by male standards, that
their unique vision has not been valued.

POETRY

"You can open your pants in public view,
but don't open the kitchen door,” snorts
Williams.

While Hanson denounces male critics for
being "not tuned in to female sensibility,"
she admits another problem, that "women
don't generally have the ego-strength of men
and are more vulnerable to criticism"--for
which reason the group restricts its mem-
bership to women. Shaw elaborates: "We
felt that with only women, we'd work on a
sharing human basis; just because we're wo-
men. Well, it works and it doesn't work.
Right now it's the closest thing to an artis-
tic community there is here."

Flandrick describes it another way. "Most
women I know are just working on becoming
self-centered--that's different, you know,
from being selfish. I used to buy the myth-
ology of artist-as-neurotic, of having to
transcend the ego. Well, women for the most
part don't have an ego to transcend. If
poetry is going to be saved, it's going to
be the women that save it."

Although the Women Poets profess to reject
male poetic sensibility, they have not yet
defined an alternative. "We've never evolved
a standard," Shaw says. "But I notice that
even when women write angry poems, there is
an element of tenderness, of sorrow," Wil-
liams sees women as "less myopic, more out
of the ego bubble, than men.

"What we do know," she sums up, "now that
we're hearing enough of women's poetry, is
that it is a different body than men's
poetry, and that some of it is vital, and
some is not."

It is 16 mm, contains women from many different classes, races, and age groups speaking about their lives and what they are doing to change them. You can do something constructive for your group and help another struggling feminist venture as well, by calling at 644-4404 or at 698-6837 for rental information.

Friday, January 25, offers the feature, "Black Women," a NET production in which Nikki Giovanni, Roberta Flack, and Lena Horne talk about the black woman's relationship to black men, white society, and the feminist movement. Working Women Band Together

by Heidi Reidell

Women in Minneapolis are

working for bread, not jew-
els. As in all other parts
of the country, the bread
seems more like crumbs—
fully employed women earn $3
for every $5 earned by their
male counterparts. The dis-
crepancy in pay has widened
during the past 15 years, but
the mechanics for change in
Minneapolis are growing
stronger.

The stereotype of the work-
ing girl who leaves her job
to marry and have children
doesn't hold up today. Three
fifths of the working women
in Minneapolis are married
and living with their hus-
bands and one-third are moth-
ers with children under the
age of six.

Most women work to raise
their families' standard. In families where the
husband earns between five
and seven thousand dollars
per year, 46% of the wives
work. In Minneapolis, 15% of
working mothers are heads of
households and only 5% of
these women receive welfare
funds. One fifth of working
women are single and self-
supporting and few women have
the luxury of working solely
for personal fulfillment.

Women have always worked to
support themselves and their
families. But since the in-
dustrial revolution women
have left the home and enter-
ed a labor system based on
the obsolete assumption that
they are marking time until
they can retire to the kit-
chen.

Women's role in the labor
force has changed radically
in the last 50 years. The
average woman worker in the
1920s was 28 years old and
single. She comprised 20% of
the labor force and had a life
expectancy of 55 years.

Today, the average working
woman is 39, married and was
30 years old when she sent her
last child off to school. She
can expect to live to be
75 years old.

Working women today are
highly educated. One woman
in ten has a college degree.
However, of the 91,000 work-
ing women in Minneapolis, 42%
have clerical jobs (5% higher
than the national average)
and only 3% are in managerial
positions (0.3% higher than
the national average). In
executive positions, men out-
number women 600 to 1.

From counterculture women's
organizations to a drop-in
center at the YWCA, women are
helping each other find jobs,
training and adequate day-
care facilities.

Aside from social and pol-
itical women's groups, self-
help professional groups are
forming. One such group,
Women in Communication, has
a job placement service
where women exchange inform-
ation about job openings that
are not usually announced pub-
licly.

Some local groups are aff-
iliated with national organ-
izations. Efforts are un-
derway to start a service
modeled after Catalyst, an
organization that places wom-
en in jobs and also pairs wo-
men with similar training so
they can share one job and
work part-time.

Within individual companies
women are becoming more vo-
cal about equal pay, job ad-
vancement and adequate day-
care for their children.

Careers are no longer a
secondary concern of women.

Many are choosing to postpone
having children at all. Those with
small children are working
in increasing numbers. Thir-
ty-five percent of mothers
with children under six are
working.

There are gross inequities
in pay scales, hiring and
promotion policies in Minn-
eapolis and the nation. But
the tools of change are be-
ing wielded by many deter-
mined and dedicated people
in this city.

The traditional female occ-
upations are filled to over-
flowing. Career planners see
expanding job opportunities
in the professions (medicine,
science, engineering, law,
architecture) and in voca-
tional careers (electronics,
mechanics, etc.).

But changing a nation's
labor structure takes time
and effort. The southern
congressman who tacked the
word sex on the 1964 Civil
Rights law in order to quash
the effort, inadvertently
gave women one of their most
powerful tools of advance-
ment. From this legislation
came the momentum for poten-
tially powerful legal action
against sex discrimination
and for legally required
affirmative action programs.
The mechanics to equalize
pay and promotion policies
are there.

Those involved in chang-
ing women's role in the em-
ployment world point to one
vital force of change—the
women themselves. And women
in Minneapolis are banding
together to better their
employment situation.

Harriet Lansing and Judy
Oakes, two attorneys, have
opened Minnesota's first
all-women law firm in St.
Paul.

Located at 400 Sibley St.,
Oakes & Lansing is one of
some half-dozen women's firms
in the nation.

Although they will not be
restricting their practice
to women, the lawyers feel
that their feminist philo-
sophy will affect their en-
tire practice. Assisting
them is a law clerk, a stu-
dent at William Mitchell Law
School.

Both Lansing and Oakes are
graduates of the University
of Minnesota Law School.
Oakes previously was an as-
sistant attorney general for
the state of Minnesota (the
first woman to be promoted
to that post) while Lansing
was a city attorney in St.
Paul (the first woman to
be appointed to that position).

Study

Dear Sisters:

I am a graduate student in

the School of Social Work at

California State University,
Sacramento. I am presently
working on my master's thesis.

Lesbian mothers are now en-
gaged in court cases to gain

or regain custody of their
children and are in dire need
of support from many levels.
My hope for this thesis is
that it can be used to streng-
then the arguments and dispel
the negative stereotypes of
Lesbian motherhood, as well
as to increase society's a-
wareness and acceptance of
Lesbians and Lesbian child-
raising.

I have developed a question-
naire in conjunction with Del
Martin and Phyllis Lyon and
other members of the Lesbian
community, which is now ready
for distribution. My popula-
tion of subjects can include
any woman who considers her-
self to be a Lesbian who is
raising or has raised a child
whether or not they are now
living together.

To reach as many women as
possible, I need your help.
Can you announce the exis-
tence of this research to as
many women as possible? Wo-
men who are willing to com-
plete a questionnaire can
drop me a card letting me
know they will participate.

All replies will be held
strictly confidential and re-
sponses will be anonymous and
in no way connected to the
names or addresses of respon-
dents.

Obtaining a large number of

Lesbian mothers for my sample
is crucial to the effective-
ness of my thesis; any publi-
city you can give to this ef-
fort will be critical to its

success and greatly apprecia-
ted.

Thank you very much.

On April 2 a new task force of the Elizabeth  
Blackwell Women's Health Center, which is a

cated in the People's Center, was formed.  
This newly-organized task force is a patient  
advocacy and referral group.

A patient advocate for women is defined as a

a health care facility in order to give her  
support. The group sees itself as mainly  
existing for being advocates for general ex-  
aminations and operations that are minor,

aspirator-type abortions, at the moment.

gains more experience.

Besides patient advocacy, the group is going  
to compile a complete list of referrals for  

the Women's Health Center, listing area doc-  
tors. By doing this, the group hopes to  

by COCO WEBER

supply women with more and better options  
and overall health care. At the moment, the  
are getting together an attitudinal form to  
distribute to the consumers or the patients  
on the quality of treatment they have re-  
ceived.

book in which is listed every doctor in the

TO KATE.

"Device Piece for Walker-to Kate" has so  
many elements within it to talk about that I  
have opted for a brief description: as a  
means of encouraging all women out there to  
see the piece or at least be on the alert for  
other works by Carole Fischer, and then I shall  
devote myself to totally subjective feelings  
on the subject.

———

Materials used are brick, glass, red elastic  
and Kotex. As shown in the photo, the materials  
are either balanced or stretched over one an-  
other. Not evident in the photo is the soft  
breeze which plays over the lines of stretched  
elastic.

Now to the subjective area. Obvious vis-  
ual contrasts have been pointed out in other  
reviews; shiny glass against dull bricks, trans-  
parent alongside opaque, hard brick versus soft  
Kotex, etc. Simplistic observations which do  
little justice to the artist's efforts.

Similes and metaphors abound to further  
"explain" what is happening vis-à-vis the  
Walker's Invitation Catalogue: "...sheets of  
glass propped against a wall, with taut bands  
of elastic pinned beside them and stretched  
across the floor, allude to gossamer curtains  
on a drying frame."

Thus we are told that a work which is capable  
of evoking diverse memories and feelings; a  
work which understands the dynamic use of space  
and concrete “earthly” objects to draw us into  
the realm of abstraction essentially comes down  
to gossamer curtains. The woman's experience in  
art?

Carole Fisher with components far Device Piece Series

a review by Margaret Hastings

The catalogue continues. "For the first  
time socio-political statement is also intro-  
duced in her use of sanitary napkins as an in-  
tegral part of her construction." In a woman's  
life, Kotex, Tampax, et al. are hardly socio-  
political; they are necessities. It is the  
world's unhealthy reaction to them which brings  
into play the political element. It is also  
easier to dismiss such a reminder of women's  
bodily functions with political clichés than  
express honest reactions. If red elastic  
stretched full length conjures images of cur-  
tains, then certainly the Kotex reminds us of  
menstruation.

Trying to tell you what "...-to Kate" is all  
about, what it reminds me of or its political  
intentions would be a bit pretentious. Its  
very strength lies in its unlimited implica-  
tions, ideas and visual imagery. Is the red  
elastic blood? Possibly. Does the glass sig-  
nify fragile prettiness or a sinister quality  
with its sharp cutting edges? Choose one, both  
or neither.

Carole Fisher has taken separate units  
and formed connections of movement, reflection,  
repetition, contradictions—all that stuff one  
learns in art schools. Through such connections  
common, identifiable objects merge into one  
another to express a world outside of their  
limited forms. Louise Nevelson does this in her  
works; good poets use words to the same end.

Gossamer curtains are only a small part of it.

THEY SAY THAT’S  
WHY WE'RE “i ERE by CHARLOTTE MASTERMAN  

We're sitting in a circle, the eight of us,  
so we can all see and hear each other. The  
brochure about consciousness raising groups  
told us people feel more like talking in a cir-  
cle; it's more intimate. But tonight, like  
always, anxious thrills shoot up my arms, and I  
don't feel any more like spilling what's inside  
me than I did last week or the week before.  
Shiela sits across from me, her eyes blankly  
staring through me. I don't think she'll say a  
thing tonight, either.  

Janet looks like she'll catapult right out of  
her chair if she doesn't talk. So she tells us  
what's hurting her. Her old man left her for  
another woman, she tells us. It blew her mind,  
and she got involved with a man. Now her kids  
despise her. But they still adore the old man.  
She thinks it's unfair. What hurts her most is  
when they call her slut and whore. The others  
try to comfort her with realities that exist  
for them, but not for Janet's kids.  

Maddening jitters begin to creep inside my  
skin when everything goes quiet. I think maybe  
I've had too much coffee today, but I know it's  
not the coffee. Janet's hurt starts mine up,  
and I want to talk and I don't. What's  
broiling under the surface scares the hell out  
of me. But Jennifer saves me having to decide  
if now's the time.  

I watch her as she speaks, and I wonder if  
she wouldn't be kind of pretty without her  
mouth all pinched together like it has a draw-  
string pulled through it. Her feelings spurt  
out like pop-gun fire. Her family's angry with  
her. Says she should snap out of whatever ails  
her, they're tired of her whining after app-  
reciation. Says they'd appreciate her more if  
she didn't constantly remind them. But I won-  
der about that. I wonder if they don't want  
her to shut up so they won't feel guilty. I  
wonder who's screwed up, her or them?  

Gracie pipes up in her wire thin voice, "He  
says I need help." She's always saying that,  
but she keeps the rest a secret. My jitters  
are going crazy now. My hair feels like it's  
crawling and I smooth it down hard with my  
palm. I look at Shiela staring at nothing, and  
I wonder where she is.  

I wonder, too, when we're going to get be-  
yond gut-spilling and start helping each other  
somehow. Maybe that's it. Maybe we don't know  
how. Or maybe all the poison has to come out  
first.  

Mellanie's voice booms out with its usual  
energy. She's different from the rest of us,  
not what you'd consider feminine. She's very  
tall and moves like a willow whip, graceful  
and all--but she's got a vibrance that makes  
her look aggressive even when she's sitting  
still. I don't think anyone will ever beat  
her down for long. Seems like she'd just boomerang no matter what.  

She's always been open, right from our first  
meeting. Listening, I wonder with a secret  
smile what tonight's revelation will bring.  

She tops off last week's episode by telling us  
about several suicide attempts. You may think,  
Aha! So they did get to her. But I'm not so  
sure. I wonder if that was Mellanie's way of  
saying, Okay, if there's no place for me and my  
way, screw all of you! She sighs and wears a  
wry smile, "Damned near made it last time, but  
my goddamned neighbor found me. I could have  
killed her."  

I envision Mellanie stretched out white and  
dead, her brown eyes lusterless, glaring, and  
something knifes at my insides. I wonder if I  
should tear back the thin tissue that covers  
the burning thing in my gut. I open my mouth,  
but the words won't come. Nobody notices be-  
cause Doris lets loose with a story of how she  
went berserk one day. She even gets me laugh-  
ing. I can picture sweet, docile Doris, who's  
too timid to ask for the salt at supper, hurt-  
ling everything in sight at this guy she's liv-  
ing with, a huge man with lead fists, and him  
peering stupidly at her. "He slapped me around  
afterward, but it was worth it," she relished,  
throwing her head back, cackling and slapping  
her knees, "oh, man was it worth it!" Her  
eyes widen and she leans forward, like the  
most important part is coming. “He was scared—  
scared—I could see it in his eyes, you know?  
And that . . . " she chuckles in between her  
words, ". . . that makes me .. . double over  
and . . . laugh, which makes him," she can hard-  
ly talk now she's laughing so hard, “even...  
even madder. He told me... told me I was...'  
nuts. Oh, my stomach . . . someone make me ...,  
stop:" . By now everyone is giggling loud and  
hard. Doris is holding her stomach, doubled up  
in her chair. When the laughing eases into  
softer, sighing spurts, Gracie chimes in with,  
"He says I need help." And everyone is sudd-  
enly quiet, like when you snap off a radio, and  
no one laughs at what Gracie says because she  

looks so forlorn.  

Silence creeps in through my pores and pushes  
out 'til I think my skin will burst into a  

million fragments. A warning roars through my  
brain, but I ignore it because it's too late—  
I hear a stranger's hollow voice and I realize  
it's mine ". . . in a commune .. . with lots  
of 'liberated' people—the men were at liberty  
to make all the rules and fight the important  
battles of society with their rhetoric while  
the women were at liberty to do all the shit  
work. Oh, it was equally divided between us."  
Everyone laughs. "At first we were like pio-  
neers, you know, making a new utopian society  
and all that, and we didn't complain 'cause our  
mission was so important. But after awhile,  
there were things that stuck out so you couldn't  
ignore them." My taut skin has little  
spasms, then relaxes a little, while I get my  
bearings. "We were privileged to gaze up into  

continued on page 11

continued from page 10

their bearded faces while they made all the  
important decisions, and we went along like  
sheep—and not one of them worked to speak of,  
only short part-time jobs, and every one of the  
women had work except for two who were pregnant  
and one girl who was sick a lot. Course, they  
were conducting the revolution," I say, and we  
all laugh at the picture of a bunch of guys  
sitting around jawing a revolution. "But the  
women ended up fighting among themselves, like  
we couldn't stick together because we seemed to  
be pitted against each other. Cuz it's always  
been that way? I don't know. I suppose we  
were scared because we thought we were depen-  
dent on them." I pause a minute so I can get  
something straight in my head, so they'll un-  
derstand. "That really got me, how we fought  
with each other and how really the men were de-  
pendent on us and we never saw that. But that  
wasn't the worst."

They're waiting now. Prickles run across my  
scalp. I fight to loosen my throat so I can  
talk. "Well... I got pregnant. And the  

guy I was living with... in the commune, you  
know, there were all couples... he has a fit,  
yells at me asking how I could let that hap-  
pen, and I say I didn't use artificial insem-  
ination, but he doesn't think that's funny,  
just stands there screaming at me. I say I  
want us to get out and live alone. He won't  
hear of it and when I push him about this he  
lets it out that he doesn't want to live with  
me any more, not anywhere. I ask him shouldn't  
he be responsible for his own child? Then he  
lays it on me..." I see his flushed,  
twisted face, ugly now, not beautiful like it  
was when I first knew him, and the burning in  
my stomach shoots up between my ribs. "He tells  
me it isn't his kid, and I don't know what to  
say I'm so shocked, I can't believe my ears. I  
ask him how he can even think that, and he says  
with all the men in the place how does he know,  
and I say with all the women in the place does  
that mean he's been playing around? And he  
won't answer, just sits there, starts his pout-  
ing."

I can't control my shivers now, nor my voice’  
erratic up and down swings, "I find out later  
he did get it on with several of the women—  
after all the love and honesty shit he spouted!  
I stuck with him cuz I didn't know what else to  
do. I figured he'd have to want his kid once  
he was over the shock. But finding out about  
him and the others, that was too much. I con-  
front him with it and you won't believe what  
he says—he says ‘It's a free world, isn't it?'  
And that's the excuse he used to get out of  
claiming our baby, said he was free to accept  
or reject it, and besides, he still wasn't  
sure it was his. He says all these things and  
I can't believe anything's real, that I'm hear-  
ing all this, and I feel like I'm going nuts,  
everything I put my faith in believed in  
- + » all disappearing like the world is a mir-  
age and nothing solid... "My heart is  
drumming wildly in my ears. I'm sure they're  
going to pop. I don't see anyone in front of  
me, everything blurred, wavering, like in one  
of those horror house mirrors. I feel cold  
drops slip down the valley of my breasts. My  
ears ring and I hear someone screaming, "You  
lousy sonofabitch how can you reject your own  
baby? You! You say you cherish life and here  
you are trying to save a sick society and you  
can forget you made a life and what about  
that life?"

Everyone is gaping at me and I clam up and  
breathe hard to stop the beating in my ears.  
That crazy Gracie says, "He says I need help,"  
and I think I'm going to scream. But I wait  

holding my breath cuz they're sitting there  
gawking at me, not unkindly, just the way  
people do when they're embarrassed.

I try to calm my voice but it tilts up, "Well  
when I have my baby they say I have to  
give it up."

Someone gasps, "Why?"

"Because I killed him." There, it's out now,  
the poison, and I can say it with a steel edge  
because now I'm empty inside and don't feel  
anything. "I stuck a knife in his gut. I did-  
n't think about it, just did it. And I'm not  
sure I wouldn't do it again, except I want my  
baby." I try to tell them after I get out of  
here I'll go to prison, but the words won't  
come. Instead I see him again—astonished,  
grasping spurting blood, rasping, "Bitch!  
Bitch!" These were his last words.

The lights blink, warning us it's time to  
break. We avoid each other's eyes. Doris takes  
Gracie's arm, leading her like you would a  
small child and they head for the hallway that  
leads to gray dormitories and iron cots.

I stay, because Sheila's trembling.  
I put my arms around her.  
She lays her head on my chest, whimpering.

I say, “I know, I know.  
It'll be all right." But I know it won't be  
all right. They've told her she'll never get  
out of here if she doesn't adjust. She's terr-  
ified of that, and I know she won't sleep and  
I'll sit up with her tonight.

Gracie's short soliloquy carried through the  
hallway—"He says I need help." Doris soothes  
her, "Sure, Gracie, I know. They say that's  
why we're here."
